column7: All of us have woken up on the weekend and wished that our favorite brunch spot could magically appear at our door. Well, now it can, thanks to this weekend delivery service that's taken over the kitchen of the Ukrainian Village's Darkroom nightclub. Choose from tasty quiches (the Lorraine is a good bet but the weekly special proves more interesting), ham-and-cheese-filled flaky croissants, French toast filled with various stuffings (cream cheese is our favorite), simple yogurt with granola and fresh-brewed Intelligentsia coffee. Add a copy of The New York Times and a dozen red roses and your breakfast-in-bed dreams come true.

Closed after fire.Authenticity is the M.O. of this Kedzie gem, and to that end the light, crispy falafel is made with fava beans (rather than chickpeas); the maqloba (an Egyptian dish resembling pureed spinach) is studded with bits of lamb and brought to life by a squeeze of lemon; and the kebabs are simple, tender and only made with Zabiha Halal meat. The Pakistani/Indian portion of the menu doesn't disappoint, either: The onion paratha is made to order and is just as flaky and flavorful as anything you'd get on Devon.

This restaurant is now closed.When more than half of the folks running an Italian restaurant are Mexican, it's no surprise when they open up their own place next door. That's what happened at Bella Notte, whose adjacent private party space was recently turned into this tropical retreat, complete with murals designed to transport you to the Mexican seaside. The menu aims to do the same, with a focus on seafood and steaks lightened up with fruity salsas and tropical tubers, and a bar list of citrus-kissed cocktails.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago; Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 65

column7: Next door to sibling Sushi Wabi, this modern Indian spot does a nice job updating the fiery cuisine with snazzy street snacks (try the fried banana peppers stuffed with lentils and paneer) and cocktails (the gingery, cumin-laced margarita and the cardamom-packed "Bengali Tiger" are delicious). Heat-seekers should request extra fire with classics like chicken tikka masala and lamb rogan josh, while those looking for something new will find it with the juicy tamarind-date glazed chicken or garlicky shrimp salad.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Modern-day Turkey isn't the idea here, so if you're looking for contemporary Istanbul, get a plane ticket. This dining room hearkens to times of eating on luxurious floor cushions and sucking on hookahs like they're Tic Tacs. You can make a meal out of the hot appetizer platter—thin zucchini pancakes, tangy rolls of feta-stuffed phyllo and the Turkish pizza, a housemade pita piled with perfectly seasoned ground lamb. Or fill up on the A La Turka special: sautéed beef and grilled vegetables served with a slightly sweet eggplant puree. Either way the portions are sized for big appetites, so you won't leave hungry.
column8: Good for groupsVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)

column7: This tiny Ukrainian Village dining room is tight on tables and menu items—there are about a dozen of each—but what it lacks in size is made up for with charm. The simple Italian fare has absolutely no bells or whistles, but, luckily, most dishes don't need any. A duo of meaty mushrooms—perfectly roasted portobello and sautéed oyster—is dressed only with balsamic and thyme. For more intricate dishes, look to seasonal specialties like juniper and clove–braised pork shanks over Tuscan white beans, or grilled marinated leg of lamb with roasted parsnip puree and toasted garlic spinach.
column8: Notable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 80, x80

column7: Like a Zen koan shocking the mind into enlightenment, this Korean vegan restaurant (formerly located on Southport) is an awakening—for vegans, vegetarians and carnivores alike—to how delicious a meatless, eggless, dairy-free meal can be. Supposedly employing "Zen meditation cooking energy," chefs whip up everything from vegan dumplings, organic veggies and noodle soups to spicy curry and tofu dishes. Several flavors of vegan ice cream like cappuccino, green tea and plum are available in warmer months.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendly

column7: With a kitchen full of Moroccan women churning out countless specialties from their homeland, it's easy to forgive a few pitfalls. But order the right dishes and you won't have to. The briwates (Morocco's answer to the egg roll) are fine, but the Andalous combo, a slew of appetizers that includes silky spinach packed with cumin and lemon, is sublime. The "famous couscous" left us lukewarm and wondering just how it earned its moniker, but the chicken in the meknes tagine falls from the bone, crusted in impossibly crispy skin. And just when your plate has been cleaned and it's time to leave, a steaming cup of Moroccan tea steps in, giving you a good excuse to linger.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77

column7: You know those Italian places you see in the movies? Those charming neighborhood joints where the walls are lined with empty bottles of wine (most of them baring messages of thanks from customers past) and the room has a constant candlelit glow? The kind where the menu isn't a revelation, but the big portions of food are hearty and delicious? Where herbaceous spinach lasagna and savory eggplant parmigiana pull in regulars who've been coming "for years"? Yeah, this place is exactly like that.

It has nearly double the space of its former Wrigleyville location, but this Italian stalwart has retained all of its charm: The exposed brick, rustic, frescoed walls and flickering candlelight could warm even the residents of the cemetery across the street. The menu features traditional pasta and meat dishes that, while not earth-shattering, are satisfying. All your marsalas, piccatas and parmigianas are represented, but don't miss the delicate, lemony grilled calamari starter or the rigatoni al pomodoro secco, with its fat mushrooms and just-heavy-enough Gorgonzola sauce. Skip tiramisu and go for the bomba al cioccolato, a ridiculously moist cake exploding with rich, bittersweet chocolate.

More than 60 years old and still plugging away, this Chatham tablecloth spot serves dependable comfort food for the nattily dressed Sunday-church crowd. Matronly servers are as sweet as the peach cobbler (canned fruit, but great crust). Start with the seafood platter, a crispy combo of fried scallops, shrimp and oysters, battered with a perfectly seasoned cornmeal-flour mix. The "Southern specialties" side of the menu is the way to go, but be prepared for a gravy train. The light-brown pan gravy is poured over tender short ribs and pan-fried pork chops, but the flavorful fried chicken should be ordered without. For sides, go with black-eyed peas, cheesy mac and corn-bread stuffing, and don't even think about leaving without a slice of sweet-potato pie.
column8: Private party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendly

column7: It's the sauce. Don't get us wrong; we love the fresh toppings, including meaty chunks of mild sausage and fresh vegetables that are crisp and crunchy when you bite into them. But it's really the sauce—full of fresh tomato flavor, speckled with oregano, basil and the faintest hint of red pepper—that's made this recently expanded pizzeria a Chicago institution. In terms of crust, both the deep-dish and the (not very thin) thin-crust lack the flakiness of other local pies, but they resist sogginess after a night in the fridge, making them the breakfast of champions.
column144: El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77

column7: When chef Arun Sampanthavivat opened this stately legend 21 years ago, he began cultivating what would become the first Thai restaurant in America to nab four Mobil stars, a AAA award and a James Beard for Best Chef in the Midwest. These days, brilliant Thai food is prevalent in Chicago, so visit this upscale stalwart only if you have money to burn and the desire for ethnic food in an interesting, art-filled, tablecloth setting. For $85, you'll get a 12-course tasting of excellent food, including delicate beef panang curry, textbook pad thai, ethereal lemongrass crab cake and perfectly steamed, curry-drizzled lobster. But we can't help wondering if these diners don't know that these same dishes can be had elsewhere in town for a fraction of the cost.
column144: El: Brown to Kedzie. Bus: 80, X80

column7: Vegetarians and vegans hit pay dirt with this completely meat-free spot. During the week, veg-heads hit it up for popular South Indian dishes like dosas (thin, crispy rice-lentil crêpes filled with potatoes and onions) and uttapam (similar to dosas but thicker like pancakes with onions dropped right into the batter). But on the weekends (Friday through Sunday), the main attraction is the buffet—a massive spread of about a dozen North Indian vegetarian dishes (of which more than half are also vegan). The selection rotates, but you'll typically find gingery lentils, creamy spinach studded with cheese cubes, smoky eggplant mashed up with mushrooms, and potatoes with cauliflower in an oniony gravy.
column8: Good for groupsBYOBVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: This nationally acclaimed small-plates spot is tiny, looks like a sauna, has communal seating, doesn't take reservations and is as loud as hell. But it works, and at five years, is still as enticing as it was out of the gates. Food & Wine Best New Chef Koren Grieveson keeps regulars on their toes with seasonal additions like asparagus crostini with red-bean hummus and a cumin-laced salad of arugula, spinach, shaved apples, pickled shallots and pancetta vinaigrette. If you can steer yourself away from stalwarts like chorizo-stuffed dates, go for whatever pops up on the specials blackboard.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsNotable wine list
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 56, 125
column204: 2007 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best Small Plates

column7: Replacing culinary wizard Graham Elliot Bowles is no small feat, which is why Avenues chose Curtis Duffy to do so. With stints at Alinea, Trio annd Charlie Trotter's under his belt, Duffy's progressive cuisine is both spontaneous and organic. The formal dining room glows golden with a view of the Mag Mile below—a perfect setting to splurge, sit back and let the sumptuous experience unfold.
column8: ViewsPrivate party room(s)Notable wine listVegetarian-friendly

column7: When the French controlled Vietnam, baguettes crossed cultures, and one of the finest results of this is the banh mi sandwich. They're plentiful in this area, but this bakery creates most of the bread restaurants use, so go try the source. We like the barbecue pork and the Ba Le special, which piles housemade pâté, headcheese and sliced pork onto a crusty baguette along with tangy carrot and daikon slivers, cilantro and jalapeño. Customize your toppings a bit and you'll get a fresh sandwich instead of the pre-made ones used to keep up with carryout traffic. Shrimp spring rolls, flaky croissants and canned coffee drinks are must-trys.

If you were worried that this barbecue gem was down for the count, rest assured that the smoker is once again burning. The sage- and fennel-flecked sausage is still custom-made by a local sausage maker, and still gets significant smoke time over the smoldering hickory and cherry wood. Rib tips remain the juiciest pork option (over the often drier spare ribs), and also the best value. Skip the beef ribs; spend the dough on "Miss Winters'" outsourced 7UP, sour-cream and chocolate cakes instead.

People generally seem to love gargantuan portions (for the value, most likely), but when the heaps actually taste good, it's a win-win situation. Since moving next door to digs that are a touch more swank, this Italian favorite is suddenly packed with couples lingering over decent bottles of wine and specialties like garlicky housemade sausage links with blistered bell peppers, fresh cavatelli and rapini swimming in white wine garlic butter sauce, roasted chicken oreganato and the juicy, seared New York strip with sweet and vinegary peppers. The marble and mahogany bar and handful of café tables up front are perfect for a stop-in drink or dessert.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Blue to Chicago; Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 65

column7: There are a few birrierias (spots that specialize in Mexican goat stew) sprinkled throughout the city, but all it takes is one visit to this one before you stop caring about the rest. The scope of the menu may not win you over at first—this joint serves only about half a dozen items—but after trying the delectable tongue tacos, the cabeza tacos full of luscious beef cheeks, the simple yet rich goat consommé or the goat tacos bursting with sumptuous meat, you'll find you won't want for anything else.

With a name that translates as "countryside bistro," this restaurant is one of our favorite places to be. The room is so warm and inviting—its nooks and picture windows create a cozy house feel—we could stay all night. Especially with chef Michael Altenberg at the stove. Ingredients are organic across the board, and they meld into French and Belgian bistro classics with unforgettable flavors. There isn't a bad thing on the menu, but if we had to limit ourselves, we'd go with onion soup, mussels steamed in Belgian ale, roasted chicken and pan-seared flatiron steak flanked by amazing frites. Oh, and all of the day's ice creams.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seating
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column7: Paul Kahan's James Beard Award–winning, minimalist chic restaurant is as popular as ever, with chef Mike Sheerin and pastry chef Tim Dahl indulging the too-cool-for-school crowd. Early spring ingredients grace cocktails (like the Mister Pink—a mixture of gin, rhubarb and ruby-red grapefruit), while bobwhite quail gets asparagus and wood-grilled sturgeon is accompanied by English peas and braised peanuts. Two lunch prix-fixes make the experience easier on the wallet: a $22 three-course menu with offerings like duck tartare and white chocolate mousse joins the popular $15 prix-fixe featuring the whitefish sandwich or lamb burger.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 56, 125

column7: The overwhelming trend of late pairs sushi with a loungey vibe, but when the fish is this good, we can happily coexist with Bucktown babes in pointy heels eating sashimi and sipping pinot grigio. The menu balances Japanese classics and fun rolls (we love the wholly untraditional House Crunch). Servers are honest about what's freshest, and every time we go for the yellowtail, the quality is great. Likewise, the creamy scallop nigiri and spicy white tuna roll are unforgettable. On the cooked side, try tender negi beef rolls—almost as yummy as the White Castle sliders you'll score when you're hungry again an hour later.
column8: Good for groupsGood for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: This is the oldest of Kevin Boehm and Rob Katz's restaurants, but a couple of changes in personnel are making the place new again: It has just nabbed cocktail genius Benjamin Schiller (formerly of In Fine Spirits) to do its cocktails, and pastry chef Kate Neumann has been tapped to fill the big shoes left behind by Elizabeth Dahl. But among all this change there is a steady force: Chef Giuseppe Tentori's sophisticated Mediterranean dishes are still the stars of the show.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seating

column7: Hungover rock stars, early-rising soccer moms and everybody in between seem to flock to this bright, cheery spot for fancy morning cocktails and a bite or two. Among the run-of-the-mill numbers on the menu are some dishes worth the often-very-long wait. The chocolate tower French toast—no doubt the menu's piece de resistance—is a creamy, luxurious pile of chocolate bread smothered in what is essentially melted banana crème bržlée. It's definitely more dessert than breakfast, but sweet tooths won't complain.

This old-school favorite opened its doors in the Heart of Italy neighborhood in 1933, which almost explains the faded travel posters and weary saloon decor. But the kitchen is far from tired, going beyond typical pastas and parmigianas to specialize in rustic dishes from Siena, owner Luciano Silvestri's boyhood home. Tucked between the chicken Vesuvio and the stuffed shells are a rich ravioli filled with porcini mushrooms and a spirited rendition of penne alla puttanesca. Surprisingly, a long list of pricey Tuscan wines contains some interesting finds.
column144: El: Pink to Western. Bus: 21, 49, X49, 60

column7: Cuban food goes upscale at this contemporary and undeniably pleasant spot. Standards are dressed up with fancy touches like saffron cream, garlic polenta and sun-dried tomato pesto, and it's all executed with competence, but with a little less oomph than the dramatic menu descriptions suggest. Two enormous pork chops arrive tender with plenty of honey flavor but only a trace of the advertised jalapeño. The ropa vieja, flanked by crunchy, sugary plantains, is juicy and fork-tender, but you can't help feeling like you could order it at your local Cuban dive for half the price. But with the eclectic crowd and excellent mojitos, those shortcomings are forgotten quickly.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 11, 50, 80

column7: A decade ago, it was considered daring to venture down the alley into this restaurant's almost hidden entrance. Now that the neighborhood is fully gentrified, it's a little harder to snag a table on weekends. What hasn't changed is the cuisine: simple, seasonal ingredients brought together without too much fuss. Roasted beet salad is incredibly good, with frisée, mâche, toasted almonds, Manchego cheese and a drizzle of truffle oil. Duck breast is moist inside, crisp outside and comes with tasty duck confit ravioli on a bed of caramelized onions, wilted arugula and Asian mushrooms.

Lincoln Park loves its tapas joints, and this is the granddaddy of them all, packing in crowds for a somewhat T.G.I. Tapas feel. Lettuce Entertain You may be the Viacom of local dining, but here the ingredients are fresh and good quality: zesty Manchego, full-bodied olive oil, tangy anchovies and spicy chorizo fill the menu. Thick bacon is wrapped around juicy dates and roasted, and sherry tomato sauce tops tiny, tender meatballs. But the buck stops when we can't find a thread of saffron in our paella, and we're confused to see Mexican touches here and there at a supposed Spanish spot. Most of the loud, sangria-filled patrons don't seem to mind.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating
column98: 2009 Eat Out Awards, Readers' Choice: Best Tapas
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: The French flavors at this charming Wicker Park staple are as rich as ever, even as the menu changes to highlight spring ingredients. Bright, seasonal flavors balance heartiness in dishes like a pan roasted end cut veal chop, served with Shooting Staff Farm baby turnips, morels and a sorrel cream sauce and Alaskan halibut with spring onions, morels, bacon and thyme. A $23 prix-fixe menu is offered Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings.
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 73

column7: Laurent Gras doesn't let a single detail get away from him at this homage to all things ocean—from the first feel of the velvety menu to that last, ethereal bite of macaroon, the bicoastal chef is in complete control. To wit, à la carte exists only in the lounge; the restaurant offers a four-course and a 12-course menu of inspired and sublime options like salted cod puree with ribbons of smoked gelatin and sliced geoduck with a touch of fresh wasabi. But don't fill up on fish: L20 has the best bread in the city, and you'll want to eat as much anchovy-stuffed brioche as you can.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at bar
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: A Blog-o You Can Trust (must-read restaurant blog written by chef Gras)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151, 156

column7: The food at this Caribbean spot is a lot like the Tommy Bahama–ish decor (which includes the occasional fake bunch of bananas): It's not exactly authentic, but it'll pass in a pinch. Jerk chicken wings are absolutely enormous and have an equally big, spicy flavor. Shrimp and conch fritters are crispy and golden brown on the outside, and fluffy in the middle. Plantain-encrusted tilapia is curiously bland, but the juicy ropa vieja sandwich on soft, house-baked bread makes up for it.

column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine list

column7: At this tiny Pilsen storefront, regulars get special treatment (a.k.a. refried beans, not always on offer), newcomers just get blank stares and everybody gets the carnitas. Ordered by the pound (our server recommended a half-pound per person, but we think that's a little stingy), the juicy pork (choose between "just meat" or "everything," which includes skin, ribs, etc.) is served to you on a platter with nothing but a side of corn tortillas and a spicy salsa verde so that you can concoct your own tacos. Not leaving any part of the pig to waste, the limited menu also includes fresh, warm, delicious pork rinds.

Trotter remains one of the best chefs in the country, proving nightly that not only did he train the younger talent in town, but he can still school them. À la carte doesn't exist here, so go full throttle with the contemporary eight-course tasting menu and tack on wine pairings; this team hits them out of the park. Trotter changes the menu every other week or so, but his current salutations to the season include Millbrook Farm venison loin with coriander, preserved pearl onions and hedgehog mushrooms, plus roasted Muscovy duck with bitter melon and duck consommé. A vegetarian tasting menu and nonalcoholic beverage pairing are also on offer for you health nuts.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: It's not just red-sauce joints and Italian lemonade in Little Italy. Another option is this quaint spot, where the walls are the color of buttercream and the pâté is just as smooth. The room feels slightly like the lobby of an upscale retirement home—the clientele doesn't help matters—but the food is anything but stale. The mushroom quiche is thick with earthy 'shrooms and crunchy bread crumbs, and the steak frites comes with a particularly herbal maître d'butter and habit-forming shoestring fries. This place might just be that dependable little spot you've been looking for when the wait at Le Bouchon is insane.

This century-old brownstone is a quintessential Chicago steakhouse in every sense of the word. Conventioneers and local businessmen with fat expense wallets head upstairs for white-tablecloth service, pricey wines from a 650-bottle list and 48- or 64-ounce porterhouses fit for a king. We prefer the subterranean piano bar, where every inch of wall is covered with vintage photos of Capone and crew and the high wooden tables are packed with loud storytellers, unapologetic smokers and uncompromising carnivores. Go for the creamed spinach-topped baked clams, the New York strip (ask for it "charred") and the fatty but tasty lamb chops.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine list

column7: This place knows how to exploit sushi's sex appeal while maintaining a low-key, neighborhood-favorite vibe. Slippery, curvaceous morsels of tuna, yellowtail, salmon and more are served in a dark, sultry dining room full of slick minimalist furniture and tableware. The main focus is great-quality raw fish, but a few liberties are taken, and with success. The ceviche maki pairs lime-marinated scallop with mango, cilantro and jalapeño; salmon gets stuffed in a spring roll, fried and served with green curry dipping sauce; and the po' boy maki combines crunchy whitefish with unagi, avocado, cream cheese and a spicy eel sauce for non-traditional, yet delicious, results.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsBYOBVegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column198: Other location: South Coast, 1700 S Michigan Ave (312 662-1700)

column7: The soft focaccia and fruity olive oil delivered to your table at this popular Gold Coast mainstay are good indicators of what's to come. Start with some antipasti—it's not on the menu, but on your way in you probably passed by a table stocked with the wonderful chunks of Parmesan, white beans slick with olive oil and herbs, and thin slices of tender prosciutto. The garganelli pasta dish is doused in lamb ragu; and housemade gelati are decadent endings.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125
column198: Other location: Coco Pazzo Café, 636 N St. Clair St (312-664-2777)

column7: The real draw of this small, Little Italy storefront is the Maghrebin food. Taking influences from Moroccan, Algerian and Tunisian fare, it's a mash-up of cuisines resulting in delicious tagines, cheesy soufflés stuffed with beef or chicken that aren't cooked in tagines but are tasty nonetheless. Or go for the comforting plates of couscous sporting huge chunks of potatoes, carrots and zucchini surrounding flavorful cuts of lamb. Come on, you can pass up pasta for a night, can't you?

Hopefully, Suzy Crofton likes the clean, contemporary look of her restaurant, because as owner, manager, sommelier and chef, she spends a lot of time here. Her seasonal American cooking has inspired a couple of dishes that regulars won't let her take off the menu, like the jumbo lump crabmeat crab cake and the smoked-apple chutney–topped Gunthorp Farm pork belly. But for fall she's managed to sneak in some new cultworthy dishes, such as a starter of fresh cod brandade with sweet-and-spicy potato rouille; a salad of mustard greens, pancetta and crispy potatoes with goat-cheese dressing; and an entrée of Columbia River sturgeon and horseradish croquettes.

The Thai owners of this blissed-out spot are self-described "biospiritualists," which means that they don't serve "land animals" (only veggies and seafood), they aim to use the freshest ingredients possible (never frozen) and the bar serves nothing but freshly squeezed juice concoctions. Housemade, garlic-flecked, steamed potstickers are delicate wraps with spinach-carrot-cabbage filling, and the Dharma Garden spring rolls are the epitome of fresh, with bright flavors of Thai basil and mint. A rich coconut milk Massaman sweet-potato curry starter comes with flaky roti for scooping up every drop, but save enough room for restorative entrées like steamed lime salmon hiding under a mound of fresh garlic, ginger and chilies.
column144: El: Brown to Kedzie. Bus: 80, X80, 82

column7: The Dining Room has ended its era (banquets and private affairs may still be held there), so chef Mark Payne has shifted his focus onto the Café. Winners abound on the recently unveiled menu: Roasted Vidalia onion soup is sweet from caramelized onions and rich from beef shank braised in the broth, a mound of prime steak tartare is coupled with waffle-cut potatoes fried in duck fat and drizzled with truffle oil, and there's a fantastic ricotta gnocchi tossed in duck ragù with briny olives and aged pecorino shards. Compared to these gems, desserts are a bit lackluster. Ingredients are top notch and execution is nearly flawless, but it's the high prices that keep us from making the Café a regular spot.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendly

column7: Comfy digs and an accommodating waitstaff draw a casually dressed crowd from the nearby Piper's Alley and Second City theaters to this family-owned Italian restaurant. Starters include fresh clams and mussels in white wine garlic sauce and a signature salad of mesclun lettuce, gorgonzola cheese, pine nuts and tomatoes topped with warm balsamic vinaigrette dressing. Besides the requisite selection of pasta, chicken and veal, the restaurant features two fresh fish entrees and a grilled duck breast tossed with portobello, field mushrooms and fettuccine.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72

column7: It's always a good sign when Chinese restaurants are packed with Chinese people. But we wish they'd share their secrets to sidestepping land mines on this menu—we've found a lot of bummers, but the winners have us hooked. The cigar-shaped pot stickers are among our favorite (ask for house chile oil to stir into the dipping sauce). Sweet-and-sour fans will love the crispy, french fry–like sticks of eggplant glazed in garlic sauce with wood ear mushrooms and flecks of red chilies. The sautéed lamb with cumin and sesame seeds, whole red chiles, onions and jalapeños is a bit fatty but juicy and flavorful. And the "pan-fried smoked pork cake" is a crispy, pitalike sandwich stuffed with a pancetta-ish pork, hoisin and scallion slivers.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)BYOBVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendly

column7: If you're looking for good fried chicken, look no further. This West Side institution has been serving up stick-to-your-ribs soul food for more than 40 years. The crispy, black-pepper-laced fried chicken is made to order, so expect a 20-minute wait—but it's worth it. For sides, go for the biscuits, greens, mac and cheese, candied yams and black-eyed peas. The matronly servers are no-nonsense, but if you come back, they'll remember you with a smile. Peach cobbler is tasty, but if you spy glass cake stands on the diner counter filled with triple-layer caramel, chocolate or coconut cake, don't leave without snagging a slice.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)BYOBPrivate party room(s)

column7: This cozy Mexican mainstay has a recent addition with its sleek second-floor lounge, which boasts subdued lighting, a flickering fireplace and a polished wood bar. Grab a table upstairs and order some of our favorites: tilapia-filled tacos, inky black beans with perfect white rice, tangy (slightly charred) skirt steak and plantains with crispy edges. In warmer weather, the back patio is required seating, and if you're lucky, you'll be visited by the ever-present owner, José, who's quick to pour tequila shots for newcomers and old friends.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplaceCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 76

column7: Yellowed photos of sunny Cuban beaches line the walls of this tiny storefront, a casual meeting place for the local Cuban community. Don't miss the standout ropa vieja, a soft pile of garlicky, tomatoey shredded beef that releases juice and flavor with every chew. Traditionalists will love the authentic bacalao (salt cod), the fried pork chops and the boliche (slow-cooked eye-of-round offered only on Thursdays). Show up early—you may walk by and see some older Cuban men smoking cigars and grunting at the television, but if it's after 8:30pm they won't let you in.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 74, 77

column7: "Larry the Jew" is at the helm of this slick underground operation, which has all the chutzpah of a New York Jewish deli but none of the grittiness. Ordering a sandwich on the marbled rye is your best bet, and whether you go with thinly sliced turkey or celery-flecked tuna salad, the goods are piled on thick and high. Sides like tangy potato salad and an assortment of mustards will keep you happy, but it's the gooey, heart-stopping grilled Reuben that will keep you coming back.

This Ethiopian choice stands out for consistency and punchy flavors. The ground beef in the sambusa is livened with peppers, making the timid potato-and-carrot variety pale in comparison. Vegetables shine in the entrées, starring two types of split peas: the rich yet tame alicha and the spicy wat, both stewed to melt-in-your-mouth perfection and served with injera bread. Fat and bones abound, but don't let that stop you from gnawing on the kay wat, beef cubes simmered in the "diamond sauce," a gingery, cumin-laced red sauce with a nice chile kick.

Folk-art collectors Renee and Rodney Carswell's funky, casual dining room is an all-day draw for those looking for an interesting meal for a reasonable price. Brunch and breakfast standouts include New Mexico–influenced tongue scorchers like green-chile enchiladas and huevos rancheros—perfect when balanced with fresh-fruit smoothies and strong coffee. At dinner, local and often organic produce appears as salads and sides for comforting classics like chorizo meat loaf and roasted chicken mole. Keep an eye out for Brazilian dishes on select Thursdays as a prelude to Sonotheque's monthly Braziliance parties.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: Owners Bruno and Melissa Abate decorated his high-style Italian restaurant with a wall of simulated grass and mannequins dressed in flashy couture, but the diverse crowd here comes for the food, not the fashion. We love the crispy, paper-thin pizzas from a wood-burning oven (try the napoletana, topped with oregano and anchovies) and the pastas (a simple but spectacular risotto bolognese was a recent special). Entrées are hit-or-miss—on one visit, the veal Milanese was limp and underseasoned—but the personable servers make reliable recommendations.

Don't waste your time searching for the crudo and antipasto. This is Bridgeport, so when locals want to eat they stick to thick, roasted pork chops (how one person could eat the order of two is beyond us) and big bowls of penne tossed with spicy pesto, capers and succulent nibs of prosciutto. The kitchen can get overzealous with its fire sometimes—an order of lemon-kissed grilled octopus was pretty charred and the chops a bit dry—so request it toned down, unless you're into well-done. But don't be surprised if your waiter tells ya to get lost. Like we said, this is Bridgeport.

Since opening its doors in '87, Frontera Grill has been the spot for an intensely flavorful, impeccably fresh slice of Mexico, courtesy of celeb chef Rick Bayless. With the help of chef Richard James, the menu changes often—currently the focus is on food as bright and sunny as the colorful dining room. Spicy serrano-marinated grass-fed flank steak gets a flavor burst from hand-crushed tomatoes, grilled knob onions and sweet corn tamales, while garlicky Alaskan king salmon rests in a creamy sauce of fresh chilaca chiles, served alongside Living Waters green beans and crispy epazote. And don't let summer go by without trying one of the impeccable margaritas.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 65

column7: For some, Sundays are for church. For others, it's dim sum time. This spot offers one of the largest selections in town and proves the most consistent overall. A mix of neophytes and lifers pack into the giant banquet space (a favorite in the Chinese community for weddings) to settle in for the barrage of carts that wheel by brimming with a dozen different dumplings (shrimp-peanut, chive and pork stand out); fluffy buns (barbecue pork and pan-fried veggie-pork are awesome); and various fried and steamed morsels of hangover-absorbing snacks. Don't miss the taro puff, ribs, potstickers and sweet egg custard tarts.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Sometimes you want a good piece of sushi without the black-clad servers, hip house beats, triple-digit bill and lighting so dim you can't tell your toro from your tako. This tiny, no-frills sushi café offers just that, slicing up fresh, meaty cuts of all the standards, including tasty salmon, fatty tuna, mackerel and yellowtail. For starters, try the housemade pickles and the soy-sesame-ginger marinated, grilled baby octopus. If you're into Americanized, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink maki rolls, the Chicago Spicy Crazy is the one to try. Lazy? They deliver for a small fee.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 74

column7: For the past three years, Shawn McClain's moss-colored, Asian-tinged house of Zen has been the only upscale dinner experience Chicago vegetarians can truly call their own. And with the recent addition of brunch, vegetarians now have another Sunday-morning go-to. Chef de cuisine Molly Kipp's superseasonal dinner menu was recently updated to include items such as agnolotti with stinging nettles, snap peas, baby squash and mascarpone; chilled arugula soup; and roasted halibut with fingerlings, fennel and asparagus.

This Polish staple's simple, superb soups include creamy mushroom—packed with toothsome 'shrooms—and borscht in a teacup, delivering a blast of beet and an unexpected "egg roll" of liver paste on the side. The Polish Plate features the greatest hits of the menu's carbo-comfort foods: cabbage rolls, pork cutlet, tangy kielbasa, pierogi and buttery dumplings perked with scallions. Surveying neighboring tables manned by Polish-speakers inspired us to order a meaty pork shank with horseradish and sides of housemade pickles and sauerkraut that turned out to be delicious. There's a liquor store across the street if you choose to BYOB, or sip a glass of kompot, a traditional Polish drink made by boiling dried fruits with sugar and water.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 81, 91

column7: When in Chinatown, it's often hard to distinguish between the good and the bad. But if you're at this popular pick, you should do okay. Start with crispy shrimp dumplings (the menu says they're pan-fried, but they look dropped-in-a-vat to us) and follow them with the pork chop in a sweet, aromatic barbecue sauce and crispy shrimp coated in a salty, spicy mix that stars the revered Szechuan peppercorn. You won't find dessert on the menu, but if you ask, you'll be served an inky black-bean soup with tapioca—it's a surprisingly sweet, creamy and light ending to your meal.

Come hungry. As delicious as the heavy Lithuanian food at this diner is, its name is about as far from the truth as possible. You can get the diner fare anywhere, so don't bother with pork chops and tuna salad. Instead, focus on Lithuanian specialties like kugelis, a pan-fried square of potato pudding that's rich with the flavors of bacon and onions, and sweet, crêpelike pancakes called blynai, topped with fruit (order them unfilled rather than stuffed with the dry and spongy cheese). Pork lovers will flip for the fresh bacon buns, served on Friday only, which are exactly what they sound like and the koldunai, fat dumplings stuffed with meat and sprinkled with—you guessed it—more bacon.

Yeah, it takes somewhat of a theme-park approach, but this homegrown minichain of Creole food is still the closest you'll get to New Orleans in Chicago. Bottles of hot sauce take up as much room on these tables as the food does. Unless, of course, you order one of the po' boys (the shrimp is a good bet), which are piled so high they necessitate a knife and fork. Daily made soups like the hearty gumbo stick to the theme, but if you're still skeptical about the authenticity of it all, order one of the neon-green margaritas served in a tall, curvy glass—about halfway through you should start feeling just like you did on Bourbon Street.
column144: El: Blue to Washington; Red to Lake; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: If the early closing hours of this two-year-old breakfast-and-lunch spot has prevented you from checking it out, here's your chance: It's now open for lunch and dinner during the week. Breakfast and lunch items (such as the rich biscuits in a thick vegetarian mushroom gravy and the tuna melt on marble rye) will be available all day, and a rotating list of specials (chicken piccata, stuffed peppers) will round out the menu for dinner. Breakfast and brunch will still be available on the weekends, but with such long lines, you may be better off getting your bacon-and-egg fix on Monday night.

The father and son behind this rib house know a thing or two about barbecue, hailing from a part of Arkansas where smokers are more common than microwaves. Their style of 'cue employs real wood (rather than gas) to impart smoky flavor on slow-cooked meats. Bring a hungry crew, stake out a table in the simple but spick-and-span dining area and order up a couple of slabs of meaty, tender spareribs, a whole mess of rib tips and a plate of hot links. If you're still hungry after the main event, juicy smoked chicken and crispy catfish should round things out.
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 74

column7: Thought this was just a bar to belly up to with a Belgian brew in hand? One bite from the seasonal menu and you'll know there's much more. Carnivores can exercise their organic options with the likes of smoky brisket sandwich or grilled Dakota beef flank steak. Other highlights include the CB&J: a grilled sandwich of housemade cashew butter, fig jam and morbier cheese on sourdough bread. The somewhat hidden back patio is the perfect spot to sample through the city's best beer list.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningFireplaceOutdoor seating
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best Beer Bar

column7: Never tried Central American food? Here's your safe entry. It's simple, authentic, cheap, supercasual and friendly. Start with the hearts of palm salad—huge, tangy stalks on a bed of shredded cabbage that's been tossed in a lime vinaigrette, along with radishes, cilantro, cucumber, pickled beets and ripe avocado. Another menu standout is the pepito sandwich, a toasted, gooey combo of juicy rib-eye steak, caramelized onions and mild cheese on French bread. Make it a meal by adding a side of perfect white rice, soupy black beans and sweet plantains. Bring a bottle of Malbec to match, and end the meal with one of the shakes (oatmeal and tamarind are our favorites).
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingBYOBVegetarian-friendly

column7: As the saying goes, big things come in small packages, and the big flavors that spill out of the kitchen of this tiny diner may open some eyes. The menu is wildly erratic: Classic American greasy spoon standbys make an appearance, but the bread-and-butter, so to speak, of this place is Asian-influenced dishes that can transport you from China to Thailand to Korea in a single bite.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 22, 80

column7: Gifted with the hands of a warrior, chef Macku slays fish instead of dragons at his sophisticated Japanese storefront. Making yearly sojourns to Japan, the Chan clan (chefs Kaze and Hari round out the family) studies with their master for inspiration. The result is a form of fusion that dresses up slick cuts of nigiri with seasonal, cooked toppings and includes creations like whitefish tempura wrapped in shrimp and drizzled with a parsley butter, and pan-friend tofu steak with an olive oil and soy dressing garnished with a mixture of seasonal seafood. Menus change with the seasons, and Tuesday nights are a steal: Four courses with wine pairings goes for $45.

This Roman-style trattoria has become a favorite for those with Euro nostalgia. The simple rooms are matched by an authentically simple menu. We love the caprese (the mozz is so good we order it even when tomatoes aren't in season); the ever-changing grilled and roasted antipasto veggies; and the tart green apple and celery salad dressed only with olive oil, fresh lemon and shavings of delicious Parmesan. Couple these starters with the warm, crusty bread and follow up with the guanciale-dotted spaghetti alla carbonara and the sage-, shallot- and duck breast–filled ravioli in tomato cream, and you can skip main courses altogether. But don't miss the kiku, a simple and delicious baked custard and fruit dessert.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Weekends are popular times for this Ecuadorian spot—that's when Ecuadorian bands take to the stage in the dining room, and apparently some people like their dinner with a side of pan flute. Us? We'll take the quieter weeknights, when we can really focus on the pinchos, three skewered and perfectly grilled shrimp drizzled with a sprightly chimichurri, and the llapingacho, your choice of sausage, steak or chicken (go for the thick, grilled steak) flanked by potato pancakes topped with a rich, savory peanut sauce. And, since the music isn't there to carry us away, an oversized pomegranate margarita should do the trick.

Classic French in Hyde Park? Yep. A midlife career change prompted chef Mary Mastricola to open this almost-hidden, slightly upscale spot eight years ago. The French wine list offers affordable choices and the trusty menu gets updated with seasonal additions every month or so. Early-fall eats include boneless rabbit filled with truffled hazelnut mousse, monkfish paella with jumbo shrimp and trout Grenobloise. Older theatergoers (Court Theatre is nearby) gobble up the early $32 three-course prix fixe (offered 5–6:30pm), while younger couples from the neighborhood take the last reservations (8pm) for a solid night out.
column92: 1504 E 55th St, in the Hyde Park Shopping Center
column144: Bus: X28 SB, 55, X55. Metra: Electric Line to 55-56-57th St

column7: Specializing in dishes from the Mexican coastal state of Guerrero, this spot lays out many seafood options, but meat is always center stage. The concentrated flavors of cecina (salt and citrus–cured beef) mesh perfectly with guacamole. An excellent rendition of an increasingly popular meat, goat barbacoa is served as savory, tender chunks. The charbroiled skirt steak is coated with cheese and salsa, making for a gooey, tasty dish. Enhancing otherwise standard menu items are moist housemade tortillas and frijoles charros, whole pintos simmered with pork. If you BYOB, beware that the owner might ask for an ID and a receipt to prove you paid for your poison.
column144: El: Blue (Forest Park branch) to Cicero. Bus: 12, 54

column7: Chinatown gurus know this menu by heart, so we'll speak to the neighborhood novices peering into windows wondering where to go: This place is the best spot for Szechuan cuisine in town. It uses plenty of Szechuan pepper, dried chilies, garlic and ginger to create flavors that are incredibly addictive. Our favorites are Chengdu dumplings, crispy Chinese eggplant with ground pork, "chef's special" dry chili string beans, twice-cooked pork, ma po tofu, Szechuan prawns and "chef's special" dry chili chicken. Trust us or choose at random—you won't be disappointed.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Late-night dining

column7: We're dubious of a Mexican joint where the servers push mojitos as their favorite drink. But it made sense when we saw a menu that started somewhere in Mexico and took cues from around the world. The lamb, an enormous shank, is laced with cinnamon and wrapped in banana leaves. Skip the empanadas, but don't miss the crêpes filled with cream cheese and caramel; they're tart, sweet and delicious. Like the food, the mariachi goes global, plodding along singing traditional Mexican ditties only to segue into tunes like "Ruby Tuesday" and "Cecilia."

If you were to wander in off the street, you might think this gem is little more than a charming German pub. It is, and it has been since '71, but since '91 it's also been one of the best spots in town for rouladen, thin beef rolled with bacon, onions and pickles. The German comfort food staple is served with tasty brown gravy, sweet braised cabbage and perfect, fluffy spaetzle dumplings. Stick with the authentic offerings like hackepeter (rich, fresh steak tartare on rye with capers and onions) and the wiener schnitzel (pounded-thin veal breaded and fried crispy), which is great with a heavy squeeze of fresh lemon. The gratis fruit schnapps is a perfect ending to the meal.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: Yes, it's small, it's crowded and you'll have to wait, even with a reservation. But it's the closest thing Chicago has to a true French bistro, right down to never-fail favorites like the flaky, caramelly onion tart and butter-topped steak flanked by perfectly crisp frites. An afternoon visit might yield a shorter wait without sacrificing any of the satisfaction, with a new lunch menu featuring hearty, simple fare like a sandwich of warm brie, proscuitto, red pepper and arugula and steamed mussels with frites. Finish the meal off with an apple tart and pretend you're in Paris, minus the snooty waiters.

There's no other Vietnamese joint in the city with a room quite as pleasant, sophisticated or styled as the dining room here. Dishes gain from French-colonial-Vietnam flair, such as recent additions like pan-seared codfish in rich tomato-mango sauce and wok-prepared lemongrass chicken spiced up with basil-chili sauce. Regulars rely on house favorites like crispy shrimp beignets and the lean, juicy ginger-marinated duck and know to head upstairs to the dim, sexy lounge for an after-dinner drink.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barNotable wine list

column7: Now that chef Bill Kim has left to focus solely on his Urban Belly hit, former chef de cuisine Chad Starling is at the helm of this upscale Asian fusion spot. Along with chef Starling's promotion comes a winter menu including Thai chile–smoked flat-iron steak with sweet and sour sweetbreads; braised Swan Creek Farm rabbit-leg crépinette with bacon, curried lentils and Riesling emulsion; and venison, marinated in soy and mirin and served with miniature organic pumpkin, ruby-red sweet potatoes and huckleberry reduction.

The first thing to know before heading for this Chinatown gem is that it's not the giant Three Happiness on the corner of Wentworth Avenue, and we stress this because the difference is monumental. Regulars toss "little" before the name to avoid confusion, pack the tables nightly, ignore the far-from-spotless decor (or lack thereof) and know to skip the so-so appetizers in favor of black pepper beef with rice noodles (ordered "crispy"), stir-fried Dungeness crab in chili-seafood XO sauce (the deliciously goopy mess is best spooned over rice rather than wrestling with fruitless claws), crispy salt-and-pepper shrimp and Cantonese-style crispy-skin chicken.

This local favorite has one of the city's best seasonally driven menus, so expect weekly changes that'll keep you up to date on the season's crops. During brunch, look for a strada with house-cured pancetta, ramps and peas, while sweet fiends get dealt a rhubarb preserve–topped brioche French toast. At night, vie for a table to try recent specials like white grapefruit tossed with white asparagus and cured hamachi or whitefish sided with stinging nettles and black trumpet mushrooms.
column60: Breakfast, brunch (Sat, Sun), lunch, dinner (closed Tue)
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best Brunch
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74

column7: The menu reads like an eclectic tribute to Southern, Cajun and Creole cooking, and the kitchen consistently nails the classics (gumbo, fried green tomatoes, shrimp Creole). There's an oddball spin on some dishes, but it mostly works, particularly with the crawfish étouffée risotto and "loafs" (a.k.a. po' boys) drizzled with melted Brie. The barbecue shrimp served on grits should satiate most Southern cravings. The restaurant's mantra, "sit long, talk much," translates into long waits on weekend nights, but quick bar service keeps the cold Abita beers coming, so time flies.

We didn't stick around very late, but given all the chrome, sexy lighting and bared midriffs we saw, we're pretty sure this place turns into the city's consummate Bulgarian nightclub. (That would also explain the 2am closing time.) During lunch and dinner hours, however, it's a surprisingly good restaurant. The menu is full of small plates like herbaceous sausages, dill-flecked yogurt-cucumber salads, fried zucchini and feta-packed burek—all of which taste good even without a cocktail in hand.
column8: Late-night diningGood for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: This restaurant is now closed.Chef John Manion's Nuevo Latino joint puts out addictive standbys like flaky empanadas oozing with goat cheese, but you'd have to visit quite often to keep up with the seasonal subbing. The cold-weather menu features starters like braised rabbit with Spanish chorizo and saffron risotto; a hearty seafood stew of shrimp, mussels and scallops; and seared duck breast in a spiced apple jus with sweet potatoes and brussels sprouts. A tropical cocktail list and desserts like passion fruit crème bržlée are the perfect excuse to linger and soak up the hot preclubbing weekend crowd.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 72

column7: It takes a lot to brighten a corner as industrial and dreary as this, but we challenge anybody to visit this pan-Latin mecca and not feel at least a little bit sunny. Chef-owner Mario Santiago's food remains as colorful as ever: He pairs juicy mangos and plump shrimp in a quesadilla and gives chicken fajitas a kick with gobs of cinnamon and chipotle. There's not much to look at from the restaurant's patio, so focus on the rotating cast of ceviches (like shrimp-avocado or tilapia) and dishes dotted with greens and herbs fresh from the restaurant's on-site organic garden.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)

column7: We're usually too busy stuffing our mouths with this tasty Middle Eastern grub to talk. If we could, we'd tell you that the foul moudammas are warm fava beans simmered in mouth-puckering herbs, lemon juice and olive oil. We'd tell you that the whole red snapper is broiled to such crispy, salty, juicy perfection that its addictive powers put a spell on us. And we'd tell you that the dining room is warm and romantic and that you shouldn't leave it until you've had the flaky, buttery, housemade baklava, made on the premises nightly.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hours) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76

column7: Apparently, someone gave the Merlo family the memo that there is a recession going on, and the former Merlo Ristorante has been dialed down into this more affordable trattoria. The signature osso bucco remains (as does its $29 price tag), but its fellow offerings now include impressive housemade pastas filled with ricotta and artichokes and crunchy EVOO-fried baby octopus. Don't let the name incite sausage cravings though—no in-house meat curing is taking place.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76

column7: This sunny, friendly sandwich-and-coffee joint helps kick-start the day with countless baked goods and specialty coffees, but it's the basic sandwiches gussied up with impeccable ingredients that get us in the afternoon. Our favorites: the BLT made with extra-thick bacon and the lean, juicy, rosemary-and-thyme–encrusted roast beef. The weekend crowd can be a bitch, so if that's the only time you can get here, be prepared to fight your way to the front of the line.
column8: Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: When we want high-end sushi without the high-end scene, we head for the simple outdoor tables here and dig into house specialties. Signatures like yukke toro (fatty tuna tartare with quail egg and housemade soy sauce) and kani nigiri (seaweed-filled with baked spicy crab) aren't exclusive to this locale (Mirai shares its head chef with Japonais), but the funky neighborhood and surrounding postdinner bar choices are. A closer look at the menu reveals that diners pay an extra $2 to $5 per item at Japonais, so when here, use that extra dough to attack the specials sheet, which often offers supremely fresh flights of tuna and whitefish of varying fattiness.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for dining at barGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: We know that the pastry case at this Guatemalan bakery—with its rows of golden pound cakes, muffins and cookies—seems like the draw here. But on the wall behind the counter is a small dry-erase board, and on it a list of savory dishes. Order the sumptuous tamales with a center of tender, well-seasoned chicken; excellent chile relleno stuffed with a complex filling of chopped pork, onion and carrot; and rellenitos, a fried plantain dumpling stuffed with beef. Don't get us wrong, the pound cake is good, but the savory dishes are the reason to return.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 76

column7: Chef Carrie Nahabedian delivers an upscale experience minus the pomp, courtesy of a snazzy room, great service and a seasonal menu that reads like a who's who in regional, sustainable foods. On the spring menu, rhubarb jam sweetens Hudson Valley foie gras; wood-grilled wild ramps and stinging nettles pepper risotto; and parsley root canneloni rests in Jerusalem artichoke broth. Choose from a cheese plate with new selections like Zingerman's Lincoln Log goat's milk cheese or an enticing parfait of rhubarb layered with buttermilk panna cotta for dessert.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listGood for groupsGood for dining at barOutdoor seating

column7: Ryan LaRoche (Tru, DeLaCosta) replaced Andrew Zimmerman (who's now leading the kitchen at Sepia) as the chef de cuisine collaborating with Exec Chef Christophe David in this stunning—if a bit chilly—dining room. The chefs wrap crab so neatly in thin slivers of gorgeous beets that it resembles a maki roll, and cook meats expertly, such as the lamb, given a Morrocan treatment, which was as tender as brioche. End on a high note with pastry chef Frederic Moreau's fantastic, slightly molecular versions of crème brulée and mille-feuille.
column8: ViewsPrivate party room(s)Notable wine listGood for groupsOutdoor seating

column7: If the city were flooded with Persian joints tomorrow, this spot would still be packed. There's something about the casual room brightened with colorful tile murals, the smoky baba ghanoush, the cinnamon-and-tomato–braised lamb shank and those tender chicken kebabs, charred outside but still juicy inside, plopped down on deliciously fluffy rice alongside charbroiled tomatoes and onions. A cup of Persian tea to follow, and we're in heaven.
column198: Other location: 4651 N Kedzie Ave (same phone number)

column7: Okay, so technically you're not eating outside, but when you're only a few feet from a pond in the middle of Lincoln Park, you are as close to nature as it gets in the city. Even more so when you sample chef Bruce Sherman's menu that's concocted with as much locally grown organic food as he can get his hands on. Long summer days mean the start of seasonal lunch service with dishes like squid fettuccine tossed with snap peas, pickled greens and garlic chips and an open-faced grilled asparagus sandwich, served on toasted ciabatta with watercress, caramelized onions and a poached egg.
column8: ViewsNotable wine listVegetarian-friendlyFireplace

column7: You'll never know how relaxing Celtic music can be until you spend an afternoon at this Scottish ale house. Listen closely as you hang out on the serene outdoor patio, eating fish and chips (it's all-you-can-eat on Wednesdays and Fridays) and drinking from one of the best Scotch whiskey lists in the city—soon you'll be humming along.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: As summer winds down, flavors just keep getting kicked up at this West Loop favorite, where chef Michael McDonald amplifies classics with seasonal ingredients in dishes like the Berkshire pork chop flanked by baby turnips, grilled asparagus and pickled peaches in a bing cherry balsamic sauce. Stephanie Prida is just as bold with her desserts, putting out grown-up versions of nostalgic warm-weather treats such as a cornbread funnel cake with glazed blueberries, candied bacon streusel and fro-yo. Specials like $5 wood-fired pizza on Fridays and Thursday nights in the bar (featuring $7 Wagyu gourmet hot dogs and $4 burgers) are hard to resist—and get into.
column8: Good for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 20, 65

column7: Chef Erica Fisher is now at the helm of Jerry Kleiner's South Loop Chinese extravaganza, but regulars need not fret—signatures like the sticky soy-chile Mongolian lamb ribs and the Peking duck "three ways" remain firmly in place. Vegans should also rest assured that at least a half-dozen options are still on offer at all times, and those with either smaller appetites or smaller budgets will appreciate that everything on the menu is also available in half-portions.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, X3, 4, X4, 12

column7: This sunny, popular brunch spot earned its rep with "frushi" (fruit and coconut milk–laced rice) and pancake flights. Brunch is still served daily until 3pm, pastries are baked on-site and the signature juice machines are in place at the bar. Sweet fiends should fall in love with the coconut-infused French-toast kebab, while those looking for a savory day-starter could opt for "omelet #6," fluffy eggs stuffed with garlicky asparagus and mushrooms topped with toasted almonds and a drizzle of balsamic.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22
column198: Other locations: 2011 W Roscoe St (773-248-0999); 75 W Harrison St (312-447-1000)

column7: If you've ever wondered what it'd be like to actually feel years being taken off your life with a single meal, Pepper Canister's Irish-ish pub menu is just the ticket to kill your curiosity. Forget the "saucy chips," which are skimpy American fries with sides of sour cream and mustard. Instead, go greasy with the Irish Breakfast, complete with fat slabs of sweet, fried ham and soft, meaty sausages, or the "toastie special," a buttery, oniony, cheesy mess of a grilled sandwich that's apparently all the rage in Ireland. Both are perfect for the drunk, the hungover and anybody trying to pack on the pounds.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart, Red to Grand. Bus: 65, 125

column7: This Lincoln Square sleeper fills up in the early evenings with families diving into crispy, thin, dinner-plate-sized pizzas. Baked in a wood-burning oven and served uncut in true Italian style, pizza toppings range from the simple (a Margherita dressed with fresh mozzarella and basil) to the intoxicating (a Quattro Stagioni with quadrants of artichoke, olive, prosciutto and mushrooms.) Later, neighborhood couples slurp up pastas and appetizers (try the suppli, crispy rice balls oozing with cheese) that live up to local authenticity standards. The wine list offers a fine choice of Italian varietals at a reasonable price per glass.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81, 145

column7: This crowd-pleasing sister to the original Uno's pizza institution features a cozy, below-street-level dining room/bar that reeks of that "old Chicago" feel, complete with black-and-white tiled floor, historical photos, and plenty of Ditka and Butkus memorabilia. Knife-and-fork, deep-dish pizza is its sole raison d'être, with a rich crust that gets crisp from its time in a traditional black iron pan. The pastrylike crust is the vehicle for a massive amount of cheese and fillings, with a straightforward tomato sauce ladled on top. We prefer the bright-green fresh spinach and broccoli (your perky waiter calls it "spinoccoli") over the bland sausage. Tourists love it, but, secretly, jaded locals do, too.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningKid-friendly

column7: The fabulous outdoor patio may be closed for the season, but this joint (a venture owned by the guys behind Lumen and chef Michael Taus) isn't letting the cold weather get it down. Instead, it's putting out cool-weather dishes like sweet-potato-and-truffle risotto with a brown butter vinaigrette and a phyllo-encrusted escargot with Camembert fondue. Miss the elbow rubbing of the outdoor space? No worries—there's plenty of elbow rubbing to be had at the communal tables indoors.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: Best Elbow Rubbing (outdoor communal tables)

column7: Looks like a wine bar finally got our memo. A little more than a year after opening, this sleek, slightly clubby spot procured chef Ian Swope. He's replaced tired, typical wine-bar fare (think hummus-and-olive platters) with dishes such as a subtle scallop carpaccio; a succulent slice of braised pork belly offset by a tangy white-bean puree; salmon filet flanked by irresistible brussels sprouts; and a trio of dessert wontons, one sweet, one bitter and one salty. We couldn't figure out how we were supposed to share these dishes—they seemed plated for one. Then again, who'd want to share?
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: From the shingled roof to the oompah music, this North Side fave is the place to get your Teutonic eat on. Many trundle in for the extensive collection of German beer (and who doesn't want to hoist a stein of Weihenstephaner?), but the food is sehr gut, too. The butter-soft smoked Thuringer sausage has a great mellow taste, while the Sheboygan brat makes a delicious mess with mustard and a heaping pile of sauerkraut. Try the hearty rahmschnitzel, a breaded pork loin swimming in mushroom gravy. Skip the disappointing black forest cake—the only dessert on the menu—and fill up that stein one more time.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: Even though this Southern-style comfort food isn't the best in town, but still has enough cream, grease and sugar to taste pretty good. Especially when you're hanging out at a comfy bar with a beer and a basket full of corn bread, hush puppies and apple butter. You could also take a seat in the kitschy dining room and clog your arteries with the big, fat, drive-in burger; the creamy chicken shortcake; or the snappy blackened catfish. And don't leave your liver out—there's a list of more than 70 domestic whiskeys.

It doesn't look like anything out of the ordinary: The smoky interior is typical of your average corner bar, the televisions are tuned to Wheel of Fortune and regulars shoot strange looks. But getting to the heart of what makes this place different (and fabulous) is as easy as finding the Caribbean specialties on the menu: sancocho, an intricately spiced soup with luscious chunks of pork; jerk chicken that's sneakily spicy, leaving a slow, long, delicious burn; and sweet plantains that weren't exactly sweet when we visited, but got a drizzle of honey to make up the difference.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 76

column7: Spend more than a million bucks on building a restaurant on an undeveloped stretch of the Chicago River, and you too can have a spot capable of transporting Chicagoans to a distant land. We're not sure where we are when we're here, but the Ian Schrager–esque space is swank, sexy, vibrant and, incredibly, she ain't just nice to look at—she can cook, too. The modern Japanese food centers around superb-quality raw fish, presented simply as sashimi or whacked out into tasty rolls. Don't leave without having the Kobe carpaccio, Tokyo drums, kani nigiri, yukke toro or "Le Quack Japonais."
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)ViewsGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 8, 66

column7: Snake your way past the Moroccan lanterns and rugs in the bazaar beyond the door and into the simple dining room to try specialties like briwates, diamond-shaped lemon-chicken egg rolls; zaalouk, a smoky mix of eggplant and tomatoes; and Fez tagine, a tender lamb shank in an eggy sauce studded with prunes. Generous pieces of dense, syrupy baklava may satisfy a certain sweet tooth, but we preferred the sweet and savory chicken pastille, a flaky, sugar-dusted phyllo pie. It's traditionally reserved for important people so puff out your chest and pretend.

The masterminds behind TRU have done it again, but this time think Italian share plates for a nice price. Servers will steer you toward the $35 three-course table tasting, where seasonal tastes arrive in waves and you choose only your entrée. Marinated olives in herbed oil with warm focaccia are followed by antipasti like veal meatballs and Maine Mussels in a spicy broth. Hearty pastas rotate but can include a tasty bolognese pappardelle and hand-rolled ricotta cavatelli with wild mushrooms. Skip the wine list and try the creative "Just Bring Me Wine," pairings in three different price ranges.
column8: Good for groupsNotable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: This place should be called Converted Carnivore Skeptic. It's packed with as many meat-eaters as vegheads, all Zenned out by the loopy lavender walls and the Korean spiritual guru video playing on the front room TV. We don't know exactly what's in the crispy "unchicken" drumsticks slathered in tangy, sweet barbecue sauce, but we know we love them. Steamed veggie dumplings are delicious, especially if you whisk some chile paste into the side of soy sauce. Noodle lovers should try the yakisoba in fruity Worcestershire-like sauce or the glass noodles made from sweet-potato starch and brimming with crisp, bright vegetables.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 147

column7: Known as Tank to Anglos, this spot is the answer for indecisive diners wandering Argyle Street. For Vietnamese-food pros, authentic picks are done well; for novices, the staff is apt with both English and suggestions. Lotus root salad (#5) is everything this cuisine can be—limey and minty with shrimp flavor, crunchy peanuts and a subtle chile kick. Pho broth is rich and complex, with all of the right accompaniments. Creamy coconut milk chicken curry (#92) gets oomph from both sweet and new potatoes; seafood rice noodle soup (#97) is great for anchovy lovers; and garlic-fish sauce-marinated "shaking beef" (#176) is flash-seared and served with vinegar-laced watercress.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)BYOBVegetarian-friendly

column7: Be warned that the namesake dish, nehari, a spicy Pakistani pot roast, will induce craving so strong you'll consider relocating to Devon. First-timers should know that the half-inch oil slick atop the gingery gravy is supposed to be there; it's ghee (clarified butter) and should be stirred in before ladling the comfort food onto fluffy rice. For a nice contrast, order the Frontier Chicken, which pops with ginger, garlic and fresh cilantro. For a complete meal, use garlicky nan to sop up the cumin- and chile-laced yellow dal or the fiery kahari gosht—tender lamb cubes bright with green chili, curry leaves and fresh garlic.

The room is reminiscent of a retirement-home cafeteria, and the menu has multiple personalities, but somehow Yoshi pulls it all together. Considering his 20-plus years in the game putting out mishmashed food long before the term fusion was coined, it's no shock to see yellowtail with guac, an oxtail–goat cheese spring roll or a Wagyu burger topped with a huge chunk of Brie. Thanks to Yoshi's former gig as a fish guy, seafood sings here, especially the fat, juicy mussels in fragrant lemongrass curry. Desserts, on the other hand, were disappointing across the board, but we like a restaurant that goes out on a limb, so we're willing to head elsewhere for a finish.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77

column7: Tangy, spongy injera takes the place of silverware at this Ethiopian hot spot. Spinach sambusas—hot, crispy dumplings—are a fine way to start your meal, but if you follow the directions on the menu, you'll have enough food that you won't need starters at all. Be brave and try the fiery zilzil tibs, beef strips sautéed with peppers in berbere sauce, an Ethiopian specialty made with red peppers and cumin. Or go for the doro alicha, a fragrant, tender, milder chicken dish. This stuff is likely to induce a food coma, so snag a table with big, cushy chairs.

Ribs—the hickory-smoked variety, to be specific—are the specialty of this Hyde Park house. Choose from "The Boss" (a whole slab) or smaller portions such as The Ranch Hand and Jr. Ranch Hand—each which come with fries, cole slaw and bread. For a little variety, opt for one of the Chuck Wagon Combos—the "chix 'n' ribs" combo gives you two pieces of fried or barbecued chicken and a half-order of ribs for less than $11.

The family who owns this Bucktown stalwart opened a classier joint down the street last year, but those looking for a more casual Peruvian experience still pack this place on the weekends. Mostly they're piling in for the sprightly ceviche, big platters of mixed marinated fish brimming with the tart, fresh flavors of lime and jalapeño. Cooked seafood doesn't fare as well (the plump shrimp we ordered arrived in a rich walnut sauce, but it wasn't enough to cover up the overly fishy taste), so focus on the beer-marinated duck instead, which comes with plenty of cilantro-flecked green rice to fill you up.

"All over the map" isn't usually a compliment, but Rique's takes pride in giving diners intriguing tastes of unfamiliar dishes from Mexico's diverse regional cuisine. Namesake Enrique Cortes recently moved on to another project, but Victor Arellano, a veteran of Chicago kitchens such as Bertucci's Corner and Café Central, takes the reigns promising not to change a thing. Strong menu staples will remain, such as shredded chicken with oregano and onions in a chipotle-tomato sauce, or achiote-marinated grilled chicken in a tomatillo–pumpkin-seed sauce. Better yet, visit on Saturday nights for the $20, four-course prix-fixe menu that showcases food from a single Mexican state. Recent examples include pre-Hispanic food from Tlaxcala and Caribbean-influenced food from Quintana Roo.

It's easy to dismiss this place as a scenester sipping spot, but the food is surprisingly worth a visit, even if slick digs aren't your bag. The South American/Southeast Asian menu comes from co-owner Maripa Abella (also owner of Thai Lagoon), whose Sunday brunch has been such a hit, it's been expanded to Saturdays. So glide past the line of lemmings at Bongo Room, grab a seat here, and start off with the Vietnamese coffee with powdered sugar–topped, beignetlike doughnuts and the coconut-milk rice pudding with fresh fruit. Pan-Latin classics like black bean arepas and huevos rancheros are delicious, especially with a spicy Bloody Mary to wash it down.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining

column7: Typically we'd tell the server to save the speech, but here, it's somehow still charming when the bubbly girl "from da neighborhood" explains how the namesake owners Roseanne and Salvatore came to open their Little Italy spot. Cozy cuteness aside, the food's among the best on the Taylor Street strip. Start with the lightly charred but tender grilled calamari; get a pasta course of big, fat garlicky shrimp tossed with shells and broccoli; and go for the veal saltimbocca with a side of spinach for the main event.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for groupsVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendly

column7: If you've never wanted to live in Lincoln Park, consider what it'd be like to call this adorable Italian eatery your neighborhood spot. The locals seem to head here at least once a week, so there's always a wait, especially for the garden tables. The cozy-cute surroundings inspire foodies to let the spotty menu slide, but we enjoy the mezzalune al burro, a subtle yet hearty preparation of ricotta-and-spinach–stuffed pasta in brown butter; raviolini alla Maria, salmon-filled ravioli in a creamy pesto sauce; thin, whole-wheat pizzas; and manicotti preparations that change weekly.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76

column7: Beware the "poison sauce." It sits there in a bowl on the table, beckoning innocently as if it were just another salsa verde. But it's a fire that is tough to put out, and there's no guarantee you'll be able to taste anything afterward. And that would be a shame, because with a menu offering tangy ceviche on crispy tostadas; hand-shaped shrimp empanadas; fish tacos slathered with seasoned crema; and juicy shrimp tossed in copious amounts of garlic, there's a lot you're going to want to taste.

A classy choice for the symphony set and couples looking to indulge, this institution proves excess is best. Slide into a cozy booth and start the assault with classic borscht, sour cream-slathered dumplings and caviar blini. Follow up with creamy beef Stroganoff or oniony, nutmeg-laced, ground-beef-stuffed cabbage rolls. Finish up with hot farmer's-cheese blintzes or Klara's apricot-and-plum strudel, a family recipe from the restaurant's matriarch. Skip the wine and order a flight of house-infused vodkas (pepper, pineapple, ginger, coriander and more).
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams; Red, Blue to Jackson. Bus: 3, 4, X4, 6, 7, 14, 26, X28, 145, 147, 148, 151

column7: Almost ten years after opening, chef-partners Rick Tramonto and Gale Gand are busy tending to other projects while exec chef Tim Graham and pastry chef Meg Galus keep TRU relevant. They do it with splurge-worthy menus ranging from a $95 three-course with sarsaparilla quail and Moroccan lamb three ways to a $145 nine-course "Chef's collection" featuring frog legs and pan-seared foie with bay scallops. Of course, you can always rewind time and add on Tramonto's caviar staircase for an upcharge.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listVegetarian-friendly

column7: True, this long-standing Thai spot is an Anglo favorite that isn't going to whip out ant-egg omelettes and fermented pork sausages to impress the authenticity police. But we like the fact that we can visit for an inexpensive dinner with friends who aren't such adventurous eaters, bring a bottle of wine and settle into the low-lit room for consistent, tasty, somewhat pan-Asian eats. Green-curry tofu is rich and fragrant, studded with green "globe" eggplants and basil leaves. Tom kha soup packs plenty of lime punch, as well as a garden of vegetables. And modernized creations deliver flair, especially the sesame-crusted tuna with ginger sauce. Crab rangoon, miso soup and tempura veggies will please the kids (or adults who grew up in strip-mall towns).

This spot's a neighborhood stalwart in a neighborhood that, frankly, needs stalwarts.
