column7: Ixcapuwhateva got a pretty new name and a spankin'-new address, but chef-owner Tomas Bahena kept it real after the move and stuck to his delicious regional Mexican roots. Thankfully, he has toned down the old motley color scheme, but we were delighted to see that the exquisite menu survived. Wafts of musky corn from the kitchen make our mouths water for cheesy tamales and chilaquiles vegetarianos (so soft they feel like pasta). Skip all of the insanely intricate desserts and keep it simple with the housemade ice cream: The strawberry is to die for. We only have one burning question: Where'd the crowds go?
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 73, 49, X49

column7: Schlep to the 'burbs for a Greek meal when Greektown's a stone's throw away? You will once you taste this cozy, authentic eatery's crispy fries doused in lamb gravy and feta (ask nicely for this unlisted treasure); tender, falling-off-the-bone lamb; earthy, monk-made wines like Agioritikos; and addictive fasolia gigantes (lima beans in a heavy tomato sauce). Spiro and Sofia Papageorge, the enchanting owners, treat every patron like long-lost family.
column144: El: Green to Oak Park. Bus: Pace 309, Pace 311, Pace 313, N20

column7: Seafood is king at this cozy, casual Peruvian spot, so start with the hefty mixed ceviche of fresh calamari rings, big shrimp, baby octopus and huge mussels (a value at $12) and move on to the family-size paella made with subtly flavored rice and studded with every creature from the sea. Meat eaters will love the lomo saltado (tangy, tender, marinated beef strips sautéed with tomato and onion and topped with a heap of crispy fries to sop up the steak juice), and the rich Peruvian beef stew, fragrant with baking spices and generous with melt-in-your-mouth chunks of beef roast. End with sweet, crispy plantains and amazing dulce de leche cookies.

We could be snarky and say that it's all about the scene here, but the sushi is so damn good, we won't. Countering the aloof, black-clad servers, the Sade remix–loving DJ and the throngs of clubgoers filling up on preparty snacks are incredibly fresh sushi and creatively cooked dishes. Flash-cooked, citrus-tinged shrimp tops cool green tea–soba noodles; spicy, vinegar-tossed slaw is topped with tempura soft-shell crab that's drizzled with wasabi honey; impeccable grilled salmon gets earthy plum sauce and seared mizuna greens; and crunchy, gooey maki like the Ecuador, Godzilla and Tarantula overload our senses.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: If this sleek, boisterous Puerto Rican spot is representative of the island's cuisine and culture, we're booking a ticket to San Juan. The space's French doors, modern art, hardwood floors and 1920s bar are an ideal setting for modernized classics like lomo de cerdo (pork chop in mango-rum sauce) and escudo boriqua (lamb chops in papaya sauce). The strong mojitos may fool you into thinking you can dance like the spiffy locals who pour in once the band starts around 10pm on Saturdays, but you might want to look into salsa lessons at the next-door dance studio first—these dancers are fierce.

Hotel lobbies aren't our dining rooms of choice, but we make an exception for the sultry vibe of this low-lit Mediterranean spot with a lake view from the patio. Chef Kristine Subido updates her menu for warm weather with pan-roasted sea scallops over pea purée; hanger steak tossed on the grill with spring onions; and roasted artichoke croquettes served with a lemon aioli. The menu breakdown is a little mystifying, but three small plates or two large feed a group of four just fine.

Let's go over this one more time, because it's still a little confusing: The Hearty Boys used to own this restaurant, but no more—now they're running their own place in a studiolike complex around the corner. Their longtime chef Joncarl Lachman has taken over this spot, and he puts out great, seasonal American food. For fall, he's stocking his menu with full-flavored comfort foods, like a brie-and-lamb burger on a pretzel bun and a braised rabbit couscous with porcini mushrooms. He's cut the cupcake flight out for now, but in its place is a Gouda tasting to start the meal and a tasting of Terry's Toffee to end it.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77, 135, 145

column7: Now that chef Erick Williams is comfortable in his role as executive chef at Michael Kornick's River North stalwart, he's constantly tweaking his menu. These days, those tweaks involve an ode to fall ingredients: pumpkin soup with toasted coconut; pan-roasted black bass with Nichols Farm red bell peppers, fingerling potatoes, fennel and saffron-scented nage; and roasted, farm-raised squab served with sweet potatoes, wilted greens and housemade bacon. Pastry chef Tony Galzin gets into the autumn spirit with a warm maple pound cake with roasted figs and crème fraîche sorbet.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156

column7: It's kind of like riding the El: The wait at this always-packed tapas joint can be long and annoying, but once you get inside, things go pretty quickly. Cheap plates of patatas bravas (soft, habit-forming cubes of potatoes immersed in a spicy tomato sauce) and croquetas de pollo (creamy chicken and ham fritters) arrive at the table almost immediately, dropped like afterthoughts by overworked servers. A plate of Manchego and a pitcher of sangria to tide you over, and you won't even notice the wait.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), to Chicago. Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

column7: We can't rave enough about this stylish Turkish spot in Chicago's newest Restaurant Row. We show up every few days to wolf down the manti (Turkish ravioli stuffed with bits of lamb in a creamy yogurt–and–chile oil sauce), whole slabs of juicy, salt-crusted sea bass and some of the best hummus around. Savvy regulars skip the filling entrées and instead fuel up on apps and sides like lightly fried zucchini pancakes with chilled yogurt dip and char-grilled calamari with chilled oil, diced tomatoes and garlic. Couple these dishes with a few baskets of warm, homemade sesame bread, and you'll still have enough pocket change for a robust cup of Turkish tea.
column144: El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 49, X49, 50, 77, 152

column7: Hey, we thought it was weird, too: An upscale hotel dining room with a menu that's two-thirds Italian and one-third Asian would normally send us running. (So would the atrocious upholstery on the banquettes.) But this place surprised us at every turn. We watched as a pizza maker rolled out the dough for our deliciously sweet, creamy, salty pie of grapes, goat cheese and sausage and baked it to perfection in a wood-burning oven. And believe it or not, a trio of plump seafood dumplings were tasty little things that could have come out of any Chinese kitchen—or, for that matter, an Italian one.

Most of the guys who go to this sporty, sceney homage to stainless steel don't seem to care what the food tastes like—it's more of a tits and beer thing for them. But if they'd pay attention, they'd find that most of the menu is much better than the chewy, cardboardish pizzas. As counter-intuitive as it may seem, the antibar food is where the gems are, like the mildly spicy braised lamb lettuce wraps and the perfectly golden roasted chicken.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Chef Rangsan Sutcharit's Thai creations draw faithful crowds to his charming eatery on the border of Oak Park and Chicago. Panang curry is the perfect balance of spice and tang. Noodles such as the pad kee mao ("drunken man's noodles") are tender and flavorful. Everything in the pad thai is incredibly fresh, from the sprouts to the sweet turnip. Best of all, the chef isn't shy with the presentation skills he perfected during nine years turning vegetables into works of art at upscale Arun's. Once you become a regular, you can call ahead and make off-menu requests.
column144: El: Green to Oak Park. Bus: 72, Pace 311

column7: If you're looking for interesting tequilas, a few contemporary Mexican snacks and an under-30 crowd bobbing their heads to everything from Morrissey to Moby, this spot will work. The back room has more of a dining-room feel, but we prefer the front lounge, with its illuminated tables and Tim Burton–style metal tree sprawled out over the bar. Take advantage of Tuesday's $5 sangria pitcher special, or splurge on one of the hundred or so sipping tequilas. Skip the so-so entrées in favor of antojito menu picks like bright ceviche made with huge chunks of tilapia, scallops, shrimp and octopus; fish tacos, with plump pieces of barely battered tilapia wrapped in warm tortillas; and the "Salud" nachos, a mixture of cool, creamy guacamole, pico de gallo, black beans and cheese.

Yep, it's another Brazilian churrascaria that's offering an all-you-can-eat onslaught of more than a dozen cuts of spit-roasted meats and endless trips to a veggie-packed salad bar for close to $50. This new kid on the block isn't a chain like its competition, but the owners already have their eye on expanding. Obligatory caipirinhas and mojitos anchor the cocktail list, but specialty martinis and slick plasma TV screens hint that they're aiming at a style-conscious crowd.

The hour-long wait is laborious, but in the case of this blink-and-you'll-miss-it Mexican grill that sits in a strip mall, it's worth it. Usually, the word rustic is saved for earthy European fare, but that's the only way to describe the flavor of piping hot tortilla soup thickened with blended tortillas; buttermilk-tinged, slawlike house salad; and caramel-colored, chargrilled chicken perched on a pile of smoky chipotle mashed potatoes. We'll be back, no matter how much gas it takes to get there, especially for the mango cheesecake (a breathtaking mix between flan and mousse) topped with fresh mango and raspberry puree.

Fans of Indian food can get their fixes while also trying Nepalese fare at the same time at this spot that serves both. Among the Nepalese offerings (no dairy, milder spices, and less oil than Indian food), we go for khasi ko maasu, goat meat on the bone stewed in a gentle, savory broth; and jhane ko dal, mashed yellow lentils sautéed with cumin and cilantro. Of the Indian dishes, the palaak paneer, creamy spinach with tart cubes of curdled milk, and lamb vindaloo with potatoes and a smooth tomato sauce stand out. The classy décor, soothing music and Nepalese/Indian beers add to the experience, and a variety of vegetarian dishes are included in the bargain lunch buffet ($8.95 daily).
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 201, 205, Pace 208, Pace 213

column7: After establishing themselves as a popular sushi lunch spot in the South Loop, this budget-minded biz recently expanded with this new, swankier locale. Sashimi is still the way to go—big, thick cuts of very fresh, cool standards are dependable and tasty, and richer indulgences like fatty tuna and sea urchin are equally good and almost always available. Interestingly, the cooked menu is offered as small plates, making it easy to try a handful of unique dishes like roasted chicken-stuffed lotus root in crispy tempura batter and baked sesame-crusted scallops with wasabi mayo.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Steakhouses—if you've been to one, you've been to them all, right? Well, no, but if you've ever felt that way, chef Charlie Brown's Tuscan take on beef should prove refreshing. Ignore lesser entrées like the ho-hum salmon and order a steak, which comes plated on a pile of arugula and crusted in your choice of Parmesan, Gorgonzola or roasted garlic. You can also forgo a crust in favor of four sauces (we fell pretty hard for the horseradish cream), but why not just order both? That way you won't have to focus all of your morning-after guilt on the creamy garlic mashed potatoes or the gooey, gluttonous and ridiculously delicious Gorgonzola garlic bread.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy. Bus: 1, 7, 28, 126, 151, 156.

column7: What would a soda fountain be without an outdoor spot from which to watch the world go by? Late-night hours (till 11pm weekdays, midnight weekends) mean you can get a postdinner jolt from the caffeinated "cream express" milk shake (vanilla and espresso). Or grab a scoop of the Lakeview Barhopper (chocolate ice cream with Jack) to get a jump on the night's festivities.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 22, 36, 76, 156
column198: Other location: 3425 N Southport Ave (773-248-6104). Kiosk at Buckingham Fountain

column7: For 81 years, the awning-covered picnic tables of this Far South Side ice-cream shop have been packed with locals feeding their sweet tooth. It has added smoked brisket and pulled-pork sandwiches to the menu this year, but the classic Rainbow Cone is what keeps us coming back, until 11pm. The five-flavor cone features slices of chocolate, strawberry, Palmer House (vanilla with cherries and walnuts), pistachio and orange sherbet stacked one on top of the other for an unbeatable classic.

You might expect a place that has a 70% vegetarian menu to have boring dishes made with soy milk and flaxseeds. But this coffee shop/bar/restaurant/performance space will surprise you with dishes like the grilled quail with caramelized salsify. During brunch, the winners keep coming: The huevos rancheros are gooey, cheesy and substitute black-bean cakes for tortillas; and the fruit plate sometimes comes with passion-fruit sorbet and a slice of white-chocolate banana bread. It's all so heavenly it may make carnivores think about going veghead. (Or at least 70%).
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: Chaise is both restaurant and lounge, and it hawks martinis as vehemently as it does dishes such as an autumn salad of parsnips and Asian pears; sweet-potato latkes; and beef short rib in red wine jus. But it's the rooftop deck (covered in a tent in chillier months) and alfresco patio that steal the show—at least for those looking to rub elbows with Miami Beach wanna-bes.

Koi has no reason to be jealous of its popular, older sister, Chens in Wrigleyville. This pan-Asian hot spot's got its own cool vibe. Even though this isn't the place for a Chinese or Japanese cuisine purist, the food can be unexpectedly good, especially the Szechuan red snapper, lemon chicken and mu shu wraps. If you dig unpredictability, go for a sushi special plate, a selection of fish compiled on the chef's whim, starting at $40. Be sure not to overlook the selection of specialty teas, which includes rare varieties like miteag genmaicha, a mix of sencha and brown rice.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 201, 205, Pace 208, Pace 212, Pace 250

column7: Chicago-style pizza is legendary around the world, but great debate swirls as to whose is the best. Though this institution is no longer at its original Superior Street location (opened in '66), the wooden walls covered in graffiti advertising that "Hans was here" were transported over to this new spot that used to house Planet Hollywood. Tourists flock in droves, so skip weekends. The famous deep-dish has a cornmeal crust that's void of the butter glaze others give the pan, so it's not greasy (but also not very flavorful). Luckily, the punch comes from the sauce, which is tangy and ripe. Try half spinach–half sausage (let it sit for a minute when it arrives to avoid a runny mess), and wash it down with a Goose Island 312.
column8: Good for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 65, 125

column7: So the sushi isn't going to change your life or replace your swank weekend sushi bar, but we love this carryout spot as an easy Loop lunch option. Zippy chefs concoct daily specials like eel rainbow rolls and nigiri orders on the fly, while the refrigerated case is stocked with just-made combos (Cali, Philly and spicy tuna is a good one). Miso soup and seaweed salad are tasty, but a bit salty, and the cool edamame (soybean pods) are a ready-to-go protein boost. But our hands-down favorite thing about the place is the "wall of fruit": It's the sign that true fresh-fruit smoothies are being made (in flavors like watermelon, lychee, mango and avocado) in an area where other spots use that grainy, premade powder, tapioca-drink crap.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams; Red, Blue to Jackson. Bus: 1, 3, 4, X4, 6, 7, 14, 26, X28, 126, 145

column7: Don't sweat the man dozing on a recliner in the middle of this eclectic, Western-themed dining room. Soon he'll be awake, bringing bowls of black beans to your table, begging you to add them to your food to "make it right." It's true that the beans make the tostadas—already piled high with shredded chicken, fresh guac and sour cream—a little better, and they may add life to the thin quesadillas. But the tacos—especially the spicy chorizo wrapped in two tortillas and overflowing with tomatoes and cheese—don't need any help .
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 49, X49, 72

column7: You've seen it all before: the white tablecloths, the oversize wine posters, the empty bar in need of a liquor license. But Pietro Cristillo's nod to his native Capra deserves more than a cursory look. The antipasto plate includes thin, grilled slices of garlic-topped zucchini and tender, meaty folds of prosciutto and salami. Housemade, perfectly cooked pappardelle is paired with a rich and subtle mushroom cream sauce that's even better when you add a pinch of salt. Finish with the Caprese cake, rich with fudgy chocolate and ground almonds. If you don't live close by, this spot may not be worth a special trip, but it's heaven-sent for those already in the 'hood.

Sometimes you want straight-up Thai. None of that authentic, secret-translated-menu stuff; you want the pad thai, lad nar and crab-and-cream-cheese–filled wontons you first tried in college. If that's the case, this spot's for you. The crispy roll appetizer is oddly addictive: fried, cigar-shaped rolls of paper-thin rice wrapper holding in threads of vermicelli noodle, ground chicken and sprouts. The peanut-vinegar sauce shines in the fried tofu starter, as does the tangy, spicy lime dressing for both the papaya and the charbroiled sliced beef salad with big chunks of tomato. Pad thai is tasty enough, but the chicken is bland; a better bet is eggplant basil (which can fluctuate from good to great) or the spinach and pork in tamarind curry.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingBYOBVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 49 X49, 50, 70

column7: There's really no way to explain how bizarre and overwhelmingly varied the weekend brunch buffet at this Bucktown sandwich shop is without listing a portion of what's up for grabs. So here goes: cheesy Western-style scrambled eggs; mini–peanut-butter–and–jelly sandwiches; "famous" BLTs; beef tacos; blueberry pancakes; liverwurst–and–cream cheese bagels; and the signature Twinkies, straight from the box (but conveniently unwrapped). The coffee's good, but the garden seating is lovely, and besides, where else are you going to get a spread like that for 12 bucks?

You could walk right by this spot and think it's nothing more than a greasy spoon. You'd almost be right. But once you head to the cute, often-barren patio, open up a bottle of your own wine and check out the modest prices, you'll become much more forgiving. Start with the loukaniko, homemade sausage sautéed with onions and peppers (an app portion is available by request), and the huge Mediterranean salad with tasty dolmades, feta, peperoncinis and more. Also tasty are the flaky, peppery spanakopita and the Spartan pizza, which swaps spicy hummus for tomato sauce and is topped with grilled chicken, spinach, feta and olives. The roasted chicken is flavorful, but often dry, so ask for extra basting sauce.

Stuck as we are in the Midwest, Southern staples such as real grits and biscuits can be hard to come by. But this enormous West Loop eatery (the sister to the Lakeview location) has made it its mission to bring "mornin' hon" hospitality to the heartland. The brunch is often touted as the city's best, and while we're not willing to go that far, we can definitely get down with the plate-size fruit pancakes and savory corn cakes (try the latter with some hot sauce), the dense corn muffins and buttery biscuits, and the spicy (but not hot) andouille chicken sausage.

The quaint Bucktown take-out window has set up this second shop west of the original in Logan Square. Just like in Bucktown, passersby will find it hard to resist the refreshing watermelon, the fresh strawberry (with seeds and pulp galore) and the sweet, creamy mango (how Miko makes the ice so creamy without dairy is beyond us). The banana with chocolate chips is a more acquired taste, but it's one that, luckily, more people now have the opportunity to try.

If it looks like a bar, smells like a bar and sounds like a bar, then...you do the math. But two things keep this place from going the route of sports-bar-beer-bong culture: excellent house brews and expertly executed pizzas. The crispy pies hold a lot of weight, so after you choose your pizza style—red, white or New Haven–style "plain" (red sauce, no mozzarella)—start piling on the goat cheese, spinach, meatballs, anchovies and, if you're really going New Haven–style, clams or mashed potatoes. Wash it down with a pitcher of the crisp Golden Arm, and you'll never disparagingly say "pizza and beer joint" again.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendly

column60: Breakfast, lunch, dinner (closed from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday)
column93: La Casa de Isaac Mexican Restaurant
column186: La Casa de Isaac Mexican Restaurant

column7: Don't look for any signs marking this Bronzeville lounge and restaurant. Just follow the train of cars in line for valet. This upscale eatery is hidden on the second floor of a nondescript commercial complex, but the eclectic menu (and funky vibe to match) makes this a spot worth seeking out. This is soul food transcended. Start with the crab cakes, and then go for the chipotle ribs or steak. You'd be hard-pressed to find anything elsewhere like chef David Blackmon's signature bayou catfish, a tasty dish of two crispy filets stuffed with Cajun spiced crabmeat on a bed of grilled vegetables. Reservations are key, especially if you hope to catch the live jazz on Thursdays.
column144: El: Green, Red to 47th. Bus: 3, X3, 47

column7: A bookstore in the dining section? Yup. But it's more than a bookstore; think wine bar with tasty bites in a spot that just happens to be filled with books. While we were sipping delicious Vina Marian (a Spanish blend of verdejo and sauvignon blanc), we tried the soups—sweet onion tomato and carrot ginger bisque—which are so tasty, the snack grew into a full meal. The vegetarian sandwich is a cool, fresh combo of tomato, cucumber, provolone and mixed greens on slices of ciabatta spread with herbed cream cheese. Bookworms can enjoy 1/2 price wine and beer at the store on book club nights, the first Wednesday of each month.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: If you're craving sushi but don't want the brain-numbing dance beats, here's your salvation. For nearly two decades, this traditional Japanese spot offers more of a steakhouse atmosphere—with low lights, jazz tunes and TVs at the bar—and keeps the focus on food. Sushi is best ordered as sashimi; you'll get thick, meaty cuts, and you should ask for a side of the perfect, warm rice for contrast. Standards are all great, but try some not-so-common choices like sea urchin and escolar, a firm, oily fish with full flavor. Aside from sushi, try the kani su, a salad of cucumbers and meaty pieces of crab in tangy vinegar dressing. Deep-fried oysters and pan-fried scallops are rich and flavorful, as is grilled yellowtail collar, and the seafood udon soup is a sweet-salty, share-size favorite.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73
column198: Other location: Hachi's Kitchen, 2521 N California Ave (773-276-8080)

column7: This clubby, dimly lit sister to Tango Sur is a lot like escaping to Buenos Aires—without the inflation. An unconsciously chic gang of international exiles sips mojitos and flirts to classical beats and tropical grooves either at the tile shard–covered front bar or at tables for two. The best of the picadas (apps) are the simple, garlicky eggplant and the mixto plate of the lauded empanadas and beef milanesa (fried steak chunks) with bright and tangy chimichurri sauce. If the amazingly good mojitos go to your head, soak up the booze with more substantial fare like the vacio, a grilled skirt steak with chimichurri, or dos tiras, tender short ribs. Both are a bargain at $13.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningPrivate party room(s)

column7: Despite the cramped quarters of this kitschy diner/ice-cream parlor, a line for a vintage mustard-toned booth can stretch out the door. Why? More so than the ice cream, chocolates, or the small menu of soups and sandwiches, it's nostalgia that draws people out in droves. The fancy silver trays with white paper doilies and saucers filled with chocolate and caramel sauces no doubt bring back fond memories for many, whose families have made this place a tradition since it opened in 1921. Equally as reminiscent of the good old days are the display shelves, which are crowded with memorabilia from the Beatles, who just had to have some Margie's ice cream after they played Comiskey.

It's slim lunch pickings on this stretch of Ashland, so for people looking to grab an inexpensive bite at someplace other than KFC, this wholesome food is worth the sometimes-slow service. The simply decorated room (okay, it's really just undecorated) retains a feeling of coziness, and the straightforward menu follows suit. Crispy, thin-crust pizzas, fresh and crisp Greek salads, and sandwiches stacked with everything from turkey to curried eggplant all have homemade appeal that'll make you think your mom is in the kitchen. The only exception is the soft, plate-size oatmeal cookie with chunks of white chocolate, dark chocolate and raisins. Unless your mama was Betty Crocker, she never made cookies like this.

Just south of Pilsen in an industrial no-man's land you'll find this dependable outpost of a five-restaurant "empire." It's not the best Mexican food in town, but the draw here is three-fold: The remote location and strolling mariachis (dinner only) create a temporary vacation feel; the handmade tortillas arrive minutes-fresh, hot and slightly charred; and the warm salsa is among the best in the city, a cooked version with blistered pieces of roasted chilies mingling with small chunks of stewed tomatoes. Cesina (thin, citrus-marinated steak) is tasty, but sometimes overly salty; and chicken enchiladas drenched in mole sauce will please your sweet tooth. Stick with cerveza, unless your 'rita preference is sweet over sour.
column144: El: Pink to 18th St, Orange to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 21, 60

column7: Greek diners don't typically reach cult status, but somewhere along the line, this unassuming Gold Coast staple picked up a few celebrity endorsements and became a destination for locals and tourists alike. Is it worth dealing with the mobs on the weekend? Well, we don't know another place that serves egg skillets like this spot: The portion is enormous, the eggs are soft and fluffy, and Tempo is smart enough to know that the only bread that can stand up to eggs are thick slices of Texas toast. So if you're into that—or equally massive plates of pancakes and French toast—go for it. Just bring a book.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: The servers here sport more ink than a Bic factory, and the place is outfitted with more wood than a forest, but that's what gives it its charm. The long bar that takes up most of the room gives this place a pub vibe, and the simple food follows suit. Turkey sandwiches pack bacon and avocado into big loaves of Italian peasant bread, apple-walnut salads are drizzled with maple dressing, and the brunch menu tacks on two eggs and bacon with an order of pancakes or French toast. But let's get real: Everyone's here for the massive burgers named for metal bands and the people watching, the latter of which passes the time during your hour wait for a table.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best Burger

column7: Fans of the shuttered Calvin Woods's Ravenswood barbecue spot Smokin' Woody's will be happy to know Woods has another location in Logan Square. The St. Louis native sticks to the strictly hickory formula he uses to smoke brisket, pork shoulder and ribs for barbecue he classifies as "a cross of Texas and Carolina style." The pulled-pork sandwiches that fly out the door of the original location (500 pounds a week) are on the menu, along with what Woods calls "blue plate specials": baked chicken, meatloaf and spaghetti. Spaghetti? St. Louis–style barbecue spaghetti, of course.
column198: Other location: Smokin' Woody's, 4160 N Lincoln Ave (773-880-1100)

column7: The thin-crust pizzas that earned this spot acclaim in the southern suburb of Mokena are also a draw at this newer University Village outpost, where they share menu space with homey classics like fried chicken and barbecue ribs. The grill is aimed at UIC students for lunch and the area's new residents for dinner, with spacious windows brightening up the place during the day and a lengthy bar menu making it a drinking destination at night. Look for two dozen import drafts and signature cocktails, like the vodka-based Morgan's Up.
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)
column93: Morgan's Bar & Grill on Maxwell St
column186: Morgan's Bar & Grill on Maxwell St

column7: We normally wouldn't condone spending more cash on Indian food than you would along Devon Avenue (which, in some cases, is also a notch tastier), but the perk here is delivery. Thanks to one of the largest delivery areas we know of, a simple phone call (and an extra $2.50) will lead to well-packaged, steaming hot classics arriving at your door. Fried-food fans will love the mix platter, packed with samosas, chickpea-battered potato patties, crispy prawns and Indian-style onion rings. For the main event, go with yellow lentil, roasted eggplant or oniony okra. Meat eaters will love the raisin-and cashew-studded chicken shahi korma, but skip the lamb unless you like it tough. And since the heat level seems to cater to the Anglo neighborhood, request "spicy" if you're looking for scorchers.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 74, 76

column7: We'll admit it: We've never really considered trying the food here when we were sober enough to taste it. No. 3 in the local "chain" of straightforward diners has always been a 3am favorite of Boystown barhoppers, so we were pleasantly surprised to find that in the light of day, this place can cook. The frittatas are great, especially the combo of bacon, mushroom, Gouda cheese and caramelized onions. We're not complaining about the pancakes stuffed with sautéed apples or the french toast coated in corn flakes either. Add a cup of strong (and always fresh) coffee to the mix, and it's a great way to start the day—or end the night.
column60: Breakfast, brunch, lunch, dinner (24 hrs Fri, Sat)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
column198: Other locations: 1746 N Wells St (312-337-2454); 2114 N Halsted St (773-327-1400)

column7: The way food is touted here—by wheeling over a cart of uncooked meats, including a live lobster—can be a little off-putting (not everybody wants to witness their dinner being wheeled off to its death). But there are reasons why Morton's is so famous: the classic Chicago steakhouse interior, tailor-made for sealing the deal (business or pleasure); crab cakes with hardly any filler; generous lobster cocktails; and barely seasoned steaks that stand out for their flavor (rib eye), their tenderness (filet mignon) or both (porterhouse). The signature dessert, Godiva chocolate cake with Häagen-Dazs ice cream, tastes exactly how you'd expect it to, so save your money and pick up a pint on your way home.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Red to State/Lake. Bus: 29, 36, 144, 145, 146, 148

column7: It's a concept that's almost impossible to pull off: Serve dishes from India, Brazil, Korea and China, tone it down for "American" palates and charge anywhere between $20 and $45 an entrée. So it's no surprise that things here are hit or miss. The tastiest dishes are the free ones: a basket of fresh, warm nan to start with and an indulgent trio of potatoes (sweet, fingerlings, gratin) that arrives with the entrées. We like the crab-stuffed sweet-and-sour shrimp, the sophisticated organic beet salad and the subtle roasted cod. But steer clear of the chewy duck and lobster chow mein, and don't blow your money on the steaks—there are steakhouses for that.

Northwestern kids know a thing or two, right? So we figured that since they pack this highly designed dim sum/noodle house nightly, we should get over our pan-Asian suspicions and try it out. The dim sum's not really dim sum (dishes are too big and too expensive), but some items, like the moist, steamed bao (buns) (essentially char siu pork doughnuts), and the one-dimensional but tasty sesame noodles make good appetizers. The toothsome Mongolian pork stir fry is sweet but not cloying, spicy but not hot. But forget about the blah salads and desserts—we'd have preferred a fortune cookie instead.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 205, Pace 208, Pace 212, Pace 213

column7: If you're a small-town kid at heart, cure your homesickness by heading far south to Hegewisch. This place is packed with local families on Wednesdays and Fridays for the house specialties: fried chicken and walleye pike. Aside from the simple, thin-crusted, greaseless chicken and the hefty portions of crispy fish, you'll get pickled beets, cottage cheese, fries, slaw and raw green onion—all for around ten bucks. "Down-home" doesn't do the scene justice; the brother-and-sister team that runs the place hands out Hot Wheels to kids who finish their meal and takes advance orders for the Polish-sausage-to-go that is made around the holidays.

The bartenders here whip up some of the tastiest, seasonal cocktails in the city, and it's hard to drink just one. That's why it's vital to fill up on the small plates from Moxie's eclectic menu, such as the jerk pork or "mammoth wings," which really aren't that mammoth but pack lots of tongue-tickling spice. Heavier dishes include gnocchi sprinkled with toasted garlic and lobster rangoon, which is light on lobster, heavy on cream cheese, and just the thing to offset a few lemon martinis.

Looks like those of us waiting for the small-plates trend to meet its overdue death will have to wait a little longer. The people behind John Barleycorn have unveiled this enormous Lakeview spot, which specializes in Mexican "tapas." Expect lots of meat on skewers, small fish dishes and snacks like tacos. Don't worry if the place is packed—you're bound to get in before the 2am closing time.

This Thai spot is the sister restaurant of Lincoln Square's outstanding Spoon Thai, and being right next to the Thai Consulate, we figured the food would be far from Americanized stuff. Surprisingly, the fare is decidedly tame, even for Gold Coast tastes. This isn't necessarily a bad thing (and could be a good jumping off point for Thai-food novices) because what it does, it does well. Chive dumplings get things off to a good start, the somtum (papaya salad) is fiery and flavorful, and the panang beef curry is perfectly balanced, with manageable heat.

This sushi lounge's slick, contemporary digs are more than just a pretty face. The kaki shooter—oysters, scallion, quail eggs and a lemon-soy sauce—is a tangy, salty tongue teaser. Another solid but simple starter is the "Dynamite"—shellfish and mushrooms baked with spicy mayonnaise. For entrées, the Asian-spiced lamb chop is a solid choice, or you can go the raw route with the luscious sushi. Occasional karaoke in the lounge and a private room for parties add to the draw.

First Armitage Avenue, then Gold Coast, and now the third arm of the blossoming local tea company has opened in the former Noble Fool Theater building. Expect trademarked concoctions like Teappuccino, Maté Laté, Smootea, Tea Sparkle and Tea Sangria, all tea-based concoctions aimed at making tea as coveted as coffee. Pastries, quiches, sandwiches and salads round out the menu, and the café offers small tables with Wi-Fi access for lounging. A small retail area carries a slew of tea accessories, as well as gourmet jams, chocolates and other edible finds.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 14, 20, 22, 29, 36, 56, 60, 124, 147, 151, 157
column198: For other locations, go to argotea.com

column7: The Chicago-Evanston border is a gold mine of Jamaican cuisine. Among the tried-and-true, we like this tranquil ocean-blue dining room. Conch fritters are juicy and flavorful; channa cakes (fried chickpea patties) are greaseless with fragrant curry notes; and the saltfish—slightly funky, salty pieces of dried fish hiding tiny morsels of bacon and peppers—is a must-try for the adventurous. Jerk chicken is deliciously seasoned and juicy, but far from spicy, so speak up if you'd like more heat. A rich, salty and slightly sweet simmering sauce douses meaty braised oxtails with plump butter beans. Don't skip dessert—coconut carrot cake and Grape Nuts ice cream are knockouts.
column144: El: Red, Purple, Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, 147, 151, Pace 215, Pace 290

column7: Don't let the lack of Indian patrons make you skeptical—they're staying away because this place serves alcohol (something that many Eastern religions forbid), not because the food isn't good. The meat-loving sibling of Udupi Palace, this white-tablecloth spot is one of the classier restaurants on the block, so entrées are about a buck more than elsewhere. Try the crispy vegetable pakoras, massive rounds of bubbly garlic nan, a fiery bhindi masala (okra sautéed with onions and tomatoes) and a chicken tikka masala dripping in a rich, creamy and, if you request, spicy sauce. Indian beer is tempting, but nothing's going to tame the fire in your mouth like a creamy mango lassi.

You'll hardly recognize this recently reopened sushi spot: Gone are the tangerine walls, industrial carpeting, low drop ceiling and the unsettling walk through the kitchen to reach the restroom. In their place is a giant space (it expanded into the next-door storefront) with soaring ceilings, eclectic artwork, a new "kushi bar" (skewered meats and veggies) and, thankfully, the same great sushi. Still reliably delicious are the fresh and crunchy dragon roll and the spicy sweet potato maki, but the kushi is about as bland and unexciting as you'd think food on a stick would be. Part of the price of a sleek new look: Ringo is awaiting a liquor license, so BYOB while you still can.
column144: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: The owner-waiter is Mr. Syed (who goes by Bobby), the cook is his lovely wife and the name Bhabi means "sister-in-law." At least the food's not confusing. You might just rub elbows with some of the area's top chefs digging into delicious vegetable samosas, nearly two dozen unique breads and flavorful entrées like pureed rapini, baby eggplant and butter chicken in spicy tomato-cream sauce. Be warned: The spice level is definitely not Americanized.

The so-so Mexican spot Brioso has morphed into this welcome Tex-Mex/Southwestern restaurant with a spiffed-up paint job and a menu with more hits than its predecessor. There are frothy, fruity margaritas plus the house drink—vodka mixed with key lime and prickly pear juice—to get you feelin' fine. Move on to creative takes on standby starters like chile-crusted calamari and nachos with slow-roasted pork and chipotle salsa. For entrées, try the thick blue cheese–crusted rib eye, grilled shrimp with creamy polenta or chipotle-rubbed baby back ribs. Banana cream pie sticks out among the desserts, but not as much as the rough-around-the-edges service.

Some believe the privilege of dining in a building so beautiful and rich with history is worth any price. But despite the carefully retained details from its former life as a 1904 fire station, we still don't understand why the cedar-planked Dover sole with browned butter, while flavorful, costs $40.99. Thankfully, the rest of the menu is fair enough: The CF 104 Tower, tender prosciutto encasing three sprigs of asparagus and mascarpone, is a heavenly start; the hearty pot roast falls apart with the touch of a fork; and a juicy rib-eye is topped with a luscious mixture of shallots and blue cheese.
column8: Notable wine listOutdoor seatingKid-friendlyGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 62

column7: Karen Gerod elevates lunch at her West Town café, and you may never want to make your own sandwich again. Using Red Hen breads and the freshest and most seasonal ingredients, she comes up with different creations every day (a recent creation piled turkey with cucumber, red onion, avocado, Jarlsberg and a yogurt dressing). The former caterer and wedding-cake maker also bakes scones and cookies daily (she has a soft spot for the lemon-ginger variety), and she makes coffee drinks, like the signature High Dive, a caramel-vanilla latte, using 100% fair-trade coffee.

Look, if you order one of the more sophisticated dishes—the bland white fish, perhaps?—you're missing the point. This place is all about the stuff you really want: juicy chicken tacos, cheesy nachos, deep-fried stuffed peppers. Don't want to eat for a few days? Get the gigantic fajita quesadilla, an oversize tortilla bulging with grilled slices of steak or chicken, bell peppers and onions that'll fuel you for weeks. And if you feel guilty for eating so much, down one of the house margaritas: They're so big and potent that you won't remember a thing.

column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: This tiny Euro-chic café is billing itself as the first organic carry-out restaurant in Chicago. The warm, whole-grain pretzels—baked throughout the day on the premises—may indeed be good for you, and no doubt the organic salads are, too. And the sandwiches, such as the Black Forest ham and Gruyère on soft "bretzel" bread, aren't exactly unhealthy, either. But our doctor probably wouldn't condone our favorite part of the store: an entire wall dedicated to chocolate, stocking what must be at least 30 different bars.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Orange, Purple (rush hrs); Red to Washington

column7: You can work on your novel for as long as you want in this bustling, slightly smoky European café, but sooner or later you're going to need something besides cappuccino to sustain you. When that time comes, order the  tirokafteri, a spicy feta cheese spread that comes in a portion big enough to feed four. After that, a golden square of the flaky, housemade spinach pie should provide your greens for the day. If you're there after 1:30pm, finish with a dessert crêpe; before then, these sweets aren't available, so you'll have to stick with coffee. But sip slowly—in true European fashion, refills aren't free.

No run-down rooms, no grumpy old-school service, no cigar puffing at the tables. In the world of steakhouses, Phil Stefani's slick, cosmopolitan version is as refreshing as shrimp cocktail (which, by the way, is decent, but the crispy roasted quail perched on top of a fluffy polenta-and-Gorgonzola soufflé is a better way to start). If you're up for steak, expect expertly prepared porterhouses, with a well-seasoned crust hiding tender flesh. But if it's lighter fare you're after, dig into the roasted red king salmon, a dish that perfectly balances the textures and flavors of the firm fish, soft Yukon potato puree and ten-year balsamic.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: Whether you're grabbing a meal to go or sitting down to eat at the counter of this bright storefront, expect your food to be served in a Styrofoam container with plastic forks. Carryout packaging is fine by us, because the dinners—such as the tender and gamey curried goat—are so generous you'll probably want to take part of it home. No knives are needed, either, because the oxtail falls from the bone with the touch of a fork. The specialty is excellent jerk chicken (sweet, hot and saucy) and juice concoctions made from fresh fruits and veggies, but the caramel cake is hot on the trail to becoming a signature standout.
column144: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs), Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, Pace 215

column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: If you stick to the menu basics served in this simple but pleasant dining room, you'll miss out on the best stuff. Get adventurous with kung chae naam plaa, raw shrimp marinated with lime juice, fish sauce, garlic and chile—a searing Thai take on ceviche. The Isaan-style pork-and-rice sausage is almost as addictive as the naem khao thawt, a crunchy, salty, tangy salad of fried rice, tiny ham bits and flecks of cilantro. Curry fans should try the kaeng som kung sot, a thin, slightly sour, shrimp-dotted tamarind curry, or call a day ahead to request special housemade fish balls doused with amazingly good green curry.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: This bastion of solid, authentic Vietnamese eats nails consistency and flavor. We like to start with the tiny beef sausages wrapped in la lot leaves (#1), as well as lotus root salad (#18), a sprightly mix of crunchy lotus root and rau ram, also called hot mint. Memorable entrées like catfish in a clay pot (#72) and chicken taro yellow curry (#62) match perfectly with a side order of garlic-laden, stir-fried water spinach. Wash it down with a glass of chanh (housemade limeade soda), and finish with the crispy tapioca flour–battered baby bananas.

Big, packed and loud, this is the type of place strong cocktails are made for, and their takes are stellar (particularly the bigote, a mojito-'rita-colada combo). The meal starts off as promising with minitacos that pop with flavor (we particularly love the pork roasted with chile peppers). Entrées like chicken breast smothered in a sweet mole are solid, but the fajitas are much more of a show: They're served in a hot, mortar-like molcajete where the peppers and scallions sizzle until you stuff them into housemade tortillas.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 4, 29, 62

column7: At this adorable, sunny, daytime-only café, health food is tasty enough to eat. The owners are committed to organics and offer meat-free options, but they're okay with a little cheese, butter and sugar every now and then. Case in point: thick, dense blueberry pancakes (chose maple or pomegranate syrup) and a heaping breakfast sandwich of fried egg, gorgonzola, applewood-smoked bacon and fresh thyme. If that's too good and gooey for you health nuts, there's always the Vegan Epiphany, an organic tofu scramble that just may live up to its name.
column8: BYOBOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50, 84, 147

column7: Chef Jean Joho is best known for the jacket-required dining style of Everest, but his brasserie is casual both in design and spirit. The menu of simple Alsatian food matches: The classic salad lyonnaise, rife with chewy lardons, is a solid starter, but it can't compete with the crispy, onion-filled tarte flambé (which you can score free from the bar on Tuesdays).
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listOutdoor seating

column7: Irony doesn't exist at this red-sauce joint, so take a cue from the name and the Sopranos mobile dangling over the cash register and behave yourself. It'd be a crime to get yourself banned from this place because while it might not be doing anything new, its brand of Italian classics is impeccably executed. Thin-crust Margherita pizzas shimmer with olive oil and explode with the flavors of basil, garlic and fresh mozzarella; enormous portions of chicken Parmesan are greaseless and immersed in a chunky, fresh tomato sauce; and the housemade tiramisu is so boozy you may forget you're in the States.

This restaurant is now closed.Nostalgic Le Francais stories most often involve now-retired chef Jean Banchet. But the man at the stoves during the '90s was Roland Liccioni, who's back in at the helm. The room itself is as staid as ever, but the food seems to be at once classic and reinvigorated. Age-old French techniques are combined with Liccioni's Vietnamese heritage and homage to season in dishes like scallop cake with pholike broth, roasted sweet corn soup with poached lobster, duck-leg confit with curried duck jus and a trio of crème bržlée that includes both Grand Marnier and passion fruit. The wine list straddles the fence between once-a-year splurges and everyday sippers, satisfying the suddenly diverse clientele at this 33-year-old culinary gem.

After closing for a couple of months and skipping town for a break, chef-owner Michael Carlson is back, and he's determined to remind people just how he earned his nod as a 2006 Food & Wine best new chef. Not much about the cozy, simple, hip-hop filled room has changed, though there are some new faces in the kitchen and new dishes on the menu. Go for the full-blown tasting menu and you'll be rewarded with an insanely rich beer-cheese soup , sumptuous venison paired with a white chocolate foam and a dessert like banana puree over caramelized plantains.

Thinking of spending your Sunday morning at this classic Chicago diner? Better check the weather: The line snakes out the door and onto Lou Mitchell Way well into the afternoon. Customers are treated to fresh, sugar-dusted doughnut holes (and, if you're a woman, Milk Duds) while they wait, but the real feast starts when you sit down. Stacks of "meltaway" pancakes are perfectly browned, omelettes come in hot skillets (try the sweet, rich apple-and-cheese variety) and juicy, gooey patty melts seem too big to finish. But as with the rest of the irresistible dishes, you'll find room.

Past the dark bar (where regulars pour tall bottles of beer into frosted glasses) lies a dining room heavily decorated with oil paintings and plastic flowers. Once you're here, remember you're not here for burgers and steaks, so stick to the Ukrainian side of the menu. Dense stuffed cabbage is topped with a thick mushroom gravy, and potato pancakes are thin and crispy (eat them while they're hot). But it's all just a vehicle to get to dessert: powdered sugar–dusted blintzes whose browned and crisp exteriors that give way to sweet, decadent cheese.

Adam Gould recently purchased this tiny new Lakeview takeaway space that offers almost 200 flavors of all-natural cupcakes. A handmade display shows off the sweets in flavors like chai-tea latte, orange-cream cooler, German chocolate, key lime, maple cream and hot chocolate. Each day, eight flavors from the collection are featured, rotating according to popularity and season, but the dogcakes, carob-based dog treats, are available anytime. Check out the flavors of the day at cupcakesacrossamerica.com.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77

column8: Good for dining at barFireplace

column7: There's a fine line between kitsch and authenticity, and this homely chicken shack sits right in the middle. Because despite the crowds of gay Moby-lookalikes, Starter-jacket-clad teenagers and yuppie moms sneaking in cigarettes after devouring whole birds, this place still looks and feels the way we imagine a rural Kentucky chicken shack does. And that's a good thing. It means juicy rotisserie chicken's flanked by tortillas and salsa; sides like sweet corn pudding (skip the disappointing mac-and-cheese); and finales like apple pie. Of course, Chicago ain't Kentucky, so specials like fried sage leaves and lobster-mushroom risotto satisfy cravings for big-city cooking.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)BYOBKid-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: It may be a magnificent mile for shopping, but when it comes to dinner, Michigan Avenue often comes up dry. If you're looking for something other than burgers and swanky Italian, head for this unassuming Armenian restaurant (the only Armenian place we know of in town). Sink into a booth in one of the room's dim and romantic corners, and recharge with cheesy, flaky spinach-stuffed phyllo triangles (called boereg); juicy, flavorful kebabs; and bowls of spinach flavored with sweet onion and lemon. The lone server can make the experience infuriatingly slow, but that's nothing the mahalabeya—a creamy milk pudding topped with walnuts and lemon syrup—can't make you forget.

You'll be lured in by the bright vintage sign, the novelty of eating in the Fine Arts Building and the cute art-school servers. Inside, you'll find a diner as old-school as Doug E. Fresh: chrome counters, tattered booths, a bakery case full of pie. But the point here is to take advantage of the sidewalk dining, to sit on this quintessential Chicago strip and order a no-frills breakfast of eggs and bacon or a generous grilled cheese on thick multigrain with hot, Parmesan-sprinkled chips. Avoid the lean burgers and skip the trucked-in desserts: Boulevard Treats, run by twin sisters who've been at it for more than 30 years, is two doors down.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams

column7: A good French bistro never gets old—even when it gets up in years. This lively and charming standby celebrates its 16th birthday this month, yet it still packs in customers every night, sending them off happier and fatter than they were when they arrived. The new fall menu, which went into effect last week, includes irresistibles like navarin d'agneau printanier (a hearty lamb stew), oven-roasted pork tenderloin with apple-Calvados sauce and grilled housemade lamb sausages served with potato salad and lemon confit, proving that this place may be getting older, but it isn't losing its touch.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 36, 66

column7: The dramatic two-story steel-and-mahogany entryway is the first hint you're in for something big at this contemporary American hot spot. With the exception of the cocktail waitresses' skirts, everything here is huge. A virtual mountain of calamari is served Asian-style with a light hoisin–serrano chili coating, and a tender lavender-and-honey–glazed pork chop is four inches thick, yet perfectly cooked. With desserts like the triple-chocolate cake—served in two ginormous wedges with housemade raspberry sauce and a petite dollop of whip cream—it's easy to see why doggy bags here are full-size shopping bags. We needed two.

column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: So you're interested in trying Thai food, but you're spice-phobic or are downtown hitting tourist spots. Relax, newbie, and let the servers at this family-friendly spot guide you through the extensive menu. When the Rocket Roll appetizer—a crunchy, cigar-shaped, shrimp and pork spring roll—is delivered to your table, you're instructed to wrap lettuce leaves around it and dip it in garlic sauce. And when you get your flavorful pad thai, your server explains that squeezing lime over the noodles brings out its flavors. Order the panang curry noodles, and you'll be warned it's "medium spicy," but when you dig in to the giant dish of rich, creamy curry and wide rice noodles, your palate will register only a hint of heat. Think of this as a safe training ground before you move on to more adventurous lessons in Thai cuisine.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendlyPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barGood for groups

column7: Every Korean barbecue joint basically has the same menu. It's the quality of the meat, the marinades and the accompanying side dishes (banchan) that distinguish one from another. This mainstay nails all three. Strips of tender meat taken from beef short ribs (kalbi) get a sweetish garlic-soy-sesame oil marinade, while slices of pork (bulgogi) are saturated with a similar, but spicier, mixture. While your meat sizzles away on the charcoal grill inset in your table, sample your way through banchan like pickled turnips, kimchi, eggy potato salad and tofu skin with green chile. Once the beef and pork are nice and charred, wrap them in a lettuce leaf and add a dollop of peanut sauce. With a big bottle of Korean beer (OB or Hite) and a couple of friends, it's a perfect DIY dining experience.

Give a Middle Eastern chef a pizza oven and he comes up with laham ajeen—a crispy, paper-thin, pizzalike starter topped with parsley-kicked, finely ground beef; tomatoes; onions; and peppers. The oven was left when the previous tenants went out of business, a fate the new owners will surely avoid because of their lentil soup alone. The fresh-flavor train keeps rolling with the entrées: The juicy marinated chicken kebabs, kifta kebabs, beef shawarma and charbroiled catfish stand out. Each comes with a veggie soup–like stew that's meant to be spooned over the fluffy white rice for added oomph. Add a side of jajeek (minty cucumber-yogurt salad) to complete the meal. And though the baklava is tempting, we head to the grocer next door for a pint of hard-to-find Mashti Malone rosewater ice cream.

As part of the Inspiration Corporation's 13-week program (the same group that runs Inspiration Café), refugees and the recently homeless shadow paid pros at this full-service, contemporary American restaurant. They'll be gaining experience and a city-issued food service and sanitation certificate, working toward a fresh start on life. Baked goods and coffee kick-start your day; brunch brings omelettes and more; lunch features global belly-fillers like curried-chicken–salad sandwiches; and the dinner crowd gets classics like chicken roulade with wild rice.

This new sushi spot took decorating tips from the Mad Hatter and color cues from a Life Savers roll in here, warping them into an LSD-influenced underwater scene. Somehow, the decor, along with equally wild takes on artistic maki rolls, works. In addition to eye-crossingly delicious nigiri, try the Ocean Drive, a refreshing roll of tuna, yellowtail, avocado, green peppers, spicy mayo and cilantro wrapped in cod sheet. Also excellent is the Dragon Festival, an amalgam of flavors and textures like soft-shell crab, cucumber, avocado, eel and tobiko. With chili oil, eel sauce, lime juice or creamy wasabi dotting the creations, soy sauce likely will (and should) go unused.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: This upscale Italian option in the Marriott offers antipasti like little neck clams; a salad of heirloom tomatoes, mozzarella, bocconcini, fresh basil and sea salt; and a selection of steaks and chops. The standard breakfast buffet, offered seven days a week along with the a la carte menu, features made-to-order eggs, waffles, pancakes and a selection of breakfast sausage.

You'd be hard-pressed to find a living person who remembers Gertie's early days—its original location at 55th and California started serving ice cream in 1901. Lindy's launched its famed chili biz in 1924, and in the mid-'70s, a local entrepreneur purchased both businesses and put them under one roof. The chili is supposedly still made from the original recipe, and it's a tasty one at that. But in the summer, we go for ice cream, which is about as creamy as it gets this side of gelato. Superrich milk shakes and malts are perfect for sipping while reading the framed newspaper clippings from Gertie's golden oldie days.

Sarah Levy had to close her popular candy store/bakery at 11 East Oak Street to make way for a bigger, better Barneys. But she hasn't moved far: She recently re-opened at 70 East Oak Street, where there's more room for her crunchy clusters of chocolate and nuts and her decadent baked goods like chocolate-raspberry brioche. She's taken the opportunity to expand her menu to include pressed sandwiches, such as a grilled cheese with truffle oil, and to expand her gelato selection, which now offers flavors such as fresh blueberry. We'd scream at her for making our bodies decidedly not swimsuit-ready, but, alas, when we're here, our mouths are always full.

This is one of our favorites for feeding our need for every type of corn creation under the sun. The banana leaf–steamed tamale is delicious, with a feather-light exterior of incredibly smooth masa hiding tender shredded chicken kicked up with green chiles, and the empanadas are the lightest and flakiest in town. The sopes (lightly griddled, dense corn patties) can be topped with everything from pastor (roasted pork) to huitlacoche ('shroomlike corn fungus) to spinach. Skip dessert and finish with a "bull"—a blend of rum, lime juice and beer with a tart tamarind flavor.

column8: Private party room(s)FireplaceCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: This Wicker Park outpost from the Francesca's chain packs in the hungry and hip for small plates of simple Italian fare for dinner, but it seems few people know it also serves brunch. The steak sandwitch goes above standard with herb butter on roasted onion bread, plus a handful of pecorino and truffle oil–laced fries, while the signature Traviata pizza comes stuffed with herbed robiola cheese, mixed greens and sea salt. And while we're not sure why it's called "panettone" French toast, since the Italian cakelike bread isn't used, it's a good dish nonetheless, topped with sweet mascarpone cream, fresh berries and thick, aged balsamic vinegar.
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendly

column7: Skip the Chinese side of the menu and dive into Vietnamese specialties like young papaya salad with pork, shrimp and a bright nuoc cham dressing. The famous fish sauce-chili-lime-garlic-ginger blend also makes an appearance on various bun or rice-noodle plates, including peanutty, grilled, lemongrass beef. Banh xeo (often called "happy pancake") is extracrispy here, and should be wrapped in the lettuce leaves and herbs that are served alongside. The lazy Susan–topped tables are perfect for spinning around a hot pot, whose simmering broth may contain anything from shrimp to vegetables to a whole eel, depending on your mood.

column8: Good for dining at barLate-night diningFireplace

column7: Because it sports a façade that blends right in with its busy comic-store neighbor, this place can be easy to miss. So keep your eyes open—we've discovered that within the serene pink-striped walls is some of the most delicious café fare around, all made with a heavy Bosnian hand. Start with the tongue-wagging tuna sandwich and the four-dollar house salad that's a meal in itself. Or make like the Bosnian construction workers do on their lunch break and chow down on the made-from-scratch chevapi, something like an Eastern Euro cross between sausage and hamburger. All of the sandwiches are plunked down on fat rounds of crumpetlike bread made daily in the family-run kitchen.

When talk of cholesterol and arthritis meds tops the conversational buzz inside a restaurant, it's a pretty good indication the menu is tailored to the AARP set. The steakhouse-style lineup includes prime rib, Dover sole almondine and calves liver—exactly what you'd imagine being served in the themed, but still elegant, dining rooms (the Garden Room, the Tack Room). Lobster Bently, a house specialty of breaded lobster swimming in garlic butter, should be a menu no-no for the impact it could have in thinning out the clientele. The real draw of this sprawling restaurant is the beer garden, a spacious outside spot where locals convene over steak sandwiches and burgers and play cornhole (a.k.a. beanbag toss).
column144: El: Orange to Midway. Bus: Pace 390

column7: With a mantra like "corporate coffee tastes funny," the boys behind Hyde Park's Istria better be prepared to resist expansion. That may be difficult: People are bound to respond to roasted-to-order coffee, fresh panini and the dozen varieties of housemade gelato. They're the antithesis to Starbucks now, but with a second location at the Hyde Park Art Center, better get it while it's still indie.

This is the sort of chipper, happy-go-lucky place that positively drips with good vibes. Start with a cup of meat-free chili and any of the oversized sandwiches—the BLT with sun-dried tomato mayo and the grilled veggie panini rock, and the house favorite is a tuna powerhouse aptly dubbed "The Cat's Meow." The little ones buzzing through with Mom can't seem to get their fill of baked goods lining the glass display case. Come to think of it, neither can the studious types digging into the free magazines in the corner.
column144: El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77

column7: Goths, mall punks and the Halsted St crowd have a monopoly on the booths at this diner's Belmont Ave location, but this older, brighter location, where '50s decor meets an '80s soundtrack, belongs to stressed out DePaul students, hungry cops and a sprinkling of staff from the nearby Children's Memorial Hospital. Burgers, burritos, sandwiches and salads are available, but the fluffy omelets and even fluffier pancakes are what really make this gem shine.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: Soda bread? Black-and-white pudding? Not so much. This Irish bistro serves food you'd find in modern-day Dublin, which means Guinness isn't just on the epic beer list, but also in a rich onion–and–white cheddar soup. Bangers and mash are up for grabs in the form of savory lamb sausage and potatoes—the fingerlings are roasted with Morbier cheese and apples and served next to the sausage on a fragrant cedar plank. If a full meal isn't in the cards, stop by for a great Irish whiskey at the gorgeous bar.
column8: Good for dining at barFireplaceOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)

column7: The portions are generous, the room is comfortable and the food is reliable. This, plus the place's ability to glide from family-friendly pasta joint to romantic trattoria as the night progresses, is what packs 'em in every night. Good bets are crispy calamari, quattro stagioni pizza, rosemary-laced roasted chicken and housemade sorbetti. The food isn't going to conjure any memories of travels to Italy, but in Little Italy's gradually less-Italian landscape, this is a safe venture.

The people behind Basil Leaf Cafe are getting in the gourmet-to-go game with a ten-table cafe where the focus is the well-stocked deli cases. Mix and match from a dozen salads (like shredded chicken couscous or roasted beets with yogurt) and just as many heat-at-home main courses (think chanterelle-sage-apple-stuffed Cornish hen). Three dozen cheeses and a smallish, but eclectic, wine and beer selection round out the options.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 74

column7: You'll often find members of the local Indo-Pak community sitting on the ornately carved, brightly colored wooden furniture, discussing what appear to be important matters. We think they're chatting about how incredibly good the food is. Don't-miss dishes include yellow lentils rife with roasted garlic; silky smooth lemon-kissed rapini (commonly known as Italian broccoli); fiery chunks of chile chicken; and delicious, tender goat chops (which the menu calls "champs"). Quell the heat with the amazing Chopal lassi, and refrain from bringing wine or beer out of respect for the devout Muslim staff and diners unless you do it incognito towards the back of the house.

Traditionally, Ethiopian food is eaten with your hands, so if that's what scares off potential diners from this 20-year-old enclave, we urge you to wash up and get over it. Break off pieces of flat, spongy injera bread to scoop up the succulent morsels of wat (the spicy, tender, boneless lamb stands out among the choices) and alitcha (stewed cabbage and flavor-layered lentils are favorites). Those with a sweet tooth will enjoy the honey wine and shouldn't skip the house dessert, a delicious sweet-and-sour cream topped with tart raspberries and honey.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: You'll think Sbarro. You'll think corporate cafeteria. But if you look past the Kraft parmesan on the tables you'll find that this West Loop lunch spot can put out some solid, made-to-order Italian food. Bruschetta is sharp with red onions and garlic, and eggplant parmigiana—served as a portion as big as your head—is smothered in a a hearty red sauce. The pasta primavera (choose your favorite pasta shape) is flavorful but as soupy as minestrone. Skip it and save room for the housemade Italian cheesecake and tiramasu (but ask them to hold off on the cheap chocolate syrup).
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Scene reigns supreme at this venture from Rob Katz and Kevin Boehm, owners of the steps-away BOKA, so settle into a comfy booth and take it in while perusing a menu rich with seasonal standouts. Where to start? A garlic soup with rhubarb compote and chive blossoms is as good a place as any. Or a summery lobster club sandwich with bacon and baby greens. Or artichoke risotto with hearts of palm and a Parmesan cracker, accented with preserved lemon and mint vinaigrette. There's not a bad place to start, really, but make sure to save room to bookend the meal with stellar cocktails and Elizabeth Dahl's delicious, nostalgic desserts.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Good for groupsVegetarian-friendly

column7: Chef Brian Jupiter has come up with a menu of upscale bar snacks for his heavily sequined clientele of celebrities, celebrity wanna-bes and celebrity stalkers. His beef tenderloin skewers could be something out of a T.G.I. Friday's kitchen if they weren't so tenderly prepared. His thin-crust buffalo-chicken pizza, while tasty, can't escape that stigma. But Jupiter's game is elevated with his "tuna two ways": tangy tartare and a seared filet on a bed of risotto sweetened with corn and lobster. Yet no matter how good the food is or how many movie stars roll up, the cocktails will never be worth the asking price of $14.

Matsumoto has reconcepted into what is now a sushi and hot-pot restaurant. Sushi is supremely fresh, but don't stop there: The more social, and fun, option is either the shabu-shabu or sukiyaki. Both are self-cooked, one-pot meals of either sirloin or Wagyu beef and a heaping array of tofu and veggies, including onions, cabbage, mushrooms, chrysanthemum leaves and leeks. But while the meat is simmered in seaweed broth for shabu-shabu, it's seared in melted pork fat for sukiyaki before a sugary mirin-soy broth is added. (We prefer the more savory shabu-shabu to the supersweet sukiyaki.) Both come as the main event of a four-course meal that includes quick-pickled mountain veggies, sashimi and a fruity Jell-O-ish finale.

One of three dozen restaurants in the Hawaii-born Roy's empire, this spot boasts a seafood-heavy menu that offers both classic dishes you could find at any location and original creations from the executive chef Kevin Dusinski. Hawaiian swordfish (shutome), snapper and butterfish are among the main-event picks, and they're nearly always cooked well, but it's the butter-based sauces and gluttonous sides like Chinese sausage fried rice that provide the can't-stop-eating-it appeal. Don't pass up the lobster ravioli starter or the simple yet tasty chocolate soufflé.

If the name alone doesn't tip you off, seafood's the name of the game at this modest, banquet hall–like Chinese staple. So start off right with crispy salt-and-pepper calamari dotted with crunchy onion and jalapeño bits, or opt for the land portion of the menu with crispy chicken—a half or whole bird with golden, crackly skin and fresh lemon and spiced salt to add simple zing. The huge menu spans from kung pao chicken and pineapple fried rice to shark-fin soup and stir-fried abalone with sea cucumbers.

Chicago-style pizza joints are a dime a dozen, but New York–inspired takes are harder to come by. Grab a booth in the dim, casual, somewhat shabby room (it's not bad, but the place does much more take-out biz) and dig into the flavorful meatballs, tangy tomato sauce and toasted bread that make for one great meatball sandwich. Basic but fresh ingredients are turned into a handful of pastas, like angel-hair with shrimp and spinach ravioli in tomato cream. But pizzas rule the roost—the thick-crusted, square-cut pan is a good base for hearty toppings like Italian sausage, but we prefer the thin crust for delicate classics like spinach, tomato and garlic.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76

column7: This place had us at the premeal hand towels: aspirinlike tablets that grow into towelettes when servers pour hot water over them. But this pint-size sushi spot offers more than just gimmicks. Sushi man Mitch prides himself on serving oversize pieces of nigiri (he says that's how he was taught, and he's not changing) and creative rolls (we particularly like the Crazy Horse combo of tuna, salmon, yellowtail and avocado topped with tobiko). Nonsushi eaters can opt for traditional Japanese dishes (teriyakis, tempura, udon) or try house specials such as linguine with veggies, prawns and soy-ginger sauce. The owners' Korean heritage shows up in the flavorful bulgogi (thin slices of marinated beef with a sweet soy sauce) and veg-heads get their pick of nine fish-free maki.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151

column7: This bright, roomy space offers ample seating to indulge a rich chorizo torta piled with Oaxacan cheese and avocado and a mixed greens provinciana salad with pepitas and roasted corn. Don't forget co-owner and chef Laura Cid-Perea's signature pastries: Sampling from several varieties of her incredible tres leches cake is the perfect way to end a meal.
column144: El: Blue to Medical Center. Bus: 9, X9, 20, X20, 126

column7: We've had bowls of soup smaller than the margaritas at this upscale Pilsen option, but that's not a complaint. The bilevel space is lively and colorful (we particularly love the James Dean painting on the wall), the service is attentive and friendly, and the Mexican menu updates classic dishes with delicious success. We'll be back for the mild pan-fried tilapia flanked by delicious roasted zucchini and the flank steak paired with three enormous grilled shrimp in bright white wine sauce.

Do the young Greeks who pack this trendy, clubby restaurant know something you don't? Yes. And they probably want to keep this place to themselves. But we have to crash on nights when we want Greek munchies like the Florina peppers (two roasted red peppers stuffed with creamy feta), loukanika (a pork-lamb sausage), "toasts" (essentially panini) and huge gyro platters. If you can stop yourself from talking by shoveling in the food, nobody will know you don't belong.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Late-night diningOutdoor seating

column7: If we were restaurant psychologists, we'd diagnose this place as being bipolar. The front room is a boisterous bar with Big Country on repeat; the dining room is a serene, candlelit venue for local cabaret acts. But whichever vibe you prefer, the menu is the same: Sweet, meaty crab legs are a standout from the raw bar, chunky crab cakes are topped with a sharp chive mayo, and juicy salmon filets are flanked by perfectly grilled shrimp. Of the Middle Eastern dishes, the Egyptian chicken is so juicy and flavorful you won't be surprised that it's been marinating in yogurt all day.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningPrivate party room(s)

column7: You can't check out the action in this Korean-barbecue spot before you take the plunge—the windows are covered. But if you stand at the door and smell the intoxicating aromas of soy sauce, sugar, rice vinegar and garlic, you'll know this place is going to be good. Try to talk the server into letting you cook your own sliced beef (as is customary at Korean-barbecue restaurants) because the salty-sweet marinated meats (from beef tenderloin to octopus) we cooked tableside were more tender than the kitchen's version. Of the giant wave of little side dishes that accompany the barbecue, don't pass up the moist fish cake, perfect with a bottle of Korean beer.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 78, 80, X80

column7: The solemn Thai ladies here churn out reliable regular menu items, but for authentic heat, we order from the "Thai menu." Tofu is sculpted into hearty fried sheets and then stuffed with even more firm tofu for a remarkable impersonation of meat. Lime-based soups open up the palate for entrées like preserved egg with basil and curried roasted duck (an excellent balance of richness and slight spice). Service can be stern, but for a blast of Bangkok in the Western Suburbs, this is your best bet.
column144: El: Green, Blue to Harlem. Bus: 301, 303, 310, 393

column7: Take note: When this Gibsons offshoot calls itself "Lux," it means it in an old-school way. Both the food and space seem to be imported from a simpler era, with dishes like luscious filet mignon "sliders" and impossibly crispy, impeccably juicy fried chicken presented without fanfare. Sometimes the straightforward approach can backfire (like with the bland turkey burger) but for the most part this spot's a gem. Especially for those who appreciate well-made cocktails and solid food to make you nostalgic for "simpler times"—even if you never experienced them the first time around.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: With a lot to look at—primary colors, a koi-stocked fountain, plasma screen—it's tough to focus on the menu at this sushi spot on Division's Restaurant Row. But when you do, you'll find all of the usual suspects, plus upgrades like medium fatty and fatty tuna, sea urchin and Spanish mackerel. The chef plans on adding to the cooked menu (which now includes tempura and teriyaki) once it's up and running full speed.
column184: NOW NAMED AKI SUSHIChanged name 8/4/007 jst

column7: For almost two decades, this simple dining room has been the safe bet for Americanized favorites like chop suey and egg foo young. But take a cue from the smiling fish on the menu: Seafood's the real draw.
