Sea creatures from shrimp to lobster are fresh, especially the fish-of-the-day (large-mouth bass, recently); ask for it steamed whole with ginger and onion. The lobster's affordable ($33.95) and can be prepped seven different ways. Spicy salt-and-pepper prawns are huge, lightly battered and crispy, and go great with an order of the garlicky young pea shoots listed on the specials menu.

The Caribbean couple who owns this joint spawned loyalists with its take-out spot in Gresham before opening this VFW hall–like space with apparent ambition for big numbers (three dozen tables wait for patrons). Get the fiercely spicy jerk chicken with perfect kick and pink flesh from hours of low smoking; deliciously oily king fish prepared escovitch-style with vinegary pickled peppers; and perfectly tender and meaty goat swimming in brown curry rich with allspice, garlic and Scotch bonnet.

The Moroccan-themed, Suhail-designed space that was deemed the date destination upon opening in '99 is still warm, cozy and lush—in other words, exactly how you'll feel after downing one of the obscenely potent cocktails. This summer Tizi Melloul turns ten and they're celebrating with a new $35 five course tasting featuring fire-roasted Prince Edward Island mussels and lamb tagine. Start the night with a cooling cocktail, like a cucumber martini or vanilla-infused housemade lemonade.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: Thailand native Apidech Chotsuwan used to own Bangkok Thai in Boystown, but after a mind-blowing trip to Japan, he sold his stake in the spot to ready this half-Thai, half-Japanese restaurant named after his boyhood obsession. Chotsuwan trained the Thai chef to handle standards from noodles to curries, while he mans the sushi bar, serving up nigiri and maki for the budget-conscious, as well as teriyaki and katsu for fans of cooked Japanese fare. Pulling double duty as interior decorator, Chotsuwan decked out the space that formerly housed Saussy in an orange-and-black color scheme. (They are his favorite butterfly hues, not an homage to Halloween.)
column144: El: Blue to Grand. Bus: 8, 9, X9, 65

column7: The stretch of Halsted Street that lays claim to this classy tavern is packed with upscale eateries and the buttoned-up crowd dining at them. More gastro pub than sports bar, this spot keeps that scene grounded. Grab one of the tables that surround the beautiful, dark-wood bar and start with a Black Duck martini and plate of scallops wrapped in salty bacon. Move on to the New York strip seasoned simply with salt, pepper and rosemary. It's not Alinea, BOKA or Landmark. But then again, it's not supposed to be.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seating

column7: Truly good lunch spots are as rare as Burger Kings are abundant, which is why it's worth a trek to this gallery-district lunch counter no matter where you work. The Pyrenees sandwich takes the eponymous cheese and pairs it with tabouli, tomato and lettuce for a creative, light lunch. Likewise, the chicken sandwich goes Mexican with creamy avocado and a hint of hot sauce. Daily soups, such as mushroom barley, are fresh, light and simple, and a glass case in the front of the store is stocked with freshly-baked quickbreads and cakes. Slices are big enough to feed two, but you can keep it for yourself and finish it for breakfast.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156

column7: The authentic Northern Italian eats at this tony Gold Coast mainstay are luscious enough to make you forget their over-inflated price tags. But if you can swing it, go all the way, dahling. Order up a bottle of Barolo and buttery risotto sprinkled with slices of black truffles. Follow up with organic chicken stuffed with spinach, mozzarella and wild mushrooms. Dessert shifts gears by heading for France, with bombes and financiers as dolled up as most of the patrons.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: First it opened as Room 12, but the wise owners behind this brunch-lunch spot decided to reopen as Bongo Room to remind people of their affiliation with the Wicker Park brunch icon. A diverse clientele of South Loop locals mingle over the same menu of candy-sweet lemon-blueberry pancakes and creamy rock shrimp–and–avocado breakfast burritos. Only they get to do it in a cheery, sunlight-filled room where a table can be scored within a comparatively quick ten to twenty minutes.
column144: El: Red, Green, Orange to Roosevelt. Bus: 12, 29, 62

column7: When a restaurant this size is this busy (it seats 400, but an hour wait is typical), it must be making somebody happy. Jerry Kleiner's colorful—if slightly dated—design can make a person smile, and the mojitos and margaritas don't hurt, either. On the pan-Latin menu you'll find all sorts of variations on traditional fare, like oxtail pupusas and mini whitefish tacos. Some of them, like the juicy ropa vieja, raise this restaurant's bar, but it's the crowd here that entertains the most, so chew your food with your mouth closed but your eyes open.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for groupsOutdoor seatingLate-night diningGood for dining at barKid-friendly

column7: This Nuevo Latino hot spot has the looks of a lounge but it isn't all show. After chef Bryan Garcia left last year, sous chef Edie Jimenez (formerly of Red Light and China Grill) took the reins. Menu standouts like the seafood cocktail, crispy flautas stuffed with agave-roasted beef and the beer-braised short rib remain, but it's in the weekly specials—like a snow crab bisque that gets a kick with Mexican chiles—where Jimenez breathes new life into relatively ho-hum dishes.
column8: Outdoor seatingLate-night diningVegetarian-friendlyPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barGood for groups

column7: This restaurant is now closed.When this sleek little sushi den first opened its doors a few years back, it was the talk of the town for serving live fish, or "fresh-kill," that some claimed would arrive to the table still twitching. Now that the novelty has worn off, the focus has shifted to an omakase, or chef's choice, format with menus ranging from $35 to $100. The $35 (ten nigiri, two maki mono, soup or salad, dessert) and the $60 (ditto, plus premium fish cuts, soup and salad and a cooked entrée) are the best values. The fish is amazingly fresh, ranking among the best in town; the housemade soy and fruit-based sauces are delicious; and hand rolls like the spicy tuna blow away the competition. Buyer beware: Value doesn't translate to the limited wine and sake list, so if you've got a bottle at home, eat the $20 corkage fee and bring it.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine list
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 70, 72

column7: Located on a strip of Broadway known for its Vietnamese spots, the cuisine shifts to Thai at this simple, bright storefront. Anglo favorites abound, but the gems of the menu are the authentic eats. Start with yum woonsen, a spicy glass-noodle salad with tiny bites of fresh shrimp and ground chicken, and namtok, a pork salad with bright flavors of cilantro, red onion, peanuts and roasted rice powder. For more tangy-spicy-salty, go for the name klug, deep-fried rice with bits of ham, pork fat, peanuts, chiles and plenty of lime. Sweet sticky rice with mango or chilled lychee are perfect simple endings.

The "wow" factor at this take-out joint dedicated to bao (steamed Asian dumplings) could be anything: It could be the fluffy bao stuffed with sweet, dark-red barbecue pork, spicy Mongolian beef or Thai curry chicken. It could be the kung pao rice bowls laced with crunchy cashews, or maybe the pomegranate ginger ale spiked with sharp slivers of fresh ginger. But it's probably the mere fact that you're eating so well at a fast-food restaurant in a mall.
column92: Water Tower Place, 835 N Michigan Ave
column198: Other locations: 175 W Jackson Blvd (312-334-6395); 1 W Wacker Blvd (312-658-0305)

column7: The deep-red walls and friendly service make this charming Ravenswood spot as warm and comforting as the food. And because it's BYOB, it's hard to beat the value. Bring a bottle of Sangiovese to match with the soft grilled polenta topped with the chunky house ragù. The housemade tricolored rotolo is our favorite of the pastas, stuffed with ricotta and spinach, then baked to hot, hearty perfection. Specials like chicken parmigiana baked in a cream-based red sauce are winners—but so are most of the dishes on the menu, so order with confidence.

The theory goes like this: The first time you eat at this unassuming Greek spot, you may try the gyro salad—well-spiced slices of meat sitting atop simple greens—and you'll think: "Not bad." Next time, you'll scan the affordable, limited menu, try the creamy taramasalata on warm rounds of pita, and say to yourself: "Pretty good." But according to the cultish customer base that swears by this place, it's on your third visit—when you order the juicy chicken kebabs, the vinegary Greek fries or the flaky spanakopita—that the spell is cast and you become one of them.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 22, 74

column7: This sunny, clean-as-a-whistle catfish 'n' barbecue hut houses some tasty soul food. The cornmeal-crusted filet of catfish and butterflied shrimp are heart-stoppers but worth the risk, and the messy "mini" rib tips are twice the size of any we've seen elsewhere. Soulful sides are mandatory: gooey mac and cheese, fried okra, slow-simmered greens and the creamy banana pudding finale. Rounding out the menu are burgers, but if you go late, most of the food has already been snatched up, and pickings are slim.
column144: El: Green to California. Bus: 20, X20, 52, 94

column7: It's not typical for us to get down with fast-food. But according to everyone who's eaten this "crazy chicken," there's nothing typical about El Pollo Loco. The chain that hatched in Mexico 30 years ago is famous for its birds, which are marinated in a secret blend of citrus, spices and herbs and then grilled over an open flame. As at the California locations, the Logan Square outlet will include sides like pinto beans and a salsa bar packed with avocado salsa and pico de gallo. So will the food make you go crazy? No. But after you try it, the cravings might.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 82

column7: If you're still living at your mama's house for her home-cooked meals, then this tiny family-run Polish hideaway is for you. Navigate your way through gargantuan dishes of crispy fried potato pancakes, soft potato dumplings with earthy mushroom gravy and stuffed pierogi, all of which are made more incredible when slathered with sour cream. (What isn't?) Pork and veal dishes rule the dinner menu, but don't miss the shaved beet salad or dense crêpes filled with sweet cheese and topped with powdered sugar. Plus, with the TV blaring and family feuds roaring in the kitchen, you'll feel right at home sipping drinks from colorful plastic kiddie cups.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 49, X49, 66, 70

column7: Roscoe Village's indie coffee shop has spawned a Logan Square location. Expect the same coffee, sandwiches and kitsch as the original, plus extra room for live music. There's also a room in the basement that can be reserved by any club to host meetings, so don't be surprised if you see some caffeine-high superknitters going all ballistic with their yarn.

You know the place is authentic when Japanese old-timers shuffle through the door like they're simply coming home. We've become best friends with the thicker-than-usual miso soup and the lightly fried potato croquettes. We also love the giant shrimp tempura, the flavorful goma ae and the sweet unagi (eel) rice bowl. If you go the route of the healthy elderly women, that means filling up on chicken teri don, a lovely platter of slivered teriyaki-style chicken served over lettuce and rice. But what this home-style cafeteria is known for are piping hot udon bowls, the thick flour noodles edging out bits of meat and fresh-chopped vegetables.

Head for this home-style cucina in the Heart of Italy for feather-light, spinach-stuffed gnocchi in cream sauce; juicy chicken à la tippi (pounded breasts fried in a Parmesan, egg and basil batter, then smothered with a tart lemon butter sauce); and whitefish Vesuvio. The small waitstaff seems frantic (this place gets packed early), but it still manages to coerce the crowd into entire-room birthday sing-alongs. Save room for the freshly made tiramisu—it's a legend in its own right.

They say practice makes perfect, and the pitch-perfect bistro dishes here show years of rehearsal. The Epcot Center feel of some other Lettuce Entertain You restaurants is missing. Instead you get a cozy and bustling bistro serving everything from steamed mussels in a white ale broth to a megacaramelized apple tart tatin. Nightly plats du jour like duck à l'orange and steak tartare are as consistently delicious as menu stalwarts such as seared skate wing in lemony caper butter and the awesome steak frites.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 134, 143, 151, 156

column7: The Puerto Rican family that runs this comfortable, mustard-colored restaurant may assume that gringos wandering in are looking for Mexican food (and they will cook it for you), but the authentic Puerto Rican specialties are the way to go. The belly-busting guachitos, is a delicious off-menu request that combines fried plantain with salchicon (salami-like sausage) and fresh guacamole. The mofongo (mashed, fried plantain) is easily as good as what we've had on the island. If more exotic dishes, like braised baby goat sound too risky, then the tender carne guisada (beef stew) is an easier route with just as tasty results.
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 49, X49, 74

column7: Marshall Fields-turned-Macy's has brought celeb chef Rick Bayless into the fold with this foodcourt counter offering tortas, huaraches, quesadillas, tamales, salad and soup, but with fillings that counter most fast-food notions. Smoked pork loin and applewood bacon top the torta Cubana, Amy's All-Natural Chicken Chorizo shows up in a quesadilla, and steak joins garlicky mushrooms and chipotle sauce for an earthy huarache. And at $7 for a creative Loop lunch, don't be surprised if lines will probably rival Frontera's weekend queues.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 3, 4, X4, 14, 20, 26, 60, 145, 147, 148, 151

column7: Say the name of this chicken joint to a Guatemalan, and he'll light up like an American who finds McDonald's french fries in Siberia. Established in Guatemala in '71, the KFC–like chain now has more than 200 restaurants around the world, each serving up "original recipe" and "extra crispy" fried chicken. Also on the menu are mashed potatoes with chicken gravy, fries, chicken burgers, sandwiches and salads. Latin flair shows up minimally, in menu items like horchata, flan and beans and rice. But it's the marinated-then-deep-fried chicken that's won the hearts of most of Latin America.
column92: Brickyard Shopping Center, 2730 N Narragansett Ave

column7: Levy Restaurants' latest contribution to Chicago's culinary scene is as much about the view as it is about the food. Fortunately, both are worth a visit. The menu—equal parts seafood and steakhouse—is nothing out of the ordinary, but everything is of exquisite quality. King crab legs from the extensive raw bar are impeccably fresh and sweet, filet mignon is perfectly tender, and a side dish of roasted butternut squash with pumpkin butter and goat cheese is so decadent you can skip dessert. Things can get pretty pricey, so to make sure this experience is worth the cash, ask the maître d' to give you a window seat.
column8: ViewsGood for groupsNotable wine listOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 125, 156

column7: The competition's stiff on Randolph Row's strip of global eats, but this sushi spot stands out for its classy-not-clubby vibe and creative concoctions. Skip traditional maki and go with the Dragon Fire, a roll that swaps yellowfin tuna for nori, wrapping the fish around crispy softshell crab and teriyaki-glazed eel. Another twisted take on rolls is the Jazz Spring, a crisp soybean sheet–encased combo of both super white and fatty tuna, freshwater eel, and a bright ohba (Japanese mint) leaf. Skip the $30 lobster tail from the entrée menu and go for a $4 grilled lobster skewer instead, and spend the extra dough on sashimi cuts like fatty yellowtail, bluefin tuna and sweet red snapper.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: When we tell you that this Korean spot is slick, sexy and seductive, we're referring to the servers, the space and even the food. Unlike most Korean barbecue houses, there's no tabletop grilling here, but the kitchen doesn't falter a bit. Opt for the delicious o jinga bokum, strips of squid imparted with the heat and flavor of chiles, or the kalbi, grilled slices of beef short rib that are sweet, salty and every bit as tasty as the vinegar-soaked daikon underneath.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyGood for dining at bar

column7: Work up an appetite before you arrive at this Ravenswood storefront; deciding between the Mexican and Ecuadorian specialties is almost impossible, so you'll probably end up choosing both. Make sure to try the Llampingachos, two savory potato pancakes paired with a peanut sauce and a fried egg (mix the runny yolk with the sauce for maximum creaminess); oversize spicy pork sopes; and rich and tender goat stew, cooked with beer and laced with the faintest trace of cumin.

You've probably passed up this place a million times, but the core group of regulars at this brick-and-wood–filled, tavernlike Italian joint have kept the place afloat for more than a decade. We can't vouch for the regular menu, but its brunch buffet is tough to beat. For $12 you can have your fill of fresh fruit, mixed greens, baked goods, all the porky breakfast standards plus delicious brown sugar–smoked ham (carved-to-order alongside roasted turkey and sometimes brisket), onion-flecked potato chunks, and chilaquiles. Don't miss the fluffy made-to-order omelettes, blueberry-studded pancakes and French toast.

Regressing back to childhood is a very good thing when you're doing it at this lively, lime-green café. Pastry chef Stephanie Samuels makes the kind of desserts you used to find in your lunch box: Ding Dongs, Thin Mints and superb cream-filled cupcakes. But like any good lunchbox assembler, she provides predessert nourishment with seasonal soups, poached-chicken sandwiches on soft, housemade wheat rolls, and a luscious Sunday brunch menu of powdered sugar–dusted squares of French toast with marmalade syrup and salmon cakes with tangy lemon aioli.
column8: Outdoor seatingKid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: After 24 years of churning out Italian food to Lincoln Park locals, this family-run restaurant has become a dependable spot for solid, simple food. Start with the vinegary tomato and move on to the signature "specialty pizza"—garlic, olive oil and tomato on thin or pan crust (we like the thin). The pizza may not look like much, but it packs a powerful punch of flavor. For a quicker bite, the hot, crusty Italian sub (packed with salami, capicolla and Fontinella) pairs perfectly with a cold glass of Peroni.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: There's no better place to cheer on your team than this down-home, blue-collar institution that's been serving up cold ones since 1881. Arrive at least a half hour before game time if you're plan to eat—and you should definitely plan to eat. Just-like-Mom-made classics include crispy pork tenderloin smothered in perfect pan gravy and greaseless fried chicken. Add doting servers, cheap beer and a living room–like atmosphere, and you've got the best sports experience short of front-row tickets.

This eight-year-old steakhouse still hasn't lost its sparkle—mirrored tiles, pro athletes, and a neon-glowing Champagne and caviar bar are as posh as the menu (created by founding chef Michael Shrader who recently took back the reigns). Lobster dots mashed potatoes, steaks (reputedly cooked at 1,200-degrees Fahrenheit) are prime, and catch-of-the-day dishes are well prepared and over-the-top. Ditto for excessive desserts like the pouf of cotton candy studded with candy and ice cream. And you don't have to head for the loungey Ghost Bar upstairs to spot celebs; each bathroom stall is fitted with a tiny TV.
column8: Good for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 14, 20, 56

column7: Pearls? Check. Bright pink lipstick? Check. Cup of coffee? Check. Cigarettes? Well, since the smoking ban, that's the one signature item that namesake owner Nelly is missing, and apparently, so are her Romanian regulars. The crowd has thinned since the ban, but you'll still spot occasional handsome expats chowing down on earthy cuisine: platters of mititei (grilled sausages); fried kraut with bits of bacon fat; heaping bowls of polenta with feta; and excellent soups.

Tucked in a South Side basement enclave is this tiny pupuseria, widely known for made-to-order pupusas (hand-pounded corn-meal pancakes stuffed with pork, zucchini, or cheese and frijoles). The three-table room is often full, but grab a stool at the little bar for a bird's-eye view of the lovely bandana-clad chicas in the open kitchen grilling up thick chubs of Salvadorian sausage and stirring pots brimming with sweet tamales. The wait is forever, but with simple sides like fried plantains, vinegary slaw and fried chunks of chicharrones (pork cracklings) to satiate, who's looking at the clock?

A blend of cozy bohemian hangout and hoppin' breakfast haunt, this spot's sun-splashed walls inspire all-day coffee sipping while leafing through the menu. Try the tasty frittatas (really just open-face omelettes) and the French toast, a gooey mayhem of three-inch-thick brioche slices stuffed with sweet cream, covered with fresh strawberries and bananas, and smothered in raspberry sauce. Lunch lightens the ingredient load, with perfectly crisp panini (the pesto caprese features homegrown tomatoes and freshly picked basil), made-from-scratch tuna and egg-salad sandwiches and a few huge salads.
column60: Tue–Fri 6:30am–3pm; Sat, Sun 7:30am–2:30pm (closed Mon). Brunch (Sat, Sun).

column7: Residents of this southern suburb (halfway between Homewood and Park Forest) skip the commute for big-city dining in favor of this inviting, decade-old global eatery. A few French favorites dot the menu (bouillabaisse, beef bourguignonne), but don't let the name fool you; the kitchen casts the net far and wide with good renditions of everything from shrimp jambalaya to veggie lasagna. Pick from the barlike atmosphere in the front room or the slightly more serene back area and put yourself in the hands of friendly servers as honest as the conversational menu. Ingredients are fresh, you can get anything made "your way," and the wine and beer selection are surprisingly good for a restaurant in a strip mall.

Loosely translated, vicinato is Italian for neighborhood, and though this corner tavern may not be in yours, it's worth a trip to eat good in the Heart of Italy. Expect big plates of traditional fare, including bianco nero ("white black"), a wide bowl of tasty mussels and clams in garlicky broth, and pillow-y potato gnocchi made in-house and topped with a meaty ragu. Service is understated but helpful, though try to sit in the paneled bar instead of the rather bright dining room—smoking is permitted there but adds atmosphere, as does the clientele. For dessert, share a dark chocolate ice cream tartufo the size of Tony Soprano's fist.
column144: El: Pink to Western. Bus: 21, 49, X49

column7: Wheeling's hottest destination restaurant isn't Le Francais; it's the cavernous rustic Italian restaurant from TRU vets Rick Tramonto and Gale Gand. Belinda Chang handles the wine list, which is packed with good finds and decent deals. The meat lasagna, inspired by Tramonto's mother's recipe, is housemade, and the freshly made cavatelli is tossed with crumbly lamb sausage, softened rapini and roasted garlic (a similar combo can be had on a tasty, cheesy, hand-tossed pizza). Fish and steak entrées are usually stellar, but we're on the fence about desserts; Gand's trademark touch is somehow lost in simple creations like tiramisu and profiteroles.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlySuburban

column7: Chef Heather Terhune's food draws mobs of tourists and local ladies seeking nourishment after a particularly grueling shopping session at Macy's. For them, her seasonal menu of updated American classics is perfect—sophisticated and unintimidating. Case in point: her winter menu, which offers thyme-and-mace–roasted duck breast with mashed sweet potatoes and a dried fig gastrique; oven-roasted acorn squash over date-and-pistachio studded couscous; and a warm apple-walnut dumpling served with vanilla bean ice cream.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington. Bus: 56, 60, 124, 157

column7: This sexy eatery was the first to brave Randolph Street, so we're not about to argue, especially when it comes to its rustic Italian food. Golden housemade gnocchi is doused in a creamy, earthy truffle sauce; tuna fillet is dressed up with a lively combo of balsamic and mint; and the café Vivo, a gelato-Frangelico milk shake, is sweet, smooth and utterly unshareable.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: The missus of this husband-and-wife team greets you warmly on your way in and happily walks you through her hubby's specialties. A former cook at the Palmer House Hilton and Heaven on Seven; he's capable of elevating typical taquería fare. Standouts include the caldo de pollo, a gargantuan serving of Mexican chicken soup served with rice and tortillas (perfect for a chilly night); the ceviche with citrus-spiked tilapia and shrimp; and cactus salad dotted with jicama, avocado and mango-chipotle dressing.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column7: Near the strip mall that's home to the popular Mexican spot Wholly Frijoles is this tasty, affordable Japanese joint, where waitresses dole out dishes faster than lightning. Start with crispy flounder triangles wrapped in seaweed with Japanese mint and a touch of plum paste, and the French maki, an addictive roll of shrimp tempura, red-leaf lettuce, rice and mayo. The seven-piece "Sushi B" platter is a steal considering the chefs cut sushi twice the size we're accustomed to. But no matter what the reviews on the walls claim, skip desserts; they're just plain weird.

This old-school, family-style Italian joint has been in the neighborhood for nearly 20 years now. It has kept residents coming back with a menu of dependable classics such as chicken Vesuvio and housemade lasagna served in a space that looks like a transported cocktail lounge from the '50s—making it a good late-night stop for signature martinis and Sinatra standards. Come back the next morning for its new Sunday brunch, featuring hearty egg dishes, local favorite Milk and Honey granola and a range of juicy cocktails.

Rogers Parkers craving everyday, affordable Asian opt for this adorable lavender-and-orange storefront. From the Thai portion of the menu, go with the crunchy spring roll and the panang curry packed with eye-watering heat. Of the Japanese options, the deep-fried spicy tuna roll is delicious, nigiri cuts are generous and fresh, and maki are tasty though standard. One exception: Sweet-potato maki, usually a bland concession to vegetarians, is pimped out with green onions, cream cheese and tempura crunch, and slathered in wasabi mayo and eel sauce. Not so authentic but, oh, the creamy goodness.
column144: El: Red to Loyola. Bus: 22, 36, 151, 155. Metra: Union Pacific North Line to Rogers Park

column7: The more sophisticated side of Rick Bayless is no less delicious than his lively Frontera Grill side—it's merely more exquisite. His attentiveness to local, seasonal ingredients shines through in dishes that pay homage to spring, like a grilled asparagus and lime-poached rhubarb salad with slow-cooked sunchokes, aged cheddar cream and microgreens, or pan-roasted Maine lobster with salt cod croquetas, pickled ramps and crispy chile threads. Two chef's tasting menus are on offer (one for $85, one for $90); add paired wines to either for $50.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 65, 156

column7: The dolsot bibimbap at this quiet, strip-mall Korean joint has garnered a cult following over the years. The steaming classic of egg, beef, veggies and rice is delicious (particularly the caramelized bits of rice at the bottom of the stone bowl), but don't ignore the other treats on hand. The bulgogi, grilled on your table over a bowl of hot coals, is sweet and garlicky and accompanied by paper-thin slices of vinegar-soaked daikon, a spicy yet cooling cucumber kimchi and an impossibly flavorful soup with tender cubes of tofu.

Determined to intertwine the eating and drinking experience, chef Stephen Dunne focuses on elevated bar food at this West Town spot. Some of his food (fried pickle spears, a Wagyu burger) act merely as sponges for the impressive beer list. But the duck confit is sublime, the fish-and-chips crisp and flavorful, and the crab salad light and inspired. The ultimate beer and food pairing, though, comes at dessert, with the addictive Black & Tan Float, a root-beer float made with Guinness ice cream.
column8: Good for dining at barLate-night dining

column7: There are only a couple of ways to explain the crowd that gathers around this bar drinking cocktails and beer (despite the fact that this is a wine bar): Either Oak Park has a lack of good bars or everyone's here for the food. It's probably the latter. A trio of hummus is spiked with herbaceous spinach and spicy red pepper. Pizzas' cracker-like crust is a vehicle for savory flavors of onion and feta. And earthy hay-smoked beef tenderloin is smoked (yes, over hay) in the yard by the chef himself and cooked until it's just juicy and pink beneath the crust.

If you haven't explored Little Village, this would be a good starting point. As at all good Mexican joints, the owner's regional heritage shows up in the food, and in this case, the inspiration is the state of Guerrero. This means you can expect a few exotic options, including bull's testicles, rattlesnake, wild boar and alligator. But for our money, we go with house specialties like fried smelts; thin, cured venison cecina; and tender baked goat served with chunky guac, warm housemade tortillas and an addictive, thick, smoky pasilla chile sauce. Everything from typical tacos to burritos can be had, but we can't vouch for those—you don't order salad at a steakhouse.

Rome it ain't, but this place can get so packed you'd think the pope was in the kitchen. It's been like this since 1985, and here's why: a carpaccio salad comes with thin slices of beef, arugula and shaved parmesan; soft morsels of veal sidled by sharp, garlicky, wilted spinach; and a rich wheel of tri-color pasta in sweet and nutty four-cheese sauce touched with nutmeg. Skip the store-bought berry tart in favor of housemade tiramisu and cheesecake—authentic touches amid the faux Roman-ruin decor.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72

column7: Shawn McClain may have been the face of this South Loop steak-centric spot, but executive chef Aaron Deal is about to take over handles the day-to-day executing like a pro. Lately, we've been smitten with Camarota's specials like rabbit two ways—the leg braised and served with English peas, fava beans and asparagus, and the white meat rolled in housemade bacon and baked into a potpie. The restaurant recently added weekend lunch, with a serious incentive to head to the South Loop: The popular burger—topped with caramelized onions, bacon and steak sauce—is now available for $5 from noon–4pm every Saturday and Sunday.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red to Harrison. Bus: 6, 29, 36

column7: You could easily make a meal of wine and cheese here, but you may have a hard time resisting going further. Especially in summer, when the sidewalk patio invites lingering over chef John Caputo's global small plates.Recent dishes include the Latin flavors of black bean, roasted red pepper and corn salsa served over arctic char; a pizza topped with spinach, goat cheese and Spanish chorizo; and a Mediterranean-inspired salad of chickpeas, artichokes and mozzarella in a lemon vinaigrette. No matter the season, gelato is always our preferred ending.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: You can get the same atmosphere—or lack thereof—at any of the taquerias that pepper this intersection of Ridge and Broadway. But you can't get this gem's fantastic housemade horchata redolent of cinnamon and nutmeg. You probably couldn't find a mole as complex, with its sweet, long finish. A carnitas taco anywhere else probably won't be as overstuffed or juicy. And you'd be hard-pressed to get such food at the same time—on the weekends, this place is open 24 hours.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136, 147, 151(24 hrs)

column7: Chef Michael Lachowicz made a name for himself at the legendary Le Francais and Les Deux Gros—such a name, in fact, that he christened his latest venture after himself. Though he's not reinventing the wheel here, the man can cook. Delectable classics abound: gooey cheese puffs, smoked salmon-topped potato pancake, an impossibly tender filet–and–short rib duo, and a rich hot chocolate–and–soufflé combo. Lachowicz proves that no matter whose name is on the door, the draw is what's on the plate.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific North to Hubbard Woods

column7: Jana Buchtova knows that Chicagoans are well-traveled people. So she opened a European-style deli to remind them of where they've been. She's likely to succeed: Her breads are imported, par-baked, from Europe, and she's using th em on her panini, including one that layers prosciutto, fresh mozzarella and an olive tapenade. If that doesn't do the trick, she has a whole line of imported meats and cheeses, and serves Italian coffee drinks using Lavazza beans.

After a fire at the original Khan sent fans of this smoky kebab house into fierce withdrawal, the owners set up shop in the former Jewel of India space. We're happy to report our favorites are just as tasty: the spicy, marinated, char-grilled chicken chunks (boti), the juicy sausage-shaped ground-beef patties (seekh kebab), and veggie dishes like creamy spinach with potato chunks (aloo palak) and cumin-laced stewed chickpeas (chana masala) are all as great (and cheap) as before. Service is slower at this larger space, but the trade-off is that the air isn't quite as thick with the charcoal smoke that ultimately destroyed the previous location.

This Puerto Rican café is essentially a full-on living room, with a blaring TV and shelves packed with tchotchkes. Elba, the owner and chef, makes do in her pint-size kitchen and plates up specialties like housemade blood sausage, plantain-encased pork tamales and fried codfish pancakes. Pick a cola out of the cooler and relax to the Puerto Rican pop-rock, just like the tables full of toe-tapping regulars do.

Tucked between the Swedish stalwarts and shiny new bistros and sushi houses in Andersonville is this red-sauce Italian spot, which has been serving up can't-go-wrong classics to the locals since 1963. A much-needed recent remodel modernized the dining room, but the menu remains solidly old-school, with dishes like crisp chicken parmigiana and shells stuffed to the hilt with fresh ricotta. Feeling fancy? Try the fluffy gnocchi filled with Gorgonzola and served under a blanket of tomato cream sauce.

A chain steakhouse inside a hotel isn't the first place that comes to mind to satisfy carnivorous cravings in this town. But if you've got a taste for old-fashioned indulgence, it would be a shame to overlook this spot that does wonders with monstrous cuts of USDA Prime, gargantuan lobsters and classic artery-clogging add-ons like creamed spinach and French-fried onions. Add a martini or two, and you'll be partying like it's 1959.
column8: Outdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State; Red to State/Lake. Bus: 4, X4, 29, 36, 60, 146, 151

column7: This four-year-old traditional French bistro takes its name from the famous author (although it's spelled with an extra m), whose birthplace is just up the street. Tucked into the 1920s-era Write Inn, this spot has little signage, making it difficult to find. But once you make your way in, the ambience is everything a hard-core Francophile could want: stucco walls, cozy banquettes, soft lighting, French music and even esoteric gastronomic quotes on the menu. Chef Christopher C. Ala's menu doesn't push the envelope. However, bistro staples like escargot, roasted sea bass, cassoulet and beef Wellington are well executed. A budget-friendly wine list includes several selections by the glass.
column144: Bus: Pace 311 to Ontario. Metra: Union Pacific W to Oak Park

column7: Amid the construction dust that's lifting from the nearly complete University Village neighborhood is this casual Japanese spot, where the service is warm and welcoming enough to fool diners into believing it's an old favorite. Half of the menu is dedicated to teppan (Benihana-style open grill), and the teriyaki-glazed shrimp, steak and veggies are tasty enough, but the sushi offerings impress more. Stick with the specials board for interesting and supremely fresh catches like shaved ginger-topped aji (horse mackerel), meaty bluefin and rich, grilled yellowfin collar.

As Lincoln Park's go-to Italian joint for all occasions—witness the awkward Internet date in one corner, the anniversary celebration in another—it's easy to get the impression that people are coming here out of habit. In fact, the throngs of people are attracted to the warm, homey room and the housemade pastas like spaghetti with veal meatballs and fennel-flecked Italian sausage, or sumptuous gnocchi paired with a lively pesto sauce. They're so tasty you'll realize that the locals' habit is for good reason.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: Well, there's not really a lot of pie here—it seems the name is purely for the pun of it—but this sunny pizza shop nevertheless has a lot going for it. Thin slices of roast beef and cheddar are piled impossibly high on thick, fragrant slices of rye, and the "California Pepper"—the spicy, creamy specialty of the house—layers turkey, cucumber, pepper-jack cheese and avocado cream on jalapeño bread before being topped, like all sandwiches here, with the quintessential green olive. The pies are pretty ho-hum, so stick to a bottomless cup of Intelligentsia instead.

With its dim, smoky bar, weathered posters of Paris and battered leather banquette, it's no wonder this mainstay is a draw for local bohemians who seem content to sit for hours eating, drinking and typing on their laptops. The atmosphere is so comfortable that it almost overshadows the food. Almost. Once you try the trio of pâtés (it's worth it for the silky salmon pâté alone), the simply prepared steak flanked by a pile of hot, crispy frites or any of the namesake crêpes (we like the crème bržlée for a sweet ending), you'll understand how it's weathered more than 30 years.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: Hope you like salad. The pizza at this newly reconceptualized, former lounge adjacent to Osteria via Stato is as thin as paper. And while that provides an excellent crispy base for the bright San Marzano tomatoes in the Margherita and the earthy combination of pancetta, fingerlings and smoked mozzarella on the sauceless potato pie, it's hard to get full off this stuff. So you'll need the arugula salad studded with sweet dates, and probably the Caesar salad, too. And while you're at it, may as well throw in the indulgent spinach-and-pecorino fonduta.
column8: Notable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: Chef Jim Bee's loyal followers are no longer limited to catching his cuisine only at Lincoln Park's legendary Sai Café; Logan Square is now home for Sai's sister sushi spot. Hachi is Japanese for bee, which is dually fitting since chef Bee's place has been buzzing since it opened more than a month ago. Sleek decor is sophisticated but not sceney, the sake and wine lists are packed with ideal sushi partners, and the creative starters and maki steal the show from the thick, glossy cuts of expected fish varieties. Try the crunchy-creamy tuna masako, the citrus and sesame oil–kissed chilled octopus, and the slick miso-glazed black cod.
column198: Other location: Sai Café, 2010 N Sheffield Ave (773-472-8080)

column7: Ever since the November arrival of chef Steve Chiappetti, this tourist standby has been trying its hand at a more upscale experience. Overall, it's working: A carrot-curry-crab soup is a beautiful dish, each ingredient distinct yet in harmony with the others, and "Chiappetti's Lamb" arrived at our table so tender it could barely be moved from the tagine it was cooked in to our plate. But while the food might be upscale, Chiappetti's whimsical (and almost childish) approach to plating—entrées arrive in big wooden boats; the "junk food cart" of housemade marshmallows and brownies arrives in a mini-shopping cart—keeps the experience from getting too haughty.

All-you-can-eat cereal. Blackboard fresh catch tilapia specials. Huge salads (no iceberg lettuce here). Red Hot pancakes. (Yep, that's pancakes with Red Hots cinnamon candies baked inside.) Any place with that varied a menu is going to have some hits and misses. Needing a steak knife to eat our stuffed bell pepper makes that dish a miss. But the salads, grilled sandwiches and enormous omelettes are all made with fresh veggies, and there's no greasy-spoon feel. Plus, there's never anything wrong with a big bowl of Cocoa Puffs.

A new restaurant every 84 years is a slow expansion strategy. This chocolate-shop/ice-cream parlor extraordinaire opened its first store in 1921 and its second in 2005 in a tiny former Fannie May candy shop under the Brown Line. Outpost two has the same cramped quarters as the Bucktown store, the same menu (sandwiches are an afterthought) and the same ambience. The ice cream itself is nothing fancy. It's all about the perfect hot fudge (served in a separate dish) and the multiple menu pages of indulgent, old-fashioned ice-cream sundaes.

This cozy Brighton Park Salvadorean restaurant is our favorite for empanadas de leche (sugary fried plantain pockets stuffed with thick condensed milk), pupusa chichurrones (pork-filled cornmeal pancakes) and chunks of deep fried yucca. The panes con pavo is also an interesting find: housemade bread smothered with gravy-laden turkey. The back of the menu is saved for Mexican offerings (try the ground-beef tacos), just in case you can't find Mexican anywhere else in the city.

It's easy to link Indian and Pakistani food, but it's not easy to tie a dusty minimart to a restaurant. Blame it on convenience; hell, if you're selling the ingredients, why not cook with them? In the back of this bustling market are some scattered tables and a wall menu touting authentic Pakistani favorites such as frontier chicken, tongue-searing palak aloo (creamy spinach and potatoes) and belly-warming curried dal (lentils). For a sample, tease your taste buds with veggie samosas, then amble over to the huge selection of glass-encased sweets and grab a bite to go.

The riverside location of this steak-and-chops joint is such a big part of Chicago's personality that it may surprise you to learn it's not a Windy City original (the chain started in New York in 1977). Nevertheless, it still hangs with the big boys. Here's how: a creamy and slightly smoky split-pea soup; an enormous "crackling pork shank" that flaunts both a crispy, deep-fried exterior and incredibly juicy meat; an all-American wine list; and, of course, those big, fat steaks, all of which are consistently cooked to perfection. (But steer clear of the New York strip. You know, just on principle.)
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplaceGood for dining at barKid-friendly
column144: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 29, 36

column7: If you smell something delicious when you walk into this Puerto Rican diner, don't bother trying to figure out what it is. It could be any number of the greasy-spoon comfort foods that are dished up here daily: chunky, tomato-heavy goat stew or garlicky mofongo, savory balls of plantains studded with corn. Then again, it could be the oniony jibaro (dubbed "hee-ba-roe" on the English menu), a gooey cheese-steak–like sandwich that substitutes plantains for bread. So take a seat—looks like you've got some research to do.

We love Indian food as much as the next guy, but when you work in the Loop, jetting off to Devon Avenue for a midday fix isn't realistic. But now there's hope: This newcomer promises to bring nan, samosas and boti kebabs to Loop lunchers, and it promises to deliver them fast. The interior is pretty sparse at the moment, with an assembly line of steam tables and hot lamps as the only decor. But when we're craving chicken tikka, we'll take what we can get.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph; Red, Blue to Washington. Bus: 14, 20, X20, 56, 60, 124, 156, 157

column7: We'll admit there's a somewhat amateur edge to the service you get in this ornate dining room. But at least these servers have an excuse: They're students from Washburne Culinary Institute. Luckily, the solid food (also cooked by students) helps make up for any service missteps: The crisp and greaseless Frito misto de mar—fried tilapia, calamari and shrimp—made us realize that being a guinea pig isn't all that bad. We're hoping for the same reaction from fall's new menu additions: creamy butternut squash soup, grilled Australian rack of lamb with roasted sweet potatoes, and a maple-glazed pork chop with garlic-roasted mashed potatoes and sautéed collard greens. The $25 three-course dinner on Wednesdays and Thursdays is a good excuse to give this place a try.
column144: Metra: Elec S Chicago to South Shore. Bus: 6, 26, 71

column7: This large Irish pub's marquee announces its daily specials to the neighborhood; time your visit based on the signage and you may find yourself with a bill for $1 burgers or 25-cent wings. Even at full price, Celtic Crown is still worth a visit for better-than-average bar food. As you'd expect at an Irish pub, the corned-beef sandwich is satisfying, as is the barbecue-rib plate (note to true 'cue fans: They're baked, not smoked), and you can indulge your inner grammar-school student with Tater Tots. With TVs blaring and bar patrons quaffing another one, the atmosphere is loud, but the waitstaff never overlooks the diners for the drinkers.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 78

column7: Rent a car, take the Metra or con a friend into driving—do whatever it takes to get out of your city snobbery and into this classy, comfortable restaurant that serves food as seasonal and delicious as anything within city limits. Chef Paul Virant (a 2007 Food & Wine best new chef) marks the start of fall with dishes such as a brined and wood-grilled Gunthrop Farm rack of pork with wild rice, roasted Genesis Growers cauliflower, Hillside Orchards chestnuts and preserved sweet cherries. Of course, the menu changes nearly every week, so there's no telling what'll actually be on the menu when you arrive. Luckily, the Friday and Saturday burger nights (dry-aged beef with housemade pickles and preserved tomatoes) are a constant.
column144: Metra: Burlington/Santa Fe to Western Springs

column7: You might expect to walk into the gallery space at Lillstreet Art Center and be assaulted by fumes from paint and clay. But now that the eight-table First Slice Café resides in the corner, you'll instead inhale the aroma of fresh-baked pie (red wine and poached pear, peanut butter and chocolate, plus old standbys like apple). First Slice's nonprofit credo means it uses its funds to help feed the hungry. But because the chefs use local and organic ingredients, you won't feel like you're making a sacrifice by eating here. In fact, we'd come back for the hot chicken–and–blue cheese sandwich and the not-too-sweet chocolate-ginger scones no matter who was benefiting from our tab.
column92: In the Lillstreet Art Center, 4401 N Ravenswood Ave

column7: Since 1972, this underground institution has been luring Chicagoans with the promise of famous sandwiches and pizzas. Its "Pizza Pot Pies" are in no way, shape or form actual pizza—they're more like bread bowls filled with pizza sauce and melted cheese. But the grinders, such as the Italian combination that piles on Genoa salami and smoked ham, are so mammoth, crispy and warm, and the salads topple with such insane quantities of artichoke hearts, olives and peppers, that we'll forgive the false advertising.
column93: Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder Co.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 22, 36
column186: Chicago Pizza and Oven Grinder Co.

column7: All signs point to wine bar: exposed brick and beams, a wall devoted to wine storage, 250 by the bottle and 32 by the glass. But as our waitress said, "Wine is the gimmick; the food is the selling point." Case in point: the melt-in-your mouth beef carpaccio surrounding a salad of baby bok choy and greens. Entrée knockouts include a perfectly cooked rack of lamb with mint pesto and white-truffle crème bržlée, and filet mignon with shallot cabernet butter and a potato galette.
column93: The Stained Glass Wine Bar, Bistro & Cellar
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 205, 206, Pace 208, Pace 212, Pace 213
column186: Stained Glass Wine Bar, Bistro & Cellar

column7: This national chain is a dependable pick when dining with a group with varied tastes. The menu spans Asia, including esoteric Malaysian specialties such as oyster omelette and water spinach stir-fried in spicy shrimp paste. Other tasty takes include the Indian roti pancake with curry dipping broth, Chinese-style onion duck, ayam rendang (chicken chunks simmered in an Indianish coconut curry) and crispy red snapper done Thai-style with tangy tamarind lemongrass sauce. There's also an entire page of Japanese offerings from udon noodle soup to grocery store–quality sushi, but we're thinking it's best to stick to our regular spot.

When there's a tiny Mexican storefront on nearly every corner in the city, how do you figure out which deserve your cash? Go where the scent of charred meat permeates and the dollar stretches for miles. This two-person crew doles out crispy, meat-stuffed tortas; king-size Suiza (Swiss cheese) burritos packed with grilled steak, crumbly ground beef or pulled chicken; and big bowls of fresh seafood caldos (that's soup to gringos). The chiles rellenos tacos and the Mexican gyros torta are packed with flavor but lack spice, so if you're looking for a blast of heat, douse them with one of the spicy housemade salsas.

This Japanese-Korean restaurant's decor is a metaphor for the kitchen's food: nothing too flashy. The flavors of the many turns on fish are subtle, and the presentations are easy on the eyes. Fish is fresher than tomorrow (the sea urchin is especially tender), but the Korean dishes—such as bi bam nang myun, cold, fiery noodles—are the menu's thunderclap. Service brings a happy mix of wizened sushi chefs and youthful servers. The restaurant is attached to next door's Paradise Beauty Shop & Sauna—a rubdown would make a fine dessert.

Devotees of Wicker Park's Le Bouchon might tell you otherwise, but the bistro essentials at this sibling spot are just as tasty. The setting is much more open and airy than Bouchon's cramped space, but the rest of the package is pretty much the same: indifferent servers, plump mussels drenched in creamy white-wine broth, onion soup that tests even serious cheese-lovers' thresholds, juicy grilled hanger steak with bordelaise and simple bouillabaisse jam-packed with seafood. The French-focused wine list is half off on Mondays, and there's a $25 three-course meal offer on Tuesdays.

When it comes to breathing life into Spanish bar foods, this small, contemporary spot in Heart of Italy is an oxygen tank. Pintxos—small open-face sandwiches found in Basque bars—are the draw here. The selection changes weekly, but if you're lucky, you'll snag the spicy blood sausage–stuffed red pepper, the juicy lamb or the simple serrano-and-Manchego combo. If not, fall back on tapas like the huevos flamenco (a casserole of potatoes, chorizo and fried eggs) or baby eels, savory and slick with olive oil. But skip the rubbery anchovies and boring scallops—it'd be a shame to leave yet another tapas joint with a bad taste in your mouth.

In the pantheon of Chicago hot-dog stands, Wolfy's deserves a seat on the dais. The room is sparkling clean and the staff is sweet—think of it as the anti–Wieners Circle. Though it offers a lot more, take a cue from the iconic signage that features an impaled hot dog on a sparkling fork and stick to the sausages. The Vienna Beef chargrilled polish is near-perfect, but it's Wolfy's hot dog, one of the best in the city, that will make even the most jaded hot-dog eater smile.

Dinners here start when your server hands you the Long Island iced tea list—15 ways to get really wasted, really fast. The menu is accordingly full of the kind of simple, filling food you want to eat when you're drunk. We liked the tomato soup with "grilled cheese croutons" (actually an entire sandwich), but we'll never forgive our server for suggesting the dreadful lemon-pepper chicken. The meatball casserole and s'mores were more successful: hearty, tasty dishes that only a snob wouldn't love.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 9, 11, 77

column7: Despite numerous reviews that heaped on the praise when it first opened, this basement dining room remains somewhat of a secret after-work spot. Guys tuck their ties into their shirts so they can dig into the signature ravioli, such as delicious butternut and acorn squash, with abandon. Sweet-potato gnocchi, fragrant with orange rind, comes in a brown-butter sauce, and the veal scaloppine is drizzled with a delectable porcini-sage-veal reduction. Take a cue from the businessmen and protect your clothes: You'll want every last drop to land in your mouth.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Madison; Blue, Red to Washington. Bus: 14, 20, X20, 124, 157

column7: First of all, there's the 21-cent falafel with a crisp, browned crust that cracks open to reveal a fluffy green center. But a trip to this dingy storefront wouldn't be complete without also trying a bowl of mossabaha, hummus studded with whole chickpeas and pools of olive oil, or a plate of the rich beef shawarma. Daily specials, such as Wednesday's stuffed lamb, typically run out around lunchtime, so if you want some, you'll need to take the day off. Trust us, it's worth a vacation day.

The subterranean outpost of this Portland, Oreg.–based chain (so much for it being "original") typically has less of a wait than its Gold Coast sibling. This is a good thing because waiting in line and watching people partake in that enormous apple pancake—a mountain of caramelized cinnamon apples—can be torture. It's foolish not to at least try the perfect buttermilk pancakes when you're here, even if you're more in the mood for the fluffy salami scramble; luckily almost everything comes with a short stack.

The portions are as big as the personality of this ten-year-old breakfast-and-lunch institution that's packed with tchotchkes, Nagel posters, mismatched chairs and oilcloth tablecloths. Blueberry-studded pancakes the size of dinner plates are dense with fruit and topped with strawberries; and giant chunks of flaky salmon, white and green asparagus, and goat cheese stuff a five-egg omelette served with crispy potatoes. Of the sandwiches, the turkey Reuben stands out, thick with 1/3 pound of turkey, kraut and gooey cheese, with ridiculously rich double-battered fries and housemade soup on the side. The only thing scaled back here? The prices.

Winter's the best time to duck into this tiny, cozy bistro, whose side-street entrance is tough to spot. Sure, this Café Bernard sibling is open year-round, but there's nothing like warming up with tender beef bourguignonne on a bed of egg noodles or duck confit ladled with berry sauce when it's extremity-numbing cold outside. Candles provide nearly all the light, but luckily you don't need to see the meaty snails in bubbling garlic butter to know they're incredible. However, you will wish you had a flashlight for the shockingly inexpensive wine list—many bottles are $29 or less.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73, 74

column7: Stop by midday for chef Judy Contino's acclaimed pastries and desserts, and chances are you'll pull up a chair in the small, charming bakery café for lunch. You won't go wrong with any of the handful of rotating daily menu options like carrot-jalapeño soup, spinach salad with blue cheese and lemon vinaigrette, and roasted eggplant–and–goat cheese sandwiches—perfect light fare before you dive into that picture-perfect meringue tart or the delicious ice cream scooped out into chocolate-lined Chinese takeout containers (try the intense chocolate almond).
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77

column7: The Joy Yee miniempire took root in Evanston back in 1993 and continues to pack in everyone from students to local office stiffs who loosen up with platter-size portions of pan-Asian food. The menu's a bit less adventurous here than at the Chinatown outpost, but we still stop in for mussels with black-bean sauce, garlicky chicken with string beans and gargantuan bowls of udon-noodle soup. And it wouldn't seem right to leave without a pastel-colored bubble tea from the spot that claims to have introduced it to Chicagoland.

This retro hotel restaurant promises to bring you back to the 1940s, and while that may sound exciting, it loses its appeal when you're forced to eat meat loaf and wedges of iceberg lettuce. But all is not lost: A bit of modernity sneaks into a decent roasted chicken. Desserts like red-velvet cake, strawberry shortcake and lemon meringue pie won't send you to the '40s, either, but they will give you flashbacks to childhood.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: This is the Devon Avenue spot you take your spice-phobic parents to while still managing to get good grub and throw back an Indian beer or two. With locations in Schaumburg, Westmont and downtown, this place's accessibility is pretty obvious, but thanks to personable service, your requests for various heat levels will be met. Go for the vegetarian thali, a combo platter of mashed, roasted eggplant; creamy spinach; simmered black lentils; rice and nan. Meat-eaters should try the gosht pasanda, a sweetish, creamy, cashew-based gravy dotted with chunks of lamb, or the murg methi chaman, a fenugreek chicken dish bursting with fresh herb flavor.

After local chain Lettuce Entertain You sold this pan-Asian money-maker to the folks behind Chili's, the restaurant slacked on quality. So LEYE bought it back and revamped the food. Thanks to freshly roasted peanuts, fiery blistered chilies and made-to-order sauces, it's better than ever. In addition to authentic Chinese specialties like Mongolian beef and Thai curries like a scallop and shrimp combo, prime beef goes into the lettuce wraps, Niman Ranch pork is used in the fried rice, and local produce has found its way onto the stir-fry bar.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listVegetarian-friendly
column198: Other locations: 60 E Ohio St (312-951-1888); 215 Parkway Dr, Lincolnshire (847-808-8880); 1950 E Higgins, Schaumburg (847-527-8881)

column7: Gerald Freeman has a fever, and the only prescription is more Victorian and Art Nouveau antiques to hang on every square inch of wall and ceiling space (including the bathroom stalls) of his 40-year-old Rogers Park restaurant. The menu's as long as your arm, but we skip the mediocre apps and entrées for the pan pizza—a gooey, melty mess of cheese, fresh veggies, oregano and basil on a thick, crispy crust—that's perfect with a frosty mug of beer.

If you're thinking Quentin, think again. This corner neighborhood spot is a lot less about hit men and kung-fu Uma than it is about seductive, oversized polenta fries served with tomato chutney, and thin, crispy pizzas piled with spicy arugula and prosciutto. Pork chops are paired with red wine-and-vinegar–soaked grapes and creamy rosemary mashed potatoes. While it may not have anything to do with the star filmmaker, this place is still a blockbuster.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: This Mexican seafood house is decorated with so much aquatic paraphernalia—fishing nets hang from the ceiling, a mural of underwater life is painted on the wall—you may feel like you're at Sea World. Luckily, this isn't amusement-park food. The crispy, whole red snapper is covered with chunky veracruzana sauce, the deliciously simple broiled shrimp is sweet and buttery, and the lively, tangy ceviches get a kick from jalapeño. One taste of this superfresh coastal cuisine and you'll know Disney had nothing to do with it.

Brave enough to fight the crowds at this adorable brunch spot? Bring a snack. A hostess may give you a cup of coffee while you wait, but you won't be eating anything until you sit down. But as legions of fans have found, the cobb salad sandwiches (chicken, avocado and blue cheese on toasted challah), hearty buckwheat-blueberry pancakes and decadent French toasts (an "orgy" puts the chocolate, strawberry and mascarpone–stuffed varieties all on one plate) are well worth the wait.

Cheeseheads reserve most of their enthusiasm for pigskins, but they can muster some excitement over curds once in a while, too. At this offshoot of a Green Bay staple, you can do both: Flat screens show football and other sports, and the kitchen puts out authentic dairyland fare. Butter burgers—topped with ketchup, pickles, raw white onions and, of course, a buttered, grilled bun—are cutely wrapped up in butcher paper and are indeed de rigueur. Otherwise, thin-crusted pizzas and chewy, golden fried curds make good beer accompaniments. Salads are available, too, but that wouldn't be very Wisconsin of you, now would it?

A mall setting could doom any restaurant looking to be taken seriously, but apparently the hordes of locals filling every seat in the house not only accept the location, but embrace it. Di Pescara fills a void for north suburban diners looking to skip the hassle of heading to the city, leave the tie at home and still get a big, fat steak, a bowl of pasta and a decent bottle of wine. Alpana Singh's five-bucks-a-glass bets pair well enough with standout dishes like ragù-drenched pasta ribbons; gnocchi with crumbled Italian sausage and broccolini; crispy, breaded, bone-in veal chop topped with lemon-kissed arugula; and a prime sirloin with a nice salt-and-pepper punch.
column144: Metra: Milwaukee N to Lake-Cook Rd

column7: The Gibsons folks go rustic Italian with this cavernous dining room decked out with reclaimed wood and subway tiles, vintage mirrors and mismatched chairs. To ensure authenticity on the plate, they've enlisted chef John Coletta, who doesn't disappoint with housemade salumi like beef bresaola, spicy soppressata and duck prosciutto served with housemade giardiniera and mostarda. The pizza is among the better thin-crust versions in town (go for the Margherita), and small plates of grappa-cured salmon and braised pork–filled ravioli topped with crispy speck and al dente fava beans are impressive. Living up to the name, the affordable, half-Italian, half-global wine list is offered in quarter, half and full liters.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating

column7: Raul Arreola's menu is a nod to traditional Mexican fish houses known as marisquerías, and the man can work magic with all things aquatic. Firm whitefish chunks get tossed with jalapeño, cilantro and lime juice for lively ceviche, whole red snapper mojo de ajo, and the fish tacos are flanked by a bowl of smoky squid and octopus-laden guajillo broth. But Arreola's greatest achievement—and the dish that is quickly becoming the restaurant's signature—is from the land: the borrego en mole negro, four petite lamb chops paired with a rich and endlessly layered mole.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 53, 74, 82. Metra: Milwaukee North to Healy.

column7: Thirty years old and still ticking, this German-American party hall really gets going on the weekends, when couples and families raise steins to the traditional tunes of live bands. It may look like the owners forgot to take down the holiday glitz, but the strands of white lights and greenery are up year-round, adding to the festive feel of the cozy space. Meat and potatoes fill the menu, with the best bet being the combo platter of smoked pork chop, roasted pork loin, bratwurst, rouladen, griddled potatoes and spaetzle. The only thing missing is weinerschnitzel, so add on an order as well. The thin, flavorful veal cuts with perfect, crispy breading are great with your pick of nearly two dozen German beers.

We loved the Old Irving Park location of this Mexican gem, so we thought we'd check in on the Belmont-Cragin outpost. Verdict: Just as good as the original, plus there's a huge banquet room with a booming sound system up for grabs the next time you and 74 of your friends need a place to party. Until then, stop in for menu favorites like giant torta sandwiches (try the huatulco) and sopa Azteca, a chicken tortilla soup packed with tender poached breast meat, nutty rice, cilantro and crispy corn tortillas strips. Another soup worth venturing out for is the caldo del Ismo, a heavily spiced seafood soup brimming with shrimp, clams, mussels, snapper and half a crab. Savor it with a bottle of Pacifico while watching Mexican soccer on the big screen.

Peanut butter and jelly. Cagney and Lacey. Romance andÉfish. At least that's the vibe at this upscale Chase Plaza–level institution, where the only thing that could get in the way of a couple's canoodling is the single long-stemmed rose that's artfully placed on their table. It's common to see couples feeding each other forkfuls of crispy and bright citrus-ginger salmon, deep-red slices of seared tuna and "clams casino," a tasty dish even if the clams only serve as a vehicle for garlicky slabs of bacon. If PDA isn't your idea of appetizing, head upstairs for some pub grub at Nick's Grill.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison. Bus: 3, 4, 14, 20, 26, 56, 60, 124, 145, 147, 148, 151, 157
column198: Other location: 10275 W Higgins Rd, Rosemont (847-298-8200)

column7: There's an interesting distraction during the long wait for a table at this sunny vegetarian brunch spot: A TV shows Indian guru Sri Chinmoy (of whom every employee is a follower) lifting heavy things—a crew of firemen, a helicopter, a plane. Impressive, but we're bigger believers in the two-inch-thick French toast slathered in peach butter and maple syrup, or the pesto-laden free-range scrambled eggs in the Satisfaction Promise, which comes with crispy potatoes and crusty bread. The Coconut-Peanut Veggie Wrap is a bit bland—heavy on fresh veggies, brown rice and tofu, but low on coconut and peanut flavor—but the dish's salvation is its side: chunky mashed potatoes with mushroom gravy.

The only way this old-school slice shop could get more New York is if Woody Allen was rolling the dough, Sarah Jessica Parker was tending the sauce and Michael Bloomberg was working the register. Big, foldable slices are thin and can be piled with spinach, artichokes, ricotta and fresh tomato—though real New Yorkers know that plain is the way to go. Housemade sausage and pepperoni-stuffed "New York rolls" and thick Sicilian slices round out the menu, and the BYOB status keeps things cheap. (Though you might want to bring your own glasses, too—all they'll give you is a pair of Styrofoam cups.)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76

column7: If there's one thing at Old L'Viv you definitely don't want to make a choice between, it's the soups. Before digging into this old-school Ukrainian restaurant's buffet, you'll have to decide between the silky and gorgeous borscht, the chicken soup sprinkled with fresh dill, or cabbage soup that's tart with housemade sauerkraut. Can't call it? Go crazy and order all three. You're going to gorge yourself on the buffet's oniony potato pancakes (Mondays and Fridays only), tender schnitzel and rich, creamy blintzes anyway...why not get a head start?

The demise of Australian Homemade is a lot easier to swallow since it's being replaced by another ice cream shop, even if the two couldn't be more different. This outpost of the homey original on Broadway is a little bigger and has a larger coffee component (like the Lavazza Grand Espresso or the Intelligentsia houseblend), but the ice cream, root-beer floats and banana splits remain exactly the same.

Chicago's most quintessential restaurant is not a steakhouse or a laboratorylike kitchen putting out cutting-edge cuisine. It's a cafeteria. But before you get in line at this 66-year-old institution, decide what you want. You'll pass by plates of Jell-O and chicken salad, but this line moves too quickly for you to make decisions on the spot. Overwhelmed? We'll make it easy for you: Grab one of the inhumanely oversized corned beef or pastrami sandwiches (there really is bread under all that meat, we promise), a potato pancake on the side and a packet of Tums for dessert.

We'd hit this cramped spot just for its frothy, boozy margaritas (especially the sweet-tangy tamarind). The key to avoiding wicked hangovers is filling up on the fantastic food, but skip the chips and watery salsa, and instead start with the coctel de camarón—plump shrimp, avocado and sweet tomato sauce on Saltines. Of the many veggie options we love the plantain-stuffed enchiladas slathered in chocolaty mole, and carnivores will swoon over the revoltijo ajijic, a plank of plantains topped with diced steak, onion, peppers, mushrooms and blanketed with a web of Chihuahua cheese. The flan or the dulce de leche–stuffed crêpes are fine finishes, but we'd rather have another margarita, please.

Chef-owner Mark Grosz didn't bring with him the pretension of former employer Le Francais, but he did bring the skill with classic Euro dishes and the accompanying hefty price tags. Close to ten different seafood entrées are offered on any given night, and while the multi-ingredient preparations border on overwhelming, Grosz somehow manages to balance flavors while completely flipping off subtlety. Big portions mean you may be full by dessert, but it helps to justify $30 entrées in a dated room where regulars rock the "casual Friday" look.
column8: Notable wine listOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar

column7: Sushi options in the Loop just increased now that this sister location of the old-school Old Town institution has hit the scene. Pop in for grab-and-go lunch combos of standard sushi cuts and maki rolls ranging from California to spicy salmon. Cooked teriyaki rice bowls make up the hot portion of the menu. You can try angling for one of the dozen or so seats, but the carryout line and ready-made grub make it easier just to head back to the office.
column8: Good for groupsGood for dining at barVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Quincy. Bus: 1, 7, X28, 126, 151

column7: This fairly fast, affordable Italian minichain has expanded from the 'burbs into the city, with an identical menu of standards like spaghetti marinara, fettucine Alfredo, fried calamari, Caesar salad and rectangular thin-crust pizzas served on wood planks. Its straight-up, no-frills approach extends to the beer and wine list, where options are limited, listed as simply merlot or chardonnay.

The smoking ban has taken effect for barless restaurants like this one, but you'll still leave here with the essence of ash wafting from your clothes. That's no reason to stay away from the charcoal-fueled Korean barbecue, however: The wang kalbi and dai ji kalbi are marinated, not saturated, in their respective sauces, which gives the high-quality meats a chance to speak for themselves. Don't want to smell like a campfire? Try the bibim naeng Myun, a big bowl of cold buckwheat noodles and beef that's topped with a wonderfully spicy and full-flavored chili sauce, or the hae moul pajun, an egg pancake packed with generous chunks of tender shrimp and calamari.

There's a clear dichotomy at this often-overlooked spot: Older neighborhood folks come for the well-executed if dull Chinese dishes (inauthentic takes like sesame chicken and mooshu beef); and the younger crowd devours the fresh, delicious sushi. The ambience is a nod to the old-school patrons—floral carpeting, white tablecloths, smooth jazz and a roaring fire. But we'll overlook the hotel-lobby décor as long as the flavor-packed maki keep coming: Dee's maki, a giant, two-bite roll packed with lettuce, tuna, salmon, yellowtail, avocado, crunch and sprinkled with tobiko and the guilty-pleasure Mexican maki, a tuna roll spiced up with cilantro, jalapeno and lime.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: Train enthusiasts and kitsch lovers will adore the ultracutesy decor of this restaurant in the Davis Metra station: The walls are painted to look like denim; the flatware and napkins are tucked into jeans pockets; the menu is on a clipboard; diners sit in armchairs; and copper pipes serve as light fixtures. We groaned a bit, but once we looked at the wine list (handily categorized by flavor profile) and tried some dishes (don't miss the rich goat cheese–and–artichoke tart or the velvety braised short ribs with blackberry-mint sauce), we would have been on board even if our server wore engineer's overalls and gave us our change from his belt.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 205, 206, Pace 208, Pace 212, Pace 213

column7: This unsung steakhouse doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel, but that's no sin when the steaks are this incredible. Great steaks come at a price, so you won't mind the hefty tab after tasting the smooth, smoky, dry-aged New York strip, which just might be among the best steaks we've eaten. Not far behind was the butter-soft, marrow-encrusted sirloin, so rich it could double for dessert. Ask for the housemade mashed potatoes and chipotle-spiked corn on the side, and a prime table by the window.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)ViewsKid-friendly

column7: Suckers for free food eat well at this family-run Persian spot: Order the village salad of tomato, cucumber, pepper, stuffed grape leaves, basil, olives and feta and you'll also get a bowl of lentil soup. Choose entrées such as the baby lamb shank simmered in walnut-pomegranate sauce or the lemon-honey chicken breast with currants, and you'll not only get soup but a perfectly dressed house salad as well. And the vanilla ice cream topped with honey and cinnamon? You won't find that on your check, either. Thirty years of business result in a room that's a bit dim and weathered, but the service is extra attentive; complimentary roses are handed to departing women. Cheesy, but cute.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76, 151, 156

column7: Open for a few years now, this tapas lounge is still packing them in and has made a few tweaks to its menu to keep people interested. Of the new fall/winter dishes, we like the sound of the tocino (cava-braised pork belly with sweet beet puree, apple fritters, citrus crème fraîche and hazelnut) and the cinnamon-sugar-coated apple empanadas. What we really love, though, is the skirt steak, served with a bubbly crust of Manchego. It certainly wasn't this good when the restaurant opened; apparently People can change.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: If you can overlook indifferent service and bad music, give this newcomer a shot. Skip apps and go straight for the goods: generous sushi that tastes flown-in fresh (especially the buttery salmon) and the yakitori, grilled skewers of guilty pleasures like crispy chicken skin and meaty gizzards, good-for-you eats from asparagus to eggplant and unusual finds of bacon-wrapped tomato and chicken-stuffed portobello. Bonus: You can use the pointy skewers to end your misery when 2Pac's "Dear Mama" is played.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72

column7: Years of fending off the Zagat-clutching crowds at their flagship Greenwich Village spot gave the brothers behind this New York classic the confidence to expand, which is exactly what they've done: to Tokyo, Las Vegas and now, the Gold Coast's Biggs Mansion. Every meal here starts with complimentary antipasto, fried zucchini and garlic bread sticks, followed by entrées such as saltimbocca (veal sautéed with sage and prosciutto) and spaghettini bolognese—with a healthy slice of New York attitude on the side.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: This old-school Italian joint is holding strong in its ever-changing 'hood. As has been the case since opening 75 years ago, cash is the only thing accepted, both by the cute Italian boys parking your car (permits rule the block so valet is the only option) and the indifferent waitresses who all seem to be related. The chalkboard menu rarely changes, and regulars never even glance at it before ordering the house specialty: lemon chicken Vesuvio minus a fistful of garlic, the roasted, citrus-spritzed chicken is among the best around. After a couple of bites, you'll get caught up in the tradition of the place, enough to overlook iceberg salads, standard pastas and carafes of jug wine.

Just on the cusp of Greektown's eating mecca lies this sprawling spot known for cuisine that's from the Mediterranean island of Cyprus. The owners have taken the traditional, rustic village food and added a luscious, upscale touch.
