Try the halloumi (a milder version of saganaki) and the incredibly tender six-hour slow-baked lamb, served tableside in foil. Everything is made to order, so enjoy the wait with a bottle from the Greek wine list. Your pastitsio tsoukas, long noodles layered with ground beef and covered in a crispy béchamel topping, will be worth it.

Venturing into this sushi spot can be a bit intimidating (with its purple-and-green decor, it could double for the Joker's bedroom, and the place is nearly always empty), but the payoff is worth taking the chance. Sample your way through dozens of loose-leaf teas (the dragon well and the magnolia oolong are amazing); start with the marinated squid salad, and pay attention when the server rattles off the maki specials: These are the kitchen's best bets. If the "Hot Spot maki" is still around, get it. Honey-drizzled mushrooms are wrapped in spicy crab, shrimp and eel with slivers of jalapeño for addictive results. Sushi snobs be warned: The sashimi is mediocre, so stick with maki and tea.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, X80

column7: Since copperblue opened more than a year ago, we've been impressed with how chef-owners Michael Tsonton and Victor Newgren keep their atmosphere and service down-to-earth. Most recently, they've turned their original menu into a highly seasonal "Farm Menu." The offerings make up a who's who of sustainable and organic producers—oven-roasted Swan Creek mallard duck breast, Green Acres fall vegetable ragout, Gunthorp organic pork confit—so you always know exactly where your dinner came from.

Adjacent to Inner Metamorphosis University, this vegetarian spot is a great postyoga fuel-up, offering a nearly all-organic menu. Meat-eaters won't be fooled by the Chicago Polish—the spicy tofu dog is missing the requisite snap of an encased meat. But thanks to heaps of sauerkraut, mustard and relish, you'll hardly care. It's overdressed with orange vinaigrette, but the Winter Salad—with its huge chunks of creamy feta, carrots, walnuts, cashews, dried cranberries and green onions—is mealworthy, and the veggie-packed, crispy-crust Organic Garden pizza makes junk food seem healthy.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Purple, Red, Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, 147, 151, 201, 205, 206, Pace 215, Pace 290

column7: The large crowd at the counter of this bare-bones Indo-Pak spot seems chaotic, but the diners are really just waiting for their postmeal chai. So push your way through and order a bowl of delicious dal, loaded with bay leaves and chile peppers. Ask for the chile chicken and spoon the greasy, delicious, fiery red chunks onto the dense paratha. And while you're at it, add a briyani to the mix. It's a huge portion, but the lamb that tops the fluffy rice is so tender that eating it with the provided spoon is no problem. And even if you eat half, you'll get your money's worth; like everything here, it only costs about four bucks.

Fess up: There are times you don't want to trek to Pilsen, Maxwell Market or even to La Pasadita. You just want to gulp down an obnoxiously large electric-blue margarita, right? Well, don't worry—there are others out there just like you who are eschewing authenticity, and this is where they go. So as you dig into chunky guac in a bowl the size of your head, relish the sizzle of shrimp as you add it to your bulging fajita or inhale that pork taco, look around you and take comfort: You're hardly alone.

It always feels like a warm, sunny day when we eat chef Carol Wallack's Hawaiian-influenced food. Just take a few bites of artichoke fritters, pork-filled postickers, tempura-fried calamari or mains such as bacon-wrapped cobia and cocoa nib–crusted scallops—and you'll warm up instantly. (The comfy room and veteran service help, too.) Keep on the lookout for occasional wine or beer dinners, and opt for brunch on the sidewalk cafe for a fresh-air wake-up call.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, X80

column7: The Chatham residents who mill about inside this tiny, smoke-scented, Jamaican carryout spot are all waiting on the same thing: the best jerk chicken around. Members of the Grant family work in tandem, taking orders for rich, allspice-laced oxtails and heaving jerk-rubbed chickens out of foggy smokers before packaging them in Styrofoam containers along with sides of cinnamon-candied yams and buttery braised greens. Ask for an extra side of the lappable jerk sauce to dip your chicken in, order wings for the juicy dark-meat factor, and be prepared to either make do with one of only two rickety tables or eat in your car—the killer scents make waiting until you get home unbearable.

A Colombian bakery is rare in Chicago, so we can see why this tiny gem is usually packed with devout regulars. Stopping by for the heavenly variety of sweet baked goods is the norm (try the flan de leche and the caramel napoleon), but we make a meal out of the rotating tins of meaty snacks that pile up in the hot case. Beef and chicken–stuffed empanadas, flavorful palito de queso (cheese-stuffed pretzel sticks), and wildly rich chorizo roll out of the kitchen every few hours, so arrive early for a choice bar stool and you can pluck your picks from the freshest batch while sipping turbo-strength Colombian coffee.

We thought the light had dimmed on this Latin-theme diva, but recent visits have proved she's still alive and kicking. Packed with mojito-swilling regulars on the weekends, Mambo Grill's dark room, Latin sounds and around-the-world rum flights add up to a sexy singles scene. Best bets include the flaky mushroom-and-roasted-corn empanadas, tres queso chile rellenos, crisp Latin cobb salad in a refreshing mojo de mango rum vinaigrette, coconut-curried tilapia, and a tequila-marinated skirt steak that's tempting enough to drag us back on a weekday for another helping. But in the light of day and when we're not-so-under-the-influence, lunch is a bit lackluster.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 65, 156

column7: People go to other diners for greasy bacon and eggs, fatty hamburgers, and limp french fries. But they come to this one, a tiny, charming room whose walls are covered with '50s-era nostalgia, for food they can watch being made to order in the open kitchen. Sitting at the long counter, you witness the eggs being cracked for your fluffy omelette, the batter being stirred for your thin and airy pancakes, and, if you're there on the weekend, the rich, sausage-studded gravy being spooned over dense, buttery biscuits. But the kitchen staff can see you, too, so try to control yourself while stuffing it all into your mouth.

A vegetarian restaurant in a college town is like a Hooters by the airport: It's a sure thing. Among the students at this more than 20-year-old institution you'll find plenty of thirtysomething couples, septuagenarians and families eating their way through the meatless menu. Kids may dig the too-dry fried seitan sticks, which become more edible when dipped in barbecue sauce, but we'd rather start with the tofu "crab" cakes, two moist, crumbly tofu patties wading in a creamy red-pepper sauce. We miss the sizzling, hotter-than-the-sun fajita skillet, but we don't long for meat while piling black beans, guac, seitan, red peppers, salsa and brown rice on corn tortillas. Order a decadent dessert from the attached bakery, or keep grooving that healthy vibe by grabbing a smoothie to go.
column144: El: Purple to Dempster. Bus: Pace 205, Pace 250 Dempster

column7: Raw foodists are rejoicing that chef Mehmet Ak is making 100% raw, 100% vegan and mostly organic renderings of Turkish and American classics. But they're not the only ones who will enjoy his delicious "pizza"—a flaxseed cracker topped with garlicky tomato sauce, fresh avocado and marinated mushrooms—and his lively marinated spinach. The nutty "zoom" burger and sprout-heavy tabouli, on the other hand, are probably easier to swallow for raw foodists, if only because, for them, there aren't many other options.

If you've ever found your girlfriend's younger sister hot but realized your girlfriend is more dependable, less flighty and doesn't treat you like you're a dork, you're a Naniwa kinda guy. The older sibling to the trendy Ukie Village Bob San, this old-school sushi house hasn't changed much during its 10 years. Straight-up sushi (luscious salmon, slick mackerel and bass with ponzu are standouts) and classics like Japanese pickles and boiled-spinach apps hold their ground, while dragon and rainbow rolls are about as crazy as it gets. Service is fine, but sit at the sushi bar if you want more personal attention. Chatting is your only defense against the '80s elevator music driving you bat-shit crazy.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: If making a 4,500 square-foot room feel cozy and welcoming seems like an impossibility, then the owners of this massive West Town coffee shop have done the impossible. The space is littered with couches, pillows and distressed-leather chairs. The walls are covered in sunny pigments and works by homegrown artists. Though the free wi-fi is distraction enough, the cafe's book collection is large enough to occupy you for a year of lazy Sundays. Intelligentsia provides the coffee beans and a few local bakeries, including Little Miss Muffin and Sweet Cakes, are responsible for the pastries as well as the vegan and dairy-free desserts. The sandwich selection, although small, gets a major boost with fresh slices of bread from local bakery Red Hen.

Holding strong in the middle of an industrialish residential 'hood is the mother of all breakfast haunts. It's like Granny's cozy kitchen but with the morning news flowing via a stream of chatty city employees, laptop-wielding businessmen and convivial construction workers. They fuel up for the day on whole wheat pancakes, football-size omelettes and biscuits with sausage-packed gravy. Lunch stays on the heavy side with bowls of beef stew and thick, delicious sandwiches. Since everything is made from scratch, doors close promptly at 3pm so the staff can prep the next day's fare.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 65

column7: A few things to keep in mind while visiting this popular Lincoln Park eatery: The carbonara, made the real way (with an egg and everything!) is excellent; the gnocchi, outsourced from an Italian-grandmother type, is rich and fluffy; and the salsiccia alla calabrese, with soft, sweated peppers and succulent sausage, is a good bet. The wine list is surprisingly decent for a restaurant at this price level. And the rest of the foodÉwell, it passes muster. Thin pizzas, bulging panzerotti and a somewhat mushy eggplant parmigiana are fine but nothing special.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 9, 11, 74

column7: If you don't think dropping a few extra bones for organic/artisanal/free-range food is worth it, this is a good place to test your theory. The menu is packed with first-rate ingredients that enable ordinary dishes like bacon and eggs or a burger and fries to kick your ass. The kitchen isn't afraid to gild the lily by slipping luxury items into already decadent dishes: Eggs Benedict gets truffled hollandaise, a club sandwich is studded with lobster, and mousse is made with fancy Callebaut chocolate. Placing your order at the counter means you get optimum bang for your buck.

Befitting its conventional-yet-cozy decor, this classic steakhouse/brewpub has a menu that holds few surprises: a little chicken, a little fish and a whole lotta meat. Skip apps like so-so shrimp DeJonghe and tough mussels and go straight for the wet-aged steaks, expertly cooked beneath a 1,400-degree infrared broiler that caramelizes the exterior and locks in the juices. Our massive porterhouse was ridiculously tender and juicy, while our rib eye was just as good (although it could have used a little judicious fat trimming). Brockway also brews its own beer, and our caramelly Grossvater Erlbecker Amber Lager was worth the Metra ride there.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplaceSuburban
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Palatine

column7: In a neighborhood full of neighborhood Italian joints, this tiny, one-room restaurant doesn't exactly stand out. But we don't discount the allure of a place where you can get reliably good pasta and where the warm, welcoming waitstaff treats everyone like a ten-year regular. Waiters amiably offer to sprinkle fresh Parmesan over everything, from the calamari and mussels appetizer swimming in an herbed marinara sauce, to the Alfredo–sauce–laden cheese tortellini studded with prosciutto and peas, to the chicken breast topped with asparagus and shrouded in a melty film of mozzarella. We pass on the extra formaggio, but when we're asked if we want more of the thick, crusty bread, we say hell yes.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 74

column7: Normally, if we have to preface a review by stating the food's "not bad," we wouldn't even waste your time. But this place has to be seen to be believed. Stone and jewel–covered walls, multiple handmade fountains, strange backlit paintings, fake flowers and twinkling lights hanging from the ceiling, an elevated pillow-laden seating area, an actual Mercedes emerging from behind a velvet curtain under a 15-foot-high stage of sorts—all come from the brain of the Iranian owner who has lived in the space for ten years before opening it as a restaurant. Perhaps if more people came, entrées like the rice-stuffed peppers and beef and lamb kebabs would taste fresher than they do, but with eye candy like this, we're willing to chill with a hookah and Turkish coffee until the food improves.

When you sit down at the eight-table Royal Thai, you'll be given two menus: the standard and the vegetarian. Both offer more than one restaurant's worth of options, allowing Royal Thai to hold its own among the city's many Thai joints. A Chinese influence finds its way into some of the dishes, like the light, fragrant Chinese flowering cabbage soup, chock-full of soft wontons. Classic dishes, like pad thai, are sauced just right: enough for flavor, but not so much that you need to play "Where's the Noodle?" Soups are among the strengths, particularly if you want something out of the ordinary. Try the tom kha pla (tilapia in spicy coconut-milk broth) or the potak, which is chock-full of shrimp, mussels and squid.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78

column7: While the man behind the moniker (Jacky Pluton) has since split from this cozy French bistro, at least he didn't take the charm with him. Chilly weather makes escaping within all the more inviting, especially if you can score one of the windowside tables for two. It's tough to go wrong if you're prepared to forget calorie counting and dig into dishes like the indulgent pan-seared foie gras with duck rillettes. Onion soup is a cheesy, crunchy-crouton–studded dream and the sirloin that makes up half of the ubiquitous steak frites is juicy, flavorful and well cooked (though the frites are just so-so). Skip the ho-hum desserts and go for the imported cheese plate instead.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific N to Central. Bus: 201, 206, Pace 213

column7: Face it: The Japanese are just cooler. If you've seen the way young Japanese hipsters trick themselves out, you know what we're talking about. But if you need a reminder, this tiny, minimalist sushi shop should jog your memory. There's no sashimi served here, so check out the creative honey roll—which flavors tuna with mustard, wraps it in crunchy tempura flakes and adds just a touch of honey—or more traditional rolls like a creamy spicy scallop or a simple hamachi roll. Too boring? Sides like wasabi mashed potatoes kick things up.

Rumor has it that if you aren't gay, male and cute, the service you get at this Boystown stalwart will be less than kind. We'd like to squash that rumor right now because these waiters are rude to everyone—gay, straight and in-between. If you can brush off the attitude, you can make a nice meal out of the decadent Parmesan deviled eggs (oddly but pleasantly served warm) or the ribeye steak sandwich with blue cheese fondue on ciabatta bread. While you're at it, you may as well order a bottle of wine; after all, you'll be saving money on the tip.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: What this counter-seat–only birria (goat stew) joint lacks in size, it makes up for in flavor. Though all of the soups (birria, pozole and menudo) are way better than average, it's the carne en su jugo that kills. A rich broth, chock full of creamy beans, bacon and chopped-up skirt steak hits the spot every time. Tacos and tortas round out the tiny menu, but seem completely unnecessary when faced with a giant bowl of steak soup. If they have them, order their homemade tortillas and fashion your own bacon-steak tacos.

The food at this Mediterranean spot isn't going to change your life, but the service might. Should anything go wrong while you munch on crisp pizzas, garlicky hummus, a perfectly fine steak, say the word. Servers will tend to you with honest concern. And that, more than anything, is why you'll come back.

This old-school, full-service fishmonger has flair that's a little bit country and a little bit, uh, Scandinavian. Inside the small hut there's a fish counter (half fresh, half smoked) and a small grocery featuring Scandinavian staples like lutefisk and herring. Indulge your yen for deep-fried eats with the juicy sea scallops, spicy popcorn shrimp, hush puppies and clam strips. Don't even try to resist the allure of the elusive deep-fried cheese curd. There's no seating inside, but there are specially designed bags to keep your fish crispy and hot until you get home—or at least to the parking lot.

This spacious Lincoln Park all-day eatery has an all-over-the-map menu (Greek egg lemon soup, bacon-mozzarella burger, cornmeal-crusted grouper over leek, red pepper and potato ragout), 75 flat screens to be canvases for digital art, and a handful of Wi-Fi-accessible computers and laptops for guests to use.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton; Brown to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73, 74

column7: If Viaggio were like so many other restaurants of its kind—Italian-American joints where the red sauce has no nuance and the endless menu no soul— there would have been no reason to order classics like the Sunday gravy or meatballs. But this West Loop joint is different precisely because it takes care with dishes that so many other people simply slap together. Here, the meatballs are juicy, the veal is perfectly pan-fried and the gravy is immensely hearty. So even though you've had these dishes countless times before, it feels like the first time.

We give the owners of this new contemporary-American spot props for trying to lend edge to a typical dining room by adding tastefully framed Sailor Jerry flash and playing Pitchfork picks. But diners more serious about food than an upscale rock & roll vibe will be disappointed. Lobster pizza's crust is bready, maki's rice is both mushy and sticky, and the pork belly half of a surf and turf combo is overcooked to a chewy mess. Servers are helpful and earnest, but we'll respectfully disagree with ours that the frozen blood-orange "soufflé" is "ridiculously good."
column8: Outdoor seatingLate-night diningGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 65, 66

column7: In lots of ways, eating here is like going to your Italian grandmother's house for Sunday dinner. It's loud, a little dysfunctional and the decor is pretty worn, but all that fades into the background at your first taste of that housemade red sauce. Don't have an Italian grandmother but wish you did? NU students and neighborhood families feel the same way, crowding the basement-level eatery to carbo-load on mega portions of mostaccioli, eggplant Parmesan and half-moon calzones oozing with creamy mozzarella. Wine snobs dine here, too, to see what new bottles oenophile Dave is serving up from his ambitious global collection.

This bare-bones grocery store on the edge of Logan Square has a secret. Crammed in the back behind rows of provisions is a bar-stool-only Cuban dive pumping out tasty pressed Cuban sandwiches (served with paper-thin, hand-cut french fries) and wickedly strong Cuban coffee, all at bargain prices. It also whips up killer fried pork ribs and falling-off-the-bone stewed oxtail (both served with black beans and rice). For an even cheaper alternative, go for the dollar hotbox items up front; the papa rellena (a huge, crispy potato ball packed with ground beef) is a great snack on the go.

You don't hear much about this big, bilevel restaurant in the Gold Coast. But there's something to be said about an Italian spot that's outlasted countless restaurants in the 17 years it's been open. We think its secret is keeping things simple: The warm and inviting dining room and curvaceous bar entice diners, and the food doesn't disappoint. There's the impeccably fresh buffalo mozzarella; hearty bowls of cheesy, housemade gnocchi; and a wine list that—like everything else—is nothing if not dependable.

It's hard not to look at the long lines that plague breakfast joints like this and wonder what could possibly be worth the wait. Luckily, brisk service ensures that the wait will never be too long, and full thermoses of coffee set on your table promise that you'll always have a full cup. Java is crucial when navigating this sunny café's lengthy menu: The pages are packed with options like sweet, plate-size pancakes, thin feta frittatas and classic diner sandwiches like BLTs (or BLTEs, which add an egg to the mix).

Formerly a dingy dive that served up some great Indo-Pak food, Usmania currently resides across the street into a newer, swankier spot. Luckily, the food is the same. The straightforward menu yields well-executed versions of Pakistani standards like nehari and kebabs, and the rice biryanis are great, particularly the one made with mutton. Also, make sure to try the delicious nan and some of the daily specials to keep things interesting. The warm staff earnestly tries to live up to its claim of being "the finest family restaurant in Chicago," and as you luxuriate in the new dining room, sipping on a mango lassi (no booze is offered, and it's not BYOB), you can see it's not far off.

The "international" part of the name comes from the fact that this Lincoln Park spot serves both Mexican and Caribbean fare, but you'll do best forgoing anything tropical-sounding and sticking with traditional, well-executed South-of-the-Border staples. Creamy guacamole, enchiladas in smoky mole sauce and nicely grilled carne asada somehow seem fancier served in the candlelit dining room, but beware of potent margaritas that can make the meal seem a little out of focus.

You'll find more than lattes and shrink-wrapped muffins at this bright and airy new coffeehouse. The pastry spread includes tasty croissants and cinnamon rolls, but the real draw is the small menu of sweet and savory crêpes, including Nutella and banana, cinnamon and sugar, and spinach and goat cheese. There are also a couple of decent quiches and a few salads (some hit and some miss—we're not big fans of strawberries on salad, especially in winter). It's all served with the nicest flatware we've ever seen at a coffee shop—supershiny and pleasantly heavy in our hands.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, 49B, X49, 78, 81

column7: The boys behind Schoolyard, Brownstone, Kirkwood and Gaslight offer starving suits everything from simple sliders to fat-daddy steaks. A happy-hour menu, global wine list and a couple dozen beers look to draw after-work crowds.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark. Bus: 22, 156.

column7: It only lasted about three months, but dinner at Dodo—like the restaurant's namesake extinct bird—is no more. But chef-owner Kim Dalton has the chops to keep this breakfast-and-lunch spot alive. She keeps us coming back for the a.m. standbys that got us hooked in the first place: the veggie-packed tofu scramble and the thick Greek yogurt topped with housemade granola and berries. During lunch, Dalton elevates simple, unpretentious food like thick, indulgent ground-beef sandwiches and daily straightforward soups into something special. Her greatest feat, though, is the Japanese pancake, a savory, veggie-stuffed flapjack that actually makes cabbage sound appealing for breakfast.
column204: Best chef to wake up to

column7: Judging by the mob scene on opening weekend, folks in Lincoln Square have been frothing at the mouth for a new Moroccan restaurant. It's confounding how a tiny storefront lit by one fluorescent bulb and devoid of much charm besides a rug or two decorating the burnt pumpkin–colored walls could attract such a rabid crowd—until you taste the food. From the pickled baby artichoke hearts, olives and warm pita plopped on your table as soon as you sit down, to the crevette pil pil's plump shrimp swimming in a light, earthy tomato sauce, to the Sultan's Tagine's falling-off-the-bone braised lamb shank resting on a bed of sweet peas, the exquisite food eclipses the erratic service typical of a just-born restaurant.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Sitting by the windows overlooking Millennium Park has its pros and cons: Watching the crowds is transfixing, but with food this good, you want your attention focused on your meal. The whisper-thin beef carpaccio starter is sprinkled with Parmesan chunks and juicy capers; mango is the perfect foil for the shredded duck in the warm duck salad; and the porcinis encrusting the flatiron steak impart a subtle woody flavor. We can think of no better last meal than the Kobe burger: melted Gorgonzola topping thick-as-your-fist beef between buttery brioche, served with a heap of thin, crispy fries. Skip the defib—strap on some skates to get your heart pumping again.
column8: Private party room(s)ViewsOutdoor seatingKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison; Red, Blue to Monroe. Bus: 3, 4, X4, 14, 26, 145, 147, 148, 151

column7: Though they have a heavy hand with the tahini here (the hummus tastes more like sesame seeds than garbanzo beans), the kebabs at this strip-mall joint are among the best in this area (and considering it's the apex of the Middle Eastern scene, that's saying something). The kefta kebab is where the grill man excels, but the chicken and steak kebabs (as well as the shawarma) are equally juicy, well-seasoned affairs. Of course, it's natural to want hummus, baba, spinach pies, etc., with this food, but stay focused—that's what the other joints on this strip are for.

It's not the only Guatemalan spot in town, but with two decades under its belt, it might just be the oldest. Start off with the bright pink tamarind-and-rum cocktail, and you'll blend right into the cozy room's color scheme. The menu is heavy on seafood, with standouts that include grilled tilapia, grilled shrimp and seafood soup. The excellent chuchitos (Guatemalan tamales) are something like a loose lettuce wrap, and the burritos aren't your standard Mexican variation but instead emphasize fresh vegetables and black beans. A handful of Guatemalan beers and desserts such as mollete bread pudding seal the deal.

Sure, you could order a meat or seafood dish at this hole-in-a-wall joint, but why? Regulars are willing to endure slowish service to enjoy fresh, vegan mock-meat dishes. Start with flavorful tofu- and seitan-studded hot-and-sour soup and plump soy gluten pot stickers—the latter are perfectly fried and surprisingly nongreasy. You'll need restraint to keep from inhaling the honey-kissed sautéed seitan dish in one breath, but take a pass on the sludgy-sauced mock-meat cashew entrée. Don't leave without sampling a lychee tapioca smoothie.
column184: Now called YUMMY YUMMY ASIAN CUISINE

column7: If you've never been to a Harold's, you must not live in or frequent the South Side. For years, outposts of the "chicken king" empire have multiplied like rabbits, making it nearly impossible to go five blocks without bumping into another shack turning out the best fried chicken around. So out of 50 or so locations, why did we choose to highlight this one? After sampling our weight in wings, we believe it's the best. Order the four- or six-wing plate, ask for it "fried hard" (extra crispy) with pepper (lemon-pepper if you want zing) and get both mild and hot sauce on the side for dipping. (It's 27 cents for sauce on the side, but do it unless you want your chicken drenched.) If you can't make it home without tearing into the bag, prepare for your car to be covered in crunch.
column198: Other locations include 1361 N Milwaukee Ave (773-252-2424)

column7: The buzz on chef Homaro Cantu has been reaching fever pitch lately: He's working with the government to "end world hunger" with edible paper, cooking with military-issued lasers and going up against Iron Chef Morimoto in a soon-to-be-aired battle. But what's going on in the mad scientist's restaurant? More of the same, and always something new. Extending his new green color scheme ("It's futuristic and energetic," he says) to the dining room, stark-white has morphed into mossy-green, with warmer results. On the plate, it's anybody's guess what the night's tasting menu holds, but current trickery includes a play on Vietnamese egg-drop soup in which frozen egg- and microgreen-pellets are dropped tableside into steaming soup, and triple-seared beef is paired with "caramelaserized wine." Yes, a laser is involved in a wine pairing.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine list

column7: You can take Emergen-C, pop Tylenol and swig DayQuil all you want, but you're never going to get over that cold without some chicken-noodle soup. Luckily, with three locations (find 'em at www.thesoupbox.com), you're likely to find Soupbox's freshly made soup somewhere nearby. This location also features made-to-order salads for everyday eating, but when you get sick, go for one of the 12 daily soups on offer. We like the delicious (but slightly thin) vegetarian chili and hearty Southwestern bean, but we wouldn't recommend the rich, soy cream–based clam chowder if you're all stuffed up; just use it as inspiration to get better.
column198: Other locations: 500 W Madison St (312-993-1019); 2943 N Broadway (773-938-9800)

column7: It's no surprise that Henry Chang's new restaurant, housed in his former Valhalla Wine Shop and across the street from his überstylized eatery Ping Pong, is just as slick, sexy and affected as the rest of his projects. But it's shocking that such a cool-conscious place uses the word japas (Japanese tapas). As it turns out, the joke is on traditionalists: Small plates of dishes such as fresh tofu sprinkled with chile oil and peanuts and prosciutto topped with ponzu sauce, crunchy toasted shallots and charred asparagus make for brilliant, unexpected combinations of flavors. And the sushi (never frozen) is simply impeccable. Yet the biggest surprise is the service: Unlike across the street, the servers here actually smile.
column8: Outdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Late-night dining
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 152

column7: This place is serious about Neapolitan pizza: A custom-built, oak-stoked oven kicks out bubbling beauties with perfectly charred peaks and valleys in less than two minutes. The hand-formed crust is paper-thin at the center, thicker toward the edges and has the unmistakable chew of a true Neapolitan pie. Aside from the simple marinara or Margherita (which can also be had with fresh buffalo mozz that's flown in each Thursday), toppings run the gamut from fennel-flecked sausage to bitter rapini to prosciutto ribbons. Add a humble Italian wine-and-beer list, after-dinner options such as espresso and limoncello, and you've got a great night out.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best Thin-Crust Pizza

column7: The weather's cooled off, which means this Italian spot from two Coco Pazzo vets—chef Tony Priolo and wine guru Ciro Longobardo—is getting cozy with its newly unveiled fall menu. Priolo is taking the cue and infiltrating his menu of regional Italian pastas, pizzas and antipasti with fall flavors: Take, for instance, oven-dried tomatoes served with basil and buffalo mozzarella; chickpea-flour fries with Parmesan; mushroom-topped pizza; and braised short ribs over soft polenta.
column8: Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyNotable wine list
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: The Urban Oasis Award (best patio)

column7: Looking for great Cuban food? Wind through the grocery aisles of this "food mart" to the rear corner and you'll find a dozen tables, a friendly counterman and a wall lined with brightly colored signs touting house specialties. (Grab an English menu from the counter if your Spanish is weak.) You can find Colombian and Mexican fare, but it's the Cuban eats that have drawn regulars here for 30 years. Bring friends and share the standouts to try a bit of everything: the Cuban sandwich (the best in town), pork-filled tamale, crunchy bacalao (salt cod), the roasted pork dinner with yellow rice, an order each of garlicky green and caramelized sweet plantains, and a round of the perfectly rich and slightly sweet cafe con leche.

Take a pass on pastas and break out the chopsticks: Little Italy has a sushi spot. With one 20-year vet chef at the sushi bar and another in the kitchen, both cooked and raw food get their due. Straight-up sushi joins classics like katsu (pounded fried pork, chicken or beef) and bento boxes of teriyaki, tempura, rice and ginger salad.

Chef-owner Theo Gilbert is a stickler for buzz words like seasonal, local and organic, but he's not all talk. In fact, ingredient availability dictates the menu so much that by the time we report on our latest cold-weather eats at this charming, brick-walled neighborhood spot, they may not be around. Get in quick for capellacci di zucca, or "pope's hats," with squashes and parmigiano in a sage-brown butter sauce or the whole grain pappardelle with Paulina Market sausage, roasted peppers and onions. The tiny kitchen gets hit hard on busy nights so, for the wait, start with tortellini in brodo–a white truffle scented broth, but save room for the honey-lemon panna cotta.

Here to prevent Loop lunchers from sandwich overload is this Mediterranean café, which touts itself as serving "fresh and healthy, low fat and low cholesterol" food. It's cute that the owners think we're interested in the health benefits, isn't it? They don't seem to realize that we're going to crowd this place for their hearty kefta kebab, daily specials such as the Moroccan chicken and anything having to do with the fluffy, dill-flecked rice. If we're still looking for health food after all that, we'll have to go somewhere else.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake. Bus: 22, 24, 156.

column7: This cavernous space's ambience is a bit spartan, but it's comfortable, family-friendly, and the staff is always welcoming. Expect a fairly quiet office crowd midday, but at night the joint is packed with loud, young professionals at the bar up front, while families who want to hear themselves talk sit at tables in the back. Notables from the cross-section of satisfying, if standard, pasta dishes and entrées include pasta with besciamelle sauce and chicken breast encrusted with pistachios. Numerous daily specials—garbage-style salads, "catch of the day" seafood dishes, red-sauce pastas—are posted on boards for those who get bored with the regular menu.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Edison Park. Bus: 68, Pace 209

column7: The term "barbecue joint" usually brings to mind a hole-in-the-wall with a grease-splattered pitmaster. This is not Merle's. With big screen TVs, an ample bar, and pictures of Elvis scattered throughout, the ambience is closer to Applebee's than authentic. What it lacks in atmosphere, it makes up for by offering decent barbecue at a decent price in a location with decent public transportation options and parking. Tables are set with rolls of paper towels rather than napkins so you can get to work on St. Louis ribs, baby back ribs or the other finger-lickin' meat of your choice. The corn on the cob side can be mushy, but the fries and sacriligeous broccoli hold their own.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 202, 203, 204, Pace 208, Pace 250

column7: There's always a wait for a table at the Lucky Platter. All three square meals are favorites with both locals and NU students, who crowd into the small booths and tables. Peruse the extensive collection of art on the walls while you wait, and once you're seated, try the veggie-potato hash at breakfast, the jambalaya at lunch and Tandoori chicken at dinner. The sides are fantastic: Mashed potatoes and gravy, sweet-potato fries and gratis corn bread are all equally tasty.

Come hungry to this South Indian vegetarian spot, because the portion sizes are enormous. Start with rasam, a spicy cilantro-and-tamarind soup that's hotter than a Bikram-yoga session (a few bites of rasa vada—lentil doughnuts served with an array of chutneys—temper the heat). A delicious variety of breads—including poori (think fluffy and fried) and a fantastically crispy, record album-size dosai rice cake—complement the coconut chutney and various curries of the Royal Thali sampler. We've had better palak paneer before—Mysore's version is a touch too sweet—but when you leave stuffed and toting a huge carryout bag of leftovers, there's no arguing with the value.

Lincoln Parkers who mourned the loss of Las Fuentes, the casual Mexican restaurant that formerly occupied this space, will be happy to hear that Tepatulco's chef, Geno Bahena, is supplementing his menu with a handful of Las Fuentes' most popular dishes. Crispy chiles rellenos, queso fundito with shrimp or sausage, and carne asada are aimed at bringing in diners with more, shall we say, Anglo tastes, while those seeking adventure can still dig into Bahena's mole-smothered signatures.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: West Logan Square must have been pretty hungry before this simple sandwich-and-shake shack came along, because now that it's here, locals are cramming in and eating everything in sight. That means that not everything on the chalkboard menu will be in stock, but if you're lucky you'll snag a bowl of thick, peppery, housemade minestrone. Sandwiches (such as the Reuben, filled with thick slices of beef and mercifully light on Thousand Island dressing) and hand-dipped shakes are the stars of the show, but it wasn't until we tried the superb sweet-potato pie that we truly understood what all the fuss was about.

The kids from Lane Tech High School flock to this mod version of a neighborhood soda shop—tucked into the corner of a strip mall—to sip funky, fruity bubble teas in a rainbow of colors and flavors; play board games; and take advantage of the free Wi-Fi. Tapioca-laced teas (which originated in Taiwan) can be ordered clear, milky or frozen in flavors that run the gamut from strawberry to red bean. There's also a small selection of sandwiches, instant ramen noodles and penny candy, all served by a supersmiley staff.

Even those who know the local food scene may not have heard of Le Petit Paris. Too bad for themÉit just means you are more likely to get a seat at this excellent French bistro. The seasonally changing menu is full of French classics, like the mushroom-laden beef bourguignonne and luscious veal "Marengo," and half-price bottles of wine on Thursdays never disappoint.

North Suburban diners can skip the trek to Devon Avenue and settle into this comfy spot. Thanks to an owner who hails from Nepal, the standard Indian menu also offers a handful of Nepalese specialties, the best of which are the mo mo dumplings packed with spiced chicken and served with fiery, creamy achaar dipping sauce; the mild braised goat in tomato-based curry; and the rich trio of black-eyed peas, bamboo shoots and potatoes. Of the Indian items, the vegetarian "special dinner" is delicious, and anything done "vindaloo" is no joke, so order it only if your tongue can handle a scorching. The $9 lunch buffet is a good way to sample the menu without breaking the bank.

In the bustling Avondale neighborhood, earth-toned walls, hardwood floors, colorful artwork, gracious service and occasional live music qualify as an upscale dining experience. At this Ecuadorian/pan-Latin spot, appetizers (such as the signature piping-hot, tamalelike humita) and desserts (particularly the spongey, sweet corn cake wrapped in a banana leaf) steal the show. Seafood dishes are a bit overpriced for what you get (the $5.95 tilapia lunch special is a better bet), but the juicy churrasco steak is tasty and filling with sides of avocado, fries and eggs. Guatita (peanutty tripe stew) is popular with regulars during colder months, especially when coupled with a cold Mexican beer.
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 60, 80

column7: Ravenswood locals can wave good-bye to Bongo Room, Toast, Orange and all those other funky brunch spots in town. Because now, thanks to Jon Cignarale–himself a veteran of m. henry and Uncommon Ground—they have their own. Dishes like oversize pancakes stuffed with blackberries and topped with orange butter, eggs served "sassy" (atop chorizo hash) and spicy vegan chilaquiles (who knew tofu could be greasy?) are carried through this bright, cheery dining room by the tray-full during the busy weekend brunch. But with the good comes the bad: The wait for tables is already beginning to spill out onto the sidewalk. So the search for the next great, undiscovered brunch spot continues.

Smoky jerk chicken is the main reason to stop in, but don't skip the rest of the menu at this Jamaican favorite. Braised oxtails are meaty, thickly coated with a savory-sweet sauce that melts into the bean-studded rice, and come with braised cabbage and a couple of greaseless plantains. The kick of the moist, spice-rubbed catfish is nice as is, but with a few drops of jerk sauce it becomes a fierce and fiery addiction. Grab a ginger beer and banana pudding to round out the order.

The main event at this Vietnamese hole-in-the-wall is, as the name would suggest, the steaming bowls of pho (pronounced "fuh"), a Vietnamese beef noodle soup that is the perfect elixir on a cold and snowy Chicago day. When bleak weather subsides, switch gears with something bright and springy, like the citrus-kissed beef salad piled with crunchy bits of peanuts, fresh mint and green chiles that add just the right amount of heat.

Americanized Thai restaurants are a dime a dozen, so why is this successful? Two reasons: It's across from Webster Place theater and does a brisk premovie crowd, and the affable chef-owner, Tommy, is revered by regulars as the nicest guy around. When he's not in the dining room kissing babies, he's in the kitchen turning out dependable Thai standards. The crispy shrimp and the lime-dressed chicken salad are good starters, and the duck or the garlic-lemongrass shrimp are tasty entrées. Vegetarians will be happy with the flavorful tofu and crisp veggies that dot nearly a dozen meat-free dishes.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 9, 74

column7: Oh damn, the owners of Katachi transformed its so-so sushi concept into a slick, sophisticated space featuring dim lighting, black wood booths andÉfusion cuisine, though fused with what, we're not sure. Now Katachi maki standbys are joined by head-scratchers like cheesy garlic bread, "bacon stick" (a breadstick wrapped in bacon and sprinkled with Parmesan), New England clam chowder and a pork chop slathered in tomato sauce. Best to stick with the Asian dishes: The donburi set (fresh cuts of fish on sushi rice) and yakisoba are solid, if not inspired, and a limited menu is served until 4am.
column144: El: Red to Sheridan. Bus: 36, 80, X80, 145, 151

column7: Husband-and-wife team Mohammad Islam and Malika Ameen have firmly entrenched themselves in River North's dining scene, giving Merchandise Mart folks an after-work haunt while also maintaining "dining destination" status. As spring slowly creeps in, leeks get crisped alongside roasted lobster, pickled cipollini accompany slow-cooked rabbit, and huckleberries and lemon sorbet brighten up a key lime custard–topped pavlova. Don't have an AIG bonus to blow? The bar menu—offering small plates of salted cod gratin, goose-liver pâté and braised bacon with a honey-tangerine slaw—tops out at $10.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156
column204: The You-Scream-We-Scream Best Ice Cream Award

column7: Should the thick-crust theorists and thin-crust connoisseurs ever stop their quarreling for a night, this is where they'll come together. Because here, the bubbly crust fits somewhere in between those two camps. Whether piled with feta and spinach (like the garlicky Popeye pie) or housemade meatballs and fresh mozz, the simultaneously crispy and fluffy crust never buckles. Nor does it get in the way, so purists on both sides should be satiated. And if they're not, the well stocked beer list (including Fat Tire and the entire Anchor Brewing lineup) can be tapped to calm things down.

Buttermilk pancakes arrive topped with bananas and drizzled with a rum-caramel sauce; an omelette comes stuffed with black truffles, ricotta cheese and arugula; and shaved lamb, herbed goat cheese and carrot purée between slices of multigrain bread make for a hearty breakfast sandwich. Needless to say, this place serves a solid brunch. Come at night and try chef Robert Levitt's slow-roasted Berkshire pork, which falls apart the moment it meets a fork. Other fall flavors to be found include grilled organic chicken with whipped potatoes and seared cod with braised leeks and honey-glazed red potatoes.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49

column7: Serving pizza to the Southwest Side since 1949, Vito and Nick's is the king of thin-crust pizza done Chicago-style. With Old Style on tap and the Bears on TV, surly waitresses shuffle bubbling-hot pies to a full room of revelers. The crispy but pliant crust, tangy sauce and top-quality sausage separate this pizza from other Chicago thin crusts. Sure, the place has other things on the menu, like spaghetti, but it's the pizza that keeps customers loyal through the generations. The wait times for pie can run a little long on weekends, so order your drinks by the pitcher, and enjoy a true Chicago scene.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Start with the savory items if you must—you won't regret digging into the fantastic arancini or the fiercely herbal mint-and-pea fazzoletti. But the focus of this Sicilian bakeshop is desserts like the sfogliatelle cookie (delicate layers of pastry encase orange-kissed ricotta); the cuccidatti butter cookie packed with figs, walnuts and cloves; ricotta-filled cannoli; and the barca di crema, a square of puff pastry filled with cream and topped with amarena cherries that are so intoxicatingly delicious you'll swear they've been soaking in liqueur. Beware that the shop closes early if the day's supply runs dry.
column60: Wed–Sun noon–8pm (closed Mon, Tue; occasionally open late)

column7: Has star chef David Burke given Chicago a steakhouse like no other? Let's put it this way: We've definitely never come across a crab cake quite so deliciously unique (the impeccable meat is shaped like a maki roll and crusted in Japanese pretzels), and the popovers that stand in for bread are a nice twist (even if they were a little burnt). We found the filet to be unstoppably tender and rich; the strip, not so much. And while desserts are creative (fill your own doughnuts), over-the-top desserts are de rigueur at steakhouses. So is it different? Yes. But not so different that your parents won't like it. Which is good, because you'll want them to take you here again and again.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listOutdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: It gets overlooked among the slew of Middle Eastern restaurants that dot this stretch of Kedzie Avenue, but the exceptionally fresh fare puts this Lebanese spot at the head of its class. Pita bread makes for a soft and warm utensil to scoop up moutabal, a spread of eggplant mashed with onions and peppers. Kibbeh is made to order and is one of the least greasy and most flavorful versions in the city. Kebabs—both chicken and kefta—are juicy renderings of high-quality meats. And unlike the restaurant's popular neighbors, there's never a long wait to get inside.

Gluttony grabs hold in this kitschy kitchen, and it doesn't let go until the band plays its last bluesy rockabilly note (usually about 1am). So skip the brisket, ignore the chicken, and resist filling up on the addictive sweet-potato fries: You need to reserve your hunger for "The Rib Sampler." It's a huge plate of baby back ribs, spareribs and rib tips—a pile so big it might intimidate you. But don't worry: The pink, smoky meat pulls off the bone easily and the pockets of fat melt on your tongue, so you'll have no trouble cleaning your plate.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 50, 70

column7: Every time we find ourselves stuck in traffic on the Eisenhower, visions of this spot's BBQ pork noodle soup help to soothe the road rage. The menu here ranges from Cantonese and Szechwan standards like beef with broccoli and kung pao chicken to more exotic dishes like mashed wintermelon crab soup. Pan-fried noodle dishes are a must-order, as are any variety of the unbelievably light and spicy salt-and-pepper seafood dishes. Premium ingredients, great service, and someone with an expert hand in the kitchen makes this one of the suburbs' best-kept secrets.

It may not be as lively as taking a seat at the Cell, but for many Sox fans this bare-bones, wood-paneled room is the best place to catch the game. A couple of beers and a few home runs are all these guys need to nourish them. You, on the other hand, may need a little more. Skip the pasta and go for a muffaletta (an enormous sandwich stuffed with salami, cappicola and provolone, topped with a tapenade) or the "CB&G" sandwich, which piles on succulent roast beef soaking in its own juices. Hoping for something fancier? What are you, a Cubs fan?
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)
column60: Lunch (Mon–Fri), dinner (Tue–Fri), open on weekends during Sox games

column7: Ten items—seven hot, three cold—comprise the menu at this genuinely old-school Northbrook lodge. Still, nobody pays much attention to anything except the beer, the shrimp cocktail and the burgers. As far as shrimp cocktails go, this one is fine, blanketed in a bright cocktail sauce piquant with horseradish. The burgers standout more: Topped with sweet grilled onions and encased in a soft bun, they're so tender an 80-year-old could still chew it. And plenty of them do.

Contrary to dining trends, the Depot is not a "contemporary take on" or an "upscale version of" a diner; it's simply the real thing. Everything on the menu is simple and excellently seasoned: Golden breakfast potatoes get a sprinkling of paprika, big bowls of chili have enough bite to wake your taste buds up (but not burn them off) and the juicy pieces of turkey on the open-faced sandwich are covered in thick, peppery gravy—so much that you may have trouble finding the bread underneath it all. Housemade desserts tempt from behind the counter; sadly, they look better than they taste, so stick with coffee.
column144: El: Blue to Austin Lombard (Forest Park). Bus: 12, 91, Pace 305, Pace 315

column7: If you're into comfort food, huge portions and supporting local farmers, this casual folk art–filled dining room is for you. Current seasonal specials sure to please meat-eaters include braised free-range pork shoulder with roasted kabocha squash and tomatillo-green chile sauce or the grilled grass-fed sirloin with wild mushroom-leek ragout. Vegetarians get plenty of love with dishes like edamame hummus, smoked tofu-veggie chili, a Southwestern falafel burger and killer mac and cheese. If you're finishing up with a show at the adjacent Schubas, prepare to hear the music from a food coma.
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9 (24 hrs), X9 11, 77

column7: This basement trattoria oozes hole-in-the-wall goodness. Expect "homestyle" fare (think housemade doughy delights with rich gravies typical of an Italian grandma). The lost art of complimentary starters lives on with a choice of a fresh mesclun salad or a cup of minestrone. Both starch-o-phobes and the carb-indulgent can leave well fed: The vast menu (plus several daily specials) includes archetypal Italian treasures such as eggplant Parmesan, gnocchi with sausage, portobellos with Gorgonzola and roasted red peppers, and rigatoni smothered in a creamy tomato sauce. Pricing is pretty friendly, but don't even think about BYOB-ing now that they've got a liquor license.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77, 156

column7: This Algerian crêpe place makes the standard French crêperie pale in comparison. You can find the typical butter-and-sugar or banana-and-Nutella combos, served with whipped cream or ice cream, but the savory crêpes are where Icosium lets its Algerian flag fly. Fillings include mostly organic vegetables, halal meats (including merguez, a lamb sausage) and even escargot. Those who are watching their carbs can opt for the same ingredients in salads. Even everyday green tea seems special here, served in a charming teapot with a teacup rimmed in gold with fresh mint leaves on request.
column144: El: Red to Berwyn. Bus: 22 (24 hrs), 50, 92

column7: Owner Brad Rubin scoured the country to research this Jewish deli/diner. His pastrami is tender, fatty and full of flavor; the milk shakes are thick and oversized; matzo balls are enormous, fluffy things; and the brisket is good enough that any grandmother, Jewish or not, would want to claim it. Recent additions to the menu include a vegetarian-friendly tofu scramble and 11 different salads that will satisfy even that picky, meatphobic family member. Does it hold a candle to other Jewish spots in the country? That's hard to say. But Rubin definitely holds his own as the charming/obnoxious host, giving this place enough character to become a fixture in its own right.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, X3, 4, X4, 12

column7: Jerk-chicken huts are as rampant on the South Side as drag queens at a Dolly Parton concert. But thanks to the smiley hospitality of owner Tasha Fisher, a spick-and-span seating area and hefty portions of unforgettable Jamaican classics, this spot shouldn't be lumped in with the rest. Combo dinners save the indecisive: We like the juicy jerk chicken and tender curry goat. Adventurous eaters with a penchant for funky-salty flavors will love the akee, Caribbean fruit sautéed with onions, peppers and saltfish that's perfect with the hush-puppy-like festival bread.

Getting a good meal in Chinatown takes some trial and error, but looking around at other diners' plates can tip you off to a place's specialties. Here, every table is brimming with the pan-fried "salt and spice" shrimp, giant shell-on beauties with a thin layer of crispy crunch. (Ask for chile oil for dipping.) Go family-style and feed four with the shrimp, a heaping bowl of curry-laced Singapore noodles, a plate of garlicky Chinese spinach and a roasted duck with tangy hoisin sauce for dipping. Fresh-fruit smoothies make for the perfect ending.

Given the neighborhood and decor—plasma televisions display faux fireplaces—this pan-Latin joint could be written off as something akin to Chi-Chi's. But it takes only a promising pair of subtle lumpia—Filipino egg rolls stuffed with crab, coconut and longaniza sausage—to realize that this spot deserves a closer look. Tilapia arrives flaking apart after being cooked in paper in a sherry-spiked broth; Chicken Negra Modelo is glazed in its namesake beer and flanked by luscious spinach and cheese chilaquiles; and the Sandwich Coobah is as solid a Cuban sandwich as any other—despite the chain-restaurant–style misspelling.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar

column7: On an otherwise unremarkable stretch of Northwest Highway, this Jefferson Park café stands out. From the front door you'll see decades' worth of vintage goods—Bakelite jewelry, retro toys and other treasures from days gone by—and it's all for sale. So, too, are the Sicilian-style pizza slices and Italian-style pastries, plus smoothies, coffee and tea. There are a few small tables where you can dine among the resale finds, but the best bet is to grab a bar stool at the counter and chat with the friendly staff.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56A, 68 Northwest Hwy. Metra: Metra Pacific NW to Gladstone Park

column7: If you're not the show-tunes type, you may want to keep your distance. Then again, if you're not the show-tunes type, you probably weren't thinking about eating here to begin with, because the cabaret performers (Wed–Sun evenings) are just as important as the food. Dishes such as the meaty shiitake-mushroom pancakes (touched with maple syrup and offset by balsamic vinegar), cerdo relleno (pork loin stuffed with herbs, dried cranberries and pine nuts) and the Tuscan skirt steak are kind of like the performances: They may not be perfect, but they still do the trick.

If you're looking for a reason to venture to Willow Springs, look no further than this restaurant's yard. Situated on a hill lush with shrubbery, flowers, wildlife (the last time we ate here we witnessed two grazing deer) and a gazebo, it's a sight so romantic that even the most bitter divorcée would yearn for her wedding day. And what a tasty wedding it would be. In addition to roasting one hell of a succulent rack of lamb, Chef Jerome Bacle presents three-course Friday night tasting menus themed around a single ingredient like apples, fennel, or recently, thyme—in dishes like mushroom-thyme risotto, roast pork loin and vanilla-bean tapioca with banana-thyme sorbet. All of which is almost—almost—enough to distract you from the view.

Is it a bar? A breakfast place? A deli? A dinner spot? This newbie is supposed to be all four, but a mural of nasty, red-eyed bats is only suited for a sinister school cafeteria. Luckily, the sandwiches and pastries justify overlooking this place's identity crisis: The thick, crusty bread is from Evanston's Bennison's Bakery and sweets come from Ann Arbor, Mich.'s Zingerman's Bakery. From the sandwich menu, we liked the Tabu Club (chicken breast, Muenster, bacon, lettuce and rémoulade on seven-grain) and the Blue Lightning (chicken breast, hot sauce, Muenster, blue-cheese dressing and lettuce on sourdough). Stop by in the morning for free coffee—just avert your eyes from the painting of flying rodents.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingSuburban
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 201, 205, Pace 208

column7: It's 6pm Saturday, we're going to a play that starts at 8pm and we're in the middle of an assholes-to-elbows crowd at this theater-district restaurant. A 90-minute wait for a table? Hell, no—we'll sit at the bright, window-filled bar, where we can order from the full menu and ask the busy bartenders to keep the sidecars coming. We'll skip right to the main course: The steak au poivre, a 12-ounce New York strip, is ridiculously tender and even better topped with caramelized onions. With service this fast, we have plenty of time to linger over one of the baked-in-house desserts and still catch the show.
column8: Outdoor seatingGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Red to Lake; Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs), Pink to Clark/Lake. Bus: 22, 156

column7: If it weren't for the fact that it's located in a brand-spankin'-new strip mall, you'd think this sunny café had been the neighborhood hub for years. The smooth service and easy-going atmosphere are thanks to the Italian family who runs the joint. The Ruffolos (who are related to the owners of Bridgeport's Franco's Ristorante) have extended the most important meal of the day to cater to late-risers, serving their hangover-helpers until 3pm. Whether it's dressed-up omelettes or straight-up bacon and eggs, all breakfasts come with the namesake hash browns. But our vote goes to the "killer" hash browns, a massive attack of potatoes topped with cheese, onions, sour cream and cornflakes that's baked to bubbly perfection.

If you can walk by this place and not be drawn in by the sight of plump, juicy rotisserie chickens rotating over smoldering coals just on the other side of the window, you're either a vegetarian or a moron. Assuming you're neither, get into this Colombian eatery, order the droolworthy chicken, and don't stop there. Try the cheesy corn cakes, meat-filled turnovers, tangy marinated skirt steaks topped with bright green chimichurri (think Latin American pesto), sweet plantains and fresh fruit drinks.

This clubby River North spot might surprise you by turning out some pretty expertly prepared steaks and pastas, so as long as you're simply looking for solid, American fare, you'll do fine. More adventurous diners should stick to cocktails and enjoy the beautiful outdoor space, where padded wicker furniture and plenty of greenery serves as the backdrop for the even prettier crowd.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Thankfully, this pan-Asian newcomer, which is tucked into an out-of-the-way strip mall, has fantastic food. Without the refreshing wasabi-spiked grapes amuse; bacon-wrapped, vinegar-and-soy–glazed scallop; and superfresh maki (try the white tuna roll drizzled in truffle oil), we'd have run screaming—the service was that bizarre. Walking into the barren restaurant, we were escorted to a holding pen–like room where we waited for five minutes until our table was "ready," which essentially meant pulling out the chairs. Servers rearranged utensils with agonizingly slow precision after each course, and asked how we liked the food a dozen times. By the time we got the skippable desserts, we were ready to bolt. No matter—how long can it be before a Cold Stone Creamery moves in next door?

Mornings at Meli appear to be the epitome of a picture-perfect breakfast: Fresh juices are made to order; omelettes are fluffy and made from Phil's "cage free" eggs; "Meli toast," the signature French toast, is drizzled with honey; and (slightly thin) marmalades are made in-house. It's not revolutionary food, but it's solid, and so long as you skip the disappointing soups and sandwiches served during lunch, you may just have yourself a new place to call second home.

It started out as a coffee shop, a place to sip the strong, sweet, spicy coffee and teas Morocco is known for. But once owner Boucheib Khribech started whipping up batches of his couscous (at first, only on Fridays), his customers got hooked. So now, along with pots of tea, you're likely to see plates of Khribech's thick hummus, juicy kefta kebabs and signature lamb tagine, with a big shank that falls apart before your fork even touches it. Order a hookah and smoke one of the flavored tobaccos while finishing up those last drops of tea.

We could pretend that we wait all winter to make the trek out to this Oak Park mainstay. But the truth is, we've been sneaking in visits all winter long. These folks have been making their rich, fatty ice cream since 1910, and they haven't survived all this time on summer business alone. Since the restaurant portion of Petersen's closed, the savories are no longer available. But that's okay—it was always merely a preamble to the hot-fudge sundaes—two mounds of luscious vanilla flanked by a pitcher of the viscous sauce—the tall root-beer floats and the infinitely creamy milk shakes.
column144: El: Green to Harlem/Lake. Bus: Pace 305, Pace 307, Pace 309, Pace 313, Pace 318

column7: This is it? The man behind TRU, Ambria and Everest started his Lettuce Entertain You empire with this shabby joint? Opened in 1971—with, we're assuming, much of the same look it has today—this tightly packed hamburger shack is a reminder that Richard Melman has just as many casual, fast-foodish joints as he does fine-dining rooms under his belt. We'd give him credit for his range alone, but then we'd be forgetting about the thick, juicy, antihealthy "Gruntburger," topped with addictive fried onions and blue-cheese dressing; the sloppy buffalo wings; the spoonable milk shakes with thick whipped cream; and the world's first salad bar that, despite being a salad bar, is pretty good.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 73

column7: Sweets and beats are the name of the game at this late-night dessert lounge. No alcohol is on offer, but in addition to coffee and tea, oversize slices of cakes are served (six signature flavors include red velvet, German chocolate and lemon). The cakes are brought in from 75th Street's Brown Sugar Bakery, but the DJ-driven sounds—ranging from jazz to hip-hop—are homespun.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 12, 24, 21, 29, 62

column7: The Jamaican-born chef at this mostly carryout restaurant goes by the nickname Doctor C, but the only prescriptions this doctor writes are for authentic dishes from his homeland: Jerk chicken and catfish, red beans and rice, oxtail, curried goat, and stewed chicken.

You'd think that in Randolph Row's ever-evolving restaurant climate that the granddaddy of the block either would have become obsolete or changed with the times. It's done neither. The decor still looks like Drew Carey's Mimi and Dame Edna got in a catfight; the Frenchie bistro menu originally developed by long-moved-on chef Michael Kornick remains relatively intact even though chef Paul Wildermuth has taken the reigns; and the crowd fills every single jewel-toned seat in the house, especially on weekends. The onion soup, spit-roasted chicken, steak frites and unbeatable apple tarte Tatin continue to satisfy, even with flaming makis just across the street.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: The thin-versus-thick debate means nothing at the original Pompei, which has been making traditional thickish, square, Italian bakery–style pizza for the neighborhood since 1909. Pompei has fancier digs and a gussied-up menu these days, luring healthy types from the nearby medical centers for crisp salads with addictive housemade dressings. Scoot through the long cafeteria lines with the diehards who come in for slices of sausage, hand-cut pastas with gargantuan meatballs, and classic pepper-and-egg sandwiches.

The primarily meat-based menu is pretty idiot-proof at this no-frills Nigerian restaurant; you simply point to one of the color pictures. Carnivores won't be disappointed with the tender-to-the-bone beef and chicken, or the wintertime pepper soup with goat, but hard-core vegetarians will have a tough time here, though they can count on the sassy owner to help construct a meal out of entrée sides like black-eyed peas with white rice and überspicy chile sauce, dodo (fried plantains) and soft yam porridge. Regardless of whether you go with meat or veg, bring oodles of ice-cold beer to fight off the searing heat.
column93: B and Q Afro Root Cuisine
column186: B and Q Afro Root Cuisine

column7: If you thought a chimney crashing through the ceiling and obliterating the kitchen below could keep Club Lago down, then you have obviously never been to Club Lago. Recovery was never in question for the feisty, 57-year-old pasta joint. Despite new paint and new beer taps, the place looks exactly the same and is even staffed by the same servers (save the lone new girl), so it's easy to regress to old habits: massive portions of lasagna, soft roast beef on white bread, watery carafes of Chianti and—this is crucial—some pasta with Lago's meat sauce.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: The Viagra Award for Staying Power (57 years strong)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66
El: Blue to Belmont. Bus: 52 California, 77 (24 hours)

column7: Chef-owner Alex Cheswick has turned his Grand Avenue restaurant into a contemporary food–lover's destination. Signs of summer are popping up all over, from a fried-green tomato salad with a lemon-thyme vinaigrette to gnocchi tossed with zucchini and yellow squash. Two different prix-fixe menus are available for the penny pinchers, one for $25 earlier in the week (Mon–Wed) and another for $35 later (Thu–Sat). Most important, both offer a flight of cupcakes for dessert.
column144: El: Blue to Grand. Bus: 8, 9, X9, 65

column7: As is usually the case with pan-Latin or pan-anything joints, Olé Olé puts out myriad dishes, but nothing is exceptional. That's not to say that some dishes aren't solid—the hot and flaky picadillo empanadas are a good appetite-inducer, stuffed with sirloin, onion, raisins and egg. Made-to-order guacamole is creamy and impressively fresh, though our batch, which we ordered at "medium" heat, was pretty mild. Camarones con naranja y tequila is a nice, simple dish: The shrimp are well cooked and the sauce has a tequila tang. It's a dish that speaks to the restaurant's biggest strength: Its potent margaritas, mojitos and caipirinhas.

The name of this casual spot in the Glen pays homage to the bustling development's predecessor: Glenview Naval Air Station. But the aeronautical theme (flights of wine excluded) ends there. The global-inspired menu jumps around from light, crispy spring rolls with three dipping sauces to feta and sun-dried tomato–topped Mediterranean chicken. The "stuffed" bone-in pork chop arrived sans stuffing, but the heaping helping of creamy mashed sweet potatoes offset our disappointment. Herb-crusted rack of lamb served with a mustard-cream sauce or lightly seared scallops over swiss chard are better options. Save room for Carol's Famous Cookie Sundae. Frankly, we'd never heard of it, but once word gets out, Carol's going to be a busy lady.

The original Borinquen (it's one of three) is also the busiest. Local Puerto Ricans and Rican food lovers alike populate this authentic spot from the time the first café con leche is slurped down to the minute the last jibarito sandwich (steak between crispy pounded plantains) is consumed. Juicy onion-flecked steak, garlic-smothered plantains, crispy empanadas, yellow rice with pigeon peas and seafood salads are found on most tables in the dining room. The smooth flan is ripe for seconds, and a walk-up counter does a brisk take-out business if you're on the go.
column198: Other locations: 3020 N Central Ave (773-622-8570); 3811 N Western Ave (773-442-8001

column7: North Siders: the wait is over. The chicken king has arrived and is bringing the city's best chicken with him. The latest location for the iconic South Side fried chicken empire boasts the same menu of finger-lickin' goodness. For the newbies, go for the wings, request "fried hard," with pepper and smothered in both hot and mild sauce.

A fire forced this sunny, Greek-tinged breakfast favorite to shutter two years ago, but it recently reopened with an overhauled menu to match its renovated digs. Breakfast specialties include the open-faced lox bagel sandwich, baklava waffle and a spinach and feta cheese omelet. Like the breakfast offerings, the endless lunch and dinner options–ranging from club sandwiches and seafood to burgers and pasta–are typical, though some would call them classic.

In the wee hours of the morning, the industrial laborers at this 24-7 stainless-steel–dominated diner just south of the Cell fill up on steak and eggs platters, pancakes and hash browns to tide themselves over until noon. When the lunch whistle blows, however, it's Kevin's eponymous burger, "the One and Only," that the hardhat crew favors. You can also get cheese on your "One and Only," a hand-formed patty, seasoned with a secret blend of spices.

Lincoln Square's Pizza D.O.C. must be suffering from an inferiority complex since its prettier, more interesting sister opened in Evanston. The bright space houses a wood-fired oven that churns out 29 varieties of the original location's signature thin-crust, uncut 12-inch pizzas. Don't miss the spaghetti alle vongole e bottarga, a perfectly seasoned plate of pasta and clams with a nice crunch from dried roe. If you're trying to limit your carbs, the mahi mahi with garlicky capers and olives won't seem like a sacrifice at all.

Martial Noguier could have slowed down now that he's got a cushy hotel job at the Sofitel. Instead, he's putting out some of the best French food in town. His dishes—delicate hamachi carpaccio, peppery tenderloin au poivre—brim with intricate flavors and textural details. A new spring lunch menu (available Monday–Friday from 11:30am–5pm) showcases some of his favorite farmers' market finds in dishes like a Camembert cheese sandwich with honey truffle butter, apple salad and roasted hazelnuts served on homemade brioche or a marinated salmon filet served with zucchini spaghetti, carrot puree, star anise and veal jus.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: Best Revival Act (getting Martial Noguier to revive Sofitel's restaurant)

column7: The trend of cutting-edge Spanish cooking hasn't yet reached this tapas bar, which serves up small plates that are tried-and-true. Chicken croquettes have a hot, crisp crunch that gives way to a creamy center; slices of tortilla Española are tall and savory; and monkfish flakes apart in its delicious broth. There are some weird dishes on the menu—a cold noodle salad topped with crispy duck confused the hell out of us. But when the weather is warm and you're sitting in the back garden slowly draining a pitcher of dry sangria, it's easy to let a little misstep slide.

This counter—like every good Jewish deli—is manned by workers who are gruff, efficient and impatient. The food is equally no-frills: Thinly sliced corned beef is piled on high; lox platters include red onion, cream cheese and tomato, but lettuce stands in for capers (which are available for an extra charge per request); housemade blintzes are small pockets of delicious creaminess served on paper plates; and coffee is self-serve. Chicken soup is on the menu, too, but this place is situated in a pharmacy, so if that doesn't do the trick, the cold meds are just a few feet away.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 36, 50

column7: If we told you that Bridgeport's best diner was connected to a gas station, would you believe us? If you didn't, you'd miss out on housemade, chunky French onion soup; table-flamed saganaki with a hot golden crust; enormous Greek salads; and a juicy baked chicken doused with lemon and dried herbs that's worth the 45-minute wait to prepare it. Is the Friday fried fish special the best in the city? Hardly—it's the one dish we could do without. But hey, it's this or a gas station hot dog.

This diner's long been a neighborhood favorite for it's super-friendly service (especially from owner Gus, who renamed the joint a few years ago to honor his mom), thick milkshakes (try the peanut butter) and all-day breakfast. The massive menu is all over the map, from penne di portabella to teriyaki chicken. But we stick with the diner staples that Stella's does best: massive 1/2-pound burgers, gargantuan egg skillets, and fun takes on fried foods, like Tabasco-spiked onion rings.

The Beverly neighborhood breaks out of its friendly tavern mode with this upscale French bistro that's more contemporary chic than country chic. Chef Aaron Browning earned his Franco stripes in the revered local kitchens of Le Vichyssoise and Everest, but here, his menu gives classic French dishes a dose of contemporary flair, with a focus on season. For spring, Browning is doing a Michigan asparagus and shiitake mushroom soup, as well as a goat cheese and ratatouille tart. The new lunch menu features simple fare like a house-roasted turkey breast sandwich with alfalfa sprouts, tomato and avocado mayonnaise.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)

column7: The couple who runs this tidy Thai joint are a bit unpredictable as far as sticking to regular hours, but the loyalists who flock there don't seem to mind making a quick phone call before heading out. That's thanks in part to the owners' sweet demeanor, but mainly due to the tasty eats. Most of the salads have the sour-salty-spicy kick Thai food is known for; our favorites are the gingery ground pork with peanuts (nam sod) and the grilled shrimp with lemongrass. The perfectly balanced "kang" green curry is packed with bamboo, eggplant, basil and your choice of meat or tofu and will leave you quite satisfied.

If you're like us, you've walked by this Wrigleyville African restaurant countless times, always curious but never venturing inside. Time to take the plunge. Start with fried yams: crispy, starchy slices served with a slightly spicy tomato sauce for dipping. Or get your yam fix with the "House Special," a mixed plate of sweet caramelized plantains, savory yam porridge and your choice of fish, meat or chicken (the tilapia, immersed in yet another spicy pepper sauce, is a good bet). After one meal you'll no longer be curious about what's inside—but you may have a problem walking by without stopping in.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: If this cozy bakery-slash-café offers what its name portends, the afterlife will be pretty sweet. Baked-from-scratch goods, including cakes, cookies, cupcakes and scones are the real draw, but the weekend brunch (served until 3pm) offers favorites like buttermilk pancakes and breakfast casserole with ham, red peppers and cheese. Lunch and dinner focus on salads, sandwiches and a small selection of comfort entrées like chicken and biscuits, chicken potpie and meat loaf–all made with reliably fresh ingredients.

Who would have guessed that pure nirvana comes in three varieties: mild, hot and suicide? Chicken wings are the only reason to walk into this grungy NU dive: plump and double-fried, the wings are coated with one of three housemade sauces. Hardcore types go for either the hot sauce or the vinegary jalapeño suicide version, which packs a hint of sweetness with its heat. Newbies may scoff at the ranch dressing served for dipping instead of blue cheese, but we think it cools the palate just enough to ready us for the next round.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 205 Chicago

column7: The dramatic space and heavily choreographed service here are dead giveaways that this place is a chain (it's one of the first of a new concept from Houlihan's, Inc). Luckily, the food doesn't taste like it comes from a chain. Seafood is flown in daily, and the fish is full-flavored (which is good, considering that the house preparation is simply to grill and butter it).
