A golden filet of halibut gets a more elaborate treatment, served over a delicious sweet-potato hash. But for the most part, this kitchen lets the food speak for itself, and it's dignified enough that you'll like what it has to say.

The latest project from Jonathan Segal—a partner in Japonais, Le Passage and P.J. Clarke's—offers a menu of nothing but mini portions. All of the eats—from cheeseburgers to a cucumber-dill "high tea minnie"—are teeny-tiny and served in quantities of three, six or a dozen, and the retro decor is going for a '40s feel. Cue the models and the guys who love them.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: Be prepared to grab a margarita at next-door El Cid while you wait for a seat to open at this tapas joint—there's almost always a wait, and the bar remains packed throughout the night. While you're sipping, remind yourself what you're waiting for: spice-rubbed pork with a crunchy sprinkling of pistachio; cheese-and-mushroom–stuffed red peppers plated on a creamy chickpea puree; and a crema Catalana packed with cinnamon. Resist that second margarita if you can—these are tapas you'll want to remember the next day.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 76

column7: The name (pronounced "shnee pek") refers to the runny nose–inducing, housemade habanero salsa, but the truth is, everything is so masterfully executed there's no need to douse dishes with fire. Must-haves include Yucatecan specialties like tacos de cochinita, rich pork tacos cut by pickled onions, and papadzules, housemade tortillas stuffed with egg and topped with sprightly pumpkin-seed sauce. If the relleno negro tacos are on offer, order as many as you can—the shredded pork-chicken-beef mixture is immersed in a midnight-black sauce with throat-tickling heat and endless flavor. You won't have room for the chilled, citrus-kissed, roasted pumpkin slices, but definitely take them to go.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: Now you can get a side of Southern eats with your live music. FitzGerald's has enlisted Oprah's favorite, the Wishbone minichain, to take up residence in its adjacent restaurant. Expect the same blackened catfish you'd find at the city locations, plus weekend brunch.

The lazy Susans atop each table are the first clues to this Chinatown favorite's specialty: large portions meant for sharing. Bring a big group and key in on the family dinner portion of the menu, which offers several meal options based on the size of your clan. The "family for four," for example, includes the soup of the day, shrimp, lobster, Peking duck, orange beef Chengdu, fried rice and a vegetable–so much food, you may not have room enough for that post-feast fortune cookie.

This tiny gem is a shining star among the myriad Mexican joints populating this strip of Logan Square. Breakfast choices run heavy, with huevos (eggs) mentioned no less than 15 times on the menu. Get your daily quota in tortas, sandwiches or burritos that head south of the border with a twist. Toasty Cuban sandwiches and Mexican molletes (vegetarian pizzas) keep company with American favorites like Philly cheesesteaks and char cheeseburgers. The café con leche, this spot's wildly potent namesake, is a lip-smacking way to rev up for an afternoon of bargain shopping nearby.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 76, 82

column7: Locals tend to know the best spots for a taste of home, and so do Chicago's Finest, which explains a near-constant cop presence. Every seat in this popular Chinese eatery is usually taken, and portions here are gargantuan, so it's best to share everything. Go old-school indulgent with a tasty eight-pack of crab rangoon and move on to a crazy-tender order of Mongolian beef loaded with scallions. The garlic eggplant has none of the sweet spark the Thais give it, so skip that and splurge for the house specialty of salt-and-pepper shrimp.

We're not going to pretend that this place isn't tourist hell (the last time we saw more Wicked sweatshirts wasÉwell, never). But if you can deal with the long waits and the T.G.I. Friday's vibe, you'll be rewarded with surprisingly delicious grill fare. Steak skewers are sweet, succulent and plated atop an enormous heap of addictive fried onions. Golden "beer can chicken" get its intense flavor from loads of garlic and an herbal spice rub. And Black Angus burgers are thick and dripping with juices. All of which prompts one question: Why are we letting the tourists have the run of this place?
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingKid-friendly

column7: Half the joy of eating at this Greektown stalwart is seeing how many times you can get your server to say "Opa!" The other half comes in the form of the savory saganaki and the keftedakia—small, luscious meatballs simmered in tomato sauce. The sea bass lacks punch, so choose the rich and flaky spinach-cheese pie or the fantastic loukanika sausage instead. Honey-laden desserts are solid across the board, so order with confidence. But for maximum "Opa!" make sure you finish with a cup of the potent coffee.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: Back when chop suey was considered ethnic food and sweet-and-sour chicken was regarded as spicy, Orange Garden was born. From dragon-heavy decor to the sodium-laden menu, this place hits all of our nostalgic Chinese food buttons. When we want a ridiculously large portion of kung pao chicken, crispy crab rangoon and all the free, watery tea you can drink, this place always delivers with brusque, efficient service. For reasons we can't explain, we crave the spicy mapo tofu, in all its inauthentic, messy, gloopy pork-and-tofu glory.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: The sit-down dining room of the Hyatt's new three-zone restaurant offers American classics like grilled seafood and steaks for dinner. The adjacent Forno is counter-service Italian, with brick-oven pizza and panini, and the 160-seat bar, dubbed M/X, offers small plates of antipasti along with cocktails, wine and beer.

Republic Pan-Asian has morphed into a seasonal American spot. We're a bit confused by the holdover sushi menu alongside fall's most flavorful, locally grown ingredients, but one bite of a cheesy grit cake goes a long way to silencing doubts. So skip the maki but make room for rich, comforting creations like pork belly with apple kraut and a velvety puree of sweet potatoes and chestnuts or a medley of grilled wild mushrooms and nutty barley with Brie and celery root matchsticks. Maybe it's the changing weather, but we'd take these over cold rice any day.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seating

column7: Owner Dan Sullivan, whose great-grandfather built the space in 1915, recently merged the cafe with the sandwich haven Dagel & Beli. His infatuation with spoonerisms (the transposition of the initial consonants of two words) inspired this sandwich shop's moniker, and also led to some interesting names for its steamed bagel sandwiches, such as fart smella (roast beef and blue cheese on an onion bagel) and royola lubin (corned beef, sauerkraut and Swiss on a rye bagel).

Sox fans who prefer a plate of pasta to a mustard-slathered brat can get their fix at this casual spot where butcher-paper–topped tables abound. Old-school touches include black-and-white snapshots of yesteryear Chicago on the walls and a menu loaded with dishes like veal marsala, chicken Parmesan and cream-sauced pappardelle.

If you're that vegetarian who feels dissed every time you dine out (how many times have you heard "Well, I guess we could take the bacon off the cobb salad"?), this place will be your nirvana. The 26-page, global, meatless menu takes awhile to navigate, with choices inspired from cuisines of America, Italy, Mexico, the Middle East and, most notably, India. Given that the owners of this 25-year-old veg haven are Indian, we suggest sticking to the filled crêpelike dosas, the rice-lentil pancakes dubbed uttapam, any of the veggie-packed curries and the addictive crunchy-sweet-spicy bhel chaats. Unlike Devon Avenue, a 1-to-7 spice meter ensures personalized heat levels, but also unlike Devon, prices are relatively steep across the board.

This cute South Loop spot is part slick, part casual, with soothing bamboo-decked green walls and a staff that's eager to please. Jump around the massive, multicultured menu and you'll find great dishes across the board, from Chinese soup dumplings to ponzu-drizzled sashimi to Vietnamese-style grilled lemongrass beef. Generous sushi cuts are tasty (but a tad pricey), the signature duck soup is a standout but we found the red curry a bit gloopy and not nearly as spicy as the menu warned. No matter; dozens of other dishes do the trick.

The small menu at this friendly BYOB is heavy on sandwiches, and the few entrées on offer—pan-seared salmon, mild chicken tikka masala—don't stand out for their creativity. But the kitchen has a way of sneaking surprising flavors into otherwise standard fare. Case in point: spicy, creamy and endlessly flavorful harissa aioli that covers a pile of hot, crispy calamari. The Indian touch carries over to brunch, where buttermilk pancakes are topped with chai syrup, and tamarind chutneys come alongside chickpea pancakes.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendlyBYOBOutdoor seating

column7: For a while there, it looked like Ethiopian food in Chicago was going the way of the dinosaurs. Thankfully, this unassuming strip-mall gem is breathing new life into the scene. There are many dishes we're tempted to pile onto the spongy injera, from the kifto (buttery yet fiery ground beef) to the lega tibs (garlicky, oniony but slightly tough lamb). No matter what, the yekuanta firfir is a must—the chunks of flavorful charred jerk beef mixed with berbere sauce is so delicious it should keep this place from going extinct.

This simple, homey restaurant—the result of a quick makeover of Erba—doesn't have necessarily high aspirations: It just wants to be a good neighborhood spot serving solid comfort food. Sometimes it's exactly that: Herb-tossed mushrooms on toast turn out to be a pungent, earthy appetizer, and luscious braised short ribs with mashed potatoes are the height of cold-weather dining. A breakfast pizza (actually served as an appetizer for dinner) with fried eggs and bacon is a little too dry to be entirely enjoyable; same goes for the meatballs that dot the spaghetti. But the room and service are both so warm that the neighborhood will likely be forgiving.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column7: Nine-to-fivers will have to skip work to avoid the crowds at this dim sum stalwart, but it's worth it to bypass the weekend frenzy. What's the fuss? Hangover cures in the form of fried or steamed dough stuffed with savory, sometimes spicy pork and more pork. The classic bao are proper pillowy buns and crêpes are characteristically silky wraps for shrimp, beef or greens—try the pan-fried version of both for a bit of crispness. Skip the short rib unless you're a fan of gristle and bone; instead, save room for interesting options like tender baby octopus with a vaguely curry flavor and crispy eggplant stuffed with steamed squid. First-timers, don't fret: The menu features photos of all 56 items.
column60: Breakfast, lunch, dinner (dim-sum menu served until 3pm)

column7: You can't walk a dozen blocks in this town without bumping into a Chicago-style hot dog, so what's so special about this one? We think it's owner Jim Murphy, who takes a lot of pride in greeting regulars and walking new customers through their orders—this man clearly loves his job. Polish sausages and Italian beef are on offer, but we keep it sweet and simple with a red hot, grilled and dragged through the garden, with a side of hand-cut, skin-on fries, dropped in bubbling oil only when you order them to ensure freshness.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77
El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77,

column7: With only a smattering of tables and stools, this tucked-away sushi house is ideal for folks who like their fish with a dose of intimate, family-run personality. Begin with ika sansa, a wildly flavorful marinated squid, and the snappy tatiki salad of mixed greens topped with flame-seared tuna. The bright and fresh maki rolls come with whimsical names like Granny Smith, Smoky Bear, and our favorite, Winter Blossom (salmon, yellowtail and Japanese mint muddled with black tobiko). Skip the gomae roll and instead order the appetizer in its traditional form; the spinach simply plopped in a bowl and slathered with sweet sesame paste.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 77, 156

column7: This sunny, popular brunch spot earned its rep with "frushi" (fruit and coconut milk–laced rice) and pancake flights. Brunch is still served daily until 3pm, pastries are baked on-site and the signature juice machines are in place at the bar. Sweet fiends should fall in love with the coconut-infused French-toast kebab, while those looking for a savory day-starter could opt for "omelet #6," fluffy eggs stuffed with garlicky asparagus and mushrooms topped with toasted almonds and a drizzle of balsamic.
column144: El: Purple (rush hrs), Orange, Pink, Brown to LaSalle/Van Buren; Blue to LaSalle; Red to Jackson. Bus: 1, 7, 22, 24, X28, 126, 145, 151
El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77, 152

column7: Long before Chicago's great sushi boom, this Old Town stalwart (opened in '67) taught us how to tell nigiri from sashimi and miso from udon. The garden patio out back (which, weather permitting, will open in early May) is loaded with fresh flowers and, like the friendly staff, somehow raises the comfort level for those intimidated by the sushi scene.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column198: Other locations at 240 E Ontario St, 312-587-0600 and 20 N Dearborn St, 312-744-1900; and a smaller cafe at 311 S Wacker Dr, 312-765-8701, plus the suburbs.

column7: This opulent, 24,000-square-foot multiroom space was supposed to be Eric Aubriot's new home, where he would combine French and Moroccan cuisine in the most seamless, sophisticated ways. But, in a turn that really surprised nobody, Aubriot didn't last but a few weeks, leaving behind a restaurant that serves a limited menu of kebabs, hummus, lentil soup and a few tagines. Everything is cooked appropriately, but it all needs salt and other flavor enhancers. Still, it's worth it to go once, if only to gawk at the amazing tile work, fabrics and belly dancers (who are more than happy to let you get a good look).
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningFireplace
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 20

column7: Tucked away in a below-sidewalk-level strip mall, this Mediterranean spot is easy to miss. Popular Middle Eastern staples like smooth hummus, smoky baba ghanoush and spinach pies (which are cooked on the grill, lending them a nice charred flavor) share center stage with Moroccan specialties. Lamb shank arrives so tender it's falling apart all by itself, but it lacks the delicious flavor of the juicy chicken and kefta kebabs.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

column7: Knowing what you want will go a long way at this chic (chic for a stripmall, that is) Filipino joint. There's no menu for any of the meals other than breakfast, and the guys behind the steam table aren't good at answering questions. Don't be shy about pushing them to talk, though—otherwise you may end up with a bowl of pig ears. Those who don't mind eating things they've never heard of might enjoy the mongo beans, a stew that resembles lentil soup and includes chunks of beef and chicken curry is a good choice for timid eaters—the chicken is fried before the spicy (but not hot) curry is added.

When Sunday morning finds you cranky, impatient and in desperate need of coffee (read: hungover), the wait for a table at Lula can seem like cruel and unusual punishment. That's when this handy standby comes in. The grace and sophistication of Lula's food is missing in this brunch menu, but the thick and hearty oatmeal pancakes become surprisingly dreamy with a slathering of maple butter; the salmon (smoked in-house) is thick, meaty and smoky-sweet; and the Irish breakfast pairs delicious sausage with a pint of Guinness. The best part: There's no wait—at least not yet.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74

column7: What's not to like about this Andersonville trattoria? It's cute, it's bustling, service is helpful, and the food straddles the border between good and great. Year-round don't-miss items include the tender, lemon-kissed grilled octopus and the salumi plate. The weather change has us craving its farro with soppressata and local squash; the garganelli with pancetta, tomato ragù and homemade ricotta; and the wood-grilled rabbit, served with a celery root-turnip salad. All pastas are housemade and, like the signature panna cotta, unbelievably good.
column8: Notable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: Apparently, when Joe Farina left his corporate chef position at Rosebud and opened his own spot in the South Loop, his legion of family, friends and fans followed. Kisses and Bridgeport-worthy "aaayyyyy"s abound, with enough gelled hair and tanned skin in here to make both Michael Kors and George Hamilton jealous. Both the mediocre Italo-American food and the '80s soundtrack scream "chain," but if you're intent on finding diamonds in the rough (that aren't on the fingers of the clientele), the salumi and the orrechiette with sweet sausage and rapini will do.
column198: Other locations: 1467 N Milaukee Ave (773-342-2100); Bionda To-Go Café, 400 S Financial Pl (312-435-0400)

column7: As one of the few sit-down spots in the area, Gruppo di Amici could underachieve with substandard fare and still lure East Rogers Parkers desperate for higher-end options. Luckily, owners Lori Alderete and Phaedra Divras aren't just phoning it in—the wood-fired hearth that cooks their Roman-style pizzas was custom-made in Italy, for chrissakes—and their dedication pays off with a devoted clientele who pack the house for the capricciosa pie (a delicious heap of hard-boiled egg, prosciutto, olives, artichokes and mushrooms on a chewy crust), simple margherita and tangy funghi e formaggi (goat cheese, mushroom, EVOO).
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: This slick little Japanese spot aims to bring a little class to your lunch hour. Situated in a corner of one of the Presidential Towers, it's convenient for grabbing a bite, but this is no fast-food joint. Sit down at a table (or the sushi bar) and indulge in a bento box full of crisp and sweet tempura shrimp, plump California rolls and a salmon fillet topped with a creamy mushroom sauce. Sushi is influenced by the Loop, with maki named "Monroe," "Randolph" and "Jackson." Thankfully the "Lake" roll—golden fried oysters with ginger and mayo—tastes nothing like its namesake.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 14, 20, 56, 60, 124, 125, 157

column7: Slated to reopen as Ventuno in late Feb.Jerry Kleiner has a way with rooms: Give him one of Al Capone's old liquor warehouses, and he turns it into a flamboyant room stocked with cleavage-baring socialites. He doesn't have as much luck with chefs, though—Daniel Tucker is the restaurant's third since opening. Tucker hopes to make his mark this fall with dishes like a smoke salmon salad topped with a fried egg; a roasted duck breast with polenta and sage; and a short rib pot roast with roasted root vegetables.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: The Thai owners behind New York's Peep, Spice and SEA have a flair for slick and stylish dining rooms and cheap and tasty eats. This first Chicago outpost seems no different. Small plates of Asian-fusion creations average around five bucks a pop, making it easy to go nuts with a menu that includes coconut-crusted shrimp, duck crêpes and crispy ginger calamari.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77

column7: This upscale pan-Asian spot on a seedy strip of Uptown sticks out like a little sore thumb, all bright and shiny amid its tired surroundings. It's just as chipper inside, with black-and-white décor and Esquivel-esque music keeping things lively. Starters like grilled avocado salad with minced spicy tuna are tasty, but heavier on style than substance. Creative maki include a tom yum roll made with shrimp paste and topped with ponzu sauce, and a crispy shellfish roll filled with soft shell crab, shrimp and scallops. You'll find the standard array of Thai noodle dishes and curries, too, but your best bets are from the sushi bar.
column8: Good for dining at barBYOBVegetarian-friendly

column7: Housed incongruously within a colonial-type Naperville mansion, Masala Yangu administers a serious smack in the taste buds with a range of East African dishes reflecting both Middle Eastern and Indian influences. Calvin and Rahila Young balance delicious meats like charbroiled lamb and minced beef with hefty sides of pan-fried spinach, kale and cumin-laced cauliflower. When Calvin asks if you'd like sauces, say yes—the lemony pilli pilli is mind-blowing. Feeling dexterous? Order ugali, a corn paste used as an eating implement to scoop foods. A run at the lunch buffet clocks in under $10 and provides a solid overview of the menu.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: If you happen to blink while on your way for a dose of Germanic oompah in Lincoln Square, you might just miss one of the better Thai restaurants in town. The range of "safe" bets and more exotic, authentic eats is vast, but all is tasty. You can probably manage the regular menu yourself, so we'll offer tips on the Thai-language tome (there aren't English translations available anymore, but spend a couple of minutes with the server and you'll get what you want). Don't miss the tangy "waterfall" beef salad tossed with roasted rice powder, the earthy "boat" noodles with pork, the spicy-sour Isaan-style soup and the crispy catfish steaks smothered in pasty red-curry sauce.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: This small, bright storefront cafe has won the hearts of the neighborhood—residents of the surrounding condo buildings can spend hours here with the New York Times and a cappuccino. Any West Loop workers looking for a low-key, down-to-earth lunch will become fans, too. The limited, carb-loving menu is full of hearty Italian-American classics like garlicky linguine with clams, rigatoni mixed with spicy sausage and doused in a creamy tomato sauce, and a portobello mushroom and artichoke panini that's heavy on the balsamic. Food this basic makes for a disappointing dinner, however, so in the evening hours stick to visiting for a post-meal cup of coffee.

The flashing pachinko machines, the oversize "lucky cats" and the glowing bar of ever-changing colors are supposed to make this dining room seem like a Tokyo-away-from-Tokyo. But it's hard to think "Japan" when the menu says "Mexican" (tacos with "Asian guacamole"). So stick with the sushi: Kamehachi vet Toku Iwamoto turns out quality cuts of fresh hamachi and tai, not to mention fabulous "tumiki blocks," rectangular maki made without nori. It may not look like the maki you're used to. Then again, few things at this place are supposed to be familiar.
column8: Good for groupsGood for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Here's hoping the nice folks behind this neighborhood Italian spot can beat the bad mojo of this previously unlucky location. If customer service is any indication, things look good, though the food is less consistent. The grilled portobello mushroom topped with garlicky sautéed spinach and roasted red pepper had a nice, smoky char, but a house salad arrived topped with limp red onion rings. Skip the unimpressive Spiedini alla Griglia, pounded filet medallions wrapped around prosciutto and provolone and go with the tender, fluffy gnocchi with marinara sauce and the perfectly cooked seared salmon instead.

It's not going to win any awards for most welcoming decor, but look past the Big Buck Hunter arcade game and the handful of tables that could use some busing, and you'll find some of the freshest tacos in town. Meats are grilled on the spot (our favorite is the perfectly spiced carne asada), then sprinkled with fresh cilantro and onion and served up with a fiery, take-no-prisoners salsa verde. Wash it down with a cooling horchata and a side of creamy,Êmade-to-order guac—served with a mound of fresh-from-the-fryer chips—that rivals the fancy tableside preparations you'll find at upscale Mexican spots around town.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78

column7: If you're looking for an outdoor patio for a night of drinking and a few bites of sustenance to keep you from getting entirely sloshed, head here. The tree-lined patio, with views of guitar heroes marching into Old Town School of Folk Music, is tough to beat for a lazy summer's night. The signature Bad Dog black angus burger with crispy fries is a good bet, but steer clear of the sickeningly sweet mango and tequila glazed pork ribs. But only go when you have time to settle in; the service can be just as leisurely as the night.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingFireplace
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column7: Yeah, you can get your taco fix here, whether you prefer steak or ground beef or chicken or tripe. Same goes for burritos. But if you're not ordering the "meat lover's" platter for two at this Little Village spot, you're missing out. The sizzling plate is piled so high with steak, bacon, chorizo, sweet grilled onions and peppers and whole jalapeños that it can barely be carried to your table. If it's fish you're after, whole red snapper comes many ways, including topped with veracruzana sauce packed with sweet, softened carrots and onions. After dishes like these, you'll ditch the tiny tacos altogether.

Could anything be more fabulous than a gay hamburger chain? Not if you're into fried food and burgers so over-the-top that they border on obnoxious. Sandwiches here are less about the meat and more about the toppings: "Buffy (the Hamburger Slayer)" packs in big flavors of red wine and aioli; the "Barbra-Q Bacon Cheeseburger" has so much on it (onion rings, barbecue sauce, bacon) it can hardly be held. If big burgers aren't your thing, head straight for the fried Twinkies; they're just decadent enough to be universally appealing, no matter what team you bat for.
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)Late-night dining

column7: Dan and Mike Cordis set out to create a modern-day supper club, and quite frankly, they failed—their restaurant (in the former Biasetti's space) feels so authentically homey, old-school and nourishing that there are few modern things about it. But this is a good thing: It means you get a complimentary relish tray to start your meal (though the hummus on it would be the exception to the aforementioned authenticity); a buttery crab cocktail and a well-dressed Caesar salad as appetizers; and a hefty slice of lasagna, redolent of nutmeg, for an entrée. The "baseball steak," a tough impersonation of filet mignon, left us cold. But the rest of the experience was so warm, we'll overlook that.
column8: Good for groupsGood for dining at barLate-night diningOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, X9, 80, X80

column7: One of the best Italian restaurants in town isn't tucked away on some corner in Little Italy. Surprisingly, it's smack-dab in vanilla Lincoln Park. Chef Riccardo Michi knows a thing or two about regional Italian food—his family founded the Bice restaurant empire in Milan, and he served as chef of the first stateside location (New York, '87). Seasonal specials change daily here, but recent dishes like whole pompano with salmoriglio and grilled asparagus or saffron risotto "Milanese" with sausage and green peas are a testament to the authentic flavors you'll find here consistently.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 74

column7: This small, cheery room is packed with Colombian tchotchkes (as well as a stuffed armadillo hanging on the wall), which gives the place a festive vibe. What are they celebrating? Chicken, and the fact that they turn this blank-slate-of-foods into a dinner that's plump, juicy, golden, perfectly charred and endlessly flavorful. Tender brisket immersed in mild tomato sauce, crisp fried yuca, and a strip steak with fresh and lively chimichurri grace this menu. But they're just back-up. For once, the lowly chicken is the star of the show.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, 152

column7: If this design-your-own-sandwich bar—with its selection of eight breads, 28 fillings and 25 sauces—doesn't make you slip into a coma of indecision, then, we're sorry, but you're probably one of the most boring people on Earth. A list of suggestions is on hand to help indecisive lunchers, but with 100 selections, all of them as tempting as the Diego R. (steak, avocado, cilantro, cheddar, chipotle chutney and adobo sauce), it doesn't really help. So when you're here, grab a menu to study from at home. And tell your boss that, from now on, you're going to need some extra time on your lunch hour.

This small BYOB Thai-Japanese spot in Edgewater packs in crowds who come for the artfully prepared dishes that stand out from typical neighborhood Asian. Gems include the signature Massaman curry made with lemongrass, coriander and garlic; a heat-packing chicken- and prawn-studded smoked chile combo; and "Metallica" maki made with scallops, spicy mayo and black tobiko. If the higher-than-average prices are off-putting, try the lunch specials, which include three-course deals for just $6 to $12.

It's hard not to like a mustard- and ketchup-hued hot dog joint with its own foosball table and a menu of artery cloggers named for the owner's family members. Throw caution to the wind and go for Kali's Killer chili cheese dog or Pokey's grilled Polish with all the trimmings and a free side of fries to boot. The menu also offers burgers, a smattering of sandwiches, veggie dogs and some salads, but why bother? A dog and one of Huey's thick "rockstar" milk shakes are the best way we can think of to load up on nitrates and saturated fat.

This restaurant is now closed.This former Assyrian restaurant has recently transformed into a tandoor-focused Indian spot specializing in boti and kebabs (much in the same vein as nearby Khan). Stick to the back page of the menu, where the barbecue items are listed (plus a few puffy paratha breads to mop up everything): The crimson-stained chicken boti is tender, and fantastic when drizzled with mint-green cilantro-yogurt sauce; fish filets are rubbed with a cumin-paprika blend before being grilled to juicy perfection; but the minced lamb and beef seekh kebabs don't get much of a char and instead arrive a bit mushy. Still, it's impossible to argue with the prices, the flavors are fresh and it's a welcome addition to Devon's crop of eateries.

If you're not wearing flip-flops, you're probably overdressed at this bright, laid-back coffeehouse. This international joint (Chilean/Mexican/Italian) is typically quite, so you'll have the server's attention to ask for suggestions from the massive menu of salads, housemade empanadas, wraps and sandwiches. Go with the South American chacarero (juicy steak and ripe avocado on a soft roll) and don't miss the avocado smoothies or perfect café con leche. The creativity won't blow you away, but everything's affordable, fresh and flavorful.

At this Shanghai-style Chinese restaurant, the xiao long bao, or soup dumplings, are a magical creation of hot soup broth and pork or crab encased in dough. The restaurant also offers Beijing specialties like cumin-coated grilled lamb skewers, millet congee and the classic Chinese hot pot, which has been somewhat successful in luring diners seeking the wonders of the fonduelike, do-it-yourself meal. Whether it's the soup dumplings that tempt you—or the chewy homemade noodles in spicy sesame oil or the fist-size meatballs braised in the house sauce of dark soy, sugar and vinegar—once you get in the door, you'll wonder how you've gone without for so long.
column144: El: Red to Cermak/Chinatown. Bus: 18, 21, 62 (24 hrs)

column7: Designer pizza's all the rage right now, but we've still been longing for a simple, no-frills Neapolitan pie—the kind that's cut into perfect triangular slices, not kiddy-size squares. Salvation has come by way of this immaculate Lincoln Square storefront, where the industrial-size mixer in the corner is a cue that this place takes its thin crust seriously. Add a perfect sauce to topping ratio, a smattering of fresh salads and house-made dressing options, and the result is the perfect little takeout pizza joint. Skip the creative toppings, like Brie and eggs, and stick with the stellar standbys. Bonus: Delivery's free.

A recent face-lift and menu revamp have turned this former ho-hum Thai restaurant into a bright spot in the neighborhood. We'll be back for the delicate wasabi vegetable rolls and creative-but-not-kooky maki; try the Lagarto roll made with spicy scallop, avocado, white tuna and tobiko. Thai options include curry fried rice dotted with bits of pineapple and a perfectly snappy stir-fried asparagus with shrimp. If you forget to BYO, the housemade ginger ale should cheer you up. Maybe the snide servers should drink a double dose.

A hodgepodge menu of from-scratch regional dishes from central Mexico has customers feasting on food such as orange roughy bathed in white wine, tomatoes and onions, and spicy chicken mole. Tucked behind the building is a spacious patio that's utterly magical on a summer night, and most evenings you'll find a handful of diners relaxing under the stars, enjoying one of the restaurant's specialties: a humongous Cazuela, a potent elixir composed of fresh-squeezed juices and five shots of tequila.

This trusty Italian spot lures locals into its sunny dining room with its extensive wine list and keeps them there with its solid menu. Tender meatballs simmering in marinara seem the perfect mate for a medium-bodied Italian red, while entrées like saltimbocca Siciliana—chicken topped with savory prosciutto and fontina—seem made for a lemony glass of white. By the time dessert comes you'll probably have had your fill of drinks, but make room to end your dinner on a sweet note with the housemade tiramisu.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 73, 74

column7: Even though former Joffrey ballet dancer Sam Franke took over this neighborhood joint a year ago, the goal of original owners Craig Fass and Mandy Franklin to have a pub with good grub and an ever-expanding beer list remains. Thankfully nobody told him that dishes like the rich and creamy duck confit mac-and-cheese, the hearty and perfectly balanced barbecue pork-and-coleslaw panini go way beyond the call of duty of normal pub grub. If we're lucky, nobody ever will.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 9, 11, 77

column7: It's tough to choose among the many Mexican spots hawking specialties via window signs around these parts, but if you're in the mood for an outdoor setting to sip 'ritas (they're non-alcoholic unless you bring your own tequila) and enjoy decent eats, head here. Seafood is the house focus here, and most of it is pretty tasty, particularly the sautéed garlic shrimp (crunchy skin and all) with lard-rich beans and tomatoey rice. Meat-eaters should try the tangy-spicy pastor pork tacos. Margaritas only come frozen, but they're flavorful, if not particularly strong. Tip: Go for the ceviche late in the week rather than Monday (unless you like the recently frozen weekend leftovers).
column144: El: Red to Loyola. Bus: 22, 151, 155. Metra: Union Pacific North Line to Rogers Park

column7: Its walls have been made into a makeshift variety store—glassware sets, Afghani DVDs and pressure cookers hang, readied for purchase—but the draw here is the amazing Afghani food. After tasting your way through the ridiculously cheap menu, you'll be convinced it was opened to satiate your vegetable cravings. Big bowls of slurpable curried lentil soup, stewed eggplant with garlicky yogurt sauce (borani badinjan) and all-day-simmered spinach with tender chunks of lamb (sabzi chalow) make for veggie nirvana. Hefty, marinated kebabs are char-grilled to perfection and served with an addictive side of buttery basmati rice.

Midwesterners who pine for old-fashioned salads, sandwiches and baked goods like Mom used to make will find a good selection (macaroni, pea and pearl-onion salad, anyone?) at this sunny new Edgewater bakery/café. We like the more modern panini—especially the caprese with prosciutto—as well as the rotating assortment of fresh-baked breads, including multigrain and hearty deli rye. The Metropolis coffee—a special blend brewed exclusively for the bakery—may not be as retro as a packet of Ma's Sanka, but we like it that way.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr or Berwyn. Bus: 22, 36, 50, 84, 151

column7: If you work anywhere near the West Loop, you have to make this Italian grocery a part of your weekly routine. Work your way through the tiny aisles with jam-packed shelves offering imported pastas, olive oils and biscotti galore and head for the deli counter in back. Here you'll find the best Italian sub in town: a nine- or 12-inch crusty sub loaf (baked next door at D'Amato's) brimming with spicy cappicola, genoa salami, mortadella, provolone, oil, vinegar, oregano, lettuce, tomato and spicy housemade giardiniera. Grab a San Pellegrino and a pint of Ciao Bella gelato on your way out and you've got the best lunch in town for less than ten bucks.

For edginess, look elsewhere. Here, expect fresh seafood and meat, and excellent ingredients honorably prepared. Scallops are food zine–photo perfect, plump and tenderly browned; rich, moist pork tenderloin comes blanketed with refreshing fruit salsa (as far-out as this kitchen gets). Vegetarians may feel left out (although the gazpacho is crunchy and garden-fresh), but they can get their dose of starch with the killer potatoes au gratin with bubbling Gruyère. For dessert, be a kid again and try the amazingly comforting root-beer float.
column144: El: Green to Harlem. Bus: Pace 307.

column7: Like almost everything Twisted Spoke's owners (the Einhorn brothers) do, this tiny pizza joint has unexpected details of excellence that betray its machismo, carefree atmosphere. Fresh garlic and pristine basil (free for the asking), bacon, French olives and more all add up to some pretty delicious pizza. The red pesto pie (which owes its fiery hue to its sun-dried tomato base) has two standout features: the meaty and brilliantly spiced sausage and the chewy crust.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 36, 152

column7: Relax—this isn't the touristy red-sauce joint on Rush Street. Here, there's not a fanny pack in sight. Instead, this bustling, low-lit room is full of dark wood and red leather, lending it an old-school feel. If you can get a seat (be sure to make a reservation), you'll be told about the specialty, a bone-in filet: It's soft as pudding, but a little underseasoned. The perfectly pink Norwegian salmon is offered with an optional wasabi glaze, which you should get for the additional depth and heat. And if you're on a budget, grab the burger. It's thick, juicy, great with blue cheese, and only sets you back twelve bucks.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barOutdoor seatingLate-night diningGood for groups

column7: If we have to explain to you how this place got its name, it's time you went back to school. But if it's tapas you want an education on, the 48 varieties on offer here should be a good primer. Excellent imported meats include smoky, crispy-skinned links of chorizo. Goat-cheese croquettes (fried sans batter) are paired with sticky, sweet balsamic. Paella looks and tastes lackluster, so ignore it. But don't skip dessert. We know, desserts aren't the strong point of tapas joints, but the luscious crema Catalana? Let's just say it schooled us.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barLate-night dining

column7: Small, nondescript pizza joints open in Chicago about as often as city politicians get indicted. But this spot stands out due to its ballsy location (a, shall we say, transitioning stretch of Howard Street) and its aim of feeding Rogers Parkers authentic New York–style pizza. Slices are the way to go: They're huge, delicious, greasy and foldable, with a nice, slightly crispy and charred crust. Other offerings include Italian beef, wings, salads and pasta, but we say you should do as the New Yorkers do: Grab a sausage, pepperoni or cheese slice and get out.
column144: El: Red, Purple, Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, 147, 151, 201, 205, Pace 215, Pace 290

column7: A little west of Pilsen's main strip, this long room starts off narrow and then opens up into a large dining area, complete with a stage for the band in the corner. Throw a couple of the heavily touted "best margaritas" in the mix and you have an instant party. But that's not to say this place won't work for a lunch or early dinner, too: Chicken tostadas are piled so high you can make a small meal out of just one; tamales are stuffed with deliciously spicy shredded pork; and burritos are stuffed to the max with succulent beef and creamy refried beans. (Don't worry—it's a good walk back to the El station, so you'll work it off.)

Sometimes you don't want artisanal ingredients manipulated by globe-trotting chefs. Sometimes you want the stuff of your childhood memories—actual comfort food—not nuevo comfort food. This is where you go when you want those absurdly large portions of lasagna, pizza and other Italian classics, topped with almost too much Parmesan and red sauce. You'll dine in a dated booth, on paper place mats emblazoned with a map of Italy. Take leftovers home for lunch tomorrow, and go back to low carbs the day after.

Thankfully, all went well with final inspections, and University Village has been rewarded with a taste of this local pan-Asian minichain. The vast photo-filled menu from the Chinatown spot is duplicated here, so anyone who's addicted to the mussels with black-bean sauce, garlicky chicken with string beans or gargantuan bowls of udon-noodle soup have nothing to worry about. And smoothie addicts? Don't fret: There's a massive wall of fruit at this location, too, so those blender-mavens will be able to concoct whatever smoothies and bubble teas your taste buds desire.

This new bar and grill may just look like your average cozy neighborhood joint, but there are a few hidden gems on the menu for adding a belly buffer so that you can have one more (or three more) beers. The "Nachos con Fusion" is a huge, gluttonous portion, so share them or suffer tomorrow. Mini–tenderloin sandwiches were juicy and oozing with herbed butter and the house salad is a garden of perfectly dressed crisp veggies. Just skip the ostrich burger, chicken wings and "ranch chips" until the kitchen can iron out the newbie kinks.

This is the place you wish would open near your house: A sunny, cheerful room sporting a bakery case that overflows with stacks of saucer-size cookies, baskets of thick bagels and rows of immaculate tarts. Michael Andersson doesn't bake all this stuff; instead, he sources it from organic (or at least organicish) bakeries around the city. That gives his kitchen the space and time it needs to make the meaty lobster rolls (low on mayo, big on citrus juice), crusty Cuban sandwiches and the fresh bowls of fruit salad that accompany every dish. Now, about that apartment across the streetÉ.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 22, 36, 73, 74

column7: An adorable, hip coffeeshop in Pilsen, and it's not on 18th Street? Believe it. And while you're at it, you might as well know that it's also vegetarian-friendly and cheap. Sides like veggie Puerto Rican rice with gandules (pigeon peas) and green olives, sweet potatoes boiled with raw sugar, and sazon (seasoned) hash browns showcase chef Papi Perez's Caribbean roots. But the hearty comfort food is universal at Aorta: Weekend brunch options include French toast (order the thick slabs "crunchy") and "gypsy skillet" (two eggs any way on a bed of sauteed vegetables and potatoes). Both include complimentary OJ or coffee and a pastry.
column144: El: Pink to Damen. Bus: 21 Cermak, 50

column7: Flora may be its bread and butter, but this quaint fixture sticks to its tradition of serving shakes, malts, ice-cream sodas and sundaes, as it has since 1927. Stop into the charmingly old world shop for a seasonal bouquet and it's difficult to resist being seduced into snacking—if not on ice cream, then on a piece of pie and a cappuccino.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 84, 136, 147, 151

column7: Bellying up to the sidewalk window is the easy part. Deciding on a cool treat from the lengthy menu—therein lies the rub. While soft-serve frozen yogurt, ice-cream sundaes and milk shakes are available, it's the more than 20 flavors of homemade Italian ice (a simple corn syrup–free combo of fruit, sugar and ice) on offer that are the real draw. From strawberry and peach to passion fruit and coconut-banana, you can beat the heat here with virtually any fruit under the blazing summer sun.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: What's a Brown Cow, you ask? Three scoops of chocolate ice cream, hot fudge, peanut butter and chocolate sprinkles served in a milk pail—a sugar-coma–inducing indulgence. But the decadent treats at this old timey café don't end there. Open up and say "Ah" to the Trough: several pounds of ice cream—one scoop of each flavor—served feed-box–style. Of course, not everyone wants belt-busting amounts. If you're looking for the classics, Brown Cow offers shakes, malts and a root-beer float, as well as children's birthday party favorites like ice-cream cupcakes and cakes.

If it's warm outside, there's no way to avoid it: You'll be lured to this restaurant's insanely scenic riverside deck. From here you'll be treated to cool river breezes and a view of the skyline that seems to go on forever. Frozen cocktails only enhance the experience, but take serious caution: The vaguely-upscale menu of junk food is as bad as the view is good, so eat elsewhere beforehand.
column8: ViewsOutdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark. Bus: 22, 156

column7: Walking into this swank space, you won't think "pizza," but you should: The Gorgonzola and pear–topped pie with balsamic drizzle is insanely delicious. To sustain your high, knock back a three-wine flight; good range, decent pours and value-priced at only $8.25. You could stop right there and be happy, but if you must proceed, go with the signature pistachio chicken with herbaceous polenta. It's covered in nut-meal and fried, then drizzled with creamy red-pepper sauce for addictive, indulgent results. Skip the veal medallions; they're overwhelmed by pancetta and fontina. Instead, carbo-load with popular pastas (including several all-veggie options) and a stellar version of bread pudding.

If the chandeliers and Persian rug–upholstered banquettes in this dining room don't make you swoon, just wait a second: Soon you'll swoon over the focaccia-like bread that's set down on your table with a block of crumbly feta cheese, tart pickles and ripe tomatoes. Enjoy, but don't go too crazy—you'll want to leave room for the kashk-e-bademjan, a soft, savory eggplant puree with an underlying tang of yogurt; the sotani, juicy prime-rib kebab alongside another kebab of ground beef, lamb and veal; and the gormeh sabzi, a sprightly beef stew full of mouth-puckering herbs and lime.
column144: El: Blue to Montrose. Bus: 53, X54, 78

column7: We recommend this colorful Little Village spot, but be warned: The jukebox is haunted. A few minutes after we started digging into the juicy chicken with thick, peppery mole, the juke suddenly lit up and started belting Spanish-language soft rock. Thirty seconds later it stopped, so we continued eating the platter of small, crispy grilled onions and a savory chorizo taco. After about 15 minutes, we thought we were in the clear, but then the jukebox started again (rocking a little harder). This time, however, we hardly noticed—we were too immersed in the nicely charred carne asada to care.

If you don't blend in with the demographic at this Serbian market/café—that is, if you aren't a young, beefy Eastern European guy—it can be a little can be a little intimidating to take a seat. Get over it. Flaky, housemade pies are filled with either meat or cheese and have a chewy, buttery crust. Slow-roasted beef is succulent with a crisp, charred edge. housemade baked goods include soft rounds of white bread and krofna, puffy, sugar-dusted doughnuts. Besides, these guys are much too interested in watching football (that's soccer to you) to pay you any notice.

The abruptly shuttered Wrigleyville Ethiopian stalwart has reopened in Evanston, where an NU crowd uses spongy injera bread as knife, fork and spoon to sop up traditional entrées. Combo plates offer the best bang for your buck, giving you a chance to try as many as four entrées, like yeater kit wot (yellow split peas with garlic, cloves and cinnamon), yesiga wot (a spicy beef stew) and azifa (cold lentils with tomatoes and jalapeño). It's best to go with someone you want to cozy up with, since everyone's food is served on a mesob—a single, large platter symbolizing intimacy and loyalty.

Oak Park's most splendid dining room has a generously sized octagonal bar, dark wood and white tablecloths. Oysters Rockefeller rule, but those who choose to eat on the wild side take theirs raw. A sweet-potato pancake complements macadamia-dusted shrimp atop a lobster-vanilla reduction; Dover sole is light as a feather and pumped up with well-executed amandine or meunière sauces; and tenderloin with Amish blue cheese is an explosive marriage of rich meat and pungent dairy. With superb wines (go ahead and ask for tastes), masterful mixologists and live jazz, many patrons "dress for dinner." (If you think this means a clean tank top and baseball cap, you'll probably feel more at home at neighboring Poor Phil's.)

In the spot formerly known as Latin Sandwich Café, sandwiches are the name of the game, and for good reason: The Chilean versions are assembled on crusty, housemade white bread and feature addictive fillings (such as the pork, avocado and mayonnaise in the creamy "pernil con palta"). But what we're really smitten with are the empanadas, two-handed affairs filled with beef, onions, olives and hard-boiled egg that are a meal in themselves. If all those carbs put you into a food coma, a full lineup of espresso drinks is on hand to perk you right up.
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80, 82

column7: Nothing says summer like lining up on the rainbow sprinkle–coated blacktop with the crowds outside this ice-cream shack just north of the Lincoln Village movie theater, waiting for a soft-serve cone dipped in chocolate or cherry coating. Grab a spot on one of the benches for people-watching that reflects a great cross-section of city types—blue-collar working stiffs stealing a quick break, large Orthodox Jewish families who love that the ice cream is certified kosher, high schoolers on first dates. If you're feeling indulgent, try the Buddy parfait, made with vanilla ice cream, hot fudge and salted peanuts, or one of the myriad of funky-flavored shakes, like caramel or marshmallow.

Regulars at this roadside dive know to call in their orders ahead of time so they don't have to drool for 20-plus minutes waiting for their fresh-from-the-fryer, juicy birds. You'll find a few tables next to the pop machines, but this is mostly a takeout joint that caters to a steady stream of NU students and fried-chicken fanatics who go bonkers for the slightly peppery, battered chicken dinners, complete with fries, cole slaw and bread for sopping the grease. Wings—kept whole here, instead of cut at the joint, and served with hot, smoked or honey-barbecue sauce—rival nearby Buffalo Joe's and Hecky's BBQ for hometown favorite.

Besides the nine kinds of fresh popcorn on offer (including jalapeño, garlic, dark chocolate, cheese and caramel), this South Side spot scoops out 17 flavors of Hershey's ice cream, which include black walnut, butter pecan, cappuccino crunch, cookies and cream, moose tracks and Superman.
column60: Mon–Fri noon–10pm; Sat noon–11pm; Sun noon–9pm
column93: Chicago's Best Gourmet Popcorn & Ice Cream (CLOSED)
column186: Chicago's Best Gourmet Popcorn & Ice Cream (CLOSED)

column7: The bright, ever-changing decorations at this retail outlet for the Wisconsin ice-cream company of the same name are matched only by the more than three dozen flavors of ice cream that rotate in and out of its freezers. At any given time, flavors can include cinnamon, cherry chocolate chip and horchata, a take on the Mexican rice-milk beverage. A selection of soft-serve yogurt, sorbet, sherbet, sugarless and soy-based flavors is also available. Be sure to visit around holidays—the owners go all out, turning the place into a virtual haunted house for Halloween and some sort of bunnyland for Easter.

Just a short jaunt from the Brookfield Zoo, this shop has an old-fashioned vibe and offers up Oak Park's own Petersen's ice cream in more than two dozen flavors, including cappuccino crunch, moose tracks and Superman. The small café also sells coffee, a variety of pastries and nostalgia-inducing candies.

Located in the Lincolnwood Mall, this outlet of the national Freshens chain, which specializes in soft-serve frozen yogurt, offers six flavors including pecan, strawberry and vanilla fudge. Parfaits, milk shakes and "candy-blasted" creations are available, but calorie counters can opt for fat-free, low-fat, and fat-free, no-sugar-added flavors. Regular ice cream is also on offer in flavors such as coffee, cookies and cream, and moose tracks.

What sets San Francisco–based chocolate specialists Ghirardelli apart from other sweet shops is that you can usually choose your poison in either bar or ice cream form. The Intense Dark sundaes, spawned from the chocolate bar series of same name, mix cocoa-heavy chocolate with flavors such as espresso, raspberry and mint chip. The parlor's '50s-era decor, which includes wood pretzel-backed chairs and white marble–topped tables, is a fun spot to sip milk shakes, root beer floats and coffee, but you can also take your treat out to the tables in front.
column93: Ghirardelli Soda Chocolate Shop & Soda Fountain
column186: Ghirardelli Soda Chocolate Shop & Soda Fountain

column7: The Hartigans took a sizable risk when, in 1996, they decided to transform their Baskin-Robbins franchise store into a family owned-and-operated ice-cream shop. It seems the gamble has paid off, though. The store now carries more than 50 flavors from Wisconsin-based ice creamery Cedar Crest, and everyone from Northwestern students to stroller-pushing moms and dads can be seen coming in for a double-dip cone and and cup of joe.

We don't know what's cuter: the Golden Years couples taking tango lessons here on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and weekend evenings, or the hand-formed empanadas filled with a sweet and savory combination of raisins and chicken. Hearty Milanesa sandwiches fit breaded veal between thick slices of warm focaccia, but don't fill up—occasionally the dessert special will be hojaldre cake, a seven-layer beauty of caramel and crispy cookies that'll have you doing the tango in your seat.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 66, 70

column7: This Lincoln Park stalwart may have shot itself in the foot by opening Red Rooster, the more casual, less-expensive dining room in the back of the building—on a recent Saturday night, Bernard was barely half full. Have people forgotten about the classic French fare this spot has been dishing out since 1972? If they have, they should get their hands on the housemade duck pâté (immensely improved with the proper amount of mustard), plump scallops drizzled with balsamic, and a rare, peppery filet mignon flanked by soft, creamy potatoes. Finished off with a classic creamy crème bržlée, it's a meal they won't soon forget again.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73, 74

column7: Plan for a late weekend dinner to take in the full experience at this Colombian steakhouse, crammed with an assaulting array of artificial flora and fauna, booming televisions and waiters dressed à la Juan Valdez (minus the mule). Once the music starts playing, crowds young and old hit the dance floor, but you'd be wise to stay put and take in the action while feasting on arepas, fried white-corn pancakes filled with ingredients like cheese and sausage. Also try one of the typical Colombian combo plates, most of which include nicely spiced fried flank steak, pork or pork rind, plus melt-in-your-mouth plantains and cassava.

Greasy and grilled options such as hot dogs, burgers and gyros crowd the menu board at this Beverly standby, but the real meat is the yogurt and ice cream. You're not going to find a laundry list of froufrou flavors here, though. They only have four: chocolate, strawberry, vanilla and one option that usually seesaws between banana and raspberry.

The centerpiece of this laid-back parlor is the 1937 soda fountain the staff uses to top-off half-full glasses of ice cream with soda flavors like strawberry, orange and grape. Twenty-eight flavors of ice cream (from Madison, Wisconsin creamery the Chocolate Shoppe) and a selection of soy ice cream, frozen yogurt and Italian ice are also on offer. Candies like salt-water taffy, jelly beans and malted milk balls are also available, by the pound.
column60: Mon–Thu noon–10pm; Fri noon–11pm; Sat Noon–11pm; Sun 2pm–9pm
column144: Metra: Rock Island District Line to Tinley Park.

column7: The waits on weekends are an indicator of this Bucktown spot's continual buzz, and a few bites of Chris Pandel's New American food is all it takes to join the ranks of fans. We're smitten with signatures like the salad of heirloom apples and Manchego; the grilled sardines with chickpea fries; the thick, juicy burger; and the devastatingly delicious egg-and-ricotta-filled raviolo. Now that he's nailed dinner, Pandel is taking brunch to the next level with dishes like skirt steak and eggs in béarnaise sauce and a skillet loaded with tender duck, greens and fingerlings, as well as a selection of brunch cocktails like a bacon-infused Manhattan.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: Best Extra Value Meal (relatively inexpensive shared plates)

column7: We doubt Amelia's can do for the post-industrial Back of the Yards neighborhood what Mundial–Cocina Mestiza did for Pilsen, but the new BYOB is certainly worth a trek. Former Mundial chef Eusevio Garcia serves langoustines over creamy risotto dotted with velvety mushrooms, pairs grilled lamb loin with a crunchy sugar-snap-pea slaw and lemony potato cake, and makes one hell of a chile relleno—a blistered green-pepper, oozing cheese-covered sweet corn and tender eggplant.

Right about where Oak Park meets Berwyn, you'll find Gina Tremonte scooping out Italian ice to her legion of loyal families who stop by often come summer. The motherly namesake behind the shop uses fresh fruit in most of the dozen flavors, with lemon, watermelon and cantaloupe coming in as the top three sellers respectively. Lemon ice fans who like theirs supertart won't be disappointed here, and fans of campy horror can stroll two doors down to Horrorbles to pick up a Svengoolie rubber chicken or a signed Basil Gogos book.
column144: El: Blue to Oak Park. Bus: Pace 305 Roosevelt, Pace 311 Oak Park

column7: Owner Guadalupe Lopez uses 14 percent cream from the local Elgin Dairy and a wild imagination to create 130 flavors of her amazing ice cream. Adding as little sugar as possible, she captures the essence of each flavor—even Parmesan cheese or sweet corn bread. Don't miss the jalapeño, tequila, mamey, avocado and coconut options. Lopez also makes Popsicles that she sells in the store. Additional location at 2635 W 51st St (773-434-3917).

As far as soft-serve ice cream is concerned, the Queen is king. Sure, it's an international chain, but this location, with its windowside booths packed with smiling faces and outdoor seating along a family-friendly stretch of Southport, retains the feel of a neighborhood original. Besides cones, sundaes and their famous "Blizzard" mash-ups, this DQ also offers hot dogs and barbecue sandwiches.

This haven for true Italian gelato serves up astonishingly creamy scoops that surge with flavor. Owner Giuseppe "Joe" Quercia—who emigrated from Naples, Italy, in 1968—makes the rotating nine flavors with 14 percent milk and no eggs. It's tough to go wrong with any flavor, but we're addicted to the Donatello (chocolate with creamed hazelnuts, like frozen Nutella), the Tartufo (chocolate with chunks of hazelnut) and the refreshing limoncello ice.

The signature dish at this Back of the Yards Mexican spot is, not surprisingly, the namesake cecina. A specialty of Mexico's Guerrero region, the cecina (strips of beef that have been pounded thin, marinated, then grilled) is served with guacamole, pico de gallo and delicious housemade tortillas—a simple but full-flavored dish. More elaborate presentations include the cecina rellena, where the meat is rolled with chorizo and cheese and topped with a cactus sauce to delicious, messy results. Crispy fried smelts are a good way to start, and house-baked Mexican pastries are a fine way to end. But beware of the molcajete sauce sitting on the table: It's spicy enough to tear off your taste buds (which, when eating here, you'll want to keep intact).

The stroller-pushing Lincoln Park mother set loves this corner Italian ice spot, probably because the all-natural, nonfat ices are nice to their waistlines. We hear them on that, but we also appreciate the classic lemon ice for its full flavor and the bits of lemon rind sprinkled throughout. Ditto for the watermelon with its sweet juiciness and, to our surprise, the chocolate ices, which are made with cocoa and packed with deep, rich chocolate flavor. You'd swear something like the "chocolate toffee crunch" is bad for you—and let's be honest, the sugar in it probably is—but we'll continue to eat it in ignorant bliss.
column93: Tom and Wendee's Homemade Italian Ice
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73
column186: Tom and Wendee's Homemade Italian Ice

column7: Typically we try not to fill up on bread at the beginning of a meal, but at this comfortable Middle Eastern joint, that's practically impossible. When the basket of fluffy, housemade bread arrives, we go through it in hyperspeed, slathering slices with excellent cold meze such as the smooth, rich baba ghanoush and cool, creamy, yogurt-based cacik. From there it's on to the massive savory pies stuffed with cheese and eggs. We might take a break from the carbs with the infinitely juicy chicken-thigh kebabs, but soon enough it's back to the baked goods as we inhale housemade baklava for an ideal ending.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)BYOB
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50

column7: Though this tiny 24-hour shack with a three-seater counter only serves two flavors of soft serve—vanilla and chocolate—it's the 54 flavors of milk shakes that draw out folks at all hours. By throwing candy, cookies and flavored syrups into the blender, they create flavors like "baboon" (chocolate and banana), Oreo and strawberry shortcake—thick shakes that pair well with an order of chili-cheese fries and a burger at 4am.

There's nothing particularly astrological about this place; it's quite grounded, actually. The salt-of-the-earth regulars have a lot of pride in the greasy hoagies and steak sandwiches, but they still manage to give love to (and save room for) the ice cream. Around a dozen flavors, including cookies and cream, butter pecan and New York cherry, are served in the cup, cone or blended into a thick milk shake.

Before you get schnitzel-faced at this friendly German restaurant, sample the dozen or so ales and lagers on tap. Don't know your Weizen from your Dunkel? The cute, German-accented waitresses are happy to make recommendations in between doling out soft pretzels with mustard and platters of sausages, cheese, pickles and olives. Stick-to-your-ribs entrées include sauerbraten, tender, red wine–braised beef served with cheesy spaetzle dotted with marjoram and onions. Before you roll out the door, have a bite or two of the housemade Sacher torte or apple strudel.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80

column7: The soft-serve here isn't your average waistband-expanding stuff. Treats prides itself on offering servings of ice cream with only one gram of fat, which is good because you're probably going to want to eat a lot of it. Along with chocolate and vanilla, four featured flavors are on offer daily (call for specials) with recent offerings including caramel fudge eclair, banana and chocolate marshmallow. The "mess" option lets you create your own creation by choosing two toppings from the selection of syrups, fruit, nuts and candies. Additional location at 2224 N Clark St.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 77

column7: From the street, Gio's looks like any other corner store in any other Chicago neighborhood. But this is Bridgeport, and Gio's packs a tiny, red-checkered tablecloth restaurant plus an array of imported Italian groceries into a space the size of a deli counter. The food is unspectacular (though it has its moments—like the arancino, a nicely fried risotto ball packed with meat sauce and peas), but the cast of characters kept us happily amused. Our sisterly waitress patiently jotted down the directions for the kids' made-to-order pasta dish and did everything short of pulling up a chair to make us feel at home, and and we still crave the frozen lemon flute, a tart limoncello-and-cream concoction that made it to our short list of perfect summer desserts.

You city dwellers might ask, Why drive to the 'burbs for Chinese when we've got Chinatown? But we swear that you won't find noodles this fresh in the city. Start with the dumplings—ethereal pockets of noodle skin encasing scallion-flecked pork—and move on to a heaping bowl of beef noodle soup. In this Chinese version of pho, the rich beef broth is redolent of star anise, but the ginger, garlic, chilies, pickles and unbeatable long, soft noodles make this house signature stand out. End the meal on a fiery note with "dan-dan noodles," a classic combo of chili paste and ground pork with ground Szechwan peppercorns over more of those tasty noodles.

Although there is a large selection of novelty gift items and homemade candies here (truffles, chocolate-covered pretzels and fudge), the nightly post-dinner rush of gay and straight couples are here for the ice cream. Standouts among the store's more than 30 flavors include blueberry cheesecake and green tea. Employees are generous with the scoops, which they plop down onto everything from small, plain cake cones to hulking chocolate- and candy-dipped sugar cones.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 77

column7: Luis and Laura Cid Perea already have a Mexican bakery in Pilsen and a Mexican sandwich shop in the West Loop. Now they're tackling the Gold Coast with a more American sensibility. Luis is in charge of the savory menu, offering sandwiches like roast beef with horseradish sauce and tuna salad with olive paste, both of which will be on house-baked bread. Laura tackles the pies, cupcakes and cobblers. (But with any luck, she'll keep her amazing mocha tres leches cake in stock, too.)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 70, 156

column7: One of the few places that uses the word lounge correctly, this slick little spot is perfect for getting to know chef Rick Tramonto's sexier side (insert lewd joke here). Belinda Chang's wine list (not to mention the full bar) is the focus, but it's augmented by Tramonto's pristine, Asian-inspired snacks—bites like rock shrimp tempura with lemongrass aioli; tuna tartare dressed in soy-sesame sauce; and a pristine selection of maki, nigiri and sashimi. The execution is excellent, but these dishes are small—if it's dinner you're after, head downstairs, where two other Tramonto restaurants wait to fill you up.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barSuburban

column7: The signature dish here is tonkatsu, pork sirloin (served in one piece or sliced longitudinally and stacked) dusted with panko (Japanese bread crumbs) and tenderly fried. This spot used to attract mostly Japanese customers who longed for homeland classics; now, many non-Asians also come for Berkshire hog meat, the lush, flavorful preference of pork-o-philes. Also recommended is the tempura-light gyoza, a worthy accompaniment to tonkatsu. The chef, hopelessly devoted to panko, also cooks up katsu-style (breaded and fried) hamburgers and salmon.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Arlington Heights.

column7: Once a neighborhood candy store, Polo remains a local gathering place in close-knit Bridgeport. Lunch is the main meal, starring charred Angus beef burgers slathered with chef-owner David Samber's garlic aioli, salads and giant bowls of pasta. Kill Friday night's debauchery with the Saturday Bloody Mary brunch that offers stick-to-your-ribs fare like Da Mare's steak and eggs and housemade biscuits with gravy. The joint oozes with tchotchkes and South Side history (an oversize photo of Richard J. Daley grinned over our booth), and features Bridgeport's own Filbert's fruit sodas and root beer.

Behind the glass curtain at this Park Manor carryout spot, Arkansas-native Mack Sevier smokes some of the best stuff in town. Go for the rib tips and hot links combo: The rib tips are smoky, extremely juicy, meatier than elsewhere in town and crisp around the edges. The hot links are not for the heat phobic, with searing bits of red chile and smoky, porky, sage-packed flavor—like a spicy breakfast sausage. Opt for the mild sauce unless you're prepared for a scorcher, and request extra napkins if you want to save your car seats.
column204: Best reason to carry Handi Wipes

column7: We're not ones to jump at the chance to be guinea pigs, especially when food is involved. But this culinary student–operated restaurant in the Illinois Institute of Art surprised us with every course. An heirloom-tomato salad offset the bright, juicy tomatoes with three flavored goat cheeses. Pan-roasted chicken came with a distinctly Southern slant, paired with warm corn fritters, a peppery barbecue sauce and smoky Hoppin' John (a mixture of pork and black-eyed peas). And just in case we ever worried about the next generation of Chicago chefs, the supermoist citrus cake and miniature cookies are the proof we need that the future looks very bright.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 3, 4, X4, 10, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151

column7: Here's how it's going to go down: You'll walk into Scooter's, and disregard the hot dogs, Italian ice and anything else that doesn't contain the words frozen and custard. You'll order a Boston shake, and you'll quiver in awe as the towering milk shake topped with hot fudge and whipped cream is handed over. You'll tell yourself you can't possibly finish it. But as you taste how dense, thick, buttery and rich the custard is, you'll soon be on your way to a full stomach and an ice-cream headache. And it'll be worth it.

Yes, the appearance of Noodles by Takashi in the State Street Macy's makes it unnecessary to haul it out to Arlington Heights for good ramen. But if you're hitting Mitsuwa for supplies anyway, skip the food court and head to this discreet jewel for steaming, savory bowls of soy sauce–based shoyu, miso or shio (salt broth) ramen. Gild the lily with extra toppings of boiled egg, fatty roasted pork slices or nori. Maki rolls, crispy tonkatsu, teriyaki and other Japanese standards round out the menu, but there's a reason the only sound in the restaurant you hear above the Muzak is the slurping of noodles.
column144: El: Blue to Rosemont. Bus: Pace 606

column7: Broke Columbia students and vegetarian Loop workers find solace in this casual spot's wallet-friendly menu of Mediterranean-inspired eats. And if value is what you're after, try the vegetarian starter sampler, a you-pick-three assortment that can include roasted eggplant dip, red-pepper hummus and crispy falafel with pita. Carnivores will find more sustenance in the kefta or beef tenderloin kebabs, but everyone can agree on subtly sweet cheesecake as a finale.

Don't let the strip-mall surroundings fool you. Named for (but no relation to) the famed Filipino-Chinese restaurant in Manila, this no-frills restaurant dishes out a highly satisfying egg noodle–and–roasted pork soup called mami. Slow-cooked, fall-apart–tender pork or chicken adobo arrives in dark, slurpable gravy, perfect for soaking up with puto, a fluffy rice-flour cake. Siopao, steamed pork buns, are airy-light with mild, meaty fillings. Wash dinner down with a sweet-tart calamansi juice (made from the Filipino citrus fruit), or top it off with halo-halo, a shaved-ice concoction jammed with slick and chewy flan, red-bean paste, coconut jelly and jackfruit.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: Pace 208, Pace 270

column7: Let the chichi brunch spots have their crème fraîche and fair-trade coffee. Old-fashioned breakfast bliss takes the form of fluffy, dinner plate–size pancakes (from blueberry or pecan to multigrain or buttermilk), fruit-stuffed crêpes, "Belgium" waffles, egg skillets, and crisp, peppery, country fried steak and eggs. Wraps and salads make for a well-rounded menu, but let's be real: You'll want to skip the iceberg lettuce and dig into one of the tasty, classic diner sandwiches (Monte Cristo or tuna melt, anyone?). It's the oldest location in the local chain and draws a crowd on weekends, but some things are just worth the wait.
column93: Blueberry Hill Breakfast Café and Pancake House
column186: Blueberry Hill Breakfast Café and Pancake House

column7: A good deli and a good pizza place—does a neighborhood need anything else? In Bucktown, both can be found under this one roof. By serving deep-dish with a rich crust and chunky, slightly spicy sauce, owner Rich Aronson is continuing a family tradition (the first My Pie was opened in 1971 by his father). The deli, on the other hand, was his idea—and a good one. Juicy house-cured corned beef, fresh-fruit smoothies and fudgy brownies you wish your mom could bake are three reasons why he may have another 30-year tradition on his hands.

Clementina Flores is a mole goddess, a woman sent from the heavens to create sauces so rich and complex, you'll want to ingest them with a straw. Formerly the mole master at Chilpancingo and Ixcapuzalco, she now combines her mole with chef Carlos Tello's food, and magic happens. For each season, mole-doused entrées take on new flavors. Try the callos de hacha al coco, a tropical take on sea scallops with a sauce combining coconut, tomatoes and cilantro. Pato con mole manchamanteles matches farm-raised duck breast with mashed plantains and pineapples to go with a sauce made with chorizo and three types of chiles.
column184: Clementina Flores is a mole goddess, a woman sent from above to create sauces so rich and complex, you'll want to ingest them with a straw. Formerly the mole master at Chilpancingo and Ixcapuzalco, she's now the consultant at this small-plates spot, and when her mole combines with chef Carlos Tello's food, magic happens. Sopesitos (little corn patties) get topped with shredded chicken and mole rojo; and the puerco de manchananteles is pork covered with the mole manchananteles, an exquisite sauce made with chorizo and three different types of chiles.

column7: The folks behind Edgewater's Ethiopian Diamond have taken over the African Harambee space. The menu is basically the same at both locations, but this Rogers Park locale has later hours, jazz every Friday, traditional coffee and hand-washing ceremonies and brunch on Sundays.
column144: El: Purple (rush hrs), Red, Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, 147, 151, 201, 205, Pace 215, Pace 290

column7: There's enough starch and Spam in this casual little Hawaiian spot to keep you set through a weeklong power outage, but don't wait for one to dive into the Big Island classics. The best of the rice-packed menu includes the curry-chicken katsu (crispy, greaseless, panko-breaded, boneless chicken with sweetish, subtly spicy curry gravy) and the kalua pork (perfectly tender pulled pork that's sweetened with a bit of pineapple juice and tossed with stewed cabbage). The "seafood-BBQ" platter comes with perfectly crunchy fish and shrimp, as well as sweet, sticky, grilled short ribs. Grab some guava or passion-fruit juice to wash them down.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 22, 36

column7: Hailing from Hong Kong (where there are 40 locations), Saint's Alp probably doesn't raise an eyebrow among anybody back in the homeland. Here in the States, however (where only three locations exist), this fast-food teahouse is a novelty. Alas, it seems as though mediocre fast food is something we have in common with the rest of the world. The teas here are great (we particularly liked the creamy and full-flavored sesame-milk variety) but the food lacks excitement. But at least there's a view: Sucking down a bowl of vermicelli noodles while taking in the sights of bustling Chinatown is this spot's strong suit.

When we dream about leaving it all behind for la dolce vita in Italy, this is the kind of neighborhood café we picture whiling away the hours in: vintage furnishings, a great selection of Italian newspapers and magazines, and a small, well-chosen assortment of pastries, panini and gelati. We'd start the day with some strong Lavazza coffee and a croissant, hang around till lunchtime for a grilled prosciutto, provolone and green-apple panino, then spend the rest of the day making our way through the rich, creamy gelato flavors (starting with pistachio). Magnifico.
