Dino Perez's parents ran Bucktown's Peruvian stalwart Rinconcito Sudamericano for 25 years, just a block away from where Perez now claims to be stepping away from "old school" Peruvian in favor of what he and chef Jose Victorio call a "fusion of Peruvian, Argentinean and Brazilian." Look for stylized presentations of classics like lomo al pisco (sautéed steak with onions, tomatoes and fried potatoes). To add to his vision of "a lively, colorful spot," Perez has included hand-painted murals and bartenders armed with juices and mixers to turn BYO liquors (allowable Mon–Wed) into cocktails.

There's a lot to choose from on the menu at this cavernous after-work spot, which owners Edgar and Marcos Castañeda very much want to be different from their family's chain of Mexican spots, Lalo's. Gone is the small-plates format with which the restaurant opened. In its place is a trio of sprightly ceviches; a duo of tamales, one stuffed with fiery strips of jalapeño; carne al pastor paired with a tomatillo sauce that's both acidic and creamy; and fish tacos that join grilled tilapia with crunchy pickled onions.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 65, 125

column7: This spot claims to be a Korean/Japanese restaurant, but its nods to Korean cuisine include a few bibimbaps and complimentary banchan. The specialty is sushi, and it's done well. The house roll takes a kitchen-sink approach, combining asparagus, smoked salmon, unagi, crabmeat, avocado, green onion and teriyaki sauce into one bloated, delicious bite. The Low Carb Maki's lettuce, zucchini, avocado and crab was bland (no shock there), but the dragon roll (unagi, avocado, shrimp tempura) was crunchy, sweet and artfully plated. Don't bother with dessert—the Korean touches come full circle with a traditional cinnamon iced tea with the check.

During Shaw's Lobsterfest, which runs until July 31, skip the restaurant's eponymous seafood item and go straight for the seasonal Maine lobster. Those with large appetites can opt for "Rocky's Lobster Deal" ($34.95), a traditional East Coast lobster broil, which includes a cup of lobster bisque, a one-pound whole Maine lobster, corn on the cob, red bliss potatoes, a side of coleslaw and a slice of key lime pie. Maine lobster is also being introduced in a number of specials, such as lobster maki, lobster and Brie penne pasta and lobster salad.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column198: Other location: 1900 E Higgins Rd, Schaumburg (847-517-2722)

column7: The Solomon's cookie warehouse has been on this stretch of Elston Avenue for years, fulfilling orders for its brisk mail-order business. For its first café, it put a swingers-era spin on the place, pumping jazz into the room and selling custom-made fedoras. Start with a chunky chicken-salad sandwich or the tuna ciabatta with bacon if you must, but be aware that it's all about the cookies here: dense raspberry brownies with a buttery cookie base, rich double-chocolate chip cookies that are simultaneously crispy and soft, and adorable thumbprint cookies filled with sweet jams.

Believe it or not, the cult item on this pubbish menu is not fried, greasy or full of cheese—it's the salads. The $5 salad special on Tuesday nights (stereotypically dubbed "girls' night out") has made the big bowls of greens topped with avocado and portobello mushroom the hottest dish on the block. But bar-food aficionados need not worry: A trio of soft pretzels (two of which are filled, respectively, with marinara sauce and mozzarella) and the deep-fried Reuben rolls (a heart attack waiting to happen) fill that niche nicely. We found the pulled-pork sandwich way too sweet, however, so skip it and satisfy your sweet tooth with the warm, gooey skillet cookie.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 74

column7: Though this Nuevo Mexican spot shares the same owners and address as Gold Coast hot spot the Whiskey, the vibe in this tiny dining room is anything but sceny. In fact, under the dim lights, it's the food that creates the most fuss. The guacamole is uncommonly creamy, the shrimp in the tacos are plump and toothsome; coriander-and-chile–crusted tuna is paired with a spicy, sweet and acidic hibiscus–blood orange and habañero emulsion, and carnitas sport an impressively crispy crust. The location does come in handy, though—skip the lackluster pomegranate margaritas and belly up to the Whiskey for an after-dinner drink instead.

The food and service haven't skipped a beat since former chef-owner Michael Altenberg (Bistro Campagne) jumped ship more than a year ago. The menu's entirely different under chef Vince DiBattista, save for the signature guanciale-wrapped radicchio with creamy goat cheese and basil aioli. The focus remains sophisticated Italian food made with organic ingredients, including a simple pappardelle bolognese that gets a boost from its delicate veal, pork and pancetta ragù. Though limited, the mostly Italian wine list offers some exciting choices, especially the dark, velvety Liveli negro amaro.

Neighborhood types in Portage Park wouldn't dream of going anywhere else for their 'za, and after tasting the pizza di casa—topped with a heavenly combo of sausage, bacon, onions and Parmesan—we understand why. We'll stick with the standbys on the rest of the gussied-up menu: a simple mixed seafood grill studded with calamari, shrimp, mussels and octopus, and eggplant Parmesan and baked rigatoni that both get a red sauce worthy of every last crumb of bread on the table.

Some cafés are customized for the weary traveler, and this bohemian outpost is spot-on. Imagine a travel bookstore, a tiny clothing and bauble boutique, and a rock-solid vegetarian eatery all rolled up into one global handful. It's a brilliant hodgepodge of working stiffs, bookish students and colorful artists ordering up the likes of soft toast with fat smears of chèvre and juicy tempeh burgers with tart blue cheese. The extensive menu reads like a round-the-world sampler platter, and the made-for-sharing portions are perfect when eaten while lounging on the Turkish-style pillow seating by the window.

Want to escape to a simpler life this weekend? Head to this 60-something-year-old hideaway. Before it was a restaurant, it was simply a family's farmhouse with a large porch where friends and nearby workers would stop in for cold beer and corned-beef sandwiches. Pan-fried burgers served on house-baked black rye came along soon after (as did a full-fledged business), and are still the spot's signature. There's nothing wrong with those burgers, but we prefer to head to Harms (as this location of the now six-strong empire is called) for Friday night's lake perch fish fry. A couple of crispy filets slathered in tartar sauce and a tall glass of weiss beer on the tree-shaded porch and we're happy.
column8: Outdoor seatingKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: Chef Juan Carlos Lopez ran a Mexico City restaurant El Famoso ("The Famous") 13 years ago, and now he's brought his straightforward menu here. That means you can expect the usual suspects, like ceviche, tacos, fajitas, chicken mole and grilled skirt steak, along with dishes like the "El Jardinero" salad topped with fresh tomatoes, avocado and tortilla strips and rotisserie chicken rubbed with 14 spices. That menu, plus a dozen tequilas, Mexican beers, fruity sangrias and margaritas, might just make him famoso in Chicago.
column144: El: Red to Cermak-Chinatown. Bus: 3, X3, X4, 18, 21.

column7: This galletería is essentially a chicken-focused version of a Brazilian steakhouse. The "endless feast" includes either baba ghanoush or cheese bread; sides like housemade polenta and deep-fried potatoes; pasta; and an unlimited supply of lamb shank, beef tenderloin and young chicken from the wood-burning rotisserie.

With high-top tables and a bar that runs the length of the room, it's clear this Britishish spot is putting its pounds on the pub scene. New and old come together on both the cocktail list and the menu: Drinks include a traditional Pimm's Cup and an St. Germain Champagne cocktail, while classic fish-and-chips and a turkey burger topped with mushrooms and goat cheese are among the food choices. The Newcastle-battered cod is crispy, fat and flaky, and the DIY meatball sandwich comes with a comforting, mom-style mushroom gravy. Attention to detail fails with the music, though; Starship's "We Built This City" wrecks the Brit-pub vibe.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Late-night diningOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156

column7: This Uptown spot is a haven for those seeking modern, upscale Indian eats. The jewel-toned room is dateworthy; the wine list is pairing-friendly. And many of the contemporary dishes—like the duck-leg confit with blistered green beans and expertly grilled kalonji chicken with almond and raisin–studded rice pulao—are worth the extra dough you'll spend here rather than on Devon. Recent additions include a snack-friendly selection of "Naanwiches"—lamb vindaloo, tandoori chicken and other traditional dishes wrapped in warm naan and served with papadum chips—as well as tasting-size portions of malai kofta and other curries.

Pastry chef Jessie Oloroso is behind the gelato creations on offer at this casual counter-service gelato/panini spot. Play the odds and sample to find your own favorite; signatures include roasted pistachio, salted peanut and whiskey. For sustenance before the main attraction, try the tart anchovy and the honey-drizzled Brie and prosciutto bruschetta. Giardiniera-topped spicy capicola and the house-cured bresaola with pickled onion are standout panini, both perfectly pressed.

We kid you not: The sweet smell of grilled short ribs emanated so strongly from this unsuspecting spot that we abandoned our previous plans and swerved into the parking lot. From our first bite of the flat seafood pancake rife with scallions and squid, we knew it was a good move. Enormous bowls of slippery noodles were a bland waste of time, but the barbecue—particularly the kalbi, whose soft layers of fat melted on our tongues—and the tasty banchan (fish cakes with a kick of spice; kimchi packing flavorful, building heat) had us hooked. We hear that many people come here to take part in the karaoke, but we don't get it; how can you sing when your mouth is full?

Lest you have any doubts about the inspiration behind this café's moniker, the place is decked out with so much Catholic imagery, it looks like a garage sale thrown by the pope. And yet—as long as you don't have an aversion to angels—this is one of the most comfortable, homey spots in Little Village. The continental menu balances upscale café grub—thin crêpes stuffed with meaty slices of smoked salmon and plated on fresh greens; a chicken-breast panino with layers of sweet, silky mango—with basic pastas and breakfast fare. Expertly prepared cappuccinos, earnest service, and endorsements from Will Ferrell and Maggie Gyllenhaal (who filmed scenes from Stranger Than Fiction here) will make you a believer.

Eating at this casual Lakeview spot is like hanging out in the kitchen while Dad whips up another one of his delicious meals. Sip a from-scratch limonada or horchata while the kitchen cooks huevos rancheros and mango pancakes at breakfast, light fish tacos studded with tilapia at lunchtime and hearty enchiladas for dinner. The heaping $8 carne asada dinner entrée, perfectly grilled and served with creamy guacamole and rice and beans, may just be the best deal in town.

The Middle Eastern crowd at this new Turkish spot should tip you off that it isn't another watered-down outlet for hummus and pita chips. In case you aren't convinced, the menu reveals its authenticity. It's filled with Turkish dishes that are largely unfamiliar in these parts, such as balik sarma, grape leaves stuffed with sardines and crisped around the edges for an aggressively flavorful, crispy starter; cig borek, a savory, deep-fried pastry stuffed with ground lamb; and manti, dumplinglike "Turkish ravioli" stuffed with more lamb and topped with a garlic-yogurt sauce.

Sick of sandwiches and salad bars for lunch? If you can head south of the Loop for your midday meal, you can get a pretty tasty dose of Anglo-friendly Thai instead. All of the standards from curries to noodles are dependable, but we recommend starting with the delicate charred-squid salad and the miang sa-wan—a sweet, limey mess of dried pork, ginger and peanuts meant to be wrapped in lettuce leaves. To feed a fish craving, try the crispy catfish tossed with Thai eggplant and green beans in red-curry paste, and if your idea of curry involves tons of creamy coconut milk, the yellow gari with sweet potatoes and chicken is your fix.

You're interested in trying Puerto Rican food, but you don't know your pastel from your pescado? Use this casual little stalwart as your entry point. You may have already tried its tamales and plantains at Taste of Chicago (where it's the sole Puerto Rican representation each year), but dive deeper into the cuisine with a mofongo (a pork-filled plantain fritter) to start, a jibarito (steak sandwich made with crispy plantains for bread) for a warm-up, and get to the main event with the sautéed steak with onions and a side of pork-flecked beans and rice known as arroz con gandules. Helpful photos of dishes line one wall (the soups taste better than they look) and the English-speaking counter staff is good with guidance.

Named for a province in the Mekong Delta, Ben Tre presents authentic, homestyle Vietnamese cooking (aimed at local Vietnamese families) in a bright, lime-green storefront. Pho, the classic beef-noodle soup, arrives properly soulful with a rich, aromatic broth and crunchy fresh herbs to sprinkle on top. The peanutty rice noodles with grilled beef and pork egg rolls (bun bo nuong cha gio) and a coconut-milk crêpe studded with streaky pork belly and shrimp (banh xeo) exemplify the kitchen's skill with traditional dishes, and the spot-on green-papaya salad (goi du du tom tit) sent us straight to the tropics.

Do you really need us to explain what the focus of this new bar is? We didn't think so. But just so you know, this enormous nightspot also offers food such as crab cake corn dogs and buffalo chicken lollipops.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156

column7: The only thing that's wild about this place is how insanely popular it is—even on a sleepy Tuesday night, you'll need a reservation. Other than that, though, the menu will be familiar (think upscale TGI Friday's). Steaks seem to be a favorite among regulars, but we found that the seafood fared better: Meaty swordfish "London Broil" is topped with juicy roasted tomatoes and sweet roasted red onion, and crab-crusted shrimp are the epitome of guilty pleasures. Our filet mignon didn't taste like much—but that's probably why it's topped with such full-flavored "crusts" as horseradish and blue cheese.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle. Bus: 1, 7, 22, 24, X28, 125, 151

column7: It's hard to keep up with the back-of-the-house changes at this sultry lounge: First, chef Radhika "Rad" Desai took her Top Chef fame and hit the pavement. Then, after a brief and promising stint at the helm, her former sous chef Noah Sandoval peaced out, too. Now "chef-consultant" Jose Victorio has introduced a menu of contemporary American food with Peruvian and Asian twists such as tilapia ceviche dotted with Andean corn kernels and ahi tuna–topped flatbread with wasabi aioli.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 56, 72

column7: For years, Everest has lived up to its name, becoming the pinnacle of high-end French dining in the Windy City. Atop the Chicago Stock Exchange, it is still the height of elegance, with views of the rooftops that made the city famous. Chef Jean Joho's seasonal menu—though often-changing—features carefully executed French specialties like boneless rabbit with horseradish, frogs legs and black cod. But the real specialty is the sense of elegance you feel just from having dined at this level.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listViewsVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle

column7: We can go on and on about how rustically adorable this tiny cucina is—with its open kitchen, twinkling lights and handwritten daily-specials board—but the real star here is the jaw-dropping food. Purple curls of lemony, flame-licked octopus and housemade pastas (standouts are the medallions rolled with ricotta and spinach in a light tomato sauce and the tagliolini with mushrooms and earthy truffle pâté) are served on delicate old china. Pollo arrosto con patate (rosemary chicken) is a typical juicy dinner entrée, while simple salads and true Italian panini offer lunch options for a mere five-spot.
column144: El: Red, Yellow and Purple to Howard. Bus: 49B, 97, Pace 215

column7: There's almost nothing wrong with the $44 porterhouse at this legendary meat emporium—it's impeccably seasoned and boasts warm layers of sumptuous fat running through the full-flavored meat. In fact, the only problem is that for $44, the thing is kind of small. But this kind of price-size discrepancy is rare at Gibsons: sweet lobster cocktail easily satiates two, the endlessly juicy prime rib comes in a hefty portion typically reserved for the Flintstones, and desserts are so enormous that servers cut them in two, packaging half in a take-away bag, no questions asked.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Kid-friendly
column198: Other location: 5464 N River Rd, Rosemont (847-928-9900)

column7: The Westin Hotel River North has tacked on this feng shui–inspired, summer-only spot—a 30-seat, flower-dotted outdoor eatery with a waterfall and views of the Chicago River. Offerings include a selection of sandwiches (crab cake Monte Cristo, grilled-chicken panini), entrée-size salads (smoked salmon with micro greens and asparagus) and stir-fry.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 62, 134, 135, 136

column7: Looks like the folks behind French bistro La Petite Amelia have a weakness for American fare: They opened this decidedly casual burger operation next door a couple months ago. Instead of escargot and tarte flambé, they serve "Big Burgers" (one patty), "Bigger Burgers" (two) and "†ber Burgers" (three), each of which comes with your choice of sauces to slather on the buns (we like the green salsa and the curry mayo the best). Despite the names, the patties aren't all that big. But throw in a hearty bowl of chili, a basket of house-cut fries, and a housemade chocolate-chip cookie topped with ice cream, and you have yourself a meal.

While its name literally mirrors Moto, Otom's menu doesn't exactly reflect the extraterrestrial creations or sky-high prices of its adjacent sibling. Instead, exec chef Thomas Elliot Bowman looks to offer creative spins on comforting classics. A recent menu overhaul injected some flair in the form of pork chops with bacon bread pudding, coffee-crusted ribs and Bowman's answer to Roscoe's: a chicken breast paired with a purple yam waffle. The bar staff goes toe-to-toe with local cocktail clubs, turning housemade bitters, fruit purees and infused liquors into the perfect precursor to an interesting meal.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Sure, there's a lot that's Disney-esque about this red sauce spot from Brinker (the company that owns Chili's), from the fake black-and-white family photos to the red-checkered tablecloths. But, as much as we hate to admit it, we find ourselves wanting to get our hands on those family-sized platters of puffy gnocchi, dense eggplant parmesan and juicy chicken marsala. What we don't crave—or understand, in this city of so many fine Italian options—are the never-ending mob scenes.

Though the sign outside Uptown's newest bar and grill gets the vintage, '40s-ish feeling just right, you might want to keep your zoot suit at home: Inside, Rihanna is singing about um-ber-ellas and martinis are made with pomegranate juice. Skip the Reuben bites and goat cheese appetizer (the goat cheese, which claims to be seasoned with harissa, is particularly disappointing). Instead, head straight for the braised pork belly Cuban sandwich, the rich meat mingling with vinegary pickles to great success, or the chicken fried steak, which arrives topped with a thick gravy that's hard to stop eating (even though it's clear that if you don't stop soon, it's going to kill you).
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seating

column7: Among the regulars huddled over cups of coffee and packs of cigarettes at the worn wooden tables is an older lady with the Midas touch. Some of her breads may already be made, but if you're lucky she'll have to bake some from scratch, which takes about 30 minutes. Order one meat-and-potato and one spinach-and-cheese, and soon she'll flip a hot pan over a paper plate, coaxing out a round of steaming, fragrant bread that resembles a stuffed Danish. She calls it pita; we think it's more like burek, but the buttery, flaky pastries are so luscious we don't really care what they're called—we just know we can never make it home with anything left in the bag.

It's no longer a private club (that practice, which entailed a miniscule $1–$5 membership fee, ended in 1996), but after more than 30 years in business, this is still the most regal restaurant in town. Owner Mary Beth Liccioni keeps the grounds (a townhouse built in 1895) decked out like something out of Dynasty: lush fabrics, ornate carpeting, giant arrangements of flowers. But chef Chris Nugent's ever-changing French-American menu keeps the food current (if still pretty rich). Guys, take note: This remains a good place to propose (or beg forgiveness). But make sure you're wearing a jacket—you wouldn't want to get scolded in front of your date, would you?

Film buffs and food geeks know Tampopo as one of the best—and most overtly erotic—food flicks ever made. This cute sushi spot may not be as, um, intense as the film, but the thick cuts of fresh salmon and yellowtail on offer here are hard to argue with. Delicious "Caterpillar" rolls (sweet unagi, cucumber and avocado) and "French" rolls (shrimp, cucumber, Japanese mayo) will satiate maki fans, while a steaming bowl of noodles and shrimp in a salty broth makes a rich, flavorful sushi alternative. Overly tough beef rolls make this place not quite as perfect as the movie. Then again, nothing ever is.

The second location of the South Loop's successful red-sauce joint varies very little from the original formula. The menu remains the same—fat meatballs, lasagna, veal scallopini and the like. Expect Sinatra-style sounds and giant martinis. The newbies to the neighborhood are packing in already.

Located inside the John Hancock Center, this tourist favorite pleases adults and kids alike with a selection of more than 30 flavors of cheesecake–from plain to white chocolate caramel latte to key lime–that are available daily. Breakfast items like omelets, sausage and bacon are available all day, along with a large selection of fairly straight ahead salads, pastas and sandwiches.

There are two kinds of Chicagoans. No, not North Siders and South Siders. We're talking Giordano's people and Lou Malnati's people. Lou Malnati's deep-dish is the pinnacle of cheesy Chicago-style goodness. Everything else on the menu—including pastas and salads—is passable, but not worth passing on the 'za. Get the butter crust. And don't worry when you develop a Lou Malnati's addiction: They Fed-Ex pizza anywhere in the country.
column8: Private party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125

column7: Good luck trying to pop into this charming little café for a grab-and-go cup o' joe. We tried, but once we got an eyeful of its warm browns and dark woods and sunk into the banquette's creamy leather, we bid adieu to the day's to-dos. The sensibly succinct menu sports far more hits than misses, including a panino piled with hot, tender roast beef, gooey blue cheese and caramelized red onions; and a Caesar salad wrap in which a warm flour tortilla hugs crisp lettuce and smoky slices of chicken. Other delicious distractions include a rotating assortment of desserts (think crème bržleé and chocolate-raspberry mousse) and a large selection of coffee and loose-leaf tea (both courtesy of Julius Meinl). Free Wi-Fi is also on offer so you can curb any sloth-induced guilt.

Despite a renovation in 1999, this hot dog drive-in is still as old-fashioned as ever, with uniformed servers bringing your order directly to your car window. Apparently scared of copycats, the owners have trademarked almost every dish, the main draw being the "Superdawg," an all-beef frank so plump it's hard to remove it from its cartoon-covered box. It may all seem like kitsch, but there is a practical side: After a meal of hot dogs, fries, burgers (try the delicious, double-decker "Whoopercheesie") and "Supershakes" (actually not very super), you can literally roll yourself home.

This small, simple and slightly upscale BYOB is proving that creative and contemporary food isn't happening on just the North Side. Opening chef Thomas Eckert has moved on, but Rob Kurecki looks to fill the void with recent nods to fall that include poached pear salad with cranberry-bacon vinaigrette, brined pork chop with apple-cider sauce and sweet-potato polenta, and grilled walleye with roasted artichokes and spaghetti squash. Clean your plate and you've earned the seasonal sundae of spiced caramel-apple gelato topped with pumpkin and sautéed apples.
column144: Bus: 9, 103, 112. Metra: Rock Island to 103rd St
El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

column7: This is health food that doesn't taste like health food, fast food that doesn't taste like fast food—and those are both high compliments. Lemony foul (fava bean puree) arrives at the table just moments after it is ordered. The "rolled pitas"—essentially Middle Eastern burritos stuffed with grilled chicken shistawook and a slathering of toum and then grilled—aren't far behind. Housemade juices like the sweet carrot-apple provide an extra dose of nutrients. But just in case your mental health requires something stronger, an interesting wine list featuring many Lebanese bottles is on hand.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

column7: It's barely big enough to hold all his fans, but chef Art Smith's restaurant is full of big-flavored, butter-laden Southern-inspired foods, most of them worth trying to get a reservation for. One of the best dishes (the goat cheese biscuits) comes complimentary, but other menu items are worth paying for—ancho chile-crusted pork chops with pickled cherries, fried green tomato napoleon with goat cheese and a pistachio-crusted chicken breast with coconut-ginger chili sauce. Almost just as important as the food is Chef Smith himself, who's occasionally in the dining room checking on guests as if, well, he owned the place.
column8: Good for dining at barFireplace

column7: This always-bustling Greek spot is popular for good reason: The food is inexpensive, you get it fast, and it tastes great. The signature artopitas—flaky puff-pastry rounds with fillings like ham and kasseri cheese, and chicken and mozzarella take center stage, but there are also fresh salads, sandwiches and traditional Greek dishes like roasted lamb and a weekly moussaka special. Bonus: The front that overlooks Halsted Street is perfect for people-watching.

Chef John Hogan of Keefer's Restaurant caters to the tourist clientele of Millennium Park with updated standards such as a barbecue-chicken sandwich (completed with a cherry-cola barbecue sauce), double-cut pork chops, chicken potpie, housemade shredded onion rings and shoestring fries served with white-truffle aioli.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: The stories are true—this subterranean tavern is still the best spot to get a made to order "cheezborger" with a side of schtick. Sam Sianis, nephew of Billy Sianis, the Greek immigrant who founded the legendary haunt in 1934, still hollers out orders from behind the U-shaped counter. Avoid weekends unless the atmosphere you're in search of includes fannypacks and camera flashes. Weekday lunch still offers a glimpse of hungry reporters, cops and downtown characters bellied up to bar in true Mike Royko fashion. Just remember: no fries, cheeps; no Pepsi, Coke.

This Italian-leaning deli from the folks behind stellar sandwich shop Milk & Honey offer cured meats, cheeses and antipasti by the pound, making it a perfect post-work or pre-picnic stop. For snacking instead of shopping, order up one of the dozen panini and sandwich creations, the best of which is the porchetta, tender roast pork dressed with ricotta salata, arugula, walnut pistou and truffle oil. The frittata panini and Intelligentsia coffee make for a good breakfast; Italian sodas and Black Dog gelato are stellar refreshers.

If you're under 50 and don't belong to a North Shore synagogue, you may feel a little out of place at this throwback steakhouse, where the entry's covered in signed photos of ancients such as Henny Youngman and Arte Johnson. But don't let that stop you from indulging in the splendor of the chopped liver with bits of hard-boiled egg, fresh challah rolls brought to the table when you sit down, iceberg-lettuce salad with green goddess dressing and the famous skirt steak with burnt onions. It's all well worth the heartburn.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendlySuburbanPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar

column7: The female owner-and-chef team behind this swank River North spot are both of Indian descent, but they aren't doing Devon. They're attempting to elevate Indian cuisine and weave in Latin American flair via dishes like chile-glazed tamarind ribs with sweet corn salsa. The new "dhaba fare" section of the menu includes eats popular at truck stops in India: goat curry, chicken in creamy tomato gravy and spicy garbanzo beans. Creative spice-driven specialty cocktails like "blueberry cardamom fizz" are tasty enough to warrant a separate visit to the bar.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar

column7: It's always encouraging to find little ice-cream shops that make their own products, so you can imagine how psyched we were to find that this gelato gem also makes dozens of varieties of filled chocolates and truffles. Go for broke and get a cup of gelato for now (the pistachio and the tiramisu are our favorites) and a custom-selected box of sweets for later (try the ginger truffle and the dulce de leche chocolate). The shop also does custom gelato cakes that will reduce the folks at Baskin-Robbins to tears.

This sleepy stretch of Hyde Park gains interest from this all-day hookah lounge. By day, the Wi-Fi and extensive list of teas and coffees attract laptop-carrying U. of C. students, but come dusk, older patrons linger over hookahs and small plates until the wee hours. Sandwiches are tasty and cheap (the red pepper and cheese on grilled flatbread is a standout); ditto for the standard but fresh soups (try the tomato bisque) and salads. After a simple meal, settle in for some hookah puffing in enclaves outfitted with cushy pillows, draperies and game tables.
column144: Bus: 2, 6, 15, 28, X28, 55, X55. Metra: Electric Line to 55-56-57th St

column7: Ken's Diner and Grill is the Johnny Rockets of kosher eating. Head to this old school soda foundation for fat, messy, tasty burgers and perfectly-seasoned fries. Also on the menu are bison burgers, pie and homemade cookies. The shakes, of course, are strictly non-dairy.
column8: Late-night diningKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: You've forgotten all about this place, or you never really had it on your radar. That's fair. But this regal dining room, sparkling chandeliers and all, is waking up and hoping to return to the top of Chicago's restaurant scene. To that end, executive chef Nick Sutton has padded his winter menu with duck confit ravioli with cherry puree; cocoa nib crusted sturgeon with roasted heirloom squash; and venison leg with parsnip-pear puree, dishes creative and seasonal enough to draw a crowd that was born long after this spot's heyday.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)

column7: Forget lugging around your lunch in a picnic basket—this Puerto Rican lunch truck in Humboldt Park lugs it around for you. As the illustration of a happily skewered pig on the side of the truck suggests, it's all about the pork here. Pulling the meat from the bone with a pair of tongs, servers pile an enormous heap on top of fluffy yellow rice (ask for lots of skin to get as much of the delicious spice rub as you can). But not everything here comes big enough for three: Baseball-size mofongo (savory balls of green plantain and pork) and mini jibarito sandwiches (pork, rather than the traditional steak, on crispy plantains) make taking the pig to go as easy as pork pie.
column92: The northernmost intersection of Humboldt Blvd

column7: These utilitarian booths, bright orange walls, beach shack-style menu board don't look like much. But looks can be deceiving. These are some of the tastiest vegan eats in the city. We love the veggie chicken submarine and the spinach pizza, both made with homemade baked goods, but make sure you wash them down with honey lemonade (provided, of course, you are not a vegan who eschews honey). Save room for the fresh daily desserts. You won't break a $10 spot.

When we say that Podhalanka has an "old world" feel, we mean old world in that premodern comforts kind of way. Not that they don't have electricity at this dive, but it is dark and not as clean as your mother would like. What it lacks in atmosphere, it makes up for in tasty, authentic Polish eats. We love the beet salad, cabbage soup, potato pancakes and pierogies. We also love talking about the old country with the buddy on the barstool next to us.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9 (24 hrs), X9, 56, 70

column7: Ann Sather is not the best dinner in town. It's not the best lunch, or the best breakfast. It may not even be the best diner food. But that doesn't matter, because Ann Sather has the sweetest cinnamon rolls in the Midwest. If you must, you can order some "real" food off the menu—crab cakes Benedict for brunch won't disappoint you; neither will Swedish specialties, such as the roasted duck with lingonberry glaze. But let's get real: You're only after those fluffy cinnamon rolls, which arrive too big for the plate they're on and submerged under warm icing. Lucky for you, they come with almost every order.
column198: Other locations: 5207 N Clark St (773-271-6677); 3411 N Broadway (773-305-0024); 3416 N Southport (773-404-4475)

column7: You could pop into this old-school bakery/café for a bowl of tomato bisque, which is topped with sweet whipped cream (an odd addition that actually works). Or you could simply nibble on a club sandwich stacked with hardboiled eggs and thick slices of tomato. You could even nosh on a cheesy, individual-sized quiche Lorraine and call it a day. But if you don't end things with a silver pot of coffee and a slice of cake (we like the chocolate with raspberry preserves and fluffy buttercream), you're really missing the point.
column60: Pastry shop: Sun–Thu 7am–7pm; Fri, Sat 7am–8pm. Café: 11am–4pm

column7: You may find it daunting to sit under paintings of severe Polish street scenes, amid what seem the dour denizens of a former Soviet state. But suck it up and savor Angelica's tasty chow at Perestroika-era prices. Start with the excellent $2 soups (cucumber, white borscht, etc.), all housemade and served with serious bread for sopping. Hand-wrapped pierogi are deliciously sauced with warm bacon fat while "Beef Roll with Pickle and Bacon Inside" is a hunk of toothsome meat encasing tart vegetable, drowned in gravy and served alongside full-flavored buckwheat. Of the many Polish brews to choose from, Browar Lomza proves a decent match for this satisfying comfort food.

DJs spinning and customers dancing in the dining room may not be for everyone, but if you're into that, you're in for a treat with this pan-Latin restaurant's food. Much of the menu's built for sharing, from combo platters of empanadas or ceviches to a four-course menu available to groups of four or more that offers grilled seafood paella, chimichurri-crusted beef tenderloin and more. Shared plates are all well and good, but as for the mojitos—you'll want one (or three) of your own.
column8: Notable wine listGood for groupsGood for dining at barOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66

column7: Drawn by tales of this pizzeria originating Chicago deep-dish, tourists and new transplants often flock here for their first Windy City meal. Around lunchtime, a crowd can be found in the lobby ordering their pizza in advance while waiting for one of eighteen tables that are packed into the small building. Each pizza takes at least 45 minutes to cook, but it's worth the wait when the waiter finally arrives with the steaming pan and dishes out your first cheese-heavy slice. If you've got a larger party or just can't stand the wait, head down the street to Pizzeria Due (619 N Wabash Ave), Uno's more spacious sister.

If you can get used to all the soy milk, tofu and tempeh on the menu, this vegetarian restaurant can feel like a normal, everyday diner. Waits for weekend brunch can get painful (even though the menu is served daily), but patient non–meat-eaters are rewarded with dense (and fairly flaky) soy margarine biscuits and sweet chocolate-almond muffins made with vegan egg substitute. French toast is a little soggy and lackluster—but after all, this is diner food.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Andersonville's other Mediterranean spot (located right next door to its competition, Reza's) heavily touts the health benefits of its food. What it doesn't tell you, though, is that you're likely to stuff yourself so silly that the health benefits will be canceled out. The gluttony starts with complimentary rounds of warm, thick pita served with red-pepper hummus and incredible, half-off deals on wine daily. Continue with the aromatic Moroccan chicken buried under toothsome couscous and juicy kebabs (the kefta is particularly tender). Don't stop until the last spoonful of Tunisian housemade hazelnut pudding is gone.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningFireplaceOutdoor seatingKid-friendly

column7: Breakfast may be the biggest meal of the day here, but most people leave Lumes so stuffed with pancakes that they're ready to take a nap. The basic buttermilk pancakes (which come with almost everything on the menu, including the veggie-packed, Nerf football–size omelettes) are fluffy and golden, and blintzes are thin and filled with sweet cheese. But it's worth forgoing all that and waiting 30 minutes for the German-style "Dutch Baby," a bowl-shaped pancake with crisp edges and a soft, warm middle. Finishing it will definitely make you want to crawl back into bed.

Unless you're lucky enough to have a grandparent sitting at home frying up fresh batches of falafel, this may be the freshest Middle Eastern food you'll find in Chicago. The refrigerated case is filled with rows of plump, glistening, marinated chicken and just-formed kefta kebabs waiting to be grilled-to-order. Freshly baked savory pies, bursting with spinach and big chunks of onion, sit on the counter. Behind that, a man drops falafel into a pool of bubbling oil. We don't care who your grandma is—she's not making anything like this.

This sparse new Middle Eastern cafeteria has a rich history behind its deep-red walls: Owner Rashad Moughrabi has been in the restaurant business since the 1970s. He's been serving his signature "steak in a sack" all the while, and the sandwich still holds up, with thin, juicy slivers of steak and caramelized onions piled into a pita with diced tomatoes. Other menu highlights include creamy hummus and nicely grilled chicken shawarma with tahini sauce. Skip the blah eggplant salad and the mashwiya, a zucchini and yogurt dip that should pack more of a punch.

Restaurants may come and go, but the Bagel never closes...it just moves locations. In its latest spot (the third since 1950), the deli has managed to bring a little Jewish curmudgeonliness to Boystown. So when you're at the take-away counter ordering your potato knish, or sitting in one of the booths dipping a fluffy roll into the magnificent, housemade chicken soup, you might have a brusque comment or two thrown your way. But this is to be expected. After all, the Bagel hasn't survived all these years by being nice.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 145, 146, 151

column7: Not everyone gets dim-sum cravings on Sundays. To feed your need during the week, this spot serves Chinese breakfast every day. Check off your order on the provided paper (no rolling carts here) and soon you'll be stuffed with all the classics, from Chiu Chow–style (meaning, hailing from Hong Kong and its surrounding region) dumplings to memorable salt-and-pepper squid. Come 3pm, a co-owner and another kitchen crew take over, swapping out the dim-sum menu for dinner offerings, again primarily of a Chiu Chow–style. Go for the clams in slightly spicy black-bean sauce, salty egg tofu with four types of 'shrooms, green beans with dried fish slivers and minced pork, and Japanese-ish eggplant with beef.

This neighborhood favorite is a bright, sunny spot on an otherwise boring strip of Damen Avenue. Standouts from the menu of typical Thai fare include plump green mussels in a soy-fish broth flecked with green onions, green chiles and basil, and the Rama special—crunchy steamed broccoli and fresh ginger served over rice with a yummy housemade peanut sauce. Curries are on the soupy side, but tasty nonetheless. A weekday dine-in lunch special offers an appetizer and entrée for just $6.50. Added bonus: There's free lunchtime wireless Internet access every day except Sunday.

Lincoln Square may have lost many of the Germans who settled there over the first half of the 20th century, but this bastion of oompah fun, baron-size beers and heaping platters of carb-tastic classics remains. The plastic, feather-stuck alpine hats passed out to patrons Disney-fy the experience a bit, but long wooden tables built for big groups add to the campy party atmosphere. The lederhosen-clad Brauhaus Trio performs nightly, packing the raucous dining hall with duos who ditch their rouladen to jump up and dance zwiefacher-style (think polka with quick turns).
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Purists may scoff at the ho-hum offerings, but this long-time favorite continues to pack in crowds who may prefer their pad si-ewe come a little more Anglofied than authentic. You'll find perfectly fine versions of standard noodle and rice dishes like lad nar (crispy wide noodles sauteed with veggies and topped with gravy) and Chinese fried rice. Vegetarians will do particularly well choosing from inspired sides like watercress with garlic bean sauce and chilled steamed broccoli with Dijon-soy dressing.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77
column198: Other locations: 1542 N Damen Ave (773-394-0100); 950 W Diversey Pkwy (773-281-8448)

column7: This quirky Indian snack and sweet shop is just a stop for a quick bite: Think of a Devon Avenue-style McDonald's. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Here you can catch up on Bollywood's latest soundtracks while you stack your plate with samosa, pakora and kulfi. If you time things right, you can have your fortune told by an in-house palmist.

They had us at hello, those dreamy, creamy cupcakes. (Us and every other Chicagoan with taste buds.) This sweet-as-can-be little bakeshop may have cornered the local market with its simple little chocolate and yellow cakes slathered in a colorful array of buttercreams, but there's much more to salivate over here. We like the puddings (butterscotch, chocolate, banana with Nilla wafers), the crispy, big-as-your-head cookies, the seasonal fruit crisps, the whoopie pies. We haven't found a dud here yet.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage; Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 73

column7: Chef Laura Frankel of Skokie's kosher spot Shallots Bistro will oversee the kitchen at this casual, daytime-only café in the recently revamped Spertus Institute of Jewish Studies. Expect baked goods and coffee in the morning and salads, sandwiches and sushi for lunch. An on-site mashgiakh will keep things kosher.
column144: El: Red to Harrison. Bus: 1, 2, 3, X3, 4, X4, 10, 14, 26, X28, 146

column7: The newest addition to the Chicagoland restaurant empire offers more of the same to its loyal biz-cas clientele: pricey, well-portioned steaks, chops and fish in a comfortable yet elegant atmosphere. Fans of the plush steakhouse feel should settle in comfortably and go for broke with a nice bottle of Cab, the 18-ounce Delmonico rib eye and sides of sauteed mushroom and garlicky spinach. An upstairs room offers privacy to broker that big deal.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingNotable wine listGood for groupsGood for dining at barKid-friendly

column7: Korean food is all about the barbecue for us, so imagine our surprise when we realized that, for once, the kalbi was taking a backseat. At Woo Chon, we'd gladly forgo it for the rich dolsot bibimbap, a fantastic version of the classic rice-egg-meat-veggie casserole, the plump seafood pancake or the doeji kimchi bokkum, luscious slices of pork mixed with spicy kimchi. And then there's the best surprise of all: the tofu soup, which gets props not just for its deep layers of flavors, but also for being free.

Old Towners don't care about all the authentic Mexican spots that have been opening lately—their loyalty is to this sea-blue burrito-and-margarita shack (which, of course, is filled with more piñatas than you can, um, shake a stick at). The main ingredient here is cheese: It's melted on the suiza overfilled with spiced beef and the sweet mole enchiladas (but not, thankfully, on the hearty chorizo tacos). Not everything here is tailored for the American palate, though: The salsa on the table packs a good amount of heat—the perfect pairing for one of the famous margaritas.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

column7: A vegan baker is like a cyclist without legs: Uncommon but not unheard of, and—if Sweet Cakes is any indication—sometimes just as successful. Emily Smith, chief baker and co-owner (with her dad) of this East Village destination, presides over the ovens here, and despite not eating cream or eggs or milk chocolate, she still manages to put out perfectly solid red-velvet cupcakes topped with an indulgent buttercream frosting; saucer-sized chocolate-chip cookies with plenty of deep brown-sugar notes; and hearty corn muffins hiding a whole hardboiled egg inside, the perfect handheld breakfast—that is, if you eat that sort of thing.

With a menu of only cupcakes (flavors change daily but include the insanely popular red velvet) and beverages, this take-out bakery bears a striking resemblance to other cupcake shops in town. But it hopes to distinguish itself with gluten-, sugar-reduced and sugar-free options, "pupcakes" for dogs and its custom cupcake carry-out boxes, which keep the icing perfectly in place.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: "The Packers can kiss my ass," "We close when we feel like closing" and "Nothin' but cash, no exceptions" are among the oh-so-perfect-for-the-setting sayings we overheard from the bartender-server in just one night at this 39-year-old, subterranean seafood spot. Grab a table in the tiny Christmas light–strewn room, and start out with the chowderific "Mulligan stew" and an order of crispy calamari. For more fried goodness, have the "Thirty-Two Pointer" for an entrée—a crunchy pile of smelts, perch, frog legs, clam strips and fat shrimp. And if you're looking to crack some crab, splurge on the massive, meaty king legs—they're so succulent and sweet they'll double as dessert (the only true desserts on offer are gratis lollipops).
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76

column7: We give them props for the pretty dining room, but we don't understand why the cooks at this new Thai spot are shy with spice. Maybe they figure the condo dwellers flooding these parts can't handle the heat, but when you can wipe your eyes with the papaya salad, even Grandma would be bored. Quick solution: Doctor up the handful of dishes that show potential—crispy salmon-basil rolls (request peanut sauce for dipping), shrimp noodle panang curry (ask to add veggies) and "tiger smiling," marinated grilled beef tenderloin cubes on a bed of watercress (specify medium-rare to medium). If you don't mind being the world's most annoying diner, you'll end up with some pretty good eats.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 12, 29, 62

column7: For more than a decade, the sweet Vietnamese couple that runs this little gem ran their restaurant on the strip of Argyle Street often dubbed Little Saigon. Citing skyrocketing rents and lack of parking as the two motivators, they moved to the northwest edge of Logan Square a couple of years ago. The casual room, doting hosts and home-style food make the experience seem like eating in someone's home, only this someone churns out barbecue shrimp and sprout–packed Vietnamese pancakes; rice noodle bowls brimming with barbecue pork, crispy egg rolls and peanuts; tangy, spicy lemon shrimp; and restorative, delicate chicken broth–based soups.

The word radhuni translates roughly from Bengali to "home cook," and this Indian-with-a-Bengali-twist restaurant seems to have a few of those in the kitchen. Must-try starters are the slurpable, crimson-red tomato soup, and the "Bengol" kebab, chicken chunks wrapped in a whole-wheat flour casing and deep-fried. Skip the confusing Radhuni special salad, but don't miss the juicy and smoky tandoori chicken, delicious nan, and housemade mango and pistachio kulfi (ice cream).
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Started by CEO Gregg Majewski—a man who was instrumental in the Jimmy John's chain—this local burger shack hopes to bring its Black Angus burgers, soft brioche buns and thick chocolate-peanut-butter shakes to all corners of the country. Maybe that accounts for the streamlined menu— burgers, fries, shakes, and breakfast egg sandwiches are the only items on offer. But though the restaurant may not be cooking very many items, the things they are cooking they're cooking well: burgers are thick and juicy, piled with fresh toppings and flanked by tasty (if McDonald's-ish) fries. So if this outpost isn't convenient, just wait—we have a feeling there'll be one near you soon.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams

column7: This former prepared foods shop is now a full-fledged restaurant that's carved out a niche with its reservation-only Saturday night "underground" dinners and tasting menu–only format (four courses for $45, seven for $85, 13 for $150). Value comes via the spot's BYOB status, and dishes that put season at the forefront but are also consistently creative. The menu changes according to the chef's whim, but recent seasonal additions include rhubarb with tea-smoked baby octopus, stinging nettles in a mussel-studded miso broth and fiddleheads with spring lamb leg. Take advantage of the back patio on warm nights.

If you want to get a preview of the spot that's slated to open in December in West Town, head to the western 'burbs where chef Andy Park (of Starfish and Sushi Ai) unveils the menu that will eventually run at both spots. Per usual for Park, specialty maki with names like King Kong, Black Light and Firecracker dominate the menu, while a dozen cooked Japanese entrees and raw bar make up the rest.

We've seen couples linger over dinner here, head to a nearby movie, and come back later for coffee and dessert. The draw of the place is dishes such as the housemade salmon-and-ricotta–stuffed ravioli neri; the creamy, perfectly al dente risotto with peas, ham and asparagus. But the meal doesn't end there: Just when you think you can't eat anything else, the friendly owner comes over and pours a shot of housemade limoncello.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 9, X9, 73, 74

column7: Unwrap your Italian beef sandwich (you ordered peppers on it, right?) and spread out the paper like a tablecloth. Grab your sandwich with both hands and hold it in front of you, keeping your elbows on the table. To take a bite, lean toward the sandwich; do not, under any circumstances, move the sandwich toward you. Doing so will only lead to juices spilled onto your clothes—and if you're simultaneously working on a messy side of cheese fries (which you should be), you don't need the added risk.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 125, 156.

column7: Sometimes it's nice to just get out of the city for a few hours, and the ride up Sheridan Road along the North Shore to this cozy, tranquil French bistro is a good excuse to expand your horizons. The menu—a rotating list of carefully executed seasonal dishes and tasty standards like steak frites and roasted duck breast—isn't anything you won't find within city limits, but the location overlooking Lake Forest's historic Market Street sure beats an urban landscape of snarled traffic and dumpsters. Be sure to save room for fancy housemade s'mores for dessert.

Weary shoppers have long escaped the Mag Mile for respite in a glass of vin and a heaping bowl of steamed mussels at this solid bistro. Hanging hats, comfy banquettes, brass accents and a lengthy bar add to the Frenchie flair. The menu sticks to standards like roasted chicken, steak frites and crème bržlée, all of which scratch that Left Bank itch. A sidewalk patio offers prime people-watching in warm weather, as well as a charming place to enjoy weekend brunch.
column8: Private party room(s)ViewsOutdoor seating

column7: The wise-cracking wait staff is as much a part of the gimmick as the memorabilia and music dating from the 1950s to 1970s at this Disney-esque diner, which is a particularly fun visit for families but not necessarily anyone else. The food's almost an afterthought, but you can't go wrong with classic burger, French fries and gravy, and kitschy-cool desserts like the world's smallest ice cream sundae (basically a shot glass–sized portion).
column8: Private party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendly

column7: This dimly-lit fondue spot is a reliably romantic date destination. For pairs on a first date, the four-course Prince Geja Combination ($44.95 per person), while pricey, allows you and your date a chance to break the ice while experimenting with various dips. A salad starter is followed by the cheese fondue appetizer with bread, grapes and apples. Then, beef tenderloin, chicken breast, lobster tail, jumbo shrimp and sea scallops are brought out to be cooked in the tableside hot oil pot. Indulge, but be sure to save room for the flaming chocolate fondue dessert, served with cake, marshmallows and several kinds of fruit.

If it gets any more old-school than this circa-1941 steakhouse, we haven't seen it. Filling every inch of the wood-lined dining room are naugahyde bar stools, chairs and banquettes as blood-red as the steaks (both well-aged, we might add). Servers range from formal to gruff, but they mean well and they deliver the goods: textbook veal vesuvio, a "garbage" salad fit for four, calf's liver sauteed with onions and bacon, perfectly seared chops and garlicky shrimp de Jonghe that the veteran staff swears the joint invented. Believe 'em—these are the Chicago old-boys you don't want to piss off.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for dining at barFireplace

column7: Eating in this quasi-fancy dining room gets you free admission into the adjoining jazz club, but there's no reason why dinner here shouldn't be an attraction all by itself. Chef Hal Lascano takes his work seriously, and is particularly good with seafood. Silky strips of smoky salmon and tender, pan-roasted scallops are a good way to start, and his Asian-influenced tuna, brushed with a soy glaze and plated on vermicelli noodles, is a delicious second act. But it's really the world-class wine list, which seems to go on forever and has a fair share of bottles around the $30 mark, that steals the show.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listOutdoor seating

column7: The legendary Cubs announcer may be gone, but his spirit lives on at his popular namesake eatery. These days Caray's widow, Dutchie, greets patrons who continue to crowd the place during Cubs games as well as the off-season for gargantuan steaks (23-ounce poterhouse, anyone?) and classic Italian dishes like chicken Vesuvio, sausage and peppers and veal picatta. The walls are awash in memorabilia that will keep sports fans entertained for ages.

A sushi restaurant that serves Taittinger Champagne and Rodney Strong Pinot by the glass obviously aims for a sophisticated clientele. And since it's on East Illinois Street, that's exactly who this newish spot is getting. High-rise dwellers and moviegoers fill the dark, comfortable space later in the week and settle in for the lengthy process of reading the massive menu. Most of the sushi classics are fresh and tasty but overpriced (ditto for the cooked entrées). You'd do better with the creative concoctions from the "Fusion" portion of the menu, like quick-seared tuna topped with tart green apple, jalapeño slivers and sesame ponzu, or the surprisingly delicious shishito peppers stuffed with cream cheese and crab and scallop meat.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyGood for dining at barLate-night diningOutdoor seating

column7: With neighborhood favorite Julius Meinl just down the street, we're a little concerned for this new cozy, dark-wooded indie café—and not just because of Poupée's potentially unappetizing name, which is French for "doll." The panini and salads are by no means as good as Meinl's, but to its credit, the food, like the gooey but bland chicken quesadilla, is certainly lunchworthy and usually a couple of bucks cheaper. If it's just a pick-me-up you seek, grab an Orange Mocha Mio—a delicious combination of Lavazza espresso, orange chocolate, steamed milk and whipped cream—and cozy up to free newspapers.

Awash in underwater blue-green hues and pulsing with ambient techno (lest we forget we're in Boystown), this spot is a neighborhood draw for older gay couples and even older Lakeview lifers. While the solid menu offers few surprises, what Jack's does, it does well: a grilled calamari starter with spicy tomato-pesto that's as simple as it is delicious; and a four-inch-high ice-cream turtle pie that's a gut-busting ender.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: This popular Edgewater haunt remains a solid Latin American option. Start with the small, but tasty, beef and spinach-mushroom empanadas with spicy avocado sauce. Red snapper, shrimp, squid, scallops and clams swim in the cazuela de mariscos' creamy tomato sauce, and the flank steak (sobrebarriga a la criolla) is so tender, chewing is almost a formality. Savor it, though, just as you should the delicious margaritas—shaken and poured into martini glasses tableside.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Good for groups

column7: Old-school doesn't begin to describe this Chicago landmark. Though not the original (which opened in 1938 in Beverly Hills), the Lawry empire's second notch has stood its downtown ground since 1974. When we need a break from the fancy cheeses and foams, we head here for comforting nostalgia, order the Lawry cut medium-rare, use the crispy Yorkshire pudding to sop up the mahogany gravy, go for the lobster tail add-on, finish with a dense, simply delicious slice of chocolate cake and savor every last minute in our favorite time warp.

The accolades on the wall of this restaurant suggest that it's one of the best, most innovative Chinese spots in the city. But look closer—the articles are all from 1993. Since then, it doesn't appear that the restaurant has changed much, neither in the dining room nor on the menu. But even if it no longer feels new, it is at least still solid. Because some Chinese basics—pudgy pork-stuffed dumplings; salty, crispy soft-shell crabs with stir-fried chiles; sauteed bean curd with ground pork—don't have an expiration date.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 50, 84, 147, 151

column7: Skip the spate of breakfast basics at this the city's first Dutch pancake house, and order the one savory pannenkoek. At a centimeter thick, almost a foot in diameter, and topped with baked-on slices of bacon and havarti cheese, it will quickly prompt comparisons to an open-faced crêpe. While not all of the three varieties of pannenkoek on offer are as delicious (indeed, the chocolate-banana topping turned the pancake into a soggy, overly sweet mess), this cheery and charming little breakfast nook is well worth at least one trip, if only to slake a curiosity about the Dutch treats.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Skip the fries and skip the milk shakes—you're not here for that stuff anyway. Just order the Italian beef sandwich, and get it as messy and spicy as you can (that is, ask for extra gravy and an extra spoonful of the crunchy giardiniera). The thin strips of beef are tender and flavorful enough as it is, but the sandwich doesn't really sing until it's got a little kick of spice. Alternatively, you could order the combo, which seasons your beef sandwich with a crackly skinned Italian sausage. But come on—you couldn't possibly hate yourself that much, could you?
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago, Red to Chicago. Bus: 65, 66, 156.

column7: Take a number: This always-bustling bakery, an Andersonville stalwart for more than 75 years, churns out myriad goods, such as breads including the popular cinnamon-raisin and limpa loaves; a number of petit fours such as carrot, rum roll and Swedish cannoli; and marzariner—a traditional Swedish almond tart. It's well worth the wait.

The name of this joint is meant to make you believe that the food here will be so good you'll sprout wings and fly. That didn't quite happen when we dug in to the simmering plate of loukaneko (hearty Greek sausage) or the smooth, tangy taramasalata, but it nevertheless got our meal off to a good start. Entrées, on the other hand, we can take or leave. Better to skip the chewy scallops and typical spanakopita and go right from the apps to dessert. Their desserts, baked in-house and brought in from sister restaurant Artopolis Bakery, include the delicious milopita (flaky apple pie spiked with cinnamon and honey). Sadly, it was the closest we came to getting our wings.

The only problem we seem to run into when dining at Jerry Kleiner's pan-Asian West Loop stalwart is what to order; the vast menu is packed with tempting options. Having tried most of it, we can say we love starting with the five-spice ribs, the octopus-and-avocado kimchi salad and the crunchy calamari-tangerine salad. Next, we go for the fisherman's stew (it's the miso-lobster chili broth that makes it), the pork chop with thick black-vinegar demi-glace and the peanut-studded panang-beef curry, with an order of edamame stir-fried with pearl onions and cashews. Share with friends, try a bit of everything and come back to find your own favorites.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20.

column7: A restaurant in a preppy clothing store on the corner of Michigan and Chicago Avenues; could anything be more precious? The short answer is no. But while you will undoubtedly be entertained watching fur-clad women whisking in, kissing in-house socialite Bunky Cushing on both cheeks and sitting down for two bites of a Waldorf salad, there are a few other things worth experiencing here. The Dover sole, for instance, is prepared tableside with so much pomp you'll think you're eating with the Queen of England. Us? We'll take one of the expertly shaken sidecars and the burger, which, surprisingly, is pretty damn good.

In Chicago Rosebud is not a sled. It is a local chain of classic—yet tasty—Italian restaurants. There's nothing particularly innovative about the rigatoni alla vodka, clam linguini and other baked and tossed pasta dishes. But they always arrive in large portions, tasting like you expect and you'll walk away full. There's no real reason to choose one location over another other than convenience.

Normally we don't condone paying through the nose for Chinese food when Chinatown options abound, but this gorgeous fourth-floor terrace, brimming with fresh flowers and offering a view of the historic Water Tower, is hard to beat. And elevated takes on five-spiced duck, drunken baby chicken and wok-baked lobster mostly surpass expectations.
column8: ViewsNotable wine listOutdoor seating
column92: The Peninsula Chicago, 108 E Superior St

column7: Not only is the plush rooftop patio with a 40-foot bar, sharp sound system, sofas and stools perfect for a nightcap (or night-starter), it's great for sashimi as well. We're not crazy about the mushy rice, so skip the nigiri in favor of slick cuts of the day's fresh catch. For a break from the mundane happy-hour rituals that abound downtown, the $10 bento box promo offered from 5 to 7pm is a good deal, but it's on Wednesdays after 10pm that this slick spot turns booty-rific for Favela Nights, a weekly party driven by Rio rhythms and a rotating cast of performance artists.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingViewsGood for dining at barGood for groupsLate-night dining
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156

column7: As the name suggests, dessert is not to be missed at this bright café: Moist miniature chocolate cakes and swan-shaped cream puffs end the meal on a perfectly sweet note. But don't discount the savory options. Spring rolls wrapped in thin pastry (as opposed to rice paper) are superfresh; roasted duck salad is a heavenly combination of rich duck, cool cilantro, sharp green onion and a hint of chile pepper; and panang curry is sweet and slurpable. Ignore the mussels, though—when there's a huge pastry case to choose from for dessert, they're just not worth the stomach space.

Nothing's changed much in the 76 years since this Old Town rib institution first startedÊpacking in the crowds, and that's okay with us. Once in a while, we'll still cram our way into the old tavern to wait among the masses (no reservations are taken) for the falling-off-the-bone, baked-then-grilled babybacks with a side of the "zesty" (really tangy) sauce. Add a side of the pork-flecked baked beans and an Old Style, and it's a perfect Chicago meal.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

column7: Perhaps best known for its wine list, this quiet restaurant on the first floor of the Margarita European Inn may still be Evanston's best-kept secret. Because in addition to the extensive, all-Italian wine list, there's also a list of well-executed, appetite-inducing apertivos. And there's even food to go with it—dishes like stalks of spring asparagus paired with a nutty Parmesan and lively tomato fonduta; housemade ravioli stuffed with a sweet-and-savory combination of caramelized onions, pancetta and spring peas; and perfectly juicy slices of lamb lined with dark, flavorful char marks from the grill.
column8: Notable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingFireplaceSuburban
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 201, 205, Pace 213

column7: Of the six locations of this homegrown pancake chain, this is the original. The granddaddy of the bunch has been packing in flapjack-craving families since 1960, and only the prices have changed. Settling on one kind of 'cake is tough, so go with a group and graze. The apple pancake is killer, with apple chunks, cinnamon and sugar baked together until the edges caramelize with crispy glaze. Plump blueberries burst out of fluffy hotcakes that arrive with warm blueberry sauce alongside for a double dose of fruit. Swedish-style pancakes have perfect lacy edges and a requisite topping of tart lingonberries; couple them with smoky sausage patties for a perfect breakfast, and don't forget to down a glass of pulpy, freshly squeezed OJ.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: The man behind White Palace Grill and Hollywood Grill is behind this affordable Loop diner stocked with a full bar and a menu of munchies, hot sandwiches and breakfast served all day. And since it's not every day you come across a rooftop deck in the middle of the Loop, we recommend taking it upstairs if weather permits for an after-work drink.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red, Blue to Jackson. Bus: 1, 2, 6, 7, 10, X28, 29, 36, 62, 126, 151

column7: The namesake chef behind this 12-year-old restaurant knows a thing or two about tapas—the Spaniard was the opening chef for Café Ba-Ba-Reeba!, Chicago's first tapas spot. Here at his solo venture (where Saturdays are raucous and Sundays are serene), little has changed in a city that's in the grips of small-plates mania. The classics still rule the show: salty-sweet bacon-wrapped dates in roasted red-pepper sauce, killer garlic potatoes, crusty bread topped with tangy tomatoes and whisper-thin jamón serrano, and perfectly grilled shrimp in garlic butter. Skip the too-rich goat cheese–eggplant rolls and the oversauced spicy potatoes, but don't miss the velvety flan.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

column7: For more than a decade chef-owner Gabriel Viti has been the culinary darling of the North Shore. His eponymous restaurant is the flagship of his restaurant empire and it is easy to see why. The white tablecloths are offset by the mahogany interior, and the service and food are equally elegant. Expect seasonal French and Italian cuisine, a large selection of pasta and an impressive wine list.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingNotable wine listSuburban
column144: Metra: Union Pacific N to Highwood

column7: This novelty cafe located inside the American Girl Place store gives girls the opportunity to have a proper meal or afternoon tea party in public with their dolls, who actually get their own "treat seat" at each table. The menu includes kid-friendly foods like mac-and-cheese, chicken tenders and, for dessert, cookies, but parents won't balk at items like the broccoli-and-mushroom quiche and lemon-pepper tilapia.

The massive outdoor patio with a close-up view of the city skyline is the main draw of this Greektown spot in the warmer months, but—snarky service aside—there are reasons to dine inside, too. The restaurant's signature dish—lamb and artichokes in lemon sauce—is tender and nicely tangy, and other menu standbys, such as creamy taramasalata (fish roe spread), charbroiled octopus and well-seasoned gyros, are up to neighborhood standards. Skip the same old baklava for dessert and opt for the dreamy galaktibouriko, lemon custard in honey-coated phyllo dough.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)ViewsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingFireplace

column7: Located inside the Harrington Inn & Spa, this intimate, ten-table dining room has three atrium-style window walls that look out onto the banks of the Fox River. At breakfast, plenty of sunlight pours in as diners start their day with souffle pancakes, frittatas and basics like bacon, eggs and hash browns. In the evening hours, classics like beef tenderloin, duck and filet are served in flickering light from the towering stone fireplace.

Though named after a hedonistic festival, this is a quaint, family owned restaurant that has been serving up what it calls "recipes from the Old Country" in the Heart of Little Italy for over 25 years. Nouveau Italian cuisine takes a backseat to over 20 pasta dishes and a long list of classics like chicken parmesan and veal scaloppini. Bacchanalia is not nearly as sinful or risky as its name implies, but is certainly satisfying.
column144: El: Pink to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 60
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 73, 74

column7: A mega-rotisserie serves as the heart and hearth of this cozy Mag Mile restaurant, where the simple, quality American food has a dash of Tex-Mex flavor. Rotisserie chicken and lamb find their way into many of the oversized sandwiches and salads. It's popular with the suits during lunch, and in the evening tired shoppers looking for a substantial dinner stop in for a meal that won't challenge their palates or their purses.

column92: Foundry Shopping Center, 700 W Northwest Hwy,

column7: The tacked on "Italian Bistro & Pizzeria" is the first clue that this location of Bacino's goes well beyond the "heart healthy" thin and stuffed pies that put this Chicago chain on the map. The decent breakfast selection includes waffles and omelets, but we'd recommend going in the afternoon or evening for one of the nine pasta plates and, yes, the pizza.
column144: El: Red, Orange, Pink, Brown, Green, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake. Bus: 2, 3, X4, 10, 26, 29, 66 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 148, 151, 157

column7: The torchbearers for authentic indie eateries are recommending an LEYE Chinese spot? Well, yes, but with caveats. As opposed to the pan-Asian Big Bowl, the theme here is regional Chinese, with renditions of Mongolian, Cantonese, Shanghai and Szechuan dishes. The menu is massive, so sip on the slusheelike, citrus vodka–spiked, frozen ginger ale while perusing. Best bets include crispy cubes of sesame-coated tofu drizzled with garlic sauce; salty-sweet star anise–braised pork with scallion pancakes for wrapping; and shrimp with wheat noodles and mushrooms in a spicy chile sauce. Skip the fried rice and beef dishes unless you want to regret not making it to Chinatown.

column92: Hawthorn Fashion Square, 700 N Milwaukee Ave.,

column7: It may not look like anything special—there's no celebrity chef, no four-star reviews tacked to its walls. But this River North stalwart has been around so long because it does something almost no other restaurant of its kind does: It serves until 3am, every day. That's not its only use: The hefty burger (which arrives on the rare side of medium-rare), the generous grilled shrimp in a fiery tomato sauce and the barbecue salmon don't taste at all bad during the day. But somehow, they taste doubly good after midnight.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Amid tony Gold Coast restaurants is this authentic Paris-style bistro, complete with the day's paper dangling from wooden rods, silver-plated egg stands beckoning hungry drinkers to the zinc-topped bar and a menu that delivers all the classics in reliable fashion. Wine-steamed mussels and butter-drenched escargots sate shellfish-lovers, while onion soup's beefy broth and gobs of Gruyère satisfy comfort-food cravings. Steak frites is fine, but too thin for our taste, so instead opt for the peppercorn-crusted New York strip if you're craving red meat.

Could the sibling restaurant to the Empty Bottle turn out good food? Surprisingly, yes, but with caveats. We've been underwhelmed by regular menu mainstays like the catfish sandwich and the burger, but after repeated visits, we figured out that the specials board is where it's at. It changes frequently, but recurring hits include crunchy fried chicken and adobo chicken cooked in coconut milk, plated with fried spinach and sweet-potato fries. Season comes into play with specials like chilled cucumber soup and watermelon lemonade, plus vegetarians have plenty to choose from, including a popular Caribbean-style curried vegetable and tofu stew.

Designed like some sort of cross between Denny's and Burger King—only with a soul-food slant—this South Side minichain may be the only fast–soul-food joint in town. But while the food takes only minutes to arrive at your table, it tastes like it was slowly, carefully cooked with love over a home stove. With its crispy, golden crust, the mustard-fried catfish is clearly the restaurant's standout dish, but don't discount the juicy smoked chicken, collared greens, pork-studded black-eyed peas or delicious peach cobbler, which puts those other fast-food pies to shame.

A restaurant that's survived nearly six years in the notoriously fickle nexus of hipsterdom must be doing something right. Locals return to the sexy, dimly lit space for the reliably fresh, generous cuts of fish and the inventive maki (don't miss the perfectly crunchy Hot Night), most of which stop just short of ridiculous (with exception of the Shiroyama, a goopy, mayo-soaked mess topped with baked scallops). Chef's specials change monthly, but we're praying the creamy Brazilian lobster sashimi will stick around forever—it's so sweet and smooth you won't mind that there's only ice cream for dessert.

This tourist-packed, Disneyland-like version of a rickety New Orleans shrimp shack sports all the proper decorative contrivances like chipping paint and seafaring kitsch, a zydeco soundtrack and the requisite menu of shrimp dishes and other "Dixieland favorites" like baby back ribs and barbecue pork. Clothing, stuffed shrimp dolls and "Run Forest Run" license plates are sold in the gift shop.

column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningFireplace

column7: Muy caliente is more like it—enchiladas del mar, packed with shrimp, scallops and crab, sounded innocent enough, but the guajillo pepper sauce crept up on us, and pretty soon we were sweating bullets. Puerco en chile verde con nopales,which paired luscious pork with cactus, proved a much more mild choice. Empanadas vary, but if you hear the word "guava," save it for later—the syrupy filling makes much more sense at the end of the meal than at the beginning.

It doesn't hold up to the big-name steakhouses more centrally located in higher-rent districts, but Carmichael's is a good choice if you're on your way to United Center. On-the-ball service and a warm bread basket with a crock of melted cheddar cheese help balance out cuts of beef that tend to be more chewy than melt-in-your-mouth. Sides like garlic mashed potatoes are worth saving room for, but be prepared for a bit of sticker shock when all those yummy add-ons are tallied up.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seating

column144: El: Red to Clark and Division. Bus: 22, 36, 70.

column92: Leo Burnett Bldg, 35 W Wacker Dr
