column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to State.

column7: Surrounded by all the boisterous Clark St Cubs bars pushing pub grub, this upscale Chinese restaurant and sushi bar–specializing in crispy duck, whole red snapper and a variety of stir-fry dishes–stands out like a sore thumb. The tables are nicely spaced in the sleek, minimal dining room, which is given a splash of color by a variety of potted floor plants.

What, you ask, does Niche offer to lure you all the way out to Geneva? Chef Jeremy Lycan (formerly of 302 West, which preceded Niche at this address) composes New American dishes with a big emphasis on seasonal ingredients. The fall menu features a spicy pumpkin-and-sweet-corn soup, New Zealand lamb shank with roasted chanterelle mushrooms, and a grilled honey-glazed tuna filet in steamy organic miso broth flanked by carrots and snow peas. For dessert—the highlight of our last visit—choices include a pumpkin tart (short-dough crust, caramel sauce, nutmeg-scented whipped cream) and a "blackberry buckle" (streusel topping, cinnamon ice cream, and vanilla and blackberry sauces).
Rosebud plans to open in the former Chicago Prime Steakhouse location in April 2007.

Okay, you didn't come to town to eat school food. But, trust us, CHIC Café ain't no standard lunchroom. Students at CHIC (Cooking & Hospitality Institute of Chicago) test out their chops, both in the kitchen and in the dining room. Most still need to practice their table-waiting skills, but the menu rarely disappoints. And, because the students are still learning the ropes, the meal's always a bargain.
column92: Cooking and Hospitality Institute of Chicago, 361 W Chestnut St

column7: The name seems to suggest that no matter how thoroughly you stuff your face with the Jewish deli goods on offer, stress release will still elude you. But we beg to differ: Sitting in the bustling space on a weekend afternoon, drinking a Dr. Brown's and noshing on the "Katfish" (a perfectly executed tuna melt on fragrant, toasted rye) and the warm Reuben oozing with Russian dressing, we couldn't feel more at ease.
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 49, X49, 50, 56, 72

column7: All Greektown restaurants are not created equal, and when it comes to taramasalata, tzatziki and htipiti (a spicy feta spread), this elegant stalwart rises above the rest. From there you can go one of many routes: two thick, juicy (but unadorned) lamb chops; the "Shrimp Costas," big, garlicky crustaceans piled atop angel-hair pasta; or the meaty gyros. No matter which route you take, make the simple, cinnamony, housemade rice pudding your final stop.

With the waitresses brandishing brogues along with the shepherd's pie and Guinness pints, you know this Lakeview Irish pub is the real deal. Besides potpies, fish and chips, and other Emerald Isle imports, everyone from neighborhood families to tipsy Cubs fans stops in for the above-par bar grub. You can't go wrong with the char-grilled skirt-steak sandwich, turkey-and-corned-beef Reubens, and Bass Ale–battered onion rings the size of your head.
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating

column7: The taqueria menu at this family-run traditional Mexican restaurant can provide a quick, tasty taco or a big burrito if you're on the go, but it's the slowly prepared dishes like the chipotle filet, as well as the upscale dining room with its seasonally focused menu that really set this place apart. The fresh, often creative daily specials are also worth keeping an eye out for.
column144: Bus: 68 Northwest Highway, Metra: Union Pacific Northwest to Edison Park
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76.

column7: Half Italian steakhouse, half North Woods supper club, EJ's Place offers the perfect combination of upscale Chicago and laid-back Wisconsin to its North Shore clientele. Old school bartenders and waiters give the place a genuine feel. The menu is a collection of entirely predictable steakhouse plates prepared with the least amount of fuss.
column8: FireplaceGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Suburban

column7: While there are Mexican restaurants with better menus and better margaritas, it's hard to compete with El Jardin's outdoor seating in the warmer months. There's a good deal of sunshine seating—the front patio seats 40, and the spacious garden in the back seats 100—but the wait for a table can sometimes be rather lengthy, especially on game days at Wrigley Field, located just three blocks north.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: The rather average offerings at this late night Mexican restaurant are made more attractive by both their value and their round-the-clock availability. From 11pm until 5am, six entrees ranging from burritos to burgers to seafood are offered for the paltry price of $6.75 apiece. And from 5–11am, you can plop down into a colorful booth and partake of huevo-heavy breakfast items and Mexican sausage.

Men—lots and lots of businessmen, their suit jackets shucked and their ties loosened—fill every seat and corner of this hidden West Loop restaurant. It's not the most conducive setting for eating dinner, but if you must, ignore the flavorless housemade ravioli and make a meal out of the baked clams and a steak. The meat comes completely unadorned, but it's juicy and as big as your plate—and if you're a real man, that's exactly the way you'll like it.
column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace
Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: Despite the Christmas light–laden decor, the permanent soundtrack of classical-music "hits" and the puny cocktail list (which reinforces the classical-music theme with names like "Too Hot to Handel"), we're going to resist the urge to call this fondue restaurant "cheesy." Instead, we'll call it "memorable," because while the Swiss-cheese fondue, beef bourguignone fondue (cubes of sirloin cooked in an oil fondue) and the buttery garlic bread that accompanies it all is merely solid '70s grub, the bizarre experience as a whole is something you'll never forget.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendly

column92: Water Tower Place, 835 N Michigan Ave

column7: This family-owned neighborhood pub does beer, wine and food better than most in their category. The beer selection—around 15 on tap and 13 in bottles—is surpassed only by the wine list–100 are available by the bottle and 12 by the glass. Those looking to dine can take a seat on the patio in the warmer months and pick from a lengthy menu featuring Gorgonzola ravioli with Parmesan cream sauce, black olives and tomatoes; blackened flank steak and mushroom salad; and a small selection of poultry and chops.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 73

column7: From the second you take your seat and a manager asks, "Howyadoin?" in her thick Chicago accent, you know this place is about as classically Chicago as they come. And judging by how crowded it is, it may be one of the main culprits behind the city's obesity problem: Enormous entrées like tender baked ribs and juicy barbecue chicken come with bread, salad and big, hearty sides like the twice-baked, cheesy gratin potatoes. Real Chicagoans, however, should have no trouble cleaning their plates.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 56A, 81, 85, 85A

column7: This elegant, if somewhat drab restaurant is able to cater to the downtown crowd without totally losing Devon Avenue quality. The extravagant daily lunch buffet offers a dozen entrees for under $10, and is a good opportunity for those with less experienced Indian palettes to try a little of this and a little of that without worry.

After 12 years of expressing his Spanish side at Tapas Barcelona, Spanish-Italian owner Giovanni Garelli decided to channel his mother's Italian heritage by opening Gio just up the street in 2003. Service is friendly, and the long bar is comfy for grabbing a quick bite. But we tend to linger, starting with antipasti of fennel salad and wood-roasted peppers, moving on to the fettuccine with rich porcini sauce or mezzaluna stuffed with lobster and ricotta, and wrapping up with the veal limone or cioppino seafood stew.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for dining at barGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlySuburban
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 201, 205. Metra: Union Pacific North Line to Evanston-Davis

column7: True to its name, this charming Lincoln Park spot injects dishes with sweet tamarind every chance it gets: Light and fresh cilantro, mint and basil–packed spring rolls get a sweet tamarind dipping sauce, and the crispy rice noodles in the mee krob are flavored with tamarind, green onion and egg. But even when the signature ingredient is omitted, dishes can still stand out: Crispy catfish arrives in a red curry with a lot of kick (go for the pad see-ewe, thick rice noodles with crunchy broccoli and juicy chicken, for a milder option), and a cakey pumpkin custard makes for a sweet, tamarind-free ending.
column144: El: Brown, Red to Belmont. Bus: 7, 8, 9, 11

column7: Exposed brick and plasma-screen TVs have taken the place of worn pool tables and dart boards after a fire forced a redesign of this neighborhood dive. But while the digs may be snazzier, the signature pan pizza—in all its glory with a ring of caramelized cheese around the crust—remains the same. Skip flavorless fried-vegetable appetizers, salads and sandwiches and save your appetite for a couple of ginormous slices of a sausage pie, dotted with perfectly spiced, Ping-Pong ball–size pieces of seasoned ground pork.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningKid-friendly

column7: What do Madonna, Oscar De La Hoya and the Mexican National Soccer Team have in common? Their pictures are all posted on the walls of this Humboldt Park taco joint. (We're not saying they all ate there, but the owners clearly are fans.) This primarily Spanish-speaking restaurant specializes in the authentic street food of Puebla, the central Mexico town credited as the birthplace of mole poblano. Because Puebla has a large concentration of Lebanese immigrants, you'll find tacos arabes, pork tacos with thick, pitalike wrappers. At Taquería Puebla, these chipotle-spiked beauties and their friend the cemita milanesa (a breaded pork steak with cheese and avocado on a sesame-studded bun) are among the best of the menu.

Located in a sleek corner of a new Loop office building, this contemporary restaurant by the Bar Louie folks is bustling with countless pin-striped professionals who require a glass of wine to go with their office gossip. Like their attire, the food is safe but it works. Big, juicy shrimp are wrapped in bacon and topped with a jalapeño sauce; short ribs get a tangy crust of mustard, herbs and bread crumbs; and a shaved-apple salad is refreshing and sweet. But while you don't necessarily need to be a banker to eat here, you do need to keep bankers' hours: The kitchen closes at 7pm.
column144: El: Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Quincy. Bus: 1, 7, X28, 56, 60, 124, 126

column7: You might be surprised to find a real barbecue joint out past the airport and just beyond a giant landfill, but if you're looking for the type of 'cue that typically gets passed through a bulletproof window but served in a sit-down restaurant, this is your best bet. There's no skimping on smoke when it comes to the pink and meaty baby back ribs (ditto for the pulled pork and house-smoked ham). But skip the blah brisket in favor of more molasses-rich baked beans, creamed corn and andouille-packed gumbo. Grab a cup of classic banana-pudding parfait for a sweet ending.
column198: Other locations: 800 E Higgins Rd, Elk Grove Village (847-437-9555)

column7: Drag in all your Mag Mile shopping bags and don't fret about the worn-looking jeans you're sporting–you won't get any dirty looks here, just friendly, attentive service and a solid meal in an unpretentious environment. The spacious second-floor perch is decked out with marble floors and tables, curvy velvet-upholstered booths, and vaguely Greek-inspired wall mosaics. The menu cuts a broad global swath: pasta dishes and oven-baked pizzas; flautas and quesadillas; and Asian additions like the duck potstickers and crispy Ahi sushi rolls.

If the plethora of newspaper clippings in the lobby are any indication, this import from Beverly Hills was the restaurant in 2000. Now that the buzz (and, as a result, the crowds) has died down, the effect is just the opposite: You can sink into one of the roomy leather booths, put down a few well-executed classic cocktails, tear into a citrus-marinated skirt steak (or, if you're feeling a little heart-healthy, the cedar-planked barbecue salmon) and relax, knowing that nobody will ever find you.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for groupsGood for dining at barOutdoor seating

column7: The rock 'n' roll memorabilia at this shiny, over-the-top pseudo-museum might've gone to our heads, but we're seeing band homages everywhere. Okay, the "Joe Perry of Aerosmith Quesadilla" is shamelessly overt, but do Paul and Linda have anything to do with the "Classic Wings?" Does Jeff Tweedy know about his "Tupelo Chicken Tenders?" And why the hell would "Creamed Spinach" be on the menu if not to reference Eric Clapton's psych-blues trio?
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Heartland is as much a playground for twenty- and thirtysomethings as it is a restaurant. Local music acts ranging from folk to rockabilly to jazz flock to its stage as frequently as the local art on the walls changes. Top billing, however, belongs to the menu. To the delight of vegans, vegetarians and the cholesterol conscious, organic whole wheat breads, salad plates, seitan fajitas and black bean burgers are offered, but red meat–seekers won't be disappointed when the turkey alternatives to bacon and ham arrive plated next to their generously-sized omelets. The general store adds to the close-knit community feel, selling a range of items from clothing and books to fair-trade coffee and jars of honey.

If double-headed dragon rolls and ginger soy–tinis are what you expect from your sushi experience, go elsewhere. This old-school sushi den has been offering Japanese standards in a no-frills setting for 25 years. It's got a solid sake list, fresh nigiri (don't miss the buttery toro or the tender baby hamachi) and traditional maki. Fish-haters can sample housemade gyoza or choose from a huge list of appetizers, noodle dishes and tempuras. Judging by the autographed photos of Japanese pro-baseball players displayed in the sushi bar, this place is a homesickness cure for at least a few jocks.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: Sometimes you just want no-frills, good-value sushi without a side of slick decor, snooty servers and doont-doont-doont beats. This overlooked spot on Randolph Row meets that tall order (save for the beats, which are apparently required of raw fish houses). Still, the volume is tolerable enough that we can focus on our friends and our food. The best of the latter includes thick squares of sashimi (fresh salmon, superwhite tuna and yellowtail are all fresh and flavorful) and the punch-packing Lion maki roll (yellowtail, tuna, avocado, cilantro and jalapeño rolled tight and drizzled with chile sauce). Wash it all down with the value-priced sake; two people can sip for around $12.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningBYOB
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Though this Contempo American restaurant is a chain, it makes an admirable attempt at separating itself from the stigma usually associated with corporate clone cuisine. Almost everything here is prepared in-house: the burger beef is fresh-ground, steak and fish are hand-cut in the kitchen, the salad dressings are mixed on the premises and even desserts like the occasional key lime pie are made from scratch. As an added bonus, the amber and black modernist decor doesn't look like it came off an assembly line.

If you can stand the cheesy '80s rock (Greg Kihn Band, anyone?) and crowds that love coupling those tunes with mai tais, this seafood stalwart is worth a visit for the specials alone. Weekday early-bird deals include a pile of snow crab legs for $13.95, but you can get massive Dungeness crab and shrimp or fish prepared every conceivable way for decent prices any time. Ribs, steaks and chicken are also on offer, but skip them. In fact, skip table service as well, and grab a stool at the bar to fill up on beer and oysters.
column8: Outdoor seatingGood for dining at barLate-night dining

column7: Don't be alarmed by the guys in the corner wearing jeans and T-shirts; unlike a lot of steakhouses around town, it's perfectly acceptable to dress down here. As for the rest of the typical steakhouse formula, everything is pretty much in place: Apps include all the usual suspects, including oysters Rockefeller generously topped with barely wilted spinach. Choose from several cuts of savory steaks presented on a tray before your meal, and juicy herb-crusted lamb chops fill in for those who aren't in the mood for beef. Desserts offer a breath of fresh air, though: They're sized for a normal human being, so you can actually finish them.
column8: Outdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 125, 156

column7: This semi-upscale Indian restaurant takes its name from the cylindrical clay ovens that make possible its better offerings. Out of these ovens, or "tandoors," come 10 varieties of piping-hot fresh bread, as well as meat dishes like tandoori chicken marinated in yogurt and spices, lemon-garlic lobster tail and seekh kabobs, seasoned ground lamb on a skewer. Also popular is the samosa filled with lamb, peas, ginger and fresh coriander. Stop by during the lunch buffet for a chance to try a little of everything.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 125, 156

column7: When you begin brunch by showing your ID at the door, you know you're in the right place for a Bloody Mary. Spicy and sweet, garnished with salami and completed with a beer back, it's practically a meal in itself. Don't let that distract you from the food, however. Corned-beef hash is packed with onions—add a little salt and the flavors jump off the fork. Breakfast tacos are a good way to spice up your egg intake. And the Spoke's signature "fatboy" burgers are thick, juicy and perfectly tender. Take it down with a pile of those fantastic fries and you'll be living proof that you are what you eat.

Many old-school sushi lovers—the kind who scoff at new-age maki—consider this 21-year-old Evanston spot the best sushi place around. We wouldn't go quite that far, but we do love the generous pieces of superfresh nigiri (especially the melt-in-your-mouth toro). The simple maki—yellowtail with scallions, salmon skin—are satisfying, too, but other Japanese standards are a little ho-hum. Still, prices are reasonable, service is friendly and the atmosphere is no-frills—a perfect combination for indulging sushi cravings without breaking the bank.

The pasta menu at this Andersonville staple invites you to choose a housemade pasta and pair it with a sauce of your choice. But this is risky business, because while the whole-wheat fettuccine might be a good pair with the classic (and delicious) carbonara sauce, it could just as easily be a dud (hint: it is). Diners playing it safe should order from the entrée menu, where pastas and sauces are already paired for you. There, misto di pesce (grilled seafood) manages to get the calamari, octopus and shrimp perfectly cooked; crisp polenta squares are topped with braised leeks and Gorgonzola; and tender (if fatty) osso buco comes with a delicious side of saffron cavatelli.

You most likely haven't been here because it looks like just another anonymous pizza joint in a strip mall. But venture inside and you'll find a dim, homey, five-table restaurant that is one of the tiniest—and most charming—Italian spots in town. Crispy thin-crust pizza is what the place is known for (we like the puttanesca version with the addition of briny anchovies), but pasta fans should go for the housemade agnelotti mezzaluna stuffed with spinach and ricotta. Is everything a hit? No—the bologna on our antipasto platter had to be Oscar Meyer—but we're not the type to pick on the little guys.

There's something about the arepa chorriada at this Colombian steak house: By most standards the dense, polentalike slice of "corn bread" smothered in melted cheese and onion-and-tomato criolla sauce is greasy and unattractive. But the combination is such pure, simple pleasure that before you can overthink it, you'll be scraping the plate. That's the theme here: Before you can exclaim how enormous the bandeja paisa combination is, you've already sliced into the juicy New York strip, torn off a crisp piece of fried pork and broken the fried egg and mixed the yolk with the beans. And by that time, your mouth is too full to get the words out anyway.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76, 77
column198: Other location: 4920 W Irving Park Rd (773-202-0999)

column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: If the setup of the dining room (which looks much more like a bar than a restaurant) and the hours (food is served until 1am) are any indication, this spot is for drinking your dinner. With that in mind, order the Taberna margarita (yes, it's the more expensive of the two margarita choices, but trust us, it's significantly better) as your main course and get the gringas (a cross between a taco and a quesadilla filled with mild chorizo), steak tacos and piquant shrimp ceviche on the side.

As the best barbecue joints on the South Side do, Lem's requires that you order through bulletproof glass and then take your ribs elsewhere to be devoured (it's take out only). But it would take much more than that to scare away devotees of these spareribs and rib tips, which have a thin, vinegary sauce heavy with spice and charred outer edges that hide pink, juicy pork. Honestly, the only truly scary thing here is arriving to find the line snaking out the door.

We'll admit that we were briefly fooled into thinking that this old-school lodge truly was old-school. But once we got past the log-cabinish exterior and saw Niman Ranch ribs on the menu, it became obvious it was a Lettuce Entertain You spot. Nevertheless, it seems to have gotten some parts of a Wisconsin lodge experience right (for one thing, bacon cheeseburgers are listed as "light dinners"). The signature tomato soup is creamy and sweet, and crusted whitefish is flaky and buttery. We wouldn't recommend the flatbreads, but we do suggest sticking around for dessert—the creamy ice cream and sundaes are some of the best outside of the Dairy State.

If you tried to explain to the posthipsters at this Division Street staple that the menu is more carefully thought out than it is at most bars around town, you'd be greeted with little more than a puff of cigarette smoke in your face. Luckily, the kitchen musters more enthusiasm about their hearty, tasty, no-frills comfort food. Market-priced salmon is on the menu here, but that's not the point; the point is a round of beers and a platter of cheesy, jalapeño-spiked nachos; an impressive slice of onion-studded meatloaf; salty, hand-cut fries; and a fat slab of ribs painted with a dark, full-flavored sauce.

Mama Thai offers dependable versions of classics (papaya salad, green curry) that shun less accessible flavors of funky fish sauce and fermented rice. If you're a fan of "secret Thai menus," you're setting yourself up for a letdown; if you're fine with fresh food prepared Ameri-Thai style with restrained use of authentic ingredients, you may have found yo Mama.

The combination of the words cheap and sushi usually sends us running, but the high turnover at this popular Wrigleyville spot leads us to believe that the fish must be fresh. One bite of the silky salmon confirmed that at least some of the nigiri fares perfectly well on its own. Still, this sushi shows better in maki. When it's paired with spicy mayo and cilantro in the "Mexican" roll, or with layers of tempura in the "crunch" roll, you can't tell that it's not the most high-quality sushi around. And if you can—well, then we suggest ordering the delicious beef teriyaki instead.
A historic mansion in Naperville provides an unexpected setting for tapas and paella.
column8: Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlySuburbanPrivate party room(s)

column7: Decades ago, Da Coach helped the Bears shuffle to a Super Bowl win, but currently the only bowls Iron Mike is associated with are the piping-hot "souper bowls" of corn chowder and crab bisque coming out of his restaurant's kitchen. Predictably, the memorabilia-rich decor and the menu reference Ditka's former sports glories: "Kickoffs" include fried calamari, chicken wings and crab cakes, and the half-pound Fridge Burger is appropriately, if gratuitously large. Sunday brunch, beginning with the signature bloody Mike, features items like the French Toast of Champions, slices of Texas toast coated in Wheaties and sprinkled with powdered sugar.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningFireplace
Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: Taste the city's original caramelized crust pan pizza at this quaint and cozy family-run parlor. Before opening this antique- and jazz-filled pizza joint, Burt Katz owned Inferno, Gullivers and Pequod's, concocting his signature, crunchy, nearly-burnt crust. Toppings are across-the-board fresh, with tricolor peppers, portobellos, quarter-sized Italian sausage patties and tangy sauce all adding up to one hell of a pie. Katz and his wife Sharon are a two-man team (save for a guy who helps out on the floor on Saturday nights) and will likely welcome you like family once you become a regular.
column144: Metra: Milwaukee N to Morton Grove

column7: Aromas of garlic assault you at the door of Habana Libre, and they don't stop there. Tostones (crispy plantains) and the fried yuca come with a garlic sauce so strong you'll feel it in your pores the next day. But garlic's not the only thing on offer here. Papas rellenas crack open to reveal silky potato, the fragile crust of the empanada de carne is buttery and flaky, and creamy pork croquetas outshine their fish and chicken counterparts. Go for the Cubano over the pan con lechon and get the camarones (shrimp) in the spicy "Cuban-Creole sauce." And seriously, watch out for that garlic—or else you'll have to cancel your romantic rendezvous.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: Some Evanstonians remember when this spot was a Greek joint. These days, the menu includes an assortment of juicy burgers, hefty salads, decent pastas and tasty mains, but you'll still find remnants of the old guard. Go for the starter that combines sautéed spinach with feta, tomatoes and a drizzle of olive oil, and the savory grilled Greek chicken redolent of a lazy lunch in Corfu. To keep the Northwestern-faculty regulars comfortable, the space is simple and unpretentious, with warm, stylish decor. The big-band tunes make you want to linger, and you should—desserts like chocolate-mint cheesecake from nearby JR Dessert Bakery are worth the extra time.
column8: Good for groupsVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendlySuburban

column7: After being closed for almost six months of renovations, this American cafe in Bloomingdale's had re-opened just in time for a mid-holiday-shopping nosh.

The term "shrimp lollipops" may not sound masculine, but everything else at this business-focused restaurant across from the Civic Opera House caters to the power-suit-wearing crowd. Loosen your tie (and your belt, portions are big) to fit in here while dining on standards like burgers, steaks and chops. Servers here know how to get you in-and-out quickly, which is excellent, whether you're going back to the office or to the opera.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hours) to Washington

column7: The waiters at this Greektown staple have lit so many plates of saganaki that their spirited cries of "Opa!" have dwindled to bored, tired whimpers. And who can blame them? Parthenon claims to have invented the flaming cheese, so it's supposedly been doing this shtick longer than anyone. As far as saganaki goes, it's pretty good. So is the garlicky gyro meat (another dish the restaurant claims to have invented, having the first patent on a rotating cone rotisserie). But the less-ordered suckling pig is where this kitchen really shows off its experience.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningKid-friendly

column7: At first glance, you might think this tiny storefront is nothing more than a yuppified Italian spot, but dig a little deeper and you'll find some truly tasty pastas. A dense, nicely spiced bolognese sauce is a perfect accompaniment to housemade ricotta gnocchi, but slightly more souped-up dishes like penne alla melanzane with eggplant, tomatoes and fresh mozz come together well, too. Everything from meatballs to pine nuts to shellfish are offered as add-ons for customizing. There's a small beer and wine list (the house Chianti is a value), plus daily dessert specials.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 73

column7: You get your money's worth at this Southport sports bar and grill—but considering that every dish here costs five bucks, that's not really saying much. We give the place props for their marketing skills—the menu is a great way to get people in the door and spend money on drinks. Their cooking skills, on the other hand, could use some work. No matter how simple (decently spiced tilapia tacos) or ambitious (rotisserie pork), the food tastes, well, cheap. But most of it provides a solid base for drinking, and at the end of the day it's only a few dollars...so how can we complain about that?

column8: Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace
column93: Pete Miller's Seafood and Prime Steak
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 205, Pace 208, Pace 250
column186: Pete Miller's Seafood and Prime Steak

column7: Don't come to this classic family restaurant looking for light fare; there is little to none. What you will get is Italian-American comfort food in large portions with no frill. Pastas on offer include lobster ravioli, baked lobster macaroni and cheese and rigatoni with spicy sausage. And like any true family restaurant, Phil and Lou's offers a ribeye steak (this one's 18 ounces), brown sugar–brined pork chops and meat loaf and mashed potatoes. This place reminds us so much of dining out with the fam that we can almost see dad picking up the check.

As pleasant and sunny as this dining room is, sticklers for authenticity should steer clear. The rest of us, however, may be able to appreciate the "Heavenly Tofu" (tossed with peanuts, chile peppers and soy sauce to sweet-hot results) and "Bite Size Delights" (tiny lettuce rolls with dried shrimp, ginger and coconut) for the Americanized Thai food it is. On Sunday mornings there's a brunch buffet, and if there's a better cure for hangovers than unlimited banana fritters and "Dreamy, Creamy, Crispy Crab" (a.k.a. crab rangoon), we've yet to find it.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77, 152

column8: Private party room(s)ViewsOutdoor seating
column92: Museum of Contemporary Art, 220 E Chicago Ave

column7: In true Gold Coast fashion, this sushi spot does little in moderation; the menu is a massive collection of creations like pineapple cheese wontons and bulging maki and the crowd of spaghetti-strapped young things often project even louder than the pulsating dance music. So if action is you're thing, settle in. If not, maybe take your food to go. Either way, abandon ideas of simplicity and just enjoy over-the-top signatures like crispy "RAckin' shrimp," garlic mango lobster spring rolls, and the spicy albacore "Pacific" roll finished with red-beet tempura and sauteed cashews and pine nuts. Skip super-sweet desserts in favor of more sake sangria.
column8: Good for dining at barLate-night dining
column198: Other locations: Glenview, 2601 Aviator Lane (847-510-1100); Lombard, 310 Yorktown Center (630-627-6800)

column7: The promise of a well-cooked steak au poivre and a glass of red at this friendly French spot raises our spirits after even the most soulless of shopping forays at nearby Woodfield Shopping Center. A recent visit for the three-course spring tasting menu had mixed results: The ratatouille risotto had depth from a meaty stock, but bland chicken Dijonnaise over salty spinach was a letdown. Ditto for the overly salty peppercorn sauce that obliterated the perfectly cooked beef tenderloin. Even so, we've got a soft spot for this place, so we'll still return in hopes that the kitchen eases up on the saltshaker soon.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column92: Mount Prospect Commons, 1746 W Golf Rd,

column7: This neighborhood sushi spot is often packed to the gills with chic SoPo types giving off a too-cool-for-school vibe, and there are a few head-scratchers on the maki menu (a "fire roll" made with salmon, jalapeño and melted provolone). But sometimes the chef's creativity works, like with the Mexican maki filled with yellowtail, avocado, cilantro, jalapeño and a squeeze of fresh lime juice. Non–sushi eaters have plenty of good options to choose from, including gingery beef tenderloin and crispy crêpe–wrapped duck breast.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9, X9, 77

column7: There's a lot to love about this casual Italian Boystown spot (save for the occasionally aloof, indifferent servers): It's BYOB; it's bustling without being a clubby mob scene; the design is sleek but comfortable; and the simple Italian dishes—pollo al mattone, a Tuscan herb–rubbed half chicken; trota rosso, ruby-red trout stuffed with braised fennel, olives, capers and garlic; and pesce e patate, a cornmeal-crusted skate wing flanked by garlic fries—are much-needed in this Italian-bereft 'hood.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 145, 146, 152

column7: This newish addition to Buena Park is bright, cheery and easily mistaken for just another American café. But as the name suggests, Middle Eastern specialties can be found scattered throughout the menu. Baladi salad—full of thick chunks of cucumber—is dressed with tart lemon juice and parsley; falafel sandwiches bulge with warm chickpea balls, crisp slices of red onion and creamy tahini; and the baba ghanoush garden plate is rife with smooth, smoky flavors. Yet the American palate is not left out: A freezer case is stocked with more than 20 varieties of Homer's ice cream.

It's hidden under a loud, shaky pair of El tracks on a dark, deserted corner in the West Loop, but that doesn't keep this historic room from being a destination for Northern Italian fare. Of all the appetizers, the fried, housemade gnocchi will likely tempt you the most, but we suggest skipping it and heading face-first into the entrées. Between the housemade ravioli (filled with ricotta and topped with brown butter and crunchy bits of fried sage) and the enormous portion of juicy grilled, stuffed pork chops, you won't have room for much else anyway.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 20
El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington

column7: You'll find the usual array of staples at this Greektown mainstay, from spreads like tzatziki and taramasalata to gyros platters and moussaka. There are twists here and there (you can order the requisite flaming saganaki studded with shrimp), but not much will surprise you. To us, the biggest draw is the service. From the host with a genuine smile who sat our party to the fatherly waiter who made wonderful wine suggestions and nudged us to finish the food on our plates, we felt like we were in caring hands throughout our entire meal—a refreshing change from the snippy service we've received at other restaurants on this strip.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue to UIC Halsted. Bus: 8, 20, 126

column7: Like the popular Benihana restaurant chain, Ron of Japan's chefs prepare your food in the teppanyaki-style—on a sizzling iron plate set into each table. Each grilled meal (choices include filet mignon, lobster tail, chicken breast and tofu) is served with two shrimp kogane-yaki (an appetizer topped with an egg-yolk sauce), chicken soup, a salad, veggie rice, green tea and dessert. Not only do you get a meal, but, as with all teppanyaki-style dining, you also get a table-side culinary performance from the restaurant's knife-wielding chefs.

Latin fusion is the name of the game at this upscale River North restaurant where Cuban, Puerto Rican and Peruvian influences mingle on the dance floor as well as the kitchen. The glammed-up, mojito-sipping clientele is usually loud and lively, but touches like dark woods and plush booths add notes of comfort to the airy room. If you're looking for a little more privacy, the six-seat, reservation-only chef's room gives front-row seats to chef Benjamin Soto's culinary show. Latin bands and DJs perform on weekends, and complementary salsa lessons are held Thursday through Sunday.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 125

column7: When you're feeling nostalgic for an early-20th-century roadhouse vibe, what you seek is Russell's, a west suburban favorite for almost 80 years. Line up, place your order, then head for a wooden seat with your plastic tray of corn on the cob, slaw and ribs. Since way before Flay, Russell's sauce has been on supermarket shelves; it's quite sweet, so we ask for it on the side. Barbecue purists may scoff at the baked ribs' lack of hickory flavor or their pinkish smoke ring, but this spot's a favorite with families thanks to big rooms, long communal tables, "junior" portions, and beer and wine to help the 'rents get through it all.

A dark and cozy date-friendly ambiance, seasoned servers and old-school Italian dishes (including a killer-value steak)—what's not to like about this place? Couples should snag a booth, the perfect spot for sipping a well-priced bottle of Chianti and kicking the night off with the signature cheesy garlic bread. Shrimp de jonghe is fresh (and garlicky as hell, so don't forget the mints), ricotta-filled manicotti and gnocchi in meat sauce won't disappoint, and the extrathick New York strip is seasoned only with salt and pepper before hitting the grill for a spot-on medium-rare. Drinkers should skip dessert and finish the night at the adjacent bar.
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 54A, X54, 80, X80

column7: It's not the hot spot it was when it put River North on the map in the early '80s, but this cavernous Italian mainstay still keeps the crowds coming. The flatbread pizzas are a good bet, especially the Yellow Tomato Bianca with housemade mozzarella and aged provolone. The wine list is as big as the dinner menu, with more than 30 by-the-glass options. Expect a huge family crowd on Sundays, when kids 12 and under get to don chef gear and make their own pizzas at no charge from 5–6:30pm.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for dining at barNotable wine listGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66

column7: Husband-and-wife owners Jeff Zhang and Sandy Yu (Farmerie 58, Rise) have moved their 16-year-old Chinese-restaurant-meets-sushi-bar to new digs down the block, tacking on Sunday brunch and a few new dinner specials en route.
column144: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Busy sipping on the ridiculous-but-tasty tropical-teaser cocktails and gazing at all the pretty passersby on Damen Avenue from one of the 20 sidewalk tables, it never dawned on us to try the burgers. Good thing we did, because they're the best on the block. The half-pound of Black Angus beef is cooked perfectly medium-rare and served on a buttered and grilled bun, which is key. We're torn between the blue cheese and the brie with caramelized onions, so try them both and decide for yourself.
column8: Good for dining at barCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: Slice of Life and Hy Life Bistro are a one-two kosher punch. Slice of Life is the dairy half of this restaurant building, with big booths, colorful murals and a substantial menu. The dairy kosher kitchen serves up a mock chicken cacciatore on rice or pasta that is large enough for leftovers the next day. The spinach citrus salad is a non-dairy treat, with a wine vinaigrette instead of the standard bacon dressing that ruins so many spinach salads. Hy Life Bistro is the kosher meat restaurant, with a darker, heavier vibe and a more substantial menu. Choose from beef riblets, southern fried chicken and more.

If a French chef cooked up American comfort food (think meatloaf, braised short ribs and pot pie) you'd end up with South Water Kitchen. There's nothing really spectacular about the menu, but nothing wrong with it either. Come here for a solid meal and a tasty specialty drink before heading to the theater. You won't leave hungry or disappointed, but you won't write home about it either.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs)

column7: This self-proclaimed "most fashionable Thai restaurant" actually is a pleasure to be in: Even after being open long enough to be a River North stalwart, the dining room has clean lines that still feel contemporary. You can go the Americanized route here, feasting on crab rangoon and the like. But we recommend dishes like hor mok (steamed catfish and basil with a pronounced anise flavor) and pad kra-prao (a stir fry of vegetables and meat with fiery, fried basil leaves).

column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

column7: You'd think a chain steakhouse would get lost in the shuffle, but this spot distinguishes itself with nightly live jazz and although the cigar bar is no more, smoking is welcome (if not encouraged) on the patio. There's also an extensive wine list so you can sip while you work your way through the signature 20-ounce bone-in Kansas City strip. Though the menu is standard—steaks, chops and seafood are joined by mandatory hearty starters and the usual sides— it's reliable.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night dining
Private party room(s)Outdoor seatingFireplace

column7: The Spanish tortilla? It's great, the oniony egg-and-potato wedge tender but not mushy. The pincho de pollo, juicy chunks of chicken on a skewer? Very nice, especially when slathered with cumin mayo. And the arroz con leche? It's filling, but if you can fit in the cinnamony pudding, it's a delicious way to end. Yet the real reason to visit this popular Evanston haunt is not the food, but the patio, an idyllic spot to put away some sangria, and—because it butts up against the patio of a retirement home—maybe even get some sage advice from a wise elder.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 201, 205. Metra: Union-Pacific N to Davis

column7: Full of worn brown-leather couches and dark, polished wood, this room exudes an Ivy League kind of pomp. Yet when there's a football game on, it quickly becomes about as dignified as a locker room. Artichoke dip and pizzas appease the fans, but the real finds are old-school staples like juicy, mushroom-topped London broil. Those football fans may come in handy if you order the chocolate cake for dessert—it's so ridiculously huge, you'll need at least a few of them to help you finish it.

Okay, so it's no secret that the gratis bowls of salsa you get at Mexican restaurants are partly a ploy to whet your appetite for margaritas. But the fiery pico de gallo at this Ukie Village favorite is so hot it's ridiculous. If you make the mistake of eating too much, the slushy frozen 'ritas will indeed put the fire out. But so will the avocado in the torpedo-size chorizo burrito, the thick blanket of cheese on those enchiladas and the creamy frijoles you'll eat alongside tender steak tacos. And if that doesn't work? Dance it off on the weekends, when they have live music.

Vegetarians know that just because a dish doesn't have a hunk of pork sticking out of it doesn't mean it's animal-free. This Anglo favorite caters to those phobic of fish sauce– and dried shrimp–laced Thai specialties, going so far as to omit oyster sauce when a tofu version of noodle or rice classics is ordered. "Drunk noodles" are among the best around, stir-fried in spicy soy with onions, tomatoes, straw mushrooms, bell peppers and hunks of tofu. Pescetarians should go for the gingery steamed tilapia, while meat-eaters should just take a day off; beef is standard at best and chicken dishes employ only flavorless white meat. The weekend buffet (offered Saturday for lunch, Sunday for lunch and dinner) is a steal—30 dishes for $11.75.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs); Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Luca Corazzina has taken over the reins at this Italian stalwart now that chef Dean Zanella has moved on. While the changes have been minimal on paper, a recent visit yielded an unremarkable dinner, revealing that the real draws now are the cocktails and the desserts. At the bar, cucumber purée makes a Tom Collins even more refreshing and muddled navel oranges transport a mint julep from the South to southern Italy. Meanwhile, pastry chef Kimberly Schwenke keeps season in mind by topping crumbly pistachio shortcake with ripe strawberries and a delicious ricotta-stawberry jam gelato and giving a blueberry-coconut crostata a scoop of coconut gelato.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Pink, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington/Wells. Bus: 14, 20, X20, 56, 60, 124, 157
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73.

column7: Don't go to Tokyo Marina if you're looking for fancy-pants feng shui seating arrangements or marvelous maki creations. This is a basic raw fish emporium where chefs acquit themselves yeoman-like, churning out fresh stuff for decent prices. You won't be wowed, you won't be bummed, but if you get a combo platter or chirashi, you will be quite content.

column8: Private party room(s)FireplaceCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 205, Pace 208, Pace 250
El: Brown, Purple to Sedgwick. Bus: 22, 36, 156.

column7: Theatergoers needing an Italian fix before the show have a few options on Halsted Street, but none as classically red-sauce-and-Chianti as this. Melanzane del pecaraio—roasted eggplant topped with tomato sauce, goat cheese and black olives—packs in endless sweet, salty and tangy flavors, while the conchiglie del mercante tosses the shell-shaped pasta with spicy Italian sausage. If the housemade pappardelle doused with truffle oil is on offer, get it; the housemade tiramisu you can leave alone. (Leave the happy ending for the show.)

Chef-owner Giovanni DeNigris brought his Pugliese dishes with him when he relocated his Evanston trattoria to Lincoln Square. Portions are hefty: Prosciutto with melon arrived with half a shaved pig on the plate. Pasta dishes include inspired turns like ziti with fava-bean puree and chicory tomato stew, and cavatelli crudaiola, housemade corkscrews with tomato pulp, basil, arugula and ricotta. Dishes like roasted chicken with olive oil–lemon sauce could use a dash of flash. The lunchtime café menu is loaded with Italian comfort food, including arancini and grilled sausage and peppers, while a deli area sells imported olive oils, dry pastas and cured meats.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Expect a little Gold Coast attitude served up with your sushi at this swank spot, where the neighborhood's beautiful people come to feast on just-as-pretty (and tasty) maki. Try one-of-a-kind rolls like the "White Tiger" (spicy salmon and asparagus with honey mayo, topped with white tuna) and the "Tuna 4-way" (spicy ahi tuna topped with layers of yellowfin, shiro and toro tuna and an orange-mango sauce). Carnivores can dig into juicy beef tenderloin with lobster mashed potatoes, a dish almost as rich as the restaurant's signature "Tsunami Tower" dessert—chocolate Florentine cookies layered with vanilla ice cream and berries, then topped with chocolate mousse.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingFireplace

column7: From the outside, this place looks like it was held over from the '50s—or at least an episode of The Sopranos. But get inside and you'll find a contemporary, family-friendly restaurant, the kind of place where many Northwest Siders throw wedding receptions (which is exactly what you're likely to find in the banquet room). Serving a classy version of Italian-American red-sauce fare, the kitchen puts out melanzane stuzzicante (garlicky discs of fried eggplant), petto di pollo alla senape (juicy chicken breast in a shallot-mustard sauce) and big squares of cheesy lasagna at record speed; but a nice selection of grappa is on hand should you want to linger.

No, you're not seeing things. The food coming out of the kitchen at this Devon eatery is indeed heading two ways: Tandoor-grilled meat kebabs and other Northern Indian classics beeline through a hallway to the adjacent sibling spot Viceroy, while vegetarian South Indian eats are showcased here under the newer moniker Sagar. Technically, you can order Viceroy's menu here as well, but the draw is really the impressive dosas, from the spinach-slathered, three-foot-long palak masala dosa to the lacy cream-of-wheat version dubbed "rava." With the excellent coconut chutney and vegetable-dal sambar soup alongside, it's a meal in itself.

Like Millennium Park, Water Tower and Navy Pier, this windowless red-sauce joint is more tourist attraction than restaurant. In fact, it's a downright theme park, the entire room designed to look like an Italian village, complete with businesses, a perpetually-revolving water wheel and a mischievous black cat in the corner. Like most theme parks, the focus is more on the experience than the food, a point the weakly executed minestrone and soggy pizza only reinforces. If we were you, we'd take advantage of the hearty lasagna and the extensive wine list. After a glass or two, the decor can get pretty convincing.
column8: Notable wine listVegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams. Bus: 1, 7, X28, 126, 151

column92: Arlington Town Square, 60 S Arlington Heights Rd

column7: Though their original street-level location is now a Starbucks, relegating this restaurant to the InterContinental lobby's second floor hasn't diluted any of its charm. In fact, the view from up here may be improved: From a window seat, you can watch Mag Mile shoppers do their thing while you nosh on hearty chorizo-risotto cakes, an inspired tuna poke and perfectly roasted chicken. And if you don't have a window seat? The majestic lobby—and the well-to-do tourists hanging out in it—is view enough.

This upscale Edison Park Italian spot is a big hit with the trendy neighborhood types, who pack the expansive, rustic-feeling rooms until you feel like you're part of one big, noisy party. They come for the signature tenderloin stuffed with garlic and herbed cheese and covered in wine sauce, plus well-executed pastas like penne tossed with sausage, rapini and ricotta—all giant portions served on platters. If you drive, take advantage of the complimentary valet—something tough to find in other 'hoods.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listVegetarian-friendly
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Edison Park. Bus: 68 Northwest Hwy

column7: Chef Anthony Scelzo's playful Tuscan-influenced menus are updated monthly and are marked by Scelzo's dedication to incorporating organic produce and other seasonal ingredients with fresh seafood and meat. The amber-tinted dining room, which resides inside the Wyndham Hotel, owes much of its elegance to the tables readied with bright, starched linens, caramel-colored wood chairs that match the large exposed ceiling beams overhead.

Grilled and wok-prepared Pan-Asian fare doled out in generous portions are the specialties at this stylish, if gimicky outpost of the New York-based restaurant chain. Business people on a power lunch, couples dining before heading to the Goodman and even slightly more adventurous tourists can be found gawking at the chefs behind the exhibition kitchen and squinting to read the excerpts from Marco Polo's diary that are (for better or worse) inscribed into the floor tiles.
This new Belgian-style waffles café has a carryout window for grab-and-go, with stand-up counter space and a few chairs if you choose to top your waffle off with a scoop of housemade gelato.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: A new French bistro that's open late and offers well-executed classics like escargot, steak frites and crème bržlée wouldn't get most people's couture in a clump, but for Evanston Frenchie-philes lacking in options, it's très magnifique. A short walk from Century 12 theater, it's perfect for a postmovie tarte flambe (try the heavenly duck confit, spinach and Gruyère) and a couple glasses of wine (don't miss the half carafe of surprisingly good house cab or sauvignon blanc-sémillon for $12.50). Or skip the savories altogether and dive right into profiteroles drenched in chocolate sauce.

Far more Michigan Avenue than Cermak Rd, this double-decker restaurant lures hungry bag-toting shoppers and tourists with contemporary, simplified (some would say bastardized) versions of what one would find in Chinatown in a sleek, modern setting. A nod to the low-carb craze, the lettuce wraps, available with chicken and vegetarian fillings, are a popular item. Standards like wonton soup, lo mein and mu shu pork are also on offer.

Far above the hustle and bustle of Michigan Avenue lies the serene tranquility and decadence that is Seasons. Some of the dishes here are forever on the menu (so as not to disorient the power lunchers), but chef Kevin Hickey has a creative streak driven by the restaurant's namesake. Now that things are getting cooler, he's serving a filet in oxtail-red-wine sauce, duck breast served with a side of foie gras and hoisin jus, a bento box of autumnal vegetables and, while he can still get them, plums baked into a cake and served with verbena ice cream.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listGood for groupsViewsFireplaceKid-friendly
column92: Four Seasons Hotel, 120 E Delaware Pl
Neiman Marcus Michigan Ave, 737 N Michigan Ave

column7: Now that Three-Headed Productions has successfully made Le Passage relevant again, chef Nick Lacasse intends to keep it that way. He's ushering in the warm weather with seasonal dishes like a pasta with morels, ramps and chèvre, while halibut gets smoked potato puree, creamed arugula and grilled zucchini. Mixologist Charles Joly has adjusted his "culinary cocktail" menu to be just as bright, with drinks like the Lost in Translation, a mix of Yamazaki 12-year whiskey, green-tea ginger syrup, yuzu, grapefruit and fresh basil. Drink up.
column8: Good for dining at barLate-night dining
column93: The Drawing Room at Le Passage

column7: Smak tak translates to "delicious, yes!" in Polish, and we're not about to disagree after sampling sauerkraut pierogi flecked with tiny pieces of mushroom, thin and crispy potato pancakes that rival our grandma's and stuffed cabbage rolls ladled with tangy tomato sauce. It's all served up in a tiny Jefferson Park spot with a vibe that's more ski lodge than diner—just the kind of cozy place to warm up and settle in for the night as the weather turns nippy.
column8: Private party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)Fireplace

column7: Neighborhood restaurants are tricky things, and Broadway Cellars is a good example why: The friendly, neighborly service and living-roomish ambience are precisely what every neighborhood wants, but the food only sometimes lives up to the environment. Our advice is to order the rich duck lasagna, the hearty and well-spiced coffee-rubbed pork loin and, if you can stomach the name, the Mmmmini burgers. This place might just be the neighborhood joint you've been waiting for.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating

column7: This Little Village taquería distinguishes itself by its location off the main strip, but also with its food, which is a step above the standard 26th Street fare. Camarones a la diabla, shrimp in a fiery red sauce, are flanked by a pile of buttery, corn-studded rice; caldo de res (beef soup) overflows with corn on the cob and a succulent, savory slice of beef; and tacos come with deliciously sweet grilled onions. Don't worry about getting addicted—thanks to its late-night hours (open 24 hours on the weekends), you'll never have to go without a fix.
column144: El: Pink to Western. Bus: 21, 49, X49

column7: The primary purpose of a wine bar is to drink, of course. But because drinking on an empty stomach is a one-way ticket to drunk-dialing your ex, falling asleep in the bathroom or other drunken drama, we're thankful this spot puts just as much focus on the food. The housemade empanada hides earthy mushrooms inside its flaky crust; hefty crab cakes get a golden exterior of panko crumbs; a caprese salad gets a twist by using blue cheese instead of mozz; and a pizza topped with caramelized onions and pears goes perfectly with an off-dry riesling (while also creating a base to soak it up).
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 36, 62, 65

column7: This Ohio-loving, toaster-shunning shop steams every bagel it serves, and if that sounds weird, you obviously haven't had one of its warm, soft sandwiches yet. Steaming the bagels (or, if you must, wraps and sub rolls) makes ambitious sandwiches like the "Bacon Boat to Turkey Town" (stuffed with turkey, bacon, chive cream cheese, red onion, banana peppers and spicy mustard) and "Mikey's Munch" (roast beef, pepperjack, avocado and peppercorn dressing) manageable. If it's a crisp bagel you prefer, though, you're out of luck.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: A bar with an ambitious food menu is always a risky venture. On one hand, the bar could be the next Hopleaf. On the other, the food might come straight from the microwave. But Weather Mark's food is not quite either: The signature, upscale version of pigs-in-a-blanket—a venison and boar sausage wrapped in puff pastry and served with grainy mustard—isn't bad (though sometimes it arrives overcooked), and the chili is hearty and boasts a slightly sweet, slightly spicy flavor. Entrées like the seared chicken and the tilapia fall flat, though. So stick with the apps—otherwise you'll spend your evening gawking at the diners who knew better.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 4, 12

column7: For this second location of the popular Argyle Street Vietnamese eatery of the same name, the owners have handpicked about half of the items from the original menu, only now they're serving them in a swank setting on chocolate-toned wooden tables and offering a couple dozen wines to match up with your meal. The standouts of the original location continue to impress here—crunchy shards of green papaya topped with slices of roasted pork, la lot leaves used to roll garlic-laden ground pork into sweet sausages, beef short ribs marinated in shallot and honey soy sauce and grilled, thick catfish filet baked in caramelized fish sauce.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: Sometimes we crave Chinese that isn't exactly authentic, and we don't think it's a crime. Maybe we just want the Americanized Cantonese dishes we ate when we were kids—the fried stuff, the plum sauce, the MSG. When that happens, we turn a blind eye to the drab decor at this Edgewater dive (or better yet, opt for takeout) and jump in. Skipping over the gummy chow fun and other noodle dishes, we order just-greasy-enough vegetable egg rolls, tangy ginger beef, and shrimp with pea pods, and then devour the chicken-fried rice that comes free with our order. We're shameless, and we're happy.

This restaurant is now closed.Judging by Hinsdale's gorgeous homes, it's apparent that this village's inhabitants have money to spare. If you're in the same boat, you'll love this contemporary Mexican spot. If not, it's pretty tough to get past the overpriced menu. Pork-stuffed baby plantains, crabmeat and roasted veggie tamales, and chiles rellenos in Oaxacan-style mole are all delicious starters, but each costs about $12 for two bite-size tastes. For $30 the grilled venison with a yucca blue cheese mash and Sam Adams beer mole sauce is great quality and a hefty portion, but for $18, we expected the shrimp crêpes entrée to contain more than two shrimp. Figure in $10 house margaritas and you're looking at a splurge that may keep Chicagoans within the city limits.
This coffee shop features coffee and espresso from Schiller Park roaster Fratelli, breakfast pastries from Bennison's Bakery in Evanston, desserts from J & R Bakery and housemade sandwiches.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, X80

column7: Do not ask for ketchup when you order one of the legendary slender, snappy hot dogs that come topped with a fistful of fries at this SRO institution that's been serving 'em up since 1951. The scowling, surly types behind the counter don't go for sissy stuff like that. Claim your place at the end of the perpetually long line and entertain yourself by watching potatoes being cut and fried into perfect greasy strips while you wait. Once it's your turn, order your dog with everything, then count your blessings for the wax paper–wrapped bliss that lies before you.

The beer selection alone is enough of a draw at this local brewery, where we can happily while away an afternoon nursing a crisp 312 Urban Wheat Ale or malty Smoked Porter. But pair our drinks of choice with a Paulina Market sausage sampler of locally made links or a baked Bavarian pretzel, and things look even better. If we throw caution to the wind and indulge in a Stilton burger, a black-pepper-crusted patty smothered in stinky cheese and roasted garlic cloves atop a pumpernickel roll, we know we'll be rolling home—but rolling home very happy.

At this small-plates restaurant/lounge/jazz club, food is making a play for the limelight with items from the raw bar, which features a nightly ceviche (a recent shrimp special got both heat and sweetness from a spicy cocktail sauce) and a crab cocktail studded with corn and cilantro. The hot plates are less successful—a lobster spring roll was short on lobster, and gnocchi had the consistency of clay. But head downstairs for some music, and you'll probably forget any missteps.
column8: FireplaceCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, X3, 4, X4, 12

column7: Well, "winners" might be a stretch, but we're certainly not going to call the folks who sit at the green formica counter in this windowless Holiday Inn lobby bar losers. Besides, we're right there with them, watching the television in silence and slowly sipping our beers with satisfaction, knowing that no matter what, nobody's going to find (much less bother) us here.

How does a seemingly typical Mexican restaurant survive Lakeview's changing landscape for more than 25 years? By being consistent with the simple stuff and throwing in a few specials every now and then to keep things interesting. The regular appetizer menu is Anglo-ized and boring, so ditch that and go for the flaky beef empanadas from the specials list. Stick to that list for the delicious pomegranate margarita (made with real lime, not a mix) and the chicken enchiladas in smoky red mole. If there's room, finish with the insanely rich flan.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76

column93: Sweet Dreams Organic Bakery and Café
column186: Sweet Dreams Organic Bakery and Café

column7: After going into hibernation during a renovation in the winter of 2007, this Italian-focused restaurant in Cubs territory reopened its doors with expanded version of its menu. There are three times as many panini—including the Italian, a meat-lover's dream piled high with pepperoni, salami, ham, provolone, lettuce and tomato—and several new pizzas including the spinach, bacon, mozzarella and pesto pie. Pasta additions include eggplant parmesan, shrimp primavera and blackened steak alfredo.

We (and DePaul students) come here for the Hobbit, a triple-decker BLT on sourdough with sun-dried–tomato pesto, mayo, bacon, avocado and alfalfa sprouts, but end up staying for the homemade apple dumplings and fine selection of teas. There's plenty of people-watching at this quirky Lincoln Park standby, too, though if you're feeling antisocial, order that Old Man and the Sea tuna sandwich bike-delivered—but please, no hot coffee deliveries, unless you're lucky or rich enough to live next door.
column8: Private party room(s)FireplaceVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: You won't need the photographic history on the walls to tell you that this restaurant has been around since the '70s—the decor (including the gold, sparkly and slightly ragged booths) will tip you off right away. The heavily chandeliered dining room and the crowns on the servers' heads make it clear that owner Helen Maybell Anglin takes the title "Soul Queen" seriously. Mac and cheese isn't her strong suit, but once you hit the buffet of sweet corn-bread muffins, aromatic stuffing, tender short ribs, golden fried chicken and bright-orange peach cobbler, you'll happily bow down to the throne.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating

column7: Embracing the no-frills concept like champs (save for the enormous television in the back of the room, the place is pretty bare), this corner storefront's main attraction is the promise of Middle Eastern food in a sea of Korean spots. Silky hummus and smoky baba ghanoush are strong points, though a complimentary salad dressed with olive oil and mint is a welcome surprise. Squat rounds of falafel have a crisp crust hiding a fluffy center, and even if the chefs cook the hell out of the shish kebab, it's nothing a slathering of the creamy, housemade toum (garlic spread) can't fix.

The menu at this Middle Eastern spot doesn't contain anything you haven't tried before—there's the usual assortment of falafel, hummus and kebabs. The surprise comes when you taste the bright, fresh flavors in these dishes that can be ho-hum at so many other places. The appetizer combo for two is the best place to start—the enormous platter of smoky baba ghanoush, greaseless falafel, creamy hummus and dolmas easily makes a meal. But save room for the shawarma—both the chicken and lamb/beef varieties of marinated, rotisserie-cooked meat had us plotting how quickly we could make a return visit.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76, 77, 145, 146

column7: The sassy hot dog girls behind the counter at this classic roadside shack have had enough of drunk yuppies crap. Enough so that they've developed their own brand of smack-talking that's now synonymous with a late-night dog run here. Get your Chicago red hot with the traditional fixings—mustard, onion, neon green relish, pickle spear, tomato, celery salt and sport peppers—an order of thick-cut fries and a big, fat lemonade. If meat's not your thing, don't worry—they've got veggie burgers on hand, too.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

column7: The smiling fellow in the back bobbing around to the reggae that's blasting throughout the ramshackle room? That's Daddy-O. You learn his name right away, as each regular who walks through the door hollers out nearly the same carryout order: "Half jerk, dark, Daddy." He'll scoot through the room to the window-box smoker near the front door, slide back a pane and pull out a jerk-spiced chicken, plop it on a plate, carry it to the back, and pack it up with plantains, beans and rice. Add on an order of the stellar curry goat or braised oxtails and he may just toss in a cup of the rich gumbo and a wink.

No matter the schizophrenic nature of Chicago's ever-fluctuating weather, things will always remain bright and sunny in this blue-and-yellow, breakfast-and-lunch–only spot. Enormous omelettes like the fluffy California—filled with copious amounts of avocado, tomato and green onion—are good standbys, but don't discount the quirkier fare: "Bacon waffles" add bits of bacon to waffle batter for surprisingly tasty results. For lunch, the patty melt is a greasy, cheesy, delicious mess—exactly what it should be. Unfortunately, the same can't be said about the lackluster housemade pecan and cinnamon rolls.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)BYOB
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 12

column7: This upscale comfort-food spot boasts a soothing room, a fairly priced wine list and a handful of specialties from chef Gilbert Langlois. Ever-changing entrées are a bit hit-or-miss, but the fish and beef are typically highlights of the menu. For more excitement, try Langlois's recently debuted fall dishes such as seared scallops with sugar-cured kalamata olives, vanilla-bean "mayo," pumpkin oil, sage and roasted walnuts; braised short ribs with celery-root puree, roasted chestnuts, pickled fennel and chocolate; and a jam-packed bouillabaisse of clams, mussels, oysters, salmon, crawfish, squid and scallops in a garlic-parsley broth that's sure to stop your shivers on even the chilliest fall evening.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 50, 78

column7: Victoria Medina's restaurant Caliente in Buena Park proved so popular that she's expanding her business with this second Logan Square location. The menu is similar, though larger, with brunch dishes such as egg poblano hash, lunch eats like mini Cuban sandwiches and "Argentine" burgers, and dinner options that include chipotle short ribs and cilantro buttered lobster tail.
column8: Private party room(s)BYOBOutdoor seating
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 49, X49, 74

column7: The family behind Wicker Park's ultrapopular, ultracasual Middle Eastern stalwart Sultan's Market reaches out to the late-night weekend crowd with this second location, serving food until 3am on Fridays and Saturdays. The stellar salad bar, crave-worthy falafel, soups, stuffed pies and imported packaged foods are a near carbon-copy of the original's.

The folks behind Kansaku know their sushi. And judging by the young, hip people packing the sophisticated spot on a recent Friday night, they also know Evanston was ready for another upscale sushi joint. Servers were green (one nearly dropped our plate of maki rolls onto the sushi chef), but once dishes like the seafood ceviche—plump shrimp, octopus, mussels and crab topped with a generous smear of black tobiko—made it to our table, we were enamored with the freshness and presentation. Rolls are the usual gaudy extravaganzas, but our favorite was a simple twist on a classic: salmon maki topped with toasted garlic.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: Do whatever it takes to snag one of the three tables in this tiny Guatemalan café—you don't have enough hands to take away everything you'll want to try. Croissant sandwiches are fine, but don't miss the chile relleno sandwich, a delicious spread of peppers and onions on soft, housemade bread. Tamales are served in the banana leaves they're steamed in and hold a tender chunk of bone-in pork. Desserts are a must—take sips of the especially smooth cappuccino in between bites of strawberry empanada and tall, moist chocolate layer cake

It could be the mosabaha—creamy hummus with an extra dose of tahini and dotted with whole chickpeas and sumac—or the warm, savory, fava bean–based foul that make young families, professors and undergrads willing to endure the long (but quickly moving) line for a table here. But after tasting the shish taouk, big hunks of infinitely moist chicken; the juicy, parsley-flecked kefta; and the expertly prepared cubes of filet that are as juicy as berries, we're pretty sure it's the kebabs.

As one of the few restaurants in Chicagoland specializing in the traditional Japanese omakase, Sakuma offers eight small courses to give you a chance to sample the breadth of Japanese cooking in a single meal. If your idea of perfect Japanese food involves mango salsa, cream cheese and tempura crunch, then these delicate soups, pristine sashimi and ethereal tempura will readjust your taste buds with quiet retaliation. Not to imply that the food isn't exciting—the signature first course of wasabi-spiked lobster salad, sweet soy black beans and deep-fried shrimp balls will pique your interest for what's to come.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyFireplace

column7: Even though this room is no longer operated by Henry Adaniya, and it is obviously no longer called Trio, its history of creating famous chefs—Tramonto, Gand, McClain, Achatz—has not evaporated. So any chef worth his spaetzle would feel a little honored to take over this kitchen. Hopefully that's how chef Andy Motto feels now, because he's a great chef, and though his food may not be as revolutionary as some of those other guys', it is nevertheless very, very good. From his liquid cauliflower ravioli and lamb and Wagyu plate to his smoky artichoke and quail salad, the food is nuanced, rich and executed brilliantly. In fact, we don't think Motto has anything to worry about, except maybe the desserts. Can somebody please get this guy a pastry chef?
column8: Notable wine listOutdoor seatingFireplaceSuburban

column7: On the weekends this intensely popular taquería is packed to the rafters with families enjoying steaming bowls of menudo and carne en su jugo—the house specialty. During the week it's a bit mellower and menudo isn't on offer, but you can still order the carne en su jugo. (This version of the primordial beef soup doesn't come with grilled knob onions, so don't forget to order them separately.) Not into soup? Order the carne apache, essentially carne en su jugo without the broth—steak, beans, radish, avocado and bacon served with tortillas. Folks from Jalisco say this spot is as close to home as it gets.

The Northwest Side finally got its meat hooks on some great barbecue. St. Louis spareribs are near-perfect—juicy, pull-apart tender, with subtle smokiness that doesn't overwhelm the tangy spice rub clinging to the sticky, crunchy exterior. Pillow-soft chicken's slick, seasoned skin gives way to meat that's partially pink from smoke and fully flavorful, but if you must add more oomph, go with the thinner, vinegary sauce of the two options. Don't miss the pork-and-beans (gussied up with caramelly onions, bits of brisket and brown sugar) or the creamy mac and cheese, which gets a perfectly simple crust of bread crumbs.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Awards, Readers' Choice: Best Barbecue
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80, X80. Metra: Union Pacific NW to Irving Park

column7: Culinary pedigree at this new nightspot comes à la chef Scott Donaldson, a vet of Spiaggia and May Street Market, whose menu includes lamb "lollipops" and pork-confit empanadas.
column8: Good for groupsOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: The staff is as sweet as pie, the room is airy and comfortable, and the menu is affordable at this BYOB Vietnamese spot. The only downside is that compared to the stellar spots around Argyle Street, the food here is a bit standard. Skip so-so entrées and make a meal of starters like shrimp- or tofu-packed spring rolls, sweet potato and shrimp fritters, and shredded green papaya salad studded with bits of crunchy toasted garlic and peanuts.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74

column7: If you're looking for a place near downtown where you can get a great burger and a great beer, Hop Haus is halfway there. Riding on the growing appreciation for craft beers, the owners (also the muscle behind the Leona's chain) have invested heavily in fantastic beer pairings for each of the 20 burgers on offer. The burgers themselves are somewhat mediocre (although the ground lamb patty with feta, cukes and smashed kalamatas is mighty tasty) and the dining room is a corporate-feeling. But with cocktails from stellar (though already departed) mixologist John Kinder, 25 great bottles under $35 and the best beer list in River North, we'll deal with a few missteps.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 65, 66

column7: Good ramen is hard to find, especially in the Loop. And while we're grateful for chef Takashi Yagahashi's return to Chicago (after successful runs in Detroit and Vegas), we have to try hard to shrug off the $9 price tag for a bowl of noodles in broth. The best way to avoid buyer's remorse is to go with a friend, split a bowl of the shio ramen (typical noodles boosted by a soy-miso broth, ground pork, baby bok choy, ground ginger and sesame seeds), and supplement with stellar starters like the steamed bun stuffed with glistening braised pork.
column92: Macy's on State Street, 111 N State St, seventh floor
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 3, 4, X4, 14, 20, 26, 60, 145, 147, 148, 151

column7: At this family-owned Italian grocery, there is a lunchtime ordering procedure. Choose a crusty roll from the bread bin and get in line at the deli counter. When it's your turn, hand your roll to the man behind the counter and tell him what you'd like on it. Generous quantities of prosciutto, fresh mozzarella and ridiculously good soppressata are all rock-solid choices. Many of the items are made or cured in-house, including the mozz, the soppressata and the capocollo. Before you check out, take some time to scan the aisles for imported pastas, olives, tomatoes and sweets.

This taco shanty gives a splash of psychedelic color to an otherwise sober and gray stretch of Elston Avenue.
