Heroes of the Mexican Revolution peer at you from photos as you chow on made-to-order guacamole, unique barbacoa beef tacos and breakfast (egg and chorizo) burritos. On the weekends, folks flock here for restorative bowls of menudo and pozole. For those with a taste for the odd, tacos de ojos (yes, cow eyeball tacos) will delight and horrify. The tiny dining room can't squeeze in more than nine people, but the front porch will accommodate any overflow during nicer weather.

Like Gene & Jude's, Jimmy's is a purist's hot-dog stand. No seating, no char-anything, and for crissakes, no ketchup. You'll find nothing but tasty Vienna Beef hot dogs and Polishes served on steamed buns, and rolled up into paper with a load of greasy, hand-cut fries. As a consolation for the much-maligned ketchup-lover, Jimmy's sells a decent housemade habanero hot sauce to dip your fries in, or to pour on your "supreme tamale." It's open late-night, which is the best time to catch sketchy parking-lot antics.

This member of the legion of Chicago's Neapolitan pizza joints is good enough to become your favorite new neighborhood spot. The quattro stagioni piles big cuts of high-quality prosciutto, fat artichokes, mushrooms and olives onto perfect, bubbly crust, and the verdure, with its heaps of asparagus, peppers, eggplant and zucchini, nearly takes care of your daily veggie requirements in one bite. Panini, served only at lunch, are pretty tasty, but the gelati are as smooth and creamy as any we've had in European gelaterias.
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9, X9, 77

column7: This seafood smoke shack was born when the steel industry was thriving and the area was populated by hungry day laborers. Set at the base of the famous Blues Brothers bridge, this little white box is still smoking and frying up some great seafood. Loyal customers come from all over for the smoked shrimp, but leave room for the smoked fish available by special order only. Usually, you'll see folks sitting in their cars eating fried shrimp and fish out of paper bags, a quintessential part of the experience.
column144: Bus: 26 South Shore Exp. Metra: Electric Line to 93rd/South Chicago

column7: This kosher, clubby French bistro is a hit with the locals in Skokie—the waitstaff and diners schmooze like one big happy family. You may feel a little left out of the party, but it's worth the trip for melt-in-your-mouth steaks that rival many pricier downtown steakhouses (the bordelaise, in a red-wine reduction topped with crispy onions, was our favorite). Other standouts include hearty seasonal stews and the house special Black Hat dessert, a molten Belgian chocolate cake with sorbet that somehow tastes fresh and new in the sea of chocolate lava cakes served all over town.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seatingSuburbanLate-night dining
column60: Lunch (Mon–Thu), dinner (Sun–Thu, Sat after sundown; closed Fri)
column144: El: Yellow to Skokie. Bus: 54A, 97, Pace 254, Pace 250

column7: If you've always wanted to dine at Spiaggia but just can't foot the bill, your solution is this adjacent sibling café. The ingredients come from the same kitchen, so they're just as impeccable, and the attention to regional (mostly Northern) Italian tradition is just as detailed. The room is more casual, prices are lower and service is less formal, making it a perfect lunch escape from Mag Mile shopping. House-cured sardines, lemon-dressed arugula or buffalo mozz with oven-roasted tomatoes are all great starts, but save room for incredible pastas like gnocchi pillows in perfect wild-boar ragù or strands of perciatelle tossed with guanciale, Calabrian peppers, garlic, onion and fresh basil. An Illy espresso will keep you from needing a nap.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)ViewsVegetarian-friendly

column7: You're not seeing double; there's a second Stanley's in town. This West Loop sibling offers the same affordable comfort-food menu as the original—mini corn dogs, Kentucky tomatoes, hush puppies, pot roast, meatloaf, fried chicken, sweet-potato pie—as well as the same, famed brunch buffet to soak up your hangovers with a good dose of grease and a little hair of the dog that bit you.

More Tex-Mex than traditional Mex, Pancho Pistolas traffics in locals searching for gringo favorites like fajitas and chimichangas. You'll also find decent standards like carne asada and day-starters like chilaquiles, a perfectly delicious way to recycle day-old tortillas. Most dishes would register negative points on the Scoville scale, but the crowd is festive and the staff seems friendly, so no one will mind if you ask for hot sauce and doctor dishes yourself.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)Cheap (entrees under $10)

column7: You know a 'cue joint means business when giant napkin dispensers are affixed to the walls beside the tables. Expect to get deliciously messy while chowing down on lean but tender Texas-style brisket, hickory-smoked pulled pork, and pink and juicy baby back ribs about which Bobby Flay has raved. The sauce is not housemade (it's Sweet Baby Ray's), but we're still licking our lips and dipping the crispy sweet-potato fries right in it.
column144: Bus: 68 Northwest Hwy, Pace 209Metra: Union Pacific NW to Edison Park

column7: Chef-owner Daniel Nguyen, formerly of Uptown's Pasteur, says for this spot he's "taking ideas from all over the world but using what I know about Vietnamese food." The results: specials such as Japanese-tinged lobster-avocado roll, seaweed salad with baby shrimp, and label-defying dishes like pinot noir–marinated beef shish kebabs skewered with fresh pineapple, bell peppers and cherry tomatoes.

This is the nice guy of Chicago's restaurant scene: dependable, pleasant and a little bit milquetoast. The menu of French classics is executed with results varying from solid (a beefy French onion soup) to lovely (a decadent duck confit) and all the way down to miserable (a mushy cassoulet). When it comes to dessert, go for the chocolate bread pudding—on some nights the only other option is a store-bought Bailey's cheesecake, and there's nothing nice about that.

With their upscale, three-restaurant food court in the Westin Hotel, Rick Tramonto and Gale Gand have upped the ante for dining in Wheeling. This traditional steakhouse is the most traditional (and expensive) option, offering a solid–but for the most part uninteresting–menu of all the usual steak and seafood suspects. The steaks are fine and all, but we prefer the braised-beef short ribs, with their luscious layers of buttery fat. For dessert, you'll want to go equally simple: The Brooklyn Blackout isn't very complex, but it's one of the only desserts on the menu without an off-putting gimmick.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)SuburbanGood for dining at bar

column7: This restaurant and lounge offers cocktails like the paloma and two kinds of sangria to wash down the hot and cold tapas.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76.

column7: This slick sushi den stands out amidst its budget-bin neighbors, but when stacked up against other similar spots, it's really the creative small plates that are worth a second glance. The menu is massive and overwhelming, but go right for the Dragon Fire (crispy softshell crab, eel and asparagus bound together by thin slices of raw tuna). The bacon-wrapped scallop–and–blue crab cake and the White Sox maki are almost good enough to overlook the poor service, detracting music and industrial dungeon look.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 56, 72

column7: We've seen a couple of menus floating around this aptly named eatery, but we've never spotted anyone actually ordering from one; bargain buffet is the name of the game. You don't come to be wowed by the subtleties or spiciness, but to fill up on reliable classics like tandoori chicken, samosas, peas-n-cheese, butter chicken, creamy spinach, black lentils and cardamom rice pudding. Like the flavorful mulligatawny soup, many of the buffet's pans are packed with vegetarian dishes, which—along with the price—is what draws in Belmont hipsters and hippies who are perfectly oblivious to the less-than-spotless surroundings and the somewhat surly older couple operating the joint.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: This seafood restaurant has been the flagship of the Drake Hotel's dining program since 1933. Sea-blue tablecloths, uniformed waiters and nautical paraphernalia are all proudly presented without a hint of irony, which is why it may be the only restaurant in Chicago where you can, and should, order throwback dishes like lobster Thermidor or Dover sole prepared tableside.

When it comes to truth in advertising, this 18th Street counter-service spot is 50% on target. Pollo: check. Express: well, that's debatable. However lackadaisical the service, it's serious about the first part: The roasted bird is the only main available, in half or whole size, plain or adobado (the latter, spiced version is the way to go). Legs and thighs are moist, and the drier rest is easily spruced up with fresh, warm tortillas, fluffy rice, porky beans and pickled onions.

For large groups or those seeking a late-night meal in Chinatown, this spacious place at the southern edge is open until 2am every night of the week and has a large and affordable menu brimming with authentic dishes. The adventurous eater seeking fresh seafood can handpick lobster, eel or clams from the front window tank, while the squeamish can opt for the hot-and-sour soup or one of the many casserole entrees like short ribs in house sauce. Sharing is encouraged (hence a lazy Susan at each table) so come with friends and you won't be forced to make those ever so difficult decisions.
column8: Good for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)Late-night dining

column7: Are breakfast bao—stuffed with egg, bacon and cheese or, more successfully, egg with a peppery crumbled sausage—the new Wheaties? Maybe. But if you aren't ready to give up cereal just yet, there's plenty more to try at this outpost of the LEYE chain. Potstickers are fine; better to go with the Thai curry-chicken rice bowl with its mild, yet aromatic and complex, yellow curry. Or just stick with the bao, steamed buns stuffed with fillings such as slightly spicy kung pao chicken or the sweet and rich barbecue pork. A cup of tart fro-yo is a required finish.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Jackson; Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy. Bus: 1, 7, X28, 126, 151
column198: Other locations: 1 W Wacker Dr (312-658-0305); 835 N Michigan Ave, Water Tower Place (312-642-5888)

column7: The letters in its name stand for "Abundant and Tasty," an apt description of the food at this classic neighborhood diner. Large omelets filled with fresh veggies, cheese and meat and other breakfast favorites like hash browns can be ordered all day long, while steaming bowls of chicken soup and solid sandwiches are offered in the afternoon and evening.
column144: Bus: 22, 96, 155. Metra: Union Pacific North to Rogers Park

column7: Depending on how you look at it, Daley's restaurant has been around since 1892 or 1937 (the first date reflects the original opening date of the restaurant; the second the current incarnation). Either way, it's one of the oldest restaurants in the city. But there's no time for this homey diner to dwell on the past—the space bustles with a mix of Woodlawn locals and U. of C. students, especially in the mornings, when they gather for the ethereal Belgian waffles (offered with a side of juicy chicken wings), hearty Denver omelettes and warm, buttery biscuits.
column144: El: Green to East 63rd-Cottage Grove. Bus: 4, X4, 59, 63

column7: There are no seats here—just stools. There's barely a menu, either—just a short list of things you'd expect from a place that's straightforward enough to call itself "Diner Grill." The burgers are thin little things; but stacked up two or three on a bun, they're exactly what you come to diners for: food that's hot, greasy, cheesy and cheap. Of course, you may be here for breakfast, in which case the bacon is extra-crispy and the pancakes are substantial enough to get you through the day. (But if, like most people here, you're eating them in the middle of the night, that's beside the point.)
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, X9, 80, X80

column7: No matter who you are everywhere else in the world, at Eppel's you're always somebody's baby. "Sit anywhere you like, baby," the hostess will say to you. "You like your soup, baby?" the server will ask. Whether you actually do like your soup is somewhat beside the point (not that the garden vegetable isn't perfectly nice). Because when it comes to a place with this much character, it doesn't matter if you're eating the chicken melt (a plump breast resting on a croissant and submerged in Swiss) or the golden miniature waffles—as long as you're taking in the experience, you'll leave completely satisfied.

Though you wouldn't want to make this 24-hour greasy spoon your regular breakfast spot, when the 3am post-bar hunger pangs set in, it's comforting to know this place has a seemingly endless supply of bacon and eggs, pancakes and crispy hash browns, as well as an open booth with your name on it. The interior, dominated by nicotine-stained yellows and browns, feels like a truck stop from the '70s, which, consequently, is probably the last decade the gum-smacking, biscuits and gravy plate–toting waitresses changed their hairstyles.

There is a bevy of 24-hour greasy-spoon diners in this city, but none of them offer anything as curious as Jeri's "jailhouse special," a plate of fried bologna, eggs, hash browns and toast. Kind of makes you wonder what Jeri was up to before the grill, doesn't it? Get there before 2pm for the biscuits and gravy; the rest of the cheap eats are served all day and include fries and patty melts.

For a heaping helping of Bridgeport from days gone by, this Edward Hopper–esque joint offers reliable renditions of the BLT and freshly griddled hamburgers, all served with a steaming side of sleeves-up, workingman's reality. The chili recipe is allegedly a "family secret," but we suspect that family is the Hormel clan; slightly soupy bowls of red are quirkily priced at "$2.50 or $2.70 without beans."

Packaging timeless diner fare in the kitsch of the seventies helps this candy-colored eatery draw large crowds. Rays of retro sunshine pour from the flower power interior: Bright-orange Formica tables sit on linoleum floors, and the yellow walls are dotted with memorabilia from Me Decade stars like Gumby and David Cassidy. The menu playfully follows (leisure) suit with items like "Green Eggs and Ham" (spinach pesto, scallions, smoked ham, Texas toast and hashed browns) and "Not Your Mom's Meatloaf," served with rosemary-garlic mashed potatoes.

Fancy-shmancy breakfast food—the kind with goat cheese in the omelettes and too much fruit in the pancake batter—is a bit much on mornings when we want to quietly nurse away the night before. That's when we head to this Andersonville diner, a neighborhood mainstay cluttered with Swedish folk art and plates packed with hearty, no-nonsense food. The Viking Breakfast—two eggs, three Swedish pancakes with lingonberry compote, falukorv sausage and toast—is our favorite hangover cure, but we're just as happy to order a stack of rib-sticking potato pancakes or Swedish meatballs and mashed potatoes later in the day.

Restaurants-America's catchall bar and grill tackles the business lunch scene with a menu of burgers (veggie, salmon, turkey, black angus), sandwiches (philly steak, blackened tuna, chicken-avocado) and salads (cobb, caesar). Like any happy-hour joint worth its sliders, specialty cocktails like a black cherry mojito or desert pear margarita complement a list of wines by the glass and draft beers. Stop by for starters like jalapeno hushpuppies and chicken skewers, or settle in for something more serious with entrees like New York strip and fish-and-chips.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake. Bus: 22, 134, 135, 136, 156.

column7: This former Greek bakery now makes about 1,000 deliciously crusty loaves of bread a day, providing the canvas for eight different banh mi. Pig out on the meaty grilled-pork version or the "seasoning pork," which layers glistening pork belly atop a slather of peppery housemade pâté. To make a meal, grab sides from the pastry case and fridge. (The owner is quick to warm up items and offer cups for wine if you choose to eat at one of the two tables.) Don't miss the dried shrimp sticky rice topped with Chinese sausage; steamed buns packed with black pepper–seasoned pork, hard-boiled eggs and black mushroom; tartarelike "ham snacks" with raw garlic and chilies; and cheese-filled croissants, evidence that the French occupation of Vietnam had at least one positive outcome.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 49, X49, 81

column7: With wood-fired pizza spots opening faster than a Cubs catcher can throw a punch, it seems like thin-crust pizza has replaced sushi as Chicago's trendiest cuisine. The swankiest of the bunch is Frasca, with arches reminiscent of a Tuscan wine cellar, sexy red leather banquettes and wallpaper of bare branches climbing up the curved walls. The cavernous space is packed to conversation-inhibiting capacity with twentysomethings chomping on chewy thin-crust pizzas—we like the fennel sausage, onion and mozz Capone—and tossing back reasonably priced wines. The tender, wood-fired shrimp was a simple, yet delicious app, and the carrot cake tiramisu was a dream of a finish.

True story: We visited this corner Italian stalwart and we didn't even go to Steppenwolf afterward! Turns out you don't need the theater as an excuse to visit this inviting dining room, because the ortolano pizza—piled high with spicy arugula and a sticky balsamic reduction—is an attraction in its own right. Grilled hen is flanked by rosemary-scented roasted potatoes, and the wine list is full of great by-the-glass options. In fact, you may want to rethink your pretheater dining altogether—this place may very well steal the show.

The couple behind the recently shuttered Tom Yum on Foster Avenue has taken up residence at this 24-seat BYOB. All the Thai classics and then some are on offer, plus there's a Japanese menu of sushi, teriyaki and maki. Look for a backyard patio to open soon.

Aggressively flavorful, rich mainstays like the Gage burger, dripping with melted onion marmalade and gobs of Camembert, keep this downtown gastropub buzzing. But chef Dirk Flanigan's summertime offerings are further amplified by seasonal ingredients: a peppered hanger steak is brightened up with watermelon, basil and mint, while roasted Amish chicken gets green beans tossed with arugula, citrus and goat cheese. Not hungry? Sidewalk seating across from Millennium Park is the perfect place to enjoy a sparkling cocktail like the Forbidden Fruit, made with prosecco and fresh grapefruit juice.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison

column7: Warm tortillas overflow with succulent meat, onions and cilantro at this homey corner spot. Beef tacos are the main attraction, with options of asada (charbroiled chunks), cecina (thin grilled strips), or picadillo (ground beef with peppers and onions). The housemade chorizo isn't half bad but the al pastor is not to be missed. It's more than tacos that keeps this place consistently packed, though: The weekend special of mole poblano with chicken is a steal, and if you're still recovering from the night before, a big bowl of menudo—a traditional Mexican hangover cure—should nurse you back to health.

Once you get used to the musty smell in this cute-as-a-mochi spot, you'll be able to concentrate on the mostly sushi menu. Until then, breathe through your mouth and think about peonies. Ready? Okay, start with the tuna tataki (chunks of cool tuna, avocado and red onion in a lemon-soy sauce) or the chive dumpling, perfectly pan-fried until lightly crisp and bulging with fresh chives. Avoid maki with unagi sauce: The chef has a heavy hand when it comes to ladling, and the rolls become a soggy mess. Instead, go with the Baby Bears (salmon, avocado and spicy mayo, topped with a sliver of lemon) or the Garden (asparagus, cucumber, avocado and spinach).

East Coast–style pizza in Chicago? Yep, right down to the namesake coal-fired oven. The pies these guys are turning out are immensely impressive, with slightly charred bubbles here and there and crisp edges that give way to a salty, yeasty chew. We're fans of the sweet-heat combo on the Fiorentino, a marriage of red peppers and hot salami. The housemade sauce incorporates canned tomatoes, but they're high quality and taste fresh and bright, not tinny and overly sweet. Fans of ricotta could skip red pies altogether and go with either the white pizza (ricotta dominates, but mozz, pecorino romano, oregano and fresh basil round out this light option) or the pesto (salty black olives combine with the fresh ricotta for perfect balance).
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 65
El: Brown to Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77

column7: You heard it here first: This place is poised to become the next Chipotle. Just like the slick burrito chain, the sandwich shop hails from Denver and operates on a higher plane of the quick-service industry. The main draw is not so much the sandwiches, but the list of condiments that can be piled on them: basil mayo, banana peppers and kalamata olives just for starters. The suggested combinations—a turkey sandwich with chipotle mayo, corn relish and avocado; a thin pizza with artichokes, olives, feta and oregano—lean toward bold, powerful flavors. But with a build-your-own option, the possibilities are endless.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: The Mexican makeover this place got doesn't do much to cover up its former life as a diner: The stools and booths may be vibrant thanks to a few coats of bright paint, but the old-school feel remains. Still, you'll find nary a burger or fries on this menu, which focuses on the cuisine of its namesake, a small town high in the Mexican mountains. Don't miss the Tilapia Tanzitaro—the dish, tender tilapia topped with a bright combination of jalapeños and olives, is a recipe that's been passed on through generations of the owner's family, and for good reason. You could go for the flan for dessert, but it's better to peruse the Guatemalan section of the menu and order the bean-stuffed, sugar-sprinkled plantains (rellenitos) instead.

Colombian chef-owner Gloria Santiago and her Puerto Rican husband, Jaime, have put their heart into this casual eatery, and it shows. The colorful space is modest, but the food is complex, hearty and belly-busting. The steaming bowl of herb-flecked sancocho, or hen stew, makes for a great lunch, packed with yuca, plantains and corn. For a dinner for two, go with the glistening, brown-skinned rotisserie chicken and the bandeja paisa (country plate), an assortment of tender skirt steak, fantastic housemade pork sausage links, a dense corn cake, crispy chicharron, a hunk of avocado, beans. Cut up the over-easy egg, the sausage and the avocado, add a dash of salt and pepper (Gloria has a light hand with seasonings across the board) and try to get a bit of everything in each bite.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82

column7: The owners of Wicker Park's most popular BYOB sushi spot Coast expanded their biz with this South Loop sibling. Expect the same stellar quality of sashimi and nigiri, cult-worthy signatures like the white tuna ponzu and the south scallop rolls, and a BYOB policy for at least the next eight months.

Before it was Gracie's, this Mexican spot was the go-to place for superstrong margaritas and tried-and-true combo plates. Now it's back (the family behind the restaurant owns the building), with souped-up decor (there's fancier art and darker paint on the walls) and the same frothy, potent drinks, plus a few more sophisticated menu items. Plump camarones al ajillo (shrimp in garlic butter) is a welcome change of pace. But standbys like enchiladas, flautas and carne asada are lackluster—and at prices that mirror Lincoln Park real estate, you'd do better in a lower-rent district.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 73

column7: Mexican cuisine in Humboldt Park is as commonplace as fireworks on Puerto Rican Independence Day. But beyond taquerias and take-out burrito joints, options are fairly limited, which is why this spot is so welcome. The menu is full of refreshingly different, modern Mexican dishes like plantain-filled enchiladas with mole sauce; side salads topped with guava dressing; and chile en nogada—a poblano pepper filled with ground beef, fruit and nuts. Not to mention the decor is attractive and the waitstaff is eager to please, putting this gem more on par with Fondo del Mar than Arturo's.

A better name for this place might be Alfresco, because the wine garden in back—with its walls covered with murals depicting provincial Italian life—is the restaurant's most sought-after asset. Sitting here, it's nearly impossible not to take advantage of the restaurant's white wine list (or its considerably un-Italian pitchers of sangria) while noshing on tender grilled calamari with feta and roasted red peppers, or light, crispy artichoke fritters. Heartier fare, like rigatoni tossed with spicy Italian sausage and goat cheese, is available, but go easy—overeating is perhaps the only thing that will make you want to leave.
column144: El: Blue to Grand. Bus: 8, 9, X9, 65

column7: After his father passed away, Alan Yuen renovated his family's chop suey house (even installing beautiful hardwood floors himself) and set about turning out solid Canto-American classics. Sesame beef and honey-walnut shrimp are joined by creations like stir-fried seafood in a shredded potato "bird's nest," pan-seared salmon with lemongrass curry, and boneless Peking duck with Grand Marnier sauce. Don't want to go out? Take advantage of the brisk delivery service.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 76, 82

column7: The main draw of this tiny Indian-style restaurant, which offers both Northern and Southern specialties, is the all-you-can-eat buffet, a spread that sends the scents of exotic mustard seed, cardamom, cloves and rose syrup into the street. Vegetarians are addicted to the paneer cheese in spicy-sweet curry and cinnamon-tinged chana masala (chickpeas with chilies), while meat-eaters devour mouth-watering butter chicken in tangy tomato sauce. Every spice-laden dish is procured from a Ramineni family recipe, and the diverse offerings even include some Indo-Chinese cuisine (think fried rice with Indian spices).

What you'll find at this delightful hacienda-size Mexican institution are chiles rellenos con queso, two snappy ancho chiles stuffed with queso anejo, smothered in butter, cheese and mole and plated with simmered beans and golden rice. Others opt for the sopes—griddled masa patties topped with chorizo, beans and picadillo—and one of the muy grande tequila-bombed margaritas.

On a cold evening, this eatery—with its candlelit room and wood-burning oven busy baking two dozen types of pie—is a welcome discovery. The 'za is somewhere between Chicago-style bar pizza and the relatively spare Neapolitan varieties; we're fans of the Pugliese pizza with onion and pecorino cheese. There's also strong representation from Italy's Dalmatian coast neighbors; some Bosnian specialties show up on a "secret" menu that diners can request. We were impressed with the cevapcici, sausage dressed with a creamy cheese and raw onions, cushioned in fresh-cooked pita. Our favorite of the lot is the must-have house-cured smoked beef: dense, chewy, salty and, like most great works of art, complex.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 49 (24hrs), X49, 81 (24hrs)

column7: This new Indian spot offers a dozen preps each of chicken, lamb and seafood dishes. Vegetarians get their due with a couple dozen options of their own, including a veggie-packed korma and onion-laden black lentils. Owners prefer that you don't BYOB.
column144: El: Red, Purple, Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, 147, 151, 201, 205, 206, Pace 215, Pace 290

column7: This somewhat amorphous place has a bar feel, but the food is far better than any mere watering hole could dish out. Plates of curried chicken, bacon-wrapped scallops, drunken calamari and pizzas are not only killer and generously sized but cheap to boot. Brisku's is also very active in its Irving Park neighborhood, providing an outlet for local bands (Saturday nights bring out the headbangers), supporting local softball teams, dance troupes and indie filmmakers on the hunt for reasonable catering.

We'd like to romanticize that a good Italian deli is one that's been up and running for years, where the mozz and salumi are made in-house, and the accents are as thick as the torpedo rolls. But in the newly built-up southern South Loop, exceptions are made for the only Italian deli around. None of the ingredients piled onto the Italian sub are housemade, but the imported salami, capocollo, mortadella and prosciutto are good quality and are generously layered onto fresh LaBriola bread. Fist-size meatballs are flavorful and a good add-on to a pasta, while the calzonelike pane ripiene stuffed with fennel-packed sausage and peppers is a meal in itself.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 4, 12

column7: The motto of Crust, Michael Altenberg's certified-organic pizzeria, is "Eat Real." Eat simple and good is more like it, as that's the general take on straightforward salads composed of impeccably fresh vegetables; tender pulled pork topped with crunchy slaw on soft housemade brioche and flanked by sweet beet chips; and the pizza (appearing on the menu as "flatbreads"), which has a bubbly, half-inch–thick crust that is slightly, pleasantly chewy. When it is topped with béchamel, caramelized onion, bacon and caraway seeds—like the "Flammkuchen" is—it can be very good.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: In a dilapidated, mostly deserted suburban shopping mall, Chodang Tofu Village stands out as a clean, well-lit and very chartreuse dining zone. The chef sculpts soybean curd into many shapes: cubed in bibimbap; fried chunks tossed with sweet-sauced shellfish; and thinly sliced, wrapped with equally thin sliced beef around asparagus and served with a tart vinaigrette—an unexpectedly delicious creation. All dishes benefit from garden-crisp vegetables and a light touch of cooking oil. A vegetarian could dine here as comfortably as a carnivore, though the cold waitstaff seems not to care much for either.

If your idea of Mexican food leans toward Tex-Mex classics like chile relleno, fajitas and queso fundido, you should be right at home at this new sit-down spot in Sears Tower. Most of the salsas served with the housemade chips are mild and "meh," but the smokier chipotle version packs a nice punch. Massive platters of decent marinated skirt steak and grilled chicken come with lardy refried beans and red rice, as well as the requisite shredded iceberg, sour cream and guac. For something a bit more interesting, the spinach chicken enchiladas fit the bill. But for a real thrill, sit outside, make it a margarita-lunch and enjoy the view of the adjacent parking garage and the wail of downtown traffic.
column92: 233 S Wacker Dr, second floor Sears Tower,
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy

column7: Behind Duke's nondescript façade, you'll discover what seems to be the wild fantasy of some hunting enthusiast/interior designer—as well as Chicagoland's "fanciest" Lithuanian dining. In a room of dark wood, sturdy beams, heraldry and portraits of medieval nobility, diners enjoy hearty sausages, sauces and pickles favored in Baltic states. The "fried bread hill" is a perfect drinking buddy: a bready Lincoln Log–like construction coated with garlicky cheese. For an entrée, the ground boar wrapped in bacon is a flavorful blend of both wild and domestic porkers. Visit the well-stocked deli for cheeses, meats and housemade salads to take a piece of Lithuania home with you.

Yes, it's in Under 55, a corporate cafeteria. And no, we didn't think there was any good food down there, either. But this new Middle Eastern stand makes its own perfectly spiced beef-and-lamb shawarma and then lets you top it off with your choice of impeccably fresh condiments: uncommonly smooth toum (garlic spread), cooling mint yogurt and a chunky Armenian tomato-and-onion salsa. But get it while you can: The concept of this stand changes every six weeks, so it will soon switch to Indian flavors, then Chinese. (If you get addicted to the shawarma, though, don't worry—it returns to its Middle Eastern roots every three months.)
column144: El: Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Madison

column7: This Peruvian spot is still relatively new to Lakeview, and it's trying to make a good impression: Sunlight fills the clean dining room, and (plastic) flowers greet you at every table. But even if the dining room weren't pleasant, chances are the food would still win you over. Ceviche mixto, full of toothsome shrimp, squid and octopus, sports a bright, tangy flavor; shredded chicken is flavored with a delicious mix of lime juice and cilantro; and pescado a lo macho smothers crispy fried fish in a delectable tomato sauce.

Vivo's new sister spot is very much a lounge, with ottomans, banquettes and coffee tables standing in for traditional dining-room furnishings. But even while trying to figure out the best way to dine from a square stool, we can appreciate chef Chris Laramie's assortment of hors d'oeuvres–size dishes. The mini Kobe burgers—juicy and topped with crispy pancetta, Camembert, fresh arugula and a ripe little slice of tomato—are the best of the bunch, but duck confit flatbread is a strong second. Tuna tartare isn't revolutionary, but it wins points for freshness. The DJ gets bootie-rific around 10pm, so plan accordingly whether you're looking for low-key lounging or Cosmo-induced craziness.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: When we don't have time to cook, the idea of stopping someplace where we can have healthy, inspired meals is consoling. For this, Winston's is a good choice. Sandwiches are a bright spot—turkey and fig compote with blue cheese and grilled chicken with smoked Gouda on pretzel roll stand out. A rotating selection of prepared foods like beet salad with goat cheese and a savory bread pudding with bacon and caramelized onions stand up to other gourmet markets, but pickings tend to be slim. There's also a freezer case filled with meats, soups and more semiprepared fare for when you have time to at least pretend you're cooking for yourself.

It's a no-nonsense room with no-nonsense service and a no-nonsense menu—and yet, for quick, dependable Middle Eastern grub, this tiny restaurant makes perfect sense. The lentil soup has an addictive peppery flavor, and it threatens to fill you up. But leave room for the creamy baba ghanoush and hummus, and especially for the lamb kebab wrap, a thin pita stuffed with full-flavored ground-lamb patty, parsley and tahini. (You can skip the overly thick beef shawarma wrap, though.) Picking up a piece of baklava here may seem odd, given that the Middle Eastern Bakery is right across the street, but since you're being sensible, why make an extra stop?

Sitting on this café's brick patio isn't so different from hanging out on an Italian piazza, but if you need a little more inspiration, try ordering the mini arancini—tiny, cheesy rice balls that pair exceptionally well with a glass of prosecco. Because the pastas here are all housemade, it's best to let them shine by opting for a simple sauce: Tomato and basil spaghetti pairs well with the straightforward marinara; for a spicier option, try the plump ravioli with fiery arrabiata. Portions are pretty generous, so you'll probably have some to take home; but if you clean your plate, you can grab more from the attached pasta shop.
column144: Bus: Pace 311 to Ontario. Metra: Union Pacific W to Oak Park

column7: The original owner of Logan Square's Café con Leche is behind this new outpost, where he's kept the Cuban standards, plus added dinner and a slew of American classics to the menu.
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56

column7: A general store and post office in the late 19th century, Capannari Ice Cream's building currently houses this ice creamery and parlor, which offers up more than 20 standard flavors of ice cream, with hard-to-find flavors such as Irish cream, ginger and pineapple rotating in and out of the freezers throughout the year. It also shakes things up with seasonal flavors like sweet potato pie, eggnog and blue cheese with pear compote.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific Northwest to Mount Prospect

column7: In the people-watching crotch where Wicker Park and Bucktown collide, offering margarita pitchers in a breezy, open-front restaurant nearly guarantees a packed house, regardless of what's on the plate. That's why we were surprised at the better-than-average eats served at this newish Mexican spot. 'Ritas are ripe, chips are fresh, salsa is complex and smoky, and sizzling platters of seafood are downright scarfworthy, brimming with perfectly seared, fat scallops; spice-rubbed langostinos; and tender calamari tubes. Just skip the pedestrian stuff—especially the rock-hard sope and enchilada starters—and stick with the parrilladas, or mixed grills.

These days there are three locations of this decade-old, homegrown carry-out spot, but this is the original. Once the cold days are behind us, the store transforms from Soupbox (where a dozen soups are on offer) into Icebox and starts scooping out 20 flavors of "icyfruit." Cantaloupe and honeydew are among our favorites, and we love digging into the watermelon and coming up with chunks of fruit, proof that this place favors the real deal over fruit syrups.
column198: Other locations: 50 E Chicago Ave (312-951-5900); 500 W Madison St (312-993-1019)

column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80, X80

column7: In business for almost a hundred years now, it's doubtful that any Chicagoan hasn't had this dairy farm's milk or ice cream at some point in his or her life— if not every Friday night. The ice cream, proudly touted as being 18% butterfat, is already rich and sweet enough on its own. But that doesn't stop this shop from pairing it with warm brownies and hot fudge, or with coffee to create frozen lattes.

Aromas of fresh waffles pervade the air of this Bridgeport parlor, evidence of the signature, housemade waffle cones. Dipped in chocolate and adorned with various brightly colored candies, these deep cones are indulgent carriers for one or both types of chocolate ice cream on offer here (though our preference is for the darker variety). Should the ice cream get to be too rich, you're in luck: Like all good Italians, these guys focus on espresso, the perfect antidote to your forthcoming sugar crash.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: The lines at this quaint, stand-alone ice cream parlor can sometimes get so long they snake all throughout the interior and outside the door. True to their old-fashioned ways, though, the staff here (mostly high-school kids off for the summer) remains nonplussed. If you're here more for the atmosphere (not the mild, airy ice cream) then you won't mind. But if you're here for the frozen stuff, go with the burnt caramel gelato—one of the only flavors actually worth the wait.

Smack-dab in this North Avenue strip dominated by Italian-American eateries you'll find this casual café. Pizza, panzerotti, sandwiches and salads are on offer, but we stop by for a scoop of gelato. At least two dozen flavors are on offer daily (a combo of mainstays and rotating options) and each is made in-house from a base that's imported from Italy. Flavors like hazelnut and pistachio are solid picks, but branch out and you may find that your new favorite is a unique combo like chocolate-pear.

The soft-serve here isn't your average waistband-expanding stuff. Treats prides itself on offering servings of ice cream with only one gram of fat, which is good because you're probably going to want to eat a lot of it. Along with chocolate and vanilla, four featured flavors are on offer daily (call for specials) with recent offerings including caramel fudge éclair, banana and chocolate marshmallow. The "mess" option lets you create your own creation by choosing two toppings from the selection of syrups, fruit, nuts and candies. A second location can be found at 3319 N Broadway.

You can't miss this establishment's towering sign beaming a bright, anthropomorphized hot dog down Western Avenue. Obviously, the dogs are the main event here, along with a few other greasy, grilled options. But after you've had your fill of Vienna Beef, top things off with a scoop or two of their hand-dipped ice cream, which comes in eight flavors including Superman, rainbow sherbet, and cookies and cream.

Lito Valeroso's Filipino heritage shows in the Far East flavors this creamery churns out. By the pint or simply by the cone, more than 44 flavors are on offer from traditional mint chocolate chip, French vanilla and pistachio to uncommon, Asian-influenced flavors: ube (sweet purple yam), lychee, avocado, mango and even whiskey. Each ice cream can also be blended into a shake, malt or bubble tea. A second location is in Skokie at 4558 Oakton Street.

Located in the Chinatown Square mall, the booths and tables at this Cantonese spot are usually filled with a mix of longtime Chinatown residents and chatty tourists who come for traditional dishes like fried spaghetti, curried ox tongue and a variety of congee. Among the signature dishes is the surprisingly cheap ($6.95) Ken-Kee special, which features, among other things, squid, chicken and pork skin.

There's nary a piano in sight in this suburban chain, which begs the question: What's with the name? It means "slowly slowly" in Italian, which still doesn't explain the weird collection of Elvis figurines, movie posters, Marilyn Monroe memorabilia and, no kidding, a James Brown doll. Regardless, the menu is a predictable medley of gut-busting Italian favorites—from antipasto to Vesuvio—and you won't leave hungry. Portions are huge and mostly in the "when in doubt, put more cheese on it" category of heavy, which isn't always a bad thing. The orecchiette pecorino—ear-shaped pasta loaded down with sausage, cheese and marinara—is so wrong, it's right.
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Dee Road

column7: Diners in Oak Park are getting a dose of the thin-crust pizza craze at this open, airy spot. The crust is a bit greasy (and it's the generous slather of oil that blackens the bottom), but the toppings are fresh, the dough is perfectly tasty and the combinations are tempting (especially the fennel sausage, goat cheese and roasted red pepper). Pizza aside, this spot is worth visiting even just for appetizers and affordable wine list. Try the perfectly grilled octopus and baked clams sprinkled with spicy cherry peppers, but for vino, just use your instincts and sample around the half-glass pours—the college kids waiting tables couldn't guide you with a map.
column8: Notable wine listOutdoor seatingKid-friendlySuburban
column144: El: Blue to Austin. Bus: Pace 311, Pace 315, Pace 320

column7: A Thai-sushi spot might seem like a welcome change of pace on a stretch of Italian red-sauce joints. And it is—just so long as you stick to the Thai food. The sushi we tried here was mediocre at best (and at times of questionable freshness). But the chicken satay in the sampling platter was perfectly tasty. Ditto for the curry fried rice, which arrived with plump cubes of tofu. The extensive cocktail list may tempt you to end your meal with a nightcap—a fine choice, but don't forget that Mario's Italian Ice is right next door.

Power lunch just isn't what it used to be: It's cheaper. Prices on this contemporary, eclectic cuisine in the Merch Mart have come down with the market. Make a stylish Loop lunch out of a beet and candied-pistachio salad and a corned beef sandwich with avocado, spicy mustard and salt-and-vinegar chips. Dinner is equally satisfying; the kitchen here knows its fish, and its seafood offerings are bright ones—grilled baby octopus with white beans, tangerine and olive oil and halibut with artichokes, yellow tomatoes and mixed-olive tapenade.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156

column7: East Coast–style pizza joints are more common than they used to be in these parts, but expats from the land of thin crust know to approach with caution—the majority are sad imitators of the real deal. Not this Highland Park newbie. It's like the Edens led us straight to Brooklyn, from the bubbly crusted pies made with a perfect sauce-to-cheese ratio to the slick-haired, gold chain–wearing customers folding their slices and watching the oil drip onto their paper plates. You'll find calzones and garlic knots, too, and—pinch us, it's like we're dreaming—cups of Mario's Italian Ices with wooden spoons and cakelike black-and-white cookies. The owners say a city location is in the works.

The sophisticated sibling to the well-known West Loop sandwich shop has swank digs, a well-stocked bar (including around 60 American craft beers), and an expanded menu that includes burgers, a fish-of-the-day sandwich and apps. Of the latter, the massive portion of hummus is a garlic-lovers dream, and of the burgers, surprisingly, it's the veggie version that takes best in show. Loaded with black beans, fresh corn, cauliflower, roasted red peppers and eggplant, it's a great match for a yeasty Bam Bière from Jolly Pumpkin. For dessert, take the horchata martini or fresh mai tai on the patio, and you'll have a pretty hard time recalling Jerry's humble beginnings.

Despite significant staff shifts—Kendal Duque and Peter Vestinos (chef and cocktail master, respectively) have been replaced by Andrew Zimmerman (formerly the chef de cuisine at NoMI) and Joshua Pearson—very little feels out of step at this acclaimed West Looper. Its newbie sheen worn off, Sepia has taken on the qualities of a stalwart: a classic place serving autumnal standouts like white bean soup with slow-cooked pork; pork cheek salad with pickled pumpkin; a flatiron steak with bone marrow beignets; and a butternut squash-infused Old Fashioned.
column8: Notable wine listOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 56, 125

column7: Lincoln Square residents love this tiny coffee shop for its laid-back vibe, free Wi-Fi and we're-not-Starbucks sense of camaraderie. A menu of light, Mediterranean-inspired dishes includes flaky croissants split and topped with tomatoes and melty cheese, and hummus with artichoke salad on a pita. There's a rotating roster of quiche selections, as well as tasty smoothies and Italian sodas. Intelligentsia's the caffeine of choice, while desserts come from local standouts such as Southport Grocery.

Some might think this place has been overlooked since the chef changed over, but the packed house during lunch service proves it's not the case. Chef James Okuno proves he's an expert at pho—the beefy broth is simple, with a touch of star anise and heaps of tender shredded brisket. Don't bother with pseudo-fresh and flimsy maki—stick to creative combos like miso-glazed scallops over beet risotto, a standout item amid pedestrian pot stickers, crab rangoon and seaweed salad.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy

column7: Tom McDonald of Webster's Wine Bar didn't plan for his beer-focused tavern to be such a food destination, but the eats here take center stage. The dinner menu is full of tempting plates such as mussels sautéed in Unibroue and duck breast in a port reduction over Israeli couscous. Recent additions to be on the lookout for are a cheddar-and-bacon-laden burger and a plate of German-style sausages, both perfect food for experimenting with the Belgian-heavy beer list.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barFireplaceVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: This bright and cheery all-day eatery is a much-needed addition to West Humboldt Park. Chef-owner Charles Armstead starts offering breakfast at the crack of dawn, tempting Grand Avenue commuters with his homey sausage casserole, Lavazza coffee and chill background music help ease you into the day. Lunch and dinner are a who's who of comfort food. Meat loaf is better than Mom's, but hold the American cheese. For the star of the show, get the blackened salmon, well-spiced, perfectly seared and plated with delicious garlic mashed potatoes. Follow up with the fantastic banana bread pudding with peanut butter anglaise.

Though the owner of this new tapas joint once owned tapas-fusion spot Twist, here things are strictly traditional: sprightly white anchovies on crostini, dates wrapped in (perhaps overly crunchy) bacon, spicy patatas bravas and oversized pans of well-executed seafood paella. For sweets, mini profiteroles and creme caramel satisfy. Overall, the food sticks primarily to straightforward standards, which might make it hard to praise for some but it's also equally hard to fault.

This new sister to the popular Carducci in Lincoln Park, with its hint of a Goodfellas feel, seems a tad out of place amid the other, trendier-than-thou spots on Division. But crowds are already pouring in to listen to an old-school crooner play "Volare" on an electric keyboard while they dig into red-sauce favorites. Some dishes miss, like paper-thin eggplant overloaded with goat cheese and marinara and a caprese salad made with some not-so-summery–looking tomatoes. But others are right on the mark: Linguini frutti di mar has a garlicky bite and is studded with plump shrimp, clams, mussels and calamari; meatballs and thin-crust pizza would do any nonni proud.

This restaurant's namesake, tapsilog, is like a Filipino hangover helper. Featuring dried or cured beef, a mound of rice and fried egg, it's a comforting treat sure to sop up the stomach slosh of a late-night bender. In addition to the traditional tapsilog, served on a banana leaf with a side of fried banana, the restaurant also offers additional meat options, including pork sausage, milk fish and our favorite: sweet, crispy-skinned chunks of cured pork. If you just can't decide or are new to Filipino cuisine, a weekend buffet features quite a spread, including garlicky pork in adobo studded with black peppercorns, and lumpia, crispy pork egg rolls.

It's nothing to find Dunkin' Donuts inside a subway station, but we were pretty surprised to stumble upon this soulful kiosk in the LaSalle Blue Line stop. Reggae tunes float through the air while books on spirituality, artwork and even jewelry await buyers. But the real draw is the delicious, healthful, meat-free eats. Bright tabouli is packed with plenty of nutty bulgar wheat but also gets a dose of finely diced carrots, lemon juice and parsley. Nuts, fresh fruit and Medjool date jam are layered to create "paradise pie." Potato salad goes Caribbean thanks to yellow curry powder, but it's the jambalaya pâté that stands out. The blend of pecans, sun-dried tomatoes, onions and carrots is great solo, but even better spread onto spicy blue corn tortilla chips. It's the healthiest you'll ever feel coming out of a CTA station.

Like its sister restaurant, Maiz, Tamalli is devoted to all things corn: Every dish consists of masa in one form or another. The namesake tamales are the natural go-to items here, and the tamal de elote, a sweet tamale topped with onion, tomato and crema, is as silky and tender as porridge. It's a hard act to follow, but the alambre cazuela—do-it-yourself steak tacos—measures up nicely. The mango licuado (Mexico's milky answer to the mango lassi) is a grand finale.

There's a disorienting flurry of activity going on inside this riverside joint, which has apparently tapped the Loop's feverish hunger for Middle Eastern food. First-timers shouldn't waste time trying to figure things out—just get in line and pick a bread ("hand-stretched" flatbread or wheat pita—go for the flatbread), a filling (we like the juicy fire-roasted chicken) and then sauces and toppings. The line moves quickly, and workers exhibit little patience, so you won't have much time to think. Luckily, with options such as kalamata olives, caramelized onions, a cool yogurt-cucumber sauce and roasted–red pepper aioli, it's hard to go wrong.
column144: El: Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Quincy. Bus: 14, 20, 38, 60, 124, 125, 157

column93: The Garden Restaurant at The Art Institute

column7: Despite the shop's boozy name, your blood-sugar level will be the only thing above the legal limit after a visit to this no-frills Humboldt Park bakery run by Aussie pastry chef Naomi Stepanek. She creates unforgettable delicacies from Down Under like lamingtons (small sponge-cake cubes filled with raspberry jam and covered in rich Belgian chocolate and French coconut), plus intoxicating treats such as Hungarian pancake pie and Door County cherry scones.

Da'Nali's is hidden in an unassuming Skokie strip mall, but that's only the first of its many surprises. This yummy family-friendly pizza place is the only brick-oven, kosher vegetarian restaurant around. It is also one of the only restaurants with a kosher pastry chef. Save room for the great cheesecakes. Like many kosher restaurants, post-Shabbat evening hours are hopping busy, with lots of live music.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: This kosher grill's buttery hunks of certified rib eye, prime skirt steak and aged prime rib put it in the culinary category of Gibsons for the yarmulke set. But thankfully, Taboun is decidedly casual, a welcoming place for families where vegetarians can rub elbows with carnivores over tahini-rich hummus, fiery matbucha (hot pepper and tomato salad) or coriander and cumin–rich falafel. Meat-eaters shouldn't miss the juicy chicken shawarma or the peppery mushroom–slathered beef pita. (To keep things kosher, BYO certified kosher wine or domestic beer; the latter is inherently kosher.)
column8: Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyBYOBGood for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Were it not for the name, you'd never know this place was kosher. Okay, maybe the yarmulke-clad Jew running the place will tip you off, or the fact that there's no meat on the menu. Still, the main dishes—pizza (a crisp bottom crust gives the slices a bit of crunch), lasagna (made to order and served in its own bubbling dish) and a few Middle Eastern dishes (such as the well-done, but still tasty, falafel)—don't taste like they've been made according to ancient dietary laws. Which is exactly the point.

From the looks of it—booths, a counter/bar, coffee cups upturned on saucers—this bright, homey spot could pass for an all-American diner. That is, if the Polish words on the menu and coming from the TVs don't tip you off otherwise. If not dining in, visit the deli next door and stock up on the full-flavored, crackly skinned housemade sausage. Throw in some herring (served with crisp apples in cream) and pillowy potato pierogi. Most of this stuff can be found on the "Polish plate" served in the dining room, piled together with mashed potatoes and drowned in a tomatoey sour cream sauce that's the best part of the dish.

Czerwone jabluszko means "red apple" in Polish, and this eatery on the far northwest side of Logan Square is the apple of the eye of anyone who wants to eat from the old country. (The red apple on the sign is a handy marker.) Chow down on an all-you-can-eat buffet that will fill multiple rooms (and bellies) with classics like pierogi, stuffed cabbage and carve-your-own turkey. Alternatives to the sauerkraut-style savories include crêpes and sweet pierogi.
column144: El: Blue to Belmont. Bus: 53 (24 hrs), 56, 77 (24 hrs)

column7: Those who frequented this spot when it was simply Marge's, a no-frills corner tap, may not recognize their former watering hole. Now the pub has servers in white shirts and black ties; bright, starched tablecloths; and a surprisingly solid menu. As a starter, the homemade chips were perfectly crisp and made a habit-forming vehicle for warm Gorgonzola. House-smoked barbecue ribs, covered in a tangy, housemade sauce, needed little coaxing from a fork to fall right off the bone. Despite the changes, Marge's hasn't completely lost its old-timey charm; a new dark wood bar, tile floors and stained-glass lighting just give it a little more class.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 72

column7: For deli fiends for whom the Chicago–versus–New York debate never ceases, here's hope: a Chicago deli with a New York touch. The pastrami at this tiny place (which reigned in the '70s on Morse Avenue) is top notch, and even diehard Chicagoans find it hard to resist this place's lox, herring, corned beef and gefilte fish. Like all good delis, Ashkenaz puts its efforts into its food, not its decor, so do as a New Yorker would do: Deal with it.

To get to Metro Klub, you need to walk through the Crowne Plaza Chicago Metro hotel or its Dine restaurant. But if you're looking for a kosher restaurant downtown, it's worth the slight maze, as this is one of the minuscule options for dining with the kosher crowd within the 312 area code. This Glatt kosher eatery serves up turkey clubs, skirt steak, salmon and other non-dairy lunch dishes in an atmosphere that's more upscale than most kosher restaurants.

Brooke Dailey and Gina Howie, two friends who met at the French Pastry School, opened this homey bakery in June 2007. And though we hate to state the expected, we have to admit it: This place is pretty damn lovely. From cakey, star-shaped muffins to flaky pain au chocolat, the pastries are just as sweet and delicious as they should be. And their brownies? Tinged with crème fraîche and dark chocolate, they are some of the most serious and decadent we've ever had the pleasure of savoring. The homey shop also sports a small selection of baking-inspired gifts. Cute stuff, but we'd rather receive one of their mini pies any day.

There's something of a spell that comes over those who venture into this kosher bakery. You may come in determined to buy only one thing—a fluffy loaf of challah, for example. But before you know it, the aromas of cinnamon and chocolate take over, and soon you're ordering bags of rugalach, a dozen black-and-white cookies, and whatever that was that the person in front of you in the perpetually winding line ordered. Carbs be damned, and don't say we didn't warn you.

This restaurant is closed.Chef Jeffrey Mauro isn't a stranger to contemporary American cooking: He tops his house-baked English muffins with scrambled eggs, caviar and potato-bacon foam; pairs Amish chicken breast with a lone tortellini stuffed with a creamy mixture of foie gras and shallots; tops his poached halibut with succulent shreds of pork; and infuses spicy ginger into the tapioca that arrives with the pear tart. It's solid—if slightly precious—food, creative and for the most part perfectly delightful to eat. Pity, then, that since this place has more satin and silk than an upscale 19th-century brothel, it will always be overshadowed by the decor.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningFireplace
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 11, 125, 156

column7: In his take on contemporary Korean, chef Paul Choi deconstructs traditional Korean fish stew into seared monkfish with a concentrated sauce of the stew's spicy-sour flavors and douses heirloom tomatoes with soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, and slivers of ginger, garlic and green onions. Purists will find bibimbap and chapch'ae, but made with locally grown vegetables, prime sirloin and heirloom pork.

It's a certain kind of eater who's attracted to old, colorful neon signs like the one that announces this diner—an eater who won't have any qualms with wood paneling or nonorganic eggs. In fact, people come to this place specifically to get away from that kind of eating. Digging into Standee's Denver omelette (ask for it with gooey American cheese) or the open-face hot turkey sandwich may be a cathartic experience not because it's high quality, but because when you're in the right mood, it tastes as good as anything in town.
column144: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Granville. Bus: 36

column7: In biz for more than 30 years, Torishin serves izakaya-style "drinking foods" favored by Japanese salarymen though perhaps less familiar to gaijin. Try the buta ponzu, sliced pork served on ice with vinegar sauce that offers pleasantly unfamiliar textures and temperatures. From the sea, standouts include maguro shiso age, marinated tuna wrapped in minty shiso leaf and tempura fried, and ika-maruyaki, moist and flavorful grilled squid that's sliced and topped with ginger. Torishin's old-school chefs refuse to tart up their fish with newfangled tequila sauce or foamed roe, promising instead good quality at a good price (careful, though: premium sake hits $80).
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Suburban

column7: Of this Berwyn spot's 100 rotating flavors, 16 are made fresh daily; we elected to have one scoop of each in a half-kilo container ($8.95). Though they're less dense than other gelati we've enjoyed, tastes are true and intense (deep chocolate, realistic melon and nontraditional selections like Reese's Peanut Butter Cup). Panini are clearly an afterthought, showing marginal commitment and leaving our palates flatlining. Gelato Uno—all marble and faux-crystal chandeliers—shares a common door and washroom with Di Nico's, a suitable place to establish your pizza baseline.
column144: El: Blue to Oak Park. Bus: Pace 305, Pace 311

column7: Past the pink door of this South Shore spot, Stephanie Hart turns out a number of "down-home delights" that smack of her bakery's eponymous ingredient. Peach cobbler, pineapple upside down cake, and sweet potato pie, as well as by-the-slice or whole cakes such as caramel, German chocolate and red velvet are just a sample of Hart's cavity-producing creations.

Baking in the Lakeview neighborhood since 1922, this popular German bakery reliably turns out cinnamon-raisin stollen, German chocolate and butter cookies and its signature "sip'n whisky cake," a moist bundt cake made with sour mash whiskey. The real draw, though, is the strudel, which comes in several varieties such as praline-pecan, cherry-cheese and poppy seed.

The name evokes unknown taco stands and birreria shacks, so it took a second to get acclimated to this contemporary Edgewater restaurant. But we soon settled in: Just-fried chips and freshly-made salsa are as nice a welcome as anybody can ask for. And with seven salsas available, you can spend your whole evening snacking and drinking margaritas. But then you'd miss out on the pillowy tamales stuffed with chicken and the succulent skirt steak. Never fear: This "little" café is actually a quickly growing operation (the first location is in Evanston), so you should have plenty of opportunities to come back for what you missed.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136

column7: Coffee from Intelligentsia and fresh bread, bagels, croissants and scones from Red Hen make up most of the offerings at this sleek four-month–old coffee shop. But it's the few homemade baked goods on offer (and the feel-good vibe) that make this place distinctive. Cranberry muffins are crowned with a crumbly, cookie-like top, and the cookies—a cinnamony snickerdoodle and a white-chocolate–macadamia nut—were butter-rich, crunchy outside and soft inside. But more than just a fueling station, this café is a vital community node: an outlet for the artists, musicians (performances on Fridays) and nonprofits in Rogers Park.

Roland Liccioni's departure from this tony brasserie last year was followed by a brief stint from Andy Motto before the latter, too, headed to the 'burbs. Now out-of-town transplant Christian Phernetton is in the kitchen. Through it all, the room has remained classic, just like the French menu, with its escargots, country paté, salad Lyonnaise, and herb-roasted amish chicken. Except now, these are more like classic deals: a Monday prix-fixe brings a three-course menu for $32, Tuesdays take half off the wine list, and Sundays the place goes BYOB with no corkage fee.

La Madia's menu is slightly bigger for dinner than it is for lunch. Still, we think the food is better for midday dining. What's merely fine for lunch (pizza fondue, for example) doesn't always pass muster for dinner. The pizzas can sometimes transition (a taleggio-and-grape pizza came out of the wood-burning oven with a thin, crisp crust); then again, sometimes they can't (a spinach-and-speck pie was too soft and overly bready). Luckily there's always the Wisconsin "electric" butter cookies, which are sumptuous, crumbly and delightful any time of day. In fact, take a few home and you might find they make a good breakfast.

We suppose it should have come as no surprise that Christian Delouvrier, whose résumé includes running the kitchen at Lespinasse and Alain Ducasse in New York, is kicking ass at the Chicago outpost of the Manhattan staple. But it's still a happy surprise that we can now get rich and savory duck rillettes; plump, saffron-laced mussels; an impossibly tender steak au poivre; and a perfectly sweet and sticky apple tart without setting a single foot in Paris.
column8: Notable wine listGood for groupsOutdoor seatingLate-night dining
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 8, 66

column7: North of Harlem's traditional Little Italy, the strangely named Rex is a 14-year-old institution run by the gregarious Josephine Pinello and her son Anthony, who serve artisanal Italian specialties to go or for eat-in. The native Sicilians cook up some relatively rare items, such as sfincione (simple bread with onion and olive oil), regional varieties of schiacciata (focaccia stuffed with cheese, meat and veg), and a braciole filled with sausage and hard-boiled egg. This is elegantly elemental food, seasoned with restraint and reasonably priced. Be there early to witness fresh-baked goods emerge from the back room.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Suburban

column7: Vetted chef Takashi Yagihashi has transformed the former Scylla space into a Zen den showcasing food that deftly combines his Japanese heritage with French training and American ingredients. Flavors are subtle and balanced; presentations are delicate and often beautiful. Seasonal dishes are fleeting, but mainstays include outstanding yellowtail kampachi with monkfish foie, melt-in-your-mouth pork belly steamed buns and an expertly roasted chicken with shemeji mushrooms and eggplant. Yagihashi has a fitting counterpart in pastry chef Cathy Miller (formerly at Shikago), who pairs toasted-almond financiers with goat-cheese cream and thyme-vanilla ice cream for dessert.
Opening in early October, this bakery space will be shared by three female pastry chefs who'll turn out gourmet ice cream, handmade chocolates and wedding cakes.

Let's get something out of the way first: Indian food in the Loop isn't held to the same bar as the stuff on Devon Avenue. The lack of options simply dictates that excellent is not the goal; decent is. Having said that, we hit this lunchtime spot to satiate kebab cravings, as the minced beef chapli seems to be the standout item, followed by a respectable chicken boti. Skip the overly sweet, cream-laden chicken mahkani (ditto for the bland vegetarian options), but do opt for a fresh-fruit shake to end on a high note.
column144: El: Blue to Clinton. Bus: 1, 7, X28, 38, 60, 125, 151, 157

column7: This West Town café sports a co-owner from Mitchell's and barista vets from Peet's Coffee. There's a focus on loose-leaf teas and specialty coffee drinks, plus pressed sandwiches (including the "East Village Veggie") and breakfast bagels with toppings such as crunchy PB, bananas and honey.

Listen up, Loop lunchers: You no longer need to hike to Streeterville to get your corned beef fix now that owner Larry "the Jew" Epstein has opened this second outpost for his famous "overstuffed sandwiches." This location's more spacious, too, so you'll spend your lunch-hour eating, not waiting for a table.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark.

column7: When it comes to the axiom about good ethnic restaurants being populated with people of that ethnicity, this hookah lounge/restaurant only gives it further proof. The place is packed with people puffing on flavored tobacco and playing card games well into the night; consequently, the food seems to take a backseat—mere nourishment to sustain everything else. Nevertheless, this is delicious (if simple) Middle Eastern fare. The foul and baba ghanoush are particularly rich, with deep puddles of golden olive oil dotting the surface, and the kefta kebabs are tender, rife with the robust flavors of beef. We wouldn't recommend the shawarma, but don't let that scare you. After all, it's not deterring others.

The walls are painted in bright, whimsical colors and dotted with the occasional painting. Yet, somehow, the divier parts of this tiny taqueria are what seem to stick out: the battered stools, the menu above the grill, the terse short-order cooks. Luckily, it takes only a few bites to forget about atmosphere. Order the tacos al pastor, tortillas bulging with pork carved off the spit and thrown on the griddle until dotted with crunchy bits of char, or a chorizo torta, the oily sausage mingling with avocado to rich, creamy results. After those, the look of the place will be the last thing on your mind.
column144: El : Purple (rush hrs), Red to Lawrence. Bus: 22, 36, 81

column7: Soul food can feel like a big hug from your granny, and while we're pretty positive Gram doesn't work here, the friendly staff and big portions just about do the trick. You may want to start with the silky, luxurious banana pudding, because after the smothered fried chicken and spoon-tender beef ribs, you won't have room. When it comes to Southernish sides, all the usual suspects are available, but go out on a limb and try the shredded turkey pasta salad—it's creamy, spicy and delicious.

This 6,000-square-foot restaurant inside the bustling Ogilvie Transportation Center has convenience and affordability down pat, but is a little hit or miss with quality. Sushi—both nigiri and maki rolls—leaves much to be desired, but stick with the $12 two-course Thai lunch and things will be fine. Go with the crispy calamari over miso-dressed greens for a starter and try the massaman curry or the "lemongrass dish" for your entrée (beware that the latter is a scorcher). Basic breakfast is fine and fresh, and if recent visits are any indication, the room will be empty anytime before the lunch rush.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington. Bus: 14, 20, 56, 60, 124, 125, 157

column7: First of all, there's the Bryn Mawr Combo, one of those delicious, satisfying kitchen-sink subs overstuffed with roast beef, turkey, ham and crunchy red onion. True, it's the kind of sandwich you can get at a million delis around town. So why come to this one? Because the family that runs this corner operation breaks the mold when it comes to deli demeanor. Instead of brisk and annoyed, they're exceedingly friendly. And as if that weren't enough, they make some mean Middle Eastern specialties, like hand-rolled stuffed grape leaves and a thick and bold hummus. Now show us another deli that does that.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 151

column7: This unassuming Italian spot is proof that you shouldn't judge a book by its cover—or, for that matter, a restaurant by its dining room. The generic, casual tables and chairs—usually filled with a mix of Northwestern students and young families with hungry kids—do nothing to hint at the sophisticated food that comes out of the kitchen. Creamy asparagus soup gets a crunchy disk of pancetta and a swirl of tangy balsamic; luscious lamb shank is pulled from the bone and stuffed into ravioli; and an organic chicken is cooked to juicy, crispy-skinned perfection.

This cavernous Pugliese restaurant in the meatpacking district (hence the name, which means "slaughter") owes much of its charm to the central wood-burning oven. After all, that's the key to the success with the Neapolitan-ish pizzas and the three-finger thick chops and steaks. That oven—along with a vaulted ceiling, brick walls, and an impressive, massive, wooden wine case—also adds to the warmth of the place, enough so that we just nod and play along that we can understand the specials the thick-accented Italian servers rattle off. Pick one; you'll do fine.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 20

column7: With country-style graciousness, the staff here serves up a generous menu of down-home Eastern European entrées with simple ingredients in pleasing combinations. Sour cherry soup is a sweet and satisfying starter, pairing perfectly with one of the many Hungarian wines (try the semidry Donausonne Blaufrankisch). Lamb shank "Transylvanian style" is subtly seasoned and served with nutty egg "barley" pasta while a nice cut of filet mignon gets delicious sweet pepper, peas and sliced liver. Goulashes, schnitzels and other flavorful, fresh and well-prepared foods are served at reasonable prices and with palpable bonhomie.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)BYOBVegetarian-friendlySuburban

column7: You'll feel as though you stepped into a Sicilian gelato bar at this little spot, where everything from the chocolate and nuts to the furniture and gelato machines is imported from Italy. A rotating roster of flavors is made in fresh batches daily, including rich, creamy hazelnut, pistachio and bacio (a chocolate and hazelnut blend named for Baci candies). Seasonal fruit gelati and sorbets also fill the menu, as do a couple panini (prosciutto with mozz, turkey with swiss) and expertly made Illy coffee drinks. The sidewalk patio is just the place to sit back and indulge before the weather changes.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 50, 76 Division

column7: Looking into the open kitchen from the dining room of this Moroccan/French/Italian/Middle Eastern restaurant, we figure chef Mohemed Sidi may be running a one-man operation. That could explain why only half of the ambitiously long menu is available (Sidi plans to offer the whole thing soon). From what we could order, we liked the briwates (small, cheesy spinach pies encased in a crisp, so-thin-it's-transparent shell) and the succulent lamb tagine (but, man, that thing was sweet). The hummus was overpowered by tahini, and most of the namesake kebablike brochettes were dried out (the luscious steak being the exception). But the benefit of a menu this big is that there's always something else to order.

If the name sounds familiar, you may have seen the Honky Tonk portable smoker kicking out 'cue at a neighborhood fest; owner Willie Wagner has been known to show up at the Hideout Block Party and Northalsted Market Days, among others. At his shop in Pilsen, Wagner serves "Memphis-style," dry-rubbed barbecue in a small country-casual dining room. The ribs are on the dry side and don't pack much juice, but the smoky pulled pork makes up for it, clocking in at one of the best around. Tender and juicy chicken comes in second for best bets, with puckery slaw and meaty beans solid runners-up.

Is the third time a charm? For Iggy's it just might be. Now in its third incarnation (this time with Dion Antic as merely a consultant, not an owner), the restaurant/lounge seems to have grown up a little: Their new home is a fraction of the size of their unruly North Ave space, and there's more room designated for eating than for drinking. The focus here is late-night eats, which is interpreted as filling, somewhat generic—but well executed—staples. Of course, dishes like the plump, Thai(ish) peanut shrimp and Greek-inspired "Chicken George" (served over a bed of oregano-spiked spinach and feta) are appropriate no matter how late (or early) it is. The underseasoned steak and eggs, however, will probably only satisfy you if you're drunk.

The new location of this Salvadorian eatery is enormous compared to its previous Western Avenue location. Other than that, though, things remain pretty much the same: The room is still no-frills, and the food is still an exceptional value. Pupusas—pancakelike patties made from masa and stuffed with a variety of meats, vegetables and cheeses—is the focus of the menu, and we like the simple frijol version the best (the pupusa loca, massive enough to serve three and stuffed with pork, cheese and almost every other ingredient on hand, is a close second). But to our surprise we liked other menu items even better: Soft, sweet corn tamales drizzled with crema, crispy Guatemalan tostadas with beans and salsa and a particularly sweet glass of horchata, a drink that doubles as dessert.

Who knew that a masa patty shaped like the bottom of a leather woven shoe could taste so divine? Apparently the patrons watching huaraches being made-to-order in the open kitchen of this tucked-away Mexican outpost do. In this sun-splashed, cafeteria-style dining room, regulars pounce on platters of blistered chile rellenos, giant meat-stuffed tortas and hand-slapped sopes. But everyone agrees that it's the made-to-order chicken soup, savory chicken mole and intensely sweet flan that keep them traipsing back for more.

The clocks on the wall of this pan-Asian spot display Tokyo, Hong Kong and Bangkok time, a reflection of the cuisines they serve. And though they may have the times right, the food is a little less reliable. Maki rolls are capably made, but our Ginger Chicken was disappointing, dialed-back Chinese. Thai food, on the other hand, has decent dimension: Don't expect in-your-face shrimp paste and other intensely funky Thai tastes, but do expect well-prepared fish cakes, curries and other Southeast Asian foods that balance authenticity and accessibility. Higher than expected prices are mitigated by BYOB (for last-minute booze buys, try the nearby Whole Foods).

It doesn't matter if Piatto isn't in your neighborhood—it still has the ability to charm you enough that it will feel like your secret spot. But while the dining room is warm and welcoming and the staff friendly and personal, the food can sometimes darken the experience. So stick to the salmon carpaccio and the pastas, particularly the housemade pappardelle with meaty chunks of braised rabbit and the intricately layered lasagna. Just stay away from the prawns and the desserts—otherwise you'll quickly find a different neighborhood to eat in.
column144: Bus: 54A. Metra: Milwaukee N to Edgebrook
