column7: Unaffiliated with this space's former tenant Spice International, this somewhat swank new Pan-Asian spot is worth a second look for its wallet-friendly lunches and creative small plates. Of the "Tastes from the sea" menu, the coconut shrimp, fried calamari and chile-spiked crab cakes stand out for their freshness and crispy texture. Fans of tom kha should try the mussels, which are steamed in a broth of coconut milk, galangal, basil and lime leaves—essentially the classic Thai soup. From the "land" menu, chicken curry with Malaysian-style roti is simple but satisfying, and the "Thalia land sampler" is an interesting mix of flavors, with juicy Vietnamese leaf-wrapped beef sausages and a creamy dip of ground chicken, peanuts and coconut milk.
column8: FireplaceCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: Tim Ashorian and Maria DiNunzio left IT jobs at Chase Bank to open Bellezza, a gelateria that also serves pastries and a lineup of Turkish and Italian coffees. While many places offering "house-made gelati" start with factory-made mixes, here they serve their own higher-quality versions prepared off-site. The resulting gelati and sorbetti have a fresh, clean flavor. The Turkish-coffee gelato is an eye-opener and goes well with slightly sweet "nazooks," walnut-cinnamon pastries based on Tim's Assyrian family recipe. For another jolt, try the affogato, a shot of espresso over gelato.

This tucked-away Southern Indian nugget is a dream for strapped diners, especially if they're meat lovers. With no veggie options on the dry-erase-board menu, the cabbies, locals and neighboring auto-shop clientele have no choice but to load up on piquant bowls of soft mutton in silky gravy and heaping plates of steaming lamb biryani. Be prepared to make multiple lightning-quick beelines for the water cooler if you choose the chicken paratha—its tasty but potent fire level can be a bit much for beginners. Cool off with a tasty bowl of homemade kheer (rice pudding).

Proprietor Izola White's corn muffins need no butter—they're buttery enough all on their own. Her candied sweet potatoes need no tinkering—they're already perfect, redolent with baking spices. Her fried chicken has a dark crust that cracks open to reveal juicy meat and her fried catfish arrives with a sweet-tart, pickle-studded tartar sauce—and if you have a problem with either (which you won't), Ms. White is usually right there in the restaurant, ready to fix it. Which is probably how she's been able to keep her restaurant open every day (except Wednesdays) for 52 years.

Chef Toyoji Hemmi considers himself an artist—at Ringo and Tsuki, he built a reputation for himself as an arbiter of "creative" sushi joints, and this one is no different. His simultaneously cool and spicy whitefish carpaccio and aromatic ebi shiogama yaki (shrimp baked in salt) are masterpieces. But like most artists, his stuff isn't for everybody—particularly the perplexing maki rolls, one of which includes pine nuts in a spicy tuna roll to disappointing effect.
column8: FireplaceLate-night diningOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 65, 125

column7: The long waits for food at Uptown's newest Ethiopian spot can be frustrating, especially when you see how good the dishes around you look. But keep your cool: Once you get your hands on the flaky, lentil-filled sambusas, the kik alitcha (mild yellow split peas transformed into a silky ginger-and-garlic–riddled puree) and the cool kitfo (Ethiopian steak tartare), you'll understand why everybody in the restaurant seems so unfazed.

The menu at this smart and snazzy new Edgewater spot has plenty of Italian influence, with standouts like balsamic-glazed portobello mushroom caps topped with goat cheese and grilled sausage smothered in caramelized onions and sweet peppers. Simple burgers and pizza get jazzed up with fancy toppings (like garlic aoili and grated Parmesan on the former, tiger shrimp and pesto on the latter). It's all served by an eager-to-please staff in a clean, modern setting with giant flat screens for game watching up front and a quieter dining room in the back.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingFireplace
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 151

column7: At first glance, this relatively new storefront might seem like just another Chinese takeout spot with a lo mein–lined steam table. But a closer look reveals that the Laotian owners mix in close to a dozen specialties of their homeland. The casual counter-ordering system means you can point and shoot, but trust us and get both the beef and pork sausages (the red-hued plump ones are tart from mild fermenting); the tangy, crispy rice salad (nam sod); the crimson chicken curry; and the sweetish, soy-rich stew of hard-boiled eggs, tofu and pork belly (pa lo). Bring a bottle of pinot noir to match, or try smoothies made with tropical fruits like sapote, which has a custardy sweet flavor.

Amiable owner Mr. Li used to guide diners through specials written on the wall in Chinese only, but now those have made it onto the English-language menu, adding to the many fantastic Szechuan options available for those looking to get out of a fried-rice rut. Both the fish with cabbage in chile oil and the mapo tofu pack plenty of earthy spice via a fistful of Szechuan peppercorns. To balance the heat, order the sugar-cured housemade bacon wok-tossed with snow peas, leeks and hefty slices of ginger. And if softshell or blue crabs are on offer, get them.

Be warned: They're not kidding about the "rustica" part. The space is tiny and somewhat cramped, the service is lackadaisical and sometimes entire sections of the menu are inexplicably unavailable. Yet, somehow, the pizza seems to make up for it. The rectangular slices (which arrive cut up into bite-size squares) have a buttery crust that's crisp on the bottom but otherwise soft and fluffy. Whether topped with the savory combination of rosemary and potato, or piled with artichokes and ham (as in the quattro stagioni), the pizza's certainly rustic, but in this case, we mean that in the best way.

column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

column7: When you do two things, you'd better do them well. Thankfully, Doc's does. This takeout spot (save for two small tables) specializes in smoothies and soups, and uses all-organic ingredients for both. We liked both the spinach-lentil and tomato basil soups. A combo of blueberries, raspberries, yogurt and apple juice was one of the best smoothies we've had—pure fruit, no fillers and fresh flavors. Metropolis drip coffee and vegan, organic and gluten-free baked goods from Bleeding Heart and Bot bakeries add to Doc's appeal as a morning pit stop.

If you ever stumble upon this strip mall barbecue joint, make sure you enter on an empty stomach. It's tough to exercise self-control when you whiff the southern scents wafting out of the tiny kitchen, where vats of baked beans, sweet yams and collard greens simmer away. The 'cue may not be smoky like some spots in town, but the whole chicken is juicy, and the rib tips are finger-lickin'. Grab a spot at one of the two fold-out tables to enjoy bootlegged horror movies and the like on the suspended TV, and don't forget the sweet-potato pie.

In its second location (the first was in the Gold Coast), this Chinese joint seems to have taken on the identity of the restaurants that surround it—that is, it's just as smart, stylish and sexy as every other place on Randolph Street. The menu is full of Chinese staples, like plump, aggressively seasoned salt-and-pepper prawns. Some are described with flowery language, but don't be mistaken—"Dreaming Roast Duck" is simply Peking duck with warm steamed buns. And "Crabby Cheese Crunch" is, yes, crab rangoon.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: The idea at this bustling restaurant-lounge is to present great examples of food from all over Latin America. That's a tough order to fill, and while the restaurant manages to get the margaritas exactly right, the food is hit-or-miss. Nachos topped with honey-kissed shreds of pot roast are an interesting interplay of sweet and savory, and the juicy Argentine carne asada comes with a piquant chimichurri and tempura green onions. But the bland ceviche Yucateco and California-inspired fish tacos left our taste buds wanting more, leading us to believe that perhaps Sol should narrow its focus.
column144: El: Green to Oak Park. Bus: Pace 309, 311, 313

column7: If you want a reliable, inexpensive neighborhood option for pan-Asian fare, this no-frills spot doesn't disappoint. Standard Thai noodle and rice dishes like pad woonsen and garlic chicken are fine, but you'll do better choosing from the sushi side of the menu. That's where creative maki options stand out; try the winter (white tuna, salmon, scallions, radish and black tobiko with wasabi mayo) and the Thailand (crispy shrimp, masago, cucumber and coconut). More traditional maki, hand rolls and nigiri can be had at easy-on-your-wallet prices.

The BIN 36 team opened this trattoria downstairs from its flagship last fall, and since then it has added more incentives to stop by. Lunch offers a pressed panini or wood-fired pizza for $12. (Other lunch items include the oven-roasted tuna, olive and lemon burger on ciabatta with a side of polenta frites and the grilled veggie panini). And after work it's offering $5 bar plates like bruschetta and stromboli. Finally, when the weather gets warmer, it will open the "piazza"—the perfect spot to sit with the excellent gelato.
column144: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 36

column7: It seems counter-intuitive, but trust us: You're going to want to eat a sandwich as your entrée at this tiny Cuban joint and then get a second sandwich for dessert. Start with one of the cubanos—the crusty bread grilled to a flaky crunch, the pork and ham complemented by a healthy slathering of mustard—or the ropa vieja sandwich, stuffed with so much succulent beef it's hard to keep the juices contained. But don't fill up: If you miss the pan con timba—warm bread, mild slices of Swiss and a sweet center of guava—you're missing the best part.

The folks behind this Puerto Rican/Cuban joint are no strangers to the restaurant industry: They ran a Mexican place in Florida before relocating here. Now they're focusing on the dishes with which they grew up: picadillo, spicy (but not fiery) ground beef studded with potatoes; lechon asado, roasted pork that's simultaneously luscious and crispy; and hot croquetas with a soft, rich interior of whipped potato and diced ham hidden by a crunchy crust. Not all menu items are available every night, but that shouldn't be a problem. The simple, homey food is bound to inspire return visits.

Producing many barrels of sparklers, whites and reds on-site, this winery-restaurant offers tours, reasonably priced tastings and wine-friendly food. Freshly made egg rolls go great with the house Riesling; tender, horseradish-encrusted filet mignon meshes well with mellow red "Winemaker's Barrel Reserve"; and blackened ahi tuna is balanced by the pinot noir. The menu's suggested pairings work quite well, and service, though a bit inconsistent, is generally informed and friendly.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)Suburban

column7: Don't be alarmed by the sounds and flurry of activity at this quaint butcher shop–cum–restaurant; it's just the Bosnian butchers in back of the attached market hacking up the day's meat. Better to focus on the divine sausages tucked into homemade bread; the chubby ground beef patties oozing with fresh, mild cheese; and the hearty bowls of bean soup. If you opt to eat in but still don't want to leave empty-handed, wander through the open doorway to the adjoining shop to pick up a variety of meats, Bosnian specialty foods and crusty breads on the cheap.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: Don't go expecting tablecloths and doting waiters—this Cuban lunch counter is no-frills, and that's just fine with the regulars who line up every morning for their eye-opening cafe cortado or their belly-filling toasted sandwiches.You might think the Cuban sandwich is the required order here (and you should try one at least once), but the big draw seems to be the steak sandwich, piled with thin slices of juice-dripping beef topped with griddled onions and toasted on the hot press. It's standing room only, and can get rather chaotic here, so grab some plantain chips and a soda and head for the parking lot if you want to wolf lunch in peace.

This no-frills seasonal stand has been churning out refreshing Italian lemonade since 1954, and judging by the deep lines on a summer day, Mario and Dorothy di Paolo's business isn't chilling out anytime soon. Though they serve snowballs (in flavors like vanilla and root beer) and nuts (lupini beans are popular), you're really there for the namesake goods: delicately shaved ice with pieces of lemon rinds and flecks of zest that taste like the real thing, so not too tart or overly sweet. Flavors get fancy—like chocolate or piña colada—but for our money, stick to the fruits (cantaloupe, for example, comes with melon chunks).

We could take a cue from the cops who stalk this bare-bones doughnut shop and go for a couple of the poofy glazed beauties in the case. Or we could make like the locals and snatch up chocolate-slathered cake doughnuts as if there was a blackout coming. But really, anytime we make it to this South Side institution, we're too busy honing in on the apple fritters—unparalleled rounds, as big as your head, with cinnamon-spiked peaks and valleys dotted with gooey apple hunks. If you can find one better in the city limits, we're buying.

Temporarily closed due to fire.Since 2001, the tiny storefront that started Laura Cid-Perea and Luis Perea's miniempire has been churning out wedding and specialty cakes, plus individual-sized pastries (the tres leches are wildly popular and come in as many as seven flavors). The couple also operates a pretty sit-down café in the Near West Side and another bakery in Little Village, so you're pretty much covered whenever that sugar craving hits.

This elegant Pan-Asian BYOB sports a menu that would send most cooks running; Malaysia, Singapore, Cambodia, India, China, the Philippines, Korea, Japan, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia, Nepal and Mongolia each get at least a half dozen dishes, while Thailand is represented with nearly 100 offerings. For a memorable meal, hop around the map—Cambodian lotus root and banana blossom salads pack bracing tart-spicy-sweet flavors; soft Vietnamese crêpes bulge with ground pork, shrimp and mushroom; and Bambu Bali catfish gets a subtle jerklike dusting. Skip the chewy Chinese five-spice pork leg but otherwise, we'd say you can safely order across the boardÉagain and again.

Free Wi-Fi and friendly service only add to the zen atmosphere patrons of this Japanese tea house can expect. A steaming pot of pine needle tea and a surprisingly affordable selection of sweets and sandwiches make up for somewhat uncomfortable benches and an often empty seating area.

Franconello may be inching north—this, their second location, is a considerable hike from the original in Beverly—but the menu has stayed the same. That means that anybody who has become addicted to "Mario's" meatballs (tender miniature meatballs presented in a cast iron crock of warm marinara), the housemade radiatori pasta with pesto and pine nuts or the chocolate-chip gelato will never have to go without. Unless, of course, they're too far north even for this new University Village spot, in which case they'll just have to wait—another location can't be far behind.

The Anglo-popular Thai joint that used to be on North Avenue has moved to this new location, a potsticker's throw south. The menu is the same, meaning you'll find all the pan-Asian fried apps you can handle, plus classic Thai noodle dishes, fried rice and curries.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 56, 72

column7: Resembling a fish shack that might sprout up in a small coastal village in Maine, this standing-room-only institution has had more than 50 years to perfect its extensive menu. The small but well-stocked market has all the accoutrements you need to create a full seafood buffet, including sides like "grandma's coleslaw" and creamy potato salad. The real score here is the fresh seafood and the breaded, fried-to-order shrimp sold by the pound in brown paper bags. Seasoned baked fish entrées might help balance out the addictive hush puppies that quickly disappear.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Late-night diningOutdoor seating

column7: Subterranean and obsessed with all things El related, this new, brightly painted hot-dog joint has the "underground" portion of its name down pat. The "red hot" part, however, is not as comprehensively explored. It does indeed make a very fine Chicago dog; the onions and pickle spear are fresh, cool and crunchy. But the real star on the menu is the "Blazin' Bacon 'N Bleu" burger, an amalgam of all things guilty and pleasurable: a thick half-pound patty of beef, two slices of bacon, an enormous pile of spicy fried onions and a healthy dollop of blue cheese.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark; Red to Lake. Bus: 11, 14, 20, X20, 56, 60, 124, 156, 157

column7: Some might call opening another Mexican restaurant in an area rife with established Mexican eateries a suicide mission, but the husband-and-wife team behind Sabor is confident the authentic flavors of its native Michoacán homeland will stand out. Soulful chiles rellenos are a standout dish; ditto for the tender beef that appears everywhere, from ribs in black pepper sauce to "ranch-style" beef tongue. Diners craving Americanized standbys will do fine with the burritos, tacos and quesadillas, but for our money ($2.75 to be exact), we'd rather go with the bright and fresh ceviche de camarón tostada.

The Palmer House Hilton's $150 million makeover included the addition of this restaurant, a contemporary dining room entrusted to chef Phillip Foss. This fall, Foss works with a wide array of hearty, autumnal meats, such as prosciutto-wrapped boar tenderloin and a tartlet of lamb sweetbreads. He also goes crazy with foie gras, pairing it with figs in one dish, apples in another and quail in a third. To check out the hotel's new look without dropping the dough for dinner, stop in for a cocktail in the lobby bar and nosh on small bites like the charcuterie plate or Kobe sliders.

For a small place, this Cuban restaurant has a big menu. If it's overwhelming, just ask the server what's looking good that day. You might get steered toward oxtails, which are meaty and flavorful, doused with a rich, stock-based sauce perfect for sopping up with crusty Cuban bread slathered in oregano-butter. Couple this dish with the boiled yuca—fibrous, dense and delicious tubers splashed with garlic—and start with ham croquettes, which are crunchy on the outside, lush and creamy within, and offset by a slightly spiced tomato sauce. A hefty South American red from the wine list should carry you through the whole meal.

The name of this new storefront in the old Palmito space is an acronym for pie, as in the pizza variety. Said specialty isn't bad—the thin crust is a tad thick and individual slices are overloaded with cheese—especially if you stick to the "creations" part of the menu with the Margherita and the Neapolitan ('rita plus anchovies). Salads have a just-picked-from-the-garden freshness, and big shavings of fresh Parm on the Caesar are a bonus. Pastas are no-frills red-sauce fare; the spaghetti laden with thick meat sauce could pass for homemade via a loving nonna's kitchen.

You could graze all day at this bustling vegetarian Indian restaurant, but first you'd have to figure out the menu. If you're not completely familiar with chaat (snacks), traditional Indian breakfast dishes and vegetable curries, ask for the TOC translated menu, where you'll find descriptions of the overwhelming options. Potatoes cooked with mustard seed and cumin are a perfect filling for the crispy, two-foot long paper dosa; order it "masala" and you'll also get a smear of tangy chutney. For a carnival of flavors, try the Swati samosa chaat, a smashed potato pocket drenched in silky yogurt, tamarind chutney and subtly spicy "salsa," with torn cilantro for pungent punch. Not sure? Order anything and you're bound to get fresh, flavorful, meat-free eats for a good price.

Two Greek Nicks (Prutsos the owner, Katsoulos the chef) are behind this casual Greek-American grill, where the menu is long on char classics like burgers, skirt steak sandwiches, Italian beef-sausage combos and souvlaki (pork tenderloin) skewers. Dishes like oven-roasted potatoes and chicken kebabs get the Greek rubdown of olive oil, lemon juice, oregano and garlic.

Open daily from 5pm to 3am, this place caters to a specific crowd: cab drivers, night shifters and anyone else who gets cravings for Pakistani food in the middle of the night. Of course, you could also just go for dinner, when the handi gosht, a mild and tender goat stew, and the jalapeño-spiked dal will suffice. But if it's a midnight snack you're after, the charga—juicy and heavily spiced fried chicken—is the only way to go.

We're not advocating taking Roger Ebert's advice on pizza (despite his former size), but we will give some credence to his claim that there's a good thin-crust pie to be found here. Pastas, salads and a handful of cheesy, sauced chicken entrées round out the options, but we suggest sticking with the pizza, especially if you're a fan of crispy paper-thin crust and square-cut slices. Order a vegetarian version and one topped with crumbled Italian sausage, plus plenty of beers to wash it down, and you're in for a wallet-friendly night in a good old-fashioned family-friendly joint.

column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 73
El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison; Blue, Red to Monroe.
El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80

column7: The thin- and thick-crust pizzas won't disappoint at this tidy and tiny spot tucked away in a strip mall, but there's plenty more on the menu to keep you coming back. We'd eat the fresh, slightly chunky housemade marinara sauce here on just about anything, but it's particularly good in lasagna and perks up plain old spaghetti perfectly. Doughy panzerotti oozes with creamy mozzarella, and gives you one more opportunity to dunk into that yummy marinara. Service is warm and friendly, but tables are sparse—the majority of business here is takeout.

Don't be turned off by the Depression-era Tokyo Hotel that houses Ginza Japanese Restaurant, and don't bother with inconsistent sushi. Instead, focus on kitchen dishes not found at trendier raw-fish venues. Sample, for instance, natto, fermented soybean packing a bittersweet punch, or yamakake, a bowl of liquefied mountain yam with raw tuna (good with natto). Plump, juicy oysters dusted with panko and deep-fried are excellent; grilled yellowfin neck is tender with fatty meat; and servers could not be sweeter.

If you build it, they will come. That's what the team behind this new Asian spot in restaurant-starved Hyde Park must be thinking. In October, after years of operating as Noodles Etc, the restaurant relaunched in a new space with a bigger menu, hipper interior and a full-service bar. The most popular dishes from the old menu—drunken noodles with basil, for example—are still available. But some creative newbies are winners, like the beef Massaman curry, a tender steak filet topped with a creamy, peanut-curry sauce and potatoes; and the delicate, crispy mussel bites (which are pan-fried then placed back in the shell).
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningOutdoor seating
column144: Bus: 6, 28, 55, X55, 171. Metra: Electric Main to 55th-56th-57th

column7: This long, narrow restaurant may be full of smoke at times—it doubles as a hookah lounge, but likely won't remain one after the Jan 1 smoking ban)—but when we visited, the air was perfectly clear. That's because people seem to be more interested in the Middle Eastern eats than anything else. With aromatic kibbeh as big as your fist, warm pita provided to scoop up the rich, olive oil–laden baba ghanoush, and an enormous chicken shawarma plate (which is more like a shawarma sandwich), we can't say we blame them. However, if you find yourself gravitating toward the dolma or the grilled shrimp kebab, resist—and pick up a pipe instead.

Of the signs that litter the walls of this take-out Soul Food shop, the most important is not the one telling you not to loiter or eat in the waiting area; it's the sign boasting 11 years in business. For a corner with not much else going for it, that's a big achievement. Of course, the reason this place has survived is no secret: From the split and buttered biscuits to the slightly sweet yellow turnips to the custardy buttermilk pie, this is simple, down-home food that nobody can argue with. Much less stop eating.

The folks behind French bistro La Petite Amelia and †ber Burger have opened this adjacent trattoria that features a brick pizza oven, an antipasti bar and a deli area for grabbing salumi-stacked sandwiches to go.

Offtrack betting has never looked so good: This new bar/restaurant/OTB spot boasts 217 television monitors, a large marble bar and food from chef Gabriel Ortega, a veteran of the Ritz-Carlton. Look for classic American fare such as sliders (made with Kobe beef, no less) and barbecue ribs to sustain your wagers of sin.

Bucktown's newest bar—located at the former Darwin's address—is, perhaps, the 'hood's most fun, too. The few well-chosen micro-brews on tap fuel intense nightly Guitar Hero battles and inspires the graffiti that covers the chalkboard walls. Sunday through Wednesday, movies like Orgazmo and Boogie Nights screen and the bar offers dinner specials like tacos and corn dogs alongside its usual burger-and-fries fare.

The reddish glow that fills this space is probably a nod to its name, which translates, roughly, to "devil's oven." But it still can't hide the fact that this place looks and feels like a bar. Luckily, the menu goes beyond bar food. The "3-way" bruschetta supplements the normal tomato variety with creative chickpea and apple-raspberry varieties, and the "pork chop Italiano" is as tender and juicy as any other in the city. The pride and joy of the restaurant, a wood-burning oven, puts out crisp, cracker-crust pizzas that are cut into squares in traditional Chicago bar-pizza fashion. But it goes one step above, offering decidedly untraditional pies such as the one topped with butternut squash.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seating

column7: It looks like just another late-night taco joint—and if that's what you're looking for, that's exactly what it will be. But the more adventurous might choose to explore the specials board (yes, there's a specials board). There, you'll find dishes that you'd expect at higher-end Mexican spots (like a platter of oysters) and, in some cases, dishes that you may never expect anywhere ("tacos de cabeza," filled with cow brains). At the end of the day, the food isn't going to blow your mind (though the barbacoa taco is unusually juicy and delicious); but the cantarito, an infinitely refreshing tequila-and-grapefruit cocktail, just might.

Irie is not the word we'd use to describe Lincoln Park. Until now. Because even though it's nestled among Armitage Avenue's baby boutiques and chocolate shops, this Jamaican joint provides a somewhat authentic experience. The meaty catfish is heightened with the warm spiciness of the jerk rub (the juicy jerk chicken flavors are even more pronounced, the result of a two-day marinade). Meat pies are small but pack a spicy punch, and oxtail is luscious, with meat that's full-flavored (even though the sauce isn't). Reggae pulses throughout the dining room, encouraging you to stay and have another drink. If you do, order a slice of the delicious lemon cake to have with your rum punch.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

column7: Yes, it's one of the best restaurant names in Chicago, but pay it no mind—or, rather, don't pay attention to the first half, which refers to the expendable portion of the menu devoted to American food (burgers, chili dogs, mac and cheese). What you want is the lahim beajin, a thin, crisp pita topped with fiery ground beef; the burek, an eggroll-like shell stuffed with a savory blend of meat, herbs and spices; and the simple but delicious lentil soup. Still want some big buns? Continue your Middle Eastern binge with some shawarma and falafel, and you'll be well on your way.

Naperville is getting some buzz with this new contemporary tapas spot. Chef John Borras did some training at Spain's legendary El Bulli, and chef de cuisine Jose Marcial is an O.G. on the local tapas scene. Together, the two are mostly successful. Mango "caviar" and skinless ravioli filled with chocolate or squid ink are both interesting and delicious, but chocolate-covered shrimp and a marshmallow–Manchego cheese napoleon have more "hmm" than "mmm" going for them. Still, with predictable tapas for the old-schoolers and creative stuff for daring diners, this is a welcome addition to the suburban dining scene.

The kitchen here isn't trying to reinvent the wheel with this menu, which offers familiar staples of contemporary American cuisine. This suits us just fine, so long as we get our hands on the juicy and flavorful slow-roasted chicken thigh; the pork chop with a side of toothsome mustard spaetzle; and the lunchtime pulled-pork sandwich, cut by tart housemade slaw. There are missteps—an overly buttery arctic char; slow, aloof service—but for the most part this restaurant provides dependable fare.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 38, 56, 125

column7: North Siders looking for a fried-shrimp fix should head here, where jumbo, Gulf-caught beauties are breaded in a secret blend of seasonings and bread crumbs that let their fresh flavor shine through. Other by-the-pound fried delights include scallops, catfish and clam strips,Êas well as an assortment of artery-clogging-but-tasty sides like fluffy hush puppies, onion rings and potato pancakes. There is a handful of counter seats, but take your grease-streaked brown bags to go, so we don't have to watch you lick your fingers.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 11, 80

column7: The owner of Jet's Public House is behind this spot with a party-hearty attitude and a menu of Anglo-Mex eats—like tortilla pizza, "Mexi-skins" (chorizo potato skins) and "Soon to Be Famous" fish tacos.

Big tables of barely-of-age BYOB enthusiasts and nervous-looking couples on budget first dates crowd into this tiny basement-level sushi spot. They're not clamoring for hours-fresh fatty tuna or trendy flaming maki; they're there for all-you-can-eat sushi for $16.99 a person. Salmon, yellowtail and tuna nigiri are fine (read: inoffensive and safe to eat), but if your sushi standards are anywhere near snobby, go with maki and drink plenty of whatever wine you brought. The avocado and tempura–packed Palatine and Volcano rolls are good bets, but be sure to finish what you order. These sushi Nazis charge extra for anything left on your plate, and that includes nigiri rice.

Stepping into this new café is like visiting grandma's house, minus all the cheek-pinching. Thrift-store couches and coffee tables strewn with out-of-date magazines and board games form comfy hang zones tailor-made for laptop time and espresso sipping. There's a daily coffee blend (all the beans are organic and free-trade), but this place isn't just for java junkies. A local Guatemalan bakery delivers Latin American pastries daily, and the mostly organic menu board sports a number of standout sandwiches, including the apple butter–ham (order it on hearty multigrain bread) and the banana–nut butter, which comes with a bowl of housemade vanilla-banana pudding that puts granny's boxed stuff to shame.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 74, 82

column7: From shuttered churrascaria Sal y Carvao rises Zed 451. The gauchos are gone, though Brazilian-style meat skewers remain, supplemented by a well-stocked buffet of soups and seasonal veggies, rendering this restaurant ironically vegetarian friendly. We found white meats somewhat mushy, though red meats were excellent, particularly beef bottom round and lamb leg. To ensure you get maximum choices, get here during busier hours when the kitchen keeps the options coming. Several flights of red wine (6oz/$12) prove highly complementary, and house-infused liquors enliven inventive cocktails. The staff is genuinely welcoming and friendly (ask for the kitchen tour to see the cool multiple-skewer cooking machine).
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsPrivate party room(s)Vegetarian-friendly

column7: It might look like a corner tap from the outside, but inside, this welcoming daytime eatery is brimming with members of the local Puerto Rican community. Large families and bleary-eyed couples fill the place on Sunday mornings for a hearty buffet of thick bacon, sausage links, oniony potatoes, and made-to-order omelets and waffles—plus Caribbean specialties like rice flecked with pigeon peas and tortilla boriqua, a layered casserole of eggs, sausage, sweet plantains, cheese and green peppers. The $12 spread also includes unlimited OJ and coffee. Have an extra cup of the latter with the sweet ending of cinnamon-spiked coconut oatmeal.

We wished this gluten-free, vegan eatery would defy our stereotype of veggie restaurants as New Age centers oozing catatonic vibes. The Balanced Kitchen doesn't, but the tasty bites still merited our time. Appetizers like raw ravioli stuffed with cashew-nut cheese and beauty heart radishes or a refreshing, textured watermelon sashimi made us forget our dairy and meat obsessions. The same can't be said for a bland teriyaki-and-tofu sandwich, but our taste buds were resurrected by a pizza topped with tomato sauce, fingerling potatoes, onions and nut cheese. Stick around for desserts like a sugar-free mixed-berry pie.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Good for dining at bar

column7: Just like the bubbly it's named for, Prosecco has the ability to make a person relaxed and happy. But this is mainly due to their great wine program (and the enthusiastic people who run it). Alas, all that wine will probably make you hungry, so you'll probably succumb to the menu. If you do, avoid lackluster dishes like the short rib-stuffed scallops in favor of the tuna crudo and the rich cavatelli with shrimp. And when it comes to dessert? Choose the liquid variety.

A casual but classy oasis of ocean-blue hues, the dining room is constantly manned by the smooth-talking, personality half of the Greek-American sister duo who owns the restaurant. The other sibling spends her nights in the kitchen, turning out cheesy fried zucchini patties, lightly charred octopus and a deliciously juicy sausage brightened with distinctive orange zest. Entrées can be a tad lackluster, but the baked béchamel-topped, shepherd's pie–ish pastitsio is comforting on a cold evening.

Chef Dan Deaton wants you to take a date to his dim, loungey West Town spot. That may be why everything here is shareable, from the Brie-crabmeat dip (nice and rich, but you've got to eat it fast, before it solidifies) and the étouffée (heavy on the rice but with plump pieces of crawfish) to the Moorish chicken (tender and flavored by sweet potato). The apple crêpes topped with a mango-flavored cream? Technically those can be shared, too. But you won't want to.

Something happened to Okcha McDonald: She opened BBop on Sheridan just a few months ago with a coffeehouse vibe and a cheery, bubbly attitude. Now she's quickly added this second location, complete with DIY grills, and both the restaurant and her personality seem to have taken on a slicker, more polished edge. More importantly, the food is better: Skip the gummy kimchi pancake and go straight for the glassy chapch'ae noodles; the excellent dolsot bibimbap, rife with crispy rice; and the expertly spiced bulgogi.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72

column7: Sitting on one of the tree-stump counter stools at this sleek, designer coffeehouse doesn't really make for an outdoorsy experience—the room is too influenced by midcentury-modern design to conjure the outdoors. But it is a lovely experience nonetheless, thanks to oversized mugs filled with lavender-scented chai lattes, hot sandwiches and baked goods. A newly added brunch menu includes Milk & Honey granola and other favorites like mascarpone-stuffed brioche French toast, and a new bar area means Little Branch is no longer just a daytime pitstop.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 3, 12, 29, 62, 146

column7: Pictures of Negro League baseball legends such as Hank Aaron, Satchel Paige and Chicago native Al Spearman line the walls at this polished soul food café, whose motto is "Enjoy Food and Digest History." Players' names and bios correspond to items on the menu, which boasts some really solid selections: The fried catfish has a perfectly crunchy, mildly spiced skin, and the thick, tender pork chop comes smothered with flavorful gravy. Sides—two come with each platter—are more hit-and-miss. Go straight for the thick and creamy mac and cheese, but steer clear of the dry corn bread–chicken stuffing and the mushy, overcandied yams. Avoid dessert disappointment and hit the bar for an after-dinner drink instead.

If you're going to eat in a mall, might as well make it the 900 Shops. Here, restaurateur Joe King of Le Colonial has taken over the former Corner Bakery spot and transformed it into a handsome kiosk serving contemporary café food: butternut squash soup redolent of baking spices; a meaty lobster roll sporting a sweet, toasted hot dog bun; and hearty, chewy oatmeal-raisin cookies. The food is a step above what you'd find in other malls, and so are the prices. (But if you're shopping here, we doubt that will be a problem.)

For its second location, Uncommon Ground went with a perfect space, a room that is so warm, so perfect, so log-cabin chic that, unfortunately, the food can't compete. So if you're going to make a point to visit (and you should, because once here you'll never want to leave), go with the basics: salads, meatloaf, its justifiably famous brunch (the Uncommon Breakfast Melt is brilliant). That way, your focus will remain on the real attraction of the place: the room.

The owners of Wrigleyville's Katachi have opened this second location that's a bit bigger than the teeny original but serves the same sushi staples. Service is a tad spotty and the sushi isn't going to knock anyone's socks off, but in a neighborhood with sparse options for Japanese, this place will suit fresh-fish lovers just fine. Besides nice-sized slabs of nigiri, there's a good assortment of artfully prepared signature rolls, including Ocean Drive maki (spicy yellowtail, jalapeño, cilantro, cucumber and mango topped with tuna) and Red Line maki (spicy shrimp topped with snapper). There's a good selection of vegetarian maki made with creative additions like spinach and sweet potato, plus a small menu of rice and noodle dishes.
This Old Town pizzeria does thin crust and deep dish, plus panini, pasta and Italian-American sandwiches.
column144: El: Brown, Purple to Sedgwick. Bus: 72

column7: Located in Schaumburg's Renaissance Hotel, this modern steakhouse's dining room is rimmed with stylish booths strewn with pillows in somewhat zany shapes, making lounging easy but dining difficult; opt for a regular table. Steak is the star of the show—the silky tenderloin and full-flavored strip stand out—but there's also "jet fresh" seafood, including lush lump crab cakes. Order fish and you'll spend dinner looking longingly at other people's meals; the preps are a bit basic. Save room for the smooth panna cotta or sorbets that burst with fresh flavor. Most steaks are $35 and up, but a wide-ranging wine list helps one swallow food prices.
column8: Good for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)

column7: With neon-orange and bright-blue graphics and booths featuring built-in drawers for storing napkins and cutlery, this casual Chinatown spot seems inspired by the Austin Powers school of interior design. The chow spans the Asian map—Hong Kong veggies, Szechuan heat, Singapore noodles and Malaysian satay. If you look carefully, you'll spot less-common items like duck kidney and ox tongue. With this broad range, everyone is likely to find something he likes, making this a good place for groups to order widely and pass plates.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groups

column7: It's all about the pastor at this no-frills Ravenswood taco joint, where the succulent pork is roasted on a spit behind the counter and carved to order for tacos, burritos, tortas, gorditas and sopes. You can also fill 'er up with chicken, chorizo or carne asada, but why bother when the pork is so tender and flavorful? A fresh juice bar churns out everything from healthy celery and carrot concoctions to rich shakes made with mamey, mango and papaya—just the thing to transport you to the tropics when the weather outside is frightful.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Not everything on the menu at this dark corner spot under the El is always available (our request for spinach pie was met with "How badly do you want it?"). But that doesn't turn out to be a problem, because everything you can get is just as cheap and solid as the next. Of course, there are some standouts: The grilled salmon is perfectly satisfying (save for the out-of-place tartar sauce); the kebabs are particularly delicious; and the steak, chicken and kefta are all succulent, tender and—seeing as how they're the showcase of the restaurant—unlikely to be out of stock.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 9, 20

column7: In the morning, this Merch Mart food court outpost of the North Shore gourmet grocer lets hungry workers mix in fresh strawberries, almonds and flavored syrups into a half-dozen cold cereals or a steaming container of steel-cut oats. Egg scrambles are simple, delicious tortilla-wrapped omelettes made with ingredients like edamame, goat cheese or sausage. At lunchtime, the place serves uncommon sausages like wild boar, lamb and duck. For nine-to-fivers too busy to make it to Hot Doug's, this is an adequate alternative.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156

column7: The only trace of owner Julio Nepomiachi's Argentine roots at his BYOB barbecue house is the chimichurri-sauced chorizo sandwiches. Other than that, it's Southern American 'cue staples (ribs, brisket, pulled pork) plus gyros as a nod to the space's past life as a Greek-American grease shop.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: You'll love the decor at this Logan Square classic American spot—antlers, evergreens and wood beams, all suggesting a rugged brand of hipness. Unfortunately, the food isn't as successful. Skip the underwhelming stuffed meatloaf, the doughy pizzas and the lackluster tomato soup and grab a seat at the bar instead. Cocktails—from classic to contemporary—prove to be the real draw.

At first glance, the menu at this little BYOB Thai joint seems common, but you should know two things: superfresh ingredients make standard dishes sing, and up on the chalkboard you'll find specials that make the trek worthy of your gas cash. From the latter, try the spicy tilapia with globe-shaped eggplants and the beefy "boat" noodles, a brisket-studded soup. From the regular menu, don't miss the crispy basil-wrapped shrimp starter or the roasted duck curry packed with grapes, tomatoes and pineapple chunks. Grab dessert to go from the small counter of imported cookies and candies.
column184: formerly called THE ELEPHANT, now called THAI ELEPHANT

column7: Take in the Suhail-designed room (think Tim Burton–esque, Rio-style Carnivale) while starting with one of the killer muddled cocktails like vodka-drenched watermelon smashed with fresh lime. Ceviches may be signature, but we had better luck with hot apps like the watercress-topped duck-confit flatbread. For the main event, don't miss the suckling pig with glistening, crackly skin, perfectly sweet plantains and lard-rich black-bean puree.
column92: River East Arts Center, 465 E Illinois St

column7: Go ahead and believe the hype about the cupcake: It's moist, it's substantial but not heavy, and the thick, sugary icing hides deep flavors of chocolate and vanilla. If you're going to pick up a dozen, you may as well stick around for a meal. The breakfast menu will please fans of cream cheese; the gooey stuff makes appearances in a pair of new seasonal omelets, including one packed with arugula, roasted tomato and lemon-pepper cream cheese. Apples, streusel and, again, cream cheese show up in the stuffed French toast, topped with maple-pecan syrup. For lunch, try the newly added grilled Tilapia sandwich on challah bread with cheddar cheese, lemon-pepper mayo and caper-tomato tapenade. Eat up, but save room for one of those cupcakes.
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9, X9, 152, 154

column7: Slow methods of cooking and West African spices merge to make Old World, yet innovative, dishes at this Chatham gem. Signature entrees include mafe, a thick stew of lamb with ground peanuts and habanero peppers, and the succulent chicken yassa, grilled chicken that's marinated in mustard powder, vinegar and lemon juice. Accompanying the giant portions of meat, poultry and fish are fluffy servings of jollof rice and picture-perfect slivers of chewy fried plantains. The large space can often feel empty, so bring plenty of friends.
column204: Best use peanut butter since PB&J

column7: Since chef-owners Kate and Eusevio Garcia split and sold their innovative Pilsen restaurant to partner Mario Cota, the menu's stayed just as creative. (Even if, with the revocation of the BYOB policy, it has effectively become more expensive.) New chef Hector Marcial has a knack for color and texture, which adds excitement to dishes like the Ensalada India, with its contrasts of crisp jicama, ripe mango and crunchy tortilla chips, or the El Mozzer, where poached eggs are layered atop long strips of zucchini and yellow squash over crumbly corn cakes. Main courses have a tendency to read better than they taste, and service can be slow, but a spongy hibiscus cake for dessert nearly makes up for the shortcomings.

At this Gold Coast sushi spot, the lights are low and the candles numerous, which warms up the slick, white, space-agey design. But to warm yourself up, count on the rich, savory unagi egg rolls (avocado and eel wrapped and fried); buttery hamachi sashimi; or over-the-top maki like the tongue-in-cheek, salmon-and-asparagus–filled "Heroine" roll.

Andersonville is already nuts about this new coffee shop, but it's not clear yet if the excitement is over the smart, midcentury modern design; the attention to sustainable products like organic cane sugar and direct-trade coffee beans; or the designery selection of magazines and books on offer. But we're pretty sure about one thing: Its smooth, expertly pulled shots of espresso, not to mention the promises of a soon-to-come crêpe menu, certainly don't hurt matters.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: Proof That Evolution Exists (a coffeeshop with sleek, modern design)
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 84
Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy

column7: Tucked away on one of Logan Square's residential streets, this Latin American diamond in the rough is the kind of neighborhood gem that deserves a little community support. The quiet guy behind the counter is a fantastic cook, evident in his four vibrant housemade salsas that start the meal; the greaseless, flattened tostones (request with garlic, or "con ajo"); fluffy rice with pigeon peas; and crispy-skinned, juice-packed rotisserie chicken, the namesake and star of the show. All of this for six bucks? Sold.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 53, 56, 74, 76

column7: Fans of Rogers Park's Quesadillas y Mariscos Dona Lolis restaurant might recognize the carved wooden panels covering this newcomer's ceiling, the first tip that this is indeed a sibling spot. The second clue should come via signature quesadillas stuffed with gooey cheese and squash blossoms or earthy huitlacoche (a.k.a. corn smut) and a few kernels of fresh corn. Don't skip those standouts, but also try the tlacoyo, a griddled masa pocket encasing subtly porky chicharrones and topped with cool crema, or the palm-sized sope filled with roasted poblanos, mushrooms and mild carne al pastor.

Every meal at this hidden gem begins and ends with a comforting little touch on the shoulder from the waitress. In between, the Latin-tinged menu offers plenty of other comforts. In the morning, pair fair-trade coffee with the plato tipico, a breakfast plate of carefully cooked free-range eggs topped with vibrant red salsa, refried black beans, slices of avocado, salty cheese and impeccable fried plantains. The daily soups, like the subtle, creamy asparagus, are a highlight at dinner. Juicy skirt steak—along with rice, guacamole and beans—proves a delicious filling for warm corn tortillas. A friend of the owners makes all the cakes, including the hulking double-chocolate that's homestyle-good.

Among those bred on the John Hughes oeuvre, this four-month-old café (its name a reference to the fictional Sausage King of Chicago in Ferris Bueller's Day Off) is certainly a curiosity. But beyond the careless look of the place, the frustratingly clueless service and the nominal sausage selection, some of the offerings haphazardly scribbled in marker on the menu board manage to be more than mere novelties. For a quick, cheap lunch, anything off the panini press—ham-and-cheese with zesty red-pepper pesto or smoky chicken sausage and Swiss on marble rye—won't disappoint. On the other hand, the overly salty Polish served naked on a poppy-seed bun just isn't fit for a king, especially a sausage king.
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 49, X49, 70, 72

column7: At this Algerian addition to Lawrence Avenue, the falafel cracks open to reveal soft, warm, fluffy middles, and the lamb shank arrives falling apart on a pile of couscous. But we found that the best items aren't even on the menu yet: Ask for a cup of the magnificent green tea spiked with mint, which provides a delicious interplay of sweet and bitter, and the juicy Cornish hen tagine, spiced with a pinch of paprika.

Nothing denotes a changing neighborhood quite like a mod sushi joint, and Shinobu is no exception: Its bright-white interior stands out in a row of no-frills take-out joints. As with most sushi restaurants in this vein, there's a selection of overstuffed maki (including the massive, appropriately titled "Godzilla"). Skip them. In fact, skip maki entirely, and go for the salmon skin salad (crispy skin tossed with creamy avocado), the chef's choice of sashimi (we found the hirame particularly lush) and, if you can wrap your head around it, the tiramisu.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 151

column7: Hmm. This is a tough one. We wanted to love this beer-and-barbecue joint, especially since the beer list is the most exhaustive American-suds tome we've seen yet. But the ribs are flavorless, and the brisket is dry and overly lean, plus the massive prints of Suicide Girl–style pinups seem like a desperate cling to a passing fad. That said, this is still a mighty fine alternative to watching the game at the Bud Light bars that rule this area of town, so we're holding out hope that the 'cue will improve and in the mean time just going for the brew.

Chef Jason Paskewitz is behind this "old-school Route 66 diner" in Lombard. The suburban strip mall sits far from any dusty highway, but details like the Formica counter, red swivel stools and "blue-plate specials" such as chicken-fried steak and meatloaf should help with the roadhouse theme.

The story behind this new cupcake café is sweeter than the goods themselves: Owner John Nicolades named it after his favorite grade-school teacher, who baked cupcakes for students' birthdays, whose recipes are behind the shop's sweets and whose personal belongings (like vintage ice skates) are fancifully displayed on the walls. In our two favorites of the half-dozen cupcakes, bits of bright carrot mesh with cream-cheese buttercream, and tangy dollops of lemon curd cut a rich vanilla cake. Reenact your own grade-school days by having a cupcake at the swing-style chairs flanking the counter. Look for morning hours featuring breakfast baked goods and coffee drinks to start in a few weeks.
column60: Mon noon–10pm; Tue–Thu 8am–10pm; Fri, Sat 8am–midnight; Sun 8am–10pm
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151

column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsNotable wine listPrivate party room(s)

column7: Given our affection for Lao Sze Chuan, we have to admit we were a bit underwhelmed by our first experience at its new sibling spot. But it turns out, maybe our American palates just aren't set up to fall in love with Shanghai cuisine, the namesake food that anchors this small restaurant's menu. However, when a Shanghainese friend explored the menu, she declared these eats the real deal. For a tasting of classics, order the dry bean curd salad, the smoked fish, the cold shell-on shrimp in sweet soy, the authentically slimy stir-fried yellow eel, sauteed gi cai greens with bamboo and the weather-appropriate casserole of salted pork.

Tony Hu of Lao Sze Chuan must be looking to become the mayor of Chinatown—he's opened this spot specializing in the food of Beijing as well as another just down the strip mall focusing on Shanghai cuisine (see Lao Shanghai). Here, a traditional three-course Peking duck meal is served, as well as dozens of types of dumplings.
column144: El: Red to Cermak/Chinatown. Bus: 21 Cermak, 62

column7: Pastry chef Michelle Garcia runs this punky, organic, vegan-friendly bakery in Roscoe Village. Here, she's doing all the bars and cookies that she did in her previous space on Chicago Avenue, as well as egg, cheese and bacon tea cakes (for those who don't subsist purely on sugar). Don't miss the Elvis cake (chocolate cake with peanut butter and bacon)–available through special order–or the cupcake menu, which varies every month.

This sushi stalwart has long been the go-to spot for neighborhood raw-fish fiends looking for good prices and no frills. You'll find a pretty standard menu of maki, nigiri and cooked Japanese fare like tempura and teriyaki dishes, but the things that keep the crowds coming are the daily sushi specials. Happy hour (noon–1pm and 5–6pm weekdays) means $1 nigiri, while the party tray (really perfect for two, available all the time), includes 15 pieces of nigiri and three rolls for $25. Service can be spotty, but at these prices you really can't complain.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 11, 36, 77

column7: Poblano tamales, pollo en mole negro, arroz con leche—remember these dishes, and all will be well at this new family operation in Andersonville. The two sisters who own the place use a lot of their grandmother's recipes, and the love they have for their family's dishes is apparent in the service, the room and, if you order right, the food. Some items falter—we wouldn't recommend the tilapia or pork in mole manchamanteles—but those that don't (such as a cheesy pork dish labeled "Bomba Frida") make up for it.

A Cuban sandwich shop ought to serve an amazing cubano, and here it's near perfect, the Swiss cheese and roasted pork sporting deep, rich flavors, the ham and mustard countering with a lively saltiness. (The pickles don't hurt either, but sometimes the shop runs out.) Even better is the pan con bistec, a heroish number boasting a copious supply of tender, aggressively seasoned steak. But don't get overzealous: Some sandwiches here fall flat, and the croqueta preparada—ham croquettes, sliced ham, Swiss cheese and ketchup—is one of them.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 49, X49, 81

column7: Opening chef Tony Galzin has left for Perennial, but this clubby gastropub's menu remains the same. Amidst a gothy, glam-rock setting that could serve as the set for a Good Charlotte video, diners will find "crabpuppies" (a combination of blue crab, sweet corn and hush-puppy batter with roasted red pepper rémoulade) and mini burgers with smoky bacon and white cheddar, as well as truffle aioli for the crispy fries. The snacky small plates are perfect with beer, but most of the crowd here seems to just stick to a liquid diet.

If you don't know that the name of this new bar and grill is a Latin music term for rhythm, the bass thumping from the speakers will soon make it clear. Early in the evening, when the music isn't so loud, the high-top tables are perfect for a meal of simple share plates: a fresh salad tossed with juicy bites of chicken; plump grilled shrimp with pungent crushed garlic; and creamy, housemade tres leches cake. Later, however, when you'll likely be drinking more than eating, you'll probably want to stick with the fiery wings.

We're not sure we'd file chip-maker Vitner's in the "local businesses worth supporting" folder as does this spot, which sports orange walls and bright, mod-style couches to match. However, it does stock plenty of homegrown products well worth a try: several offbeat panini (try the turkey, ham and Brie with pear jam) from the North Shore's AOK Gourmet, root beer from Gale Gand, chunky peanut butter cookies from Carol's in Highland Park and desserts from Sweet Thang. Even the coffee is locally roasted in Rogers Park.

No one can really explain why the bright neon lights beckoning hungry people into this cute little Mexican spot tout two different names, but both should tip you off to this place's specialty. Each of the 20 varieties of tortas (sandwiches) comes on crusty torpedo rolls packed with shredded iceberg, tomato, cilantro, onion, mayo and a smear of lardy pinto beans. We keep it simple with the first one on the menu, La 26, a combo of char-grilled skirt steak, Chihuahua cheese and chorizo, though meat fiends should try La Capitalina, which adds ham and breaded steak to chorizo and cheese. For a hidden gem on the menu, try the chicken soup. The noodles are simple spaghetti, but the broth is rich, salty and slightly spicy.

The two Korean-Americans behind this new chicken joint have a good product at the core of their operation and seem to genuinely want to make customers happy. The chicken is fresh, of good quality, and comes slathered in three different sauces: a sticky barbecue, a hot sauce–laced Buffalo and a sesame-soy glaze dubbed "Seoul Sassy." We prefer the latter, but even unadorned the chicken stands out for its juicy meat and crunchy black pepper–dotted crust. There's also a decent bibimbap (best ordered with "marinated" vegetables, beef, an egg and brown rice) and Korean-style burritos whose fresh vegetables benefit from a liberal slather of sweetish hot sauce, but the chicken is the thing.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

column7: This Loop creperie—with its stainless-steel pendant lamps and black lacquer tables—skews more Sex In the City than Saint Germain Boulevard. But look past the ladies nursing cups of java and slinging gossip and you'll find one of Chicago's better creperies. The spongy griddle-caramelized things are cooked to order, with fillings that'll whisk you from Russia (salmon roe and sour cream) to France (coq au vin). During your voyage, stop for the Katmandhu, curried chicken drizzled with spicy-sweet chutney.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake

column7: The stately dining room on the 16th floor of the Trump Tower is indeed impressive, but the close-up view of architectural gems like the Wrigley Building and Tribune Tower and the supremely polished, doting staff come with a price. Chef Frank Brunacci's artistically presented food includes dishes like fresh pasta and escargots in cream sauce with truffles and lamb loin cooked sous vide and plated with trumpet mushrooms, salsify and harissa. For those looking to impress a client or a date with a fine-dining experience, this spot is for you.

We can't recommend enough at this cheery corner spot. In fact, we find it impossible to choose between the scrumptious sope toppling with tender cactus, the enchiladas doused in mole and stuffed with sumptuous shredded chicken, the juicy al pastor tacos topped with sweet pineapple and the hearty, Mexico City-inspired "Al D.F." torta, which takes sliced ham and piles it with avocado and jalapeño. So we order it all. Oh, and also an extra order of crema, a necessary tongue-cooler if you're going to brave the fiery chicken gordita.

This family-run Filipino market has somehow managed to cram a full-blown bakery, an imported goods grocery section (squid and anchovy chips anyone?) and a sprawling takeout buffet (think sticky glazed pork kebabs and whole fried milkfish) into a space the size of a large studio apartment. Take your plate of lechon (fried suckling pig) or kare-kare (oxtail with peanut sauce) to one of the utilitarian tables by the window and watch as what seems like the whole of Chicago's Filipino community stops in for a sweet pastry and a bit of local gossip.

Chicken is the main (okay, only) thing on offer at this fast-food spot in the mega Korean market Super H Mart. The wait is long (15 minutes per order) but it's worth it, and there's plenty of people-watching or produce-ogling while you wait. Thanks to patented mixed-grains crust and fryers bubbling with 100% vegetable oil, the finished product is trans fat–free and nearly greaseless, but far from tasteless. Purists should stick with the plain marinated, dipped and fried version, while those game for vaguely odd but addictive flavors should venture out and order half garlic and half sweet-and-spicy; the latter's chile kick is tempered by savory cinnamon.
column92: Super H Mart, 7801 N Waukegan Rd,

column7: Pan flute versions of classic pop songs repeat (and repeat) on the speakers at this cheerful Peruvian spot, adding a little life to an otherwise quiet strip of Elston. The Peruvian specialties on offer include ocopa, potato slices topped with a creamy mint-and-walnut sauce; heaping portions of ceviche overflowing with tart, tender slices of tilapia and octopus; lomo saltado, heavily spiced strips of beef topped with a pile of fries to soak up the juices; and a rich slice of caramel cake good enough to make even the fifth play of "Dust in the Wind" (yes, a pan flute version) tolerable.
column8: BYOBOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)

column7: Situated among a long row of boutiques, and just a few blocks from two malls, Lito's is in a perfect position to provide that most essential of snacks: the one that provides sustenance for more shopping. The small storefront offers about eight stuffed pastries a day, including a "Hawaiian" version with mozzarella, ham and pineapple and a hearty version with shredded chicken and rice. One makes a snack; two or three make a meal—and since each one only costs a couple of bucks, you'll have plenty of money leftover to spend down the street.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151

column7: The nine-to-fivers hit this tiny coffee shop for fuel in the form of decent coffee and big, fat muffins before hopping on the adjacent El, while weekenders take the time to cop a squat for made-to-order breakfasts. We like the Frenchie, perfect little ovals of lightly cinnamony French toast alongside two eggs, bacon and a bit of fresh fruit. Omelettes are likewise reliable, ditto for filling quiche. Later in the day, locals stop in for standard sandwiches like grilled ham and Swiss or a classic Reuben and a "kitchen sink" cookie finale.

The menu at this bar is mostly made up of in-the-middle-of-a-12-pack hankerings: pizzas, burgers, quesadillas and anything else that can satiate tipsy cravings and enable more drinking. That being the case, it's silly to be too hard on the food; if it's not perfect, it is at least perfectly decent. The chorizo flatbread, probably the menu's most nuanced dish, has a good, spicy flavor but a doughy, chewy crust, and our burger was satisfying but overcooked. In general, these dishes taste less like something that came out of a professional kitchen than like something you'd stumble around in your kitchen to make while drunk. The good news: if you're in this state anyway, you'll hardly notice the difference.
column8: Late-night diningOutdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: You can practically still smell the fresh paint on the walls, yet this place is already giving every other Persian spot in town a run for their money. To get a sense of its relentlessly fresh ingredients, start with the mast-o khiar, mint and cucumber in a housemade yogurt, or the olovieh, a delicious chicken-and-potato spread. Then, move on to the juicy Masouleh (ground beef) kebab and the khoureshte gheimeh bademjan, a succulent eggplant and steak stew. By the end of your meal, you'll know what real Persian food tastes like—and you'll never want to eat that other Persian stuff again.

Cuscatleco is a term interchangeable with Salvadoran, and those are the specialties to seek out at this affordable, tidy, family-run spot. Stuffed and griddled cornmeal patties, a.k.a. pupusas, are the main draw, and for our money, the mixta of pork rinds, beans and cheese is the winner, which we smother with liberal spoonfuls of red and green salsas and crunchy slaw. Supplement the pupusas with a hen tamale and an order of pasteles de carne, crispy pinched-shut pockets of oniony beef. And don't leave without trying the plantain fritters filled with sweetened condensed milk.

Ex–Soul Vegetarian staffer Luetrice Curtis is behind this Evanston spot and the menu that mirrors the South Side staple. Comfort food abounds, though a few picks left us ill at ease: The cauliflower suffers for lack of SV's barbecue sauce, and the buffalo tofu comes undressed, with a small cup of faintly spiced ketchup on the side. But the vegan lasagna stands up to its cheesy counterparts, and the black-eyed-pea burger has a memorable smoky flavor, crisp edges and just-made freshness. The vegan carrot and coconut cakes were moist and rich enough to make us forget they were dairy-free.
column144: El: Purple to Foster. Bus: 93, 206, Pace 213

column7: Warning: Everything at this new high-design pizzeria is tiny. The space fits one communal table and a shelf of carefully selected sundries, while the menu consists of only four pizzas (and no, a create-your-own option isn't one of them). Perhaps most important, the pizza oven is also small, and the man in charge prefers for only one pizza to be cooked at a time. Could it be worth the wait? Thanks to the puffy, chewy crust; the house-pulled mozzarella; layers of fresh, earthy mushrooms; and an obsessive eye for detail, the answer, if your mouth isn't already watering, is yes.

Sure, there's pizza at this modern, design-minded Evanston pizzeria, and it isn't half bad: The bottom crust is impressively crispy, while the crust around the perimeter is puffy and chewy. But compared to the great small plates that come before it (silky kale braised in white wine, herbaceous veal-pork-ricotta meatballs), and the desserts that come after (a polenta pound cake topped with soft, sweet peaches; a magnificently rich chocolate panna cotta), the pizza will probably make the smallest impression. That's not a bad thing—it's just not a pizzeria thing.

Nia Asimis—whose family has a long history of food service on Randolph Street—has opened this small-plates spot, where she attempts to serve food and drinks from every region of the Mediterranean. It's not a bad idea, but the experience can be fairly erratic: For every good move that Nia's kitchen makes (a lovely trio of Mediterranean sausages, including a tender, housemade loukanika), there seems to be an equally bad one (piquillo peppers stuffed with chewy braised oxtail). The kitchen seems to do best with lamb, so stick to the juicy lamb-feta meatballs and the braised lamb shoulder, which is so tender it barely requires chewing.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: A string of Middle Eastern restaurants has called this space home, but none has been quite as polished or solid as this. That can probably be chalked up to owner Intranig Lieon, who spent years on the management side of Reza's and Mambo Grill and obviously knows how to run a restaurant. The name refers to the kebabs, which are skewered and grilled to order; the kefta (ground beef) is particularly juicy. But the really good stuff is the meze: Tart and spicy pickled vegetables; thick, tahini-rich hummus; and a cool, cucumber-studded tzatziki, all of which are good enough that the skewers become an afterthought.

Tea, of course, is the main attraction: Affordable bags of loose-leaf black, white, green, oolong and even blooming teas cover one entire wall. But look beyond what's steeping in your cup, and you'll find the spot's lesser-known gem—the crêpes. Though the gluten-free batter may smack a bit of Bisquick, the flavors inside make up for it. Among the savories, flavorful chicken pesto is a standout. Follow it with a cup of steamy green chai and a tangy dessert crêpe filled with mandarin oranges and rooibos mascarpone, and you'll have a surprisingly good meal for a simple tea lounge.
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 73

column7: Situated smack dab in the center of an under-caffeinated strip of lakefront high-rises, this cheery garden-level coffee shop could draw crowds (as too many do) by offering little more than java, free Wi-Fi and a few wobbly chairs. Happily, that's not the case here. Sink into one of the plush couches and order the Damocles sandwich (cucumber, roasted pepper, feta and humus on sourdough) or go with the make-your-own option by choosing from several good-quality meats, cheeses and breads.
column144: El: Red to Sheridan. Bus: 36, 80, X80, 151

column7: The food at this airy (and often empty) tapas spot is worth going out of the way for. Don't skip the deceptively simple garlic soup, a rich chicken stock dotted with soft, roasted garlic cloves and hearty croutons. Continue the breath assault with the classic tortilla Española, packed with plenty of caramelized onions and served slightly warm. Our favorites of the two dozen tapas include sautéed rings of squid slathered in a smoky and tart paste of paprika and lime, a combo of perfectly crisped potato cubes with slices of Spanish chorizo and roasted garlic, and the must-have higos con tocino, fresh mission figs roasted in a wrap of bacon and plated atop a brandy cream sauce that doubles as dessert.

It's hard to say if the bada-bing vibe here is an act or not, but it doesn't really matter—either way, Natalino's does the Italian-American thing pretty well. The menu has plenty of pastas, chops and meatballs, but also a few surprises: A sweet-and-bitter radicchio and prosciutto app and rich, lobster-stuffed tortellaccci al aragosta both stand out. For dessert, servers push a dessert called "broken" cannoli, an enormous pile of sweet mascarpone that's dotted with broken cannoli shells to scoop it all up. Nobody could possibly finish the thing, but you're not expected to—like everything here, it's all about keeping up appearances.

With all the attention other Western Avenue Thai spots get (namely Sticky Rice and Thai Spoon), this little guy often gets overlooked. True, you won't find Chang Mai specialties or ant-egg omelettes, but sometimes you're just in the mood for a decent tofu green curry. You'll get it here (but order it spicy to counter the sweet coconut milk), plus a dependable crispy noodle kee mow fragrant and fresh soups, and Anglo Chinese favorites like shrimp in a blanket, sweet-sour chicken and broccoli beef. Salty-sour fans shouldn't miss the rice nam sod, our favorite dish in the house.

You might notice that the prices for basic Korean classics like deep-fried mandoo dumplings and rice cake in red-pepper sauce (duk boki) are a bit steeper than you'd find up around "K Town," but in the virtual Korean-food desert of the West Loop, we take what we can get. The best value might be the $8.99 lunch buffet; at least you can suss out the best dishes, then return at night for your favorites made to order. Bibimbap is a house special, but take a cue from the handful of post work Korean-Americans pairing their beer with spicy beef broth kimchi casseroles.

When you do two things, you'd better do them well. Thankfully, Doc's does. This tiny takeout spot (save for two small tables) specializes in smoothies and soups, and uses all-organic ingredients for both. Soups rotate every other week or so, with about three on offer at any given time. We liked both the spinach-lentil and tomato basil, even though the latter was as chunky as marinara (which actually made for a good dip for the wheat baguette). A combo of blueberries, raspberries, yogurt and apple juice was one of the best smoothies we've had—pure fruit, no fillers and fresh flavors. Metropolis drip coffee and Bleeding Heart baked goods add to Doc's appeal as a morning pit stop.

Chef Troy Graves dresses up comfort classics at this upscale Lincoln Square spot that sports three simple white-on-white dining rooms. Graves incorporates the season's greatest hits via strawberries and braised favas with skate wing, crispy artichokes alongside grilled rainbow trout, risotto studded with morels and English peas, and a grilled asparagus salad topped with poached egg and ham vinaigrette. Opt for a table toward the back for more intimacy—this is a date place, after all—or keep going to the charming back patio.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 78, 81

column7: Japanime classics like Akira projected onto a shimmery, beaded curtain are the second clue that this is the sibling restaurant to the popular maki-only spot on Chicago Avenue (that they share the same name would be the first tip-off). Beyond that, déjà vu continues throughout the meal: "Neo" and "Mega" rolls are the stars and should satisfy those looking for over-the-top concoctions (combining bacon, hamachi, pineapple and avocado isn't our thing but maybe it's yours). Nigiri is the only deviation from the original menu, and pieces are large and fresh, but they're pricey. Stick with simple rolls and the delicious seaweed salad, and enjoy the show.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

column7: Anyone who fears Ukrainian Village is losing its ethnicity can take solace in this café. Well-heeled women chat over coffee and cake, a handful of sugar-rushing kids scrape the bottom of their fruit parfaits, and neighborhood elders, including men of the cloth, tuck into particularly good bowls of borscht, all to the tune of Ukrainian chatter. The younger of the mother-daughter team behind the classy, casual spot is right to recommend her mom's baked goods (the airy, sour cream–layered napoleon cake goes fast for a reason), but the savory crêpes, buttery panini and delicious soups are worth a visit on their own.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyKid-friendlyOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)BYOB

column7: House of Hunan's extensive menu and quick delivery service make this restaurant great for takeout, but it is also a great dine-in restaurant.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (Rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8,11, 73, 74.

column7: Expect some down-home cooking from Doc's, located within the Kingston Mines blues bar/venue. The menu features ribs, burgers, chicken, and charcoal grilled catfish.
column144: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74.

column7: This small shop front caters only to delivery and pickup, but there are small tables for those that just can't wait to tear into their sesame chicken.

Don't let the name fool you. This ice cream parlor also has a pretty hefty grill. The Greek-owned shop features gyros with tzatziki, burgers, and spinach pies. The $2 hot dogs are popular with kids and Depaul students alike.

Boasting enough root beer flavors for every day of the week, Frances' knows how to indulge its Lincoln Park customers. The simple menu and gigantic portions have kept this Lincoln Park staple in business for more than 70 years. Try a triple-decker corned beef with hot pastrami ($9.95), but skip the fries and go for the potato pancake side. Hopefully, there is still room for chicken matzo ball soup and a gigantic chocolate-chip cookie for dessert.
While the restaurant only seats about 30 patrons at a time, the family-style platters of fresh sushi and California roles make it hard to resist bringing everyone you know.

Classic Chicago Dog: mustard, relish, onion, peppers, tomato, pickle and celery salt. There is no doubt Chicago is the best, but America's Dog offers up different combinations for major cities across the states. Send your taste buds on vacation to Houston by adding a mountain of chili, or Atlanta with coleslaw (yes, on the dog), chili, mustard, ketchup and onion.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: When just walking down Wells Street has left your wallet looking slim, stop into Augustino's for a hot meal that won't break the bank. Try the Supreme meatball sub, Augie's "to die for" blue cheese steak sandwich or homemade lasagna. The three-restaurant chain has been serving up pizzas, pastas and subs to Chicago for over 25 years.

At Jose Garces's colorful Spanish spot in the Blackstone Hotel, chef de cuisine Michael Fiorello welcomes summer the way so many of us do: with barbecue. Only his is Catalan-style. Flavorful charred octopus is tossed with green olives and confit potato while grilled flat-iron steak is marinated in a rich sauce of nora chiles, roasted garlic and honey. Signatures like garrotxa-stuffed cipollini onions and spicy housemade pork sausage make enough of an impact that you'll believe Fiorello's claim to be something very different from a "run-of-the-mill tapas bar."
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4

column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingLate-night diningKid-friendly

column7: With a Moulin Rouge–like cast of weekend entertainers—from castanet-wielding belly dancers to stoic turban-topped sitar players—you'd figure the fare at this Oak Park Indian restaurant would skew exotic. Yet it's the standards like silken spinach dotted with paneer, ginger-and-garlic–infused chicken mukhni and lamb tikka masala that shine.
