The jalabi dessert, which often suffers a waxy tasteless fate, is pliant and sports a hint of orange, while gulab jaman, bathed in honey and perfumed with rose water, is an airy antidote to the dry dough bombs you find at other spots.

As bright and inviting as a warm June morning, the interior of this Edgewater Thai spot is a stark contrast to its not-so-pretty locale underneath the Granville El stop. You'll find some spicy surprises on the menu of standards, including Hot Pop Eyes (stir-fried spinach noodles cooked with curry, hot chile and stir-fried veggies) and seared duck breast with tomato, pineapple and bok choy in a red-curry sauce. Seafood lovers should opt for Scallop Dynamite, mollusks cooked with eggplant in a fiery garlic sauce, or Bangkok Street Calamari, grilled rings tossed with asparagus and chile lime sauce.

Seafood is the star at this sunny Mexican spot in North Center. Choose from four different ceviche to start your meal—the combo of white fish, octopus and shrimp delivers with bright, fresh flavors—then move on to shell-on jumbo shrimp marinated in lime, garlic and herbs or red snapper sautéed with tomatoes, cilantro and onions topped with a slightly spicy "ranchero" sauce. If fish isn't your thing, opt for char-grilled pork chops served with refried beans, rice, and tortillas or enchiladas filled with three kinds of cheeses.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 11, 80

column7: It's slim pickings for Chinese-food lovers in this neighborhood, which may be why Papajin hasn't gone the way of Filter or Sweet Thang. That's not to knock on the food. The part-Chinese, part-Japanese menu covers the basics (hi there, General Tsao) just fine, and while we weren't floored with the cavity-inducing sweetness of the lemon chicken, we were pleasantly surprised by the white cliff maki (a shrimp tempura roll with a creamy avocado-mayo topping). During the summer, nab a sidewalk table, order a Kirin and let the people-watching begin.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyGood for groupsOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)Late-night dining

column7: When a fast-food Mexican diner brags about "burritos as big as your head," the only question left is chicken or steak?
column144: El: Brown, Purple (Rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus 8,11,74

column7: Corporate bookworms and broke college students peacefully coexist at this neighborhood corner-shop cafe. While quality caffeine is the biggest draw, Sienna also has a small menu. Try some of the fresh pastries, or the spinach and feta croissant.

As pleasant and sunny as this dining room is, purists should steer clear. The rest of us, however, may be able to appreciate the "Heavenly Tofu" (tossed with peanuts, chile peppers and soy sauce to sweet-hot results) and "Bite Size Delights" (tiny lettuce rolls with dried shrimp, ginger and coconut) for the Americanized Thai food it is. On Sunday mornings there's a brunch buffet, and if there's a better cure for hangovers than unlimited banana fritters and "Dreamy, Creamy, Crispy Crab" (a.k.a. crab rangoon), we've yet to find it.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (Rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 74, 76.

column7: Classic Chicago Dog: mustard, relish, onion, peppers, tomato, pickle and celery salt. There is no doubt Chicago is the best, but America Dog offers up different combinations for major cities across the states. Send your taste buds on vacation to Houston by adding a mountain of chili, or Atlanta with coleslaw (yes, on the dog), chili, mustard, ketchup and onion.

Although Andrew Baker has made a commitment to serving only organics at this charming parkside café, he hasn't lost his appetite for junk food: The limited menu essentially consists of nitrate-free hot dogs (topped with the savory housemade chili, if that's your thing), plump spinach-and-feta chicken sausages and potato chips. Like the Trader's Point ice cream that goes into the sundaes and ice-cream sandwiches here, it's all satisfying and good—if not necessarily good for you.
Quick grub for busy travelers staying at the hotel, or any Chicagoan looking for a cheap ($7.95) lunch buffet in the loop.

Mingle with the media crowd inside the NBC building at this big menu bistro. A hot latte with a triple-chocolate biscotti and cinnamon roll is a sweet way to start the morning. Didn't have time to make a bag lunch before work? This deli serves up fresh fruit, sandwiches and burgers.
Southern hospitality and a lil' bit of live jazz make Joe's a prime stop at Navy Pier, or it could just be the barbecue ribs and seafood.

If you're out shopping the Mile or work in Streeterville (a neighborhood notorious for having limited lunchtime options), you could do worse than popping into the top floor of the Shops at North Bridge for a bite. And this is where you can get a taste of Phil Stefani's Tuscany with a smaller price tag on northern Italian-style cuisine. Go for paninis, soups, salads and pastas.

Neighborhood hole-in-wall bars are pretty common, but regulars swear CND is a diamond in the rough when it comes to the menu. Patrons are gooey for the cheesy Italian beef, and rank the broasted chicken above the gyros.

This squat brick citadel is a community gathering spot where Bulgarian dance troupes come for midweek practice while gruff-looking expats throw down pints of Kamenitza, Bulgaria's best-selling pilsner. Grandmothers stop in to peddle martenitzas, red and white bracelets to celebrate Baba Marta, a holiday that commemorates spring. Your money is better spent on comfort fare like shopsko gyoveche, a baked casserole of feta, egg and hot peppers, or katin meze, a goulashlike plate of roasted meat and sautéed onions slathered in tomato sauce.
column8: Good for dining at barGood for groupsLate-night diningKid-friendly

column7: Over the Fox River and through the forest preserve to Geneva you must go...that is, if you want to score guacamole infused with watermelon. It may sound weird, but the sweetness of the melon cuts the richness of the avocado perfectly; the flair is indicative of the innovate touches that run through every dish in this small Mexican spot on the edge of town. Instead of tired queso fresco and bottled hot sauce, steak tacos here get a dose of creamy manchego cheese and a zingy tomatillo-serrano salsa. Even your run-of-the mill flan gets cut into a two-tiered flower shape and topped with micro-mint.

For all the talk about this hot-dog joint's stripper pole, you'd expect things to be a little more wild (and naked) in here. But the closet-size space doesn't allow a lot of room for debauchery, so things remain pretty tame. That goes for the hot dogs, too: The Los Lobos (a dog wrapped in bacon and topped with jalapeños, mustard and onions) is good, but not as exciting as the description suggests. Ditto for the Ramone, which gets all of its flavor from a huge heap of sauerkraut. The best dog is the one that's simply dressed with Merkt's sharp, addictive cheddar. The only problem? To order it you have to ask for the "J. Timberlake."
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 56, 66

column7: Don't dismiss this place as just another greasy grub joint; they've been serving up made-to-order Greek dishes, ribs and, yes, burgers, cheese fries and the like, too, to a steady stream of patient customers since 1976. Standouts include grilled skirt steak on garlic bread, freshly made soups and a gyros platter that could hold its own in Greektown. But if you're feeling the need to be healthy, hefty salads like the grilled chicken on a bed of bright greens won't seem like a sacrifice. And if the weather ever warms up, you can sit on the outdoor patio and soak up some rays.
column8: Outdoor seatingLate-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: We can't call this the best Middle Eastern food in town, but we can at least give it props for reaching deeper into Egypt's gastronomic pockets than anybody else. In addition to typical hummus and baba (both of which could use more salt), this sprawling restaurant/belly-dancing venue/hookah lounge (the smoking ban doesn't seem to exist here) offers specialties like basterma, a spiced, cured beef; makdoos, a stew made with beef-stuffed eggplants; and an unusual form of pita bread that's thin, formed into oversized sheets and baked fresh right in the dining room.

Chef/owners Greg Mohr and Scott Weiner are under no delusions that the menu here is anything but bar food. But their upscale palates, along with creativity, translate into dishes that take bar food one step further. So the chicken wings are slathered with a housemade hot sauce, mac and cheese is spiked with extras such as pulled pork, and coleslaw gets a sweet dose of pineapple.

From the name to the graffiti-inspired splashes of color to the hip-hop videos playing during our visit, this buzzing River North shop is the first of what could become a homegrown mini-empire for "Yogurteur" Michael Farah. This fro-yo contains healthful live and active cultures, and the texture is about as good as can be, balancing between light and creamy. But the flavor suggests there might be some added citric acid, bumping up the yogurt's natural tartness to an almost tongue-tingling, lemonlike taste that would clash with any chocolate-based toppings.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Awards, Readers' Choice: Best New Frozen Yogurt
column198: Other locations: 500 W. Madison (312-993-9644), 135 N. LaSalle (312-533-2145)

column7: There are a couple of things you can count on at this Puerto Rican café: hefty pressed sandwiches, the crusty bread stuffed with copious amounts of fillings like sweet roast pork and grilled onions; strong espresso and café con leche; delicious pastries, such as a tangy-sweet Danish stuffed with cream cheese and guava; and a multigenerational clientele that comes in to discuss the merits of the aforementioned offerings (and everything and anything else).

A restaurant on the first floor of the Edgewater Beach Apartments building can't help but have a majestic (if slightly dated) feel to it. And while this dining room might not inspire as much awe as the building's grand lobby, it nevertheless feels stately and old-school (and sometimes just plain old). We thought maybe this place would be running on history alone, but the food was surprisingly solid: Shrimp was perfectly juicy (which is good since it's in every single appetizer), tournedos of beef were tender enough not to require a knife, and the trout was finished with a sprightly lemon-caper sauce.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136, 144, 146

column7: Housed in what was formerly occupied by Los Chilaquiles, this new, casual Mexican joint isn't necessarily bringing anything new to the area—except, oddly, American food. Half the menu here is dedicated to national pastimes like hamburgers, hot dogs and tuna salads. Still, we think it's best to stick with the Mexican fare, where you'll find solid tacos (including one stuffed with pleasantly chewy strips of cecina) and tortas (like an al pastor version featuring rich bites of pork spiked with sweet bits of pineapple). Then, if you're still hungry, you can get an order of American mozzarella sticks to go.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82

column7: Chocolate and wine may be the focus of this cheerful (if somewhat generically decorated) spot, but a proper dinner can be cobbled together with the savory small plates. Juicy slices of tenderloin on a sourdough baguette make for a hearty start, and the veggie sandwich (sporting a tall pile of sweet, balsamic-kissed slices of roasted eggplant and zucchini) is surprisingly satisfying. Of course, the goal here is to get to dessert, and for that we suggest you go as literal as possible and order the creamy PB&J truffle—solid proof that chocolate and grapes are an inspired pair.

For extreme Cubs fans who don't have Cubs tickets, this new pub offers countless flat-screen TVs and the "Holy Cow! Burger Bar," which lets you pick your burger (Tallgrass beef, lamb, etc.), toppings (crispy buttermilk onion strings) and even your bun.

This restaurant, which took over the space formerly occupied by Thai Nippon, serves food from every region in Thailand, and even ventures into more contemporary stuff (such as a Thai take on mango salsa shrimp).

The suave greetings from slicksters in suits, the sly handshakes with well-heeled fiftysomethings, the nose-thumbing move of ashtrays in the bar area...so many signs scream old-school Italian joint that you'd never guess this place was only a few weeks old. The menu of Italian-American specialties (chicken Vesuvio, veal marsala) doesn't excite much, but a handful of standards are done surprisingly well. Crispy calamari is incredibly tender and greaseless, and we could have made a meal out of the fantastic Big Night salad topped with perfectly grilled, big fat shrimp and bright artichokes. In fact, maybe we should have: Four-cheese ravioli's sage butter sauce was incredibly salty, and a chicken breast's goat cheese and spinach stuffing didn't save it from drying out.
column8: FireplaceGood for dining at barKid-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 38, 56, 125

column7: Though the shabby decor (part faux-palace-luxury, part Egyptian disco) doesn't necessarily inspire confidence in the kitchen, everything we tried at this pan-Middle Eastern spot turned out to be delicious. Labna arrived seasoned with green onion; mugs of aromatic tea were gratis; and musakhan, a traditional Palestinian dish in which thin bread is wrapped around sumac-dusted chicken and loads of sautéed red onion, was pleasantly sharp. To top it off, Habibi offers its juicy shawarma in a long soft roll, creating an entirely new but ingenious concept: the Middle Eastern hoagie.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Late-night dining

column7: Faced with convincing blue-collar neighbors to eat "ethnic food" when they opened in '61, the Cornejo family behind this joint offered up gooey enchiladas and deep-fried goodies while keeping corn tortillas and spicy chiles on hand for expats. The resulting regional Mexican and Tex-Mex hybrid experience includes crispy fried hard tacos filled with green-chile-marinated pork nuggets and the "soft cheese," corn tortillas topped with an oozy béchamel. The house hot sauce, which is sold by the pint, is as thick as ketchup and packs a satisfying tang that trumps the vinegary firewater found elsewhere.

More than 20 years ago, Chinese immigrant Nai Tiao opened Great Seas on the Korean stretch of Lawrence Avenue and unveiled a now legendary lollipop-style soy-and-chile–glazed chicken wing. Now his daughter, Karen Lim, has taken the wings to Pilsen. The decor screams franchise, but the food is the real deal. Freshly fried egg rolls are stuffed with peppery vinegar-laced cabbage and pork; soy-splashed fried rice is topped with fluffy butterflied caramelized shrimp; and the sweet-and-spicy wings, a.k.a. Little Hotties, are as good as old man Tiao's.
column93: Take Me Out, Let's Eat Chinese
column186: Take Me Out, Let's Eat Chinese

column7: A sibling of Outback Steakhouse, Fleming's has a clear agenda: They want to be an upscale, wine-focused steakhouse that doesn't feel like a chain. But despite an impressive wine list (100 wines by the glass), this place is still seriously corporate. The extra-smiley service becomes intrusive around the 20th time somebody asks you how your night is going, and the menu reads like a Best Of compilation of food from the '90s. Worst of all, the steaks are mushy, and the deep-fried mushrooms and chocolate lava cake aren't much better. And that's something even the nicest service can't fix.

The straightforward menu may not lure the adventurous seeking "secret" translated menus, but this Thai spot is still notable for having an adorable, eager-to-please staff and solid, consistent standards. Fans of basics like pad thai and panang curry will be satisfied but even more impressed with the papaya salad's balance of bright citrus, fiery chiles and just-funky-enough fish sauce. The secret weapon: the butter cookies baked by the owner's wife in varieties like subtle lemongrass, sesame seed, toasty coconut and the standout buttery clove. A plate of them arrives, gratis, at the end of the meal, but trust us—you'll also want to take a bag or two home.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 78

column7: The theme that runs through this Wrigleyville pizza shop is meant to make you feel like you're sitting on the threshold of both heaven and hell. Depending on what you order, the experience can go either way. The thin crust pizza has a nice crackery crust (though there's no trace of the PBR they claim to make it with) and a zesty sauce; when topped with big chunks of artichokes, it's a nice pre– or post–Cubs game snack. On the other hand, there's the "Wrath" sandwich: steak, pepper-jack cheese and onion on a soft white roll. The flavor is fine, but the rubbery texture of the steak? Let's just say it's not heavenly.

You can be forgiven for assuming that the bourani badenjan at this Afghan restaurant will be like baba ghanoush, but you'll be pleasantly proven wrong: It's smoother, more complex, a little sweet (thanks to caramelized onions) and a little tangy (thanks to yogurt). That's the theme with most of the food here, which always tastes markedly better than you'd expect. After gorging on the aushak, a delicate, beef-stuffed raviolilike pasta, and the kabuli palaw, a tender lamb shank cooked with sweet carrots and raisins, you'll get a handle on Afghan cuisine. And you'll wonder why there isn't more of it locally.

The owner of Pizza Metro and a former pie-slinger for Pizza D.O.C. combine wits on what they do best at this corner spot at the northern edge of Ravenswood. It's clear after one bite of the rectangular pizzas that it's Metro that's driving the style—Roman in shape and structure, the pies are thin (but not cracker-thin), crunchy (but not dry) and topped with tasty combos like al dente eggplant and zucchini or a perfect balance of salty, tart and rich with diced ham, fresh mushrooms, artichoke and black olives.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49, X49, 81

column7: After teasing Lincoln Square for months, this Cincinnati-style chili parlor has finally started dishing out 3-Ways (and 4-Ways, and 5-Ways). Chili is, obviously, the thing here, but some seriously strong cocktails vie for your attention as well.

If you're using Wisconsin custard as your bar What up, Leon's? What up Kopp's?), you're going to be disappointed here. The custard comes out of a traditional dispenser but then gets frozen, which results in a harder, less-creamy treat than we expected. This Wicker Park sugar shack lines its glass cases with chocolate-dipped everything and fluffy mounds of caramel corn, though, so even if the custard's a miss you'll still get your fix.

Jerry Kleiner has brought midscale swank and classic American eats to Hyde Park's Harper Court, making for a nice night out for locals who desperately need more options. If spinach artichoke dip and iceberg wedge salad don't excite you, try Chef Rachel Everett's juicy New York strip or pan-seared halibut flavored with a smoked tomato vinaigrette and a side of mashed potatoes with a sweet maple vanilla rum butter. Good thing the banquettes are comfy—after a meal like this, you'll need 'em.
column144: Bus: 6, 15, 28, 55 . Metra: Electric Main to 51st–53rd St

column7: The phrase "vegan fast food" may conjure up images of lettuce with a side of wheatgrass, but the grub at the city's second Veggie Bite location has more in common with your neighborhood burger joint than it does with a salad bar. Seitan subs in for steak in the fajita wrap and Philly cheese steak (which both taste strangely of curry), and "barbecue bites" come out sizzling from the fryer with a side of tangy 'cue sauce. Skip the overly sweet milk shakes in favor of delicious vegan cakes.

If you're playing the lottery, stop by this Filipino lunch counter/market, where you can pick up Lucky Me Noodles (ramen) and a lucky bamboo tree in one stop. For immediate gratification, head for the steam table filled with tender vinegar-splashed Adobo chicken, fried milkfish and humba, pork slathered with a sweet soy glaze. Excellent pancit bihon (fried vermicelli noodles sautéed with cabbage, onion, carrot and pork) and tusilog (reddish-tinted pork mixed with fried egg and rice) are made fresh to order. The stogie-shaped lumpia Shanghai eggrolls are some of the best in Chicago; wash them down with Sarsi, sarsaparilla cola.

The sign and menus might still say Chicago's Rosscoe's, but thanks to a recent lawsuit brought about by L.A.'s famous Roscoe's House of Chicken and Waffles, Rosscoe's (two s's or not) has been dropped from the name. Regardless, you can still get that sweet and salty duo of chicken and waffles any time of the day here, and that's really all that matters.
column93: Chicago's Home of Chicken and Waffles
column144: El: Green to Indiana. Bus: 1, 3, X3, 29, 39
column186: Chicago's Home of Chicken and Waffles

column7: Lifeway Foods, the local company known for its kefir products, is behind this new Ukrainian Village shop. Kefir is a fermented milk drink popular in Eastern Europe, and it contains strains of bacteria and yeasts that yogurt doesn't. The health effects are hotly debated and haven't been scientifically proven, but Lifeway claims the "probiotic" live cultures aid in digestion, among other things. Like the drink, the "plain" flavor is sour. Problem is, the flavor of the day we sampled had a strangely fakey peach flavor and overly grainy texture.

This new Ethiopian restaurant distinguishes itself from similar spots nearby with its small menu: What's usually a pages-long tome of various stews is here whittled down to a handful of options. That makes it easy to try lots of stuff, so don't skip the shuro, a delectable chickpea dish with a complex, gradual heat; the yemisir azifah, a cold lentil dish with a great piquant tang; and the "Lalibela special tibs," sumptuous bites of sautéed lamb. Or just order one of everything—that way, you won't need a menu at all.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50

column7: The longtime Lincoln Park pizza stalwart is no more, but after closing its doors on Webster Avenue this spring, O'Famé has reappeared in Lincoln Square as a mostly takeout and delivery joint. The menu's pretty much the same, so longtime fans of the thin-crust here—crispy, perfectly browned and topped with creamy mozzarella and Parmesan cheese—won't be disappointed. They might, however, be disappointed with a bland specialty pan pizza with ricotta and fresh tomato and slightly greasy pastas. Happily, the garlic bread has a perfect butter-and-garlic ratio with a good crunch, salads are crispy and made-to-order and service is smiley. Still, we miss the old place.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 80, X80

column7: The old-school (and awesome) sign and awning date back to this staple's midcentury debut, but the recently remodeled interior is brand-spanking new. In an apparent attempt to remind hungry Chinatown wanderers this is still a viable option, the owners have created a very comfortable setting, replete with lacquered black tables and romantic dimmed lighting. The menu happily remains old-school Cantonese, with specialties like crispy shrimp roll, sizzling rice seafood soup and kung pao chicken. Some items (such as the ying yang shrimp) are a bit sweet for our taste, but can be countered with the ultratart house specialty—mai tais.

It doesn't take a genius to figure out that the main attraction at this bright Mexican spot is the spice-rubbed, grilled chicken. Order at least half a bird per person—the chicken is so juicy, with such delicious charred skin, that a quarter just won't cut it. The tendency at these Mexican chicken joints is to eat the chicken with soft pita. We aren't discouraging that practice, but if you're heading here on the weekends, when they serve housemade tortillas, concocting tacos and topping them with the fiery salsa (whose flames can be put out by the rich, creamy frijoles) is the more authentic way to go.

Those ducks hanging in the window? Yeah, you're going to want to order one—you'll want to experience the interplay of the crispy skin, the soft fat and the rich, gamey meat. You'll also want the spiced, hot shrimp encased in an addictively crisp and salty coating; the sweet roasted pork with scrambled egg over rice; and the fresh dumplings, so thin you can see the pink shrimp and cabbage hiding within. It might be one of only a couple of Chinese places in the Vietnamese part of town, but it could compete with Chinatown on its best day.

From the old men gathered over pepper-and- egg sandwiches to the red-and-white vinyl tablecloths and the Filbert's soda bottles, everything about this joint is classic. There really is a Joe, and pictures of his fishing expeditions hang on the walls alongside photos of Walter Payton and John Wayne. You can have any deli meat you want shoved between Gonnella loaves, but the red-sauced chicken parmesan and the capicola, salami and mortadella–filled Italian Special are the best. And surprisingly, if you've got a hankering for Mexican, Joe's freshly fried flautas rule the neighborhood.

For the last year and a half, Paul Fehribach has brought a taste of New Orleans to Andersonville with house-cured tasso-ham-and-pimento-cheese sandwiches, spicy gator sausages with crunchy fried pickles and barbecued shrimp. Now he's hired sous chef Corey Fuller, an Alinea alum, to expand on that Southern theme. This fall, Fuller and Fehribach are rolling out dishes such as sassafras-lacquered quail with cornbread stuffing; sweet-tea-brined pork chops with molasses-baked-bean puree; and a grilled New York strip steak with deep-fried mashed potatoes.

The purple accents, lavender stools and gray walls make dining at this Peruvian spot a bit like dining inside an Easter basket. Luckily, though, chocolate bunnies are ditched in favor of braised lamb with sweet peppers and garlic and oregano–flecked rotisserie chicken so succulent that a simple twist frees the meat from the bone. Complimentary aji, a mayo-based sauce kicked up with Peruvian green peppers, is perfect for dipping crispy fried plantains and beef and raisin–stuffed empanadas.
column144: El: Brown to Kedzie. Bus: 80, X80 Exp

column7: Despite its Sbarro-ish appearance (a strip-mall location will do that), this slice shop packs oodles of charm. Similarly, normally pedestrian dishes boast surprisingly big flavors. Gigantic slices of pizza sport a tangy housemade sauce and a thick focaccialike crust; peppery housemade meatballs make for hearty subs; and panini are stuffed with smoky bacon and fresh spinach. Canadian poutine makes an appearance on the menu, too, but take a cue from all the Pacino posters hanging on the walls and stick with the Italian stuff.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendlyKid-friendlyLate-night dining

column7: By employing homeless and otherwise at-risk youth, this nonprofit café doubles as a social venture. But we've had their cookies, granola and sandwiches and think they perform a much-needed service of their own.

Opening a Vietnamese restaurant on Argyle is like tossing a coin into the U.S. Mint. Though, with most of its neighbors sporting utilitarian storefronts, Pho Xua, with its golden microsuede chairs and sleek wooden tables, is the shiniest coin in the till. The restaurant is named for the traditional beefy broth, but the best bowl in the house is the "fried duck noodle" filled with ribbons of delicious ramen, a juicy caramelized duck leg and a confetti of scallions. Segue into the noodles with a starter of betel leaf beef mini kebabs wrapped in wilted greens with a smoky honey flavor.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyGood for groupsBYOBCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: The combination of exemplary ingredients and minimalist preparation is at the heart of every dish at this simple BYOB, and this turns out to be an excellent way to cook. It allows sunchokes, dressed with lemon and parsley, to show off their crunchy earthiness, housemade charcuterie to exhibit its lingering richness, and flaky shortbreads to simply melt in your mouth with no distractions. The food is so naked that it can't hide even the smallest flaws. Luckily, those flaws are few and far between.

At this sunny, stylish eatery (the new incarnation of the former Sal & Carvao), meals are served churrascaria-style: Diners start by grazing on the "Harvest Tables" (a.k.a. salad bars) and return to their table to have proteins—perfectly cooked salmon, juicy filet and chicken thighs, etc.—brought over by men carrying huge skewers. It's not a bad way to eat if you're incredibly hungry. But if you want to eat light—or if you don't like sweet and/or cheesy foods, which almost all of this is—the influx of food could very well leave you with nothing to eat.
column8: ViewsOutdoor seatingGood for groupsFireplacePrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago; Red to Chicago/State. Bus: 66, 156

column7: Located in the Renaissance O'Hare hotel, you'll find hearty buffet fare, as well as an a la carte menu, served up throughout the day. Expect a range of Mediterranean influences combined with American classics from chef John DiMartini.

If shabby-simple were a style, this Rogers Park spot would define it. No, you will not have the best panini of your life, but you will be able to grab breakfast or lunch for two, including coffee and juice, for 20 bucks. Follow this advice for a foolproof meal: Start with a double cappuccino, add a side of turkey bacon and some feta to the garlicky spinach omelette (use the English muffin for a sandwich base), and finish with Nutella crêpes. Take your meal on the wrought iron–clad patio and it's a can't-lose scenario.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendlyBYOB

column7: Tall, pink, "Malaysian" cocktails garnished with tiny umbrellas? Check. Huge platters toppling with toothsome shrimp, hefty eggrolls and creamy crab rangoon, all encased in a thick coating of golden batter? Check. Impressively cooked dumplings, sauteed until one side is browned and crispy? Of course. Sweet, tender pork ribs? Garlicky Yu Shan beef? Sweet and sour wontons? Naturally. How else do you think Chinese-American places like this have sustained such brisk business all these years?

The monochromatic color scheme and the Lichtenstein-ish paintings may not have legs for the long-haul, but in the meantime, this is the mod antidote to the Franco-cheesiness of stalwart La Creperie. Its thinner sweet crêpes are superior to its puffy savory counterparts, so for the main event, go with the crispy Cuban panini filled with juicy hunks of shredded pork and oozy Swiss instead. Finish with the eponymous sweet, specifically the cherry mascarpone suzette smartly tempered by bitter orange marmalade.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 22, 36, 74

column7: This burger joint sports Slow Food principles (beef and chicken are all-natural, hand-cut fries are cooked in trans fat–free vegetable oil), but is the food any good? Pretty good, especially compared to the fast-food nation that surrounds its South Loop locale. Burgers are hand-formed to almost an inch thick and cooked to a nice pinky medium; opt for aged cheddar, bacon and egg toppings for an artery-clogging good time. Chicken breast is (as usual) kinda boring, so just stick with the eponymous specialty, and be sure to add on the earthy, skin-on fries. Shakes are decent, but our favorite sipper is the Lemon Squeeze, a blend of fro-yo, strawberries and lemonade.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendly
column98: 2009 Eat Out Awards, Readers' Choice: Best Loop Lunch

column7: One of the Moonshine owners partnered with a chef from Hawaii for this all-day kebab shop that offers quick sticks of Caribbean-tinged eats. Best bets are the artichoke app, yucca fries with banana ketchup, grilled shrimp and sweet potato fritters. Late-night hours enable the surrounding bar crowds, and plans for 10 additional locations in Chicagoland are in the works.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Late-night diningVegetarian-friendly

column7: If you've been looking for a David Beckham refrigerator magnet, this one-stop diner/pop- culture fridge magnet vendor/art gallery of oil paintings of Chicago athletes is the place for you. This diner was established in 1954, and everything here —from the clothes-pinned order slips above the grill to the Hamilton Beach milkshake machines—is a throwback. Malts are wet cement–thick, and freshly ground beef patties are topped with sweet caramelized onions on pillowy white buns and arrive with a nest of crispy "curly-q" fries.

column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 76

column7: The cold beer in the visible cooler, the blaring TV in the corner, the wood-paneled walls with bright red and yellow accents, the postwork neighborhood guys sipping cerveza at the tiny home bar in backÉit all adds up to a scene that's more Latino family rec room than restaurant. Hence, the charm of San Luis, which stands out for its homey feel, fresh shrimp tostadas, whole fried snapper and hangover-helping chilaquiles. Fruity 'rita fans will like the pineappley house version, but beware: It's just as sweet as the Spanglish-speaking servers.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 76

column7: This tiny restaurant is owned by the same people who own Zam Zam, a beloved Indian sweets spot on Devon. Funny, then, that sweets play just a small role here. Instead, this huge menu focuses on savory Indian staples. You can get through the menu piece by piece if you wish (start with the spicy, fist-sized samosas). But if you want to try everything before 2020, hit the juicy tandoori chicken, tender seekh kebab (beef) and spicy Bihari kebabs all at once with the mixed grill.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136

column7: When we tell you this new Southport tapas spot is hot, we mean it literally: Every tapa caliente—from the fiery patatas bravas and toothsome octopus to the bite-size chorizo empanadas and omelettish tortilla Española—arrived too steaming to touch. We took that as an encouraging sign, because if you're going to eat standard Spanish grub and down glasses of sangria (both the white and red versions here are fruity but not too sweet), it's good to do it at a place where you know the food hasn't been sitting under heat lamps.
column8: Late-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seating
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9, X9, 77

column7: There's nothing twisted or off-kilter about this second-story Old Town bakeshop. In fact, the tarts (banana cream, apple pie) and cupcakes (red velvet, carrot cake) are pure, straightforward old-fashioned goodness. It's the cookies, though, like rustic cornmeal rounds with a hint of lime and buttery shortbread, that are instant classics.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72

column7: The dining room of the short-lived Shochu is pretty much unchanged, but the owners have shifted the format from a Japanese-style izakaya highlighting the namesake distilled liquor to an American platform that matches that of their original restaurant, Deleece. Steak is the major focus (take heed: What is medium-rare here is probably just "rare," or even raw, to you), and the rest of the meat-and-potatoes menu includes a nuanced porcini-garlic soup and gluttonous beer-battered cheese curds. It might no longer be a forward-thinking restaurant, but if it can survive where Shochu couldn't, then it's probably what the neighborhood wants.
column8: Late-night diningGood for dining at barGood for groupsOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77, 152

column7: For all of you without a grill (or the know-how to use one), here's a bit of hope: Though fast food–ish in appearance and demeanor, the fare here is grilled, as the name suggests, over charcoal, and the results are akin to what you'd get on your patio. Actually, let us amend that: The dogs here have a great, crackly skin (we like the Chow dog, topped with a cheddar sauce) and the burgers, though thin, sport char marks and big piles of fresh, crunchy toppings. So it doesn't taste like what you'd grill—it could very well taste better.

Part of a small chain of sushi spots mostly in the western 'burbs, this Oak Park outpost has an elegant feel with bamboo shoots sprouting to the ceiling and a dark and comfy subterranean sake lounge. Of the more than 50 maki rolls, we liked classics like the soft-shell crab "spider" and creative takes like the "temptunava," which combines shrimp tempura, tuna and avocado with spicy mayo. Presentations are part of the show, so expect your fish formed into some sort of artful display.

Spring awakens at Graham Elliot Bowles's dressed-down solo project, where shaved radishes add bite to tuna sashimi; pea tendrils and a lavender marshmallow adorn split-pea bisque; and spring onions and white truffles brighten up creamy crab risotto. A 48-seat patio means River North diners with a taste for Bowles's quirky fare can dine alfresco on mains like grilled spring lamb with fava beans and Southern-inspired cornbread-crusted scallops alongside green tomatoes in a ham-hock vinaigrette. Pick from a bouquet of floral sorbets (jasmine, rose, chamomile, hibiscus) for dessert.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156

column8: Outdoor seatingGood for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column92: Dana Hotel & Spa, 660 N State St

column7: Though mistletoe hangs over the counter year-round, the only encouragement you'll need to kiss the cooks at this brick and timber sub shop is a bite of their sandwiches. Though provolone takes the place of traditional Cheez Whiz, the peppery paper-thin beef mixed with grilled onion and ribbons of green pepper makes this version one of the best local examples of the venerable regional classic. Lean corned beef or roast turkey BLT piled high on rye are great no-fuss lunch treats for smaller appetites.

For years, Sushi Wabi and Starfish kept a lobster claw–like grip on the West Loop sushi market. Now, Sushi Pink, with its reasonably priced sashimi and imaginative maki, threatens to tinker with tradition. Creamy chunks of lobster studded with wasabi-infused fish roe is like a nigiri riff on a Maine lobster roll, while the Bloody Mary maki spikes raw tuna with Korean red pepper paste. If raw seafood isn't your thing, the Wild Animal maki featuring roast steak, duck, and pork with a touch of scallion will sate the most voracious carnivore.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingBYOB

column7: R.J. and Jerrod Melman, sons of Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises impresario Rich Melman, are behind this midscale River North catchall that offers a menu that ranges from open-faced BLTs to halibut tacos. The crowd is as varied as the eats—tourists, ladies who lunch and local working stiffs rub elbows—and everyone seems content with the large portions and boisterous scene. Braised pork tacos with housemade tortillas are a surprise hit, and plump maki do the trick if sushi cravings hit.
Angelo Lollino of the adjacent gelato and panini shop Massa is behind Elmwood Park's first sushi spot. Look for dishes like togarashi calamari and soy-paper-wrapped spicy tuna with kaiware sprouts.
column8: Outdoor seatingSuburbanGood for dining at bar

column7: Though this Mexican seafood spot is named after the Spanish word for a thatched-roof beach hut, the dust kicked onto the outdoor patio by cars speeding through the McKinley Park 'hood means you won't mistake it for paradise. That is until you dig into limey ceviche pescado and coctel mixto pulpo camarón, the latter bathing tender chunks of octopus and plump shrimp in a spicy V8-like tomato sauce that trumps the ketchupy versions found elsewhere.

Painted the soothing shades of the Salvadoran flag and permeated with the slap-slap of fresh pupusas being made, this Mexican/Salvadoran crossbreed specializes in namesake cornmeal pockets packed with decadent chicharron, creamy beans or delicate loroco flowers. With across-the-board cheapo prices, adding a hen tamale and a meat-stuffed torta won't break the bank, so take a group, add on the standout steak sope, and wash it all down with rich tamarindo.
column93: Pupuseria los Planes and American Grill
column186: Pupuseria los Planes and American Grill

column7: Yeah, it looks like fast food, but this tiny, cheery Korean joint cooks everything to order, so the food can actually take a few minutes to arrive. And when it does, it's impressive: Both the short ribs and the chicken are lean and tender, the crunchy coleslaw sports enticing whispers of wasabi, and the cucumber salad is a refreshing foil to the crisp tofu. In short, it tastes like there's a real chef in the kitchen—and what fast food join can make a claim like that?

A breakfast joint that focuses almost solely on omelettes, waffles and fruit might sound like a place with a limited menu. But it turns out those fluffy omelettes are stuffed with all kinds of fillings, from a lively ranchero sauce to spicy chorizo. Likewise, the fruit takes three different forms: a cocktail sprinkled with salt, chile powder and lemon; fresh juice; and satisfying smoothies. And the crisp waffles (good enough on their own) can be topped with pecans and fruit. Good luck deciding among the three.

This Canadian health-food chain has brought healthy options to the artery-clogging Loop lunch scene, but we're more impressed by the swell-sounding menu descriptions than the actual food itself. Still, dieters can keep lunch low-cal with tofu and tempeh wraps, salads and brown rice bowls, but we prefer to get our calories with the tart frozen yogurt topped with fresh strawberries and toasted almond slivers.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Pink, Orange to Washington/Wells.

column7: Joe Farina added this counter-service lunch spot to his expanding network of Italian eateries, and for our money, it's the star of the family. Pastas and salads join signatures like Joe Mama's Meatball Bomber sandwich, which is our pick for best of the lot thanks to bright, zesty tomato sauce and the massive meat-to-bread ratio of the meatballs. Eggplant parm is nearly as good an option for those looking to eat relatively healthy, and the Italian beef with both sweet and mild giardiniera is the best within a Turano-roll toss of the tiny carryout space.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle/Van Buren

column7: When we're in the mood for bar food, this laid-back neighborhood favorite is among the first spots to come to mind. The TV-packed room might hint at average pub grub but excellent eats and unique touches (housemade pineapple-infused vodka, for one) elevate the experience. Try the juicy burger (order it medium-rare, topped with cheddar and sub onion rings) and the Memphis combo, a duo of crunchy fried redfish and massive, meaty spare ribs with good smoke and tender meat. Hand-cut fries complete the gut-busting good time.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for dining at barLate-night diningOutdoor seating
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 22, 80, X80

column7: Macarons from heaven. Fleur de sel caramels from someplace even better than heaven. Pastry chef Dimitri Fayard cranks out dozens of gorgeous, seasonal entermets (layers of cake, mousse and handmade chocolate) every day and for less than $5 a pop. The Manjari entremet, a chocolate biscuit topped with chocolate cream and chocolate mouse, is our current favorite, but it's hard to choose. His confections make a great gift, but the packaging is so mod and sexy, you'll want to keep it.
Maybe the churrascaria frenzy hasn't died off after all—its just changed hands. This one features the same meats, salads and desserts as the rest of them, with some sushi thrown in for good measure.

You can't see it though the glass-block window, but hidden in this nondescript storefront is a gem of a bar/pizza parlor. A grandiose statue of a Rubenesque woman is the center of the Art Deco room, and her disciples—regulars from the neighborhood—gather around her to sip Bloody Marys and debate this and that. But we don't come here for people watching alone: The kitchen puts out a nice deep-dish, with a crispy crust and a well-spiced (if slightly sweet) sauce. We'd tell you to go for the Gino's "special," with its big chunks of sausage and strips of green pepper. But really, with this atmosphere, your night's going to be special no matter what you get.
column144: El: Red to Granville. Bus: 147, 151 (24 hrs), 155

column7: Chef Ryan Poli is squarely at the helm of the latest venture from BOKA's Kevin Boehm and Rob Katz—and the results are impressive. It's tough to decide which is better, the black truffle gnocchi with tender squash and deliciously bitter chard or the rectangle of vanilla-scented crispy-skinned veal breast—get 'em both. The surest sign of summer's approach (besides Green City Market returning across the street) is the rollout of the "Cabana" menu, with offerings like mini grilled pork belly– sliders and shrimp croquettes for relaxed dining on the spacious patio.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: The Comeback Kid (chef Ryan Poli's return to the Chicago restaurant scene)

column7: You can usually tell a good barbecue spot by the ornateness of the pig on its sign. Here, where the pig tap-dances while wearing a napkin ascot and wielding silverware, the rule doesn't hold. Though it does offer pulled pork and smoked rib tips drenched in sweet sauce, this Midlothian gem (a sandwich shack housed in a North Woods style log cabin) is more revered for its incredible, two-inch thick, garlicky, grill-marked pork chop that's moist, well-seasoned and luscious all the way to the bone.
column8: FireplaceGood for groupsKid-friendlySuburbanCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Those who crave the stuff of San Francisco crêpe stands can find a suitable substitute until their next Bay trip at this cheerful Loop café. The $7–$12 price point may seem stiff for a little French pancake, but savories (mushroom, beef Stroganoff) come with salads and desserts are a la mode. Plus, while the namesake crepes may be thicker than the lacy-edged ideal, they're jam-packed with fillings, the best of which include a seafood-studded frutti di mare option.
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle

column7: The best raw fish in town is at this small, unassuming West Rogers Park hideaway. Here you'll find incredibly fresh, melt-in-your-mouth, superpremium yellowtail, bluefin, mackerel and fatty tuna. Beyond the raw, Katsu's crew has skills on the grill, turning out a tasty marinated duck breast and a crispy yellowtail collar (great with a dab of shaved, pickled daikon, a sprinkle of sea salt and a squirt of lemon).

With hundreds of tin robots, wind-up toys and other kitschy gewgaws covering every inch of wall space, your short wait for lunch will be spent giggling about Pez dispensers you had as a kid. Entrées typically zoom out of the kitchen, especially on busy weekend nights. Start with some of the freshest spring rolls in the city, light and crisp enough that you'll have plenty of room for a heaping plate of rama, with its rich peanut sauce, crunchy steamed broccoli and perfectly fried cubes of firm tofu.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendlyOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendly

column7: We have nothing against chef Chef Raul Arreola's sumptuous cochinita pibil, or his crunchy and flaky fish tacos. But it's the moles here that steal the show. Sopes get a dose of the brooding, smoky mole rojo, and white fish gets treated with a lighter, sprightly mole verde. And while its not a mole, the smooth poblano sauce pooled around perfectly grilled shrimp is so lappable, we almost don't need the seafood. In fact, we don't need any of the proteins here. All we need is some mole, a bowl to put it in, and some handmade tortillas to sop it all up.

Chef Carlos Gaytan is going for Mexican-French here, but most of his food comes off as upscale versions of the former. This isn't a problem: You'll be too busy eating to notice the lack of French flair in dishes like the perfect lamb chops, accompanied with a delicious barbacoa sope; beautiful ceviche; and excellent, beer-battered fish tacos. And when the fusion thing works, as it does with the cochinita rillettes and the luscious duck confit tacos, it's nothing short of magnifique.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: It's a bit tough to find, but once you stumble upon this little nonprofit café (part of Maggie Daley's pet project, the youth arts organization Gallery 37), you'll have found a new go-to Loop lunch spot. The simple, vegetarian-friendly menu is creative and executed with care, from housemade soups like mushroom bisque and tomato basil to crispy-edged pesto portobello panini. Make a combo out of soup, a drink and a sandwich (try the mesquite turkey with smoked gouda and applewood-smoked bacon) for $8, or start the day with Metropolis coffee and an excellent breakfast croissant sandwich.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink and Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: Middle Eastern food is usually fast, but this Kedzie newcomer, with its counter setup and self-serve soda fountain, has a slight McMediterranean feel to it. Thankfully, that ends when the food is brought out. Avoid the pedestrian hummus; instead, dredge your pita through refreshing cucumber yogurt salad or the galaya, a simmering skillet of lamb-and-tomato stew. Or just skip pita altogether and get your carb fix with a warm lamb pie. Whatever you do, you'll be washing it down with soda. Dawali translates to grapevine, but so far there's no wine in sight.

Though you wouldn't know it from the shiny interior, this diner has been slinging burgers in Roscoe Village since 1953. After a recent two-and-a-half year renovation, its new incarnation actually feels more beach shack than diner—the doors prop open to create a breezy feel, and the limited seating means most people take their food to go. But the menu—cheeseburgers topped with sweet grilled onions, Chicago-style dogs (all-beef franks heavy on the celery salt) and a full lineup of shakes and sundaes—is diner all the way.

There's little at this Italian BYOB that you haven't seen (or, in all probability, eaten) before. So if you're looking for innovation, stay away. If, on the other hand, you're looking for a good plate of sausage and peppers, or a piece of tilapia cooked in white wine and mushrooms, this may be your place. The basics are handled solidly all the way through dessert, where a housemade tiramisu and apple crisp inspire overeating. But the pizza—though topped with a sprightly sauce—is undercooked and soggy, so if pizza is what you want, stay home and get it delivered from someplace else.

Way before the Windy City got all fancy with its 'zas, Giordano's was here. Serving up hefty deep-dish goodness to Chicagoans since the '70s, this chain is still pleasing masses with no-frills gut-busters topped with sausage, spinach and other classics. The chain also serves salads and red-sauce dishes like lasagna and chicken parmesan, but why waste your time?
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

column7: Eating chef Geno Bahena's food is like watching an episode of The Cosby Show—you can't help but like it, even the 100th time around. So don't be concerned that the menu is so similar to projects of his past; take it as a sign of specialization and focus on any dish sporting sauce: tender ostrich with ancho chile sauce, for example, or lamb with dark, brooding mole negro. Those familiar with Bahena might yawn at seeing the same plates again and again, but it's worth hanging in there, either to relish in the comfort of his reruns or to be around when he finally does something new.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 74

column7: Sometimes, we just want to go to a coffee shop with a quota on Salvation Army furniture. For that, we head to this airy, brick-walled, two-room internet cafe, hunker down with our laptop (there's free Wi-Fi) and order a blackberry licuado (shake) or a cup of Intelligentsia coffee. When hunger strikes, try the grilled-chicken sandwich or the veg-friendly lentil soup. Not enough tchotchkes for your eye-candy quota? Check out the rotating art from local artists on the walls, or the neighhborhood folks glued to the row of for-rent PCs checking their Facebook accounts.

The conceit of this café is that chocolate is so vital a commodity that you could—indeed, you should—make a meal out of it. But for anybody who might have a nutritional or epicurean resistance to such an idea, panini are on hand to serve as a savory start. The thin, bland slices of bread housing thin, bland slices of turkey aren't much to look at, or to eat, for that matter. But if they're the justification you need to indulge in one of the Belgian chocolates on offer or—better yet—a scoop of Palazzolo's lemoncello gelato, it's worth it.
column60: Sun, Mon, Wed 11am–7pm; Thu 11am–9pm; Fri, Sat 11am–10pm (closed Tue)

column7: Just say the words "fresh noodles" and we're there. Clearly that's the draw to the new incarnation of the former Vive la Crêpe space, but be warned that aside from the silky pan-Asian wheat noodles, this Evanston newcomer struggles with the basics. Aside from the general problem of flavorless proteins (beef, chicken, etc.), simple soups are one-note, and apps are of the bought-and-fried variety. So stick with the stir-fried housemade noodles ("Zo's Crazy" combo of broccoli, egg, mushroom and bell pepper is tasty) and hope the rest of the game gets stepped up.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 205, Pace 208, Pace 250

column7: Despite swanky red-velvet seats and artful food, this sushi spot won't wow you with mediocre nigiri and been-there, done-that maki (most of which includes some sort of tempura). More creative dishes, such as white tuna tataki in ponzu, can be overcooked and underflavored, so stick with standards like steamed gyoza, edamame and basic rolls including spicy tuna and salmon-skin maki. Added incentives come for parents: The staff is superattentive, with servers who do magic tricks and make origami animals out of tinfoil.

New York chef Marcus Samuelsson entered the Chicago market with this seafood spot on the ground floor of the Affinia Hotel, but we're pretty convinced the Scandinavian chef is little more than the name attached to the project. Nicole Pederson, a Lula vet, recently stepped in as the executive chef, catching up with winter flavors in dishes like an heirloom-apple salad and a grilled pork chop with farro and Concord grapes. One thing has, thankfully, stayed constant: pastry chef Toni Roberts, who's gained a following for her seasonal desserts (cider-poached pear with ricotta fig fritters, pumpkin-caramel bread pudding) and delightful candies.

After a trip to Florence for frozen-yogurt sampling, 21-year-old Kim Smith decided Chicago needed a fro-yo shop with a similar modern aesthetic. Sweetened only with "natural sugar," there's still a slightly chemical taste up front. The tart-to-sweet ratio is about even, meaning it's less tart than the competition, and the texture is somewhat icier, almost like soft-serve sorbet.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: The Korean fro-yo chain (which opened its first store in 2002 and claims to have been the inspiration for its rival Pinkberry) picked Evanston as their Chicagoland testing ground, then opened in Naperville right after, and is finally in the city proper. What's all the fuss? It's wonderful stuff, with a true yogurt tang and clean, refreshing sweetness. And best of all: the texture, smooth as silk, but not scary-slick like DQ soft-serve.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 205, Pace 208, Pace 212, Pace 213

column7: Depending on the time of day, this bare-bones Euro-Asian pastry shop is either packed with cops picking up warm BBQ pork buns or older Chinese women choosing the best-looking slices of not-too-sweet melon cake. Either way, you'll be lucky to nab one of the two tiny tables, so order chef Peter Yuen's pastries to go. Get a slice of chocolate Celebration Cake, the one that won Best in Taste in the 17th annual U.S. Pastry Competition, and you'll forget all about the so-so coffee.

Over the years this garden-level Japanese spot has become overlooked. We found the sashimi to be up to par (especially the buttery maguro), but we were more intrigued by the cooked dishes. The agadashi tofu is battered and fried, rendering the tofu creamy and warm, and the oyako don takes a bowl of rice and tops it with a fluffy omelette and crispy chicken. The solid food and friendly owner will tempt you to spread the word, but you may want to keep it all for yourself.
column144: El Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus 8, 11, 74, 76.

column7: We could forgive this newish, loungey restaurant for its apparent identity crisis (black tablecloths topped with crudely ripped white butcher paper, plasmas showing sports while Euro techno beats away, etc.) if the hodgepodge of Middle Eastern and Mediterranean food were delicious, but no such luck. Hummus and falafel are indeed fresh and housemade but don't sport so much as a trace of salt or flavor, for that matter. Ditto for the underwhelming pastas (even the juicy chorizo couldn't save blah chicken linguine) and kebabs (lamb was tender, but the dry veggies and rice killed the appeal).
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 73, 74

column7: Sultan's is a good metaphor for Wicker Park's gentrification. What was once a mom-and-pop Middle Eastern grocery with a lunch counter in the back has exploded into a slick eatery in the last 15 years or so. But don't let the shiny digs, a fancier menu or the cute boys behind the counter distract you: You're here for the fresh salad bar, the zatter fattia (two spice-rubbed slabs of bread filled with feta cheese and hummus or baba ghanoush) and, of course, the falafel sandwich (a pita bursting with crispy-fried chickpea balls and Jerusalem salad).

Go preshow, postshow or without seeing a show at all—the House of Blues's restaurant is in some ways a show in itself. On Sundays, the AYCE brunch is accompanied by a lively gospel band. And on every other day, the vibrant folk art on the walls provides eye candy. The menu serves the cuisine of the American South, and while bowls of gumbo are mild and underwhelming, the Friday fried-catfish special is excellent. There's also corn bread with maplebutter, which—despite the bread puddings and cakes offered for dessert—is the best sweet in the house.
Seasonal summer sushi spot; May through October

Though it's 60 years old and inhabits the original location of the legendary Gene & Jude's, this spot doesn't seem much different than any other old grease shack. RC Cola on draft; lots of stainless steel; sullen, wary-eyed counter helpÉcheck. But, ford your way past the dogs and beefs, and you'll find the french-fry sandwich, a gluttonous beef jus–dipped bun piled high with skin-on shoestring fries, chunky giardiniera, and your choice of mozz or oozy nacho cheese.

Find approachable (and affordable) Afghan cuisine in the suburbs at this BYO, which pleases vegetarians with appetizers like kadu (sautéed pumpkin topped with housemade yogurt sauce) and entrées like banjaun chalau (eggplant cooked in tomato sauce). Carnivores won't feel left out with choices like chicken and lamb kebabs and mantu––dumplings filled with ground beef and onions. The restaurant is currently closed temporarily while they relocate to a larger location down the block.

360 degree views from the 70th floor of Lake Point Tower provide an elegant setting for French-inflected fare like a surf-and-turf of filet mignon and Maine lobster followed by a lavender crème brulée.

Tequila is the heart and soul of the southwestern Mexican state of Jalisco, the namesake of this corner taqueria—the perfect spot to line your stomach after a night of throwing down a few shots. Menacing sepia-toned portraits of Pancho Villa and his gang adorn the walls, but the real Mexican standoff comes when deciding which tacos to order. Lomo encebollada, hearty rib-eye chunks, are flat-top griddled to a perfect char with a hint of pink and tossed with caramelized onions. That and the achiote-marinated al pastor or the tangy chile relleno oozing with melted queso fresco are your best bets.

In the mood for Uzbek food? No idea what that is? Expand your horizons by starting with pickled herring, watermelon or cabbage, all guaranteed to perk the taste buds. Eggplant salad, rich with bittersweet chunks, sparkles with cilantro and is excellent plopped atop lepeshki, the round bread of Uzbekistan. There are many crisp, fresh veggie platters of spicy tomatoes, beets and carrots, while meat eaters get marinated and skewered liver, pork and beef or luscious lamb meat over roasted long beans and zucchini. For dessert, try the chak-chak, a block of fried noodles heavy with honey that's something of an Uzbek take on the Rice Krispies treat.
Jonathan Segal (a partner in Japonais) and Donnie Kruse (behind Stanley's Kitchen) tap chef Jon Foster (previously at Le Passage) to turn out bistro classics in the former BB's space.

From the spider roll to the rainbow roll to the tuna hand-roll, the maki at this stylish new sushi joint is consistently enjoyable. (Order anything with white tuna, though, and things get promoted to downright delicious.) Still, eat here and the adjective that will come to mind most is "big." The rolls are so enormous that you'll only need one or two to fill you up, and fitting the pieces into your mouth can be messy and embarrassing. Then again, if you can swallow the name of this place, you can probably swallow anything.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Bleeding Heart Bakery's punk-rock-mama Michelle Garcia has reinvented the former Chaos Theory as this kid-friendly bakeshop, where pint-height tables are outfitted with massive rolls of paper for scribbling and comfy, colorful couches for little ones to plunk down on. Of course, there are the requisite cupcakes in flavors that appeal to all ages (chocolate peanut butter, red velvet), as well as croissants, muffins, bars (try the s'mores brownie and the lemon bar) and cake "balls," bite-size rounds of the bakery's full-size cake options. Weekends are solely for private parties—fantasy affairs that include dinosaur-shaped cookies, pizza and cupcakes for decorating.

Susan Thompson and Jill Barron of De Cero have teamed up again for this shoebox-size meatless mecca, where global vegetarian fare is gobbled up by lanky diners lounging on chunky wood stools and in dark booths under dim lights. With prices somewhere between Green Zebra and Earwax or Flying Saucer, two people will spend around $50 to leave full, so to leave both full and satisfied, choose wisely. We recommend sampling among small portions of simple yellow squash "pasta," asparagus ravioli in spicy tomato sauce and the brown rice-mushroom sliders. Chocolate pot de creme is a great ending, unless you're looking to drink dessert, in which case go for the cucumber Sakerita.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)
column98: 2009 Eat Out Awards, Readers' Choice: Best New Vegetarian

column7: There are lunch cravings that often lead us to the fancy Niman Ranch carnitas at mega-chain Chipotle, but when we're in the mood for old-fashioned taqueria grub, we head here. The lard-rich refried beans and red rice are definitely standard, and the line is often long, but a few bites of classics like ground beef–stuffed flautas, chorizo and potato gorditas and juicy steak tacos in soft, warm tortillas remind us why these places are so ubiquitous in Chicago. Grab a slice of choco-flan before heading back to the office for that 3pm sugar fix.

Outside of the Maxwell Market, many taquerias have banished fresh masa in favor of machine-made stuff from local tortillerias. Here, there's a little old lady patting and shaping balls of the cornmeal dough and griddling them until they puff up like corn-perfumed balloons. And while the tacos and gorditas (including a rich picadillo) are good, the star of the show is the braised chicken tinga flecked with smoky bits of chipotle, served on a flat oval-shaped huarache and topped with crumbly queso fresco.

No cupcake has ever tasted quite like the BLT concoction at this sleek (and tiny) Gold Coast cupcakery: Sweet cake is filled with salty pieces of bacon, smeared with a completely savory ranch "icing" and topped with fresh slices of tomato. It's jarring at first, but it works so well that it's perhaps the most convincing proof that cupcakes can swing both ways. Showcased in a glass display, the rotating selection of cupcakes (including classics like Red Velvet and Chocolate for the more conservative cupcake connossieur), look like works of art—because they are.

A slice of thin-crust pizza at this new West Town takeout/delivery joint will cost you upwards of four bucks. But before you dismiss the place as a rip-off, know that the slices are the size of at least two slices from most anywhere else and come with a can of pop, making it a bargain for late-night feeding frenzies. Rounding out the menu are salads, roasted chicken dinners and a slew of hot and cold sandwiches (try the chicken Italian made with a breast topped with roasted red peppers, fresh spinach and mozzarella on warm focaccia bread, but skip the ho-hum Italian sausage if you're picky).

So maybe the carrots in the chicken soup here are undercooked, and maybe the broth itself is weak. Doesn't matter. People will order the soup for the good matzo balls, because a good matzo ball in Chicago is hard to find. And good sablefish? Good lox? Happily, these elusive goods are also found at Steve's. No, the bagel you put the fish on isn't great. And this isn't a corned-beef place, either—the beef is leaner than the economy. But all of this can be forgiven. Because what would a Jewish deli be without something to kvetch about?
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 11, 65, 125

column7: The slices at this outpost of the popular Madison, Wisconsin, by-the-slice joint are foldable, New York–style thin crust, and you can order plain old cheese if you want, but you'll probably want to get more creative. The best-selling slice is the mac and cheese, made with a crème-fraîche base, elbow macaroni and housemade cheese sauce. Other slices that'll help soak up all the suds postgame also tend to stray from a traditionalist's idea of pizza—specialties include BBQ steak and fries, and the BBFAT (black bean spread topped with feta, avocado and tomato). You can create your own concoction, too—just choose your toppings carefully if you think there's a chance you'll be tasting them again in a few hours.

This blink-and-you'll-miss-it storefront in Portage Park does a good job with Chinese staples such as General Tso's chicken and shrimp stir-fry with bok choy. There are a few misses—grilled chicken sticks and sesame beef were overpowered by grease—but for the most part you'll do just fine sticking with classics and pan-Asian eats such as Singapore fried rice noodles, thin vermicelli studded with pork, chicken, shrimp and egg, in a just-spicy-enough green-curry sauce. A recently added sushi menu is pretty standard stuff and skippable for raw snobs.

If you've been trying to turn your chimichanga-loving friends on to authentic regional Mexican, this Ashland storefront, which offers both excellent Tex-Mex and Oaxacan eats, is the perfect spot. There's plenty of drippy queso fundido and well-grilled quesadillas to act as a safety net while you blindside them with a bite of pollo poblano, succulent chicken planks doused in a chocolatey, garnet-colored mole.

Like most Peruvian restaurants, here it's all about the aji. The creamy, green sauce, with its herbal punch and jalapeño burn, goes perfectly with almost everything the menu offers. You can slather it on bread with butter; stir it into the chicken soup brought out as an amuse; spoon it on top of the papa a la huancaina, where it mixes with the cheese sauce and creates a delicious companion to the soft, boiled potatoes beneath; and, of course, use it as a condiment for the juicy roasted chicken. The only thing the aji isn't good for is the jalea de pescado; luckily, that platter of fried fish has enough lime juice to shine all on its own.

Chandeliers hang from the ceiling of this plush restaurant, which has been holding court on this corner of Old Town since before Old Town was, um, old. A few scenesters sit on the sidewalk patio to people-watch before heading out to the bars, but for the most part this is a family place, where big tables holding intergenerational groups are not the exception but the rule. Makes sense: It takes a lot of people to scarf down the big portions of chicken parmigiana, lemony grilled calamari and the capellini "Melissa" with plump shrimp and sweet sun-dried tomatoes. (On the other hand, the hazelnut-studded tartufo only requires the appetite of one.)
A converted barn provides the setting for seasonal preparations of rustic dishes like steaks, ribs and pork chops at this west suburban restaurant.

Choose from Wagyu, USDA Choice, Uruguayan organic beef and more at this suburban steak place. Lighter fare like salads, shellfish, chicken breasts and pasta offer alternatives for the less carnivorous.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)

column7: Grab and bottle and head for this little Bucktown BYO, where the Italian-influenced dishes include a Tuscan-style veal chop and a maple-leaf-roasted duck risotto.
If you can make your way through the Foodlife crowds, you'll find this casual, supper-club-style restaurant dishing out traditional American favorites like meatloaf, burgers and steaks.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for groupsKid-friendly

column7: All it takes is a slice of Vienna torte--a flourless chocolate-almond cake with a layer of apricot jam--and a precious cup of coffee (delivered on a tray) to feel oh-so sophisticated and European at this Lakeview café.
column144: El: Brown to Southport. Bus: 9, X9, 152

column7: It's all about the ribs here, whether you want baby back, barbeque beef or rib tips. Pick up some slabs to go, or BYOB and take a seat on the back patio.
column8: Outdoor seatingBYOBGood for groupsKid-friendly
column144: El: Brown, purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 73

column7: Get your "haute" dogs at this gourmet stand in the 'burbs. Try a wild game sausages and Belgian frites with dipping sauces like artichoke, red banana and wasabi--or stick to the classics with a jumbo dog or a polish.

Coco Pazzo's more casual sibling belies its Red Roof Inn location with thoughtfully prepared antipasti, panini, housemade pastas and traditional Tuscan mains like bistecca. They don't take reservations for the outdoor patio, so if the weather's nice, come early or late to get some people-watching in.

When Bravo comes around to cast a Real Housewives of Bridgeport (in our dreams), we hope it makes a call at La Vita, where couples sporting a whole lot of look dine on well-executed Little Italy standbys. Housemade cavatappi in a thick, cheesy vodka sauce tastes like grown-up mac and cheese—a guilty pleasure if there ever was one and a suitable preamble to a plate weighed down with thick, port-glazed bistecca, oversized waffle fries and buttery sautéed spinach. The créme bržlée came out cold in spots, but we were too distracted by the charming waiter to complain.

The mini-chain (with locations in Lincoln Park and Hyde Park, in addition to Lakeview) tosses pizzas with unusual toppings like a Thai pie chicken (with a spicy peanut-ginger sauce) or one piled with rosemary potatoes and chicken. Traditionalists will do well with a Chicago-style stuffed pizza, or choose from the menu of salads, sandwiches and wraps.
column144: El: Brown, purple (rush hrs), red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Roll dinner and a show into one with dinner at this hibachi house chain. Chefs show off their mastery of knives and flames while cooking up dishes like teriyaki chicken and beef at the table.

We won't blame you if you arrive at this outdoor café and doubt its ability to put out quality French entrées. The kitchen is in a shack, after all, and the whole operation looks perilously makeshift. But if you avoid the hot dishes (a disappointing—rubbery, even—slice of quiche almost confirmed those initial doubts) and focus on chef Didier Durand's renowned pâtés instead, a shift can occur. With a view of the river and skyline, a glass of rosé in hand and a table crowded with jars of duck rillettes and baskets of bread, you'll go from dubious to devoted.
column93: Cyrano's Café and Wine Bar on the Riverwalk
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple to State; Red to Lake
column186: Cyrano's Café and Wine Bar on the Riverwalk

column7: Fresh-baked pita and low prices have made this falafel place a favorite of suburbanites. There's plenty of seating, or take some hummus and schwarma--and goods from their Middle Eastern market next door--to go.
The perks at this Bucktown Middle Eastern place include some outdoor tables and its BYO status. The menu offers big portions of standards like baba ghanoush and kababs.
column8: Outdoor seatingBYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendly

column7: They do thin-crusts and calzones and whatnot, but the real deal here is the stuffed pizza: a deep-dish loaded with mozzarella and covered in tomato sauce.

Chef-owner Jenny Urban kicks up coffeehouse fare at this brightly colored café. The menu can be hit-or-miss, but we had the most success with Southwest-style dishes like queso dip layered over chunky guac served with freshly fried tortilla chips and a big brunch plate of black-bean-studded corn cakes topped with fried eggs. If Urban's friendliness isn't enough to liven up this desolate strip, a bottomless cup of coffee and a slice of housemade chocolate-orange tart just might do the trick.

Judging by the sun-faded Michael Jackson wall art and the dusty Christmas decor, the "new" in the name of this Vietnamese standby might be stretching it. Take the dated decor as a sign of longevity, and for the secret to it, scan the War and Peace–size menu for gems like lemongrass-scented chicken and caramelized sesame beef over rice noodles with fresh Thai basil and a golden egg roll filled with succulent shredded pork.

How a grimy little corner coffeehouse with a single chef (and her high school–age son working the front of the house) manages to cook much of anything—much less a well-balanced, anise-scented green curry, loaded with chunks of Thai eggplant and basil leaves—is something of a mystery. Bland noodle dishes and disappointing desserts don't do much to explain things; even though the massive cakes are made in house, ignore them. If there's even a small crowd, the wait for food can be senseless, but we'll take dependable curries and fluffy, onion-dense curried fried rice over logic any day.
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 54A, 80, X80

column7: This family-run Indianapolis minichain specializes in N'Awlins-style food served up quicker than a Bourbon Street bra disappears for beads. Step up to the counter and place a "half-and-half" order for the signature chili-cheese étouffée and the chicken-sausage jambalaya, or go easy with a bowl of dark roux-based gumbo studded with shrimp, crawfish and okra.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: After a brief opening last August, this customized ice-cream shop has fixed some technical difficulties and is giving it another shot. Select a base, type of sweetener and mix-ins, then watch as the concoction is flash-frozen via liquid nitrogen. Standbys like berry sorbet or seasonal specials like apple cider attain surprisingly creamy consistency, and hot pudding (in as nutso a combination and fluorescent color as your heart desires) on a cool night is never a bad thing, but novelty only goes so far. The end results suffer from the same shortcomings: pallid, artificial-tasting flavors that'll leave you jonesing for an old-fashioned scoop of Ben & Jerry's.

Every sushi joint has a niche—slick digs and bass-heavy beats, pristine fish and a serene, whisper-required setting. This family-run eatery excels at maki and small plates of traditional Japanese cooked dishes. Of the latter, vegetarians are well fed with a teriyaki-sauced grilled tofu steak and steamed spinach in bonito soy sauce, while the best of the rest includes broiled salmon collar (request lemon for added brightness), panko-encrusted shrimp with katsu sauce and pan-fried pork dumplings. Supplement with an order of Caribbean Secret maki; the textural contrast and flavor combo of yellowtail, gourd, masago, mayo, asparagus and tempura crumbs will make you a regular at this little gem.

The Boston-based Loop lunch spot feels like a chain, but the handful of vegetarian items and a skew toward healthy eating help set it apart from your average fast-food grill. Burgers are fine, but too lean to be delicious (yes, we know that's the point of the place, but still). So go with stuff that's supposed to taste healthy instead: "Tofusion" brown-rice bowls get a good dose of veggies and a ginger-soy glaze, flavorful baked falafel is slathered in red pepper hummus and wrapped in a whole-wheat tortilla, and turkey on whole-grain bread conjures November with its cranberry chutney. Still need midday grease? The baked "UnFries" are mighty good.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

column7: Marcus Samuelsson of C-House joins Macy's Seven on State gourmet food court, bringing all-natural, grass-fed Black Angus burgers to the table. Frozen custard gets spun into milkshakes, while chicken, turkey, fish and portobello sandwiches round out the short-and-sweet menu.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: This may be the newest venue in which Washburne Culinary Institute students can hone their skills, but it doesn't look, feel or taste like a student project. Just as the slick, contemporary dining room is accented with African touches, so too is the menu: A nuanced African ambrosia salad has mango, red onion and yams; black-eyed-pea fritters arrive with a fiery red pepper sauce; and cornmeal pie has sticky, addictive caramel notes. There's plenty for those not interested in African food, too, like a juicy (if mild) jerk chicken, and grits that are so decadently infused with butter and cheese that you'll almost ignore the shrimp scattered over them.

We walked into this tamale shop and saw a woman sitting at a table, sorting through a big pile of corn kernels. But that was just the first sign that the masa here was freshly prepared. The rustic, corn-husk-wrapped tamales have the texture of being just-ground, and when stuffed with the right fillings (read: the spicy pork or the chicken) they make for a hearty, intricately flavored meal.
