(Note: If you go for the jalapeño, be warned that the heat is so intense, you'll want to order a glass of horchata for each tamale.) Some flavors, like the pineapple, can fall flat; still, at six tamales for $6, we're not complaining.
column144: El: Red to Morse. Bus: 22, 96 Lunt

column7: Unlike most of its steam-table-toting peers, this Filipino spot doesn't offer gloopy meats in skinned-over gravy. Instead, tender pancit noodles sautéed with golden chicken, garlicky lumpia Shanghai rolls and mixed adobo chicken and pork in silky vinegar-tinged gravy are dished out fresh. The tocino, a magnificent mountain of neon-orange pork lacquered with a smoky-sweet glaze, may be the best in town.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 49, X49, 81

column7: Seafood is the thing at this upscale national chain where about 30 different fresh catches come in countless preparations.
column8: Good for groupsOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Fireplace

column7: Lettuce Entertain You expands its empire with a midscale seafood place in the western 'burbs. Fresh catches and signature dishes like lightly-breaded "Milanese"-style tilapia accompany hefty steaks and chops.
column8: Private party room(s)SuburbanOutdoor seating

column7: Tapas are supposed to simple, but the bites at this small-plates joint go one step further: They're easy. And that's not a good thing. The kitchen could stand to pay a lot more attention to the food it puts out. Because while the Spanish tortilla is hearty and the scallops are fine, the rest of the food is either over-seasoned, oddly-seasoned or under-seasoned—which leaves us under-impressed.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 29, 62, 129 (rush hrs).

column7: Since 2001, Laura Cid-Perea and Luis Perea have been churning out wedding and specialty cakes, plus individual-sized pastries (the tres leches are wildly popular and come in as many as seven flavors). A fire in summer 2008 destroyed Bombon's original 18th Street storefront, but Cid-Perea is still dishing out all of her signature pastries here and at Cake Gallery (1236 W 18th St, 312-733-9790). The couple also operates a pretty, sit-down café on the Near West Side, so you're pretty much covered whenever that sugar craving hits.

Take a glance at the dry-erase board you'll pass on your way into this spic-and-span, family-run soul-food spot—it lists all of the day's specials you'll be recounting later to friends and eating for leftovers the next day. Though the giant smoker may not be fuming while you're there, rest assured it sees some action, and the tender, if mild, jerk chicken and sauce-slathered rib tips that come out of it are mighty tasty. Ham-studded greens in plenty of potlikker are among the best in town, and a carryout wing deal for three bucks beats the pants off those extra-value meals this area's littered with.

You'd think a dish called the "Urbanbelly ramen" would be this noodle bar's signature item. But as satisfying as that bowl of clove-kissed broth and pork belly is, the best noodle dish here is the rice-cake noodles. The chewy, mini-Frisbee-shaped noodles are topped with a juicy, perfectly fried chicken breast and bits of mango, which help cool the fiery, chile-spiked broth. Like the rich lamb-and-brandy dumplings, it's the kind of dish you'll want to take your time with. But the crowds vying for your seat dictate that you eat your food fast and jet, so savor the food quickly or get it to go.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Critics' Pick: The Best Way to Use Your Noodle Award (chef Bill Kim's choice to leave Le Lan and open Urban Belly)

column7: As far as culinary queues go, the one that snakes up from this basement-level restaurant and out onto the street is rivaled only by Hot Doug's. But thanks to military-like precision from the kitchen, this line moves much faster. Good thing: It means you're only minutes away from fabulous tortilla wraps like the Fresno, featuring tender asparagus, juicy roast turkey and creamy Muenster, or the sweet-and-savory Key West that tops mesquite-grilled spiced chicken breast with pineapple and fiery pico de gallo.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendlyOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake

column7: Located right under the Thorndale Red Line station, this place would seem like a natural spot for locals to stop in for a muffin and some coffee. And you can do that, if you want to. (Though be warned: The muffin selection is limited.) But to get the most of a visit here, you'll want to focus on its specialty: Chinese baked buns. The golden dough is shaped around luscious barbecue pork and chicken, or sometimes twisted with layers of sweet, red bean paste inside. After one of those, muffins will no longer be on your mind.

The best of what this shop offers is Moroccan specialties like juicy, housemade merguez sausages, tender lamb kebabs and sides like the peppery tomato-and-green-pepper taktouka, and the equally delicious eggplant-based zaalouk.
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park/Pulaski. Bus: 53, 80, X80

column7: Diners who groaned about the modern interpretations of Indian food at a certain West Loop restaurant across the street from Jaipur will be happy to find this straightforward bearer of standards. But vets of Devon will likely put this newcomer in the "tablecloth" category of Viceroy and Tiffin, meaning you'll really have to push to get sufficient heat and the cream-laden gravies all fall into a similar flavor profile. Still, the mixed grill of tandoor-cooked shrimp, chicken and minced lamb kebabs is satisfying; coupled with delicious garlic nan and a cold beer it's a good substitute for Loopers looking to stay close to home.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Look at the main pastry case in this bakery and it quickly becomes clear that chef Abner Rarang is one of these dessert guys who sees his work as art. His cakes are gorgeously designed (many of them are topped with ribbons of chocolate that take on the appearance of silk sheets), suggesting the precision and dedication of a surgeon. But in his other pastry case he keeps the simpler stuff: Blueberry muffins (not overly sweet, and with a soft, fine crumb), oversized double-chocolate-walnut cookies, a delicious oatmeal bar that gives off the (false) impression of being somewhat healthy and empanadas (flaky and servicable, but not as great as the sweet stuff).

If the quintessential Chicago food is Italian beef, the quintessential foodie tip would be a great unknown beef stand. Chickie's has a fervent following in its slice of Little Village, but deserves to be talked up citywide. It has it all: loads of divey stand-and-eat-it-with-guys-in-hardhats atmosphere; a beefy, herb-rich gravy; a unique housemade giardinera that mixes paper-thin celery slices with jalapeños; and a fistful of excellent fresh-cut fries with every sandwich. Try it, then let people think you've known about it all along.

With a new out-of-town hamburger chain popping up in Chicago seemingly every week, it's worth saluting this homegrown Lakeview stand. It's been serving rock-solid char-grilled burgers and dogs, along with fresh-cut fries and thick chocolate shakes, to everyone from city workers to stroller moms for two decades. When we're in the mood for a burger that's not so huge it will kill us, this is where we go (but don't forget the gooey Wisconsin cheddar). And when we're not in that mood we get the Rooster (grilled chicken sandwich), which is about as good an argument for white meat as any we know.

This fish is so nice that they named it twice. Well, okay, it's certainly not the best sushi restaurant in town, but for a no-frills, easy-on-the-wallet option for fresh fish, this simple spot hits the mark. Counter service might scare purists off, but you'll be pleasantly surprised when you pick up your tray of artfully presented maki (go for the spicy Mexican roll of hamachi, cilantro and jalapeños, and the tropical roll filled with shrimp tempura, eel, cucumber, avocado and mango puree). Lunchtime maki meal deals (two rolls, miso soup and salad for about $9) are a big hit with Northwestern students, as are the sweet and colorful bubble teas.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingGood for dining at bar

column7: If the mark of a good Jewish deli is the schmaltz, Ada's is in good shape: Circles of oil glimmer on the top of the matzo-ball soup, and the peppery hot pastrami is rich with soft fat. And it gets even better: Latkes, appropriately greasy yet crisp, can be substituted for rye in the pastrami sandwich (a worthy option if your health can handle it). Plus, it has decent bagels for schmearing thick layers of cream cheese. The only area that's not so schmaltzy? The service, which, in a rejection of true deli culture, is downright sweet.
column144: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison

column7: Like a sci-fi flick or fantasy novel, the Meatloaf Bakery requires a certain suspension of disbelief. In this alternate universe, pastry cases beckon with massive "cakes" of ground meats draped in delicately piped mashed-potato "frosting." "A Wing and a Prayer" cupcakes—juicy ground chicken oozing mild blue cheese—should qualify as a ritual, and no dinner party could be complete without a dozen bite-sized "Loafitos Del Fuego": olive-flecked pastry shells encasing chorizo. But the "Burger" loaf's greasy beef patty opens the bad-meatloaf-memory floodgates of American lore, and not even dainty puff pastry can convince us that salmon should meet its end in a fishy meatloaf. These hunks of meat are far superior hot, so prepare to spend 20 minutes waiting, or let carryout make you into a believer.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 22, 36, 74

column7: The menu at this Oak Park newbie is the opposite of ambitious—it's full of clichés like mango shrimp, fried artichokes and goat cheese–marinara dips. But chef Jody Andre seems to know what kind of food people want. Not what they may think they want, but what they crave deep down when the trend police have their heads turned. Those fried artichokes turn out to have an ethereal quality, mussels arrive in an addictive, garlicky sauce, and crab cakes sport a crisp exterior and a warm, creamy middle. It's not all perfect, of course. But if you end with the impeccable goat cheese cheesecake, any mishaps will be quickly forgotten.
column144: El: Blue to Austin. Pace bus: 311, 315, 320

column7: There's an entire bird in this Korean restaurant's signature ginseng-chicken soup, and it sits in a wildly bubbling broth that's subtly enriched with ginseng. In Korea, this stuff is served in the summer (the theory being that eating hot foods instills higher tolerance for hot weather, replenishing nutrients lost by sweating), but this is a quintessential winter soup, too—not aggressive in flavor but in comfort. For something a little stronger, try the spicy tofu stew, which proves that when served soft and warm and swimming in chile broth, tofu can be just as comforting as chicken.

City-dwelling burger fiends rejoice: The wildly popular Virginia-based burger chain has followed up its Oak Park location with a Lincoln Park outpost. The hand-formed burgers and fresh-cut fries counter the painful combo of office-bright lighting, stark white-and-red decor and kitschy sacks of potatoes scattered about. Burgers are juicy, double-patty affairs that can be ordered with all manner of gratis toppings (grilled 'shrooms and onions, A-1 sauce, even jalapeños). Perfectly crispy fries come piping hot in their own paper bag, regular or Cajun-style (just a sprinkling of Old Bay). The price for all this freshness: You'll wait longer than you will at Mickey D's, but you'll eat better.

So the subterranean dining room is jarringly large, the staff generally outnumbers the patrons, and the "mulligatawny" soup is chicken broth while the tomato smacks of Campbell's. Chalk up the few oddities to Gaylord being the only Indian spot sandwiched between boutiques that sell ostrich-feathered boots, and opt to take advantage of the impressive lunch buffet. DIY chaat by smothering samosas in raita, chutneys, chickpeas and crunchy sev, then move on to flavorful yellow lentils, stewed cumin-spiced cabbage and tender chicken in buttery makhani sauce. Save room for fluffy rose-scented pillows of sweet ras malai.

This sibling of Highwood's Curry Hut has a leg up on typical tikka masala spots with a few lesser-known Nepalese specialties, so go for the dishes that truly stand out. The Bhojan (a thali-style sampler platter) is a nice assortment of flavors, and the momo dumplings are tasty, but save room for the chhoela, slices of chilled, tandoor-cooked goat tossed in a bracing salad of raw onion, garlic and ginger slivers, and the kukhura ko pakheta, chicken wings marinated overnight in the Nepalese holy trinity (ginger, garlic and cumin) then cooked in the tandoor for crispy skin and juicy meat.

This second location for River North's midscale Indian stalwart sports an identical menu to the original, with a focus on meats and breads from the tandoor and classics from samosas to soupy rice pudding.
column144: El: Green to Oak Park. Bus: N20, 309, 311, 313

column7: This Lincoln Park location of the family-owned restaurant chain offers mexican/tex mex food and the gang's all here. From mini fajitas to enchiladas to carne asada, Lalo's dishes out large and smothered portions. And if you still have room, try the mango fruit tacos for dessert.

This simple Vietnamese spot is a bit of a hike past the Saigon Stretch of Argyle Street, but sweet hospitality coupled with a handful of standout dishes make for a stop worth the gas. Use the accompanying lettuce leaves and fresh herbs to make wraps of eggy fritters of crispy shrimp and sweet-potato sticks, then give the whole thing a generous dunk in garlicky fish sauce. Fans of papaya salad should try the excellent version topped with thin strips of marinated grilled beef, while poultry lovers will devour the crackly skinned quail and its bed of juice-soaked watercress. One caveat: The pho is a tad sweet, so doctor it with plenty of lime juice and chile paste for balance.

Of all the tacos this new Rogers Park Mexican spot offers, the slightly sweet, slightly peppery pastor version is the best. The creamy refried beans make a good taco, and the steak taco isn't bad either. Chicken needs some help, though: When it's piled onto a torta, you'll need a big douse of salsa before things get interesting, and the chicken-stuffed tamales are crumbly and dry. But where this place really excels is not the food but the hospitality: The service is attentive, kind and gracious. And that, more than anything, is what sets this taqueria apart from the rest.

The stage is literally set for this Middle Eastern restaurant to become a vivacious nightclub in the wee hours: Tables are arranged around a small dance floor, and instruments for a full band (drum set, etc.) are on display. Yet the food is no afterthought. Care is obviously taken with the meze, which includes a piquant eggplant salad, herbaceous tabouli and golden cheese borek. Entrées like the chilifried (a spicy lamb stew) and the grilled quail are slightly less successful. But don't worry: If you don't feel like singing the food's praises, one of the band members soon will.

Just because "cake" is in the name, that doesn't tie this new shop down to just classics—look for fresh fruit–packed breakfast cupcakes and dollar frosting shots in flavors like milk-chocolate buttercream, strawberry cream-cheese and chocolate toffee.

Everything about this place seems like a good idea: The riverside location (admittedly more attractive in the summer than the winter), the five choices of burgers (salmon, tuna, turkey, beef or veggie), the long list of toppings for those burgers (guacamole, cheddar-bacon sauce), even the drinks program, which boasts some decent beers and artisanal sodas. Where the place falters is in some of its execution. While the turkey burger is moist and the onion rings perfect, the beef can be gristly and tough and the veggie burger mushy. Whether the milk shakes and malts can help you forget these missteps depends on if you like Wendy's Frosty—if you do, you'll leave happy.

True, this restaurant in the Omni Hotel might appeal more to tourists than locals, but that doesn't mean you have to be from Pittsburgh to enjoy a window seat overlooking the Mag Mile madness, a glass of wine and enough surprisingly good snacks to build a meal out of. Comfort-classic entrées are fine, but the "tastes" and "sharables" suit us better—a charcuterie plate of speck, prosciutto, Morbier and Brie; a nugget of crispy-edged pork belly with pear slaw; seared foie in golden raisin pesto; and a sea salt cone of o-toro tuna dolloped with avocado mousse. Just skip the sticky-sweet martinis; get your sugar hit from the classic cheesecake instead.
column8: ViewsGood for dining at bar

column7: The sibling location of Theo Gilbert's Italian spot is almost identical to the original, with two exceptions: This one has a wine list and a lot less seating. That latter point could become a problem when people start realizing that this place serves addictive antipasto (rich, crispy-edged polenta) and pastas (pasta neri, black with briny cuttlefish ink; buttery "pope's hats" stuffed with sweet squash). As at the original, the menu here changes seasonally, but is reliably tasty year-round.

Quick thinking is the key to success at this classic cafeteria: Once the line reaches the counter, you have only a few seconds to place your order, pick a side, order a drink and pay. For breakfast, we like the generous stack of French toast with a side of poached eggs (which, unlike other, more popular items here, are usually cooked to order). For lunch, it's the baked chicken, which comes with forgettable stuffing but is so sumptuous that the meat falls off the bone. At either meal there's the question of whether to eat the sweet, cakey biscuits with your meal or save them for dessert; either way, make your choice the first time around. Otherwise, it's back to the line.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendly
column144: Bus: 6, 28, 55, X55, 171. Metra: Electric Main to 55th-56th-57th

column7: The problem: A café as lovely and sunny as this—and with coffee this good—inspires lingering. But lingering requires cup upon cup of caffeine, and that could become hazardous. This European export has a solution for all that, though: a full menu of food, most of it the unlikeliest coffeehouse food you've come across. Braised lamb is served with golden, toothsome spaetzle; hearty sausages arrive with soft dumplings; and smooth, savory pork rillettes come with crusty bread for spreading. At the end of the meal, a slice of impeccable opera cake is a necessity. And with it, yet another cup of coffee.

In a world of plastic-meat sub chains, this North Side spot stands out, beloved by generations of Northwestern and Loyola students. The sandwiches on toasted bread with the vinegary "special sauce" are, if not wildly creative, hearty and filling across the board (though beware that the meatball sub, perversely, uses a sweet barbecue sauce rather than marinara). And Mrs. Nemo (there was a Mrs. Nemo?) turns out similarly filling made-from-scratch soups—a bowl of her split pea or minestrone is just the thing on a Chicago winter's day.
column144: El: Red to Jarvis. Bus: 22, 96, Pace 290

column7: Tucked discretely behind Lizard's Liquid Lounge, this unmarked carry-out-only joint no bigger than a large walk-in closet serves both made-to-order and frozen comfort foods. Pre-made meals for two like chicken pot pie and beef stroganoff are reasonably priced and easy enough to toss into the oven, but underneath the pot pie's flaky crust was a bland, liquidy disappointment, and the stroganoff was flavorless. The freshly made dishes—like light, creamy hummus; spicy lime-doused srirachia wings; and fresh-cut fries dusted with rosemary—fare much better, and although there's nowhere inside Your Kitchen to sit, it doesn't take a genius to figure out where to pass the wait.

Bruno Abate, the dapper proprietor of Fulton Market's Follia, is at it again. This time, he's brought his game to Wicker Park with a dining room that could be an Alessi showroom, an affordable wine list and a menu of housemade pastas and wood-fired pizzas that tops out at 20 bucks. While we can't recommend blowing much on main courses, we are partial to the pizzas, with consistently delicious thin crusts and toppings like silky prosciutto and fresh mozz.
column8: Outdoor seatingGood for groupsGood for dining at barVegetarian-friendly

column7: Out goes one Thai spot, in goes another. This newcomer giving the former Sai Mai space a shot keeps things similarly simple, with your basic noodle dishes, curries, soups and apps like papaya salad and chicken satay.
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 52 California, 74

column7: How is it that the McKinley Parkers sipping coffee and plowing into omelets at this new café appear as if they've been coming here for years? It might have a little something to do with Erika Gutierrez, the coffee shop's bubbly co-owner, who welcomes brunch-seekers into the counter-service spot as if it were her home kitchen. Or maybe it's the expertly toasted panini (the Philly cheese-steak version tastes better than it sounds), weekday dinner specials like fried chicken or warm fruit cobbler. It's straightforward (and sometimes, in the case the cobbler, bland) coffeehouse fare, but it's served with enough kindness to turn even a cross-town visitor into a regular.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyPrivate party room(s)Kid-friendly

column7: A torrential downpour couldn't take the sunniness out of this Pilsen café, which is covered in bright purple, yellow and orange paint inside and out. What does it have to be so cheery about? Well, first of all, it's one of the city's most successful purveyors of corn and flour tortillas. And, as they show at this café, employees clearly know how to put those tortillas to good use: piling them with tender chicken legs submerged in mole rojo, or sumptuous, slow-cooked beef in a rich tomato sauce. Satisfying tamales are available for a more portable meal—but keep in mind that you can't take the sunniness with you.
column198: Other locations: 3050 W 26th St (773-579-6120); 1434 W Belmont (773-975-2348)

column7: Sitting humbly on a quiet corner, this is a restaurant you've probably passed by a hundred times without noticing. The Northwest Siders who have been coming here their entire lives would probably thank you for that. Otherwise, there might be a wait for this homey, Italian-American food, like the mushrooms simmering in piquant pesto or the slightly-out-of-place-but-still-delicious chicken soup. Pizzas here are thin and crackery and cut into squares; it's not the best example of this style of pie, but it works—especially if you follow it with the impeccable cannoli.

At the corner of a quiet street dotted with an old-fashioned barber shop and bakery is this family-run home of serviceable pasta and pizzas. Gnocchi might be made in-house, but a better choice is spaghetti tossed in a red sauce with tiny clams and mussels, sweet scallops, squid and shrimp. Locals keep the takeout and delivery business busy, ordering crispy, thin-crust pizzas like the signature Nonna's pie, dotted with sausage and onions and heavy on the green pepper. During summer, gelato comes fresh from a storefront Nonna's operates a few doors down, since clearly the quaint neighborhood wouldn't be complete without an ice-cream parlor.
column8: Good for groupsKid-friendlyOutdoor seatingSuburbanVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Blue to Cumberland. Bus: 88, Pace 209, Pace 241

column7: Mornings at Meli appear to be the epitome of a picture-perfect breakfast: Fresh juices are made to order; omelets are fluffy and made from Phil's "cage free" eggs; "Meli toast," the signature French toast, is drizzled with honey; and (slightly thin) marmalades are made in-house. It's not revolutionary food, but it's solid, and so long as you skip the disappointing soups and sandwiches served during lunch, you may just have yourself a new place to call second home.

Have your history with a side of latte now that the Chicago History Museum has opened this café. Julius Meinl rules the espresso drink list, but the rest of the menu is an ode to Chicago, including a classic red hot, Sweet Baby Ray's barbecue chicken sandwich, a "Little Village" Mexican omelet and Blommer's chocolate-chip cookies.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 22, 36, 72, 156

column7: For quick-serve Indian in the Loop, this place is tough to beat. Only thing is, that might be because it's the only quick-serve Indian in the Loop. Still, when cravings hit, Joe's does the trick. Samosas are dependable and fairly greaseless (they're baked, not fried), and their traditional chutneys add worlds of flavor. For a combo platter, the best bet is to go with rice flanked by either the tender lamb rogan josh or the chicken tikka masala, plus the paneer cheese swimming in spinach. Just skip the blah beef, doughy nan and chickpeas that are a dead ringer for the packaged heat-and-serve meals.
Hidden away on the second floor of a health-food store, veg-head Loop workers slip into this counter-service cafe for soups, salads and rotating specials like curries with tofu or seitan.
column144: El: Brown, Green to Adams/Wabash; Red, Blue to Jackson. Bus: 1, 7, 126

column7: If you're going down Western Avenue and happen to blink, you'll miss this lunchtime spot that resembles an abandoned shack. If you do muster up the courage to saunter through the front door, you'll feel like you've stepped into a Mississippi short-order grill. The assembly line of cooks whips up mile-high, shaved-to-order corned beef sandwiches, moist meatloaf between soft white bread (Tue, Thu, Sat, Sun only), and breakfast hangover cures like buttery flapjacks, big bowls of grits and griddled ham with fried eggs.
column144: El: Blue to Western (Forest Park). Bus: 20, 49, X49

column7: It takes some time to fall for this French-African spot—luckily, you'll have plenty of time while you wait for your meal. A platter of delicate meat patties and sweet, ripe plantains can take so long to arrive that you'll be ready to eat your place mat. But it doesn't matter how long it takes for the earthy, spinachish cassava-leaf stew or the sweet-and-just-barely-spicy fish with onion sauce to arrive. Because when they do, you'll find flavors so complex that they demanded savoring—and soon you'll be the one who's taking it slow.

Don't pay too much attention to the menus here; there's little that ink on paper can do to convey the depth of flavor brimming in this food. The word nem doesn't hint that the eggroll-like appetizer is stuffed with a savory, peppery blend of shrimp and chicken, and the words beef patty don't come close to describing the homey comfort these housemade pies hide. Debbé doesn't sum up how tender the lamb is or how piquant its tomato-and-pepper sauce is. And while firire is described as "fried fish," that description says nothing about how crispy the tilapia's skin is—or about the flakiness of the flesh underneath it.

Don't be misled by the location: Finkel's has nothing to do with Kendall College (even though it's on the first floor of the cooking school's building). And don't be fooled by the name, either—this Finkel's has nothing to do with the legendary Finkl's that used to be in the Loop. Nevertheless, it's doing its best to hold up the classic deli traditions. The food is hit and miss: The pastrami is warm and nicely fatty, but the egg salad needs salt. On the other hand, the authentic, sweet-and-salty deli service is something it's gotten just right.

If Colombian restaurants are only as good as the music they play (and if you ask the owner of one, that's what he or she will tell you), this corner spot has a chance at greatness: Expert guitar stylings come from either the flat-screen in the front dining room or, on Fridays and Saturdays, from a live band in the back. Empanadas filled with tender steak make a good nosh for watching the band (especially if you put some chimichurri on them), and so does the sobrebarriga a la criolla, which is more of that grilled steak flanked by sweet plantains. But the picada grande, a platter of deep-fried ribs, fried sausage, fried beef and fried yucca? Let's just say it's a little discordant.

John Winslow (formerly general manager at Blue Plate Catering) is behind this all-day café, which serves a little bit of everything, including egg sandwiches for breakfast, panini for lunch and an eclectic lineup of dishes ranging from gnocchi to bouillabaisse for dinner. Lines snake out the door and onto the sidewalk during brunch hours, but we think the real treasures here are the dinner dishes, like the crispy fish-and-chips and the hearty shepherd's pie—not the least bit because many of them hover around $10.

"Clean yet complex" sums up this Argyle spot's namesake soup, which bears a hint of the sweet star-anise flavor others tend to overload on but relies mainly on subtle beefiness and silky fresh noodles. Those same noodles serve dozens of other dishes almost as well, but our two favorites don't include them. The banh mi thit nguoi nails perfectly crusty bread, salty ham, a slather of earthy pâté, plus crunchy daikon, carrots and sliced chiles. And the massive lotus root salad is the best around, with plump, fresh shrimp, plenty of crunchy peanuts and enough tangy, herb-flecked dressing to spoon some onto your banh mi for extra flavor.

Though it was franchised at the turn of the millennium, this location of Al's is the oldest (having opened in 1938), and the only direct descendant of the original (a wooden stand at Laflin and Harrison). These days, you'll find Italian beefs all over town, but there's something about eating one at this surviving piece of Little Italy. A six-inch bun piled with tender, thinly sliced beef is only better as a "combo" (topped with char-grilled sausage), "dipped" in beef jus and finished with hot giardiniera. Skin-on fries smothered with cheese are required eating for a meal lingering locals would be proud of.

There's not a whole lot to look at in this sparse dining room, but here's one thing worth noting: the raw kebabs, rife with fresh herbs and black pepper, sitting in the refrigerated case below the cash register. It's the freshness of these kebabs (particularly the juicy chicken), placed on the charcoal grill to order, that makes this place stand out from other Middle Eastern spots in town. (The perfectly seasoned beef shawarma, the bright and smoky baba ghanoush and the hearty, complimentary potato soup don't hurt, either.)

Being just steps from the Orange Line has given this tiny takeout joint an instant following—so much of a following, actually, that the few tables in the place are consistently packed with people shoveling hot eggplant Parmesan into their mouths while they watch the local news. The cheesy arancini are one of the restaurant's best bets; the panini, stuffed with fresh mozzarella and thin prosciutto, are a close second. And though this may not be the best red-sauce food you've ever had, the cannolis are filled to order, making for an ending that's pretty hard to argue with.

With its cartoon sandwich-with-eyes mascot, this attractive Cuban café looks as if it aspires to be a chain—but happily, the food tastes more of a grandma's kitchen than a marketing department. The Cuban sandwich is built on a hearty foundation of moist and flavorful roasted pork, and other sandwich classics like ropa vieja (shredded beef in a tomatoey sauce) and media noche (ham, pork and cheese on sweet bread) are also solidly pleasing renditions. Soul-warming black beans are a particular standout, and for an exotic touch, try a shake in tropical fruit flavors like mamey and guanabana.
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 54, X54, 74

column7: For anybody within a ten-block radius, Palette is perhaps the perfect spot. The charming room has huge windows and lots of local art, the cured salmon is right on point, and the service is usually chipper and relaxed—just as a neighborhood joint should be. But if the food alone is what you're coming here for, take care: Much of it (an overly sweet lasagna; slightly sandy scallops) is too boring to keep your interest. The good news: Whether you live in the neighborhood or not, the sumptuous short ribs will never let you down.

Never has a name so aptly summed up a business. Positioned in the front half of My Gourmet Kitchen, this little sandwich counter does five things, and all of them are Vietnamese-style banh mi. All come on crusty French bread and all come with the standard dress. Where they differ are in the fillings, and for our money, we prefer the tender chicken in gingery caramel and the "char siu" pork, equally tender but with a touch of garlic and hoisin. A few quibbles aside (carrot-daikon relish could be tangier, the pâté lacks oomph, the bread gets soggy from steaming in the foil wrap), it's a cute idea and a good snack at four bucks.
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 49, X49, 50, 72

column7: The luxe red and gold interior of this far-flung Polish café and bar belies the homey welcome it offers, but together they make for an unusually pleasant place to while away a few hours with friends. The must-have on the menu is zurek, a tart rye flour–based soup teeming with sausage and hard-boiled eggs—pure winter warmth in a bowl. Main courses are as hearty as you'd expect, with the standouts including the "Russian" (potato and tangy cheese) pierogi and a weekly special of beef stroganoff, a winey stew accompanied by housemade dumplings as fluffy as any gnocchi in town. In summer, there's a boat-shaped beer garden on the side.
column144: El: Blue to Harlem. Bus: 80, 90, Pace 326

column7: There are grills on a couple of tables here, but this isn't a place you come to for Korean barbecue. Not that the bulgogi isn't any good—it is (if a little more subdued than other places nearby). But here you'll do better to stick with the stews, like a spicy tofu and seafood variation rife with silky tofu, hard-boiled eggs, baby squid and an irresistible, throat-tickling spice. Supplement it with a seafood pancake (as thick and crusty as deep-dish pizza) and the exceptional banchan, little bowls of sweet seaweed, refreshing pickles and seasoned mung beans that will have you grazing long after your entrée is gone.

Indian sweets are an acquired taste, and this is a great shop to acquire some. It's easy to make a meal out of the chaat—fried street snacks like pani puri (crispy, hollow puffs for scooping up masala-spiced chickpeas) and bhel puri (a spicy, cereal-like snack mix drizzled with chutneys). Just save room for the technicolor desserts—most of which are variations on condensed milk and sugar. Choose from doughnut-like gulab jamun topped with ras malai (cream-soaked paneer), mango-flavored barfi and syrupy, baklava-like confections layered with pistachios. Surprisingly, the chai gets left unsweetened, so get some to counter those cavities.
column198: Other location: 1016 Golf Road, Hoffman Estates (847-490-4400)

column7: This new Logan café got a lot of preopening hype because its chef cooked at Ambria, but that should be banished from memory, if for nothing else but to keep potential diners from making comparisons. There are none. But for what Bella is—a little neighborhood spot with simple sandwiches and a couple of slightly more ambitious options—it succeeds. The incredibly affordable menu is as eclectic as the art collection, ranging from hummus (fine) to fruit-spiked guac (tasty) to hand-formed burgers (surprisingly well-seasoned and well-executed at a juicy medium-rare). One hope is that the owner ditches the weekday counter-service/weekend table-service switcheroo; it's not only confusing for diners, it sucks for servers' wallets.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82

column7: The attraction of the original Perry's on Franklin Street is that it's a bit of a mess: Random signs and posters litter the walls, the floor is worn from the constant foot traffic, and the counter guys don't have the time—or inclination—to make nice. This new University Village location doesn't have any of that. In fact, at first it feels like an imitation gone wrong: LEYE does Perry's. But this joint's lack of soul dissipates on the first bite of its warm pastrami, sliced thick, ribboned with buttery fat, and so delicious that the joint's grittiness—or lack thereof—will be the last thing on your mind.

Spending your night comparing the pan-Asian eats at this new hot-stuff megarestaurant from the Rockit Ranch crew to your favorite dumplings in Chinatown will leave you feeling salty and ripped off. So don't. Instead, go with an open mind, enjoy the people-watching, and opt for the creative signatures of the house: crispy rice nigiri topped with spicy tuna, strip steak formed into "lollipops" around lemongrass skewers, and a salad of salty, crispy-skinned duck meat. Stop by for the recently launched Sunda Social, an after-work cocktail hour (Mon–Fri 5–7pm) where flights of sake are paired with sushi, and appetizers (like the shrimp toasts with spicy tuna jam) are half-price.
column8: Late-night diningPrivate party room(s)FireplaceOutdoor seatingGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 65, 156

column7: We could tell you about Veronica and Betty Romo, the two sweet sisters who make this simple BYOB café feel warm and welcoming. Or we could recommend something from the array of tapas—we'd go with juicy dates wrapped in crispy bacon rather than the boring potatoes in marinara sauce. But we need all our energy to focus on the Gaudi Fest burger: a hunk of juicy, perfectly medium-rare, nicely seasoned ground beef, smothered in a housemade barbecue sauce, piled with thick cuts of bacon, charred onions and a mound of shredded cheddar. Because, really, that's all you need to know about.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 65

column7: In almost every way imaginable—the laminated picture menus, for instance—Pintxos feels not so much like an authentic Basque restaurant as it does a restaurant in Basque country geared toward tourists. The one exception to this? The prices. Individual pintxos (the Basque version of small plates, usually made up of roasted meats on skewers) never surpass the two-dollar mark; puffy, open-faced Spanish tortillas (egg-and-potato cakes) overflow with generous handfuls of fillings for $8; so do big plates of garlic-roasted drumsticks. But much of this food lacks flavor, so ultimately it doesn't matter how much the food costs; if it's bland, it's still a waste of money.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

column7: It's a coffee shop with vegan tendencies, but de.li.cious doesn't have that kumbaya vibe of spots such as Heartland Café. Instead, it appears to be just another coffee shop. The vegan breakfast sandwich (tofu, vegan sausage, soy cheddar) will never pass for what it tries to emulate, but it's a respectable (and filling) attempt; the vegan muffins do a better job of standing in for the real thing. But at the end of the day, it's not the food you'll come here for: It's the Chemex coffee, brewed so smooth and silky it's well worth the eight-minute wait to get it.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, X80

column7: Specials abound at this United Center area veteran: Mix and match buckets of beer are always $16, but pitchers are $6 on Tuesdays, domestic bottles are $2.75 on Wednesdays and a wing buffet is gratis on Fridays from 4 to 8pm. A shuttle to games is a draw during season, while the patio and sand volleyball court out back come calling once the sun's out.
column144: El: Blue to Damen/Paulina. Bus: 9, X9, 126

column7: Who knew Gold Coast residents would be so excited about fish sticks and burgers? But, oh, how they are: They've wasted no time crowding the bar at this new location of Bucktown's pubby stalwart. The wine list is still as on par as it was when the joint was Cru, so there are good bottles to be had. Only now you can pair them with comfort-food like those crispy cornmeal-crusted catfish sticks; thin, charred pizzas topped with prosciutto; garlicky, truffly mushroom ravioli; and warm, cinnamon-laden apple crumble.
column8: Notable wine listPrivate party room(s)Outdoor seatingLate-night diningFireplace

column7: You know that small-town, blue-collar seafood spot that's part neighborhood bar, part nice night out, part "cater my cousin's wedding"? That's "the Pier," where chef-owner Peter McCarthy favors honest (sometimes nearly naked) preps of a dozen types of seafood. Lobster tails, crab legs, crispy perch, pan-seared arctic charÉall are served simply, with new potatoes, a green veg and a wedge of lemon. The straightforward approach goes a long way with the Sox-loving crowd of Jeff Park locals; come for Tuesday's $12 specials menu or Wednesday's and Thursday's $25 three-course, and you'll get caught up in the lure of the place, too.
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56A, 68, 85A

column7: The people at this rustic West Loop café have a lot of ideas for their tiny restaurant. Some of them, like ridiculously flavorful chicken thighs with gorgonzola polenta, are quite good. But for every successful comfort food dish pulled off (spicy lamb, lobster-enhanced brandade), there's a "creative" dish (potato chip–coated skate wing, tempura-fried sushi) that falls flat. This can create for a wildly fluctuating experience, but if you steer clear of the stabs at wackiness you should be okay.

The Pastoral vets behind this cozy BYOB know the secret to making a sandwich more than just a sandwich: sourcing. That's why they let a brunch plate of smoked salmon take its cues from creamy Zingerman's goat cheese, and why Mint Creek Farms lamb gets sliced onto a baguette, then dipped in a sweet jus. And now that burgers have been added to the menu on weekdays—including a turkey-burger with chipotle-sage aioli and a salmon burger with pickled ginger—we're beginning to consider the shaded back patio more as our personal backyard.

This original location of the Zacataco's mini chain has a surprisingly long menu for such a small place. But the smoke billowing from the roof making the whole neighborhood smell like sizzling steak tells you that the menu items that matter most are the carne asada tacos. Big, tender hunks of char-grilled steak are served up on steaming hot, freshly griddled tortillas—the combination is so satisfying that you won't want any more than simple onion, cilantro and lime to accompany them (though a pair of quite respectable red and green salsas is provided).
column8: Outdoor seatingKid-friendlyLate-night diningCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: It makes perfect sense that this Greek diner should be in U. of C. territory—the interior has that dark, woodsy look of a professor's office, and servers exhibit all the sensitivity and friendliness of disgruntled college cafeteria workers. For some, that's half of what makes this place so charming. The other half comes in the form of housemade soups, like the sprightly egg-lemon, the juicy burgers and—especially—the sandwich dubbed Nick's Delight, which crams not just gyro meat into a pita, but thin layers of roast beef as well.

Whether or not the guys behind Zentra and Sound-Bar would lump their new retro-futuristic contribution to Division's yuppification as a restaurant or a bar, the food (a dozen incarnations of flimsy thin-crusts, shareable apps like bruschetta and hummus) is clearly designed for the already drunk, so we'll gladly lump it into the latter category. A cafe by day, the space takes on a loungy feel at night thanks to thumping DJ beats and a largely (and from our experience, rightfully) ignored cocktail list hawking carbonated Red Bull martinis.
column8: Late-night diningGood for groupsOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendly

column7: Vilairat Junthong, a pillar in the local Thai community who has cooked or consulted for some of the best Thai spots in town (Sticky Rice, Spoon Thai, Amarit), is behind this new Berwyn spot. Skip the menu and ask for whatever's on the specials board—you'll be rewarded with the less-familiar, more-delicious specialties of northeastern Thailand. Recent specials includes garlicky, peppery fried chicken; two kinds of pork-rice sausage; a beef "waterfall salad" redolent with lime, mint and toasted rice powder; and hunks of crispy pork belly with Chinese broccoli in a clingy paste of red chiles, garlic and oyster sauce. Don't see what you want? Ask, and ye shall receive.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyBYOBSuburbanPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Blue to Austin/Lombard. Bus: 91, Pace 305, Pace 315

column7: Soup specials like a velvety Moroccan-spiced lentil are among a few reminders of this Loop lunch spot's former life as Spa Cafe. The original owner is still on board, but the new concept comes courtesy of Salad Spinners' Rich Levy, whose idea to cut Spa's food costs is to streamline the menu, ditch the organic/health angle and go retro comfort. Most of the nine sandwiches are tasty (brisket and whitefish are smoked in-house, and delicious because of it), but with minimal veggie toppings, many wind up as little more than meat and bread. Banana-bread pudding is a memorable closer, but judging by the sparse crowds, nine-to-fivers aren't looking to follow lunch with a nap.

If you can stomach the bro-tastic Houlihan's-esque decor (stained-glass lamps over booths, flat-screens at every turn, and sports-related photos that range from Anna Kournikova eating a banana to a female Packers fan donning a cheese bra), your next bite will reward you with capable pub grub. Wings and pizza are passable, but burgers and beer are the real draw. The beer list is lengthy and varied, and burgers arrive well-seasoned, juicy, creatively topped and on hands-down delicious pretzel buns. A trio of mini ostrich, boar and lamb burgers is both interesting and well executed—it's likely to be favored by adventurous drunks eating up the joint's 4am closing time Wednesday through Saturday.
column144: El: Purple (rush hrs), Red to Howard. Bus: 22, 147, 151

column7: The man behind Marche, Red Light, Gioco, Carnivale and Victor Hotel has Kleinerized the Italian trattoria into a larger-than-life funhouse stuffed with color and tchotchkes, but the real star attraction is chef Jim Kilberg's simple food. The guy has a knack for sourcing, evident best in the antipasti table's salumi selection, but also executes his own creations with ease: Greaseless veal milanese gets saba-drizzled arugula while tender seabass is plated with perfect rapini and a balanced anchovy broth. The gorgeous, landscaped patio is a draw in warm weather; the flaky fig tart with fior de latte gelato lures anytime.

The Joy Yee miniempire took root in Evanston back in 1993 and continues to pack in everyone from students to local office stiffs who loosen up with platter-size portions of pan-Asian food. We stop in for mussels with black-bean sauce, garlicky chicken with string beans and gargantuan bowls of udon-noodle soup. And it wouldn't seem right to leave without a pastel-colored bubble tea from the spot that claims to have introduced it to Chicagoland.

For most of you, this place isn't worth the hike. But for you Far North Siders out there, it's an oasis in your own backyard. This 60-year-old gem offers three-dozen beers (including La Fin du Monde, Delirium Tremens and Smithwicks), cracker-thin "Chicago bar–style" pizza and herb-flecked garlic fries that have quite the loyal local following. Our only hope is that someone fixes the schizo jukebox that's been playing Hall and Oates every other song.

Also known as the Family Inn, this self-serve pizza parlor has fed everyone and his mother - and grandmother - in the north burbs over the past forty years. The owners must know that it's nostalgia more than anything that keeps 'em comin' back, because they haven't changed a thing in the past four decades. They still offer baskets of Ritz crackers and cheese dip while you wait for your order, mugs of Green River, Black Cherry, and Filbert's Root Beer at the bar, and crispy cornmeal crust pizza topped with homemade sauce, fresh mozzarella, and - if you know what you're doing - Italian sausage at the counter.

This remodeled public library from nightlife vets Howard Natinsky (Fat Cat, Five Star) and Cary Michaels (formerly with Rockit Ranch Productions) is an immensely comfortable space, with a glass wall of doors that open onto the sidewalk and a skylit back room that lends an airy indoor-outdoor feel. Chef Bob Zrenner's food, however, feels less at peace with itself. Pub-grub fare like greaseless fried perch and calamari was the most successful, and a gamble on the grilled octopus appetizer paid off handsomely. But the rest of the menu (from the burger to the scallops to the lamb shank) disappoints, and the mass-market wine and beer list won't leave much to excite you, either.

If you don't mind waiting 15 minutes for what would otherwise be called "fast food," then a cheddar charburger served on a challah roll (or Bavarian rye at no extra charge) and three-layer fries smothered in Merkt's cheddar spread, sour cream, and bacon bits is as close to heaven as you can get in Des Plaines. Resist gluttony and stay away from the double, as the meat-to-bun ratio equates with a wad of wet paper towels sandwiched between two dainty cotton balls, leaving you with a mess euphemistically called "burger salad." The chocolate malt is divine, and the patio seating is paradise on a summer afternoon. Interested? Get in line.

It's bright and happy in this McKinley Park spot—there's even a portion of the dining room made up to look like a tropical living room. To keep that happy vibe going, though, you need to order correctly. That means maybe starting with a quesadilla, slathered with plenty of the fiery salsa verde on the table. And it may also mean starting with the tender octopus ceviche, too. But nothing is going to be as impressive as the grilled langostinos, dusted with smoky spices. They're a bitch to get out of their shells, but they're why you came here in the first place, so dig in.

The cozy, cushy, Byzantine-style dining room of Wicker Park's new Greek dim den is all owner David Schneider, but he gets help from former Scylla chef Jan Rickerl on the simple (and often simply delicious) seasonal Mediterranean food. Minimal ingredients are needed for a poof of housemade phyllo filled with leeks and flanked by goat feta or a whole loup de mar with crackly-crisp skin aside dandelion salad, but solid execution yields maximum flavors. Nice prices and a share-everything platform means more dough for sampling through the superb Greek wine list.
column8: Late-night diningOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyNotable wine list

column7: When it opened in 1951, Choo-Choo was a pioneer of "fast food," serving its Choo-Choo burgers, Dairy Cars and Train Cupcakes via model train. The barely changed diner has gone on to become a local favorite for kids and adults alike, though it hasn't quite kept up with fellow Des Plaines burger joint McDonald's. Of course, with only one Choo-Choo and hordes of kiddies vying to eat a burger fresh off the gravy train, the management asks that you limit your visit to 30 minutes—they don't call it fast food for nothing.

Mista is all about being small: small room (it seats maybe a dozen people), small operation (one counter guy, one cook) and a small—that is, thin—crispy, crackery crust. That crust can hold a lot of ingredients, such as the organic spinach and big dollops of seasoned ricotta in the Florentine pizza. But anybody who's looking for something more substantial should go for the vegetable lasagna (with eggplant slices instead of pasta) or the meatball wrap, which is cheap and satisfying (that is, if you can ignore the fact that it's a tortilla wrap and not a sub).

What's better than eating at Old Town Brasserie? Eating there cheaper. That's the benefit (if not the idea behind) the Brasserie's Market, a closet-size take-away shop squeezed next to the Brasserie's lobby. Taking the silky artichoke-garlic soup, herb-stuffed roasted chicken, sprightly beet salad and chewy chocolate-chip cookies to go is always an option. But taking it into the restaurant's sunny dining room and reaping benefits like silverware and water service is an experience that gets you much more for your money.

The second Lincoln Park outpost of this popular brunch spot lacks the sheer scale of the now-closed West Loop location, but the menu survived the move unscathed. In addition to the "fruishi," pancake flights and customizable juices by which Orange earned its cred, the kitchen turns out eggs cooked right on the mark in huevos rancheros with tortilla chips and does a genius variation on French toast: thick-cut brioche dipped in what is effectively a chai latte.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36

column7: This recently opened sibling location of the well-loved Bucktown shop offers the same menu of tasty 100% organic smoothies and juices, as well as soups and baked goods. It's located on the second floor of the Holmes Place building, and it's worth a morning trip upstairs for smoothies like the Purple Parrot—a blend of Michigan blueberries, red raspberries, fresh strawberries, apple juice and fat free frozen yogurt.

Socialites, grab your toy poodles and head to Barneys. NYC import Fred's sits on the top floor, giving you a new place to nibble on chopped salads. You'll find the pristine digs, including an exclusive seven-table patio, a much finer attraction than the dishes, though. A springy chicken salad of green beans, pea shoots and avocado was rendered soggy via weighty dressing—and $16 sticker-shock. Too much heat turned a pizza's prosciutto into wax and dried out a dainty burger. Looking for a treat? Splurge on a Balenciaga tote—not a tiny mold of cold-in-the-center bread pudding.

African restaurants are well known for their leisurely pace, but here the mother-and-son team behind Bolat go the exact opposite route: Customers place their orders at a counter, get in line at a buffet and watch as their food goes from steam table to plate in a matter of minutes. Technically, that makes this stuff fast food, but the flavors are clearly the result of slow cooking. Goat meat has seemingly endless layers of hot and mild peppers; peanut soup has that nut's savory edge but also a peppery bite; and jerk chicken is cloaked in a sauce redolent with cardamom and cloves. The through line is the heat, which can sometimes be absolutely tongue-scorching. Order a soft, starchy yam fufu to give your tongue a break.

After years of housing U. of C. students and their professors, the booths in this cavernous, brick-walled café are pretty worn. So are the menus, and the mugs, and the tables, etc. That's half the point of coming here—to sit ceremoniously, drink coffee and make your own mark on the place. The other half is for the deep-dish pizza or, during the weekends, the brunch: Spinach-and-feta–stuffed "Florian" omelettes and crisp waffles slathered in soft butter, both of which you'll be tempted to devour quickly, so drag out your stay with a slice of pie from the dessert case.

We know it doesn't look much different from every other sports bar. But trust us, if you venture to eat the Spread's food, you'll find better-than-pub-grub fare. The Bookee Sandwich, for instance, is an instant classic: kosher salami, caramelized onions and Merkt cheddar stuffed into a pretzel roll. Ditto for the Race Horse slider, topped with pepper jack, horseradish and fried onions. And if it's a salad you want, try the "Field," blue cheese tossed in a balsamic vinaigrette over spinach. (Hey, we said the food was good, not revolutionary.)
column8: Good for dining at barPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: Although Julie Palmer (Red Kiva Lounge) named her coffeehouse after the 1950s beat hang Cafe Wha? in Greenwich Village, the River North space is more about comfort than counterculture. Free Wi-Fi, magazines you'll actually want to read and board games make this an appealing (if somewhat generically offbeat) place to stop in for a cappuccino or a glass of wine or to settle into for an afternoon. The simple workings of a sandwich press elevate the limited snack menu by adding warm pita to hummus and grilled bread to a cheese plate of Manchego and Brie.
column8: Late-night diningOutdoor seatingGood for groups
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156

column7: Don't let the massive stature and the slick, chain look of Logan's newest Mexican spot scare you away—there are actually some mighty tasty dishes lurking about, and downright delicious margaritas to wash them down with. Start with the app of crispy corn tortillas filled with braised lamb meat and topped with a mound of fuschia pickled onions, then move on to anything smothered in one of the mole sauces (the pillow-soft tamales or the roasted chicken are our favorites. Indulge the kids (or the kid in you) with fried ice cream for a finale, or cheesecake flan if you just can't bring yourself to go Chi-Chi's.
column8: Good for dining at barLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 73

column7: Two decades old and still bustling, this Thai stalwart sits under the shadow of the Lincoln Square Brown Line station, thumbing its nose at the chowhounds running around town for ant eggs and crispy caterpillars. No need for secret menus here—a broad range of staples are done well and at a good price. Wine-toting couples swap forkfuls of sweet-and-sour mee krob (a heap of crunchy noodle threads with sautéed shrimp), tart nam sod (minced chicken tossed in a limey dressing with peanuts and raw ginger) and a filling and flavorful rendition of pad ped pla dook (hunks of crispy catfish sautéed in red curry paste with green beans and eggplant). Tip: The divey liquor store two doors north has a surprisingly good beer and wine selection.
column8: BYOBVegetarian-friendlyGood for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11,49, X49, 81
column198: Other locations: 1906 S State St (312-567-9898), 143 Skokie Blvd, Wilmette (847-853-9898)

column7: The grandiose name hardly seems to suit this modest, friendly Thai cafe on the Argyle strip, which is better thought of as an approachable entry point to one of Chicago's best ethnic-eats streets. Standards like pad see ewe were mostly sweetened up for non-Thais, but we found more authenticity in the noodle soups, rich with flavors of beef or roast duck. Best of all was a rice dish called kao ka moo (translated as "simmered pork hog"), savory-sweet hunks of pork giving off wafts of the five-spice sauce they were braised in.

Adult foodies may have buzzed about avant-garde baked goods in the previous months, but as the cupcake craze simmers, pastry chefs Phoebe Walters and Kate McNamara keep things simple (if rather uninspired) at their cupcake-only bakeshop. A handful of flavors—from kid-friendly Funfetti to adult-oriented salted caramel to classic red velvet—rotate weekly, and tables and free Wi-Fi invite you to stay and taste at least a few. The muted flavors may not appease highbrow aficionados, but sometimes, a cupcake is just a cupcake.
column144: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151

column7: About a dozen of 80 Italian wines are available by the glass at this subterranean wine bar, but without an informed waitress, it was a challenge to choose. Small plates, however, were easier to select—since a quarter of the menu of cured meats, cheeses and small plates was for some unexplained reason unavailable on a recent visit. What we ended up with (a barely toasted four-cheese panino, a circle of grainy polenta topped with mushrooms, refrigerator-cold slices of bread pudding as dense as a terrine) veered from satisfying downward.
column8: Outdoor seatingNotable wine listGood for groupsLate-night dining

column7: It'd be easy to believe that restaurateur Jay Emerich (Jay's Amore) has been serving home-style Italian-American staples on Taylor street for decades—it's harder to understand what exactly his recently opened bar/restaurant could add to the neighborhood. Sausage stewed with lemony artichoke leaves gave a hint that the fare was going to be a cut above Little Italy's average, but a massive hunk of flavorless, watery lasagna killed that aspiration. Better to follow the lead of UIC students and neighborhood folk gravitating toward that known quantity (a.k.a. beer) in the front bar room.
column144: El: Blue to Racine, Pink to Polk. Bus: 7, 12, 38

column7: This little counter spot serves up savory Cuban classics, as well as traditional housemade sweets like guava pastelitos. There are only two tables inside, with more to come, so in the meantime take your lechon sandwich and plantains to nearby Eckhart Park.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: X9, 9, 66

column7: Lisa Lee and Jose Palomino took over this restaurant from Lee's aunt, who operated Taqueria y Restaurant el Gusto in the same space. Now the place looks like a proper neuvo-Mexicano joint—but for the most part, the food remains in that common, corner-taqueria category. That's not a bad thing: The queso fundido sprinkled with chorizo is decadent and satisfying, and the snapper Veracruzana-style is a well-executed, piquant dish. Anybody coming here for something completely different from what it used to be, however, should consider themselves warned that the upgrade was mostly aesthetic.

The second outpost of Billy Dec and pals' River North madhouse (ahem, bar/restaurant) opened in the former Tuscany space in Wrigleyville, replete with their signature brie-topped Kobe burger with truffle fries and a tree-lined outdoor patio.

By now, almost every Mexican-food enthusiast knows how chef Geno Bahena cooks. In fact, Bahena has opened (and closed) so many restaurants in the past four years that many people can probably recite the menu at this new joint sight unseen. But if this is an unsurprising experience, it is at least unsurprisingly good: The ceviche is sharp with lime juice and olives, the steaks are cooked perfectly medium-rare and, of course, there are the moles. Each one is distinctive in its layers of sweetness and spice, proving that there are no bad Geno Bahena restaurants. Just predictable ones.
column8: BYOBOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 9, X9, 11, 77

column7: When this Turkish restaurant replaced Bella Lounge, the atmosphere didn't change much. Now, with those (slightly dated) Sex and the City vibes still intact, Sortie is the by far the swankiest-looking Middle Eastern joint in town. Despite this, the menu has plenty of old-world, Turkish soul. The doner kebabs—juicy, shawarmalike beef in a yogurt sauce—are tender and tangy; the crispy exterior of the borek gives way to a savory feta filling; and the baklava avoids being cloying, arriving at lightly sweet. The service is pretty sweet, too—seems like one aspect of Bella they did get rid of was the snobbery.

Randolph Row's latest mega-project is co-owned by Sox GM Kenny Williams, but you're likely to care more that there are three different outdoor areas to choose from, a massive cocktail list and classic American eats served late.
column8: Late-night diningGood for groupsOutdoor seating
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 20

column7: This is the sibling restaurant of Logan Square's cult favorite Mexican joint, Fonda del Mar. But don't expect the crowds to start spilling in here any time soon. Unlike the Logan Square spot, which deftly puts out wholesome seafood dishes, fdm aims for higher-end Mexican fare—stuff like tilapia in a grainy walnut-goat cheese sauce. The food never really takes off, and some of it crashes and burns. So go for the cocktails and the sleek dining room, but explore the food with trepidation.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: This campy deli creates food that's just as over-the-top as the Broadway tunes it plays. The "Marilyn Monroe" sandwich boasts luscious slathers of duck pâté, chicken-liver mousse and Brie; the "Wham Sammich" pairs delectable lamb with goat cheese and eggplant; and the Valrhona chocolate soufflé is topped with a creamy housemade truffle—for no reason, really. Just because. It's lovely food, masterfully done, but at the end of the day it's akin to Garland's pouty "Over The Rainbow" shtick: best taken in small doses.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Tucked into the north end zone of U.S. Beer Co., Tailgate caters to the takeout crowd; a recent visit found the kitchen hopping even as customers were slow to materialize. Cheap, heartily portioned staples (there's nothing priced over $10 except the baby-back slab at $18.95) are grouped under football phrases (apps are the "kick-off," etc.). Those looking to bulk up for the gridiron should order the baked mostaccioli with meat sauce, a buttery casserole oozing with cheese. Little else gets past the line of scrimmage—with an overcooked salmon sandwich, nothing-special ribs, watery minestrone, limp fries and inoffensive chicken kabobs, you'd be better off grilling in the stadium lot.
column144: El: Red to North/Clybourn; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 9, 72

column7: East doesn't so much meet West as sit quietly alongside it at this Italian-Asian fusion restaurant on the 15th floor of the Holiday Inn Chicago Mart Plaza. Unfortunately, this is the kind of food that gives "fusion" and "hotel restaurant" a bad rap: Rubbery chopped octopus joins fresh arugula in a fine salad, a trio of mini sliders are more like marinara-drenched sandwiches, and veal meatballs have an off-putting mouthfeel and are just as bland as the spaghetti noodles they're perched atop. "Wonton cannoli" (exactly as it sounds) are actually more successful than a dry cake mysteriously labeled a "Milk Chocolate Cappuccino." Still, this is a place best left to out-of-towners afraid to stray too far from their conference rooms.
column8: Private party room(s)Good for groups
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 11, 123, 125

column7: You know you're in a neighborhood favorite when a cop stopping in for his "usual" knows the name of the stroller-pushing mom who's come to pick up her sister's birthday cake. The couple running this sparse but cheerful daytime-only spot take it all in stride—they may have only opened in 2004 but their Beverly roots go back plenty. That would explain the careful local sourcing: Sage-rich breakfast sausage, thick applewood-smoked bacon and Fratelli coffee are all produced in the Chicago area. Fill up on a solid breakfast (have it on the simple little back patio if the weather's nice) and take the cop's cue for a doughnut for the road.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Like the rest of the Renzo Piano–designed Modern Wing, the restaurant at the Art Institute is a beautiful space: sleek, pristine and awash with light. The highlights of the menu, which is overseen by Spiaggia's Tony Mantuano, exhibit similar simplicity and elegance. Eschew lackluster mains in favor of flatbreads (topped with creamy burrata cheese and seasonal ingredients like scapes) and heaping salads (like pea shoots and crisped prosciutto), then end with a rich, indulgent chocolate-hazelnut semifreddo. We said the place was aesthetically pleasing, not ascetic.
column8: Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendlyNotable wine list
column92: 159 E Monroe, Art Institute of Chicago
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison

column7: The long-established (and rather static) Middle Eastern strip in Albany Park has recently seen a couple of new entrants, and the most ambitious might be this Iraqi restaurant, both for its relatively snazzy interior and for the fact that it's open 24/7. So far, the menu seems to follow the standard offerings of its neighbors, but everything is prepared as well as anywhere: Falafel were freshly fried and served with garlicky toum, and shawarma tasted of good-quality meat and was thankfully moist and tender. Service couldn't have been more welcoming at noon, and by reports it's the same at midnight, making it a civilized alternative to late-night greasy spoons.
column8: Kid-friendlyLate-night diningVegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: The novella-length menu at this low-key alcove contains loving and helpful descriptions of an impressive selection of wines and beers. And thanks to the well-executed small plates, executed by chef Remy Ayesh and served until 1am, this is the kind of warm, simple neighborhood place you'll never want—or need—to leave.

A space this cavernous can house only one thing: pizza. Which explains why John Figlioli (of Estelle's and Bucktown Pub) opened his family-friendly pie palace in the former Ranalli's location. Figlioli outfitted the room with 20 flat-screens, but it's the shaded outdoor patio that calls for attention—not the double-crust pizza (slightly thicker than thin-crust). There are other crowd pleasers—simple but nicely dressed salads, bowls of garlicky spaghetti tossed with a couple of clams, molten chocolate cake—but it doesn't take more than decent pizza to fill the place.
column8: Outdoor seatingLate-night diningKid-friendlyGood for groupsVegetarian-friendlyPrivate party room(s)

column7: After opening Paula's and Monica's Pizzeria in West Town less than a year ago, owners John Fornari and George Dragne (of Schaumburg-based Johnny D's) are serving pizza as well as entrées like fettucine Alfredo and veal marsala in their new outpost a stone's throw from the heart of Little Italy.

Pilsen's historic Thalia Hall opened before the Columbian Exposition, and after years of sitting empty, it has been resurrected by Dominic Geraci of Wicker Park's Caffe Gelato. Look for a menu as traditional as the space: pizzas, pastas, antipasti and, of course, gelato.

Some outposts of Ranalli's serve breakfast. Some serve Mexican food. But this location, a sunny room on a side street in Andersonville, sticks to what all Ranalli's ostensibly do best: thin, pan, double-crust and deep-dish pizzas. Actually, it's the thin crust that keeps its rep intact, and when topped with, say, mushrooms and Italian sausage, the square-cut pies do an apt job at quelling cravings for cheesy carbs. But take note: On Mondays, when a large thin crust is just $10, the pizza tastes much, much better.

Marlene Benitez's follow-up to Andersonville's La Cocina de Frida has the same ambition as her original spot: classic, homestyle Mexican food, some of it with a minor twist. Funnily enough, this new version seems to be doing a better job with the execution. The guac is rich and creamy, the ceviche balanced between sweet and spicy, the chicken immersed in a complex peanut-and-chile guajillo salsa. In fact, anybody who has found themselves disappointed in the Andersonville locale may find checking this one out worth the trip.

The new owners of this neighborhood coffee shop seem to have ambitions far larger than the tiny (and seemingly unfinished) space would imply. Baristas are superfriendly, direct-trade coffee is roasted in-house, and sandwiches are named for storytellers. Options like the Garrison Keillor (turkey, cheddar, avocado, apple and honey mustard on wheat) are basic and straightforward, as are the lattes, but the genuine warmth of the place is more uncommon.

The call-and-response routine behind the counter at this West Coast–based chain—in which the person working the register repeats your order, then the crew of line cooks shouts it back—is more exciting than the meals themselves. There are countless ways to customize your burger (in S, M, L, XL and XXL; topped with a fried egg, chili or bacon) and fries ("skinny" ones, "fat" steak fries or disappointing onion rings). And the beef is of higher-than-average quality, even if it won't exactly make you rethink fast food.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendly

column7: After losing 60 pounds on a high-protein diet, owner Matt Matros decided to spread the healthy-lifestyle love to Loop workers with this acai-and-agave-nectar haven serving fruit-blended protein shakes and bowls of steel-cut oats (also, of course, mixed with protein powder in a variety of flavors). The peculiar mouthfeel of protein powder disappears much more smoothly into a hot bowl of McCann's oatmeal—especially the "Pancake in a Bowl" version, hit with maple syrup and cinnamon—than into a shake, especially when you try and fail to customize your own.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

column7: We weren't huge fans of Dudley Nieto's foray into Spanish food when it first opened, and we're guessing we weren't the only ones who said so—the chef has done away with some of the disappointing molecular stuff (the "liquid tapas", for example) and is now focusing on the traditional: house-smoked salmon pintxos; a cazuela (casserole) of chicken, eggplant and bell peppers; and a rustic Spanish flatbread with goat cheese, asparagus and Marcona almonds.
column8: Late-night diningOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 72, 156

column7: Kettle-boiled, New York–style bagels are now available in the Loop thanks to the opening of a second location of this Lincoln Park–based deli and sandwich shop.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

column7: Sweet Occasions fans can stop their mourning: The new ice-cream slinger in this space is practically identical—only upgraded. The walls are now decked out in cool grays and dark blues, and the savory menu has been expanded to include hot panini such as a roast beef with soft onions and horseradish mayo. Most important, the ice cream is the same (Chocolate Shoppe from Madison, Wisconsin). The scoops are now offered in over-the-top sundaes, but save the cash and the sugar overload—this ice cream holds up well enough on its own.

Former Blue Water Grill pastry chef Nathaniel Meads is behind this Lakeview pastry shop, and so far, he's managed to convince hungry wanderers that there is indeed a reason to navigate the odd side entrance and look beyond the shop's dreary tinted windows. Incredibly friendly counter help makes up for the rather dark atmosphere, and solid coffee cakes, streusel-topped fruit tarts and chocolate macarons make nice latte companions. Stop by in the afternoon for a selection of light, simple savory fare that changes every few days or so. Recently offerings include a chilled fennel soup and a salad of Bibb lettuce and hard-cooked eggs in a cider vinaigrette, with sandwiches still to come.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76

column7: Sean Sanders's homey, green-minded North Center restaurant may not look like much of a destination, nor does his menu read like a list of must-haves. But don't be fooled: The food, while on the simpler side, is rife with flavors both big and nuanced. Juicy chicken thighs get paired with rich polenta, beautifully seared walleye gets a lively dressing of salsa verde, and the Browntrout fish trio is made of some of the silkiest cured fish in the city. Some dishes fall flat (the chocolate-chip cookies from his grandmother's recipe are heartbreakingly not up to par). But for the most part, eating simply just got a lot more exciting.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: Small-batch artisan cheeses are cut to order at this friendly, well-stocked wine-and-cheese shop. The place is attitude-free, and if you're new to the game, wine director Jan Henrichsen will help you pair your Neufchâtel with your sauvignon blanc. Recent additions to the menu, like the Nut N' Chutney sandwich of spiced almond butter and cranberry chutney on cracked wheat bread, are perfect for a quick lunch in one of the handful of seats on the outdoor patio, or grab a Spanish cheese plate (with Mahón, rosemary Manchego and pata cabra) to go and make it a picnic.

Rarely do we get to compare the North Shore to Brooklyn, but step into this strip-mall restaurant and you'll swear you're in Crown Heights. It's not worth the drive for the food alone: Curry-laden schwarma in fluffy pita, dryish grilled chicken kebabs and thick-cut french fries are fine, but you can find better Middle Eastern fare on Kedzie. So it must be the fact that this place is kosher—and observes Shabbat by closing early on Friday and not reopening until Sunday—that explains the absolute frenzy of frum diners, standing in line among enlarged photographs of the Western Wall.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendlyOutdoor seatingSuburbanVegetarian-friendly

column144: El: Brown, Purple to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 11, 72

column7: The most consistently successful dishes at this modern, understated restaurant from the Lula Cafe crew exhibit one of two traits: first, that fresh-from-the-garden liveliness that's garnered Lula its cultish status. (See, e.g., a "stone soup" filled with bright lima beans or a squash salad accented with crunchy purslane.) Second, a distinctive wood-grilled flavor that gives an intoxicating aroma to a juicy half-chicken and earthy cheeseburger. The sweet side of the menu hits all the right notes, and Sunday brunch—featuring fried-chicken-and-waffles and ricotta griddlecakes—just might give it the cultish statish accorded its Logan Square sibling.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for groups

column7: Fro-yo never dies; it just reincarnates—this time in Lincoln Park environs. Top Starfruit's frozen kefir with anything from Brazilian gogi berries to Milk & Honey granola at this second Chicago location of the probiotic yogurt house.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: Modern in the most basic, CB2 kind of way, this pizza joint offers little to gawk at in terms of design. So the only thing left to focus your attention on is the food. The kitchen claims to have spent a long time perfecting its crust, and that may be true—but it is a pedestrian crust all the same: a little thick but still crackery. Piled with the housemade, fennel-seed sausage, the Denny's Grand Slam pizza is a very respectable nosh, and the eggplant "napoleone" is a light and charming (if basic) way to start. Still, this is truly a neighborhood spot: The only people for whom it makes sense to make the trip here are those who live close by.
column8: Outdoor seatingBYOBLate-night diningKid-friendlyGood for groupsVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland/Lake. Bus: 9, 20, X20
