column7: Add this dimly lit date-spot to the city's quirky cadre of Thai/sushi joints, but be forewarned: The wide selection of raw fish is uniformly mushy, a problem that pervades everything from a salad of tuna sashimi and avocado to cucumber-wrapped rolls of salmon and shiitakes. However unadventurous, Thai mainstays like anise-perfumed ground chicken stir-fried with basil or a bowl of green curry brimming with Japanese eggplant are better bets. Or make like fellow patrons and get so crunked on (BYO) Jack Daniel's and cases of Sapporo that you won't care what you're eating.

This sibling location of Clybourn Avenue's popular Cuban carry-out joint is nearly a spitting image of the original—same toasted Cuban sandwiches, same flaky empanadas, same garlicky fried yucca chips, same potent cafe con leche. But even if the tiny interior, with its newspaper-covered walls, elicits the same claustrophobia, the big draw here is the spacious side patio, complete with a provocative mural, colorful planters and a table for playing dominoes.
column8: BYOBOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendly

column7: Don't be deterred by the bare-bones look of this new Algerian carryout shop. The handful of forlorn items languishing in the steam table come from co-owner Mohammed Djeddour, who also owns the adjacent Tassili, which aims at a cabbie clientele. But grab a paper menu and you'll see surprisingly ambitious salads, wraps and sides, courtesy of former Mundial co-owner/chef Kate Garcia. Try a trio of salads: apricot-studded Israeli couscous, spinach and strawberries in mustard vinaigrette and cubed watermelon with cucumber dressed in thin, minty yogurt. Crêpelike Algerian-style flatbreads prove perfect for soaking up the mint pesto drizzled on wraps of roasted vegetables or hunks of roasted lamb, and pistachio shortbreads complement the carryout package for a complete dinner at home.

Simple and pleasant, this neighborhood café is comprised of a quiet room with a corner devoted to Chicagocentric art and jewelry and a back patio so calm and flower-lined you'd forget you were in the city (if it weren't for the adjacent parking lot and apartment buildings). Steer clear of ho-hum croissant sandwiches in favor of getting full-on lacy crêpes slathered with Nutella and sprinkled with banana slices, and wash the whole thing down with a tasty iced latte.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: Since you'll barely be able to see the menu in the pitch-black of theWit Hotel's first-floor, all-day restaurant, let us make some recommendations. Small plates are the best bet—and, thanks to their uncharacteristically generous size, the best deal. Juicy, marinated tomatoes (sliced in a thin "carpaccio" style) delicately offset breaded-and-fried slices of mozzarella; a trio of roasted bones—not your average hotel food—yields luscious marrow; and juicy shrimp glazed in Louisiana-style BBQ sauce deftly balance heat and sweet. Bigger plates and desserts can feel like placeholders, so those you'll have to order blindly.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

column7: Family reigns at this Bridgeport taco mainstay, from the multigenerational Solis clan that runs the joint to the extended families from the neighborhood that lumber in for a cheap dinner with no fuss. Step to the counter and order a slew of reliable classics, including solid tacos al pastor, guisado stew and greaseless chicken flautas, best when doused in the standout housemade salsa. There's plenty of room to spread out and take your time, but this is simple (if unremarkable) food, probably best enjoyed post–Sox game to soak up one-too-many seventh-inning beers.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendly

column7: Popping up in Bridgeport as some sort of budget-conscious beacon of pan-Asian flavors, Han 202 might just be the best value in town. Twenty bucks brings your picks of five different courses, with fun and flavorful options like lemongrass beef on matchsticks of Granny Smith apples, delicate salt-and-pepper baby octopus, moist grouper peeking out from a blanket of scallions and fresh ginger, and an ending of simple vanilla ice cream with a peel-it-yourself lychee. Figure in a tasteful dining room and a BYOB policy and this place has "date night" written all over it.

Looking to try Indonesian food? This friendly West Rogers Park BYOB is your only option in town, but the lack of competition doesn't mean the Rukli family that runs it is slacking. For a whirlwind tour of Indonesia's greatest hits, start with gado-gado, a salad of watercress, snappy green beans, carrot slivers, boiled eggs and tofu squares, doused with peanut sauce and meant to be piled onto krupuk, crunchy shrimp rice-flour crackers. Move on to the lamb or beef satays, juicy and full-flavored. Finish up with es teler, a parfait of avocado, young coconut, jackfruit and shaved ice, and grab a bag of savory peanut brittle for the trip home.

This offshoot of the South Loop breakfast favorite is more of an identical twin than a younger sister, serving the same menu in a remarkably similar space. Now River North residents can indulge their cravings for bacon waffles, crêpes and huge omelettes.
column8: BYOBGood for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156

column7: Longtime friends and first-time restaurateurs Julio Perez and Jose Luis Hernandez tapped Cuban-born chef Guillermo Numa to turn out traditional fare on the edge of Bucktown. Neither the food nor the decor is particularly remarkable, and the service (although helpful) can be awkward. Appetizers like tostones (fried pounded green plantains) and bolitas de yuca, fried balls of cheese-filled mashed yuca, are as good as fried street food always is, and mains like pounded flank steak with chimichurri sauce and garlic-rubbed shrimp are simple successes, but swordfish and pork tenderloin are both tough and dry. Desserts, too, feel like a crapshoot: play it safe with a café con leche.
column8: BYOBGood for groupsGood for dining at bar

column7: If imitation is the highest form of flattery, Hot Doug's Doug Sohn must be blushing. The friendly recent grads running the show at this hot-dog shop in the heart of Lincoln Park serve picture-perfect Chicago-style dogs and hand-dipped corn dogs along with a rotating menu of franks with cheeky names like the Blago ("Opening bid: $1,000") and the Snoop Dogg. Specialty sausages are hit-or-miss (the rib-eye steak dog was nearly swallowed inside a dry-and-bready French roll), and curly wisps of potatoes are not quite crispy enough to be chips nor substantial enough to be fries. Still, if it's time—not duck fat—you value, consider this a viable wait-free alternative to Doug's.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: There's nothing that weird about a soup-only restaurant. (The Soup Box, anyone?) But it's hard to describe this 16-seat café as anything butÉodd. There's no tap water (a request was met with rumblings from first-time owner Dino Agudo about health-department restrictions), there's no for-here bowls, there's nothing here really besides a rotating selection of nine vats of soup. Crab-corn and beef-barley were well-balanced, brought subtle heat and felt hearty without being overly rich (even if both were a little stingy on the proteins). For upwards of $7 for a 12-ounce takeaway container, though, the soup here doesn't leave you full so much as it does depleted.

Fortunately, this new Loop lunch spot takes its Middle Eastern options more seriously than its name. Choose between the namesake chickpea fritters, grilled lamb, chicken or beef shawarma, then have your filling rolled into pita, tossed with mixed greens or plated on rice or creamy hummus. Kefta and falafel can be a bit tough from resting under the heat lamps, but the generous use of parsley lends them an herbaceous flavor. Besides, top them with the sprightly baba ghanoush and place them in a whole-wheat grilled pita and the protein's flaws will be unnoticeable. So is this the falafel of our dreams? Not exactly. But it just may become the falafel of our lunch.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groups
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

column7: The name implies otherwise, but there are a couple of tables for dining in at this Brazilian pizzeria, where the menu includes whole pies and slices, and grilled chicken served with sides of porky black beans, rice and pita. You read that right: Brazilian pizza. It has a soft, doughy crust and comes in 50 combinations of ingredients such as codfish, pulled chicken and ranch dressing. Sounds like too much fusion? Then start with a coxinha—a shredded chicken–stuffed potato cake—in one hand and a Guarana soda in the other. You'll soon be convinced this place has Brazilian cred.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76

column7: After 22 years as Cafe Shino, this Gold Coast stalwart got a makeover and has emerged as a sake lounge, complete with two dozen varieties of rice wine, a private karaoke room, and a menu of otsumami, traditional Japanese small plates (we're fans of the crispy-edged hot-dog bites, plummy baby octopus, spicy salmon hand rolls and tofu-topped udon noodles). For a primer on sake, ask manager Kerry Tamura, who's happy to steer you in the right direction.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningGood for groups

column7: This Scandinavian gourmet store is a fixture not just in Andersonville, but in the Midwest as well. Open since 1925, the delicatessen is one of only a few that imports goods from the Scandinavian countries. Shoppers flock from the suburbs and the rest of the country to browse the selection of pickled herring, Swedish candies, lingonberries, cheeses like bond ost and västerbottensost and the always-popular Swedish meatballs.

Rarely do we get to compare the North Shore to Brooklyn, but step into this strip-mall restaurant and you'll swear you're in Crown Heights. It's not worth the drive for the food alone: Curry-laden schwarma in fluffy pita, dryish grilled chicken kebabs and thick-cut french fries are fine, but you can find better Middle Eastern fare on Kedzie. So it must be the fact that this place is kosher—and observes Shabbat by closing early on Friday and not reopening until Sunday—that explains the absolute frenzy of frum diners, standing in line among enlarged photographs of the Western Wall.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendlyOutdoor seatingSuburbanVegetarian-friendly

column7: When André Christopher, former chef of the Grocery Bistro, landed at this 30-year-old, historically Romanian restaurant, his fans were hoping for a repeat of his sausage-stuffed chicken thighs and chocolate panini. The chicken thighs they'll find, but most of the menu is dedicated to traditional Eastern European fare. The schnitzel is done perfectly, but the bland eggplant spread and DiGiorno-quality flatbreads fall fast and flat. But there is an accordion player who roams the dining room, so at least someone in the place is making music.

As is to be expected at any place that has an eight-page menu, this Turkish spot has both hits and misses. The good news? The misses—overly simple vegetable fritters, overly smoky eggplant purees—don't miss by all that much. So even if you try only one of the hits, like the vibrant lahmacun and hearty iskender kebab, you'll likely have a meal that rises to above-par levels.

Owner Jim Andrews has an edgy sense of humor, that's for sure. And there's no doubt, either, that his providing on-the-job training for ex-offenders at his hot-dog stand is a much-needed and respectable undertaking. Whether you'll be entertained by the coyly named eats (Misdemeanor Weiners, Probation Burgers) and theatrical service (you'll be asked "Are you ready to plead your case?" when you step up to the Plexiglas divider) is another story. But here's what's not up for debate: The Chicago-style dogs (supplied by Red Hot Chicago) are merely satisfactory; the fast-food style burgers are vastly improved with the addition of bacon; and Objection Onion Rings, generously battered and fried to a crisp, will actually garner no objections at all.
column144: El: Blue to Western (Forest Park). Bus: 20, 49, 126

column7: Chef Matt Troost has made a name for himself—maybe not a household name yet, but still—at this unassuming Italian spot. But he isn't resting on his laurels just yet: For fall, he's stuffing his housemade ravioli with fire-roasted heirloom squash and duck confit, pairing pork belly with a sambuca glaze and sweet fennel jam, and filling cider-brined chicken with cranberry-walnut stuffing.

Chef Todd Stein has a lot of good ideas for theWit's high-end dining spot, some of which result in really great dishes. His rich roasted chicken livers, for instance, are paired with polenta and mushrooms to a deliciously earthy effect. But he's often heavy handed with ingredients, overshadowing what could be complex flavor combinations (chicken with pancetta) with one big, clunky taste (a big slathering of honey). Luckily he's a master of pasta, and his corzetti topped with sweet corn and thick bucatini with bacon is enough to make this place a destination. For at least one course, anyway.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake; Red to Lake

column7: With the opening of this, the first city location of the yogurt chain, fro-yo fiends no longer have to trek to Evanston to get a fix. And it's just in time: The chain recently unveiled its new flavor, Tangomonium, which smacks of orange, mango, lime, banana and, well, mystery: It's a "secret" recipe that even the chain's employees aren't privy to. But is it any good? It's mellower and more accessible than the sometimes-overpowering pomegranate and green-tea flavors, but for our money, it's just not as creamy as the refreshingly sweet and tangy original.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

column7: If Coskun Eskeranli asks whether you like iced tea, or orange marmalade, or practically anything for that matter—be wary. The friendly and generous owner will likely try to give you said item for free, and considering how empty this café/grocery store/hookah lounge was on a recent visit, you'll feel much better paying for it. The grocery selection is full of hard-to-find Turkish goods, including the cotton-candy-like floss halvah and flavored tobacco. Unfortunately, a lot of the menu items—such as su boregi (feta-stuffed phyllo dough), tost (Turkish sausage rounds on French bread) and syrupy baklava—come from the grocery, too—they're just reheated.

The second city location of the Virginia-based chain hawks the same namesake burgers (aggressively advertised as never-frozen and freshly ground) and fries (made from Idaho potatoes cooked in trans-fat free oil) from beneath the Loyola Red Line stop.

With only one other location (in Jackson Hole, Wyoming), this bakery/café can just barely be considered part of a corporate chain. And yet this food tastes as if it has been focus-grouped (read: dumbed down) to death nonetheless. The cinnamon rolls are huge but contain hardly any cinnamon; the barbecue brisket couldn't be sweeter if it were candied; and the white sandwich bread on the Thanksgiving turkey sandwich is dense and gummy. So unless you're going to go for the fresh avocado salad, this chain is probably better off growing without you.

How good you think the food is at this Lincoln Park outpost of the Evanston institution/diner Sarkis is directly proportional to how wasted you are. Only kinda drunk? The Special Grilled Cheese—a fried egg, crispy bacon, guiltily pleasurable American cheese—is a pretty good bet. Totally blazed? That's what the grease-dripping omelettes and hash browns are for. But no matter how wasted you are, stay away from the Disaster Sausage—they call it that for a reason.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Late-night diningBYOBGood for groupsKid-friendlyOutdoor seatingVegetarian-friendly
column60: Breakfast and lunch daily, dinner (closed Sun)
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36

column7: On the heels of the success of Chickpea, Jerry Suqi has opened this charming breakfast-and-lunch-only spot. This time, however, it's not his mom in the kitchen but chef (and co-owner) Jeffrey Mauro, a Charlie Trotter's alum, who is putting out twisted classics such as egg sandwiches with pork cheeks and lamb crêpes with Asian pear. Even breakfast tropes here (like omelettes or steak-and-eggs) exhibit a degree of care that usually gets lost in mounds of poached eggs. Jam takes a lot of risks, some of which pay off better than others, but the breakfast amuse-bouches (such as a mini raspberry muffin drizzled with honey) always get things off to the right start.

It's worth the trip to the 'burbs just for a chance to dine in this 30-year-old restaurant's authentic Japanese-style tatami rooms. But the fresh sushi and extensive udon menu may convince you to invest in a monthly Metra pass. The children's platter—tempura, a jumbo sushi roll, chicken teriyaki, gyoza, fruit and soup for $9.99—is a refreshing alternative for chicken nugget-weary parents. Reserve tatami rooms in advance for no additional charge.
column8: Good for groupsPrivate party room(s)
column144: Metra: Union Pacific Northwest to Mount Prospect

column7: Chef Rick Spiros took a short hiatus after the last restaurant he cooked at, Mantou Noodle, abruptly closed after no more than a month. Now he's at this West Town "gastro-lounge." But if it wouldn't make that moniker sound (even more) ridiculous, the owners probably should have flipped those words: It's the hard-partying crowd that are getting the attention here—not the mid-sized plates coming out of the kitchen. Too-cold lobster rolls, soggy french fries, chewy octopus are all passable. So go for the scene, and while you're there, try the fried quail.
column8: Late-night diningNotable wine listGood for groups

column7: Bridgeview Middle Eastern grocery with a solid meat counter and an impressive assortment of locally-baked pitas and other Middle Eastern breads still warm in the package, as well as fresh spices such as za'atar, a zesty mix of sesame seeds and herbs.
Turkish delight and other gooey middle-eastern sweets sold by the pound or in extravagantly shiny boxes in a Bridgeview strip mall.

Impeccably tidy Bridgeview takeout counter selling freshly-baked spinach pies, zaatar-covered flatbreads and other healthy, satisfying baked items. If you like spicy, go for the eggplant-schmeared mohamaras; for sheer comfort food, don't miss the potato triangles. Stock up, they'll go fast and they're cheap. And as the owner implores customers (with the concern of the true artisan for his wares), reheat on a cookie sheet—never microwave!

It may be hard to imagine how you could turn an old Arby's in Bridgeview into a pasha's pleasure den, but that's pretty much what Al Bawadi has done. The over-the-top decor is matched by the superb hand with wood-grilled meats in the kitchen, producing kebabs, chicken and (unusual for a Middle Eastern restaurant) seafood with perfect juiciness and char flavor. Veggie items—psychedically bright green falafel, tart fattoush salad, smoky baba ghanoush—also pop with a brightness of flavor that they haven't had in a long time, though the tastiest thing of all might have been a freebie: the complimentary garlicky eggplant dip that started the meal. An attached hookah parlor (with separate ventilation) is next door.

Commuters heading for the Logan Square El station make a beeline for the Metropolis coffee drinks at this spacious cafe. Those not tied down by the nine-to-five prefer to roll in just before noon and set up camp to take advantage of the free Wi-Fi. Panini and wraps offer sustenance to counter the caffeine shakes, with a good assortment of vegetarian-friendly options to boot. Late-night hours make New Wave a frequent stop for night owls as well, fueling up before an evening of debauchery at nearby bars.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74

column7: Large Bridgeview Middle Eastern market with whole wheat pitas baked on premises and an especially wide-ranging meat counter.

It would be easy to miss Baladi Restaurant hidden behind a pancake house in a tiny Bridgeview strip mall, but the quality of its Middle Eastern offerings would make that a shame. The classics are tastily prepared (the baba ghanoush is especially good), and the complimentary tea with dried sage might be reason enough to return. But be sure to ask what the Arabic-only specials board has to offer—on one trip we had a grilled whole chicken, accompanied by a tangy red pepper dipping sauce, that was unbelievably tender and delicious, setting off mouth-fireworks of spices and crispy charred bits.708-233-1025. Pace: 385, 386. >
It's quite difficult to resist the tantalizing smells of baklava and other middle-eastern treats that drift from this friendly little bakery on the Burbank side of Harlem.

This Palestinian-owned bakery in Bridgeview has baklava and the other sticky-sweet treats you expect packaged to go, but the real draw here is up by the counter: a pan of warm cheese oozing out from under a layer of circus-peanut-orange crispies. This is knafeh, sort of a cross between a deep dish pizza and a cheese blintz, white cheese and saffron-colored shredded wheat topped with crushed pistachios and doused with sweet syrup. As rich as it is, you probably won't make it through a whole portion, but on weekends the locals line up and consume it like hotcakes at the bakery's few tables.

You'll be happy to know that you don't have to venture all the way to Argyle Street to find decent pho in Chicago. Chinatown happens to be home to this bold, hearty and super thick broth. Cheap eats (the crispy spring rolls are delicious with peanut sauce) and efficient, no-frills service is the name of the game at this cozy joint.

Open 24-hours on the weekends, Pick Me Up Café is a veggie organic alternative to late night grease, with vintage hodgepodge décor and a Haight-Ashbury vibe. Standout moo-free items include the falafel wrap, the vegan chili, macaroni and cheese and the tummy-warming French toast.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont; Red to Addison. Bus: 22, 152

column7: La Puebla satisfies everyone, from red-eyed co-ed to nocturnal hipster in Logan Square. This feeding hole is available 24-hours for those who like to start and end their nights with homemade tortillas, giant burrito suizos and salsa just spicy enough to keep you wanting more. And after just one of their overly substantial margaritas, belting out a bit of Spanish karaoke will seem second nature.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 76

column7: Nothing's sure to sober up the post–Funky Buddha Lounge crowd quite like the ugly lighting and uglier food coming out of the kitchen at this fifth (and first late-night) location of the local chain. Just imagine gnawing on a thin, dry chicken breastÉor inhaling the rosemary aroma emitted by a plate of "infused" French toast till the point of chokingÉor taking a bite of the cloying, slimy frushi (fruit sushi)Éyour buzz worn off yet?
column8: Late-night diningVegetarian-friendlyGood for groupsCheap (entrees under $10)BYOB

column7: Jerry Kleiner's new spot is just like his others: A little clubby, a lot sceney and intricately—some might say overly—designed. But unlike Kleiner's other spots, this one has longtime restaurant veteran Daniel Kelly at the stove.True to Kelly's (and Kleiner's) style, the menu is filled with American staples: steak, whitefish, Caesar salad. Most of it is surprisingly disappointing, but there are some high points: A crabcake arrives with a chunky avocado "salsa," and Kelly's signature chips are addictive when paired with his onion dip. And then there's Kelly's fantastic cheeseburger, which if it's not the most satisfying lunch in these parts right now, it's at least close.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

column7: This fluorescent-lit room is outfitted with a single flat-screen and some industrial furniture—not exactly the most comfortable spot for hunkering down with a bucket of chicken and watching the game. But that's no big deal, because these internationally inspired wings (in flavors like Chicago-style honey BBQ and sweet Thai chile) are fried to order, which means they'll still be hot by the time you get them home. Just make sure you have some condiments in your fridge—these things are flavorful, but not so much that they wouldn't benefit from a dousing of ranch.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77, 151, 165

column7: Don't waste time mulling over the scant appetizer and dessert offerings here—you're going to need all the extra minutes (and brain powerÉand stomach spaceÉ) to make one big decision: Neapolitan-style brick oven–fired pizza that's charred on the bottom and crackly at the edges, or a standout calzone, even more beautifully charred than the pizza, filled with creamy ricotta? Of course, smart eaters know the answer to this conundrum already: Rally the troops and order both.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

column7: Have an entire afternoon to waste? You could spend it at one of the riverwalk tables here, watching the boats cruise by while waiting for your jambalaya or catfish po' boy to make an appearance. But as much as we love the South Side original of this seasonal riverwalk sibling, it didn't bring efficiency or execution with it: A two-hour lunch might yield delicious (if greasy) chicken "wangs" and fluffy waffles, but it could just as easily result in a microwaved cup of jambalaya for five bucks. And since all the food here is served with plastic utensils and plates, it takes a lot of searching to find this joint's soul.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State; Red to Lake

column7: How could a barbecue joint that just popped up in Bridgeport boast "Since 1955" on its menu? Turns out the owners of this tiny carryout joint bought the recipes from one "Miss Ruby," who had a similar Memphis operation since, well, 1955. We're assuming to survive in the barbecue belt of Tennessee Ruby's recipes were executed with smokers, but here in Chicago, the slow-baked method yields results more akin to homestyle cooking than competition 'cue. Ribs are tender and peppery while pulled pork is juicy (but a bit stringy). It turns out that roasted chicken is the star of the show, so take a cue from the Sox-loving cops stopping by for a whole bird to take home.

The newest outpost of this health-food chain is appropriately nestled in the lobby of an Equinox gym. But don't worry: You need not be a member of the posh health club to get your hands on these salads, wraps and smoothies. (If you want a six-pack, howeverÉwell, that's a different story.)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Pink, Orange to Washington/Wells

column7: The TOC Eat Out dilemma: Do we list the second Lincoln Park location of Five Guys in our Recently Opened Listings? Or is this Washington, D.C., import (known for its Potbelly's-esque list of toppings and its skin-on fries) basically McDonald's now?

On Park District grounds and mere feet from the lake, this wraps-and-salad shack has an idyllic location that can't be beat. Bring the pooch and grab a picnic table in the sand or on the shaded patio, but make sure you're seated comfortably: The service lags (and is sometimes curt). Still, if you're prepared to chill out for about 30 minutes until you get your delicious pesto chicken wrap; smoked jerk turkey wrap; or the housemade beignets, you'll be just fine.

It's tough to critique an Italian newcomer in a neighborhood with only one other similar option (Pilsen might have a plethora of taquerias, but Little Italy it ain't). Still, while former Caro Mio chef Cesar Pineda might have honorable ambitions, they're tough to appreciate when the food is mediocre and the room already seems dated. Standards like calamari and arancini are fine but not memorable, lobster gets lost amid filler in its ravioli pocket, and braciole is both tough and underseasoned. Barring a drastic turnaround, the surrounding taquerias should remain unscathed by this competition.

In addition to pastas and filled-to-order cannolis, this Italian deli serves all the essential sandwiches: chicken parm, eggplant parm, caprese, meatball. And since this place doubles as a grocery store, it also sells the ingredients you need to recreate the sandwiches at home.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 49, X49, 70

column7: Joy Yee has marked its 16th year by relocating one storefront east in the Chinatown strip mall and putting the Japanese-leaning Joy Yee Plus in its place. It's a pretty cool space: Tiny iridescent tiles cover every inch of wall, and wooden ceiling treatments ripple like curvy white waves over the room. But the food isn't nearly as interesting. The stuff from the sushi bar is fine, but that other Japanese staple, kushiyaki (a.k.a. grilled kebabs), isn't as successful, and the pho is sad and weak. So stick to the fro-yo, which is creamy, tart, balanced—everything Asian-style fro-yo should be.

With a counter made from recycled corrugated steel and walls neatly decorated with National Geographic covers, this is one of the few cheap-eats destinations that can honestly be described as cute. The piled-high sopes and tortas heading out of the kitchen are pretty good looking, too, layered with enough avocado and hot sauce to hide pasty masa and dryish chicken. And the pastry case showcases rice pudding and tequila-mousse that are almost too pretty to eat. But it's the fish and shrimp tacos (lightly battered, juicy) that really got us taking this place seriously.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Vegetarian-friendlyGood for groups

column7: Maher Chebaro is a man who loves condiments. So while the only thing on the menu at his late-night Lakeview storefront is falafel—greaseless, if a bit dry—it's the salad bar visit that comes with each falafel pita or bowl that makes this place well worth a visit. There, toum (emulsified roasted garlic), sweet bulghur salad, spicy pickled ginger and creamy tabouli easily hide the falafel's minor shortcomings—and then some.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151, 156

column7: Eating at Raul Arreola's follow-up to Mixteco Grill can be like being on the receiving end of a Mexican-food assembly line—a good assembly line, but still. Among the dishes that taste thrown together is the mole manchamantales, a sauce that, here, can lack complexity; the fish tacos, which are sometimes wet; and the tres leches cake, which is sometimes dry. Don't get it twisted: This is still good food. But if you're expecting the surprisingly delicious flavors that come out of the kitchen at Mixteco, you should either lower your expectations, or stick to the original.

After pulling the plug on a massive, three-year project in River North, Jason Paskewitz decided to open this neighborhood bistro and give the people what they want: comforting, familiar food, mostly impeccably prepared. Steak frites rise above bistro-standard status thanks to the incredibly tender hanger cut and the pool of marrow-rich bordelaise. The house burger is a juicy, messy thing tucked into a hearty pretzel bun. The crab cake packs in more plump crab meat than perhaps any in town, retaining sweet moisture while its edges are crisped and golden. And when you can end with a crème bržlée that is so exemplary—from the satisfying crack of its sugar top to the velvety vanilla custard beneath—it reminds us that in times like these, the tried and true can actually stand out.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 73, 74

column7: Hot dogs are once again making a go of it in the former Lincoln Park Rockstar Dogs location. Unlike the previous tenant, however, this operation is decidedly no-frills. The Polish char is a better bet than the wimpy hot dog or greasy fries, and puck-tough burgers should be avoided. But don't discount the place entirely— when you take into account a 4am weekend closing time and dirt-cheap prices, the food suddenly seems much more palatable.

In a city that boasts as many steakhouses as crooked politicians, it's saying something that a national chain can still pack 'em in. Capital does so by sticking to the tried-and-true formula. In fact, close your eyes and picture a characteristic steakhouse—cushy leather banquettes in money-green, attentive servers who know their cuts, martinis in icy glasses and fist-sized crab cakes—and you've just about nailed it. So if you're gonna go classic, drop the plastic. A dry-aged porterhouse with a lobster alongside tastes better than those shoes you've been eyeing.
column8: Private party room(s)Notable wine listGood for dining at barGood for groups

column7: Don't discount that falafel sitting under the heat lamp—stuffed into a pita and topped with some tahini, it is, surprisingly, the best thing this stark takeout shop has to offer. Of course, that's unfortunately not saying very much. The baba is oddly chunky, the shawarma is dry, and the kebabs are tough (perhaps having spent some time under heat lamps as well). Still, with the closest restaurants around here being a McDonald's and a Go Roma, without that falafel sandwich you'd be doing much worse.

Chef Randal Jacobs's crispy-pork-and-peach flatbread is simultaneously sweet, peppery and creamy. His fried dough, dipped into a thick pesto, is addictive. And his smoked chicken with sweet corn panna cotta tastes like summer. And yet his best dish is a spinach salad with molten egg and chicharrones. That's right: a salad. It takes a pretty special chef to make salad so appealing, and Jacobs is just that kind of guy. Think about it: If he can convince you that salad can be decadent, what can't he do?
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 36, 156

column7: The Bad Apple advertises that it proudly serves burgers made with beef from Pat La Frieda, a wholesale butcher who's been operating out of Manhattan for nearly a century. That's supposed to be a mark of excellence for the burgers, but without the bells and whistles of the various toppings, the burgers actually aren't all that impressive. Likewise, a "beer-can chicken" sandwich, a chickpea salad and a starter of house-cured salmon are serviceable but not memorable. (The skin-on fries, crisped to a deep brown and liberally salted, were the sole standout.) Couple this with a far from cozy room, and it's tough figuring out why the place is packed.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for dining at barLate-night diningFireplace

column7: You'll find the usual array of staples at this Greektown mainstay, from spreads like tzatziki and taramasalata to gyros platters and moussaka. There are twists here and there (you can order the requisite flaming saganaki studded with shrimp), but not much will surprise you. To us, the biggest draw is the service. From the host with a genuine smile who sat our party to the fatherly waiter who made wonderful wine suggestions and nudged us to finish the food on our plates, we felt like we were in caring hands throughout our entire meal—a refreshing change from the snippy service we've received at other restaurants on this strip.
column8: Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyLate-night dining
column144: El: Blue to UIC Halsted. Bus: 8, 20, 126

column7: Chuy Valencia's brightly hued, subterranean Mexican restaurant is not the least bit serious—it's more underground dinner party than stuffy exercise in fine dining. Except you'd be hard pressed to go to a dinner party with food like this: Memelas—masa tarts—are filled with smoky black-bean puree and goat cheese where queso fresco would otherwise be; meaty hunks of halibut make for a rustic ceviche; and hanger steak comes out rare, with a brilliant guajillo-chile sauce. All in all, it's food that conveys the energy and excitement of its 23-year-old chef, but is executed with the craft of someone twice that age.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77, 156

column7: The brothers Omar and Christian Solis are behind this organic-leaning breakfast-and-lunch spot, which manages to be always sunny despite the weather outside. That sunniness no doubt has a beneficial effect on the food. In a crummier room, the Liège waffle would be deemed dry and the thick turkey panino may be dubbed pedestrian. But in such a nice setting, it's easy to overlook those flaws. Besides, if you order right (hint: get the Nanadict, a twist on eggs Benedict that swaps in crisp pupusas for English muffins) there'll be no flaws to overlook.

You'd think, when a joint's menu is 90% chicken and its storefront windows show dozens of butterflied and spice-rubbed birds, that specialty is where it excels. Not always. Perhaps this Albany Park spin-off to Bucktown's popular Pit Stop just doesn't do enough volume yet, but those cooked chickens are drying out sitting on the grill, leaving us searching for a single juicy bite among the dark meat, white meat, pita sandwich and even chicken rice soup. And the cafeteria-quality mac-and-cheese and coleslaw aren't helping matters. All this within blocks of chicken stalwarts like La Brasa Roja, Pollo Asado and Pollo Campero means that Nick perhaps should've stuck with Bucktown, where the competition just isn't as fierce.

Its menu might be narrow in focus, but this new empanada-and-coffee shop from the Las Tablas clan has an ambitious aim of spreading Colombian culture. Handmade wares, packaged foods, CDs of popular Colombian bands and fair-trade coffee are imported from Colombia, but (thankfully) the empanadas are made fresh on-site. The pocket itself is nice and crisp (if slightly greasy), but while the roasted veggie empanada packs plenty of flavor, you'll want to liven up the bland mashed potato-shredded beef version with the grass-green housemade salsa. Rich, fried foods coupled with sticky-sweet desserts (many with thick dulce de leche) don't make for a light lunch, but the potent coffee should help perk you up after a quick snack stop.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76, 77

column7: Mexican food has been served in this location before (the space was formerly home to Fajita Grill), but never Mexican food like this. Here, the salsas are complex, the moles nuanced and the meats expertly cooked. Perhaps the best the kitchen has to offer is the mole dona esperanza, a savory and spicy sauce that heightens any meat it comes into contact with (but especially pork). Runner up: the impossibly tender carne asada, which is offered with a mild but flavorful ranchero sauce and a layer of melted—and completely unnecessary—cheese.

At this tiny, 12-seat sushi joint, the nigiri is fresh, the gyoza are crispy and the prices are, for the most part, spot-on. But when it comes to the signature maki, the focus is more on crazy sauces and combinations than on the fish itself. The mango sauce on the Dark Knight Roll, along with mango in the roll, is so overpowering there may as well not be any tuna in it; the intriguing BLT roll doesn't offer much beyond bacon. Still, with solid basics and incredibly friendly service, it's worth keeping a menu around for delivery. (Eating in, however, probably isn't worth the wait.)
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 66, 70

column7: Chef Mauro Mafrici has been known in New York for years, thanks to his now-shuttered Soho restaurant, Lo Scalco. He's taken control of the restaurant in the Rafaello Hotel, where he's serving breakfast, lunch and Italian takes on seafood for dinner.

Breakfast at Rick Bayless's new baby is quiet perfection: a cup of masterfully concocted hot chocolate, a flaky egg empanada, one hell of a sugar-and-cocoa-coated churro. Lunch here is no less delicious, but it's a frenzy: Lines extend out the door for tortas filled with fatty, crispy pork carnitas and La Quercia prosciutto. The crowds keep up at dinner, when caldos like braised-short-rib soup and chicken stew with toothsome posole are the ideal prelude toÉanother cup of rich hot chocolate and a churro. It's nice when things come full circle.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 65

column7: After 40 years of slinging kosher fish out of his seafood shop Good Morgan, Aharon Morgan expanded next door and gave chef Erik Williams (Volo, BIN 36) the license to do what's yet to be done on Devon: contemporary kosher. Lightly seared escolar, a buttery super white tuna, is set off by an awesome combo of citrus, shaved fennel and ginger. For a main course, escolar pops up again, this time slathered in miso that caramelizes to a crust on a cedar plank over the grill. A "hot slaw" of braised cabbage and fennel adds that little something extra, just as the mango chutney does for eggplant hush puppies and plump shiitake do for the otherwise standard miso soup. The place would benefit from a little more atmosphere (entrées in the low $20s need music and dimmer lighting), but that minor quibble doesn't change the fact that you can't kosher food this good anywhere else. And if you can? Mazel tov.

This Lakeview location of the Texas-based franchise is basically Baskin-Robbins: Italian Edition, but aside from the color palette—faded pastels and the incumbent sterility—that's not necessarily a bad thing. Yes, the gelato lacks the thick consistency of the authentic stuff, but it's creamy, melty and comes in some deeply delicious flavors (pistachio and sea-salt caramel are both worth trying). The frequently rotating selection means more adventurous flavors like black-pepper olive oil make an appearance just often enough to keep things from going full-on 31 Flavors.
column144: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151, 156

column7: When yet another cupcake shop opens, the correct approach is not to complain: It's to compare. This new Loop shop is a tiny sliver of a storefront, similar to the Gold Coast's More. And the frosting shots on the counter can't help but bring to mind that other downtown cupcakery, Sugar Bliss. But the mom-and-daughter owners and the familiar flavors—airy vanilla cake with sugary frosting; moist, deeply-red red velvet; old-fashioned, not-too-chocolately chocolate—remind us most of Molly's, with a touch of More's sophistication.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington/Wells

column7: If you're going to get a pannenkoeken (crêpe-like pancake) here—and that's what you came for, right?—it may as well be the one topped with salami and cheese. Like the rest of the pannenkoeken, it's pretty unattractive, but because the salami has a greasy, meaty punch to it, it's likely to be the most successful dish you order. The rest of the menu—pedestrian eggs, soft waffles—isn't worth your time. For that matter, some of the other Dutch dishes may disappoint as well. Because while food of this nationality may be a novelty, at the end of the day it's simple, unremarkable diner food just the same.

Loop lunch standards are already pretty low, but this mini-chain deli drags them even lower. Sandwich meat (turkey, pastrami from Manny's) is sliced wisp-thin (perhaps to match its thin flavor), and the flimsy sandwich bread (honey wheat, marble rye) can't handle the quantity of meat. Trying to make up for the sandwiches' shortcomings with Original Rainbow Cone—the two share the space—yields only badly mixed shakes and the curiously beloved eponymous five-flavor monstrosity. The quality of the orange sherbet and chocolate, pistachio, Palmer House and strawberry ice creams on the cone isn't very good, but that's beside the point. With so much wrong with the flavor combination, who has time to complain about texture?
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake

column7: Until judges resolve Lettuce Entertain You's trademark-infringement lawsuit against Sean Tehrani, the owner of this salad-and-sandwich spot, the banner outside this place will read let us be: name pending. And that legal battle will likely be the most interesting thing about this place. Because, unfortunately, the 14 varieties of mostly organic salads (available in one giant size only, packed with enough butter lettuce or mixed greens to almost merit the high price tag), the handful of sandwiches (smoky bacon on dry foccacia) and the healthy-tasting soups here aren't sustaining our interest.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 22, 36

column7: After opening three New York City locations, this late-night taco-and-tequila parlor has entered the Chicago market, ostensibly bringing something to the scene that we don't already have. The tacos are indeed original—carnitas tacos come with cool coleslaw and rich peanuts; crispy estilo Baja tacos come with an aioli spicy enough to make you sweat—but the rest of the wares (including the much-hyped cocktails) are inconsistent. But when you taste chef Patricio Sandoval's flans, you'll be convinced that despite the growing pains, this place has something going for it. Who knows? Maybe New York has something to teach Chicago about Mexican food after all.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand; Blue, Green, Pink, Orange to Clark/Lake. Bus: 11, 22, 156

column7: Uptown's latest sushi joint is a contemporary space (aside from the industrial carpeting) with sweet service and an enormous menu. Sashimi and nigiri proved to be an unimaginative collection of tasteless tuna, yellowtail and red snapper. Cooked dishes, such as roast duck, carried more flavor—but it wasn't necessarily a good flavor. It's the cream-cheese filled maki rolls that most BYOBers are ordering anyway: If this is your thing, just avoid anything with the mealy ahi tuna, and maybe you'll like it as much as they do.

column60: brunch Sun 11:45pm-3:30pm, Sun/Mon 11:45 am-11pm, Weds-Fri 11:45 am-1am, Sat 11:45 am-2am
column144: El: Brown and Purple lines to Merchandise Mart, Blue line to Clark/Lake, Red line to Grand. Bus: Wells 37

column7: For anyone oblivious to the charms of Mongolian barbecue—or afraid of ending up with a bowl of oddly flavored mush—here are some suggestions for a fail-safe FTG experience: (1) Brown rice, not white. (2) Forget the meats—the tempeh, Quorn (mushroom meat), tofu, seitan and egg are all much tastier. (3) Sauce with one ladle of yellow curry, one ladle of vindaloo, a half ladle of chile paste, a half ladle of sesame soy and a spoonful of fresh jalapeño. (4) Just before handing over your masterpiece to be cooked, add a heaping spoonful of chopped peanuts and a stick signaling for roti bread. Then all that's left to do is to head back to your seat and start sucking down that tasty mojito.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Pink, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison/Wabash; Red, Blue to Monroe

column7: Roti sandwiches seem like the thing to get at a place called Roti. But trust us and ignore them. The grilled meat (chicken or steak) is perfectly fine, and with all the sauces you can put on it (cucumber-yogurt; red-pepper-aioli), you can definitely make it taste good. But the specialty here is the falafel. It is perhaps the least-authentic falafel in the city—it's got a fluffy, eggy, fritterlike consistency—but it is also one of the most ethereal.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

column7: Like french fries, probiotic frozen yogurt is one food group on which everyone is a self-proclaimed expert. So while we could tell you the tart stuff at Yogen Früz, an international chain that has opened its third Chicago location in the South Loop, is a bit icy, and the chocolate flavor is unevenly churned, and the smoothies are kind of watery, we'd honestly prefer to let the Red Mango and Berry Chill aficionados duke it out among themselves.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red, Blue to Jackson

column7: Reinvention is usually a restaurant's last gasp, but in Green Dolphin's case the conversion from white tablecloth to pizza joint has probably saved it. Pizza never gets old, especially the white pizza topped with thin slices of potato, which is crisp and made aromatic with healthy doses of rosemary. The red-sauce pies aren't bad either, but the main difference between the two camps—that is, the mild tomato sauce—makes the whole thing a little soggy. As it turns out, sticking with the white food and avoiding the red is a good way to navigate the rest of the menu, too: The housemade gnochhetti in lamb ragù is rubbery and boring, but the all-white plate of tilapia topped with artichokes has flavors that are simultaneously bright and salty and creamy and rich.

Is it us, or does every place that calls itself a "pancake house" put out flapjacks as dense and heavy as manhole covers? We'd just as soon make our own pancakes as eat them here, but the thin, overstuffed housemade blintzes and juicy, house-roasted ham are a different story. So is the perfectly sassy service, which—unless you're living with a particularly trying girlfriend/mother/sister—is pretty much irreplicable.
column93: The Original Alps Restaurant & Pancake House
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80, X80, 82

column7: Fusion gets a bad rap, and Havana, which carried over the happening bar scene from its former tenant, Mambo Grill, isn't doing much for the cause. The problem isn't so much the fusion of ingredients as the ingredients themselves: a dry block of lechon in the torta cubano; fishy shrimp in the seafood curry; icy tequila sorbet. Stick with a traditional dish, such as the tender sirloin steak (lomo salteado), and a mojito: The cocktails are the only things in the place that are muddled in a good way.
column144: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart

column7: Husband-and-wife pastry chefs Jennifer and Eric Estrella go back to basics—pumpkin-spice breakfast bread, lemon-blueberry scones, apple pie, malt cake with dulce-de-leche frosting—at this Wicker Park bakeshop.

How do you explain the popularity of a restaurant serving a disappointing meal for two for $100? That's what we asked ourselves here, where we experienced moldy-tasting black truffles scattered around crab-filled piquillo peppers and venison chops as tough and leathery as Helen Thomas. Okay, so maybe our scoop of caramel-goat-cheese gelato was somehow icy while everyone else's was creamy, and maybe we were the sole diners thinking that the Sirius XM smooth jazz was better suited for a Viagra commercial. But when the bill arrived and we saw that this baffling meal was $100 (at a BYO, mind you)? Call us crazy, but we don't think we're the only ones who'd feel swindled.
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 49, X49, 74

column7: The new chef at this restaurant (which has probably set a record for highest chef turnover in the least amount of time) is Dale Levitski, who has rolled out a new menu and is crowdsourcing the interior design.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 9, 11, 74

column7: At this Wicker Park sibling to Tango Sur, the lights are dim, the mojitos are strong, the wine list has tons of inexpensive by-the-glass options—just the right setup for a romantic dinner. But plan to pay more attention to your date than to the food, which has many more misses (flavorless, underseasoned steaks; lackluster seafood and chicken) than hits. For best results, go with the flaky empanadas filled with juicy beef and the parillada para uno, a skillet teeming with on-the-bone short ribs and charred sweetbreads, which will serve you, your date and then some.
column144: El: Blue to Damen or Division. Bus: 49, 50, 70

column7: It's been Middle Eastern joint after Middle Eastern joint in this space, and at the rate they've all closed, you'd think restaurateurs would take the hint and try something else. But if ever a place has had a chance of survival, this is it. The service is friendly, the room is warm, and the food has all the simultaneously bright and savory flavors that good Middle Eastern food should have. Of particular note is the lahmacun, the sprightly fattoush salad and the tender chicken shawarma—but if you want it, hurry. In this space, these things don't last long.
Simple, straightforward—ahem, pure—café fare, such as a chicken-pesto flatbread, tuna melt or "raw" salad, stays constant as this space alternates between coffee shop and sports bar.

This coffeehouse could probably survive on just the drinks alone—the coffee is smooth and rich (and that's not even the stuff from the Clover brewer), and the aromatic teas are served with royalty-like ceremony. But we wouldn't be writing about this place if it didn't have such an ambitious food menu. The beet salad can hang with the best in the city, and the house-roasted meats are turned into inspired sandwiches like lamb-and-polenta with mint chimmichurri and portobello mushroom with a heady thyme-infused cheese. Plenty of coffeehouses call themselves cafés—this place actually has the chops to back that claim up.

Le Méditerranée fills an underserved niche in Chicago food—classic, Western European fare—but it has the capacity to disappoint even the most unsophisticated European palates. A pork chop arrives flanked by a bright pile of sweet bell peppers and another pile of crispy potatoes, but the pork itself is too dry to eat (and there's no sauce to help it). Steak au poivre fares better, but again, the sides—fresh green beans, frites—outshine the main component. Francophiles, in other words, should go to a different city for the French fix. May we suggest Paris?
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Roaming chef Eric Aubriot has landed at another deli/takeout shop, this time one that he co-owns (with chef John Mega). Right now, the grocery selection is pretty sparse: a few pastas, olive oils and sausages. Behind the counter, they're slinging a handful of simple salads (all of which are vegetarian) and sandwiches (cured salmon with dill cream cheese, for instance), but we were most intrigued by the eggless cookie dough in the fridge. It's meant to be eaten raw, and if you like the taste of butter whipped with chocolate, hazelnuts and peanut butter, you're in luck.

column144: El: Purple Line Express, Brown Line to Chicago

column7: Rida Shahin's soft and chewy salted ciabatta is good enough that you could eat it all by itself and have a perfectly satisfying lunch. And in fact, until this bread baker opened his storefront bakery, his bread (sold wholesale) was the only thing he had to offer. But now he serves sandwiches and a full line of pastries, from crispy-and-chewy chocolate chip cookies to nuanced apricot-cardamom tarts. So you can go and have a nice lunch in the café if you want to. But a word to the wise: Buying a couple of loaves and taking them home makes the moment last longer.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: Cheddar fries didn't sound like something we would want with shawarma. Until we learned that this was Merkts cheddar, served with burning hot, crispy fries. As it turns out, it was the dryish chicken shawarma—beefed up with hummus, carrot salad and a burrito's worth of other condiments and served in a pita or soft, doughy laffa flatbread—we didn't necessarily need with our cheddar fries.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells; Blue to LaSalle; Red to Jackson.

column7: Uptown's new pizza shop isn't much to look at, and, unfortunately, the food follows in that direction: A thin-crust margherita pie was a bit greasy but saved by sporadic bites of basil and an accompanying plate of tiny hot peppers. The meatball sandwich fared better but still fell short of special. If anything, this spot may work best for those stumbling out of the next-door Carol's Pub. Who knows? If they're drunk enough, this may taste like the best pizza they've ever had.

Owner David Lipschutz and executive chef Jonadab Silva have reopened Jacky's Bistro, and they're paying homage to the original (now departed) chef, Jacky Pluton, in dishes like classic roast chicken and bouillabaise. Silva may be the chef at vegetarian Blind Faith Café, but that doesn't get in the way of his unimaginably rich short ribs and crisp-skinned trout, stuffed with sweet apples and onions. Sure, the desserts feel dated—but the room's understated and comfortable in a way that might have you lingering anyway.
column144: Bus: 201, 206. Metra: Union Pacific N to Evanston (Central St)

column7: Stephan Outrequin Quaisser says he doesn't want Lincoln Square locals to have to trek downtown to celebrate a special occasion. So he's taken over Tallulah and brought in chef Brad Phillips to execute a laundry list of French classics. Plump sweetbreads arrive with caramelized onion ravioli; pan-roasted poussin arrives with plenty of buttery pan sauce and a handful of chanterelles; and the veal cheeks are rich enough to get elected mayor of New York. A textbook crème bržlée and a perfect apple tarte Tatin with freshly whipped cream end things on a high note. The only thing the place needs now is some people to do some celebrating.

Uncommonly thick Nutella shakes, fries with truffle salt—where does the low-brow end and high-end begin at Eddie Lakin's burger shop? The answer is that it's intertwined, because the most crucial, highfalutin thing Lakin does—grinding his own meat and hand-cutting the potatoes for his fries—infects almost every dish. The burgers actually taste beefy, and the fries are textbook examples in frying. This means it's a little hard to see the place as what it's trying to emulate (those quick, surly, greasy Vienna shops never get it this right), but that's okay. Lakin is putting most of his efforts into his product, not the surroundings. And ultimately that's all anybody will remember about a meal here anyway.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 201, 205. Metra: Union Pacific N to Evanston (Davis St)

column7: It's ironic that a takeover from a spiritual idol can suck the soul right out of a restaurant, but that's essentially what happened with Alice & Friends Vegetarian Cafe. Recently, Supreme Master Ching Hai brought the restaurant into her Loving Hut fold, an international chain of vegan franchises that contribute funds back to the Master herself. The decor is so stark it recalls a dentist's office, but the food—meatless bibimbap, mandoo—is exactly the same.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 147

column7: If it weren't for the large grand-opening sign, it'd be hard to believe this grungy, no-frills crêpe-and-coffee shop hadn't been around for years. The assemblage of international patrons speaking in foreign tongues gives the place a youth hostel–lounge vibe, which, unfortunately, the crêpes and Illy coffee match. Sticking with sweet fillings (such as chocolate-caramel-pecan) is a better bet than the low-grade savory ones (e.g., egg-bacon-cheddar), but even that won't save the crêpes themselves, which are a tad thick and heavy. Here's hoping some of the European patrons can offer the owners a few pointers.

There's something refreshing about the idea of serving Spanish flavors in a three-course framework (as opposed to tapas), but considering the highlights of this menu are all in appetizers, you might want to go the small-plates route after all. Chicken-chorizo croquetas are addictive, snacky things, and the pan con tomate (grilled bread served with soft-roasted tomatoes and garlic) benefitted from a really great olive oil, and tons of it. Entrées (serrano-wrapped cod, steaks) got old fast and would have been more palatable in—we hate to say it—a smaller, tapas-sized portion.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

column7: Mexican-European fusion works. It works at Mundial, it works at Mexique, it works at Amelia's. But when it doesn't work, it really, really doesn't work. Unfortunate case in point: this minimalist BYOB that recently popped up on Division. The kitchen has a lot of creative energy but can't seem to rein it in: Sea bass was covered in no fewer than three clashing sauces, the shrimp in the ceviche was mushy, and sad-looking greens dominated a beet salad. And a dessert gelatin? It took a knife to saw through, which means you work for it—but it doesn't do the same for you.

The most interesting thing on the menu at this barbecue joint is the appearance of burnt ends, the crunchy, smoky bits that fall off the tips of a brisket when you slice it. Burnt ends are a Kansas City "invention," and seeing them outside of that part of the country is like spotting a unicorn. At Brand, the little guys are thrown on top of mac and cheese and mixed into a burger, and both dishes are decent. Everything else, however—from the pulled pork to the brisket—veers toward underseasoned and overcooked. So we'd recommend avoiding this one—when a burger is the best thing at a barbecue joint, it's time for a new pitmaster.

Someone chopped Kitsch'n River North in half and opened this place in the other part of it. It wasn't a bad idea—this is a huge building in a weird area that doesn't seem fit for much besides after-work eating and drinking. The execution leaves much to be desired, though, starting with the imbalanced cocktails, continuing with unappealing mains (mushy, underseasoned Kobe burger and steak; carb-on-carb potato "ravioli") and ending with an icy trio of ice creams. The short wine list (all sustainable, biodynamic or organic) and chipper servers are just about the only reliable factors.
column8: Late-night diningNotable wine listGood for dining at barVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 8, 11, 66, 132

column7: Bill Kim and Yvonne Cadiz-Kim's follow-up to Urban Belly tries hard to evoke the streets, both in its interior design and its food. But this is "urban" as seemingly defined by Disney: sanitized, toothless and scrubbed free of any grime. Some of the food is just as gutless: The Korean barbecue could use more punch, the tostones more chimichurri and the Asian meatball sandwich fewer noodles. On the other hand, the somen noodles with shrimp and corn chips are brilliant, the brussels sprouts with chorizo are addictive, and the soft serve (topped with Mindy Segal's brownies) will transport you to your Dairy Queen days—which, admittedly, is not the same as transporting you to the streets of the Bronx. But it's a start.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyBYOBKid-friendlyCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groups
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49, X49, 56, 73

column7: Don't let the slick look of this new Chinatown sibling to Chi Café fool you—this is not fancy food. In fact, it's pretty typical Hong Kong–style Cantonese, and to tell you the truth, we're not exactly sure why every TV-outfitted booth in the place is packed. You might have to be a Hong Kong expat to really appreciate the rice soups, congee and noodles, but we just couldn't get past gristly meat, slimy sauces and blah flavors. We even tried venturing into Taiwanese and Szechuan dishes, but it doesn't look as if we'll be abandoning our favorite Chinatown spots for these either.

There are two ways to do Hearty: You can go the route of extreme gluttony, starting with fried mac-and-cheese squares followed by glorious fried chicken with creamed collard greens. Or you could go the deconstructed route, partaking in a sophisticated beefaroni (no, that's not a contradiction) or a less-creamy (but also somewhat less flavorful) tuna casserole. Whichever route you choose there will be hits and misses, but if you start with a cocktail (all of them are solid) and end with the warm and fragrant New England Indian pudding, it'll be easy to forgive any bumps in the road.
column8: Notable wine listGood for dining at barKid-friendlyFireplace

column7: If you're joining the ranks of countless sushi joints in this city, you better set yourself apart or you'll swim with the fishes (so to speak). Sushi Taiyo, from the owners of Rise and Shine Morida, manages to stand out with terrible-sounding, yet surprisingly delicious, maki like the Kinomi: white fatty tuna and avocado topped with a plump raspberry and raspberry reduction. That tart-and-creamy roll, combined with exquisite sashimi and the Norwegian-ish decor make up for the more forgettable entrées, like fried calamari and bland scallops and mushrooms on rice—both of which are anything but attention-grabbing.

You'll be forgiven for not knowing what to expecting passing by LOKaL. It looks like a mod lounge, but serves Eastern European flavors; it opens daily at 9am, but it's mostly a late-night spot. (After 10pm most nights, live music gives the place a loungy atmosphere.) If you're a fan of anything fat, fried and creamed, though, almost everything here will make sense: Cabbage is shaped into a patty and deeply fried; tender, fatty short ribs are topped with a dollop of goat-cheese cream; and mashed potatoes are stuffed inside thin, delicate dough for classic pierogi. The one dish that will never make sense: the potato pancakes. Anything this dense is just baffling.

Chef-owner John Giannopoulos is behind this late-night Greek char house in Lakeview, where he'll be grilling bone-in rib eye for dinner, preparing souvlaki for lunch and ending both meals with housemade baklava and galaktoboureko, a traditional Greek custard-and-phyllo-dough dessert.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77, 156

column7: If not for the unfortunate storefront location just off the Kennedy Expressway, it'd be easy to forget that this sushi joint is in northwest suburban Des Plaines. Everything about this place oozes authentic, from the waitresses who barely speak a word of English (no worries, menus are in English) to the refreshing signature rolls coming from the chic sushi bar. Don't miss the Kiss of Fire, a roll stuffed with crab meat, avocado and cucumber then topped with red snapper and set on fire tableside.

column144: El: Red to Grand, Brown to Merchandise Mart

column7: It takes about three slices of this cracker-crust pizza to equal the heft of a normal slice, so if you're thinking that a large pie is going to feed four peopleÉwell, think again. This stuff goes down fast and easy, not only because it's thin but because it's got all the right addictive qualities: cheesy, saucy, herbaceous and piled with fresh, organic toppings. The lasagna is mostly cheese, though, so stick to the pies, and maybe the satisfying antipasto salad and, finally, the housemade chocolate cake. You've been eating organic, remember—you've earned a splurge.

The bar that took over the Pontiac space is just that: A bar. With whiskey shots, cheap beer, and quick cocktails. Of course, if you can just drink and not partake in Paul Kahan's tacos, you have more restraint than us.

Giuseppe Scurato (BOKA, Topaz Cafe) finally has a place of his own. And now that he's in charge, he'll be adding some Italian dishes (housemade pastas, etc.) to his American repertoire of dishes like flat iron steaks and seafood.
Michael Kornick (mk) goes downscale with a menu of burgers (topped with everything from pastrami to fried green tomatoes), truffle fries, housemade soda and craft beer.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington; Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 76, 77

column7: Darius Williams's cupcakes don't taste even half as bad as they sometimes appear, and that's a blessing, because the ones topped with grayish Hershey's kisses and splattered with Hershey's Syrup gave us serious pause. (Frankly, so did the disheveled look of the store.) In general, though, these cakes are moist and tender (though sometimes spongy), and whether traditional (red velvet) or dubious (orange Creamsicle), the flavors deliver exactly the taste they promise.
A sprawling menu of sushi, noodles, and entrees like lamb chops with shiitake mushrooms takes off in Logan Square.

It's tapas here, but not just Spanish ones—the menu, designed by chef Antonio Lopez, includes dishes like seared tuna with pink peppercorn and cucumber relish and house-cured salmon with dill, rosemary and cognac. In fact, the most Spanish thing about this place is probably the hours: The menu will be served until 1am.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 65

column7: Former Spacca Napoli pizzaiola Nella Grassano has teamed up with Scott Harris (Mia Francesca) for this Neapolitan-style pizzeria, a second location of which is already in the works.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151, 156

column7: Mother-daughter team Dobra Bielinski and Stasia Hawyrszczuk have opened a second location of their Jefferson Park bakery, where they'll be serving their brand of European sweets: Danishes, cookies, layer cakes and paczki.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72

column7: The owners of Lovely: A Bake Shop have opened a breakfast-all-day restaurant in Lakeview, where the menu runs the gamut from a vegetarian frittata to a flight of bacon.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendlyVegetarian-friendly

column7: Regardless of its chain status, Rock Bottom Brewery has carved out some respect in this town, thanks to local brewmaster Pete Crowley and his arsenal of limited-edition Chicago-only beers. Crowley has made the place a beer-geek destination, but recently the owners decided to invite the wine crowd, sprucing up the eastern half of the joint and rolling out a steaks and chops menu. We'll give them credit for lower prices than nearby steakhouse competition, but the cut corners show: Delmonico steak shows almost no beefiness and lamb chops are flat and flavorless. Crab cakes are perfectly fine, as are two-bite desserts like strawberry cheesecake, but we still left casting wistful glances toward the half of Rock Bottom that remains a pub.

While the aesthetics might recall a slick sushi restaurant, this newcomer trades almost exclusively in crêpes. Sweet ones are thinner and crisp at the edges, filled with straightforward Nutella or berries. Thicker, doughier savory ones span the globe ingredients-wise, but we liked the Thai-ish Spice Up (fried fish, almost overwhelmed by the sheer volume of sweet curry sauce) and Boom Boom Egg (eggs over gently spiced ground chicken).
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsKid-friendly

column7: Americanized Thai food has settled into the appropriate address, in a large contemporary space on DePaul's campus. This second outpost of Duck Walk has the same menu as the Lakeview original: approachable noodle and curry dishes, such as pad kee mao, which gets a bit of flavor from stir-fried Thai basil leaves but doesn't remotely live up to its accompanying fire symbol. A $5.95 lunch box is a good deal any way you look at it and especially in Lincoln Park, even if appetizer portions (like fried bean curd) are small. So if cheap, BYOB and friendly are more important to you than authentic, you'll find little to complain about.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsVegetarian-friendly
column144: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs), Brown to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74

column7: This quick-service fish shack shows some gourmet leanings: It's run by former Hell's Kitchen contestant Tony D'Alessandro, the fish is breaded-and-fried to order, and burgers are made from Angus beef. But don't get it in your head that this is anything other than a dive. You're best off keeping it simple with that fried fish and tartar sauce. Other dishes—crab tostadas, shrimp tacos smothered in mayo and cocktail sauce on a tough grilled tortilla, beet salad in a pool of liquid—don't live up to their aspirations.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156

column7: Technically, this restaurant doubles as a gallery space. But though there's plenty of well-curated art on these walls, there are too many tables in here to make it the kind of place you can pop into and browse. Yet there is an energy of community here, and artists often do come tosit at the bar and talk shop. Makes sense—if you want to foster artistic discussion, it helps to serve solid guacamole, well-seasoned skirt steaks, a nice chicken with housemade poblano mole and Kristoffer's tres leches cake.

Members of the Gudino family will encourage you to take your time. They'll mention this when they drop off perfectly crisp green plantains meant to be drenched in garlicky oil, and again as you're slurping yucca-studded chicken soup. Someone—maybe head cook Maricela or manager Jose—will also tell you to think of this new addition to the Logan/Humboldt merger zone as your home, right around the time they deliver a chicken thigh so thoroughly soaked through with fragrant coconut sauce it falls apart with a glance. From simple stewed pintos to dense bread pudding freckled with raisins, this is homestyle Central American cooking to its core. Bring a bottle of red wine, follow the prodding to sit back and slow down, and the Gudino's namesake (it translates to "Know My Panama") will come through loud and clear.

Nothing can stem the tide of BYOB all-you-can-eat Sushi Paras. The fourth location opened in the former Sushi X location; lunch all-you-can-eat is $15.99, dinner is $18.99, and there's a small fee if you leave anything on your plate, so order judiciously.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 36, 76, 77, 134

column7: This tiny Japanese spot sells all the expected stuff: teriyaki, fried rice, tempura, sushi and maki. But the one thing it doesn't serve is alcohol. (It doesn't allow BYOB, either, so don't even try it.)

The lower-end restaurant in the Elysian Hotel really isn't all that low-end: Chef Jason McLeod has put together a menu comprised of oysters, crudos, charcuterie and plates like duck breast with pickled quince.

Jason McLeod has gone for a seafood bent for the signature restaurant at the Elysian hotel. First courses include dishes such as big fin squid with beets and shiso; main courses include diver scallops with bitter melon and langoustines with crispy pig's tail.

Winning this year's restaurant-that-came-out-of-nowhere award is Kith and Kin, a 100-seat bistro helmed by David Carrier (a Florida transplant) and Andrew Brochu (formerly the chef at Pops for Champagne), where the understated menu includes housemade bratwursts and hand-cut pastas.
column144: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs), Brown to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 73, 74

column7: TK BLURB
column8: Late-night diningOutdoor seatingGood for dining at barNew

column7: This Des Plaines–based bakery turns out traditional European pastries (macarons, petit fours, tarts) in Niles, Arlington Heights, on the South and West sides of Chicago—and now in Wicker Park.

Believe it or not, cream puffs are actually a trend somewhere. Trying to make it happen in Chicago is an escapee from the corporate world named Eddy Lu, who's brought the Japan-based cream-puff phenom to Block 37.
column144: El: Blue to Washington; Red to Lake; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph/Wabash

column7: Pascal Berthoumieux (an alum of Kiki's Bistro, Madame Tartine and one sixtyblue) aims to up the ante on Chicago bistros, so he's serving classic French fare (escargot, coq au vin) with a side of formal Euro-style service.

For his sprawling new restaurant, chef Stephen Wambach has hired big industry names Molly Wismeier (for the wine) and Christine McCabe (pastry). He's also trying to create a name for himself with dishes like crisped duck breast with foie-gras croutons and halibut with caramelized cauliflower.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 36, 62, 65

column7: This near West Side's namesake should tip you off as to the specialty of the house. Here, pozole virgins can try the full spectrum of roja, verde and blanco and determine just which way they swing. Blanco is as basic as it gets (read: a bit boring), while the rojo brings a bit more heat thanks to rusty-red guajillo chiles. Our favorite, the verde, balances the toasty nuttiness of ground pepitas (hulled pumpkin seeds) with bright notes of tomatillos and just-fatty-enough bits of pork for a bowl much more memorable than its canned-pea color would suggest. Each steaming bowl arrives with a side plate of avocado, chopped onions and lime wedges, so doctor to your taste. Just don't miss the crispy chicharron, massive pork rinds fried fresh daily.

After building some buzz recently as the new home of the bacon-wrapped "Tijuana" hotdog (which the owner previously sold from a food cart nearby), it would be easy to visit this Little Village restaurant and go right for the dog. Just be sure not to overlook the excellent pozole, available in rojo, verde or blanco, all with either chicken or pork and only served on weekends. It's the verde that delivers a punch for heat-seekers, with fresh green chiles balanced by bright tomatillos, but the rojo is just as tasty, with more of a roasted pepper flavor. The meat lurking within the broth comes with a bit of bones, so swap them out for a different kind of crunch—raw radishes, crispy chicharron and housemade tortilla chips.

Having moved Fonda del Mar to the fdm space (3908 N Lincoln Ave), the owners here have turned Fonda's original location into a tacqueria. The $2 tacos are offered in a myriad of styles—cochinita pibil, al pastor, Baha-style fish tacos—and are all offered with eight options of housemade salsa.
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 53, 74, 82. Metra: Milwaukee North to Healy.

column7: Pepper steaks, meatloaf, turkey clubs and 10-ounce burgers are the kinds of foods you'll find on this music-obsessed restaurant's menu.
column8: NewGood for groupsKid-friendlyPrivate party room(s)
column144: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Edison Park

column7: Thick handmade tortillas, salsas made-to-order in molcajates, cinnamon-laced coffee. You can get all of that here. Their only purpose, however, is to accompany this restaurant's signature platters of chopped goat meat. As opposed to other birrierias, this goat doesn't touch a consommé until it's plated, when some of the tomato-based broth is spooned over it. At that point, a good dousing of the restaurant's intricate hot sauce, and maybe a squeeze of lime and some onions, is all you need for one of the city's best goat tacos. (Though having a bottle of grapefruit Jarritos on hand doesn't hurt, either.)
column60: Mon, Wed, Thu, Fri 10am–7pm; closed Tue; Sat, Sun 8am–4pm

column7: To say that you get more than you pay for at this dinerish Greek joint is an obscene understatement. It's not just that the portions are huge (the $8 gyros platter is piled about 10 inches high)—it's that the food is well-spiced and fresh. In other words, it's a refreshing change from most Greek spots. And refreshing for vegetarians, too, with its veggie versions of rich moussaka and pastitsio. Not so refreshing: the $11 bottles of wine, where you absolutely do get what you pay for, if not less.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyGood for groups
