column7: If you ever get a hankering for bulgogi and a bacon omelette, this Korean-accented diner hits the spot. Owner Soon Hee Lee (a.k.a. "Susie") is a doting, one-woman show who takes orders, serves them and buses tables, all the while sneaking gingersnap cookies to her younger patrons. Somehow, she also finds time to helm the wok and flattop, turning out airy pajun (Korean pancakes) slathered with a fiery jalapeño sauce, soul-satisfying bibimbap and a spicy, sweet Chop Chae—a sautéed mix of vegetables, beef and glass noodles perfumed with ginger and hit with a touch of pancake syrup.

Race through the housemade cream of tomato soup, flanked with sweet, housebaked white bread. Plow through that merely serviceable salad. And if you can't bring yourself to rush through the Oaxacan pork sandwich—and we wouldn't blame you, as it's a great sandwich, the pork and caramelized onions marrying in perfect harmony—consider taking half of it to go and savoring it at home. Because the real reason to come here is dessert—big cookies overstuffed with chocolate and oats; luscious peanut-butter truffles—and you're going to want to get to it as soon as you can.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: From Vito and Nick's in Ashburn to Pat's Pizza in Lincoln Park, it seems every neighborhood has its favored thin-crust pie. And for 48 years, Bridgeport's preference has been for Phil's. Unfortunately, in 2008, it closed its original wood-paneled spot on Halsted, leaving those years of hard-earned personality behind for a boring dining room a few blocks away. Luckily, the owners took their old-school Blodgett ovens with them, and the crispy exterior crust, chewy interior crust and hunks of fennel-flecked sausage honor the tasty tradition of the original.
column8: Kid-friendlyVegetarian-friendlyLate-night diningGood for groups

column7: Though this West Loop red-sauce-and-pizza joint is "Home of the Giant Slice," you're better off skipping those monstrous doughy triangles and focusing on the sandwiches instead. The moist, softball-size meatballs nestled in focaccia and slathered with a spicy-sweet red sauce are the best; the crispy fried eggplant parmigiana, oozing with provolone, is a close second.

The name of this restaurant loosely translates as "with the Guidance of God," which is apt, because even though there's a drab cabbie-joint vibe in the dining room, the dishes coming out of the kitchen are divine. Blessed plates include keema, minced beef bathed in rich, brown butter gravy perfumed with ginger and cardamom, and chapli, kebabs studded with coriander seeds and fired up with red and green chilies. Minced chicken kebabs sport a crispy crust and a succulent interior.

The Hackney's crew opened this Mexican sibling to cater to the Columbia students and sprinkling of office workers in Printers Row. The former should be happy with the low prices and accessible gringo fare like quesadillas and burritos, while the latter can unwind over lunch with a cold cerveza. A handful of fillings can be had in tacos, tortas or burritos, and while the chicken and steak were consistently dry, the al pastor fared better, nice and juicy with a bit of kick. Specials, like a recent chicken posole, help set the place apart from Mexichains.

Blink, and you might miss this cigar-box-sized Cuban carryout spot tucked away off a dusty strip of Clybourn Avenue. That would be a shame, especially if you're looking for a morning pick-me-up. Potent café con leche and cortaditos are the perfect pair with guava and cream cheese pastries, best enjoyed at one of the counter stools while waiting on a lunch order for later. Best bets include the meaty Cuban sandwich or the Guajrito, essentially a Puerto Rican jibarito that piles marinated nickle-thin steak, grilled onions and cheese onto crispy green plantains.

This addition to Broadway's Ethiopian strip is often overlooked, maybe because in comparison to the tomes found at the nearby competition, the menu seems small at just under a dozen options (plus five more if you get there early enough for breakfast). The Abyssinia special, a pureed stew of beans, onions, garlic and peppers, is the best of the vegetarian dishes—it has layers of flavors that betray its pedestrian looks. But the earthy yellow peas, spicy lentils and juicy lamb are nothing to sneeze at. And because there's not much else to order, there's no excuse not to order it all.

You don't have to claim a bunk at the adjacent Hostel International to get your hands on one of this café's ridiculously good Cuban sandwiches. Sure, sides of roasted eggplant, cannellini bean salad and briny artichokes are flavorful, but there's no confusion over the star of the show: The Cubano's crusty bread is toasted just right, its roast pork juicy, its pickles thick, and its mustard and gooey cheese plentiful. And once it's devoured, only a potent cortadito will keep you from calling the café's comfy couch home for the day.
column144: El: Brown, Orange, Pink and Purple to Library; Red and Blue to Jackson

column7: When you don't feel like Szechuan tendon or chicken feet, and you're in need of honest crab Rangoon, try this 40-year-old Cantonese spot where everything from the paper lanterns to the zodiac placemats is stereotypically perfect. Egg rolls are crispy pockets of five-spice pork, and pineapple chicken has enough sour to offset the sweet. For a dose of different, get the see jee som kow, barbecue pork, chicken, shrimp and vegetables caramelized in black bean garlic sauce on a sizzling skillet.

It seems every neighborhood has its go-to Thai takeout spot (or three), and this is Edgewater's. Here though, Pad Thai gets a bit more salty fish sauce to balance out what is usually a sticky sweet concoction and the basil chicken sports a rich brown sauce nuanced with anise and pepper, making both a cut above the usual suspects. Upping the ante even more is the presence of "E-san" (a.k.a. Issan or Northeastern) sausage, the grill-marked, crunchy-skinned pork links perfumed with lemongrass, ginger and pepper.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136, 151

column7: It's purposefully unclear whether the name of this California-based chain refers to the long, bright-white counter that runs along one side of the room or the tally of possible burger combinations you'll start keeping the minute you look at the menu. There are about 50 choices of ingredients to dress the burgers with, and all of them work, mainly because the patties themselves are well-cooked and juicy (even the turkey burger, amazingly). When it comes to sides and drinks, decision making becomes much easier: Sweet-potato fries, onion strings and milk shakes are a no-brainer.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

column7: Don't be deterred by signs touting char-burgers, gyros and hot dogs. Those holdovers from this spot's former life as an American grill only obscure the current main attraction: huaraches. Three bucks gets you a massive, oval-shaped masa patty filled with a thin layer of beans and topped with your choice of classics (our favorites are the juicy pastor and the chorizo-potato combo). The late-night hours (midnight during the week, 4am weekends) are a draw for boozehounds looking to sober up with the massive platter of huevos rancheros with beans, rice and tortillas—a steal at $4.50.

The fat spliff Bob Marley sucks down in the charcoal drawing hanging near the entrance isn't the only thing smokin' at this South Side shack. In fact, the star of the smoker is the jerk chicken, its crispy skin dotted with allspice and its moist hunks of bone-in meat resting on a bed of toothsome beans and fluffy rice. Blackened catfish, bathed in the same fiery rub and smoke, flakes off in buttery hunks, as does the tender, curry-perfumed goat. Making like Marley beforehand is one way to have room to try it all.

When it's warm outside and its patio is open, this tiny restaurant's seating capacity triples. But no matter the weather, the kitchen (on view from the dining room) remains mind-bogglingly tiny. That is, it's mind-boggling when you think about the never-ending number of dishes this place puts out. Blue Elephant offers straight-up Thai food like summer rolls, pot stickers and a delicious bowl of vaguely sweet Massaman curry served with roti, but you can get that stuff anywhere. Order the aromatic bowl of pasta sauced with green curry and topped with salmon, and you'll know that the more interesting fusion dishes are the way to go.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Outdoor seatingVegetarian-friendly

column7: New management of this old-school pizzeria-bar promises to clean up the worn decor (including a much-needed overhaul of the bathrooms), but it vows to leave the well-known thin-crust pizza as is. The pies themselves are pretty standard stuff, so liven things up with toppings like Italian beef and ricotta. Not much new ground is covered by the wings-and-burger-based pub-grub menu, but it's tough to beat the combo of the no-frills, come-as-you-are attitude, a satellite dish that picks up every game known to man and a decent beer list.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingLate-night dining

column7: The Roscoe Village spin-off of the wildly popular Lincoln Park original, John's Place dishes up a similar polyglot mix of comfort-food basics: hummus and veggies, carne asada with chipotle mashed potatoes, chicken pot pie. If only it did it better. A Roscoe Burger was overcooked and topped with desiccated bacon jerky, while an entrée of teriyaki salmon was oddly bland under its sweet soy glaze. Still, desserts like a gooey toffee blondie and warm, solicitous servers go a long way. Note to stroller-pushers: Your dominance of this territory means no stink-eye from romancing tables of two.
column144: El: Brown to Addison. Bus: 49, X49, 152

column7: There's not much competition in the corner of Naperville where this hotel restaurant resides, which means that chef Jimmy Sneed could probably do anything he wanted and still stay in business. Yet despite this, some of the appetizers are inspired: A butternut squash soup is supple but not cloying, and the signature sugartoads have a sweet, buttery flavor. Entrées can get a little lazy, though—the short ribs and the crab cakes are both well executed but nothing creative, and most entrées are plated with the same sides: crisp haricots verts. Essentially, it's a lot more like hotel food than it should be to achieve destination status.

Opening chefs Karen Nicolas and Wendy Carreira have been replaced by Jared Case, previously in charge of Marche's kitchen, but plenty of their seasonal Southern-tinged dishes remain, including salt-cod hush puppies, smoky oxtail hoppin' john, bacon-wrapped trout, and pork belly with lentils and rainbow chard. Hopefully Case will continue to keep attention on the plate, instead of on the bizarre decor, which includes a mural of Captain America bearing a basket of produce.
column8: SuburbanOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at barGood for groups

column7: First, a clarification on the name: It does indeed stand for Rogers Park, and it is indeed an attempt to give the neighborhood a SoHoish identity. Of course, any restaurant that hopes to redefine a 'hood ought to be a destination. While RoPa is a quintessential locals hangout, with food solid enough to become a neighborhood favorite (a heap of tender mussels, skate wing with lemon-caper sauce), it's not quite unique enough to garner a citywide following. Except, that is, when it comes to the uncommonly light and creamy housemade cheesecake, which is worth a train ride any night of the week.

The blended fruit cocktails at this sultry Caribbean joint make surprisingly apt counterparts to the spicy food, though they won't completely take the heat off dishes like the housemade meat patties. Nor will it dull the aromatic curry chicken or the fall-apart jerk chicken, whose warming allspice and Scotch bonnets cause a sweat. Coconut shrimp in creamy broth is a subtler option; ditto for lusciously fatty oxtail. Caramel cake won't hurt a bit, either. That is, until you crave it again later—now that could bring some pain.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 205; Pace 208, 250

column7: There are plenty of Middle Eastern restaurants that only serve hummus, shawarma and kebabs, so it's a relief when one like Petra Inn comes along. In addition to said hummus (particularly rich with tahini), et al, you'll find baby eggplant stuffed with piquant garlic, tomatoes, onions and green peppers; kebabs smothered in tangy yogurt; and the delicias petra—juicy chicken legs split open and slathered with garlic, paprika and black pepper. These may not be new flavors in Jordan (home of the archeological site the place is named for), but here, they give extra meaning to the word fresh.

You'd be right to be dubious of the theme-park look of this place. But think about it: If this restaurant is able to consistently fill its enormous dining rooms and is so popular that it requires not one but two parking lots, it must be doing something right. What that thing is, it turns out, is its well-seasoned steaks; plump, garlicky shrimp; crispy-skinned tilapia topped with a sprightly veracruzana sauce; and crêpes smothered in cajeta and doused with a generous dose of tequila.

Greek-style greasy-spoon diners don't dot Chicago neighborhoods as much as they used to, which is why we go out of our way for this classic. All the standards are in place: brown plastic water glasses, slightly-worn leather booths, bottomless cups of drip coffee, dependable pancakes and omelettes for breakfast, and a basket of rolls to eat while we decide between the French dip or the Greek chicken at dinner. In a final nod to dying traditions, kids can either get Jell-O with whipped cream for dessert or just save room for a free lollipop on the way out.
column8: Late-night diningGood for dining at barOutdoor seatingCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: Obviously, cheese is the focus at this deli/café/retail store, and the menu of small plates offers it in a myriad of forms: on thin, charred pizzas; in a funky, gratinlike potato raclette; and straight-up in themed flights (such as a "Midwest" flight of local cheeses). But the best vehicle by far is the cheese puffs, which are crisp and light on the outside but give way to a completely molten interior. All that cheese can get a little greasy, but that's where the noncheese dishes come in: Believe it or not, fried green tomatoes and olive-oil-laden olive plates qualify as palate cleansers here.
column8: Notable wine listSuburbanOutdoor seating
column144: El: Green to Harlem. Bus: Pace 307

column7: This combination café/tea shop claims to have the longest tea list in the city. That's hard to verify, but longest or not, it certainly takes its tea more seriously than most. Mugs arrive with an electronic timer that's been set to track how long the tea has been steeping, and servers give strict instructions on when the tea is ready to drink. The result is a perfect cup; not as perfect is the food. The café's trademark "Suzi Q's" (two poached eggs on English muffins with sun-dried tomatoes and cream cheese) and chai pancakes are serviceable but nothing special. Then again, if you're at a tea café, the food is probably your secondary concern anyway.

Diners come to this megaproject from Paul Kahan and crew for three things: to sample the massive list of brews while basking in the golden-hued, beer hall–like space; to sample impeccable charcuterie and amazing oysters from chef Brian Huston's dinner menu; or to begin their Sundays with arguably the best brunch in town. We oscillate, but currently we're in the latter camp, and once you taste the housemade ricotta, the fig-pistachio scone, the wood-fired eggs with harissa and the thick slabs of "Publican bacon" (not the strips that come with the omelette but the top-shelf stuff), you will be too.
column8: Good for dining at barNotable wine listOutdoor seating
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best New Restaurant
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 65

column7: At this South Loop newcomer, classics abound, from tandoori chicken to lamb rogan josh, with plenty of traditional meatless dishes for vegetarians. Dinner is a la carte; the lunch buffet is $11.99, and it's a solid assortment of all the usual suspects, from crispy samosas to mildly spicy chicken tikka masala. Purists will appreciate that dark meat chicken is used as opposed to flavorless breasts and that lamb is stewed on the bone. Others will have enough fun of their own staring into the massive, over-the-top chandeliers and channeling that last trip to Vegas.
column144: El: Red, Green, Orange to Roosevelt. Bus: 12, 29, 62

column7: The newest member of this Chicago chain's clan doesn't stray far from the successful formula, meaning that while the menu might include wings, pork chops and chili, the joint's bread and butter is its half-pound burger, done up in nearly a dozen ways.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage; Red to North/Clybourn. Bus: 8, 72, 73

column7: Yeah, we'd say 500 locations qualifies as a megachain, but there has to be a reason for that much replication, right? You be the judge by sampling the nine styles of wings, from fiery "atomic" to tangy Hawaiian.

The signage on this skinny counter-service taqueria touts its fare as the best Mexican food in town, and while the objective truth of that may be hard to determine, it indeed does some excellent things with pork. Tacos al pastor are tender and laced with rich adobo essence; others are stuffed with delicately flavored chicharron (pork skin) and slathered with fresh, chunky salsa verde. Weekends bring specials of menudo and birria (goat soup), the latter featuring forkfuls of soft, mildly gamey meat in a smoky broth.

Mexican eateries connected to grocery stores can be hit or miss, but this one is a hit—especially if you visit on the weekends. It's not that you can't get a satisfying carne asada here any day of the week. But if you want huge bowls of spirit-restoring posole or a pile of tender barbacoa to make into tacos, you need to hit this place up on Saturday or Sunday. And here's another tip: Do your shopping after you eat—these portions take awhile to get through, and you don't want your milk to spoil.
column8: Cheap (entrees under $10)Good for groupsLate-night diningBYOB

column7: This minichain (there are three scattered throughout the South Side) operates on the theory that there are three major food groups: ice cream, doughnuts and everything else. That means the savory food may be perfectly solid—tuna melts are stuffed so full they could feed three; burgers are charred on the outside and juicy within—but the real focus is what comes next. For most people, that means a doughnut topped with housemade ice cream. But for our money, a hot apple fritter does the job better.

The well-seasoned and sumptuous kebabs are indeed worthy of the restaurant's name, but they're even better when taken off the stick and put into a sandwich. The fluffy white rolls are soft but sturdy carriers for the juicy chicken kebab, and the pickled cabbage that tops it off is almost as addictive as the chicken itself. Grilled kibbeh (flat and sandwichlike here, not egg-shaped as it is normally found) is a hearty side to add on; the "potato chops," golden discs of potato stuffed with ground beef, work as a side, too—though eat enough of them and they're an entire meal themselves.

The Beverly neighborhood has a relaxed small-town-in-1965 feel, and one of the contributing reasons is this dose of Americana, both old enough and friendly enough to be your grandmother. The namesake burger is old-school minimalist, a deeply satisfying quarter-pound patty of fresh ground round sauteed in its own juices and served with the simplest toppings—grilled onions and ketchup-mustard-pickle on a feather-light bun. Just as good are the fresh-cut fries, cooked in beef tallow, and as long as you're dining as if it's 1965, finish up with a thick chocolate shake.

Big is the key word at Randy Zweiban's eco-modern spot, but that's a reference to the flavors, not the serving sizes. For fall, Zweiban is pairing apples with candied olives and marcona almonds for a sweet-and-salty salad; braising cabbage and serving it with meatballs (which have also been braised); and slathering chicken with lemon, garlic and honey before adding an ancho-chile sauce. As always, it pays to be careful when ordering here: If you juxtapose some of the subtler dishes with the bolder ones, the subtler ones will undoubtedly disappoint.
column8: Good for dining at barOutdoor seatingPrivate party room(s)
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 14, 20, 38, 56

column7: At this Burr Ridge spot, bold flavors are in full force: Crab cakes are topped with long strands of saffron, sumptuous frog legs are paired with a creamy, herbaceous grebiche sauce and a Kansas City steak gets finished with a port sauce and caramelized onions, which proves to be a rich and endlessly delicious combination. Desserts are the restaurant's weak spot, and service can be downright inappropriate—and yet this food is so good that these meals are enjoyable nonetheless.
column8: Good for groupsSuburbanPrivate party room(s)

column7: The China Poblana was an Asian girl kidnapped by pirates and brought to the Mexican city of Puebla who grew up to be a much-venerated nun. An equally improbable series of events is no doubt responsible for some of the city's most authentic and fresh-tasting Pueblan cuisine winding up in this tiny Brighton Park hole-in-the-wall. The main event are the cemitas, Pueblan sandwiches of crispy breaded steak, avocado and a brightly medicinal herb called papalo, served on a crusty roll. Other Poblano specialties include crispy, airy chalupas and, in fall and winter, chiles en nogada, stuffed poblanos with a walnut sauce.

If you've been heading to the Tasting Room just to take advantage of its stellar wine list, well, join the club. But with the release of its new cold-weather menu, this wine bar is quickly becoming a destination for food. In fact, with small plates like a trio of wild-game corn dogs (wild boar, rabbit and duck), Oaxacan beef tenderloin, lemongrass-kissed mussels and flatbreads topped with drunken goat cheese, you may not find yourself thinking about wine at all.
column8: Notable wine listViewsPrivate party room(s)Good for dining at bar
column144: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, X20

column7: You can pretty much guess what a menu at a Westin Hotel restaurant will look like, but with a new chef on board, Ember Grill is pushing the envelope a little. Chef James Wescoe still serves some basic appetizers, like goat cheese baked with prosciutto and marinara and a solid French onion soup. But his halibut entrée gets paired with a buttery lobster tail and a sweet corn cake, and his chicken breast gets rubbed with herbs and paired with housemade gnocchi. And dessert? Well, the chocolate molten cake may not be new territory, but plenty of diners clean the plate just the same.
column144: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 36

column7: Cops, construction workers and neighborhood locals of all stripes hit this storefront diner for heaping plates of breakfast and lunch classics: think corned beef, club sandwiches, patty melts. But while juicy, marinated skirt steak with eggs may be the star, the menu's secret weapons are Filipino breakfast specials of eggs, garlic fried rice, and longaniza (a pork sausage similar to chorizo) or tocino (sweet, thick, caramelized cured pork). Best of all, though Uncle Mike's has done steady business since 1991, it never seems that crowded, a rare find in brunch-crazed West Town.

An offshoot of the popular Butterfly on Grand, this Thai/Japanese hybrid (think curries, noodles and sushi) recently moved into Bialy's diner, redecorating in colors worthy of a monarch. The orange lights render much on the plate an unfortunate shade of gray—but if you can get past that, the food is, for the most part, a reliable bet. Stick to the basics—fresh yellowtail rolls, a hearty pad thai (for a twist, order it with wide rice noodles), steaming udon and tom yum soups—and you'll go home happy.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: It calls itself "the world's largest little restaurant," but from our perspective the place is just downright small. So small, in fact, that it takes only one server to take care of the entire room, and just one chef to make all the food. Of course, the size of the place—and the rest of the ambience—is the whole point of eating here. Because while you can get cheeseburgers with sweet grilled onions and eggs with bacon anywhere, you can only get this time-warped, authentically vintage feel at the Ohio House Motel.

Quality meat is one thing that lifts this Humboldt Park storefront above the pack of local taquerias; another is the friendly, corner-diner vibe, which makes it feel like a retreat from the bustling stretch of Armitage outside. Not surprisingly at a place called Toro, grilled steak is one of the stars, best on a taco or a thicker, hand-patted sope. But there's also juicy al pastor, seasoned pork meat in a gyros-like cone topped with a pineapple. Grab a spot at the counter to watch the action, and request that your tacos come with nothing more than cilantro, onion and the piquant red salsa.

With its impressive array of cured meats, imported cheeses, pasta and prepared salads, this Italian deli aims to bring a little Brooklyn to the north end of Andersonville—down to the talkative Sicilian owner holding court in his shop from morning to night. With that said, ingredients are great but the execution can be hit-and-miss (both subs and pasta salad get doused with too much oil). Still, we liked the mix of funky copa with grilled zucchini and peppers on the Cielo panini, and the brightly spiced vegetarian rice-and-beans salad is a pretty terrific quick-grab on the way home from work.

Peter Camphouse, who was recruited from Prairie Grass by the owners of the Morse Theatre to run this kitchen, may not have a way with crème bržlée or trout cakes, but with heartier fare he's a genius. His housemade "jahrhundertwurst" sausage sparkles with traces of black pepper, and his bratwurst is as plump and delicious as any in your past; his pot roast is rich with red wine, and his chicken confit comes with addictive wild rice-infused polenta. So by the end of your meal, you'll be too satisfied—and full—to worry about what he didn't get right.

This popular Avondale Thai spot (best known for its private-party room that held many a karaoke birthday party) may still be quite a way off from rebuilding its original location after a fire destroyed it, but in the meantime this West Town shop serves as the stand-in. The menu is identical, with the standard noodles, rice dishes and curries front and center. Best bets include the sweet and spicy "7 Buddies," a fresh and crunchy green papaya salad; and the catfish pad ped, hunks of crispy fish smothered in red-curry paste with globe-shaped Thai eggplants and al dente bamboo shoots. No karaoke, but feel free to sing along with the random tunes piped out of the overhead speakers.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: The mall location and the LEYE association might bring out the skeptic in hard-core foodies, but we have to admit the food at this affordable Italian spot is good enough to justify a casual dinner after holiday shopping on the Mag Mile. Top-notch, characteristically creamy burrata cheese and simple fennel-topped Sardinian-style pizza get things off to a good start. Pastas are standard and typically substantial, but you'd do better to save room for the pepper-smothered, crispy-skinned brick chicken or the tender veal limone. Servers have the robotic spiel down, but if chef "Frankie" is working the room, you'll glean some genuine hospitality.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendly

column7: You can forget about the falafel at Jerry Suqi's new Middle Eastern joint. You can forget about the hummus and the baba, too, which is all merely fine. What's special is the kibbeh, with its delicate, thin layer of bulgur encasing cinnamon-dusted ground beef and pine nuts. And the lamb pie, packed with sweet onions. And the lamb kebabs, rubbed with salt and ridiculously tender. This is food that has clearly been cared for by chef Amni Suqi (Jerry's mother). In fact, if you find the matriarch on the right night, she'll pull up a chair and explain how much she cares for it herself.
column98: 2009 Eat Out Award, Readers' Choice: Best New Middle Eastern

column7: A couple of Hyde Park veterans (the former owners of Istria Café) and a sandwich maker from the suburbs (the owner of the now-defunct Shane's Deli in Wheaton) have joined forces to open a casual but high-quality grocery store and sandwich shop. The shelves are stocked with gourmet groceries, but the crowds tend to gather at the deli counter for quince paste and Spanish jamon sandwiches and panini with farmstead cheese and ham pressed between pretzel bread. Oatmeal-chocolate-chip cookies are a hot item, too; still, with only four tables, the most coveted thing in the place is a seat.

Thin-crust pizzas and panzerotti—massive, mutant calzones available baked or fried—are hustled out the door with regularity at this casual corner café, which does a brisk takeout business. However, the rest of the menu is a bit hit-or- miss. Fussy basics like veal parmigiana are underwhelming and overpriced, but the simple rotolo primavera—tricolor pasta stuffed with spinach and ricotta and smothered in mozzarella—can be surprisingly addictive. Prices are higher than you'd guess given the excess of plastic ivy choking the ceiling, but the linguine al pescatore ($26.50), while still a relative splurge, delivers a tide pool of shrimp, calamari and clams. When you consider it's enough for three meals, it seems like a downright bargain.

This stalwart Pilsen hole-in-the-wall has moved into bigger, brighter digs, making it even more of an appealing alternative to the often long lines elsewhere in the neighborhood. The menu touts (with good reason) the toothsome, satisfyingly steamy tamales filled with tender stewed pork. But nearly everything is easy to like at these low prices, including carne asada with nice char flavor and a rich and complex poblano mole that's dished out over chicken or enchiladas.

After almost a decade of making Oakley Avenue a destination for Devon diners, Hema Potla has moved her original restaurant onto the main drag. The new space is about twice as roomy, with amber-tinted chandeliers, tiny bouquets on each table and the always-smiling namesake floating around the room. The menu remains largely the same, but the new kitchen is outfitted with a tandoor that turns out additions like nan and kebabs. Old favorites remain flavorful, including fiery lentils with spinach, excellent eggplant with hunks of lamb, and tender chicken in "Hariyali," a grass-green gravy of cilantro, curry leaves, peppers, yogurt, ginger and garlic.

Simple is not a word that's used casually at Antica: The dining room is so nondescript you'll hardly remember being in it, and the only thing that's rare about the food is how nakedly honest it is. The Margherita may not pass muster with Neapolitan snobs—the crust is just millimeters too thick and a little too dry. But anybody who can get past those details will be rewarded with a crisp crust and a piquant sauce. The nuances of the sauce can get lost amid the ham, eggs, peas and mushrooms (as on the fattoressa pizza). But it is a praiseworthy pie nonetheless—not because it's complicated, but specifically because it isn't.
column144: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50

column7: With the sale of Lincoln Square's Tallulah (It's still open but will be reconcepted by a new owner later this month), owner Matt Fisher and chef Troy Graves are focusing their energy on their newer restaurant, Eve. The bar continues to go the extra mile on cocktails, infusing liquors, muddling herbs and coming up with clever concoctions. And this weekend, Saturday and Sunday brunch launches with indulgent dishes like a lobster Benedict, baked eggs with chorizo and the dukkah-crusted lamb burger.

This Hyde Park newbie casts the net wide with a catchall menu of wallet-wise, student-friendly dishes: sushi, pizza, sandwiches, soup, salad, hummus. Most of it comes out of the bright, open kitchen decently prepared—the chicken pesto sandwich featured thinly sliced bird and plenty of pesto; the firm, if unremarkable, fish in the Chicago Fire roll was spiced up with cilantro, chili oil and jalapeño. Even the overly gummy pasta fagiole at least packed a lot of flavor. But when you're offering something for everyone, there's bound to be some bombs, and the caprese salad was a miss: wan, watery tomatoes and scoops of dried basil drowning in balsamic vinegar. That'll teach us to order caprese in winter.

Seemingly untouched by neighborhood change, this cozy, attitude-free diner is all about breakfast. Ukrainian Village locals stumble in for fluffy omelettes with golden hash browns or the house special, Smokey Mountain eggs: an artery-busting plate of biscuits topped with sausage gravy, eggs and bacon. But it's not all hearty, starchy fare. The neighborhood's Mexican influences are reflected in plates of chorizo and eggs with a zippy green tomatillo salsa, as well as savory chilaquiles.

There are salads and fried calamari and sliced chicken breast on this menu, but if you're ordering the right things, you're actually only hitting three foods: bread, three housemade varieties of which arrive at the beginning of the meal; cheese, whether in the form of the Bulgarian feta or in the mild (but highly addictive) three-cheese spread that comes with the bread; and meat, from succulent housemade sausages like the luscious cevapcici to thinly sliced veal. Welcome to the Bosnian diet.

At this cheerful mom and pop decorated with photos of the nearby Uptown Theater, there's a little cognitive dissonance in seeing standard Lebanese items offered side by side with Indian curry specials. But go with the flow and you'll see the charms of washing your falafel down with a housemade blueberry lassi. Vegetarians fare especially well here, as the falafel are fresh and brightly spiced, the dolmas are tart, and there's a meatless special each day (usually a simple stew or curry). Carnivores with light wallets will appreciate chicken shawarma sandwiches, and kifta are easy to like at such modest prices, too.

The Bosnian owner of Evanston's Portofino Pizzeria opened this city spot with an extended menu of thin-crust pizzas, antipasti, salads and sandwiches. A couple of Bosnian items make the list, and fusion shows up in dishes like grilled cevapcici sausage over grilled polenta with cucumber-alfredo sauce.

The generic name is hardly promising, but hidden DaVinci Code–like in the logo is the clue that unlocks all the secrets of this small taco stand: the letters "LP." This is an undercover branch of La Pasadita, Ashland Avenue's legendary trio of late-night grilled steak taco shrines. And when you taste the freshly charred, subtly spiced carne asada or lengua served simply with cilantro and onion on tacos or rolled in a burrito, you'll be glad the mini chain has reached this part of town.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54, 81, 92
column198: Other locations: 1132 N Ashland (773-384-6537); 1140 N Ashland (773-278-2130); 1141 N Ashland (773-278-0384)

column7: Consider this Lincoln Square stalwart "Greektown North"—it's got the same tangy taramasalata, creamy egg-lemon soup and the same moussaka as the rest of them. It's what this place has that the others don't—namely its signature lemon-and-oregano rubbed chicken and its selection of zimarika (cheesy Greek-style pastas)—that makes it worth venturing out of Greektown for. That, and the fact that it's not nearly as crowded, which means shorter waits, fewer people and—most important—less flaming saganaki.

The housemade gnocchi at this neighborhood pizzeria are fluffy and light, the pizzas are impressively crisp, and the housemade yellow cake with chocolate icing is Betty Crocker–ish but good. However, there is a red sauce in almost every dish—on the pizzas, cloaking the gnocchi, served as a dip for the housemade fried ravioli—so much of the food ends up tasting the same. That won't be a problem for locals, who might be happy enough to have such a friendly place to hang out in. The rest of us, however, may not find it worth a trip.
column8: Good for dining at barVegetarian-friendlyKid-friendly

column7: At veteran chef Rick Spiros's new late-night Wicker Park Asian spot, porky noodle dishes share space with a few varieties of mantou (Chinese steamed buns, also called bao), and a chalkboard over the bar lists beers and oysters of the day.
column8: Good for dining at barLate-night dining

column7: Rockstar Dogs, take two. Yes, there's a stripper pole, just like at the original in West Town. Yes, the hot dogs are named after musicians. And yes, you can still stumble in drunk on weekends after the bars close and stuff your face without anyone blinking.

There's very little this cute Mexican joint could do to be more welcoming (especially in winter, when its bright orange walls evoke memories of warmer, sunnier times). Meals start with a complimentary bowl of chicken soup, which actually has better flavor than some of the appetizers (like the queso fundido, which inexplicably does not come with tortillas). Follow the soup with the camarones rancheros, plump shrimp in a sweetish tomato sauce, or the charred, juicy carne a la tampiqueña, and you'll never feel without a culinary home in this barren stretch of Kedzie again.

This East Coast import feels like a cross between In-N-Out and Potbelly: Burgers, made to order, make up 90% of the small menu, and there's a list of toppings—grilled onions, relish, pickles, barbecue sauce—to pile on. By littering their walls with media praise for their food, this place sets expectations incredibly high. Unfortunately, it doesn't quite live up to the hype: The fries are thick and freshly cut, but the Cajun seasoning they're dusted with needs a lot more salt, and even with toppings, the burgers can be kind of blah. Still, this stuff is much fresher than McDonald's, so if you can keep your hopes in check you might be pleasantly surprised.
column144: El: Green to Oak Park. Pace bus: 309, 311, 313

column7: As close as you're going to get to a Puerto Rican beachfront shack in Chicago, Papa's is famous on the Paseo Boricua for juicy rotisserie chicken, lightly seasoned with tropical spices and roasted until it's moist and tender. But it also has a contender for Chicago's best jibarito, that "Puerto Rican" delicacy (actually invented here) in which steak (or chicken) is served up between two slices of "bread" made of fried plantains. On Saturdays, Papa has a special of lechon, succulent roasted pork. And on Sundays, Papa rests.
column8: Kid-friendlyOutdoor seatingBYOBLate-night dining

column7: Typically, pan-Asian spots suffer from casting the net too wide, but this little BYOB does a nice job of executing most standard Anglo cravings, from crunchy egg rolls and gooey crab rangoon to jam-packed maki. Thai classics are standard in depth and execution; try the "Hot Woks Noodles," stir-fried spinach noodles that resemble fettucine (stay with us now) wok-tossed with good-size shrimp, chicken chunks and jalapeño peppers for heat. Like the Akira roll (tuna, salmon, spicy mayo, ginger and avocado rolled in crunchy tempura flakes), it might not open any rabbit holes for the authenticity police, but it's tasty nonetheless.
column8: BYOBCheap (entrees under $10)Private party room(s)Vegetarian-friendlyOutdoor seating
column144: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80, X80

column7: Claiming to date back to 1927 (though the truth is it was closed for several years), this all-night beef stand certainly channels the true spirit of the old-school Chicago workingman's lunch. In an atmosphere a couple of steps below no-frills, you can accompany the excellent fresh-cut fries with the gutbomb of your choice: mild but perfectly decent Italian beef, a solid natural-casing hot dog done Chicago-minimalist style (mustard-relish-onion), or best of the bunch, a damn good Polish with hefty smoke. Eat it quick—you're not getting paid to loaf around.

Eating in a health club is a little like praying at an atheist's convention. Maybe that's why the food here leans toward the simple, food-as-merely-sustenance variety. A trio of sliders (turkey, tuna and beef, each one well cooked and exhibiting a nice pinch of herbs) come without any condiment whatsoever; a piece of tender whitefish has a noticeable lack of salt; a tenderloin salad leaves much to be desired in both the tenderloin and the salad. Surprisingly, the carrot and apple-walnut cakes aren't bad at all. Maybe the kitchen figures if you're ordering dessert, abstaining from salt and fat is just pointless.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 156

column7: If you want to call this a diner, fine. But the place is so clean and friendly that its chosen moniker of "Restaurant" sits just as well with us. (Also going against the diner mold: the hours, which stray from the late-night norm with a closing time of 9pm.) But the menu here looks like your typical diner lineup (that is: Everything that can possibly be served will be served). We say stick to the Greek stuff: the lemony char-grilled chicken, the crisp Greek salad and, believe it or not, a fluffy omelette stuffed with gyro meat.
There's plenty to nosh on at this Pilsen bakery, like breakfast burritos, sandwiches and fair trade coffee. But it's their outstanding tres leches that, um, takes the cake.

A fast-food joint that claims it's dedicated to "freshness" is one thing. A fast-food joint that proves it is another. Nesh bakes its own pita, and the soft, warm bread heightens everything put into it: smoky baba ghanoush, fried-to-order falafel—even the somewhat dry chicken shawarma benefits. Another housebaked bread the kitchen calls "shrock" (a flatbread used for wraps) is slightly less delicious than the pita. But for such fresh food at such cheap prices, it's hard to complain.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: This Evanston stalwart has been going strong for more than 30 years on the reputation of its hot dogs. But ever since a new owner took over in 2005, the "dipping dog"—otherwise known as a corn dog—has been a main attraction as well. Unlike other corn dogs, this dipped-and-fried-to-order specimen is only lightly sweet, and it actually tastes like corn. But then, everything here is done the way it should be: Chicago dogs exhibit their proper snap, thin burgers are served on fresh, fluffy rolls; and the fries—well, we know this is a hot-dog joint, but the fries are so perfectly crisp that they steal the show.
column144: El: Purple to Dempster. Bus: 201 Central/Sherman, 205

column7: This art-riddled BYOB has the disheveled look of a coffee shop (which is exactly how the people buried in their laptops at the bar use the place). But the small plates coming out of the kitchen reveal that there's someone here who's interested in more than espresso. Warm bowls of posole are packed with rich chicken and toothsome hominy; savory chorizo tacos are lightened by their lettuce-cup shells; and chunky guacamole is sprinkled with pomegranate seeds, which help cool the heat from diced jalapeño. There are no pomegranate seeds to save you from the tongue-searing shrimp "diablo," however, so if you plan to order that, BYO gallon of milk.
column8: Private party room(s)Late-night diningBYOBCheap (entrees under $10)

column7: "Pizza, burgers and more" is the tagline at this new Wicker Park spot. It could just as easily be "pizza, burgers and every other gut-busting, get-me-through-this-hangover food known to man." That includes nachos, quesadillas, mozzarella sticks and lots of Red Bull—but don't expect any of it to be earth shattering. The burgers look impressive but turn out to be merely serviceable; same goes for the wings and the crispy slices of pizza. (A chicken fajita flatbread oozing with jack cheese and chipotle mayo, however, was above average.) Still, this place delivers long past midnight, and for a drunk-dial, you could do a lot worse.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 9, X9, 56, 72

column7: Don't let its tiny size and proximity to Mediocrity Row fool you—this BYOB sushi newcomer offers up plenty of gems, from thick slabs of fresh sashimi to well-balanced maki creations. Munch on crispy salt-and-pepper calamari and silky spinach (goma ae) appetizers while perusing the massive maki list. Or just take our advice and go for the Volcano. Tiny tobiko and smelt roe add briny pop, tempura lends crunch, spicy mayo brings the heat, and cool hamachi and escolar smooth out the edges.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 72

column7: We know it's not logical, but trust us and forget about ordering sushi here. We know that's most of the menu, and you'll be tempted by one of the big maki rolls—the crunchy, quail-egg topped "Tiger Eye" maybe, or the "unagi squares" (where the eel is pressed onto cubes of rice). But unlike every other Asian-fusion place, where it's a good idea to stick with what they do the most of, you'll want to seek out the small selection of Korean food here. Because while the sushi is just okay, the tender and juicy bulgogi is surprisingly good.
The menu at this sprawling, festive Mexican joint is comprised of page after page of enchiladas, fajitas and nachos. But all that food plays second fiddle to their boozy, signature "swirl" magaritas.

The team behind the Merlo mini empire has added a third to the family, this one decidedly downscale with mismatched plates, wooden tables topped with rustic runners and a menu of trattoria staples, many hailing from the family's hometown of Bologna. Tender, chilled rabbit meat on crostini and yellow fin house-cured in EVOO are a good start, and housemade pastas are simple yet tasty (after a request for the salt shaker). The accolades belong to the braised chicken legs in a forest's worth of 'shrooms and the tremendous desserts, including a rice pudding cake studded with candied citrus and Amaretti cookies.
column8: Vegetarian-friendlyPrivate party room(s)Notable wine listGood for dining at bar
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73
